HEADLINE: NYC;
Straphangers Find a Friend In an Old Foe

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
WHO'D have thunk it?
Who would ever have cast Gov. George E. Pataki as a born-again friend of the New York straphanger? 
 The George Pataki we knew presided just two years ago over the largest subway and bus fare increase in the city's history. And gave the nod to the first cuts in mass-transit service in 20 years. And sliced tens of millions from the state's subsidy to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. And snatched $220 million from a transit reserve fund so that he could balance his own budget, a bit of fiscal legerdemain known to some as the Great Train Robbery.
Could this be the same George Pataki who talked yesterday about wanting to "empower the rider" with a menu of discount passes never seen here before? The same George Pataki who got almost misty-eyed talking about how he used to ride the New York subway as a young man?
This is a fellow juggling three mortgages for his Victorian mansion in Garrison and his estate near Lake George and his townhouse in Saratoga Springs. Yet what he spoke of yesterday was his time on the Upper West Side years ago, when he took the subway and wished he could simply hop on and off for free to sample the city's many cultural offerings.
(O.K., that was long ago. No one can remember when Mr. Pataki was last seen riding the New York trains, a point underlined yesterday at the news conference he called to announce the planned discount fares. For the benefit of the cameras, he held up a Metrocard. He had to borrow it from the man standing next to him.)
Given the Governor's record, it is awfully tempting to see his sudden championing of rider givebacks as a last-minute conversion on the eve of an election year. Could it be mere coincidence that he has done a neat end-run around the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who was looking to breathe life into his run for governor with calls for a different discount, one that would give straphangers 12 rides for the price of 10?
Only a few months ago, muck-a-mucks at the M.T.A. were insisting that the kind of special pass now being proposed was a loser. It would mean sacrificing hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue, they told rider-advocacy groups like the Straphangers Campaign, which had been appealing for unlimited-ride passes for years.
Be bold, Straphangers had urged. But it got nowhere with arguments that such passes work in other American cities, that discounts would enhance the environment by luring people out of their cars and into trains, that they might even pay for themselves some day because of the anticipated increase in ridership.
"If you offer fare discounts, they will come," predicted Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign. Yesterday, Mr. Pataki stood shoulder to shoulder with Mr. Russianoff. Count on M.T.A. board members doing the same when they meet next week to ratify the Governor's proposals. Collectively, they no more defy Mr. Pataki than Iraqi generals tell Saddam Hussein where to get off.
The discounts he now proposes will cost millions of dollars. Where will the money come from (the same money we were told not long ago wasn't there)? Not to worry. "We're very confident this can be sustained," he assured reporters.
IF he's right, perhaps it is time to set cynicism aside. Politics undoubtedly played a role. But in polite society, when someone hands you a long-sought gift, the only acceptable response is, Thank you.
Questions remain, of course. What will happen if Wall Street goes bust, taking New York's economy with it and that hoped-for subway boom as well? Hard times mean fewer people riding to work. What about the Transport Workers Union, which wants to see part of a surplus set aside for future wage settlements?
And what about using some of the spare money to undo the service reductions of 1995, then build from there? Mr. Pataki suggested there might be room to enhance services. But that came almost as an afterthought, even though many subway riders say that improved conditions are every bit as important to them as fare discounts.
No doubt, the experts will weigh in on these matters, and sure as there is a sunrise, the politicians will also have their say. But that's for tomorrow. Yesterday, the environmentalists and rider advocates had only one thing to say. It was a simple Thank you.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Study on Using Magnets to Treat Pain Surprises Skeptics

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

 BODY:
NO ONE was more skeptical about using magnets for pain relief than Dr. Carlos Vallbona, former chairman of the department of community medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. So Dr. Vallbona was amazed when a study he did found that small, low intensity magnets worked, at least for patients experiencing symptoms that can develop years after polio.
Dr. Vallbona had long been fascinated by testimonials about magnets from his patients, and even from medical leaders. But his interest in magnet therapy became more serious in 1994 when he and a colleague, Carlton F. Hazlewood, tried them for their own knee pain. The pain was gone in minutes. "That was too good to be true," Dr. Vallbona said. 
 Dr. Vallbona knew that the power of suggestion can fool both patient and doctor. But he also wondered: could strapping small, low intensity magnets to the most sensitive areas of the body for several minutes relieve chronic muscular and joint pains among patients in his post-polio clinic at Baylor's Institute for Rehabilitation Research.
Valid studies could allow consumers to make informed choices. And if magnet therapy were found to be safe and effective, it could relieve pain with fewer drugs -- and their unwanted side effects.
Endorsements from professional athletes are one reason Americans spend large sums on magnets to seek pain relief. But most doctors take a "buyer beware" attitude because many claims lack scientific proof or explanation of how they might work. The Food and Drug Administration has warned doctors and manufacturers about health claims for magnets.
Aware of the medical profession's skepticism about magnet therapy, Dr. Vallbona sought to conduct science's most rigorous type of study. Participants would agree to allow the investigators to randomly assign them to groups getting treatment with active magnets or sham devices. But neither the patients nor the doctors treating them would know what therapy was used on which patient.
First, Dr. Vallbona informally tested magnets on a few patients. One was a priest with post-polio syndrome who celebrated mass with difficulty due to marked back pain that prevented him from raising his left hand. After applying a magnet for a few minutes the pain was gone, Dr. Vallbona recalled, and, "the priest said this was a miracle."
Then a human experimentation committee allowed Dr. Vallbona to test 50 volunteers with magnets that at 300 to 500 gauss, were slightly stronger than refrigerator magnets. They were made in different sizes so they could fit over the anatomic area identified as setting off their pain.
It was difficult to design a system to prevent participants from learning whether they were being treated with a magnet or a sham.
So Dr. Vallbona asked Magnaflex Inc., a magnet manufacturer in Corpus Christi, Tex., to prepare active magnets and inactive devices that could not be told apart. The devices were labeled in code.
As a further precaution, a staff member observed the patients throughout the 45-minute period of therapy to make sure they would not try to find out -- by testing with a paper clip, say -- what treatment they were receiving.
After the investigators identified the source of the pain and then pressed on it, the 39 women and 11 men in the study graded the pain on a scale of 0 (none) to 10 (worst). Then after the experimental treatment, the participants rated their pain in a standard questionnaire. The volunteers were tested only one time.
The 29 who received an active magnet reported a reduction in pain to 4.4 from 9.6, compared with a smaller decline to 8.4 from 9.5 among the 21 treated with a sham magnet.
The Baylor scientists emphasized that their study applied only to pain from the post-polio condition. Nevertheless, their report in last month's issue of Archives of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine, a leading specialty journal, has shocked many doctors who have scoffed at claims for magnets' medical benefits.
In an article about magnet therapy for chronic pain published five months ago, Dr. William Jarvis, a professor of public health and preventive medicine at Loma Linda University in California and president of the National Council Against Health Fraud, dismissed magnet therapy as "essentially quackery."
Now, Dr. Jarvis said in an interview, the Baylor study changed his mind. "But like any other pilot study, it needs to be replicated," he said.
Dr. Vallbona's findings have led him to try to carry out a larger study in several medical centers, and they are expected to lead other investigators to conduct their own studies.
Dr. Lauro S. Halstead of the National Rehabilitation Hospital in Washington, a pioneer in studying the post-polio syndrome, was among experts who said that further studies were needed to answer questions like: Will various strength magnets produce different degrees of benefit? How long does the pain relief last? Will the effect wear off after multiple applications? For what other conditions might magnets work?
At the University of Virginia, Ann Gill Taylor's team last month began recruiting 105 volunteers with fibromyalgia, a painful muscle condition of unknown cause, to test magnetic sleep pads.
Like the Baylor study, the volunteers and doctors are not told whether the subject will be sleeping on an active or sham magnet. Participants are told that if they try to determine whether their treatment is with a magnet or a sham one, it could ruin the findings of the study. But Dr. Taylor said there was no way to prevent cheating.
Dr. Taylor said she also planned to conduct studies of possible uses of magnets in relieving phantom limb and stump pain among amputees.
Dr. Vallbona said he did not know why magnets worked for many post-polio patients but not for others, or why some said they felt improvement in areas of the body far distant from where the magnet was applied.
Magnets' medical benefits have been proclaimed for centuries. So why has it taken so long to do studies to begin to answer the questions? The reasons involve economic, political, professional and human factors.
Many doctors criticize the lucrative magnet industry for not investing in studies the way drug companies often do. "They don't do simple research," Dr. Jarvis said, and "it is hard to imagine an easier study to conduct than a magnet one for pain."
Yet doctors share the responsibility to do such research, and only rarely have they reported undertaking the scientifically controlled studies needed to settle major disputes about reported therapies.
In many such debates, doctors demand a biological explanation for a therapy's benefits. Without documentation that satisfies them, doctors may summarily reject the claims. Yet in their everyday practices, the same doctors may use other therapies that lack scientific proof for why they work.
Scientists working in nonprofit medical schools and university hospitals are strongly influenced by economics because they need government grants to pay for their overhead. Since scientific success is measured in part by the dollar amount of their grants, doctors tend not to pay for their studies, even if they are relatively inexpensive.
The Baylor study was exceptional. It was done without a grant. Had it been done with government aid, Dr. Vallbona said, it would have cost about $50,000. Magnaflex provided the active and inactive magnets free, the doctors donated their time and insurance companies were not charged for magnet therapy.
Until recently government agencies and the scientists who judge applications to them have tended not to support studies on magnets and other therapies on the fringe.
The reluctance is well-founded. Over history, so many claims for popular remedies have failed to hold up that many doctors are reluctant to put aside a promising project of their own to study something that may well turn out to be a fad.
Scientists are heavily influenced by peer pressure. Senior scientists often discourage younger investigators from replicating another group's studies because doing so is less likely to advance their careers than making novel findings.
But in an age of medical consumerism, patient demand is changing some research agendas. For instance, the National Institutes of Health has created an office of alternative medicine, which is paying for the magnet studies at the University of Virginia.
In tackling fringe areas, scientists usually know that they are stepping in deep water, risking scorn from colleagues who believe that what they are studying is theoretically unsound at best and quackery at worst. Even so, many with the courage may not know how deep the waters are.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 10, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Doctor's World column of Science Times on Dec. 9, about a study showing that magnets relieved pain in patients who had had polio, included a researcher's erroneous description of the role of Magnaflex Inc. The company, a distributor of Bioflex magnets, provided them; it did not manufacture them.

SECTION: Section G; Page 11; Column 1; Giving

LENGTH: 1128 words

HEADLINE: A Vry Brf Hstry of Phlnthpy

BYLINE: By Peter Dobkin Hall

 BODY:
Like any other activity, philanthropy has had its share of saints and rascals, some pursuing utopian visions, others cloaking self-interest in ennobling rhetoric. What follows are some hysteric, er, historic moments in the roadshow of American philanthropic life.
 Peter Dobkin Hall
 
1643
Introduction to Creative Fund-Raising
Harvard College administrators turn from learning to lucre long enough to devise a bedrock of fund-raising -- the matching grant. In a document titled "New England's First Fruits," which they dispatch to England, they cite the generosity of colonists as an inducement for giving by wealthy Puritans in the mother country. (But, after all, these folks were among the first to name a charitable enterprise after its lead donor, John Harvard.) 

1667
A First Scandal
 The English Puritan Edward Hopkins bequeaths a large sum in trust to give "Encouragement unto those forreign Plantations for the breeding up of Hopefull youth in the way of Learning"; in short, for building grammar schools in New England. The General Court at Hartford seizes the property and divides it among three Connecticut Valley towns, not one of which has a school building, let alone a school. Litigation over the Hopkins Trust continues for the next 130 years.
 
1710
The Solicitation Is Born
Perceptive fellow that he is, the Rev. Cotton Mather sets forth in a treatise on charity the golden rule of solicitation: "Get unto the Rich Men" and "put Rich Men in mind of the Opportunities to Do Good, with which the God, who gives Power to Get Wealth, has favored and obliged and enriched them."
 
1789
Building a Better Pyramid Scheme
Benjamin Franklin's will leaves trusts of ' £1,000 each to Philadelphia and Boston. Intrigued by compounding interest -- a new idea -- Franklin directs that income from these trusts be reinvested for 200 years. When distributed in 1989, Philadelphia's fund totals $2.3 million and Boston's, $4.7 million.
 
1819
Nonprofits at the Barricades
 It was the case of Dartmouth College, whose assets had been seized by the State of New Hampshire and its board replaced by government appointees. At stake, however, was the fate of the private sector. Daniel Webster pulls out every oratorical stop, declaiming, among many other things, that Dartmouth is "a small college -- and yet there are those who love it." Spectators weep. So do Justices. The United States Supreme Court declares private institutions constitutionally protected from government interference. The day is saved.
 
1831
And the Winner Is . . .
The Philadelphia multimillionaire Stephen Girard leaves his entire estate to create an institution for "poor male white orphan children" on the condition that no ecclesiastic, missionary or minister sets foot in it. Attacked by angry clergymen, opportunistic politicians and covetous relatives, the terms of Girard's will take more than 15 years of litigation and an 1844 United States Supreme Court decision before they can be carried out.
 
1838
Debate of the Century, and Beyond
A gift from the estate of the bastard son of the Duke of Northumberland and the niece of the Duke of Somerset -- 104,960 gold sovereigns to establish an institution "for the increase and diffusion of knowledge among men" -- sparks a vitriolic debate over private charity. A Southern Congressman warns that accepting it will encourage "every whippersnapper vagabond to have his name distinguished in the same way." Meanwhile, Treasury Department officials are looting the fund. Only an eloquent speech by ex-President John Quincy Adams shames Congress into restoring the missing money and establishing the Smithsonian Institution in 1846.
 
1887
Break a Trust and Make New York Culture Capital
 Samuel J. Tilden directs his executors to use his multimillion dollar estate for charitable, educational and scientific purposes that will benefit mankind. With covert encouragement from Governor David Hill, Tilden's improvident nephews successfully challenge the will. In the uproar that follows, New Yorkers rewrite charities laws that had made large-scale charitable giving almost impossible, enabling robber barons to pour their wealth into the city's hospitals, libraries, museums and universities.
 
1889
A Challenge From Carnegie
The steel magnate Andrew Carnegie urges other "men of affairs" to apply the same genius they had used in accumulating their wealth to the task of giving it away. Of those who don't, he says, "The public verdict will then be: The man who dies thus rich dies disgraced."
 
1916
It Seems They Didn't Like Him
Combining hubris and chutzpah, John D. Rockefeller asks Congress to charter his proposed $100 million foundation. The request sets off a wave of criticism of "the most hated man in America," as the newspapers call him. Samuel Gompers, the labor leader, declares, "The one thing that the world could gracefully accept from Mr. Rockefeller now would be the establishment of a great endowment for research and education to help other people see in time how they can keep from being like him."
 
1947
The Macaroni Monopoly
Searching for ways to do well by doing good, New York University Law School alumni buy various business enterprises and donate them to their alma mater. Their acquisition of the C. F. Mueller Company, for one, makes the law school the largest noodle manufacturer in the world -- and the subject of hostile Congressional scrutiny.
 
1990
On Your Mark, Get Set . . .
Estimating the collective net worth of baby boomers' parents at $6.8 trillion, two Cornell economists, Robert Avery and Michael Rendall, predict "the biggest intergenerational transfer of wealth in United States history." Among the nation's charitable fund-raisers, the scramble is on.
 
1995
The Year of the Fraud
Is nothing sacred? First William Aramony, president of United Way of America, diverts $1.2 million of the charity's money to romance a 17-year- old. Then John G. Bennett, the founder of Foundation for New Era Philanthropy, is trapped in his own matching-grants Ponzi scheme that defrauds the Philadelphia Orchestra, American Red Cross, Salvation Army and many others to the tune of $354 million.
 
1996
Ted's Excellent Idea
As he turns $200 million over to favorite causes, the media mogul Ted Turner denounces Forbes's 400, the popular annual feature listing the nation's growing population of billionaires, declaring: "That list is destroying our country! These new super-rich won't loosen up their wads because they're afraid they'll reduce their net worth and go down on the list. That's their Super Bowl."
Peter Dobkin Hall is the director of Yale University's program on nonprofit organizations.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 200 words

HEADLINE: Better Subway Plan

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I agree with your Dec. 9 editorial that in addition to the monthly and weekly subway passes just proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, another transit pricing option that deserves consideration is reduced fares for riders who travel at times other than rush hour.
Suppose that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority charges $1.50 for peak rush-hour travel but decreases the fare to $1 at all other times. Some transit customers, particularly those who enjoy flexible schedules or who already travel early or late in the peak rush-hour periods, would shift their travel times to take advantage of the discount. 
 Because so much of the cost of providing mass transit is based on the capacity required at rush hour, even small declines in ridership at peak times provide significant savings. Customers who continue to travel at the height of rush hour would benefit from shorter lines and less crowded conditions.
Cutting the price for off-peak travel would encourage more New Yorkers, including more of our low-income residents, to use the transit system.
 
RONNIE LOWENSTEIN
New York, Dec. 9, 1997
 
Chief Economist
Independent Budget Office

HEADLINE: Survey Shows Manufacturers Optimistic

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
United States manufacturers are optimistic about the coming year despite uncertainty over Asia's financial crisis, expecting stronger revenues, increased employment and stable prices, a group of factory purchasing executives said yesterday.
Manufacturers are "more optimistic about the next 12 months than they were in December 1996," the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its annual forecast. Four out of five companies surveyed said they expected business to improve over 1997. Fifty-nine percent expressed optimism about the coming year, the largest percentage expressing that sentiment since May 1988. 
 "We see growth in capital investment; we see prices very stable; we see a slight increase in manufacturing employment," said Norbert Ore, head of the association's business survey panel.
Moreover, the holiday sales outlook is the strongest since 1994, the report said, adding that 59 percent of those surveyed expected good sales, while only 1 percent expected sales to be poor.
Mr. Ore said the impact of Asia's economic crisis on the United States economy remained unclear. But so far, he said, the association has not seen evidence of order cancellations as a result.

HEADLINE: Asian Malaise Causes Stocks to Tumble

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Fear that Asia's economic turmoil will stall the corporate earnings of American companies that do business in the region pushed stocks lower yesterday.
Highlighting investors' concerns, shares of Oracle plunged 9 7/16, or 29 percent, to 22 15/16 on news released late Monday that fiscal second-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' expectations. The company cited weaker-than-expected sales in Asia and in the United States' telecommunications industry. So many shares changed hands that Oracle had the highest volume ever on the Nasdaq market, 172.5 million shares. 
 Its dismal performance infected other technology shares -- Microsoft was off 1 13/16, to 144 5/16, while Cisco Systems fell 2 5/16, to 87 7/16 -- and pushed the Nasdaq composite index down 1.8 percent, or 30.99 points, to 1,620.55. Oracle was also the leading decliner in the Standard & Poor's 500 company stock index, which fell 6.59 points, and the Nasdaq 100, which fell almost 3 percent.
Although the Dow Jones industrial average had a larger point decline than any of the broader market indexes, falling 61.18 points, to 8,049.66, analysts said the blue-chip average was largely unaffected by the Asian malaise that plagued investor sentiment yesterday. But, again, technology shares were weak. I.B.M. lost 2 1/2, closing at 110 3/8, and Hewlett-Packard fell 1 15/16, to 64 9/16.
But, the market's slump, in the wake of last week's peak of 983.79 for the S.& P. 500, should be a warning to investors not to become too complacent, traders and analysts said.
"I think we got a good wake-up call," said Arthur Hogan, a senior trader at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
After last week's market surge, and news of the International Monetary Fund's bailout package for South Korea, many investors felt the domestic stock market could reach new highs before year-end, Mr. Hogan said. "But we still have some real problems out there," which could hurt the market, he cautioned.
"It's a clear warning, whether it's overdone or not," Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, said of yesterday's declines.
"The Asian slowdown will be much more than a short episode, and the surprises in technology are much more likely to be on the down side," he forecast. "Even though the system isn't going to fall apart, that doesn't mean the economic problems they are going to face are solved."
Mr. Pradilla is advising clients to focus on companies with more domestic exposure that should not be affected by the gyrations in Asia. He cited Eli Lilly, which closed at 63 3/8, down 7/8, and America Online, which closed at 86 1/2, down 3/4, as examples.
Many multinational companies, not only technology shares, can still be affected by Asia's trouble, he said.
Yesterday, Morgan Stanley's index of the 50 largest American multinational companies fell 4.82 points, to 538.69, posting its second consecutive loss after reaching a high of 544.85 on Friday.
Some analysts contend that the records reached by some indexes last week indicate that Asia's woes will not keep the market from moving higher.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bond Prices Move Higher
 Prices of Treasury securities recovered yesterday from a three-day slump with a little help from the Federal Reserve and a weak retail sales report.
Bonds rose after the Federal Reserve entered the market as a buyer of coupon issues totaling $1.83 billion, with maturities running from Feb. 15, 2003 to Nov. 15, 2027. The Fed periodically buys Treasury securities to add money to the banking system.
Bonds then got an additional lift from the release of the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim report of weekly chain-store sales, which showed sales fell a surprising three-tenths of 1 percent for the latest week. Later yesterday, the Redbook retail report, published by Lynch, Jones & Ryan, came in as expected, up 1.5 percent for the week ended on Saturday.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32, to 100 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.11 percent from 6.13 percent on Monday.
Analysts said the Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim report in the morning suggested that the economy might indeed be slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating and restrain the Fed from raising short-term interest rates in the near term. Nevertheless, there are investors who believe recent signs of a strong economy are reasons to stay alert.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 575 words

HEADLINE: The Family Truck

 BODY:
Every suburban parking lot is stacked with minivans and sport utility vehicles that do nothing remotely connected with commercial hauling or farming. Yet these vehicles of choice for a multitude of families and commuters are classified as light trucks by Federal regulators, allowing them to escape the Federal pollution and fuel economy standards that apply to cars.
The light-truck category was created decades ago when most vehicles in this category, such as pickup trucks, were indeed used for agricultural or commercial purposes. But when regulators classified the Chrysler minivan as a light truck in the early 1980's, they created a giant loophole that now threatens to compromise Government efforts to conserve fuel, control smog and reduce carbon dioxide emissions that cause global warming. 
 In almost every way, Federal law regulates these vehicles -- which are mostly used as passenger cars -- more loosely than actual cars. While consumers like them for their power, less than 15 percent of all sport utility vehicles are used for towing or other truck-like activities.
Even so, most of these vehicles are allowed to emit nearly twice the smog-causing nitrous oxides as cars. They need only meet a fuel economy standard of 20.7 miles per gallon, compared with an average 27.5 miles per gallon for all the cars produced by a given manufacturer. They are exempt from gas-guzzler taxes that apply to cars getting less than 22.5 miles per gallon. The larger light trucks are also exempt from luxury taxes, which apply to cars costing more than $36,000, though many deluxe trucks can cost even more.
The regulatory and tax benefits of these vehicles, coupled with consumer demand for roomier transportation, have created an enormous light-truck market that now represents 40 percent of all family vehicles sold. Sales will probably reach 50 percent of the passenger market in the next five years, pushing up emissions from these less efficient, dirtier vehicles.
Even though there are still twice as many cars on the road as light trucks, the trucks produce as much total carbon dioxide as cars because they burn more fuel. By 2010 these trucks may produce up to 75 percent of the smog-causing pollutants and 63 percent of the carbon emissions coming out of personal vehicle tailpipes. Unless there is some regulatory change, light trucks will be the largest and fastest-growing contributor to transportation-related greenhouse gas emissions.
Analysts at the Environmental Protection Agency have been tracking the problem for some time. Yet tightening the loophole has been considered so difficult politically that even environmentalists have shied away from joining the battle. But a global warming treaty that would commit the United States to reducing greenhouse emissions within 15 years may finally force Congress and the Administration to look at controlling the light-truck factor.
This would not mean doing away with the light-truck category. Regulators need to come up with a more discriminating definition for trucks, perhaps requiring them to have certain structural characteristics that many minivans and sport utility vehicles would not meet. If a light truck is nothing more than an extra-big family car, as is true of most vehicles in that category today, it should have to meet the pollution and efficiency standards that apply to cars. Anything less will leave a loophole big enough to drive a truck through.

HEADLINE: Japan Bank-Aid Plan Sends Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday after the Prime Minister of Japan backed a plan to prop up the nation's banks and securities firms.
The dollar rose to a two-month high against the mark after a report showed German unemployment remained at its highest level since World War II and as German officials suggested that they were not bothered by the strength of the dollar, which has climbed 5 percent in the last month. 
 The yen, down 11 percent versus the dollar this year, gained after Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto asked his Liberal Democratic Party to consider using $77 billion to assist the financial industry, burdened by as much as $600 billion in bad loans.
"There's been some good yen buying on expectation Japan will adopt a plan to save its ailing financial institutions," said Tatsuya Enomoto, manager of foreign exchange at Sumitomo Bank Ltd.
The dollar slipped from a 5 1/2-year high, settling in New York trading at 129.59 yen, down from 130.45 yen on Monday. The dollar rose to 1.7904 marks from 1.7893 marks. The pound rose to $1.6507 from $1.6483.
The Liberal Democratic Party is expected to outline its bank bailout package on Friday. A credible plan could help the yen by restoring confidence in Japanese financial assets.
To be sure, some analysts caution against putting too much faith in any bank bailout before seeing more details and more evidence that a plan will be put into effect.
"We've been set up for disappointment in the past," said Ken Nixon, a currency salesman at Svenska Handelsbanken. "There's been no package yet. Reality is another thing. I'm waiting till we get a clearer picture."
The dollar rose against the mark after a report showed German unemployment in November was at 11.8 percent for a second month. That suggested Germany is having trouble emerging from a long slump.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Rents in South Bronx Attract New Businesses

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
Behind the gaunt facade of an industrial building in the Port Morris section of the Bronx, Ben Nadorf manufactures boxing gloves and punching bags. His company, Everlast Sports Manufacturing Corporation, employs 165 people in the Bronx.
Nearby, Harvey Morgan makes the underwires that hold brassieres in place. His company, S & S Industries, has 70 percent of the world market, Mr. Morgan estimates. He employs 450 people. 
 Last weekend, Lesley Eysler arrived in this eclectic industrial environment from the Chelsea section of Manhattan. She took 20,000 square feet of space for warehousing and distribution for her company -- called Regal Jewelry, although its merchandise line consists mainly of gifts and novelties -- in a 120,000-square-foot building at 131 Walnut Avenue. The saga of the building itself tracks the ups and downs in the fortunes of the Port Morris industrial zone.
The down side has been the gradual departure over a generation of such famous names as Farberware Industries, whose abandonment of its premises at 415 Bruckner Boulevard after the sale of the business has left 415,000 square feet of industrial space on the market. The upside is the arrival of smaller businesses seeking low-cost space with excellent access to the regional highway system.
"In the older specialty buildings like Farberware's, we won't get pots-and-pans manufacturers, but we can reconfigure the space into smaller components that can be either leased or purchased," said Neil W. Pariser, senior vice president of the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, a 25-year-old nonprofit development company known by area business people as Sobro.
One such building is 131 Walnut Avenue, once the home of Arrow shirts and Philips-Jones men's clothing. When the private real estate market was comatose in the early 1980's, Sobro obtained a $2.2 million Federal grant, took a long-term lease on the empty building from the city and redeveloped it for industrial use. Special Additions, a maternity clothing company, leased all the space.
Special Additions is still there, but it has contracted. Per Scholas, a nonprofit maker of computers for schools, took 20,000 square feet two years ago. That left two floors available, and now Regal has taken one, with an option for more.
"I went from a rent of $9 a foot to $3.50 a foot," Ms. Eysler said, "and the transportation is easier for my trucks. In Chelsea, the police were starting to give out tickets like crazy." The company will maintain its showroom at 366 Fifth Avenue.
The building Regal left is 425 West 15th Street, the former Nabisco factory on two blocks between 9th and 11th Avenues, which has been restyled the Chelsea Market. It was taken over in 1995 by A.T.C. Management, a developer-owner based in Long Island City, Queens, and is being leased out mainly to food-processing companies and other suppliers to the restaurant and hotel industries, many of which also operate retail outlets on the ground floor.
The Port Morris industrial zone is a horseshoe-shaped area at the southwest corner of the Bronx, most of it between East 138th Street and Bruckner Boulevard, but running as far north as East 149th Street on its western and eastern perimeters.
Most of the area is within the Federal Government's South Bronx empowerment zone, and all of it falls within a New York State economic development zone. An employer can get as much as $4,500-a-year in combined Federal and state tax credits for each employee living within the boundaries of the zones.
A generation ago, 30,000 people worked in the Port Morris industrial area, Mr. Pariser estimated. By the early 80's, employment had sunk to 15,000 to 18,000. Now it is up to 24,000, he said.
Among the newer arriving companies, some are expanding. One is Milea Truck Sales, one of the East Coast's largest GMC truck dealers, which arrived in 1981 from Brooklyn. It took over an abandoned garage at 885 East 149th Street and built 40,000 square feet of space with the help of an Industrial Development Agency loan from the city. Now Milea employs 150 people at three Bronx locations.
The company intends to add a 10,000-square-foot extension to its East 149th Street building, to be used to manufacture truck bodies. The expansion requires the removal of a rock estimated to weigh 10 million pounds, lying in the bed of a mapped but never-built street.
"We will buy the rock from the city, demap the street, and build," said Barry Milea, a principal in the company. In this endeavor it has the collaboration of Sobro, which will apply for a state grant of $300,000.
But the factors that keep tenants in place extend beyond public grants. Mr. Nadorf, the 78-year-old president of Everlast, occupies 200,000 square feet at 750 East 132d Street, and two years ago he took an additional two floors of 35,000 square feet each in an adjacent building.
Everlast also operates in Moberly, Mo., 35 miles north of Columbia, where it has built a 304,000-square-foot manufacturing building. But its headquarters is staying in the Bronx.
"I live in New Rochelle and I'm a Bronx boy," said Mr. Nadorf, who took over the business after the death two years ago of his partner, David Golomb, son of Jacob Golomb, who founded the business in 1910. "I'm not going anywhere."

HEADLINE: After Rwandan Terror, Albright Promises Greater Vigilance

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, on the first stop of a weeklong visit to Africa, said today that the United States and other nations share the blame for massacres that have taken place in Central Africa.
The West waited too long to respond to Hutu killings of Tutsi in Rwanda in 1994 that left 500,000 people dead, she said. Some of the fighting involved Hutu who rearmed themselves from United Nations refugee camps operated at a cost of $1 million a day. 
 "We, the international community, should have been more active in the early stages of the atrocities in Rwanda in 1994 and called them what they were -- genocide," Ms. Albright said in a speech to the Organization of African Unity, whose delegates applauded her words.
She promised that the United States would control future funding "to insure that humanitarian aid is not used to sustain armed camps or to support genocidal killers."
She also promised "to find more effective ways of preventing conflict and reconciling former adversaries, to achieve justice and accountability in the aftermath of large-scale human rights violations, and to resist the emergence of new tyrannies."
"The United States has made a strong commitment to supervise our refugee assistance far more closely and to work to keep humanitarian aid from falling into the wrong hands," she added.
Ms. Albright said that Washington would help rebuild Congo, but only if President Laurent Kabila showed a commitment to democratic reform. In May, Mr. Kabila's rebel movement ousted Mobutu Sese Seko, ending nearly three decades of corrupt rule in the country, formerly called Zaire, that made Mr. Mobutu rich but left his country in tatters.
Ms. Albright said the United States would contribute $10 million to a World Bank fund to support reconstruction in Congo, and she promised to seek aid from Congress.
The Clinton Administration is also promoting a $30 million package of assistance in eastern Congo, Rwanda and Burundi, partly to train judicial and police officials.
Ms. Albright will meet with Mr. Kabila this week.

HEADLINE: A Chef Spices Up Hospital Life;
His Illness Is No Deterrent to a Taste for His Own Cooking

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
When the chef Patrick Clark checked into Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center the day after Thanksgiving for a long-awaited heart transplant, he knew dining would be an issue.
"I mean, we all know the stereotype: hospital food, airplane food," said Mr. Clark, 42, whose poor health forced him to step down recently after three years as executive chef at Tavern on the Green. 
 But, he added yesterday about the hospital fare, "I really thought I could tough it out."
He did not count, though, on the bone-dry roast pork with mock applejack sauce. Or the mushy fish fillet with lemon. Or the veal loaf -- the last straw -- which arrived like an insult on a plastic plate last Monday. "They brought it dry, no sauce at all, and it had been microwaved at least twice," said Mr. Clark. "I started thinking that I may be here two months, three months, waiting on a heart. I have to do something."
So Mr. Clark became probably the only Columbia-Presbyterian patient ever to have his meals specially prepared, in his room, by a former executive chef of Tavern on the Green.
Last week, his publicity agent sneaked a tabletop steamer into his private room at the Milstein Pavilion. His wife smuggled in a small electric grill and simple provisions in plastic bags. And last Sunday night, he successfully made his first meal: grilled chicken with lemon and herbs, and cauliflower steamed with garlic.
"The nurses came by and said, 'Boy, it sure smells good in here,' " he said. "I think they thought my wife brought me some food. They didn't know I was cooking in here."
Until yesterday, when a reporter called hospital officials to ask about Mr. Clark's meals, his culinary protest had gone undetected by nurses and doctors. But it had been viewed with a kind of jailbreak admiration by his fellow patients, six of whom recently formed a committee to complain about constantly bungled orders and the blandness of their low-fat, low-sodium meals.
"What the hospital bureaucracy doesn't realize is that heart-transplant patients stay here a very long time," said George Tokieda, a 56-year-old schoolteacher. "And we give this hospital a tremendous amount of positive public relations. But on the food, we feel like we're being ignored, big time."
"Maybe Patrick's going to get all that changed," he said.
Allen Hyman, the hospital's chief of staff, visited Mr. Clark yesterday afternoon and later said he would try to capitalize on the chef's dissatisfaction.
"His complaint was that the food was bland," Dr. Hyman said. "And he may be right, and I said I would be happy if he would talk to our chef, and maybe we could come up with some ways to improve it."
Dr. Hyman would not say whether he planned to shut down Mr. Clark's makeshift kitchen. The hospital does not have a specific policy barring cooking in one's room, but hospital officials said they would be forced to respond if other patients complained or if nursing supervisors judged that the cooking posed a safety concern.
Yesterday, Mr. Clark seemed much more concerned with eating than with starting a revolution.
A friend from Tavern on the Green delivered a 5-ounce piece of salmon marinated in olive oil, sliced garlic, basil, thyme and crushed peppercorns as Mr. Clark had requested the night before.
Gazing at his sweeping view of the Hudson River, Mr. Clark placed the salmon in the tiny grill for two minutes, used the tip of a knife to drizzle it with roasted-garlic oil, which he keeps in a Styrofoam cup, and again accompanied the main dish with steamed cauliflower.
His only concession to his circumstances was to pepper the salmon from a paper packet. ("I forgot to ask my wife to bring my pepper mill," he explained.) But it did not dampen his joy when he took the first bite.
"Now, you can't get salmon like that in a hospital," he said, smiling. Joseph Gay, a sous-chef from Tavern on the Green who had dropped by, shook his head, saying, "You're out of your mind!"
But then Mr. Clark has always been something of a maverick. He grew up in Canarsie, Brooklyn, and did not attend a high-powered cooking school. (He graduated from the department of hospitality management at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn, whose alumni also include Michael Romano, the chef at Union Square Cafe.) But by the early 1980's he was a star, part of a team that created Odeon in Tribeca and Cafe Luxembourg near Lincoln Center.
In the teeth of the recession in 1988 he opened his own restaurant, Metro, on the Upper East Side, and while it closed only two years later, his star was only slightly dimmed. In fact, in early 1993, he had the privilege of being asked to be executive chef at the White House. He turned down the offer.
Mr. Clark said that while he initially wanted to keep his bedside cooking a secret, he sought attention because he hoped it would help to force an improvement in the hospital food. (His agent also just happened to mention that Mr. Clark was working on a book.)
As he sat in his plaid pajamas and finished his cauliflower yesterday, Mr. Clark professed not to be worried about a crackdown. "It would look pretty bad for them, right?" he said. "And they sure can't kick me out of here."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Many Players, Many Losers;
How and Why Asian Currencies Tumbled So Quickly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
In early May, Japanese officials, concerned about the decline of the yen, hinted that they might raise interest rates. The threat never materialized. But it proved to be the first sign of an Asian flu that six months later is still spreading and has already prompted around $100 billion in international pledges for a cure.
The Japanese threat shifted the decisions of global investors, who immediately began to sell Southeast Asian currencies, setting off a tumble not only in the currencies but in the local stock markets as well. Leapfrogging from Thailand to Indonesia to Hong Kong, the financial shivers eventually shook Wall Street, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down a record 554 points on Oct. 27. From its sickbed, Asia is now faced with a new year that promises very slow, if any, growth, painful bankruptcies and rising unemployment. 
 Speculators -- and the hedge funds they manage -- have been singled out by Asian politicians and others as the proximate cause of the turmoil, which spread to South Korea and continues to rattle Japan.
But the real story is much more complex, filled with bankers, corporate treasurers and mutual fund managers from the region and around the world who, unlike speculators, were not trying to profit from the fall of the currencies but still contributed significantly to their declines. Joined by many local companies, these agents actually had very strong vested interests in keeping the currencies stable.
There is no way to re-create the exact train of selling that pushed the currencies beyond the brink. But in interviews with bankers, economists, currency traders, portfolio managers, hedge fund executives and corporate treasurers in Asia and elsewhere, a picture has emerged of the sequence of events and the players who were central to the drama.
First, the talk of a Japanese interest rate increase raised fears among commercial bankers, investment bankers and others about the safety of big investment positions that were predicated on currency stability.
As these investors scurried to liquidate holdings in local currencies, the anxiety spread. Big foreign companies operating in the region became frightened, too, and scrambled to convert local revenues into dollars. And finally, local companies rushed to get yen and dollars. With everyone running for the exits, the Thai baht, the Indonesian rupiah and other regional currencies were trampled.
"Big movements in asset markets don't tend to happen unless all the actors move from one side of the ship to the other," said Peter Fisher, head of market intervention at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said in a speech in Malaysia on Dec. 2 that the I.M.F. had been studying the impact of speculators in all this. "But from what we know so far," he said, "it would be a mistake to blame hedge funds."
Among the first to take the stage in the summertime drama were the bankers and treasurers, and a financial technique of theirs known by some as the carry trade.
For years, because of rock-bottom interest rates in Japan and low rates in the United States, banks, investment houses and insurers had borrowed in yen and dollars and put the proceeds into short-term notes in Southeast Asia that were paying far higher rates. These are the carry trades.
The trades attracted so many investors because the Southeast Asian currencies had been stable for years. Still, the trades did not come without risks. Should foreign interest rates rise, or the currencies start to lose value, the profits would diminish -- or might turn into losses.
Indeed, just the threat of a Japanese rate rise was enough to cause some investors to unwind their positions. That meant they sold their Asian notes and, in the process, the local currencies.
"If you had 50 banks doing it, that could create some pressure," conceded David Puth, head of foreign exchange in New York for Chase Manhattan, which had been involved in carry trades. "There are big forces in the market that are totally separate from speculators making a bet."
American companies that do big business in Asia, like the Dell Computer Corporation, added to the pressure as they rushed to protect themselves against further declines in the value of the local currencies in which they were paid. They did this by hedging, which allows an investor to lock in an exchange rate.
Mutual funds, like the T. Rowe Price New Asia Fund, moved, too, selling Asian securities and converting the proceeds back into dollars, further driving down the value of Asian currencies.
But chief among the participants were the many local companies and banks in Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and South Korea that had borrowed billions of dollars at low rates abroad. Some used that money to expand; many banks used it for lending in overheated real estate markets. As their currencies fell in value, the amount the companies and banks owed in dollars and yen skyrocketed. To make their payments, these players also scrambled to get into dollars or yen.
What makes a currency move "is the enemy within, the corporates," said Chris Tinker, regional head of economics and debt research at ING Barings Asia in Hong Kong. Mr. Camdessus of the I.M.F. said, "The most important factor in the depreciation of exchange rates was the rush by domestic corporations to buy foreign exchange."
The underlying cause of the rout, Mr. Camdessus contended in his speech, was the mistaken faith of millions of investors in the stability of the smaller Asian currencies. Such misplaced faith makes the Asian decline similar in its origins and its unfolding to the European currency crisis of 1992 and 1993, when sudden surprising declines in the British pound, the Italian lira and other currencies ended a long period of stability there.
In Southeast Asia, the frame of mind that led investors to rely on the stability of currencies was shaped by the prevalence of "pegs" -- direct and indirect -- that local governments put in place to tie, or effectively fix, their currencies to the movements of the dollar. So certain were many investors of that stability that they refused to pay the cost of insurance, through hedging, against a currency fall.
"You had banks and financial institutions that believed so much in the peg because they made money on the peg," said Ang Thiam Huat, the group treasury manager at Natsteel Ltd. in Singapore. "So over time, it is deemed to be riskless," he explained, adding. "Peer-group pressure in the financial community is so strong that if you said it was risky, people would look on you as an outcast."
A currency trader based in Singapore for a major American investment bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "Nobody is going to admit that they did not hedge well. We have people who are still lying about their exposure."
Dell Computer, which is based in Austin, Tex., was in the same position as hundreds of local companies in Asia, taking advantage of currency stability but without insurance against a fall.
"We didn't implement the hedge in many countries because of the peg and the low volatility," said Mark Stevens, the controller of Dell's Asia Pacific Group. Slightly more than 6 percent of Dell's annual revenue of $11 billion comes from Asia.
Not until June, when the Thai baht had been under strong pressure for a month, did Dell begin to hedge against a decline in the currency. Mr. Stevens first bought insurance in the form of options, which for a fee gave Dell the right, but not the obligation, to turn baht into dollars at a set rate. Before long, however, it did actual trades that would convert the next several quarters of baht revenue into dollars at set rates.
Dell made a similar move in Malaysia in July, Mr. Stevens said, because the negative economic news there made the company feel that the currency, the ringgit, could not resist the pressure to fall.
But the problems in Southeast Asia did not make companies rush immediately to hedge their currency exposures elsewhere. Dell, for example, did not hedge in South Korea until October, in part, Mr. Stevens said, because of the high cost -- about 10 percent of the amount being hedged. In Hong Kong, Dell hedged on Oct. 23, the day the stock market there fell 10.4 percent. Dell had waited because the Hong Kong dollar's tie to the American dollar was the most secure.
As the turmoil worsened, Mr. Stevens said, Dell increasingly relied on hedges. Its coverage in the region is now nearly 100 percent for the next several quarters.
At the T. Rowe Price New Asia Fund, which has holdings throughout the region, withdrawals by individuals began to mount in the summer after the sharp decline in local stock markets. At the end of June, the fund had $1.9 billion under management. But between July 2 -- when the baht was devalued -- and the end of November, withdrawals exceeded new deposits by more than half a billion dollars, according to AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund performance. That outflow, together with the sharp fall in the stocks in its portfolio, left the fund with just $844 million.
Chip Wendler, a vice president of Rowe Price-Fleming, which manages T. Rowe Price international funds, said his funds did not have to do too much selling at the market low points. But he acknowledged what he called the "marginal" impact that the selling of local securities and the conversion back into dollars had on Asian markets when the entire mutual fund industry is taken into account. Still, he argued, such transactions alone "would never have cracked the currency."
Certainly, the speculators played a role, too. "I am sure that there were specs shorting the rupiah in Indonesia," said a top analyst at a major hedge fund, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "They saw what the corporates were doing and joined in."
To short a currency, an investor borrows an amount in local money and converts it to a stronger currency, betting that the local currency will decline in value, and thus can be bought back at a lower price when it comes time to pay off the loan. The investor profits on the difference between the two prices.
But, said Jeffrey Lim, director of structured products at the American Express Bank in Singapore, "The speculators would never have been as successful as they have been unless everyone jumped on the bandwagon."
That view -- of the speculator as just one of the players on the field -- was echoed by Mr. Camdessus in his Dec. 2 speech in Malaysia.
"It is becoming increasingly difficult," he said, "to distinguish between the activities of hedge funds and other institutional investors."
The I.M.F. report on the European currency crisis of the early 1990's summed up that situation in a strikingly similar way.
"The difference between hedging and speculation becomes blurred when most market participants become convinced -- rightly or wrongly -- that a nontrivial change in exchange rates is coming, and that the change is likely to be in one direction," it said. "In that circumstance, everyone gets into the act."

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCING: THE REACTION;
U.S. Is Split On Prosecutor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY 

 BODY:
The American public is sharply divided over whether an independent counsel should be appointed to investigate 1996 Democratic fund-raising activities, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Forty-six percent of 1,016 adults interviewed on Saturday through Monday said an independent counsel should be appointed, while a statistically indistinguishable 49 percent said the investigations being conducted by Congress and the Department of Justice were enough. 
 The nationwide telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
There is a strong strain of partisanship in the public's feelings on this issue. Two-thirds of Republicans in the poll favor an independent counsel, while two-thirds of Democrats say the current investigations are sufficient.
Americans are also evenly divided on whether President Clinton did anything wrong in his 1996 fund-raising. Forty percent said Mr. Clinton did nothing wrong, while another 40 percent disagreed. Those who perceived wrongdoing were asked whether they thought Mr. Clinton's activities were either unethical or illegal. Twenty-one percent said the activities were illegal, while 19 percent said they were unethical.
In the six times this question has been asked since March in polls by The Times and CBS News, this was the first time that the perception of some type of wrongdoing by Mr. Clinton has reached as high as 40 percent.
But the divisions in opinion have not diminished the President's job approval rating. Fifty-nine percent of Americans approve of the way Mr. Clinton is handling his overall job as President. It has remained near this level throughout the past year.
One reason for his approval rating is that 80 percent of the public currently pronounce the national economy as good. That is the most positive rating the economy has received in the 11 years this question has been regularly asked in Times/CBS News polls.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Hoops Hall and High Hopes

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Temple University performed live at the Apollo tonight, opening a new basketball arena in an ambitious attempt to use the drawing power of entertainment as a force for urban renewal.
Leaving the cramped, 3,900-seat McGonigle Hall for the 11,000-seat Apollo facility complete with obligatory luxury suites, giant scoreboard and throbbing sound system, Temple officials aspired to much more than winning tonight's inaugural game over Fresno State, 76-61, and its coach, Jerry Tarkanian. 
 It is the university's aim to use the on-campus arena to anchor and help revitalize a frayed North Philadelphia neighborhood that was devastated by riots in 1964 and left desolate. The arena will draw such basketball powers as Duke and Indiana, but the goal is for the Apollo, with its sporting events, concerts and other cultural events, to also attract new residents, diners and shoppers to the blighted residential and commercial district surrounding Temple.
The project "is not only about hoops, it is about hopes," said Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Ridge, who attended an afternoon ribbon-cutting ceremony.
Construction of the arena, known officially as the Forum at the Apollo, did not come without a bare-knuckled fight between Temple and the city. And no one in the neighborhood believes that one project can solve all the problems of vacant buildings, unemployment, drugs and crime.
But the arena, along with planned retail and entertainment endeavors, represents a tangible investment in an area that has heard mostly talk for decades. Until recently, the words were as vacant as many of the surrounding buildings.
"This is a sign of believability, that money can come back to the community and that the complex can be used to the advantage of people who live here," said Floyd Alston, president of the Philadelphia Board of Education and a community developer.
The Apollo of Temple is a complex of buildings consisting of the basketball arena, a theater that can seat up to 2,500, a student recreation center, an entertainment and community education center, a 1,200-car parking garage and a hall that includes the athletic department as well as restaurants and retail businesses.
"It is a world-class facility for a world-class university," said Temple's president, Peter Liacouras. Its most famous alum, Bill Cosby, said on Monday that the Apollo would allow Temple to "come out of the closet" by showcasing itself as a university committed both to the neighborhood and a global reach.
The $107 million complex was financed partly with $37.5 million from the state and about $40 million in private donations. Tonight, the Forum opened with fireworks; a laser show, and the dedication of the center-jump circle to John Chaney, who has coached the Owls since 1982, and to Harry Litwack, who coached the team for two decades beginning with the 1952-53 season.
A group of Chaney's former players saluted their collegiate coach by renting a luxury suite at the Broad Street arena for him for five years at a cost of $150,000.
"I feel very small tonight," Chaney said before the game. "This project means everything to the people in the community. I've never known a university that has been as committed to a community as Temple -- a children's hospital, a law school, med school, dental school. They have stayed the course while others have opted for white flight. If it weren't for Temple, there may be nothing but a hole in the wall on Broad Street."
The Apollo project was nearly derailed in 1995 because of a bitter fight between Temple and the city over control of $5 million that the university committed to building and rehabilitating 500 homes in the neighborhood. Chaney accused John Street, president of the Philadelphia City Council, of blackmail in holding up the project.
The matter was settled when Temple agreed to funnel the money to a city housing agency, where it would be disbursed by 20 community groups. Unraveled relationships have since been mended to the point that Street attended tonight's grand opening game, along with Mayor Ed Rendell. Street was booed, but he and Chaney hugged at midcourt.
"We were never opposed to building the Apollo," Street said in an interview. "But we said to Temple, 'You can't build a $90 million arena across from one of the most blighted areas of the city and not make arrangements for the neighborhood.' We believe things will work out for everybody."
Once a thriving center for commerce and jazz in the 1930's, 40's and 50's, the neighborhood is seeking a renaissance with a home ownership project, a restaurant row, a jazz center, clothing stores, a sporting goods store and a radio station. There are also plans for a movie theater and perhaps a hotel. All anchored by Temple's Apollo.
"I don't expect the Apollo will be a panacea for all our problems; that would be a stretch," said Alf Muronda, executive director of the area's Cecil B. Moore Avenue Community Development Corporation. "But we believe it will be a momentous dynamo. You hear some people say it's not going to work. And if Temple doesn't promote the area and help maintain security, we will both fail. We are joined at the hip. We believe the neighborhood is coming back; it just takes investment. Is the Apollo enough? Not by a long shot, but it's a good start."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The grand opening of the Apollo at Temple was a success last night -- the Owls beat Fresno State, 76-61. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Accord on Shoring Up Landmark Law

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Seeking to better preserve the thousands of historic buildings scattered across the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council leadership agreed on legislation yesterday that would bolster the city's landmarks law by adding penalties that are easier to enforce.
Under a bill that the Council's Land Use Committee approved unanimously yesterday, store owners who have covered up historic facades with garish business signs, or apartment dwellers who have replaced prewar windows with unseemly modern ones, would face civil fines that range from $500 to $5,000. 
 Preservationists have complained for years that the city's 30-year-old landmarks law was practically useless because it comprised only criminal penalties that have been virtually unenforced. Given the many more serious crimes they must contend with, police officers and prosecutors have been loath to pursue such crimes as a chiseled cornice or a jackhammered sidewalk.
The creation of civil fines would allow the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to issue a summons that would be referred to an administrative tribunal, which would be much more likely to issue a fine than a criminal court would.
City officials also said that the bill would help reduce the backlog of outstanding landmarks violations from its current high of more than 4,000. The landmarks law covers about 20,000 buildings within 70 different historic districts.
The bill, which was introduced at the request of Mayor Giuliani, is expected to be approved by the full Council at its meeting next week.
City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher compared the criminal fines of the landmarks law to the death penalty in a complicated trial. "If your only remedy is the death penalty, the jury won't convict, but if a lesser penalty is an option the jury will probably apply it," he said. "The civil fines are a way to get the attention of property owners who would otherwise just ignore the law."
Jennifer J. Raab, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said she believed the civil fines would be an extremely useful tool in deterring and correcting violations. "This legislation sends a message that we're serious about compliance," she said. "We're here to work with you, but you can't just paint a historic building bright pink or put up flashing lights in the middle of Brooklyn Heights."
She noted that the fact that the administration had worked closely with Council members to draft the legislation "sends a message of how important our historic districts are to our quality of life and to the economic well-being of the city."
In addition to the civil fines, the bill would increase the highest criminal fine from $1,000 to $10,000, but Ms. Raab said the criminal fines would probably remain infrequently enforced.
The bill would also make a building owner who demolished a landmark structure, or who altered more than 50 percent of two facades on a building, liable for the fair market value of the land.
Brendan Sexton, the president of the Municipal Art Society, called the bill long overdue. "The current situation is intolerable," he said, noting that the 4,000 outstanding violations in a pool of just 20,000 buildings would be unheard of under any other city law.
"With this bill, there's a chance at least that property owners will now treat their responsibilities under the landmarks law as seriously as they do the building code," Mr. Sexton said. "It may take a while for the message to get out, but people will eventually see that it's no longer cheaper to violate the law than to comply with it."
Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, another strong advocate for the bill, stressed that it included grace periods for compliance and was not intended to be punitive.
Before the Landmarks Preservation Commission even issued a violation under the bill, a building owner or a commercial tenant would be notified in writing that a renovation violated the landmarks law or that the owner or tenant was making a change without a proper permit. The owner or tenant would then be given a grace period to either alter the renovation or apply for the permit before a citation was issued.
There would also be the possibility of correcting the problem after a violation was actually issued. If an owner or tenant could prove that he had taken steps to cure the problem, the fine would be waived and the violation would be dropped.
"The whole point of the bill is to just get violations fixed," Ms. Breen said.
"If you live in a historic district and you're doing the right thing, it's pretty frustrating to see someone do an illegal addition or change something without a permit," she said. "This should help maintain the quality of life and property values for everyone."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The Bank Of America

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
South Korea's call today for billions of dollars in direct financial help from the United States and Japan, and the immediate rejection by Washington, was the latest example of the brewing tensions between the United States and its ailing Asian allies over how to quell a financial crisis that refuses to be tamed.
Time and again, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has said that the United States would put American taxpayer dollars at risk only as part of a "second line of defense," backing up the International Monetary Fund and other international institutions. There will be no repeat of the Mexican bailout, Mr. Rubin has made clear, during which President Clinton made a risky end run around Congress, committing $12 billion in direct aid to America's southern neighbor. 
 But throughout Asia, and particularly in South Korea, Washington's insistence on setting tough conditions for financial changes and its refusal to put much of its own money at risk is breeding hostility. Now, with its currency in free fall and despite a huge bailout package announced last week, South Korea is seeking an unequivocal show of resolve from the world's biggest superpower -- the financial equivalent of the 45,000 American troops that have kept North Korea contained for 45 years.
Mr. Rubin has plenty of reasons for hesitating to give that unconditional support. Ever since 1995, when Washington provided the first relief in the Mexican bailout, Mr. Rubin has feared that the United States is on the verge of becoming the world's lender of last resort, the financial superpower every country would turn to in time of extraordinary distress. He has spent three years shifting that role to the I.M.F., the World Bank and other institutions -- and insisting that countries agree to sharp fiscal discipline before receiving the lifeline.
In Korea, though, that approach may be about to face its first critical test. Talks began this week in Geneva over a peace treaty that would finally end the Korean War, and the United States has a lot riding on a stable and prosperous South Korea. If the country's financial health continues to deteriorate, the diplomatic pressure on Washington to step in could become excruciating.
Moreover, the economic cost could be enormous if the I.M.F. fails to rescue Korea. "We have regarded Korea as a firewall that could not be breached," one Administration official involved in the internal debate over what to do next said several days ago. "It is not at all clear that we can just say to the Koreans, 'Hey, we've done what we can. The rest is up to you.' "
The problem is not just Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy. Other dominoes are teetering. Russia is rumored to be quietly exploring whether it will need a bailout, though it insists it can survive on its own -- exactly what South Korea said until three weeks ago, when it began to acknowledge the depth of its troubles. Japan, American officials say, refuses to face up to the pain it will endure to pull out of a seven-year downturn that threatens to worsen. And the markets are clearly spooked about Indonesia, whose currency hit a record low today after the Government said that President Suharto, who is 76 and has a history of heart trouble, would be taking a 10-day vacation to restore his health. The last change of power in Indonesia, one of the world's most populous nations, led to a half-million deaths.
In public, officials trying to calm the markets are putting the most optimistic spin on events that they can, suggesting that the run of bankruptcies and bailouts is gradually slowing down. The No. 2 official of the I.M.F., Stanley Fischer, said today that there could be "a few more hiccups" but that "the worst is over." In private, however, few are that sanguine.
One reason that South Korea's financial nightmare will not end is that the country is finally abiding by the I.M.F.'s requirement that it disclose financial data that until now have been guarded as a state secret. The result is a regular trickle of more bad news. On Monday, for example, Seoul acknowledged that its short-term debt exceeded $100 billion, nearly double the figure it gave the I.M.F. a few weeks ago when negotiations for the bailout began. That helps explain why the Korean currency, the won, lost 20 percent of its value in the last two days.
The South Koreans say that they were not dissembling last month but were simply using a different accounting method, one that excluded $51 billion in debts held by overseas subsidiaries of Korean companies.
Nor was South Korea aided by its belated acknowledgment today that its foreign reserves fell to $6 billion last week, meaning that without the I.M.F.'s aid the country was within days of bankruptcy. Even with these revelations, the markets still believe that South Korean officials have not disclosed the true depth of their problems -- and so for now investors are steering clear of the country the way many New Yorkers drive blocks out of their way to avoid a bad neighborhood.
That, in turn, is adding to Korea's pain. If Japanese and American banks refuse to roll over the debts of Korean companies, Seoul must choose between letting the bankruptcies climb or shoring up its companies by providing them with dollars to pay their foreign debts. With the won continuing to plummet tonight, the cost of obtaining those dollars is rising every day. "These cycles feed on themselves," Clyde Prestowitz, the head of the Economic Strategy Institute here, said on Monday after returning from a long trip through Asia. "No one knows how long it will take before the private money begins coming back in."
In Mexico's case, it took more than a month and a half -- a period that Mr. Rubin once described as the most agonizing of his three years as Treasury Secretary. For a while, it seemed as if the Mexican bailout would fail; private investors simply could not be persuaded to put their money at risk, no matter how high the interest rates. Only when they became convinced that Mexico was serious about its austerity measures did the money begin to flow.
That could happen in Korea. But it might not. A presidential election there is only 10 days away, and already unions have threatened strikes if the Government complies with the I.M.F.'s conditions -- which many in South Korea view, accurately, as American conditions.
So for now Seoul and Washington are locked in something of a standoff, each waiting for the other to blink. South Korea's Finance Minister, Lim Chang Yuel, wants cash first and reforms later. Mr. Rubin insists that the order must be reversed. The question is whether he can stick with that position if one of America's biggest military allies in Asia once again finds itself on the verge of financial meltdown.
