SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 2132 words

HEADLINE: Art(?) to Go: Museum Shops Broaden Wares, at a Profit

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Rodin had pasta first. Now Warhol has pasta, too. Monet has Provencal soup, olive oil and absinthe. Rauschenberg has no food, but he has dinner plates.
The topic is not lunch, but what's for sale in museum stores. American museums have been hawking merchandise for more than 125 years, ever since the Metropolitan Museum of Art began selling etchings in 1871. But increasingly, objects you'd never expect to find in the nation's cultural cathedrals are being sold right alongside the art books and note cards and reproduction sculptures. 
 The trend horrifies art purists even as it delights consumers in search of a different gift this holiday season or a little bit of culture to take home. So what if the connection is tenuous? Museum stores bring in as much as a quarter of the money museums earn, outstripping admissions, membership and other revenue-producing activities.
The store at the Whitney Museum of American Art, where "The Warhol Look/Glamour Style Fashion" is on view, sells Campbell Tomato Soup watches, Campbell Soup cans stuffed with crayons and pasta shaped like lips from Warhol's 1950's ink drawing, "Lips." Merchandise for the Brooklyn Museum of Art's "Monet and the Mediterranean" exhibition includes soup mixes and bottles of olive oil that have no link with the art or the artist, save their association with the Mediterranean, too.
And visitors to the "Best Dressed: 250 Years of Style" exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art will find red tomato-flavored pasta in the shape of boots and bustiers in the museum store, not far from the green spinach-flavored pasta that looks like Rodin's "Thinker," leftovers from the "Rodin and Michelangelo" exhibition last spring.
Those six-ounce pasta packages, labeled "Food to Think About," are causing even more stir in the art world because they were dreamed up by the trend-setting Philadelphia museum, which created several hotly debated items for its 1996 Cezanne retrospective, most notably, bright yellow baseballs emblazoned with Cezanne's signature. Never mind that no one knows whether Cezanne ever heard of the great American pastime. The museum sold 8,750 balls for $9.50 each.
Baseballs, pasta and who knows what else are now turning up in other museums.
"The reason we make these products is so that we relate to everyone," said Stuart D. Gerstein, the Philadelphia museum's director of wholesale and retail operations.
Perhaps. But the bigger reason for this unabashed commercialism is simple economics.
At a time when money from government sources is declining and the largesse of corporations, foundations and private donors comes with many strings attached, art museums are looking for new ways to pay for mundane expenses like electricity and security. Some are increasing general admission fees or imposing fees for special exhibitions. Others are organizing exhibitions from their permanent collections to lend to smaller institutions and charging them for the privilege.
And just about every museum is looking to squeeze more money from the store. Even the wealthiest, the Getty Museum: when the doors of its new $1 billion complex in Los Angeles are thrown open to the public on Dec. 16 the main store will occupy 1,700 square feet, five times the space occupied by the old museum store in Malibu, and there will be three satellite shops elsewhere in the building. The museum expects sales to reach $5 million in the first year and $1 million in profits.
Unlike general retailers, museum stores enjoy their profits tax-free as long as their products are somehow related to the museum -- an edge that rankled with other retailers a few years ago. Now, "most stores have accepted it and gone onto something else," said Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, a consultant in New York. Even rival businesses like the Museum Store, the big chain that sells museum-related goods in shopping malls, are not grumbling, partly because they buy or license many of their products from the museums.
Around the country, museum stores are undergoing a metamorphosis. Many have started spicing up their merchandise mix, sometimes hiring managers from the retailing industry to do it. They have shed their old ideas of what is appropriate, to the dismay of some art lovers.
"I'm in favor of museum shops; I'm in favor of the appropriate use of reproductions," said Nicholas Fox Weber, a cultural historian. "But you don't take a great image and put it on a tote bag. It takes people away from the real issues of looking at art."
Mr. Weber declined to muster a reaction to the very idea of artistic macaroni. But the critic Deborah Solomon did. Before actually reviewing the Rodin exhibition for The Wall Street Journal last April, she chastised the museum for going too far with "Thinker" pasta.
Yet given the financial environment museum stores are unlikely to be stopped by carping. Membership surveys taken by the Association of Art Museum Directors and the American Association of Museums show that profits from museum stores contribute 18 to 26 percent of a museum's earned income, topping all other sources.
At the Metropolitan Museum, one in five visitors leaves with a bag in hand. Total revenues from its 39 stores in the United States and overseas in the fiscal year through June 39 came to $87.4 million, up slightly from five years ago.
And though most museums will not disclose store profits, Mr. Lagnado said, "these stores do well." A new survey, taken by the Museum Store Association, found that the average gross profit margin is 48 percent, some 10 points above that of respected department stores.
There's little wonder, then, that since 1992, while gallery space at 185 of the nation's largest museums increased by 3.3 percent, the space devoted to museum stores jumped 28.7 percent. Retailing managers have more room to offer more goods and to be creative about them.
"What's happening is that more and more museum administrators are paying attention to the gift shop," said Rena Zurofsky, a veteran of store management at four art museums, including the Metropolitan and the Brooklyn Museum. "And what retailing managers are hearing from them is not just a question of revenues or profits. It's 'Why don't I see in our shop what they have in that shop?' " Ms. Zurofsky is now chief of retailing at the American Museum of Natural History.
At the same time, administrators now know that some people come to museums specifically to shop, and then maybe hit the galleries. The Museum Store Association survey shows that 97 percent of art museum stores are outside the admission barriers. "Twenty years ago, we were loathed as much as we were loved," Ms. Zurofsky said. "Now we're welcomed not only because of the money we bring in, but also because we draw people in."
Museums have also learned that shoppers can help spread the art gospel simply by carrying bags decorated with a logo. That is why more and more museums are offering products with their brand name. T-shirts and tote bags printed with museum logos, already common, have been joined by baseball caps that allow people to broadcast their cultural loyalties just as they do their favorite teams.
 
Using Playthings As Links to Art
The Philadelphia Museum of Art put its own name as well as Cezanne's on each baseball, and its "Thinker" pasta included shapes of the museum's classical facade as well as Rodin's sculpture. The new Getty store will offer rubber toys modeled on the tram that delivers people to its doors and chunks of travertine marble, a material used throughout the six-building complex, labeled "The Getty Center" ($4.95 to $6.95, depending on size).
In a twist on the brand-name strategy, the Metropolitan recently expanded the role of its unofficial mascot, William, a faience hippopotamus well known to fans of the Egyptian galleries. He has already appeared in the museum store as a print, a ceramic sculpture, a T-shirt and a tie. Now he is a stuffed toy ($13.95) and a Christmas ornament, and is featured on a new T-shirt and tie. William may never rival Mickey Mouse in reach, but the intent to capitalize on a friendly, familiar image is unmistakable.
This search for the new is spreading fast. Come February, the Cleveland Museum of Art will be peddling angel-shaped pasta for its "Vatican Treasures: Early Christian, Renaissance and Baroque Art From the Papal Collections" exhibition. For its current show, "When Silk Was Gold," an exhibition of ancient Asian textiles, the Cleveland museum is selling silk robes ($150).
Elsewhere, museumgoers can find stuffed animals, needlepoint kits, rugs, refrigerator magnets, cookbooks, umbrellas, soaps, furniture, playing cards, kites, candles, clothing, razors in the shape of frogs and mermaids and, of course, loads of jewelry. Computer mouse pads and screen savers are popular.
Smart museums have found that they can spread their business more evenly through the year, instead of relying on the boost they get during December gift-buying, by offering merchandise keyed to special exhibitions. At the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the ubiquitous museum mug has been finessed by the Robert Rauschenberg dinner plate. The Whitney Museum sells bongo drums -- salt and pepper shakers, really ($30) -- made for its 1996 "Beat Culture" exhibition. And Museo del Barrio offers a baseball cap promoting its current "Taino" pre-Colombian art exhibition.
But even among items that have become old hat, like scarves and neckties, the number of selections is growing, with motifs from Klimt, Mondrian, Ingres, to name a few, or the image of an entire painting.
The Philadelphia museum even sells temporary tattoos of artworks ($2) from its collection. "Our idea is that people are walking around with art on their bodies that is not good, and we're giving them good art to wear," said Mr. Gerstein, citing tattoos of van Gogh's "Sunflowers" as an example.
Not every institution is succumbing to the trend. About 80 percent of the merchandise available at the Museum of African Art in Manhattan is authentic craft work from Africa. And the Museum of Modern Art, which plans to double its store space to 24,000 square feet when the museum is expanded in a few years, intends to stick with its strategy of offering distinctive, upscale objects.
"We will not put rubber-stamp images on every product we can get our hands on," said James D. Gundell, the new president of MOMA Retail, who was brought in this year from Bloomingdale's. Instead, he wants to tap artists to develop objects especially for the Modern.
 
M.V.P.: Renoir Or van Gogh
But only a few museums seem to have the luxury of peddling class, not mass. Mr. Gerstein, from the Philadelphia museum, defends the choice. "Our audience is changing, and we are looking for new ways to educate the public and promote the building and promote the collection," he said. In fact, he is so happy with the Cezanne baseball sales that he has a new one, an "Artists All-Star" baseball with 15 signatures by the likes of Renoir, Homer and van Gogh.
He defends the pasta equally adamantly. "You can make 'Thinker' pasta, put it in a bowl and tell your kids about Rodin and 'The Thinker,' " he argued. And he parries questions about good taste with humor: "The pasta tastes good."
More seriously, he added: "I don't look at things as being not tasteful. I look at it as a matter of quality." He said that Philadelphia was also producing items that should appeal to more sophisticated tastes, like a series of CD's with musical selections that artists might have listened to. Among them are "Music, Russia and Kandinsky," with folk songs, cafe music and orchestral music from 1914 to 1921, and "Music, Portraits and Picasso," with ballet, jazz and Catalonian folk music as well as classical French pieces.
That does not appease Mr. Weber, the cultural historian, who wishes that more museum stores offered local handicrafts and honest reproductions. "I think you want something that will perpetuate the exhibition so that you can take it home with you and be reminded of it on a Sunday morning sometime," he said. He regrets his own decision, as director of the Albers Foundation, to allow the Guggenheim to use an Albers painting on a tie a few years ago.
At the Metropolitan, John Curran, the vice president for merchandising activities, is taking neither side. The Met, he said, will never do baseballs or pasta, though it has baseball caps ($18). But, he added, some museums have little choice.
"How should museums stay open: should we raise taxes or raise admissions?" he said. "The most democratic thing to do is to let museums help themselves. No one is twisting anyone's arm to buy these things, and taste is a very subjective thing."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Byzantine Alliance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Two meetings are taking place this week that will affect the power balances of tomorrow's Middle East.
Most eyes are on Teheran's Islamic conference, where leaders of 55 mostly Muslim nations listen impassively to a radical Ayatollah -- whose internal theological authority they know is crumbling -- rail at the "poisonous breath" of the United States and Israel. 
 Less observed abroad, but far more significant, is Turkey's answer to fundamentalists and dictators: the first official visit to Turkey of an Israeli Defense Minister, accompanied by a large delegation of military officials, technicians and business executives.
Turkey is a secular Muslim country. As its neighbors that are Arabs -- led by Iraq, Syria and Egypt -- passed a resolution in Teheran denouncing the Turks for their growing ties to Israel, the Defense Minister of Turkey coolly replied, "We respect the Islamic conference, we belong to it, but we cannot allow it to dictate our relations."
The man who has done most in the past eight years to bring about this tectonic shift is the former Israeli Air Force general David Ivri. Reached by telephone in Ankara yesterday, the nonpolitical General Ivri told me that "despite the passionate statements from other countries, this strategic tie is stabilizing. It's not directed against anybody."
Except aggressors.
Turkey needs some new friends in the world. It sees Syria playing host in Damascus to the P.K.K. Kurds trying to break off a large piece of Turkey. It sees Iraq and Iran developing fearsome new weapons and the missiles to deliver them. It sees Germany and Greece selfishly blocking its entry into European integration, and its importance to NATO diminished with the temporary reduction of the Russian threat.
What can Turkey get from its new bonds with Israel? It has already contracted for a $630 million modernization of its air force: 54 of its outdated fighters will be equipped with the latest avionics and radar systems, and a new deal is in the works for 48 more. That doesn't turn them into F-15's, but will enable them to knock down what nasty neighbors might send aloft.
Also, Israelis know how to build advanced tanks; talks are under way on a joint design for production in Turkey. Ground-to-air missiles are on the shopping list. Because the U.S.-Israeli military tie is not subject to political vicissitudes, Turkey will look to Israel to get American permission to sell Arrow anti-missile missiles (a joint U.S.-Israel defensive weapon coming on line in 1999), and to urge the U.S. to help Ankara.
Israel's interest in the Byzantine bond goes beyond a chunk of future billions in military spending. Its airmen can now train in airspace that offers a land profile of battle sorties. Mit-Mossad intelligence cooperation is a prospect. And a nation of six million is more willing to take risks for peace with a nearby nation of 60 million as a strategic partner.
The Israelis will leave it to the Americans to remind Ankara, cracking down on Kurdish separatists and closing up the religious party, about the value of human rights.
The Turks know the U.S. will do that, too, despite our need for Turkish bases to maintain our no-fly zone over northern Iraq. Before Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz visits the White House next week, I expect him to throw the outspoken Kurdish dissident Leyla Zana out of prison, though that member of Parliament prefers to remain locked up for dramatic impact.
As General Ivri foresaw, the geopologic of Turkish-Israeli military, economic and technological ties (it's impolitic to call the new relationship an alliance) is greater than Islamic solidarity or European clubbiness. Common threats create mutual interests, and growing trust develops comrades in more than arms.
In ancient times, the Jews and Greeks lost to the Romans, who were swallowed up into the Byzantine Empire, which was broken up by the Turks, Persians, Russians, Arabs and Venetians.
In modern times, the Turks and Jews are protecting themselves against the Persians of Iran and Arabs of Iraq and Syria, who are supported by the Russians, Greeks, and Goths and Romans of Europe. The Venetians seem to be out of it, as are the Americans.

HEADLINE: Kyoto Meeting Moves Closer to an Agreement to Cut Greenhouse Gases

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Wednesday, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Negotiators from more than 150 countries moved closer today to an agreement requiring reductions in the emission of heat-trapping greenhouse gases by industrial countries, but a firm deal continued to elude them.
With a deadline looming later today, the discussions focused on a proposal put forth by Raul Estrada-Oyuela of Argentina, the chairman of the talks, that would cut average emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases during the period 2005 through 2010 by 5-percent below the level of emissions in 1990. 
 In meeting the overall target, different countries and groups of countries would be assigned different targets according to their economic profiles. Thus, while the United States would cut its emissions by 5 percent and Japan by 4.5 percent, for instance, emissions of the European Union would be reduced 8 percent. But all would fall within a narrow band ranging from that 8 percent reduction to increases of 5 percent permitted in Australia and Norway.
"The trend is a very positive one," Mr. Estrada said after the talks recessed at 2:30 A.M.
At issue are emissions of six greenhouse gases. The most important is carbon dioxide, which is produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil. The others are methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulfur hexachloride, but various proposals on reductions would leave decisions on some gases for another conference.
All trap heat in the atmosphere, and some scientific advisers at the talks say the gases will raise the average global temperature by 2 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit by 2100 if emissions are not reduced.
By comparison, the world has warmed by 5 to 9 degrees since the depths of the last Ice Age, and these scientists say the predicted warming would cause widespread climatic and environmental disruption.
On the sticky question of how developing countries can be brought more closely into the effort to control emissions, the proposal suggested setting up a special fund to serve as a conduit for the transfer of money and technology from rich countries to poor ones, so that the latter can adopt appropriate technologies.
The United States "welcomes" this concept, said Stuart Eizenstat, the chief American negotiator, who called it "exactly the kind of bridge both worlds should hope for."
Mr. Estrada's proposal also provides for developing countries to submit to binding controls on emissions at any time, at their option; some countries, including Chile, have expressed interest in this.
The developing countries have been insisting that they will not accept any further commitments under the 1992 Rio treaty on climate change, beyond general ones already binding them to take measures to cut emissions, until the rich countries submit to binding reductions.
But Dr. Mark Mwandosya, chairman of the developing-country caucus in the talks, said on Tuesday that "we will not be a stumbling block" to Mr. Estrada's efforts to forge a deal.
The United States signaled that it was moving in the direction of Mr. Estrada's plan on at least one key element, that of the emissions-reduction target. Mr. Eizenstat said the United States had proposed going below 1990 levels. Earlier reports from the European camp that the proposal involved a cut of 2 percent were "understated," he said.
Mr. Eisenstat said the revised American target was contingent on the acceptance of a package that includes the "trading" of emissions among countries and regions, and the Estrada proposal includes this feature. In emissions trading, a country or industrial company would be able to meet its target by cutting emissions itself, by buying reductions from a country or company that achieved excess cuts, or by both approaches.
Proponents of the approach argue that it provides an incentive for companies and countries that find it easier and cheaper to cut emissions to reduce them below the target and then sell the excess reductions, at a profit, to companies or countries that find it harder or more costly to reduce emissions on their own.
The Americans say this results in cheaper and more effective reductions, but the Europeans worry that countries might be able to buy their way out of their obligations.
The Americans proposed on Tuesday that the United States join with a group of countries including but not limited to Japan, Russia, Australia, New Zealand and Canada in an emissions-trading group.
This would potentially make it easier for the United States to achieve its commitments because Russia's economic troubles have reduced its emissions drastically. The European Union has long insisted that its 15 countries be allowed to band together to achieve a common target.
The Estrada plan would allow countries to meet part of their obligation by counting natural features, mainly forests, that absorb carbon dioxide. The Americans favor this, but the Europeas are skeptical.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Worried South Korea Seeks Expedited Relief
Alarmed that the international rescue package for its economy had failed to restore investor confidence, South Korea said it wanted quick access to cash originally pledged as a last resort from the United States and Japan.
The request from Lim Chang Yuel, Finance and Economy Minister, left, suggested that the depths of South Korea's financial crisis have yet to be seen. But Clinton Administration officials said they had received no formal request and that any early transfer of American funds would be rejected. Page A1. 

South Korea's call for billions of dollars in direct financial help from the United States and Japan, and its immediate rejection by Washington, reflect the brewing tensions between the United States and its ailing Asian allies over how to quell a financial crisis that refuses to be tamed. News Analysis. A1.
 
Stocks Weaken on Asia Fears
Growing worries about Asia's economic woes pushed down the stock market, led by drops in companies heavily dependent on the region. The most notable loser was the stock of Oracle Corporation, which dropped 29 percent in record Nasdaq volume of 172.5 million shares and was an important reason why the Nasdaq composite index fell 30.99 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,620.55. The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the second straight day, down 61.18 points, to 8,049.66. D12.
 
Despite the turmoil in Asia, United States manufacturers expect stronger revenues, increased employment and stable prices in 1998, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a year-end outlook. D4.
 
Philip Morris to Overhaul Unit
Philip Morris announced a makeover of its languishing international food business, which is concentrated in Europe, and will take a $630 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings. The company will shed 2,500 jobs and close some factories. D6.
 
Hasbro to Cut Jobs and Close Plants
Hasbro unveiled a global restructuring program that includes plant closings and a reduction of 2,500 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, to enhance shareholder value. The company, the No. 2 toy maker, after Mattel, will take a one-time pretax charge of $140 million. D19.
 
Gold Hits 18-Year Low
Gold dropped to $282.75 an ounce, the lowest since 1979 and the latest in a series of price declines this year. The loss of gold's value reflects the power of the world's central banks, which are selling, or threatening to sell, their hoards of gold and lending it cheaply to producers and speculators. D19.
 
Swiss Bankers Outline Goals
The two executives who will run the United Bank of Switzerland, the world's second-largest bank, set a profit goal of $8 billion by 2002 and said the merger enabled them to win Swiss Government approval for cutting 7,000 jobs. D5.
 
Europe Wants Better Boeing Rival
Leaders of France, Germany and Britain called for an integrated European aerospace and military electronics industry capable of competing with Boeing and other American giants that dominate both the defense and civilian aviation markets. D5.
 
U.S. Surgical Buying Pfizer Division
U.S. Surgical said it would acquire Pfizer's Valleylab division, maker of electronic surgery and ultrasound products. The $425 million purchase strengthens U.S. Surgical's business in instruments for minimally invasive medical procedures. D4.
 
One That Got Away
Richard Branson, the British entrepreneur, has found success in the music business, in retailing and in airlines. Balloons, alas, are another story. His effort last year to lead the first nonstop round-the-world balloon flight ended in failure. And yesterday, he and his crew never got a chance to make another attempt, as their 160-foot-high balloon broke free from its mooring and sailed crewless high over the Moroccan desert. A14.

HEADLINE: Officials Unsure About Cost and Effect of New Transit Fares

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The day after the announcement of the biggest change in fare policy in the history of New York City mass transit -- a system of monthly, weekly and daily passes good for unlimited travel -- officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority acknowledged many uncertainties yesterday about how the system would work.
Answers to even the most basic questions -- how much the pass system would cost the transportation authority to run, how many people would use the passes, and how many new buses and trains would be needed to accommodate an expected increase in ridership -- were inconclusive. 
 Although the authority has estimates for most of the problems, it conceded that they had to rely on old data and possibly outdated surveys.
The authority's current estimate of the cost of the pass program -- $236 million a year -- is at least 40 percent lower than one it made in April for a slightly less ambitious hypothetical program.
Estimates of the number of people who would buy the passes -- an increase of about 100 million rides a year, or about 6 percent, is anticipated -- are based on surveys conducted five years ago, when the authority was planning the present Metrocard system that New Yorkers have only grudgingly come to embrace.
And while officials said yesterday that the need for additional trains and buses would be "minimal to nothing" because ridership would increase most during off-peak hours, they acknowledged that the effect of new fares was notoriously hard to anticipate, especially ones intended to cause what an official called "real behavioral changes."
A much less radical change in policy -- the free bus-to-subway transfers introduced in July -- was so unexpectedly popular that the authority had to add 200 buses, a number that transit advocates said has not been enough to relieve overcrowding.
Asked why the transportation authority had not updated the surveys, Marc V. Shaw, the executive director, said, "Surveys are very expensive to do, and unless you have reason to believe that there's been big demographic changes, which we don't, why do a new one?"
Even transit advocates who have praised the new passes said that the authority seemed, to a certain extent, to be flying by the seat of its pants.
"I think this thing is being driven more by the desire to offer discounts than by any sound fiscal planning," said Alan Foster, associate director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Council to the M.T.A., a watchdog group. "But that doesn't mean they won't be able to find a way to pay for it."
"They're making it up as they go along," said Gene Russianoff, the staff attorney for another advocacy group, the Straphangers Campaign, who may be the most vocal proponent of the monthly pass.
The $236 million estimated cost of the pass program, officials said, is the difference between the amount they expect riders to pay for passes and the amount of revenue the authority would have received if those riders had paid for their trips one at a time.
To cover the cost, the authority is counting on this year's surplus, which comes from increased ridership and dedicated tax revenues, becoming part of its permanent revenue stream -- even though the increase in tax revenue is a result of the city's booming economy (a fraction of sales and other taxes goes to the M.T.A.), which could cool off in future years.
To make up the $49 million difference between the surplus and the total expected cost of the pass program, the authority plans to cut its administrative costs. Officials would not say yesterday where they planned to make the cuts, but said that it would not be difficult to pare $49 million from a $3 billion budget.
Transit officials said that a certain amount of uncertainty was inherent in any planning, and that they felt confident the monthly passes would not encounter any problems that could not be handled in the long run.
"This plan is the result of real professional people doing this for a living, really trying to do what they think is best," Mr. Shaw said. "Forecasting is always based on assumptions, but you're trying to use your best estimations based on all the information you have.
"Given all that, and given that behavioral changes are incredibly hard to predict, we think this is going to lead to a better subway system and a better usage of the subway system in the City of New York," he said.
The pass program, which could be introduced by next summer, would offer riders unlimited travel for $63 a month, $17 a week or $4 a day.
It was announced on Monday by Gov. George E. Pataki after two months of mounting public pressure on the transportation authority to use its 1997 budget surplus, which officials said yesterday was expected to hit $185 million by year's end, to give riders a break. The transportation authority board, which is controlled by the Governor's appointees, is expected to approve the plan formally Dec. 18.
In an interview, Mr. Pataki described the plan as the result of a struggle between his staff members and transportation authority staff members who questioned whether the plan was too risky.
"There's no question that we had to push the bureaucrats at the M.T.A.," he said. "Too many bureaucrats view the transit rider as a captive of the system, rather than as a customer."
Yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani continued to call for a different pricing structure, urging that riders be given 12 rides for the price of 10.
"We will press it, see if we can get the M.T.A. board to agree with it," the Mayor said. "It looks like they're not going to agree with it right now. But all of these benefits go into effect in the middle of June or July, so we have a lot of time."
By the time the pass system put forward by Mr. Pataki is a year old, the transportation authority expects it to have transformed New Yorkers' travel habits.
Officials said yesterday that by 1999, they expected that 53 percent of all trips would be taken by people holding some form of pass -- 39 percent by monthly passholders, 7 percent by weekly passholders and 7 percent by daily passholders.
About 33 percent of all trips would be taken by Metrocard users who would buy in bulk and get a 10 percent bonus, and 9 percent would be taken by users of the standard Metrocard, officials predicted.
Tokens, which still account for nearly half of all trips, would be used only 5 percent of the time, officials said. Mr. Shaw said that the projections for pass use, based on 1992 telephone surveys, were conservative.
Even if the passes turn out to be so popular that the system is overwhelmed with riders, Mr. Russianoff said, worse things could happen.
"It's great to be in a situation where your biggest problem is that you have too many customers," he said. "The problem with the transit system for the last 50 years is that they keep having a dwindling number of riders, a dwindling amount of political support. It'll be a challenge for them, but it's a good challenge."

HEADLINE: On Madison, a Crumbling Wall Is Scrambling Lives

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
It was quiet once again yesterday on Madison Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets.
Quiet, because no customers were sliding their feet into the brown leather shoes at Johnston & Murphy. The store was closed. Quiet, because no one was petting the teddy bears at the Vermont Teddy Bear Company, which had also been shuttered. And quiet, because no one was flipping burgers at Burger Heaven. 
 While drivers and pedestrians in midtown Manhattan struggled to cope with the mess created by bricks raining down from 540 Madison Avenue, a 39-story office building, there was a much more personal element to the disruption. An actress who lived in a nearby building said she was in her nightgown on Sunday when she was evacuated, and has not been allowed to return to pick up additional clothing. A business owner said his plans to retire had been thrown into jeopardy. And merchants said they were losing business at a critical time.
"This is a disaster," said Peter J. Morrell, the chairman of Morrell & Company, a wine retailer at 535 Madison that he said was losing about $100,000 a day in sales. "This is like the Grinch who stole Christmas."
For many, the worst part of the situation was that no one knew when things would return to normal. While other Manhattan stores were enjoying the fruits of a booming economy and the surge in tourism, Sunday's accident was a painful reminder of how fate can interrupt at the most unexpected of times.
"It's a calamity," said the owner of a leather-goods store, Hides in Shape, who would identify himself only as V. Kurdian. He said that while his business, which is just north of the cordoned-off area, was still open, he had suffered a 90 percent drop in sales. "This is worse than mid-February, and that is our deadest month."
Usually, of course, December ranks as the height of the retail season. And for many of the businesses on Madison Avenue, the holiday season had started out promisingly: the Vermont Teddy Bear Company, for instance, on Saturday recorded its busiest business day since Valentine's Day.
But at 12:44 P.M. Sunday, a section of the south wall of 540 Madison came loose, showering debris on holiday shoppers and dropping graphite-colored bricks into a safety net. The net then sagged and collapsed into a work platform, sending more debris to the street. Two people were injured in the accident, neither of them seriously.
Yesterday, workers constructed a steel beam that was supposed to be wedged under the weak portion of the wall. But late yesterday, officials decided that the wedging method was not feasible. So a new tack was planned for dawn today: lowering workers down the side of the wall to insert wooden planks as a temporary shoring device.
As a result, city officials said that Madison Avenue would not be reopened today, and possibly not tomorrow, depending on how the work goes and the weather conditions.
Left closed to vehicular and pedestrian traffic was the part of the avenue between 53d and 55th Streets, while 54th Street was closed to traffic for about one block. All stores within that area were closed as well.
As of late yesterday, tenants who had been evacuated from several smaller buildings south of 540 Madison -- including 538, 536, 534 and 532 Madison -- had not been allowed to return to any of those buildings.
Yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani urged patience. "I understand and sympathize tremendously with the businesses there," he said. "But the people working on this are working on it as fast as possible. What we should do is make sure they get it done safely, because what we don't want is for people to do it too fast and not make sure all the bricks are secure."
In the meantime, economic misery has become a common denominator on one of Manhattan's swankiest blocks.
Frederick Kahn, a dentist with an office at 538 Madison, pleaded with emergency officials to let him back in his offices for five minutes -- just five minutes -- to retrieve his appointment book and Rolodex. No luck.
"They said, 'If we give you five minutes, we'll have to give everyone five minutes,' " Dr. Kahn said yesterday from his home. "And they said, 'We're afraid to send an emergency person in with you, because we might have two dead instead of one.' "
It was the same story with Barbara Spiegel, an actress who is one of a handful of people who live on the block. She was wearing her nightgown on Sunday afternoon when fire officials came to her top-floor apartment at 534 Madison and told her she had to leave, and she was still wearing it yesterday.
She decided to go to the home of a friend; other residents of the block were staying in hotels, with the costs to be paid by the Macklowe Organization, the owner of 540 Madison Avenue.
Stores in the surrounding area felt the impact. Some, like Schumer's Wine & Liquors, on East 54th Street between Madison and Park Avenues, could not get deliveries because of the traffic barriers. Others, like the restaurant Bice on East 54th Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues, saw a 50 percent drop in business because of the traffic barriers and a lack of walk-in business. At Parviz Nemati Oriental Rugs on the corner of 53d Street, where prices for rugs and tapestries start at $20,000, Mr. Nemati, the owner, was anxious. His lease runs out at month's end, he said, and he had intended to liquidate the store's holdings to raise $2 million, then retire. But yesterday, he was not sure.
"People call from all over the country, and they say, 'Oh we are afraid to come in,' " said Mr. Nemati, who did not receive his first customer of the day until 4:30 P.M. If the street remains closed for much longer, he said, "I don't know if I can retire."
And there were the customers.
Mary Goldstein, who manages a restaurant, gets her hair done twice a week at Le Rebelle, at 532 Madison. But last night, Ms. Goldstein confronted blue police barriers and was told that the salon was closed. She approached a reporter.
"I was hoping you were a hairdresser and you were going to save me," she said. When told otherwise, she quietly turned away and left the area.

HEADLINE: KOREANS PRESSING U.S. AND JAPANESE FOR SPEEDIER AID

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 9

 BODY:
With investor confidence again starting to erode despite the international rescue of its economy, South Korea's Government called on the United States and Japan today to quickly provide some money that they had pledged only as a last resort.
But within hours, Clinton Administration officials made clear that any early injection of American funds would be firmly rejected. The Japanese Finance Ministry said its funds would only be available as a backup and the original terms of the bailout should be honored. 
 Both Governments said they had received no formal request from the South Korean Government, and they seemed surprised that Seoul would float such a request before it had been conveyed to Washington and Tokyo.
The Korean request, made by the Finance Minister in an interview today, came less than a week after the rescue agreement was announced and reflected growing signs that the International Monetary Fund bailout has not restored confidence in South Korea's shaky financial system.
With its holdings of dollars running low, both the country's currency and its stock market have been plummeting. Indeed, the won is in free fall, having lost 16 percent of its value against the dollar the last two days. The stock market rallied immediately after the announcement of the bailout but has almost completely given up the gain it had recorded.
"If the U.S. and Japan are committed to supporting the Korean economy, they should support the economy at the early stage, rather than waiting," Lim Chang Yuel, the Minister of Finance and Economy, said today. "This will stabilize the markets here," he added.
Mr. Lim denied that he was, in effect, suggesting that the $57 billion bailout would have to be increased. "I think we can make it," Mr. Lim said. But, he added, some of the money from Tokyo and Washington should be "front loaded."
There have been growing fears among investors that the bailout might be insufficient, especially after Seoul acknowledged Korea's $66 billion in short-term debt dominated mainly in dollars does not include $50 billion owed by the overseas operations of South Korean companies.
Under the rescue package, the United States pledged $5 billion and Japan $10 billion. But their contributions, along with those of other countries, constituted only a backup source of funds if the $35 billion from the I.M.F., the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank -- was insufficient.
The Clinton Administration, which played a leading role in orchestrating the bailout, has tried to make the contribution more politically palatable in the United States by saying there was a chance the American money would never be needed.
"They should implement the reforms that are needed to get Korea back on the right path," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who has directed the American response to the series of Asian bailouts, said in a telephone interview today. "I think the overall structure of the I.M.F. program is a strong one, and is supported by the second line of defense commitments by the other countries," he said.
But the direct financial participation of the United States and other nations in aiding South Korea, he said, "only comes later."
 Mr. Lim is not waiting only for Washington and Tokyo. On Wednesday morning, he moved up the timetable for allowing foreign shareholders to own half the stock in a Korean company, up from 26 percent currently. The limit will be raised on Thursday rather than by year-end.
 Mr. Lim also announced that the Government was suspending the operations of five more merchant banks in addition to the nine suspended last week. the merchant banks, tend to specialize in short-term lending, and Mr. Lim said commercial banks would be allowed to take on some of their functions to avoid a credit squeeze for Korean companies. The won continued to plummet on Wednesday, falling to the maximum daily limit before trading was halted.
Meanwhile, more details emerged today about just how close South Korea was to defaulting on its debt payable in dollars before the bailout was announced.
A report by the I.M.F. released by the Government said its holdings of foreign currency, mostly American dollars, were only about $6 billion on Dec. 2, the day before the agreement was reached, according to Reuters.
One Finance Ministry official said the Bank of Korea was burning through its reserves by as much as $2 billion a day to help South Korean banks that needed cash because they had lost their short-term loans from foreign banks. That indicates that the country had only a few days left before a default.
Before that point, the last official Government figure for holdings of foreign currencies was $30.5 billion as of Oct. 31, which the I.M.F. said shrank to $23.9 billion by Dec. 2. But the I.M.F. said $17.9 million was unusable because it was tied up in the foreign banking subsidiaries of Korean banks, which needed it to pay off short-term debt as their lenders demanded payment.
Without those funds, one Finance Ministry official said, the Korean banks would fail.
Mr. Lim, who holds the title of Deputy Prime Minister, said he had not yet asked Washington or Tokyo directly to speed their contributions, and he did not say how much money he wanted now.
The I.M.F. has already given South Korea $5.5 billion, with another $3.5 billion due this month followed by $2 billion in January. The Asian Development Bank will give $2 billion this month, and the World Bank is expected to chip in its first $2 billion. The money is being given in stages to insure that South Korea carries out a number of changes to pump more capital into its banking system, open South Korea to greater foreign investment and reduce political influence on the corporate sector.
One of Mr. Lim's motives for seeking American money now reflects the hostility in the country to demands by the United States to revamp its economy. He said he wanted to see dollars injected into the country now from Washington and Tokyo when it is urgently needed -- not merely as a backup down the road. "If not, they are just servicing by words," he said. "They are advising on policies and not really putting their money in at all."
Mr. Lim added, "What will the Korean public's response be? You can imagine." Similar complaints were made against the United States in the I.M.F. bailout of Thailand, to which Washington contributed no money.
Mr. Lim, 53, who became Finance Minister on Nov. 19 and led Korea's negotiations for the bailout, also said the United States and Japan should contribute because the falling won means that it takes fewer dollars and yen to buy South Korean products.
The minister spoke on a day when the Korean currency plunged to a record low close of 1,460 against the dollar. The dollar was at 1,196 won the day the bailout was announced and at 844.20 at the end of last year.
The stock market's KOSPI index plummeted 6.47 percent, to 388.00, today. And interest rates on three-year corporate bonds surged to 24.95 percent, a hair less than the legal limit of 25 percent.
"In a sense the market is telling the Government that the conditions the I.M.F. originally set are not enough," said Richard Samuelson, director of research and manager at the Seoul branch of SBC Warburg Dillon Read, a brokerage firm. "I would reckon there's some serious hair-pulling in the Blue House and the Finance Ministry," he said. The Blue House is the South Korean equivalent of the White House.
Ideally, the funds Mr. Lim seeks would be used to make short-term loans to South Korean banks to repay depositors and lenders and avert a series of bank runs and defaults. Also, a larger amount of dollars on hand would impart a greater sense of confidence among international money managers. One other use of the funds might be to buy won on the open market, thereby lifting demand and propping up its value. But the I.M.F. has opposed that strategy for fear that the money would be wasted because it might raise the value of the currency only temporarily.
Officials at the I.M.F. said they were unaware of Mr. Lim's comments, but that they saw no need for the United States and Japan to provide any additional money to South Korea now.
"Nothing has happened on the external side that suggests they need more money," said an I.M.F. official who insisted on anonymity.
The official said that South Korea had properly allowed its currency to fall sharply in value the last several days rather than using the money provided by the fund to intervene in the foreign exchange market.
The continuing devaluation of the won could worsen the crisis, however. For one thing it means that South Korea's short-term debt, officially estimated at about $66 billion, would become that much more expensive to pay back because it would take more won to repay a fixed amount of dollars. Also, foreign banks, which helped precipitate the crisis by cutting off credit lines to Korean banks, could do so again if they thought their loans would not be repaid.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Pataki Receives $17,000 For Talk to Corporation

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki went to Milwaukee last night to give his fifth paid speech of the year, receiving about $17,000 for a talk to a mutual fund management company about the post-industrial economy.
The Republican Governor's practice of giving paid speeches has come under fierce criticism from Democrats and watchdog groups who contend it exposes him to conflicts of interest with groups that conduct business with the state. Mr. Pataki has given nine paid speeches since he began the practice last year. 
 Aides to the Governor say he must supplement his salary of $130,000 because he is carrying a heavy debt load from real estate investments and has a daughter attending Yale. During the 1994 campaign, Mr. Pataki's campaign advisers frequently criticized Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for giving paid speeches.
Mr. Pataki addressed employees of Strong Capital Management, said Zenia Mucha, his director of communications. Ms. Mucha said he would be paid his standard fee, which recently rose to $17,000.

HEADLINE: $400 Million Hotel Expansion Is Planned by Mohegan Sun

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Mohegan tribe, which owns one of the nation's largest casinos, plans to add a $400 million-plus hotel and convention center to the gambling palace on its eastern Connecticut reservation, tribal leaders said today.
Mohegan Sun, the tribe's casino, has made millions of dollars by attracting more visitors than the Statue of Liberty this year, and since it opened in October 1996, roughly 20,000 day-trippers, usually from New York and New England, have come every day to gamble there. But the tribe wants to transform the casino, which has an Indian theme, into a destination resort like Las Vegas, and it intends to begin this new project as early as April, completing the job by the year 2000 at the latest. 
 The casino is in Uncasville, Conn., about a two-and-one-half-hour drive from Manhattan -- closer than Atlantic City.
The tribe made its announcement here this morning at a meeting of the Eastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, after months of anticipation as to when the Mohegans would expand their enterprise.
"In regards to what it's going to be -- and I've heard everything from a ferris wheel to a Six Flags theme park -- what the tribe is looking for is something that will be more than just gaming," Roland Harris, the tribal council chairman, told the business group. "We understand that gaming may not be forever, and that it may be cyclical like everything else."
Mr. Harris explained that the tribe wanted to "diversify the facility" by building one to three hotels that would offer 1,200 to 2,200 rooms and that might have a nautical theme that reflects the Mohegans' heritage as whalers. There also would be a 5,000-to-10,000-seat entertainment center, a 75,000-square-foot convention center and more gaming space added to the giant $300-million casino, which already houses 3,000 slot machines and 180 gaming tables.
The tribe is also planning to build a marina next to the casino, which is on the west bank of the Thames River, though it will not be part of the hotel and convention center proposal.
The planned expansion is the latest example of how the Mohegans and their neighbors, the Mashantucket Pequots, who own and operate the Foxwoods Resort Casino, have become the engine driving the economy in this region of the state. While eastern Connecticut once relied heavily on military contracts, downsizing in the defense industry has cost the region thousands of jobs, and tourism has emerged as the area's fastest-growing industry.
By making this move, the Mohegans are following in the Pequots' foot-steps. The Pequots, whose casino in nearby Ledyard is the nation's largest, have been operating two hotels for several years and have recently opened part of a 17-story hotel. The rest of that hotel is scheduled to be completed by April, giving the tribe 1,400 rooms.
The Mohegans continue to work with a partnership headed by a Sol Kerzner, a South African casino developer who has created some of the gambling industry's most opulent resorts. He has built Sun City, a lavish African casino resort with man-made lakes and golf courses.
State officials have estimated that the Mohegan slot machines will generate $370 million in revenues from July 1, 1997, to June 30, 1998. Slot machines generally account for about 65 to 70 percent of a casino's take. Foxwoods earns roughly double the amount of Mohegan Sun.

HEADLINE: 52 Charged With Fraud As Tenants

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

 BODY:
State and city prosecutors announced fraud charges yesterday against 52 residents of city housing projects and other subsidized apartments, who are accused of stealing nearly $900,000 in housing and welfare benefits by lying about their jobs, income and assets.
One Brooklyn couple hid $500,000 in assets from the New York City Housing Authority, prosecutors said. Others sublet their Housing Authority apartments while living elsewhere, or concealed employment, including city jobs. 
 Edward Kuriansky, Commissioner of the city's Department of Investigation, who announced the charges along with the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, noted that there was a six-year waiting list to get into subsidized housing.
"Our interest is in protecting the honest people who are deprived, who are more needy," Mr. Morgenthau said. "All those who stand in line to try and get in those housing projects but can't."
Prosecutors said the defendants stole benefits worth $2,870 to $43,000. These were some of the accusations:
*David K. Simms, 32, holder of an apartment at the Harlem River Houses in upper Manhattan, had actually lived and worked in Philadelphia since 1989, holding jobs at two hospitals and a Pizza Hut, while collecting rent from a subtenant in New York. Prosecutors said he received welfare benefits as well.
*Tibor Gelb, 43, and his wife, Blanche, 41, failed to report interest on more than $500,000 they had in bank accounts, and also failed to report several real estate transactions, while they were Housing Authority tenants from 1984 to 1995.
*Gwendolyn Patton, 40, an employee of the Department of Veterans Affairs who held an apartment at the Edgemere Houses in Queens, concealed her income from that job while receiving $11,990 worth of rent subsidies and $27,804 in welfare.
The investigation, reported yesterday in The Daily News, was part of a series of inquiries into welfare and housing fraud. Prosecutors said several arrests resulted from a comparison of computer data from city, state and Federal payrolls with lists of housing and welfare recipients.

HEADLINE: 'Shareholder' Model Demeans Marriage

 BODY:

To the Editor:
When Lorna J. Wendt claimed 50 percent of family assets as an "equitable distribution" in a divorce settlement from Gary C. Wendt, chief executive of GE Capital Corporation, she argued that she had earned it as an economic helpmate in her husband's career. A Connecticut court awarded $20 million, out of their estimated wealth of $100 million. 
 You note (editorial, Dec. 5) that the award, though not half, was still a "grand sum." Furthermore, incomes in the highest zones now bring extravagant wealth to some people whose "earning power is based on unique talents that have nothing to do with their marriages." Outgoing spouses should therefore be able to claim some of that wealth insofar as they contributed to it. Your headline, "Spouses as Shareholders," with its overtones of limited liability, reinforces this rejection of a connubial partnership in which all belongs to both.
Mrs. Wendt had only one rightful claim, which had nothing to do with being an entrepreneur: she was a wife. What is left of marriage if partners can claim talents or handicaps, income or losses, assets or liabilities, homes or offspring "that have nothing to do with their marriages"?
 
JAMES TUNSTEAD BURTCHAELL
Princeton, N.J., Dec. 6, 1997

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A new look at bank reforms to cut inefficiencies and risk.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
JAPAN'S financial system, built around giant banks with fingers in every economic pie, is collapsing along with real estate and stock markets -- and in the process dragging Japan to the brink of depression. Why, then, should America abandon the legal barricades that have separated banking from other financial services and inhibited the rise of nationwide branch banking since the New Deal?
The next time the White House tries to maneuver comprehensive banking reform past a skeptical Congress -- a futile exercise for the last two Administrations -- the Treasury will have to come up with convincing answers. Check that; it already has. 
 As if in anticipation of the mess in Asia, the Treasury quietly issued a report last month on "American Finance for the 21st Century." Drafted by Robert Litan, a former Clinton Administration budget official who now directs economic studies at the Brookings Institution, and Jonathan Rauch, a journalist retained to keep it short and jargon-free, the report elegantly summarizes where the financial services industry has been and compellingly argues for where it ought to go.
Financial services -- banks, insurers, brokers, investment underwriters, mutual finds -- generate just 6 percent of America's gross domestic product. But the businesses producing the other 94 percent thrive or languish on the financial services industry's efficiency in processing payments, playing matchmaker between savers and investors and spreading risk.
Largely self-regulated until the stock market crash in 1929, the industry imploded early in the Great Depression. Nine thousand banks failed and lending shriveled. Even the payments system -- the vital, workaday capacity of banks to process checks and to store working capital -- was critically wounded.
Americans blamed the natural excesses of capitalism in general, and banking in particular. They devised a new regulatory regime around tight Government control of banking and securities markets, generous deposit insurance and assured access to credit.
This system -- driven by what Mr. Litan calls "prevention of failure at all cost" -- worked well enough (if not well) until the late 1970's. But it was slowly undermined by innovation and political lobbying, as financial players saw how much money could be made via end runs around regulations or loopholes through them.
Private, uninsured money market funds drained deposits from banks by paying higher interest. Insured lenders fought back, getting permission to pay market-rate interest and invest in whatever they pleased. Unregulated lenders grabbed much of the traditional corporate business from banks and forced them into higher-risk loans to real estate developers and foreign governments.
Government was left with ineffective controls on insured lenders, but unlimited responsibility for depositors. The result was financial folly -- Latin American loan defaults, savings and loan insolvencies. The waste proved only a minor drag on economic growth. But taxpayers took a $150 billion hit. Ominously, the Government's reflexive response was to patch the obsolete regulatory structure, strengthening bank supervision and raising capital requirements.
Mr. Litan calls for a fundamental rethinking of financial regulation. "Periodic upsets in financial markets are inevitable," he argues, and the goal ought to shift from "preventing upsets to containing them." That means identifying and isolating trouble early, rather than suppressing market forces and leaving the taxpayers responsible when regulation fails. Indeed, open-ended deposit insurance is the enemy of this containment strategy. "If market participants know the Government will always be there to bail them out," Mr. Litan argues, "they have nothing to lose by taking reckless risks."
The report offers specific recommendations ranging from the utopian (international harmonization of accounting rules) to the mundane (faster payments clearing). But one in particular illustrates the general thrust of harnessing markets to excise inefficiency and contain risk. Mr. Litan would require large banks to create a thick buffer of subordinated debt -- uninsured bonds -- between bank stockholders and insured depositors. This would not only reduce potential losses to Government deposit insurance but also create a class of hostage investors to safeguard against imprudent lending. What's more, the market interest rate on this debt would give regulators an alternative way of measuring the riskiness of a bank's portfolio.
While Congress has balked at comprehensive financial reform, markets are driving change independently -- much the way they have in health care. This report is unlikely to break the interest-group gridlock that has prevented Congress from acting. But as Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin suggests in the preface, it "presents an extremely useful analytic framework," a matrix for assessing proposed changes, whether they be comprehensive or piecemeal.

HEADLINE: Broadest Measure of Trade Deficit Widens

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The nation's deficit on the current account, the broadest measure of international trade, widened in the third quarter as Asia's economic crisis weakened United States exports.
The current account, which measures trade in goods, services and investments, widened to a seasonally adjusted $42.156 billion in the third quarter, up 11.4 percent from a revised $37.852 billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today. 
 While weaker Asian demand for American-made goods and a surge in cheap imports from Asia accounted for a part of the ballooning current-account gap, investment flows to the United States also slowed.
"We're going to see even more pronounced weakness in exports in this quarter and in 1998," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
Net foreign purchases of Treasury securities and dollars declined to $43.5 billion in the third quarter from $49.9 billion in the second quarter as Japanese investors bought fewer bills, notes and bonds. The decline was offset in part by a rise in purchases from Western Europe.
Over all, the United States deficit in merchandise trade rose 9.4 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter to $51.5 billion, while the surplus in services rose 2 percent, to $21.9 billion.

HEADLINE: Line Item Languor

BYLINE: By John McCain; John McCain, a Republican, is a United States Senator from Arizona.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With the enactment of the line item veto in 1996, President Clinton became the first chief executive to have the power to eliminate the billions of dollars in wasteful spending that Congress adds to appropriations bills each year. Unfortunately, he has completely missed this historic opportunity.
The President used the line item veto to eliminate only $491 million from more than $800 billion in spending in the 13 appropriations bills for the 1998 fiscal year. That amounts to less than one-tenth of 1 percent, leaving billions of dollars' worth of low-priority, unnecessary or wasteful projects. 
 Look at some of the projects the President chose not to veto:
* A $3 million grant from the Agency for International Development to the International Fertilizer Development Center.
* $300,000 to establish a dedicated commuter lane on a highway in El Paso, Tex.
* A provision requiring the Army to build a bridge across the Bull River in Alaska and provide two 6 x 6 vehicles so that students from the University of Alaska can have access to the Golden Zone Mine. This project could cost tens of millions of dollars and will benefit fewer than 8,500 students.
* $26 million from the defense budget for nondefense purposes, including automobile technology development at the National Automotive Center in Michigan, electric vehicle research and development, and a Center of Excellence for Research in Ocean Sciences. (Tapping into the defense budget for projects that belong somewhere else is a favorite trick of pork-barrelers.)
* $100,000 to preserve a Revolutionary War gunboat discovered on the bottom of Lake Champlain on the Vermont-New York border.
* $400,000 each for research on the Preble's Meadow jumping mouse and the Alabama sturgeon.
* $500,000 for the "fine hardwoods tree improvement project" at Purdue University.
* $150,000 for the National Center for Peanut Competitiveness.
* $6 million to complete construction of a building at the National Center for Cool and Cold Water Aquaculture in Leetown, W.Va., and another $250,000 to initiate a program there.
* $3.3 million for shrimp aquaculture research in Arizona, Hawaii, Mississippi, Massachusetts and California.
* $540,000 for various agriculture-related research efforts, including dairy and meat goat research in Texas, poult enteritis mortality syndrome research in Georgia, hops research in Oregon and phytophthora root rot research in New Mexico.
Some of these projects are as absurd as they sound. Others may have merit but could and should be financed by local government or private industry. All of them and dozens more were on a list I formulated using criteria developed in cooperation with government watchdog organizations like Citizens Against Government Waste -- a list that totaled $8 billion. The President, though, left the vast majority of those projects unscathed.
I will not venture an opinion as to why some projects were not vetoed by Mr. Clinton while other, similar projects were eliminated.
Some claim partisan politics played a role, since the President eliminated more Republican-proposed projects than Democratic-backed ones. Others point to a flurry of deal-making in the last days of the first session of this Congress, in which the White House supposedly promised not to veto certain projects if the affected members of Congress would vote for particular legislation.
I have not seen compelling evidence of either claim. However, the Administration's refusal to establish objective criteria for exercise of the line item veto helped give these claims a certain credibility. And the seemingly random nature of the Administration's veto decisions left Mr. Clinton vulnerable to criticism, which may have made him reluctant to make more extensive use of the power.
The director of the Office of Management and Budget says the Administration believes that the mere existence of the line item veto power acts as a deterrent to pork-barrel spending. But threats alone will not curb Congress's appetite for pork. Actually using the line item veto will enhance its deterrent effect and, more important, eliminate any wasteful spending that is not deterred by the veto threat.
The Republican Congress passed the Line Item Veto Act last year after 10 years of dedicated effort. President Clinton, who supported the measure and could have established a vigorous first-year precedent, instead has made that 10-year struggle seem like a waste through his unwillingness to use the veto effectively.
Sadly, the people who will pay the price are the taxpayers, who in the coming year will have to pony up $7.5 billion to finance the pork-barrel habits of the politicians in Washington.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Paul Sahre)

HEADLINE: Preventing Another Flight 800

 BODY:
Aircraft manufacturers, airlines and their Federal overseers understandably like to identify the cause of an air disaster before developing changes in design, operations or training to enhance safety. But that is highly unlikely in the case of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, where investigators, after an exhaustive inquiry, have been unable to determine just what caused the plane's center fuel tank to explode. Even so, testimony this week at hearings on the 1996 crash suggests that reasonable and novel steps can be taken to prevent a recurrence.
In their testimony in Baltimore at the National Transportation Safety Board hearings, Boeing engineers essentially said that technical changes aimed at protecting the 747's fuel tank from sparks -- the traditional approach to preventing such explosions -- were not enough. There must also be a search, they said, for ways to reduce the flammability of fuel vapors in the tank so that they will not explode even if a spark is generated. That approach was recommended by the safety board nearly a year ago but was initially opposed by the industry and the Federal Aviation Administration, which preferred to concentrate on eliminating ignition sources. The manufacturer's testimony may now drive the search for solutions increasingly toward vapor reduction. 
 Boeing says its search for ways to cut the flammability of fuel has been under way for months and involves talks with others in the industry. Its efforts appear analogous to its decision to alter a part of the rudder on its 737 airliner after crashes near Pittsburgh in 1994 and near Colorado Springs in 1991, even though regulators have yet to rule on the precise causes of those accidents.
Most Americans have neither the time nor expertise to sort out the sometimes conflicting safety recommendations made by the safety board, whose mandate is to enhance safety, and the Federal Aviation Administration, which concerns itself with safety and cost-benefit analysis. But watching the two agencies feud over which changes the industry should adopt in the aftermath of Flight 800 has been unsettling. The comforting development at this week's hearings was to find both Boeing and the F.A.A. moving closer to some of the safety board's positions. That can only enhance safety and consumer confidence in commercial aviation.

HEADLINE: 8 Countries Join in an Effort To Catch Computer Criminals

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Acknowledging a need to confront computer crime more forcefully, the United States and seven other countries pledged today to search for and prosecute high-tech criminals from each other's countries even when extradition laws do not apply.
A communique signed by Attorney General Janet Reno and the Justice and Interior Ministers of Russia, Germany, Japan, Britain, Canada, France and Italy promised to coordinate efforts to combat industrial espionage, money-laundering, child pornography and other wrongdoing in cyberspace. They also agreed to develop new crime-fighting technologies like video links to obtain and share testimony from witnesses. 
 The ministers offered few details about tactics or budgets. But the fact that the first meeting ever held among the senior law-enforcement officials of the eight countries was devoted to computer crime underscored the growing concerns that world leaders share about security in cyberspace.
"We're using 19th-century tools to face a 21st-century problem," said Jack Straw, the British Home Secretary, after the two days of talks. "One person can stay in the same place and commit crimes in several countries without leaving his armchair."
Ms. Reno said, "Somebody can sit in his room in Washington, D.C., and steal from a bank in another country, or attack a computer of some private industry and disrupt the data available to that company, data that may be critical to that company."
She gave particular emphasis to the agreement to step up prosecutions of criminals who cross borders. "Too often, a criminal will flee a country and return to his or her own homeland, hoping to escape justice," she said.
The Justice Department estimates that thieves with sophisticated computer skills steal $10 billion a year from financial institutions in the United States, and American companies are believed to suffer even greater losses from foreign economic sabotage.
British law-enforcement authorities say the dimensions of the problem relative to the size of their country's economy may be even greater.
The Colombian and Mexican drug cartels that control most cocaine trafficking in the United States are using the World Wide Web to launder money in increasing amounts, law-enforcement officials say.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Enters A Sanitarium, The Victim Of a Virus

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 10

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin has a respiratory infection and will stay at a sanitarium for 10 to 12 days, the Kremlin said today.
Russian officials, painting a picture of business as usual, said Mr. Yeltsin was not bedridden and was doing paperwork at the Barvikha sanitarium outside Moscow. 
 "An acute respiratory viral infection has developed out of a cold," Sergei Yastrzhembsky, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, said at a briefing today. "The doctors do not exclude influenza developing and have recommended a stay in a sanitarium."
Clinton Administration officials said they knew of no reason for alarm.
Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the American heart surgeon who came to Moscow last year to advise on Mr. Yeltsin's coronary problems, said in an interview that he had not been consulted this time.
He said that if Mr. Yeltsin had a serious heart problem, he would probably have been taken to the hospital where he was operated on last year and not to the sanitarium.
But it was difficult to ascertain the condition of Mr. Yeltsin, who is 66, because the Kremlin has a record of hiding the severity of the President's medical problems.
The surprise announcement did little to help the health of the Russian economy, which is already buffeted by the global currency crisis. Stock prices, which have fallen precipitously since early October, dipped again today after the reports of Mr. Yeltsin's illness.
Investors seemed nervous not only because of the reports of the President's illness, but also because his autocratic style magnifies the problem of an infirm leader.
He has established competing factions within his own Government and assumed the role of the supreme arbiter, and when he has been ill in the past, major decisions have been left untaken and Russia has tended to drift.
The lack of a clear successor is another concern.
If Mr. Yeltsin were to die in office, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin would take charge for three months while elections were organized. There is a plethora of potential candidates, and the pro-Yeltsin camp has not been able to agree on a successor.
Until this setback, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be having a good year. His health reached a low point in 1996 when he was found to have coronary artery disease, and in November 1996 he underwent heart surgery in which Russian doctors placed five bypasses to remedy blockages in the arteries supplying oxygen to his heart.
Mr. Yeltsin then caught pneumonia and did not return to a full work schedule until February of this year.
Since his recovery, however, he has appeared to be vigorous and fit -- at least until last week. On his recent trip to Stockholm, Mr. Yeltsin appeared drawn and made several gaffes, implying, for example, that Germany and Japan had nuclear arsenals.
Mr. Yastrzhembsky said Mr. Yeltsin caught a cold on that trip and still had a slight temperature.
Mr. Yeltsin was last seen in public on Tuesday at an awards cermony at the Kremlin. In a display of his authority, he strode before an audience and somberly announced that he could not hand out the honors at a time when victims of a plane crash in Irkutsk, Siberia, on Saturday were being buried.
Earlier today the Kremlin insisted that Mr. Yeltsin was firmly at the helm and was overseeing the Government's handling of an abortive hijacking of a passenger plane. Then came the announcement that he had fallen ill.
Because of Mr. Yeltsin's illness, the Kremlin has postponed a meeting with political and trade union leaders on land reform planned for Thursday.
Nor will Mr. Yeltsin lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier on Friday, Constitution Day.
Those events may have forced the Kremlin's disclosure today: it would have been difficult for Mr. Yeltsin to cancel those appearances without causing alarm.
But Mr. Yeltsin plans to make his weekly radio address to the nation on Friday, his aides said.
