HEADLINE: Albright, in Uganda, Steps Up Attack on Sudan's War of Terror

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: GULU, Uganda, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Madeleine K. Albright cradled an orphaned infant in her arms today and for a moment she lost the demeanor of the Secretary of State on official business and became motherly.
"It will be all right now," she soothed the month-old girl, Charity, whose mother was killed in an attack by Sudanese-backed rebels two weeks ago. Then Ms. Albright turned to an aid worker. "It will be all right," she said. "Won't it?" 
 On the second day of a seven-nation tour through Africa, Ms. Albright came to northern Uganda to focus attention on the victims of a brutal campaign by the Lord's Resistance Army, a bizarre Christian rebel group that receives arms and aid from the fundamentalist Islamic Government in the Sudan.
She also used her visit to Uganda to step up America's verbal assault on the Sudanese Government, blaming it for the carnage in northern Uganda in recent years. Several times during the day, she vowed that the United States would continue its campaign to isolate the Sudan.
Since 1993, the State Department has accused the Sudan of exporting terror. Last month the United States imposed new economic sanctions on the country, barring American businesses from investing there. The United States has also provided about $20 million in military aid other than weapons to Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda, all of which in turn supply the rebels with arms.
Hours before touring a hospital and a center for traumatized children here, Ms. Albright met in Kampala, the capital of Uganda, for the first time with six leaders of the main Sudanese rebel alliance.
The meeting marked the highest level of contact so far between the United States and the Sudan's rebels, led by John Garang, the head of the Sudan People's Liberation Army. It appeared intended to send a message to the Sudan's Islamic Government that America supports the rebels efforts to establish democracy.
For more than a decade, Uganda and the Sudan have sponsored rebel movements inside each other's territories. Under President Yoweri K. Museveni, Uganda has provided arms and safe haven to Mr. Garang's troops, who are fighting for more autonomy and religious freedom for the mostly Christian south. In response, the Sudan has sponsored the Lord's Resistance Army in northern Uganda and two Islamic rebel movements in the west of the country.
In northern Uganda, the Lord's Resistance Army initially grew from an secessionist movement by the Acholi tribe in the mid-1980's that opposed the military takeover by President Museveni, who comes from a southern ethnic group.
In recent years, however, under the leadership of Joseph Kony, the rebel army has become a cult-like organization that says it wants to overthrow Mr. Museveni and establish a government based on the Ten Commandments.
Those who have escaped Mr. Kony's army say boys the rebels abduct are forced to become porters and soldiers, while the young girls are repeatedly raped and given as concubines to officers.
It was the victims of this conflict whom Ms. Albright visited today at the Gulu Children of War Center, a rehabilitation camp run by the Christian relief organization, World Vision.
"You are the future of Africa," she told about 200 children at the center. "You are God's gift to the world and we will do what we can to help you."

HEADLINE: Serbs Pull Out of Talks on Bosnia to Protest Warning on Kosovo

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Dec. 10

 BODY:
An international meeting intended to promote peace in Bosnia ended here today with a walkout by Yugoslav and Bosnian Serb delegates and a renewed threat of firmer action, including economic sanctions, to press Bosnia's hostile ethnic factions into unity.
The Yugoslav and Bosnian Serb delegates abandoned the two-day gathering of the Peace Implementation Council, set up after the 1995 Dayton peace accord, to protest a reference in its final communique to "increasing ethnic tensions" in Kosovo. That is a region of the truncated Yugoslavia ruled by Belgrade to the resentment of a restive ethnic Albanian majority. 
 The Yugoslav and Bosnian Serb delegates said the Bosnia conference had no mandate to discuss the situation in Kosovo. Dragomir Vucicevic, the director of the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry, called the reference to Kosovo interference in his country's internal affairs.
The walkout came shortly before the end of the annual conference, which grouped 51 countries, including the United States and Russia, and 21 international agencies.
Russia, the United States and Germany had all supported the idea of using the conference to issue a warning about Kosovo, which many outsiders see as a tinderbox of ethnic passions that can only be made more flammable by heavy-handedness from Belgrade.
Without specifically mentioning the Yugoslav authorities, the communique urged "those concerned" to "refrain from activities that might exacerbate existing difficulties."
Momcilo Krajisnik, who led the Bosnian Serb delegation out of the conference in support of the Yugoslav delegation, said the reference to Kosovo was an attempt to "try to sneak the Kosovo issue through the back door."
Mr. Krajisnik, the Bosnian Serb representative in Bosnia's collective presidency, is seen as a hard-liner. Biljana Plavsic, the Bosnian Serb president, also left the conference.
The protest overshadowed decisions to set deadlines for a series of supposedly unifying moves, like common auto license plates throughout Bosnia, and to empower the conference's top official in Bosnia to impose nation-building measures on the country's divided Serbs, Muslims and Croats if they cannot agree among themselves.
"If they do not do their job, we have to do it in their place," said the top official, Carlos Westendorp, a former Spanish diplomat who has the title of High Representative in Bosnia.
Bob Gelbard, a special United States representative, said: "The message to the parties from Bonn is unequivocal: get on with it. Stop these unacceptable delaying tactics."
Since the American-brokered Dayton peace accord, Bosnia's ethnic groups have shown no readiness to regard themselves as part of the same country. There is no national currency, no common passport and no common flag. Bosnian Serbs have different license plates from Bosnian Muslims, and the country is split on ethnic lines.
The gathering backed its new powers for Mr. Westendorp with the threat that factions standing in the way of peace would forfeit crucial economic aid. His new powers include the ability to dismiss Bosnian politicians who do not attend meetings to promote peace and unity.
"Those who help us reach our goals will receive help," said Klaus Kinkel, the German Foreign Minister. "Those who refuse exclude themselves."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities, particularly shorter maturities, moved higher for the second consecutive day yesterday on a flight to quality by investors concerned over Asian market turmoil and Federal Reserve activity in the market.
Traders noted that in times of uncertainty investors often sought the safety of the Government securities market, particularly the bill sector. Even year-end buying cannot be ruled out as managers add Treasury securities to their portfolios. 
 The Fed was in the market for a second day buying securities and adding cash to the banking system. The process is called a coupon pass, and the central bank announces that it is buying various securities and maturities. Yesterday it bought close to $3 billion in securities with coupons dated to mature from Dec. 31, 1999, to Nov. 30, 2002.
The 30-year bond gained 21/32, to a price of 100 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.07 percent, from 6.11 percent on Tuesday, the lowest since 6.05 percent last Thursday.
Market participants are avoiding aggressive moves, while they wait for more economic data this week and hope it will show that economic growth is not threatening to accelerate inflation and cause interest rates to rise.
Today retail sales data will be reported for November. Some economists expect a four-tenths of 1 percent increase over all, but a more modest one-tenth of 1 percent gain is expected if autos are excluded.
Tomorrow November's Producer Price Index should prove more favorable, according to analysts. They expect the prices paid by factories, farmers and other producers to be up only one-tenth of 1 percent, both in the overall number and when the more volatile energy and food components are excluded.
Regardless, the talk is that the Fed will not change rates at next Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: "The debate at the upcoming F.O.M.C. will center on the outlook for 1998. Prior to the Southeast Asian currency crisis and the global stock market turmoil, a case could have been made that a policy adjustment was a prudent action, given the rapid pace of growth during 1997. At this juncture, all policy makers will agree that the best policy action will be to leave the status quo."
Ken Logan, a managing analyst with Technical Data of Boston, said, "Once again overseas concerns have captivated the attention of U.S. Treasury traders," particularly the disclosures that Korea's financial problems are much worse than first thought.
Mr. Logan predicts this flight to quality buying will continue as the disarray in Asia is sorted out. This, he added, along with year-end balance sheet constraints, is likely to support the market for the balance of the week.
Despite the Asian problems, as of late yesterday the Korea Development Bank still planned to sell a $2 billion issue, either today or tomorrow.

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Sees Earnings Hurt Abroad

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Another shock wave caused by economic turmoil in Asia reached Wall Street yesterday as J. P. Morgan & Company said earnings in October and November were hurt by "unsettled market conditions" abroad.
Morgan declined to quantify the damage, only saying the downturn resulted from decreased client activity and lower trading revenue. Traders and analysts said the bank was not stuck with a huge emerging-market trading setback of the sort that recently caused the Chase Manhattan Corporation to disclose a $160 million trading loss primarily related to its Brazilian operations. 
 In fact, analysts and traders said Morgan's trading and client problems were centered in Asia, Europe, and the United States and revolved around the bank's equity derivatives and fixed-income businesses. Morgan enjoys close financial relationships with some of the world's biggest corporations and governments, and its announcement that client activity had slowed reflected the queasiness many are feeling about economic uncertainty here and abroad.
The result of Morgan's announcement was a 4 percent drop in its stock, which helped pull down other bank stocks and contributed to a downturn in the broader market, echoing what happened earlier this week on news that earnings of companies ranging from Coca-Cola to Oracle were hurting because of Asia's economic travails.
One example of the kind of problem facing Morgan can be found in South Korea. The Korea Development Bank, South Korea's largest Government-owned bank, has encountered a lack of investor interest in a $2 billion bond offering by the bank because of the country's severe financial troubles. If that bank is forced to postpone the offering it would hurt Morgan, which is managing the sale.
There had been speculation recently among bankers that Morgan might be exposed to heavy losses on a $600 million loan related to a large investment by Enersis S.A., a Chilean utility that is the largest privately owned electricity company in Latin America, in another Chilean utility, Endesa S.A. Banking sources said this was not a factor in Morgan's announcement and that losses from the loan, while significant, were not expected to be material. Morgan and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation are by far the most active trading houses among America's big banks, and the performance of both can be a barometer of market sentiment overseas. Bankers Trust declined to comment on its trading business.
Trading-related assets make up about 72 percent of Morgan's balance sheet, which gives the company a profile more like an investment bank than a commercial bank. It also means the bank's results can be more volatile than those of its more staid peers.
"This seems to happen every now and then at J. P. Morgan and it's in the nature of their business -- it's not a breakdown in risk management," said David Berry, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. "We've yet to hear from Bankers Trust, but I expect to see a weak fourth quarter there."
Trading accounted for 40 percent of Morgan's revenue and 30 percent of Bankers Trust's revenue during the first nine months of this year. In comparison, trading accounted for 15 percent of Chase's revenue, 10 percent of Citicorp's, and 8 percent of the BankAmerica Corporation's over the same period. Chase and Citicorp declined to comment on whether they were seeing a softening in client activity or their own trading revenue.
But at a conference in New York on Tuesday, Chase's chairman and chief executive, Walter V. Shipley, told analysts that the bank's trading revenues stabilized in November after a disastrous October. In an interview yesterday, a BankAmerica spokesman said the bank's trading operation was profitable in October and November, but below what it had earned in previous months.
Big bank stocks swooned yesterday. Morgan's shares plummeted $5, to $117.875; Bankers Trust dropped $1.625, to $127.5625; Chase fell $3.625, to $112.25; Citicorp fell $5.875, to $132, and BankAmerica fell $2.3125 to $78.50, all in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts had been expecting Morgan to earn $1.97 in the fourth quarter according to consensus estimates gathered by First Call, which analyzes Wall Street earnings predictions. But Morgan's unpredictable trading operation caused the range of fourth-quarter estimates to run from $1.70 to $2.16. Analysts are expected to significantly reduce fourth-quarter earnings estimates in light of Morgan's announcement.
While Morgan's problems are in the fixed-income and equity derivatives businesses, fixed-income is a more important part of its business. In the third quarter, Morgan had $416 million in fixed-income revenue and only $51 million in revenue from equity derivatives.
Morgan displayed confidence in its prospects yesterday, despite the market's doubts. The company said that it would increase its quarterly dividend to 95 cents a share from 88 cents, and that its board had approved the buyback of as many as seven million shares of its stock.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Martinez's $75 Million For 6 Years Raises Bar

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Greg Maddux's run as the player with the highest salary in baseball history ended yesterday after only four months. The new No. 1 is Pedro Martinez, who won the National League Cy Young award a month ago, then was traded by Montreal a week later, another player whose pay level was getting too rich for the Expos.
Martinez reached agreement with the Boston Red Sox yesterday on a six-year contract for $75 million. The average annual value of $12.5 million exceeds by $1 million the average of the five-year contract Maddux agreed to with the Atlanta Braves last Aug. 10. 
 The total value of the Martinez contract falls just short of the highest total of $80,662,000, which Frank Thomas agreed to for nine years with the Chicago White Sox. But as astronomical as the Martinez figures are generally, perhaps most remarkable is the salary he will have in 2004 if the Red Sox exercise their option for a seventh season.
It will be $17.5 million.
"And the guy doesn't even have a good jump shot," one baseball lawyer said, alluding to the similarity between Martinez's contract and those that have proliferated in the National Basketball Association.
However it is measured, it is a stunning deal for Martinez, a 26-year-old right-handed pitcher from the Dominican Republic, and it comes at a time of bizarre economics for baseball. On one hand, clubs are paying inflated salaries for free agents, like $35 million over five years for Wilson Alvarez by the expansion Tampa Bay Devil Rays; on the other, the Florida Marlins are dismantling their World Series championship team because they want to halve their payroll.
Martinez was not a free agent, but he could have been one after next season, and the Red Sox gambled when they traded a highly prized minor league pitcher for him. But the Red Sox were also intent on retaining Martinez as a way of signaling to their players and fans that they are serious about winning.
The Red Sox did not acknowledge that the deal was done. Kevin Shea, the club's communications director, quoted General Manager Dan Duquette as saying he was still working on the deal and "hopes it will be finalized in due time." Duquette had been scheduled to travel to the Dominican Republic yesterday, but Shea said he changed plans and did not go. "But I don't know where he is," Shea said.
Jim Bronner, who with Bob Gilhooley represents the pitcher, declined to comment on the contract.
News of the deal initially came from Martinez himself. He revealed it in the Dominican, telling Radio Universal in an interview, "I'm a little ashamed to say how much I signed for."
Martinez, who earned $3,615,000 this year, said the contract included two option years, but the lawyer who knew about it said it had only one option year that called for a $17.5 million salary or a $2.5 million buyout, which is part of the $75 million guaranteed. If the Red Sox pick up the option, the deal will become a seven-year contract for $90 million.
Martinez is one of three brothers who pitch professionally. His older brother, Ramon, plays for the Los Angeles Dodgers, and his younger brother, Jesus, was selected by the Arizona Diamondbacks in the expansion draft, then traded to the Marlins for center fielder Devon White.
"I thank God that I was chosen to show the people that with effort, they can do anything," Martinez said in the Dominican interview. "I come from a world of much poverty."
When Maddux signed his five-year, $57.5 million contract, he had won four Cy Young awards as the best pitcher in the National League in 1992, 1993, 1994 and 1995. Martinez won his first Cy Young award last month after a season in which he compiled a seemingly modest 17-8 record but led the league with a 1.90 earned run average, 13 complete games, an opponents' .184 batting average, 8.73 base runners per nine innings and 11.4 strikeouts per nine innings (305 total).
The difference between Martinez's earned run average and the e.r.a. for the rest of the league last season was 2.33, the fourth biggest differential since World War II.

HEADLINE: Swiss Bank Says Big Merger Won't Affect Stamford Office

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
When United Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation announced a merger on Monday, forming the world's second-largest bank, the news shook not only Wall Street, but also Stamford, Conn., where the corporation recently opened a $200 million main office for North American operations.
Mayor Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat, said he received several faxes from Swiss Bank the day the merger was announced, stating that the deal "was not envisioned to mean any significant changes for Stamford." 
 He also said that the merger, along with Swiss Bank's recent expansion -- it recently absorbed Dillon, Read, a Wall Street investment bank -- may mean that the bank may exercise its option to build another one million square feet of office space at the 563,000-square-foot complex.
"We see upside potential," Mr. Malloy said, sounding more like a stockbroker than a politician.
That bullishness is echoed, cautiously, by bank officials. Matthias Beckmann, a senior press officer, said no decision had been made on the location of the principal office for North American operations for the newly merged bank, which will have its worldwide headquarters in Zurich and, perhaps, Basel. But the logical place for its principal North American office -- the bank does not call it a headquarters -- would be in Stamford, in southwestern Connecticut, an hour from mid-Manhattan, he said.
"Clearly, we want to grow in the United States, and Stamford is the place to grow," Mr. Beckmann said, adding that the bank has built a new high-technology trading floor, the size of a football field, on top of a parking garage next to the 13-story structure, which sits next to the Stamford train station.
Though it seems unlikely, any moves by the bank to reduce its staff in Stamford, or, worse, abandon plans to move its main operations there would represent a severe blow to the city's economy and prestige. The Swiss bank's plans for the city have already sparked a mini-boomlet in the real estate market in the area, as bankers and traders hunt for housing en masse.
When bank officials announced that they were moving from New York City to Connecticut in 1994, it was a coup for Connecticut, but it also ignited controversy, since the state had lured the bank by granting huge tax credits -- $120 million over 10 years, $60,000 for each worker -- tied to how many people it employed in Stamford. Already, though, the bank, which opened last month, has met its obligation to garner the maximum amount of tax credits. It has moved 1,800 employees to the new location and another 400 are expected to move in over the weekend.
Under the agreement with the state, if the bank employs 2,000 people, it will receive a 50 percent credit. The bank could even receive another 25 percent tax break after 10 years if employment levels rise to 3,000.
Still, Swiss Bank and United Bank employ almost 6,000 people in the United States. And the combined bank, second in the world only to the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, has said that it intends to cut its global work force by about 25 percent over several years, as many as 13,000 people, to 43,000. Those cuts are expected to include 7,000 jobs in Switzerland and 6,000 elsewhere in the world. Analysts have speculated that more than 2,000 jobs in New York City and Stamford might be eliminated as the companies consolidate.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop a 3d Day as Dow Falls 70.87

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market was rattled for a third consecutive session yesterday after investors got fresh reminders that the turmoil in Asia could dampen corporate profits.
Technology shares continued to plummet after the Oracle Corporation's huge slide on Tuesday, a day after the company reported disappointing earnings. And yesterday, shares of J. P. Morgan, one of the nation's largest banks, fell 5 points, to 117 7/8, after the company said that it expected its earnings to be hurt by the crisis in Asia. 
 "There's this worry that the financial problems in Asia are going to extend further," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "And until investors become comfortable that the Asian situation is not explosive, the market will have trouble."
Those festering concerns helped drag all the major stock indexes lower yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average -- which fell as much as 126 points late in the day -- closed down 70.87 points, to 7,978.79. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 5.99, to 969.79.
But technology shares took the brunt of the selling. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 23.94, to 1,596.61, and the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index dropped 6.70, to 295.52.
Among the worst hit were I.B.M., which fell 3 7/8, to 106 1/2; Cisco, down 2 1/16, to 85 3/8, and Microsoft, which lost 2 1/16, to 142 1/4.
Oracle, which fell 9 7/16 Tuesday, rose 1/2, to 23 7/16.
Wall Street analysts contend that investors are once again punishing an entire sector for the sins of a few companies.
"They're extrapolating that this is endemic to the whole sector," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore. "Then the financial numbers come out and they're pretty good. That's the pattern."
But even Mr. Cripps concedes that the technology sector may be more liable to suffer from weakening demand for computer parts in Asia. Yesterday, for instance, one analyst lowered his estimate for the computer maker Compaq and shares fell 3 3/8, to 60.
Despite yesterday's setbacks, though, stock market indexes are up near record levels, and the possibility of merger and acquisition activity continues to drive certain issues.
For instance, shares of Hambrecht & Quist -- the investment bank that specializes in technology stocks -- fell 3 13/16, to 38 3/4, after reports that the firm is no longer in talks to be acquired by Merrill Lynch.
Meanwhile, shares of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette soared about 5 percent, or 4 1/8, to 87 5/8, on heavy volume after reports that Chase Manhattan Bank might acquire the brokerage firm.
In the broader market, however, the selloff of the last three days might be simply a sign that investors are pausing after a huge surge in buying in the last six weeks.
After slipping as low as 7,161.15 on Oct. 27, the Dow soared nearly 14 percent before tumbling this week. Some analysts call this an "overbought" market, a period when investors accumulate stocks so rapidly that there is bound to be a brief selloff, or a temporary lull in buying.
"The market had a pretty good run from the October lows to the recent highs," said Richard McCabe, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The market had gotten a little overbought, so the least bit of worrisome news was seized upon."
Indeed, many analysts believe that the market setback is temporary, and that the economy and prospects for profits remain robust.
"There will be an impact, and we could see a modest adjustment in corporate growth, but not enough to derail the expanding economy or this bull market," said Mary Farrell, senior investment strategist at Paine Webber. "We're a global economy, and we can withstand some weakness in one part of the globe as long as you have strength in other parts."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Journal;
Cemetery to the Stars Wins a Court Reprieve

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the sunken gardens and weather-beaten marble mausoleums of Hollywood Memorial Park Cemetery, the ghosts of the great ones linger: Cecil B. DeMille, Tyrone Power, Rudolph Valentino, Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and even Mel Blanc, the inimitable voice of Porky Pig, whose headstone proclaims with wry finality, "That's All Folks."
But the 100-year-old cemetery in the heart of old Hollywood, so close to the backlot of Paramount Studios that the brownstone facades of its "New York street" peep over the rear wall, fell into bankruptcy nearly two years ago, a casualty of aging and inattentive owners. Buildings shaken by the 1994 Northridge earthquake went unrepaired, broken stained-glass windows went unreplaced and water seeped into crypts in the shadow of the famous Hollywood sign. 
 Things got so bad that the State of California even revoked the cemetery's license to sell its remaining plots, and no buyers wanted the headaches of fixing the place. The only bidder at a public auction last month offered just over half the $500,000 asking price of the bank that holds the mortgage, and a court-appointed trustee sought permission to padlock the gates and abandon the graves to the fates.
But today, at a hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court that could have been directed by Frank Capra (who is not buried at Hollywood Memorial), a new buyer stepped forward and a Hollywood ending seemed all but assured. Judge Thomas B. Donovan approved the sale of the cemetery for $375,000 to Callanan Mortuary, an 85-year-old local Hollywood funeral home whose owners vowed to take good care of the legacy.
"This thing has years of deferred maintenance," said Thomas McDonald, who works in the business run by his wife, Eileen Callanan, who inherited it from her father. "We're very pleased at all the community support."
Indeed, local officials including City Councilwoman Jackie Goldberg, had rallied in recent weeks to try to stave off the worst, trying to get help from nonprofit groups or the Hollywood studios whose former titans are buried in the cemetery, along with Hollywood's favorite mobster, Ben (Bugsy) Siegel. There was talk, but no action.
"There has been some openness to trying to step in and help out," said Roxana Tynan, the Councilwoman's deputy for economic development, "but it really required that every other option be exhausted."
The new owners still have their work cut out for them, and the sale is contingent on a satisfactory inspection of the cemetery's books, buildings and soil, where fuel tanks from an unused crematorium must be removed.
Some state historic preservation money may be available to restore vintage buildings, and a $2.5 million maintenance endowment generates more than $150,000 a year in income that can be used on upkeep, but that is barely enough to get by.
The reflecting pool in front of Fairbanks's tomb, where the silent-screen swashbuckler's profile appears in bronze bas-relief, is muddy and stagnant and waterlilies struggle to grow. A couple of stands of bedraggled begonias surround the white marble bench that doubles as Tyrone Power's headstone, engraved, like Fairbanks's, with the "Good night, sweet prince" soliloquy from "Hamlet."
Yet unlike the other great Hollywood celebrities' cemetery, Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, where the Great Mausoleum is guarded and off-limits to the merely curious, Hollywood Memorial is open daily, and tourists armed with a free map available at the gate can trace the footsteps of the mysterious "Lady in Black" who used to leave a single flower in the bronze vase beside Valentino's crypt, No. 1205 in the grand Cathedral Mausoleum by the lake. Across the hall, a bronze plaque marks the crypt of Peter Finch, "distinguished actor, loving husband and father."
"Nine million tourists come to Hollywood each year because they want to experience the place where movie stars lived and worked and played and died," said Leron Gubler, the executive director of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce. "This is the real thing, this is our heritage, this is history."
But state law prohibits charging admission at cemeteries, so it is difficult to make money by exploiting this particular kind of history, though Mr. Gubler and others said the new owners could probably charge for maps, or for memorabilia or some kind of interpretative program for visitors.
In the short term, the sale is some comfort to family members of those buried in the cemetery, where in recent years scores of Russian and Armenian emigres and gay men killed by AIDS have joined stars like Janet Gaynor, who won the first Academy Award for best actress, in 1927. At the hearing today, Judge Donovan stretched protocol to let several family members speak town-meeting style, including Louise Haines, 80, who buried her husband of 60 years, Bernard, at Hollywood Memorial when he died at 87 in October.
Mrs. Haines said she went to her husband's crypt in a rainstorm last weekend, only to see water pouring in from a leaky roof "like a waterfall."
"What a terrible thing to have to see," she said.

HEADLINE: Dominican Sex Scandal Mars Big League Dreams

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO DE MACORIS, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
Over the past 25 years, this sugar mill town of 85,000 people has been one of the most prolific producers of major league baseball players in the world. Although a billboard at the edge of town boasts this is "the cradle of shortstops," all-star outfielders and pitchers have also been manufactured here -- some 100 players in all.
But now scandal threatens to disrupt that pipeline to the big leagues. 
 In a case that has provoked anger throughout this impoverished, baseball-crazed Caribbean nation of eight million people, Luis Rosa, who has scouted in Latin America for the San Francisco Giants and other teams, has been imprisoned on charges he demanded sex from 15 young minor league players here as a condition for playing time. (No major leaguers have made any accusations.) Mr. Rosa has also been charged with embezzling part of the players' signing bonuses and salaries.
"Like most players here, all of us come from poor, humble families, and dream of getting to the big leagues, or at least the United States, so that our parents and siblings can have a better life," said Yan Carlos Ravelo, a 20-year-old right-handed pitcher who filed the initial criminal complaint in June. "Luis Rosa took advantage of our poverty and our desperation for an American visa to make us his slaves."
In a country where the code of machismo prevails and homosexuality is still regarded with revulsion, the players' accounts of sexual abuse and harassment have prompted demands that Juan Marichal, the Hall of Fame pitcher and former Giants star who is now the Government's Secretary of Sports and Recreation, impose more control and supervision over players' signing and training.
That the Giants, of all teams, find themselves at the center of the case has added to the sense of betrayal. (Mr. Rosa has also scouted for the Seattle Mariners, the San Diego Padres, the Chicago Cubs and the Texas Rangers.)
"This is a team with a long and respected tradition in our country," Juan Ortiz, the Dominican Republic's commissioner of baseball, said in an interview. "This is not some new expansion team. This is the team that signed Ozzie Virgil, the first Dominican to play in the big leagues, and took the three Alou brothers and Juan Marichal to the major leagues."
The Alou brothers, Felipe, Matty and Jesus, were star outfielders in the 1960's and 1970's. Felipe Alou is now manager of the Montreal Expos and his son Moises played a leading role in the 1997 World Series.
In the quiet world of baseball scouts, Luis Rosa was just as much a star. In a career that has spanned two decades, he has signed so many of baseball's best Latin American players, among them Roberto and Sandy Alomar, Juan Gonzalez, Ivan Rodriguez, Benito Santiago, Wilson Alvarez and Ozzie Guillen, that, he boasts, "if you put them all together, they would make one hell of an all-star team."
Interviewed in the jail cell here where he has been held since late October, Mr. Rosa, 51, denied any wrongdoing and said he was being made "a scapegoat" both by the Giants and his former players. He attributed their accusations to a desire for revenge, set off by inadequate performances on the diamond.
"They just didn't cut it, and I had to let them go," said Mr. Rosa, an American citizen who came here voluntarily from Puerto Rico to defend himself. "Now they have been recruited by a group of unscrupulous lawyers to defame my name and destroy my career in what is nothing more than an extortion plot."
Two of the original 15 complainants, Gabriel MacDonald and Miguel Mota, have retracted their accusations. Sitting at Mr. Rosa's side, Mr. MacDonald, a 20-year-old center fielder, described himself as so poor and confused after his release, the death of his mother and the birth of a son that he invented the story in hopes of making some money.
But in a sworn statement to Dominican prosecutors, the former major league star Joaquin Andujar, a San Pedro de Macoris native who was pitching coach for the Giants development team Mr. Rosa managed during the 1996 season, contradicted that version of events.
"One of them told me he couldn't get to pitch because Luis Rosa had said that unless they went to bed together he wouldn't be allowed to take the mound," Mr. Andujar testified under oath.
Mr. MacDonald, he said, "told me that Luis Rosa had said that unless he went to bed with him, not only would he never get to play, he would not be allowed to travel to the United States."
No trial date has yet been set for Mr. Rosa. Each count of sexual harassment carries a maximum prison term of two years and each charge of embezzlement can result in a 10-year sentence.
Like many other major league organizations, the Giants maintain a farm team and training complex here. Players are scouted as early as 12, signed to contracts at 16, given three years to polish their skills and then, if deemed promising, granted a visa to play in the United States.
For the players who do not make the cut, the alternatives are few. The Giants' complex here adjoins a sugar mill called El Porvenir, or The Future, serving as a constant reminder that if they fail to make it to the big leagues, their destiny is a lifetime of menial labor.
On a visit here in late October, Jack Bair, the Giants' general counsel, issued a statement saying the team had begun its own internal investigation into the players' accusations. In a telephone interview from San Francisco, he declined to discuss that inquiry's findings, saying it would be "inappropriate to comment while judicial authorities in the Dominican Republic are processing the allegations."
Belkys Nataniel, a lawyer for several players, said she planned to file civil suits against the team both here and in the United States, since "the Giants are responsible for the conduct of their employees, and Luis Rosa was not just an ordinary employee, he was the boss." Mr. Bair, however, argued that since "Mr. Rosa and the players are in the Dominican Republic and a case has already been filed there, in our view that appears to be the appropriate venue."
Law enforcement and baseball officials here said they could recall no other instance in which a manager was accused of sexually molesting his players. But they described financial abuses, like overstating the bonus prospects are paid and pocketing the difference, as widespread.
"The majority of the scouts have their hands in the cookie jar, and I can't blame them, since most teams are trying to do things on the cheap," said Mr. Virgil, who succeeded Mr. Rosa as manager of the Giants' farm team here. "The organizations should get wise and hire good people and treat them right, so scouts don't think they have to steal equipment and sell visas to make money."
A lot of scouts here, Mr. Virgil added, no longer even bother to go out to the sugar mill settlements that have traditionally been the richest source of players. Instead, they rely on so-called buscones, freelance "searchers" who scour the bushes for prospects, sign them to personal service contracts and then auction them off to the highest bidder, taking a percentage of the player's small signing bonus as payment.
Mr. Marichal did not respond to repeated phone calls seeking an interview, but Mr. Ortiz, the Dominican baseball commissioner, said that as a result of the Rosa case he is once again pressing major league baseball to require all contracts signed in the Dominican Republic to be registered with his office. That would cut down on financial chicanery, he said.
Yet even as irregularities are investigated and the court case drags on, the hunger to reach the big leagues continues unabated. On a scorching Saturday afternoon this fall, dozens of young boys, part of the 20-team youth league that Rafael Mercedes Castro has run here since 1976, were enthusiastically practicing their fielding and hitting. Boys begin playing at 5, and by their teens the best of them are being monitored by local scouts for major league teams.
But the hunt is driven by more than the ample size of the talent pool here. Unlike American players, Dominicans are not subject to the baseball draft, which means any team that finds a promising player can sign him to a contract, usually at a bargain price.
"When the Orioles signed me in 1989, I got a $3,000 bonus," said Manny Alexander, the former Mets shortstop who was traded to the Cubs late in the 1997 season. "If I had been born in the United States, I would have been a first- or second-round draft choice, and they would have had to pay me $200,000."
Prospects here accept that arrangement not only because they have no choice but also because they dream of a big payoff down the line. Every family in town knows that Sammy Sosa, a native son, signed a five-year, $42 million contract with the Cubs earlier this year.
"Look at that kid over there," Mr. Sosa said, pointing to a shoeshine boy as he led a visitor on a tour of 30-30 Plaza, a shopping mall he has built here as an investment. "Fifteen years ago, that was me. I shined shoes and washed cars but I knew that baseball was the only way I was going to be able to lift my family from poverty."
Recently, even unproven players here have begun to wrest bonuses equal to those of American players. After a bidding war with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and the Baltimore Orioles, the Toronto Blue Jays this year signed a 16-year-old shortstop named Josean Bernhardt for $1.1 million.
As a result, "now even middle-class parents who used to urge their sons to become lawyers or architects are coming to me," Mr. Mercedes said. "Everyone knows that nothing in this country changes your economic situation as quickly as baseball."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1831 words

HEADLINE: Last Laugh for the Philippines;
Onetime Joke Economy Avoids Much of Asia's Turmoil

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
Christmas roars into the Philippines with sacks of red ribbons and plastic fir trees festooned in frosted and sequined glass bulbs. Streets are lathered in glowing stars, six-foot candles and light displays of Santa's sleigh dashing through the tropical humidity.
Determined not to be left out, the central bank on Roxas Boulevard has draped its office block in a lighted display of its own: four mammoth line charts tracking the country's inflation, foreign exchange reserves, economic growth and the rate on 91-day Treasury bills. 
 Merry Christmas.
Indeed, in the Philippines, long regarded as a comedic, boisterously democratic laggard, the turmoil afflicting other Asian economies has left many people feeling a bit merrier than usual at this time of year. The thunder of collapsing banks and the cracking of economic hubris elsewhere are even making Filipinos a bit smug.
The Philippines has been hit by a fall in its own currency and stock market in recent months, yet it has not experienced the more damaging banking and real estate chaos that has afflicted other countries in East Asia.
Unlike Bangkok and Jakarta, where cranes stand frozen over dozens of abandoned building sites, Manila is a hive of construction; with occupancy rates in the business districts at 98 to 99 percent, the thirst for new buildings remains strong. And while Bangkok's projected light-rail line is just a procession of silent concrete pillars, workers swarm over the site of Manila's new overhead light-rail line, work that has turned one of the city's main arteries, Edsa Boulevard, into a monumental traffic jam.
The Philippines has proved the exception mainly because it has not tried to leap ahead as suddenly as its neighbors, taking a conservative tack at least partly mandated by the International Monetary Fund.
"There's a bit of truth to the case of the turtle and the hare," laughed Washington SyCip, the 75-year-old founder of SGV Group, the country's largest insurance conglomerate, and widely regarded as the dean of the country's financial sector. By moving slowly, he said, the nation did not "make all the mistakes of our neighbors."
Foreign investors, rather than shying away in alarm, as they have elsewhere in the region, are still coming in. Acer, Taiwan's largest computer maker, is building a huge manufacturing center at Subic Bay. Intel, already the country's largest exporter, is expanding its production. And Seagate, an American maker of hard-disk drives, is planning to open a plant here.
Indeed, while countries across Asia, from Thailand to Indonesia to South Korea, are begging the I.M.F. to rescue them, the Philippines is toying with the notion of leaving I.M.F. supervision this month after 34 years, having successfully met the fund's targets for economic stability.
"We learned our lessons much earlier, and the past five years have been a time of resolute and pervasive correction and reform," President Fidel Ramos said during a visit to the United States last month. "In the Philippines, we have felt the lash of the turmoil, although we have not been guilty of the mistakes" made by other Asian countries.
"The Philippines," Mr. Ramos argued, "has passed third base and is heading for home plate, meaning an exit from our I.M.F. program."
In a sense, it hardly matters whether Manila leaves fund supervision; the mere discussion of such a step sets the country apart from its neighbors and provides evidence of an economy distinctly better off than the savaged economies nearby.
 Indeed, the Philippine central bank announced on Wednesday that its economy is stable enough to allow it to cut its key overnight borrowing rate to 11 percent, the lowest level since the currency turmoil began sweeping through the region in July.
In some ways. to be sure, the Philippines has mimicked the problems that have sparked the Asian crisis. The peso has plunged nearly 30 percent in value, and the Manila stock market, perhaps because many outsiders fail to distinguish it from its neighbors, has tumbled about 35 percent since July.
But the Philippines has resisted the impulse to erect the world's tallest building, to make a "national" car (while imposing high tariffs on competitors), to build a "national" airplane or to create a new capital. In short, it has eschewed the hubris that has infected many Asian tigers.
"We've gotten away from trying to devise a national car, or steel plant, or an aircraft industry," argued Victor S. Limlingan, a senior professor at the Asian Institute of Management, a leading business school. "We have liberalized the economy. There are virtually no tariff protections. What's saving us is the liberalization program. Growth has spread out."
Decades of I.M.F. supervision have, virtually all economists concur, set the country's economy firmly on rails leading to steady but unostentatious growth. In the last six years, under President Ramos, the Government has divested itself of everything from the national airline to electric power systems, banks to water supplies -- or is in the process of doing so. The Government's budget is in surplus, and sweeping reforms that would simplify the tax code while increasing revenues are on the brink of passage. And unlike Thailand, where banks are straining under a rate of bad loans over 20 percent, Philippine banks boast a rate of only 3.4 percent.
"We are more conservative fiscally," said Jose Antonio League, an official of the World Bank in Manila. "Monetary policy wasn't too bold. And the structure of the economy is not like Thailand, for example, which borrowed huge amounts externally."
Matthew S. Sutherland, head of Philippine research at Paribas Asia Equity, added: "I don't think we have the systemic problems of the rest of Asia. The property sector is not overblown; banking is not in trouble; there has not been a lot of borrowing in U.S. dollars. We don't need three years of a tighter belt and severe austerity."
After the collapse of the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos, a lot of the flagrant cronyism and corruption he nurtured died as well. And though corruption still exists, the privatization of much of the economy and an increasing openness in economic decision-making have wiped out a fair amount of the cronyism in business and government.
In part, it is from the factories of people like Victoria Reyes that the Philippines is drawing its strength. From a desire to earn enough to carpet her house, Ms. Reyes built a large textile business, Remerco Garments Manufacturing Inc., which at its height employed more than 800 people. And all her production was exported.
North and east of Manila, in Quezon City, in what used to be rice paddies and is now a warren of cement-block-walled factory compounds, Ms. Reyes and her children live and work on land that has been in the family for generations. Under a corrugated roof, with the walls open to the languid humidity of the tropics, 250 women hunch over Taiwan-made sewing machines churning out Chicago Bulls jackets, children's dresses, multicolored flannel jackets and denim children's pants.
"Indonesia, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka are our big competitors," Ms. Reyes said. "Of course China is big, too. In 1980, with China taking off, our European buyers dropped us like a sack of potatoes. But when they didn't get deliveries they came crawling back. I said no." In those days, the waning days of Marcos's martial law regime, days when the country's economy was stagnant, Ms. Reyes was one of the top 10 exporters in the Philippines.
A strike by workers in 1990 almost destroyed the business, and even Ms. Reyes acknowledged that she shared some blame. "Our pride got the better of us," she confessed. But by 1995, she was back, buoyed by the firm support of her two major American buyers and a Hong Kong garment house. Today, she said, "it's a big small operation."
The operation is more efficient than ever. "We're doing production levels we had with 600 people," she said. Still, as at all businesses in the Philippines, the falling peso and often usurious interest rates have required fast footwork. "We had about a $1 million loan in pesos," explained her son, Rufino A. Reyes Jr., the company's vice president. "Loan interest was 30 percent. It was too much for us to pay. I went to the bank and said I wanted to swap the peso loan to a dollar loan, since all our income is in dollars. So they did, and the interest rate is now 11 percent -- still high, but we can make it."
With $7 million to $8 million in sales, Remerco is relatively small next to the electronics giants -- electronics constitute about 51 percent of the total exports of the Philippines -- and competition remains fierce throughout the region. "Right now we're banking on our long-term relationship with our buyers," Mr. Reyes said. "But we have to be realistic that competition will be more."
And with companies from Remerco to Intel expanding, Philippine exports have climbed more than 25 percent in the last year. Many analysts expect foreign and domestic investment to continue to grow.
"A lot is going on in industrial zones," said Jose Mario I. Cuyegkeng, research director at ING Baring Securities. "And while we have one of the highest wages in the region, we have the higher productivity. Many people here speak English, and we have one of the cheapest middle-management salary structures anywhere."
For companies with domestic markets, things are likely to be tougher in the coming year. One tile maker, who insisted on anonymity, explained that with domestic business loan rates so high, he would have to put off his expansion plans for a while.
There are already signs that consumer spending is waning. The most recent data available indicate that sales of many larger items began to fall in July, particularly televisions, fans and washing machines.
Even so, Roberto C. Benares, who runs a small investment bank here, the Asian Alliance Investment Corporation, said that while he foresaw more mergers and acquisitions as some companies faced difficulties (there have been almost no initial public offerings on the Manila exchange since July), he remained confident that the country's fundamentals and its corporate base were sound. "If you look at the property groups, they're slowing down a bit," he said. "But they will survive. The banking sector is going to be O.K. They have been through so many troughs, they're overcautious, unlike Thai banks. Everybody is still upbeat."
Most frustrating, said Mr. SyCip of SGV, is the tendency of bankers and investors outside Asia to lump the region into one pot. "All countries in the region do have problems," he said, "but not serious enough for 50 percent declines in stock markets -- except for Thailand. Here, building is still going on. Our banking system is much more transparent. Our export figures are comfortably up, and a lot of plants are coming on line. It's a failure to distinguish one country from another."

GRAPHIC: Photo: While much of Asia is stalled, developments like this industrial park in Subic Bay are progressing in the Philippines. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Graph: "Slower but Surer"
Economists expect economic growth to slow next year all across Asia as a wave of financial crises take their toll. SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1243 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Many Proud South Koreans Resent Bailout From Abroad

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Kim Bong So stood beside his pushcart, occasionally stirring his wok, fretting that the economic crisis here is so severe that customers are unwilling to pay even for a cup of his crunchy silkworm larvae.
But Mr. Kim's main concern was not his personal difficulties making a sale. Rather, it was the International Monetary Fund's $57 billion bailout of South Korea last week. 
 "It's a national humiliation," said Mr. Kim, shaking his head morosely. He compared the rescue to Japan's seizure and occupation of Korea early in this century, and he added, "I feel so ashamed."
These days Mr. Kim has plenty of company. Many Koreans now refer to Dec. 3, the day the I.M.F. accord was reached, as a "National Humiliation Day." Some refer to the aid package as the "Second National Disgrace," after the Japanese colonization.
Of course, not everyone feels quite so humiliated or accepts the parallel with the Japanese occupation, which lasted from 1905 to 1945.
But Korea is as proud and prickly a nation as any on the globe. For an over-achiever and A-plus student like South Korea to be sent to the corner with what feels like a dunce cap is a torture more psychological than economic, and the heartbreak here on the frosty streets of Seoul is almost palpable.
This sense of humiliation may have far-reaching consequences, shaping the presidential elections later this month and profoundly affecting -- and perhaps upsetting -- diplomatic and economic ties with the United States and Japan. Already there is a deep anger in South Korea at Washington because of the conditions imposed as part of the bail-out.
"It's quite possible that next year we will experience growing anti-American sentiment," reflected Hyun Hong Choo, a former South Korean Ambassador to the United States. "The U.S. -- whether Government, industry or the people -- might make a very convenient target. That's what I worry about for next year, unless it's addressed by the political leadership."
Americans may find it puzzling that they should contribute their tax dollars to rescuing South Koreans and be blamed for it. To be sure, there is also gratitude for the American assistance, but it is often mixed with resentment and a profound irritability that arises from the embarrassment at being broke.
"I'm angry at the American and Japanese demands," complained Kim Soon Hwa, a 53-year-old woman selling hot coffee from a cart in a street market in Seoul. "If you really want to help us, don't make us buy your things. Just buy our things."
Mrs. Kim, who for all her anger was as sweet as the sugary coffee she urged on a visitor, reflected the anxiety about what is often described here as the "loss of economic sovereignty." In particular, the I.M.F. effectively forced South Korea, as a condition of the aid, to admit foreign banks and allow the import of Japanese goods that had been banned.
"Of course we feel angry," said Lee Eun Jung, a 21-year-old political science student at Ewha Women's University. "Even if the I.M.F. is an international organization, everybody knows it's run by the U.S. and the U.S. is using it for its own interests."
To the West, these conditions simply mean that South Korea will play by the rules of the international game, but here there is profound unease at the control that will be lost -- an echo of the angst that many Americans felt in the mid-1980's when Japanese companies started buying banks and properties in the United States.
"We won't have the chance to express our own opinions, to decide our own affairs," complained Yun Hye Yon, a 26-year-old sales clerk, as she mused that the I.M.F. monitoring will be like the Japanese occupation. "We've opened the road for foreigners to come in and impose their own culture on us, to exercise administration over us."
In most of Asia the anxiety has been focused on personal fears about unemployment, tumbling stock prices, lost savings. In South Korea, the sense of injury encompasses all that but is centered on something broader and vaguer -- the sting to national honor, the fear that Korea itself has lost face before the world.
"We look foolish, right?" asked Lee Hye Ok, 37, a manager of a vase shop. "So I feel especially embarrassed in front of the Japanese people, because I have many Japanese customers."
Mrs. Lee was asked if her Japanese customers now look down on her because of the bail-out. She paused for a long time, looked down, and nodded.
The passionate sense of Korean national identity perhaps arises from the nation's long history in a rough neighborhood dominated by China on one side and Japan on the other. If Koreans were not so fiercely concerned with national honor and independence, then Korea would long ago have simply become one more province of China.
Of course, the anger and humiliation are not universally felt. Some merchants note that they borrow money all the time and that it is common for lenders to set conditions.
"I don't think this is a humiliation for Korea," said Bae Ki Sup, 58, a fruit salesman with a cigarette hanging precariously from his lips. "And we can't blame other countries. It's good that they lent the money to us."
Korean newspapers have picked up this debate with vigor. The initial coverage was particularly hostile to the United States and Japan, but in some newspapers that has been tempered in the last few days.
"In the process of obtaining the bail-out loan, Korean pride was wounded, but pain and anger should not explode into unreasonable behavior," warned the Chosun Ilbo, a leading newspaper. "Already an atmosphere of anti-American sentiment has developed over the U.S. Government's alleged involvement in the I.M.F. negotiations. However, most of the current recommendations presented by the U.S. and the I.M.F. are those that we should have accepted when we joined the O.E.C.D. last year." South Korea joined the O.E.C.D., the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the club of industrialized nations, with a burst of national pride.
While many Koreans are angry at Washington, they tend to be angrier at their own Government. Politicians are calling for economic officials to be investigated and perhaps prosecuted, and many people say those responsible for the economic mess -- perhaps even including President Kim Young Sam -- should go to prison. This is not very likely, but many Koreans seem to find the discussion cathartic.
"Some people have to go to prison," said Ahn Sung Hye, an 18-year-old high school girl. "Like politicians and rich people. On the news I saw how some rich people were hoarding a lot of dollars in their homes when the country didn't have any. Those people should go to jail, too."
One diplomatic risk is that while Koreans are resentful of Americans, the United States may become annoyed at "Buy Korean" campaigns and at the growing nationalist hostility here to foreign luxury products. Many Koreans said that they would scold a friend who purchased expensive imports, although it is difficult to gauge how seriously to take such comments.
Lee In Kyu, 25, a student at Yonsei University, said he would now stop buying foreign candies or other foreign-made gifts for his girlfriend. But his girlfriend, Kim Hyung Sun, 25, seemed less impressed by his patriotism than amused by it.
"Actually, there's no possibility of his getting me a foreign-made gift," she laughed, as he looked on dejectedly. "He never gets me any presents at all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kim Soon Hwa, a coffee vendor who works in a street market in Seoul, South Korea, says she resents conditions imposed for an international bailout of her country's economy, which is in a severe crisis. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Seoul Crisis Worsens As More Banks Close
South Korea closed five more banks, accelerated its promised foreign access to domestic stock and bond markets and pledged to infuse money into beleaguered securities companies, but the moves did little to arrest the country's financial crisis.
In a strong sign that investors are losing confidence that the $57 billion I.M.F. rescue package for South Korea will work, the Korean won fell its daily allowable limit for the fourth straight day, raising the possibility that more rescue money may be required. The won is now worth about half what it was against the dollar at the beginning of 1997. And the Korean stock market resumed falling this morning after a gain yesterday. Page D4.
 
South Koreans now regard Dec. 3, the day the I.M.F. accord was reached, as "National Humiliation Day," a telling barometer of the resentment the rescue effort has caused. A1.
 
Asia Problems Hit Stocks Again
Wall Street was rattled for the third consecutive day on fresh reminders that the economic turmoil in Asia could erode corporate profits in this country. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 70.87 points, to 7,978.79, but the biggest losses were in technology stocks, which are viewed as more vulnerable to Asia's weakness. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 23.94, to 1,596.61, and the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index dropped 6.70, to 295.52. D16.
 
Bond prices advanced for the second straight day on a migration to the safe-haven of Treasuries by investors concerned over Asia's crisis. The gains pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.07 percent from 6.11 percent Tuesday. D23.
 
A $975 million purchase of Corning's housewares business by AEA Investors was scrapped over the buyer's concern about slow sales due to Asia's turmoil. D4.
 
Boston Edison Sells 12 Plants
Boston Edison sold 12 of its 13 power plants to a French-controlled company, Sithe Energies, for $657 million. Boston Edison plans to cut rates by 15 percent for its 650,000 customers, starting in March, when Massachusetts is to open utilities to competition. D2.
 
A Setback to BellSouth Hopes
The Justice Department recommended that the F.C.C. not allow BellSouth to offer long-distance service in Louisiana, another obstacle in the aspirations of the regional Bell telephone companies. D2.
 
Current Account Deficit Widens
The nation's deficit on the current account, the broadest measure of foreign trade, widened 11.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted $42.156 billion in the third quarter. Asia's economic crisis weakened American exports. D2.
 
Japan's current account deficit tripled in October due partly to the yen's decline against the dollar in currency markets. D15.
 
The dollar fell on warnings from Japanese officials they would sell dollars to defend the yen. In New York yesterday the dollar cost 129.28 yen, down from 129.59 Tuesday. D14.
 
Energy Futures Prices Tumble
Crude oil and gasoline futures prices fell almost 3 percent on signs that exports from Iraq could resume by January, just as OPEC increases production. D14.
 
No Moose on Mercedes' Bonnet
In a one-day advertising blitz, Mercedes-Benz proudly announced it had fixed the car maker's new A-Class subcompact so that it now passed the "moose test." The company sought to restore confidence in the bubble-shaped four-seater after test drivers for a Swedish car magazine flipped it over during a high-speed evasion maneuver known as the "moose test." D11.
 
A New Front in Burger War
Burger King keeps trying to chip away at McDonald's fast-food dominance. A few months ago, it was the Big King challenge to the Big Mac. Now Burger King is planning a huge promotion focused on its new french fries. A $70 million advertising campaign will feature Mr. Potato Head as spokesspud. For those unswayed by Mr. Potato Head's charms, Burger King will give away fries. D12.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Won Continues to Plummet Despite Government Efforts

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The Government struggled on Wednesday to stem the free fall of South Korea's currency and prevent a chain reaction of bankruptcies as the country's financial markets moved closer to desperation.
The Finance Ministry suspended the operations of five more banks on Wednesday and accelerated the promised foreign access to the stock and bond markets in a bid to attract overseas capital. The ministry also said it would inject money into beleaguered securities firms. 
 But the moves failed to arrest the decline in the Korean won, which fell its maximum daily limit of 10 percent today -- three minutes after the market opened -- for the fourth consecutive day.
The dollar closed at 1,719.8 won, compared with 1,565.9 at the end of trading on Wednesday. The dollar is now 72 percent stronger against the won than it was a month ago and 104 percent stronger since Jan. 1.
The Korean Stock Exchange's composite index also dropped quickly, falling 5.4 percent in early trading, more than erasing a 3.1 percent gain on Wednesday.
President Kim Young Sam, in a brief televised speech this morning, urged people not to "kneel to despair" and accepted responsibility for the crisis. "Every day I whip myself when I think about the hopelessness felt by heads of families who have lost their jobs and business owners who have gone bankrupt," said Mr. Kim, whose term ends in February.
In a further sign of lost confidence, Moody's Investors' Service downgraded the quality of South Korean bonds and other debt today, saying the country may require more foreign currency than previously thought. The move will raise South Korea's borrowing costs.
The free fall in the currency reflects frantic attempts by Korean banks and corporations to buy dollars with won to pay foreign debts.
But it also showed the $57 billion rescue announced by the International Monetary Fund last week has not calmed anxieties.
Lim Chang Yuel, the Minister of Finance and Economy, publicly called upon Japan and the United States on Tuesday to give some immediate financial assistance. His plea was rebuffed, but there were indications South Korea still might ask Japan for a short-term loan. Analysts say foreign investors and lenders not only lack confidence in the bailout package but also have little faith in the Government's ability to strengthen and liberalize South Korea's financial system.
"The Government really doesn't know how to deal with it themselves," said Kang Tae Hil, deputy general manager of international sales at Daewoo Securities, referring to the plunge of the won.
The big problem is a liquidity squeeze that threatens to create a vicious cycle of bankruptcies. As financial institutions teeter on failure, they are calling in loans to highly indebted corporations, forcing the corporations into bankruptcy. Corporate bankruptcies in turn compound the debt problems of the financial institutions.
On Wednesday, in what was called a financial stabilization package, the Government suspended the operations of five merchant banks, which are smaller than commercial banks and specialize in short-term lending. That brought the total number of suspended merchant banks to 14, nearly half of the 30 nationwide.
Korean officials said that any talk of a financial meltdown was exaggerated and that the mood was not panicky. But in a reflection of the frayed nerves this turmoil has caused, the Government deployed police officers in riot gear outside some of the suspended banks to prevent any disturbances as depositors gathered to withdraw money.
The Government also moved up the greater opening of the stock market to today from next Monday. Foreign investors will now be able to own 50 percent of a Korean company's shares. Until now, the limit has been 7 percent for an individual investor and 26 percent for all foreigners combined.
On Friday, the corporate bond market will be opened to foreigners, who will be allowed to buy up to 30 percent of an issue.
Both moves are designed to attract foreign capital. Foreign investors must buy won with dollars to invest in the market.
It is unclear whether foreign investors will plunge into the market. Nevertheless, analysts said some investors were probably willing to gamble that the won would rise and that some blue-chip stocks might be bargains.
A South Korean Finance Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Seoul might ask the Japanese Government for a bridge loan that would be repaid when Seoul received its next installment of money from the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: Japan Rivalry Puts Banking Plan in Limbo

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Japanese Government seems committed to bolstering the nation's ailing financial system with public funds, but a mystery is intensifying over precisely how such money would be used.
A proposal to raise money for a financial-stabilization package by issuing 10 trillion yen in Government bonds -- hailed on Tuesday by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka and the stock market as a potential solution -- foundered today. 
 It ran into problems on hints that the money raised -- currently equivalent to $77.5 billion -- might not go entirely to strengthening weak banks and other financial institutions. Lawmakers said that some of the funds might help finance a tax cut or some other economic stimulant, a contradiction of Government vows not to use deficit financing to cure Japan's economic problems.
In an editorial here today, a leading daily, Asahi Shimbun, called the plan "a sham."
And the Nikkei 225-stock index, which reflected investor approval of the idea on Tuesday with a 3.4 percent jump, retreated 1.25 percent today as signs increased that the plan was faltering. The slide continued Thursday, with the Nikkei index dropping an additional 298.30 points, or 1.8 percent, by early afternoon, to 16,179.82.
Further adding to uncertainty was the Government's vagueness over when it might announce a formal program for strengthening the banking system. The Finance Ministry hinted recently that the plan would be set forth as early as today, along with a broader design for invigorating the economy. Now it is unclear when either will be announced.
The proposal for bolstering the banks seems to have been caught up in political rivalry between Seiroku Kajiyama, its champion and a leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, and Koichi Kato, the party's powerful General Secretary and a strict proponent of fiscal austerity.
"Mr. Hashimoto and others jumped on this plan without the usual consultations with other party factions," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, chief economist at Credit Suisse First Boston here, "and now those groups are offended."
Ms. Sasaki-Smith and other analysts were also concerned that the Kajiyama plan, which would inject capital into the financial system through Government purchases of preferred shares in ailing institutions, would inhibit a much-needed contraction in banking.
Such a program would be similar to that of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the United States, established under the New Deal to recapitalize weak banks during the Depression. After the banks regained their footing, the Government liquidated its holdings in the market.
A string of failures last month of four large Japanese financial institutions -- the Sanyo Securities Company, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, the Yamaichi Securities Company and Tokuyu Bank -- was regarded as a measure of Tokyo's resolve to allow market forces to reshape the system, however painful that might be.
"The R.F.C. operated under very strict guidelines as to the type of bank and under what circumstances it was recapitalized -- so that it wasn't used to sustain the life of just any old bank," Ms. Sasaki-Smith said. "I've been saying for years that we have excess capacity in the banking system. This should not be a plan to sustain weak and undeserving banks."
Sei Nakai, deputy director general of the Finance Ministry's Banking Bureau, said the Government would not support any bank without seriously assessing its future, although he added that he did not think Japan's banks were insolvent at the moment. "I think this is a very good way to restore the financial system," he said.
He also noted that the Kajiyama plan would force banks to disclose the extent of their bad-loan problems more fully and would open their executives to prosecution for contributing to the loan crisis, though how far the Government would push such a house-cleaning is unclear.
"The executives of a bank receiving new capital would have to take responsibility for the problems," Mr. Nakai said. "They may not want to raise their hands, even if it means saving their bank."
Skepticism about the plan ran high today. For one thing, the original version, a five trillion yen, or nearly $39 billion, bond offering, that Mr. Kajiyama proposed last week, had been intended to support tax cuts, and many feared that it was still a tax-cutting wolf disguised as a finance-stabilizing sheep.
The collateral proposed for the new bonds also raised questions. The plan suggested that the bonds be backed by shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone and Japan Tobacco held by the Government. But the capital gains on those shares have already been pledged to service and redeem other Government bonds.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall in Hong Kong and Malaysia

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Thursday, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled here and in Hong Kong as turmoil continued to sweep Asian markets.
Malaysian stocks fell 6 percent in morning trading on concerns over the country's weakening currency, higher interest rates and a slowing economy. 
 The slide in stocks accelerated after the Malaysian news agency Bernama quoted Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad as warning that some Malaysian banks might face bankruptcy.
Mr. Mahathir, speaking at a conference of Islamic countries in Iran, said, "We are flattered when people say we shall prevail but they do not know how difficult things are now as many companies are half-dead and when people are not able to repay bank loans, banks may go bankrupt," according to the news service.
In Hong Kong, stocks fell for a third day as local interest rates rose sharply.
Hong Kong's three-month interbank offered rate -- the rate that banks lend to each other -- rose as high as 11.5 percent this morning, from 9.8 percent on Wednesday. At midday, the Hang Seng index of 33 shares was down 6.07 percent.
Also pressuring Hong Kong stocks was concern that speculators might again attack the Hong Kong currency's link to the United States dollar.
Thai stocks were also sharply lower as Thailand's currency, the baht, plunged to new lows. In the first hour of trading, the main Thai index slid 16.55 points, or 4 percent, to a new nine-year low.
