HEADLINE: MEETING REACHES ACCORD TO REDUCE GREENHOUSE GASES

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Thursday, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Negotiators from around the world agreed today on a package of measures that for the first time would legally obligate industrial countries to cut emissions of waste industrial gases that scientists say are warming the earth's atmosphere.
But details on one contentious issue -- the possible trade or sale of emission permits between countries -- remain unsettled, and may remain unsettled for months, and the United States has said it wants this issue resolved before it signs the treaty. Any treaty is subject to approval by the United States Senate. 
 The agreement reached by delegates from more than 150 nations creates a landmark environmental policy to deal with global warming, and innovative new mechanisms to carry it out.
The nations would have a year to ratify the treaty, starting next March. Talks on "trading" of emissions are expected to take place next November.
Despite the uncertainties, some environmentalists hailed the agreement as a remarkable political and economic innovation, in that it would establish a global system for dealing with what many scientists believe is the overarching environmental concern.
Opponents of the treaty condemned it as economically ruinous.
The accord -- known as the Kyoto Protocol -- would require the industrial nations to reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide and five other heat-trapping greenhouse gases to 5.2 percent below those of 1990. The United States would be required to cut emissions 7 percent below 1990 levels, on average, in the years from 2008 through 2012.
The agreement appears to represent a significant concession by the United States, which previously had insisted on the less stringent course of reducing the emissions to 1990 levels, not below them. It is also a measure of the flexibility in the American bargaining position that Vice President Al Gore said he had ordered negotiators to adopt on a visit here Monday.
It remains to be seen, however, whether the White House can persuade the Senate to accept the agreement, or even whether the United States will sign it.
Many Senators had already expressed reservations about the less stringent Administration proposal. By 2000, emissions of greenhouse gases by the United States are expected to be about 13 percent higher than they were in 1990. They are expected to be perhaps 30 percent higher in 2010, if trends in energy use continue and no other action is taken.
Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican observing the talks, said here today, "Any way you measure this, this is a very bad deal for America." He predicted the Senate would not approve it.
For his part Stuart Eizenstat, the senior American negotiator, said the United States was still waiting for more signs of flexibility from developing nations on the question of emission trading.
"We do not yet have that meaningful commitment coming out of Kyoto," he said. But, he added, the possibilities for such a commitment "are certainly pregnant."
President Clinton, visiting New York, said in a statement that he was "very pleased" by the agreement, which he said was "environmentally strong and economically sound." But he said developing nations had to do more.
And in Washington, Vice President Gore called the agreement a "vital turning point." He added, "Clearly, more work is needed. In particular we will continue to press for meaningful participation by key developing nations. We are confident that can be achieved. "
Under the accord, different countries would be assigned different targets, depending on their national circumstances and economic profiles. The European Union's target was set at a reduction in emissions of 8 percent below 1990 levels, and that of Japan at 6 percent. Other targets, albeit within a narrow range, also applied to other developed countries. Some countries may be allowed to increase emissions, but globally, emissions are to be reduced by 30 percent from the levels currently projected for 2010.
After an all-night session that ran into an unscheduled 11th day of discussion, the protocol was approved by representatives of more than 150 countries.
The countries were modifying an agreement, negotiated in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, that called for voluntary efforts to limit emission of greenhouse gases. The burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil is responsible for most emissions of carbon dioxide, the most important greenhouse gas.
As a means of promoting reductions in developing countries, the delegates established a special mechanism for transferring energy-efficient technologies and nonpolluting forms of energy production from richer nations to poorer ones. Greater efficiency means fewer emissions, and alternative energy sources like solar and wind power mean none.
The Clean Development Mechanism, as the new arrangement was named, is intended to encourage companies in industrial countries to invest in emissions-reduction projects in developing countries -- modern, fuel-efficient power plants, for example -- and get some credit for reducing their own emissions.
But the agreement was held up for hours last night and this morning by the resistance of some developing countries, including China, India and Saudi Arabia, to the inclusion of a provision enabling the industrialized nations to trade or purchase emissions rights. The United States considers this arrangement the cheapest and most efficient way of cutting emissions. Without it, American negotiators said, it would be impossible for the country to meet its emission targets.
In emissions trading, a country or industrial company will be able to meet its emissions reduction target by cutting some of its emissions itself, while at the same time purchasing part of its required reduction from another country or company that achieved excess cuts.
Based on its success with trading emissions of sulfur dioxide, a chemical implicated in acid rain, the United States argues that larger and cheaper reductions can be achieved with this mechanism.
The objectors said that the mechanism could lead to shifting the burden to less developed countries, and that countries and companies might be able to buy their way out of their obligations.
After hours of argument, delegates agreed to allow the parties to the 1992 treaty to postpone negotiations on the principles, rules, guidelines and operations of the trading system until November.
Experts advising the negotiators here say that if emissions are not reduced, the average surface temperature of the globe will rise by 2 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century, causing widespread climatic, environmental and economic disruption.
Philip E. Clapp, president of the the National Environmental Trust in Washington, who has been observing the talks here, called the agreement "a historic landmark in environmental protection." He said it would be remembered "as a central achievement of the Clinton-Gore Administration."
But representatives of the American fossil fuel and heavy manufacturing industries saw disaster in the agreement.
"It is a terrible deal and the President should not sign it," said William K. O'Keefe, chairman of the Global Climate Coalition, an industry group. Mr. O'Keefe said that "business, labor and agriculture will campaign hard and will defeat" the treaty if it is submitted to the Senate for ratification.
The protocol is generally viewed only as an early step in a continuing attempt to deal with the question of climate change. It is generally acknowledged that any attempt to deal with the problem requires a global solution involving all countries.

HEADLINE: Warm Globe, Hot Politics

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the end, Bill Clinton and Al Gore could not walk away.
They faced unpleasant political options as talks in Kyoto, Japan, wound done, and as more than 150 nations neared agreement on a treaty to cut the emissions that lead to global warming. Under the agreement that emerged, which the Administration plans to sign, the United States will have to take more drastic steps than the White House had hoped to cut greenhouse emissions. Heavy industry, from cars to coal to steel to electricity, has already joined with organized labor to fight the proposal. 
 But walking away from the treaty -- as Mr. Gore said he was willing to do last week -- would have enraged the environmentalists who are key constituents for him and Mr. Clinton. It would have isolated the United States -- which just refused to sign a treaty banning land mines -- as the leading emitter of greenhouse gasses and the only industrial nation unwilling to address the problem jointly. And it would have been contrary, their aides said, to a belief shared by the President and Vice President that global warming presents grave dangers.
But now the Administration has a larger fight on its hands, a fight that will help define not only budget negotiations next year but the 1998 Congressional elections and even the next Presidential race.
Even before the treaty was worked out, Democratic allies of the Administration were warning the White House not to seek approval in the Senate. "What we have here is not ratifiable in the Senate in my judgment," Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said in a telephone news conference from Kyoto.
Before the Kyoto meeting began, the Senate voted 95 to 0 to pass a resolution that the United States would not agree to a treaty that did not provide a role in cutting emissions for developing nations. That became a negotiating goal for the Administration.
In Kyoto, Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said flatly, "There is no way, if the President signs this, that the vote in the United States Senate will even be close. We will kill this bill."
The treaty emerging in Kyoto tonight (Thursday morning, Kyoto time) includes a new program sought by the Administration to funnel capital and environmentally friendly technology to developing nations. But White House aides said that, while they considered the provision a victory, it was not strong enough to win ratification.
The White House is also planning to propose tax incentives to encourage cuts in greenhouse-gas emission as part of its budget proposal next year, but that, too, will be subject to Congessional approval.
Two officials said that, judging by the early criticism, the public would get a positive impression of the Administration's actions. "We figured that we would probably be criticized by both industry and environmental groups," one of them said, "which has the effect of saying, 'Well, they must have ended up in a place that's pretty sensible.' "
Indeed, in Kyoto, one industry coalition went as far as to issue a statement denouncing the agreement hours before the deal was final. And the World Wildlife Fund attacked the plan, saying that the outcome was "a flawed agreement that will allow major polluters to continue emitting greenhouse gasses through loopholes."
But Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, said: "There's still much more work to be done to assure that the protocol's targets are met" but "Vice President Gore should be commended for coming to Japan and opening the doors to an agreement."
In recent polls the public has expressed solid support for action on global warming. Two weeks ago, in a poll taken by The New York Times , 65 percent said that the United States should take steps now to cut its own emissions "regardless of what other countries do." Only 17 percent agreed that cutting emissions "will cost too much money and hurt the U.S. economy."
Four years ago, Mr. Clinton promised to reduce United States emissions to their 1990 levels by the year 2000. But such emissions are now more than 10 percent above 1990 levels and rising. Mr. Clinton rarely mentioned the issue until early this summer, when, in anticipation of the Kyoto meeting, he began warning of the dangers of global warming.
But, even as he began addressing the subject again, Mr. Clinton has repeatedly said that the United States can meet what amount to rigorous emissions targets with little or no economic pain.
"I am convinced that we can demonstrate to the American people that we can substantially reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and fulfill our global environmental responsibilities as well as our responsibilities to our own people without giving up economic growth," Mr. Clinton said in an interview with The New York Times last Thursday. "But it will require a very disciplined, organized, coordinated effort to do it."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 949 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Would Need to Cut Use of Fuel Drastically

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
For the United States to meet the promises agreed to at the global warming conference in Japan, Americans would have to make significant, sustained cuts in their use of fossil fuels, beginning immediately and lasting well into the next century.
The nation's consumption of coal and oil would have to decline by as much as 30 percent from the levels now projected for 10 or 15 years from now, marking the first step toward what proponents of the treaty say would be a radical restructuring of the economy's patterns of energy use later in the 21st century. 
 In the short term, it would require car makers to sell more efficient vehicles, power companies to give up coal and people to learn to be miserly when choosing light bulbs, air-conditioners and appliances. In the long term there could be a wholesale turn to novel devices like combustion-free fuel cells and solar and wind power. Economists and advocates may dispute whether the economy would be better or worse off as a result, but it would have to be markedly different.
The country has made no sacrifices remotely like this since the oil shocks of the 1970's. At the moment, the American appetite for fossil fuels, and therefore emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, is growing.
Last month the Energy Department reckoned in its long-term forecast that this trend, fed by cheap fuel and strong economic growth, was likely to continue for decades.
So as exhausted delegates straggle home from rancorous all-night talks in Kyoto, the question is whether the United States -- where per capita emissions of carbon dioxide are more than double Japan's, triple France's and 10 times Brazil's -- has the economic strength, the brainpower and the political will to put into practice what its negotiators have promised.
The least of the problems is technology. Although expensive, substitutes for carbon fuels are already available.
But the political barriers look formidable. Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, called the treaty's prospects bleak even before the ink was dry, and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, a Democrat who favors the treaty, cautioned against rushing to seek Senate approval. Not only would the Senate have to consent to the treaty, but both houses of Congress would have to approve any legislation to carry it out, like emissions caps, a permit-trading plan, tax incentives, research budgets or reorganization of the utility industry.
As for enforcing a national energy diet, no one knows what combination of rewards and punishments might be needed to change course and head toward the targets that would be imposed under the new regime.
The Energy Department has projected that emissions of carbon from energy use will rise 1.2 percent a year until 2020. Between 2008 and 2012, when the treaty calls for reductions to be achieved, emissions are headed toward 1.8 billion metric tons a year, the agency said. The new goal under the treaty would be 1.25 billion tons during the same period.
Only a small part of the reduction -- at most 160 million tons a year, American negotiators say -- might be achieved by trading credits with Russia, whose emissions dropped sharply when its economic output collapsed along with Communism.
To meet these goals, most analysts say governments would have to put caps on emissions. But the Clinton Administration favors market-based mechanisms like trading pollution permits, rather than rigid regulations, to let companies decide for themselves how to meet the limits.
"President Clinton is right that getting to anything below 1990 levels in the U.S. is going to be a big stretch," said Christopher Flavin, an energy efficiency expert at the Worldwatch Institute, an environmental group. "Even if we are partly to buy our way there with credits from Russia, there is still going to have to be a lot done at home."
Opponents of the treaty agreed with that assessment.
"The energy use curbs needed to comply with the climate treaty are far deeper than expected," said the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a pro-business research and advocacy group. It said provisions to allow international emissions trading and other offsets would only "disguise the pain."
But there are several approaches, some buried in the treaty text and others being developed by the Clinton Administration as unilateral actions, that might help.
For example, the treaty makes allowances for trading pollution control credits among countries if that would provide cheaper ways of reducing worldwide emissions for what is, after all, a global problem.
The treaty also would allow countries to receive credit for certain changes in land use and forestry practices against their emissions limit, on the ground that trees take in carbon dioxide from the atmosphere as they grow and store the carbon for decades in the form of wood.
The Clinton Administration is working on a package of tax incentives and research subsidies that would accelerate the introduction of renewable energy sources like solar and wind power, which do not emit carbon, and energy-efficiency technologies that use far less fossil fuels.
The American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy and other conservation advocates have called for tax incentives for any vehicle, whether a compact car or a lumbering sport utility vehicle, that achieved double the fuel efficiency of today's comparable models.
Any car could double its fuel efficiency by using hybrid gas-and-electric technologies that are just coming onto the market.
Another crucial opportunity for reducing fossil fuel consumption may come with the opening of the electric utility industry to nationwide competition.

HEADLINE: Clinton Praises Bronx Renewal As U.S. Model

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
Sweeping through a sodden New York yesterday, President Clinton visited a South Bronx neighborhood risen up from despair, then roared into Manhattan for a pastrami on rye, a Christmas shopping excursion and two evening fund-raisers that produced as much as $1.55 million.
Mr. Clinton and his sprawling caravan forced already heavy holiday traffic onto side streets and into detours, creating pockets of gridlock over much of midtown and the east side of Manhattan. 
 The symbolic high point of the trip came in the morning when Mr. Clinton visited the Charlotte Gardens neighborhood in the South Bronx. Now a tree-lined street of suburban-style houses, Charlotte Gardens came to symbolize urban blight in the aftermath of the arson fires that devastated the South Bronx in the 1970's.
But over many years, the neighborhood was rebuilt, largely with city money. Yesterday, shortly after 11 A.M., Mr. Clinton walked slowly along Charlotte Street, greeting residents and an impromptu receiving line of local officials. Later, he hailed the South Bronx as a model for renewing inner-city areas, a once-unthinkable statement.
"If you can do it," Mr. Clinton told an audience at the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club in the South Bronx, "everybody else can do it."
Citing empowerment zones, the Federal tax credit for low-income housing and the Community Reinvestment Act as examples of his urban policy, Mr. Clinton announced he would release $96 million to New York through the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Innovative Home Program for more housing. He also said the Small Business Administration would make available $50 million in loans to small-business owners in the Bronx.
But after the President's speech, the HUD Secretary, Andrew M. Cuomo, said the $96 million did not actually represent additional money for New York but instead was already included in the 1998 Federal budget. "It's not a special program for New York," Mr. Cuomo said, "but New York gets more money than any other city in the nation."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had planned to attend the Bronx rally but canceled to attend the funeral of a Staten Island boy who died of an accidental gunshot wound. Deputy Mayor Randy M. Mastro attended in his stead.
Also absent was Representative Jose E. Serrano, who represents the Charlotte Gardens area in Congress. Joe Lockhart, a White House spokesman, said the Congressman felt snubbed because the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, was Mr. Clinton's host in the Bronx and because Mr. Ferrer had heard about the President's visit first. "We failed to to do a good job in the notification, and that's my understanding of why the Congressman failed to attend," Mr. Lockhart said. Phone calls left for Mr. Serrano last night were not returned.
Later in the evening, Mr. Clinton attended two fund-raising events, first a $10,000-per-couple gathering sponsored by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria that was also attended by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. It was the first meeting between the two Democrats since Mr. Gephardt criticized White House campaign fund-raising practices. They shook hands but beyond that barely made eye contact.
The event was expected to raise $800,000 to $1 million, bringing to $3 million the total amount of money Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have raised in seven events for the Democratic Congressional group this year.
The President then attended the Democratic National Committee Hispanic Gala at the Rainbow Room, where many of the 200 guests made $5,000 contributions for a meal of lobster salad and beef with asparagus. Organizers expected to raise $550,000.
Mr. Clinton's visit earlier in the day to the South Bronx made him the third President to visit Charlotte Street in the last 20 years. In 1977, President Jimmy Carter paid a surprise visit to the South Bronx, stepping out of his limousine to walk through piles of rubble and trash on Charlotte Street. City crews had razed almost every building on the block after a rash of arson fires. In all, roughly 100,000 housing units were lost to fires in the South Bronx during the 1970's. Calling his visit a "a very sobering trip," Mr. Carter pledged to help rebuild the area.
Ronald Reagan, campaigning for the Presidency in 1980, visited Charlotte Street, too, lambasting Mr. Carter for failing to revive the neighborhood. Mr. Reagan posed in front of the destroyed street, saying he had "not seen anything that looked like this since London after the blitz." Jesse Jackson, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, slept in the apartment of a South Bronx family during the 1984 primaries to draw attention to the area's lingering poverty.
"My No. 1 message here is, 'Look at where the Bronx was when President Carter came here in despair,' " Mr. Clinton later said. "Look at where the Bronx was when President Reagan came here and compared it to London in the Blitz. Look at the Bronx today."
Heavily subsidized by public money, the neat, single-family houses on Charlotte Street sold for $49,500 in 1985. Started under the city administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, the project almost died in 1983, after the first 10 houses were built. The city flirted with cutting off financing, but, prodded by the South Bronx Development Organization, it did not, and construction of all 89 houses was completed in 1986.
Today, the homes are valued at $185,000, underscoring the newly found stability and desirability of the area. Overall, more than $2 billion in state and Federal housing money also has been poured into the South Bronx since 1986, helping to create 30,000 new and renovated housing units.
The middle of the President's day was dedicated to filling his stomach and his shopping bag.
With rain turning to a light snow, Mr. Clinton's entourage left the Bronx and sped down the cleared southbound lanes of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive for lunch at Katz's Delicatessen on Houston Street on the Lower East Side. He ate a pastrami on rye with mustard while dining with Mr. Cuomo; Aida Alvarez, Small Business Administrator; Representatives Nydia M. Velazquez, who represents parts of Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan, Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn and other elected officials. His entourage of dozens of vehicles idled outside, closing down much of Houston Street.
With lunch finished by 2:30 P.M., Mr. Clinton left Katz's to go Christmas shopping. Though there were reports that the President planned to shop along Fifth Avenue, his motorcade instead went to the South Street Seaport, a decision aides attributed to logistics and a desire to minimize the disruption of local traffic.
The President spent about an hour and a half shopping, escorted by a former aide, Wendy Smith. Dipping in and out of several stores, Mr. Clinton bought $400 in jewelry, including three pillboxes and five amber pins made in Poland. He also bought six sweaters, three soft-sided leather briefcases and two trinkets from a Western store.
Mr. Clinton's presence brought commerce to a screeching halt, as shoppers abandoned stores to gawk from the railings. More than once, the President waded into crowds to shake hands.
"Is it really you?" Diane Schneider, a shopper, asked when she suddenly found herself shaking Mr. Clinton's hand. "He looked at me and said, 'Why yes it is.' He sounded like Elvis Presley."
The crowd at Charlotte Street also reached out for handshakes and photographs. Raymond Gonzalez, 57, a retired transit worker, let his 17-year-old daughter play hooky to she could photograph the President outside their home. "I shook his hand and said, 'Welcome to Charlotte Street,' " Mr. Gonzalez said. "Actually, I shook his hand four times."
Mr. Gonzalez said many of his friends regretted not applying for a house in Charlotte Gardens. "A lot of people were skeptical," he recalled. "There was nothing but rubble and brick. They figured nothing would grow here."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 16, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about President Clinton's visit to New York included an erroneous report from the White House press office about people who joined him for lunch at Katz's Delicatessen on the Lower East Side. Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, Representative Edolphus Towns and Aida Alvarez, the Small Business Administrator, were not in the group. (Reporters were not admitted to the restaurant.)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 42; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4842 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"ART ON THE EDGE: FRAMING 19TH-CENTURY AMERICA," National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Jan. 11). An imposing frame, preferably gilded, was an important part of the "sell" of a 19th-century painting. The right frame in which to dress a painting for its all-important easel display was a must for artists, who purveyed works to patrons directly from their studios. Often, they designed their own. This selection, ranging from 1860 to the 1890's, presents a variety from the collection of Eli Wilner & Company, makers of period frames. They range from elaborate Barbizon-style models used to echo natural forms in paintings, to those reflecting the taste for Moorish designs in the 1880's, to a classically ornamented gilt frame by Stanford White with an outer shadow box of wood. But the show, pegged to the rising interest in frame connoisseurship, could use much better labeling about the how and why of these elaborate mounts, and especially the design elements that went into them. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for children under 16, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck). 

THE ARTIST'S EYE, National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Dec. 28). For the National Academy's biennial series, Will Barnet, a member, has selected a motley show of 50 portraits from the academy's permanent collection. Highlights include a great self-portrait by Thomas Eakins, a horrific self-portrait by Ivan Albright, a small but richly painterly self-portrait by Lois Dodd and an etched self-portrait of fuzzy little dots by Chuck Close. Also on view are nine of Mr. Barnet's distinctively linear paintings. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for the elderly. (Ken Johnson).
"THE DRAWINGS OF FILIPPINO LIPPI AND HIS CIRCLE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 11). The first major presentation of the work of this important Florentine artist brings together more than 100 drawings, most by Filippino Lippi himself, but also by his father, Fra Filippo Lippi; Raphael; Botticelli, and Piero di Cosimo. Although primarily known as a painter, Filippino was an ardently inventive draftsman, mastering line in pen and metalpoint to push drawing to its limits. He became a wizard at the use of metalpoint, a technique of incising the lines of a drawing on prepared paper. Among other rarities in the show is a first-time pairing of Filippino's pen-and-ink cartoon for a painting showing the dead Jesus at his tomb with the painting itself, the only full-scale Filippino drawing that can be matched to an extant painting. More than most, this rich presentation brings you close to the artist's intimate arena, where with mind and hand he struggles to get it right. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8 for adults; $4 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
"FAIR AND FREE: IMAGES OF CHILDHOOD, 1824-1992," National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 360-6795 (through March 8). Even a curmudgeon who agrees with Scrooge and W. C. Fields on the subject of children could warm to this show. In paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures, it presents some 65 views of the blissful stage of life before adolescence takes over. The work, most of it by academy members, reaches back to the year before the academy's founding with a mawkish pre-Victorian painting of 1824 by Frederick Stiles Agate that shows a mother lamenting over her dead baby. But it goes on to more spirited offerings. Children playing, making mischief, doing chores, fondling pets, picking flowers or just being children are the subjects of works by Cecelia Beaux, Mary Cassatt, William Merritt Chase, Thomas Dewing, Eastman Johnson, Winslow Homer, Jerome Myers, James McNeill Whistler and lesser lights. The 20th-century components of the show are far less distinctive than the earlier part. But embellished with antique toys borrowed from various sources, the show has a lot going for it. Take the children. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for children under 16, students and the elderly (Glueck).
* "FLOWERS UNDERFOOT: INDIAN CARPETS OF THE MUGHAL ERA" (through March 1) and "KING OF THE WORLD," a Mughal manuscript from the Royal Library, Windsor Castle (through Feb. 8), Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710. These ravishing exhibitions are devoted to work from the reign of the Mughal emperors of India, and they complement each other superbly. "Flowers Underfoot" is a gathering of some 50 carpets, with images ranging from grotesque animal heads to refulgent floral patterns. The finest of them are woven of Himalayan goat's wool; the colors are magnificent. Painted versions of these treasures can be found in "The Chronicle of the King of the World," a book commissioned by Shah Jahan, builder of the Taj Mahal. The book's miniatures are being displayed outside their binding for the first time. An extended exercise in dynastic propaganda, they combine supreme naturalism with an almost preposterous jewel-like richness. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission: $8; $4 for students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
* "NEW CONCEPTS IN PRINTMAKING 1: PETER HALLEY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400 (through Feb. 8). From a famously intellectual 80's art star who hasn't been too visible lately, a big, jazzy installation that shows his signature cell image -- variously interpreted as a jail, a battery or a power plant -- exploding or melting down. Its demise is clocked in a nine-panel comic-book sequence that recurs in several kinds of prints, including acres of wallpaper hung with art, a la Warhol. A wall painted radioactive yellow adds to the nuclear-accident tone. In addition, prints, illustrations and maps from the artist's collection -- for example, an 18th-century diagram of a sewer system -- further explicate his interests and inspirations. This is one of Mr. Halley's best efforts and certainly his most revealing. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
MONA HATOUM, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Feb. 22). This survey of work by the artist Mona Hatoum -- born in Beirut of Palestinian descent, now living in London -- was to mark the New Museum's re-opening after a major interior expansion. Things happen; the reburbishment isn't finished. But the show is in place, and Ms. Hatoum's spare, evocative sculptures and installations look good. This is a deeply emotional art, one that often speaks quietly but hides very little: the body is relentlessly explored; the psychological wounds of lost childhood and of adult displacement probed. At bottom, the vision is of a world at war, even when the battle is a private and internal one. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3 for artists, students and the elderly; free for those 18 and under (Cotter).
"MONET AND THE MEDITERRANEAN," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 4). Yet another Monet show, this one with 65 mostly lesser-known paintings inspired by several trips he took, the first in 1883 to the Riviera, the last to Venice in 1908. In general, these Mediterranean views have been overshadowed by his other paintings for a reason. They're pretty, and occasionally boring, though one sees Monet adjusting to a new landscape, contriving a palette appropriate to the warm, enveloping southern light and to the tropical locale and pushing toward the sort of serialism that was to be his most creative reaction to Seurat and the other Post-Impressionists. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Holiday hours: 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Dec. 26 and 28, Jan. 2 and 4.; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Jan. 1. Admission: $8; $4, students; $2, the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
"ROMANTICISM TO REALISM: 19TH-CENTURY GERMAN DRAWINGS," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 685-0610 (through Jan. 4). Caspar David Friedrich and Philip Otto Runge are the stars of this gourmet exhibition, drawn largely from the Morgan's own holdings. Trying to show the Divine in earthly manifestations, the two produced deeply spiritual imagery inspired by nature. Friedrich's was on the melancholy side; Runge's more life-affirming. Besides Friedrich and Runge, the show includes the work of some 40 other artists, realists as well as romantics, and a group of fancy palace interiors that catered to the tastes of viewers in the Biedermeier period. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Suggested admission: $6; $4 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 (Glueck).
"THE WARHOL LOOK/GLAMOUR STYLE FASHION," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Jan. 18). Andy Warhol remains one of the most provocative American artists of the postwar years. It is almost impossible not to have complicated feelings about him, but his impact has been immense. Unfortunately, little of his importance is conveyed in this tame, patchy exhibition, organized by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, which sets out to examine how fashion influenced Warhol and how he influenced it. Elaborately installed, this is basically a show of ephemera rather than of art. But no encounter with Warhol can be without interest, and this one has its moments: the section on drag is good; the Factory-era material in general is great. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $8; $7,students and the elderly; free on Thursdays, 6 to 8 P.M. (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
* "FRANZ KLINE: ARCHITECTURE AND ATMOSPHERE," Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, (212) 988-6870 (through Jan. 17; closed Dec. 20-Jan. 5). By all accounts, the Abstract Expressionist paintings of Franz Kline reflect his complex, attractive personality. He was an American-style romantic: a gregarious melancholic with the wit and grace of a ballroom dancer, a kind of Wagnerian Fred Astaire. It's great to have him back in town in something like representative form in this scrappy but ambitious exhibition, which traces his career from drawings of city streets in the 1930's to his late color abstractions. Most of the work included is small: studies and experiments, hung salon style in clusters. But there are large pieces, too, topped off by the artist's noble last painting, "Scudera" of 1961 (Cotter).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
JOSE BEDIA, George Adams Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 644-5665 (through Dec. 20). Most of Mr. Bedia's new work, influenced by children's toys and folk carving, is modest in size and light in tone but full of complex ideas. The show includes animal fables, mythological vignettes and political dramas, as well as a series of visionary drawings of Afro-Cuban deities in this artist's incisive graphic style. Don't miss the little box in the center of the gallery: modeled on a shaman's medicine chest, it is divided into little rooms fitted with miniature altars, icons and ritual paraphernalia, everything necessary for the spiritual journey that is the basic theme of everything Mr. Bedia does (Cotter).
* LEONORA CARRINGTON, Brewster Arts Ltd., 41 West 57th Street, (212) 980-5373 (through Dec. 23). This incomparable artist, now 80, began life as an English debutante with artistic ambitions, ran with off Max Ernst at the age of 20 and never looked back. She has lived in Mexico since 1943, making tiny paintings in a fantastic Surrealist style that draws on Goya, Bosch, the Sienese painters and Egyptian art, with just a pinch of Edward Gorey. Scenes of mysterious rituals conducted by elaborately costumed spirits and equally fanciful animals reflect a fertile and original imagination, but it is the palette of glowing, misty colors and the whispering passion of the delicate yet turbulently painted surfaces that give this work its power (Smith).
SEIICHI FURUYA, "Memoires," Robert Miller Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 980-5454 (through Dec. 19). In a kind of visual diary, highly personal and often enigmatic, running from 1978 to 1997, the photographer mixes the events of his own world and the larger one. Nature photographs of worms and flowers, a view of the former concentration camp at Sachsenhausen, Germany, and other "outside" phenomena mingle with touching photographs of his troubled wife, caught in many moods and poses, until her suicide in 1985. Her sprawled body is also recorded by the photographer in a chilling shot from the window she exited, but it is reticently shown here on a color contact strip with unrelated subject matter. The intensity of the show is diminished by a few too many random memories, but as the evocation of a life, with the pains and pleasures that accompany the franchise, it's compelling (Glueck).
GEORGE RICKEY, Maxwell Davidson, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7555 (through Dec. 20). New, mostly small works by the 90-year-old master of the Modernist mobile. Along with his familiar swinging blades, tilting planes and twittering machines, there's something new: small works called Pagodas in which rooflike forms, hand painted in multicolored patterns, balance on central posts (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
BRYAN CROCKETT, Fotouhi Cramer Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-1304 (through Jan. 17). In his first solo exhibition, Mr. Crockett, whose monstrous balloon sculpture was one of the hits of the last Whitney Biennial, shows only one fully realized balloon work along with various high-tech procedures to which he subjects his sculptures. He records their deflation on video, he makes Rayograms of them, and he puts one under glass in a vacuum machine, which makes it rhythmically and suggestively swell and shrink (Johnson).
* ANNA GASKELL, "Wonder," Casey Kaplan, 48 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 226-6131 (through Dec. 20). In this impressive debut, Lewis Carroll, writer, is fused with Lewis Carroll, photographer of blossoming young girls, as his classic story of Alice and her travels is cryptically recast in a series of bright, seemingly innocent color photographs of a pair of twin teen-age girls costumed in the requisite pinafores and Mary Janes. Changing in size and camera angle, the images evoke various events, characters and lines from the story, capture the scary, tumbling chaos of the trip and its sexual undercurrents, and from a point of view that is distinctly Alice's own. More than ever, it is a coming-of-age tale, about the wonder that a girl can feel on the brink of womanhood (Smith).
"LANDSCAPE U.S.A.," Bronwyn Keenan Gallery, 3 Crosby Street, (212) 431-5083 (through Dec. 24). This lively painting show mixes styles and generations while stretching the definition of landscape in several directions. There are good recent works by Verne Dawson, David Deutsch and Karen Kalimnik, as well as exemplary earlier efforts by John Wesley and Forrest Bess. The juxtaposition of Lari Pittman's bright, labor-intensive imagery with a similarly wound-up painting made by Steve Wheeler in the late 1940's is especially rewarding (Smith).
ERIC MAGNUSON, Thomas Nordanstad Gallery, 476 Broome Street, (212) 274-1508 (through Dec. 20). Square, monochromatic canvases covered by rows of neatly lettered "found neologisms," new forms of jargon and slang gleaned form the Internet, the corporate workplace and various other sub- or mass-culture sources: "Dilberting," "Body Nazis," "Gapgeist," "Kleptocrats" and so on. Like Ed Ruscha's word-based pictures, Mr. Magnuson's paintings are fun to read, and they open up dizzying views of our contemporary collective mindscape (Johnson).
* BEATRIZ MILHAZES, Edward Thorp Gallery, 103 Prince Street, (212) 431-6880 (through Jan. 10). Ms. Milhazes, who lives in Brazil, has come through with a dazzling second New York solo show of abstract paintings. Her forms, often circular, seem to derive from textile patterns, architectural ornaments and the lacelike haloes and vegetal filigree found in the colonial-period Baroque religious art of the Americas. Her surfaces, which suggest stamping, embossing and collage, deliberately keep the artist's personal touch at a slight remove, but only slight: the result is a sense of exhilarated, erotic concentration (Cotter).
CARL PALAZZOLO, "A Personal History of Italian Film," Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through Dec. 20). The golden era of Italian film, when directors like Fellini, Visconti and Antonioni were at the peak of their powers, is the subject of these recent paintings and watercolors. Mr. Palazzolo's sketchily composed canvases include fragmentary images, words and names intended to evoke particular films or directors. In "No. 6," for instance, a partial post-Crucifixion image of Jesus is seen at the right of a gray ground across which the name "Pasolini" is also faintly stenciled. Mysteriously, a series of trompe l'oeil white cards covers sections of Jesus's body and the director's name. And so it goes through eight other anemic paintings, each making arch and veiled visual references to Mr. Palazzolo's heros and heroines and their work. Paying homage to film and filmdom in another visual medium is tricky work at best; here it borders on the silly (Glueck).
* SHAHZIA SIKANDER, Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Dec. 20). With the rigorous tradition of Persian and Indian miniature painting as a base, this talented young artist from Pakistan achieves a heady mix of East and West, and past and present, switching media, styles and scales with remarkable ease. Her most original works are the fluid, dreamlike wall paintings and watercolors, which provide a terrific foil for the refined, hyper-alert technique of the miniatures. Everything is connected by recurring images of female forms and personages, especially a tribe of red goddesses. The hauntingly beautiful narratives that result are at once declarative and mysterious (Smith).
"THREE PAINTERS," CRG, 93 Grand Street, (212) 966-4360 (through Dec. 20). In this exhibition of three young realists -- Kiki Lemars of Rotterdam, Margherita Manzelli of Milan and Sandra Scolnik of New York -- the subject of childhood or adolescence is coupled with meticulous technique, and an unsettling eeriness seems to be the common ground, one that is worth examining (Smith).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
JOHN BEARDMAN, Denise Bibro, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 647-7030, (through Dec. 20). Paintings that look as if they were made in an immediate, Abstract Expressionist manner but were, in fact, made by means of an elaborate, indirect process. Mr. Beardman applies paint to wax slabs, peels it off when dry and adheres the skin of paint to canvas in rectangular sections. The resulting fields of gesture and texture are not as remarkable as the tricky technique would lead you to expect (Johnson).
 RITA McBRIDE, Alexander and Bonin, 312 10th Avenue, near 19th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through Dec. 20). Ordinary pieces of architecture or furniture are transformed into subtly ironic model-scale sculptures: the shells of a pair of parking garages cast in bronze; the framework of an awning made of clear sections of Murano glass fastened together by brass plates; a bentwood chair made of dark amber glass, the parts joined by plastic wrap (Johnson).
KUNIE SUGIURA, Leslie Tonkonow, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 255-8450 (through Jan. 10; closed Dec. 23-Jan. 1). In a darkroom, using minimal means, Ms. Sugiura takes a new approach to the traditional Japanese art of flower arranging. Composing blossoms and sometimes bits of string on photographic paper, she briefly exposes her arrangements to light, then manipulates the developing material to create painterly effects. The result: photograms and color-toned positive prints of delicate but arresting imagery that often have emotional resonance. In one print, blossoms dance on taut strings in an empyrean space; in another, four blossoms, each at the end of a slack vertical string on a dark, swirling ground, push forlornly at the top edge of the print as if seeking escape. In a more Minimalist composition, Ms. Sugiura stacks bunches of tulips in a repetitive vertical pattern, contrasting their free organic shapes with the formality of their placement. A lovely show (Glueck).
SHELLBURNE THURBER, Jack Shainman, 513 West 22d Street, (212) 645-1701 (through Dec. 20). This excellent, Boston-based photographer presents a selection from 20 years of her work in her first solo show in New York. Other than an occasional portrait within a picture, there are no people in Ms. Thurber's photographs; but in her rich yet understated, large-format images of rooms -- from the comfortably appointed interiors of her grandparents to the most depressingly run-down motel cubicles -- she evokes palpable human presences (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Other
 
PAULA HAYES, AC Project Room, 15 Renwick Street, off Spring Street, West Village, (212) 219-8275 (through Jan. 17; closed Dec. 25-Jan. 1). In a Duchampian move, Paula Hayes offers potted plants as artworks. If you buy one, you must sign a contract promising to care for your living sculpture properly. Also on view are a lush terrarium and a section of grassy turf in a canvas-covered box; the latter is given the literally descriptive title, "Selling a Piece of My Family Land" (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
ED BAYNARD, Dillon, 431 West Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 966-2977 (through Wednesday). Along with the whimsical, flattened, candy-colored flower paintings for which he is known, Ed Baynard shows some portraits made in a cloying, faux-ingenuous style and some curiously schizoid still-life pictures. The latter incorporate televisions displaying bad news, like a scene of people investigating an airplane crash site (Johnson).
MARGARET CURTIS, Arena Gallery, 313 Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718) 624-1307 (through Sunday). Call Ms. Curtis a pastoral feminist. Her wry, airy drawings, full of feminine flourishes, often depict the wide-open spaces disrupted by a bit of down-home satire: a lascivious female scarecrow or the back of a road-side sign in the shape of a curvaceous woman. Earlier drawings review the artist's development, while suggesting that her barbs are sharper and her aim improved (Smith).
ALAN DAVIE, Joseph Rickards, 1045 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 924-0858 (through tomorrow). A handful of gouaches by the Scottish artist who emerged in the 1960's as a painter of playful, splashy abstractions. These colorful works on paper from the 70's combine painterly spontaneity and pictographic images. They are not unpleasant, but the studied simulation of childlike naivete does not wear well (Johnson).
NICOLAS DE STAEL, Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 744-7400, (through tomorrow). De Stael (1914-55) was at the forefront of French avant-garde painting in the years immediately after World War II. He enjoyed considerable success in the United States in the 1950's, but his Cubistic easel painting was eclipsed by Abstract Expressionism. This survey of his work from the 50's is the first de Stael exhibition in America in 30 years. His best paintings are the most thickly painted ones and the smallest ones. They offer not the expansive optical field of Abstract Expressionism, but a concentrated, tactile physicality (Johnson).
* "40 YEARS OF EXPLORATION AND INNOVATION," the artists of the Castelli Gallery Part 2, Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, near Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 431-5160 (through tomorrow). Less can indeed be more, as this selection of one work each by nine Castelli artists variously associated with Minimalism vividly demonstrates. It's the interaction between works as much as individual pieces themselves that accounts for the beauty of the show. A Mondrianesque arrangement of painted rectangles by Nassos Daphnis, a classic Frank Stella black stripe painting and a Donald Judd wall relief in which bright orange slats are sandwiched between galvanized-steel moldings counterpoint one another like members of a jazz trio (Johnson).
ALLAN McCOLLUM, Susan Inglett, 100 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 343-0573 (through tomorrow). In Mr. McCollum's sly installation, 1,152 colored concrete bars, into each of which the word "Thanks" is molded, are stacked like gold ingots on six tables. Thus he equates the artwork and the commodity, stamps it with the mark of gratitude that so often punctuates transactions of money or power, and once again succinctly makes the point that for all its esthetic, spiritual or intellectual aspirations, art can never fully extract itself from the lowly muck of commerce and politics (Johnson).
"MONDRIAN AND REINHART: INFLUENCE AND AFFINITY," Pace Wildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 421-3292 (through tomorrow). In this museum-quality show, the abstractionist Ad Reinhardt (1913-1967) is paired with one of the painters who influenced him, Piet Mondrian (1872-1944). The exhibition explores the relationship between these two hard-edge sensibilities, focusing on what Reinhardt took from Mondrian before going off on his own path. Reinhardt shared with Mondrian a feeling for painting as a spiritual discipline without worldly reference. Seeking a "pure" abstraction, he began in the late 1940's to take cues from the older painter's early "plus and minus" phase, the reduction of subject matter to an allover pattern of short horizontal and vertical strokes. By the 50's Reinhardt was involved with the shifting planes of color that Mondrian developed in his work after 1917. Then Reinhardt began to simplify his canvases, turning toward larger geometric blocks of color in closer values, finally arriving at his "ultimate" paintings, calm works that demand intensity of vision to see the barely perceptible colors that lie under their dense, dark surfaces (Glueck).
SUSAN ROTHENBERG, Sperone Westwater, 142 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 431-3685 (through tomorrow). Ms. Rothenberg continues to explore the relationship between image and surface, bringing her subjects closer to her own everyday life and setting them increasingly in motion. The action gets metaphorical in "White Poker," the most ambitious work here, which shows a big tilting table piled with human limbs, as if the card players were literally betting "an arm and a leg" (Smith).
JULIAN SCHNABEL, Pace Wildenstein, 142 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 431-9224 (through tomorrow). Mr. Schnabel's portraits of friends dressed up in Old World costumes project a typically imposing combination of aggression and sensuality. But there's a niggling uncertainty in the way the figures are made, especially in their wooden faces and clumsy hands, that undermines their dramatic impact. In several pictures, Mr. Schnabel has spilled puddles of white paint across the surface. In the best painting, he does away with the ironic role playing and gives his naked 10-year-old son a rough-hewn Cezannesque monumentality (Johnson).
MIKLOS SUBA, "Precise Impressions," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through tomorrow). Settling in Brooklyn after leaving his native Hungary, Suba (1880-1944) painted buildings and industrial scenes in a hard-edged style that put him in company with Precisionist artists like Charles Sheeler, Charles Demuth and Ralston Crawford. Their simplified, geometricized forms and sharply outlined contours were part of the Americanization of Cubism. Suba's work, though not as strong as the others, is seen at its best in canvases like "Factories: Manhattan Bridge" (1938), in which the view is framed by the edges of buildings, seen close-up at either side of the canvas. Suba also painted barber poles and detailed shop windows, closing in on his subjects with a tight focus. Altogether, a very engaging show (Glueck).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 39; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1151 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Portrait of Black Life, Minus the Bad News

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
There are many ways to approach history. You can look on the bright side and talk about what worked. Or you can concentrate on everything else. Or, with a little patience, you can go with a textured, light-and-dark picture that is often closer to the way things are.
The photographs of the brothers Morgan and Marvin Smith, now seen in a superbly presented show at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, represent a deliberately selective, best-foot-forward portrait of urban black life in America from the 1930's through the 50's. 
 Poverty, violence and catastrophe are left out. Accomplishment of every kind is celebrated. Yet woven throughout the preponderance of up-tempo images are harsher stories -- of rejection and exclusion, of battles lost and others only narrowly won -- and in some ways they are all the more moving for their discreet, oblique delivery.
The 150 photographs on view were the work of a pair of identical twins born in the rural town of Nicholsville, Ky., on Feb. 16, 1910. Children of sharecroppers, they moved with their parents to Lexington in 1922 and attended the city's only black high school. Their interests in painting and photography were encouraged, and after graduation, they made their way to New York.
Even during the Depression, Harlem sustained the close-knit creative network that had coalesced in the Harlem Renaissance a generation earlier. The Smiths landed day jobs with the city parks department and studied art in the free school founded by the sculptor Augusta Savage. But it was in commercial photography that the Smiths found a career, which, whatever the divisions of labor, they regarded as collaborative.
Their first pictures from the 1930's were on-the-spot shots of local political and social events and of human-interest street scenes, which they submitted to black newspapers. In 1937, a shot by Morgan titled "Robert Day Playing Hi-Li" won honorable mention in a national amateur photo contest, and he was hired by The Amsterdam News as its first staff photographer.
A few years later, however, the Smiths opened their own photo studio next to the Apollo Theater on 125th Street, a location that insured a steady and often illustrious clientele. Entertainers, community leaders and aspiring actresses alike sat for portraits. At the same time, the brothers continued to document the world around them -- its nightlife and politics, weddings and celebrity visits -- and in the process distilled an extraordinary panorama of American life.
"Harlem: The Vision of Morgan and Marvin Smith," culled from the Schomburg Center's photographic archives and the Smith family collection, captures the shape and tenor of their output, beginning with street-level images of uptown life. A subway conductor leans, smiling, from the A train, smartly dressed churchgoers crowd a sidewalk on Easter Sunday, gravity-defying Lindy hoppers shake up the Savoy Ballroom.
It would be difficult to know from these pictures alone that the 30's and 40's were a bad time for black people in America, socially and economically, though elsewhere hints of that reality come through. They are evident in the image of strikers picketing against discriminatory hiring and housing practices, and in an unforgettable portrait of the actress and writer Fredi Washington, wearing an anti-lynching arm band with the chilling emblem of a silhouetted head in a noose.
Portraits like Washington's make up the bulk of the Schomburg show. Many are in classic studio format, scrupulously lighted and posed; others were taken on the fly. But there's no question that a virtual Who's Who of black America at mid-century is on hand.
Counted among the political icons, for example, are W. E. B. DuBois, George Washington Carver (elderly, shy, bright-eyed), the historian Carter G. Woodson and Mary McLeod Bethune, the daughter of former slaves and founder of the National Council of Negro Women.
The writers and performers include well-known figures: Langston Hughes at his typewriter, performance shots of Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald and Fats Waller. But especially memorable are the off-beat surprises: Bill "Bojangles" Robinson tapping his way up Broadway on his 61st birthday, Josephine Baker distributing candy to children, a lithe young Maya Angelou in her days as a Pearl Primus dancer.
Pictures of athletes form a third celebrity category, from Jackie Robinson intently teaching his young son how to hold a bat, to the heavyweight champ Joe Louis sparring in a ring at a training camp. But this shot, like many others, hides a disturbing subtext. Because black journalists were barred from the press box at public athletic events, training camps were the only places the Smiths could observe Louis in action up close.
In fact, despite the cosmopolitan embrace of the Smiths' photographs -- Pablo Picasso, Albert Einstein and Marlene Dietrich are among their subjects -- the world they had immediate access to was narrowly restricted. And while their portraits of New York "firsts" (the city's first black police trooper, first black telegram messengers, first black woman juror) were clearly intended as proud salutes to achievement, they are also sobering reminders of racial barriers slow to fall.
And yet these portraits of precedent-setters are wonderful. Direct, unsentimental, they present their subjects as exactly what they were: everyday heroes, citizens, neighbors and friends down the block who, through a combination of circumstance, intelligence and stick-to-it-iveness, ended up as stars in the ways that really matter.
One gets the same impression of the Smiths themselves in the documentary record of their lives installed in the Schomburg's lobby gallery by the exhibition's curatorial team of Howard Dodson, Retha R. Onitiri, Monica Smith Jr., Roberta Yancy and Mary Yearwood. It includes family photos, paintings, sculptures, journals and documents of the brothers' work in film beginning in the 1950's. There are even examples of needlework produced by Marvin Smith since he retired in 1975. (He still lives in Harlem; Morgan died in 1993.)
Altogether, "Harlem: The Vision of Morgan and Marvin Smith" makes a fascinating tale, and the Schomburg has done a fine job telling it. Most of the photographs are accompanied by succinct, fact-filled texts drawn from a collection of the Smiths' work recently published by the University Press of Kentucky. (The book, lovingly produced, with essays by Gordon Parks Sr. and James A. Miller and a wealth of historical information, is a beauty.) In short, to everyone involved in organizing the project, congratulations are extended, and to the artists, many thanks.
"Harlem: The Vision of Morgan and Marvin Smith" remains at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the New York Public Library, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard at 135th Street, Harlem, through March 29.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Robert Day Playing Hi-Li" (1937), shot by Morgan Smith. (Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture)

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International;
Sports Cars Europe Keeps for Itself

BYLINE: By JAMIE KITMAN 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, England

 BODY:
NOT long after it was invented, the automobile became a prime instrument of human expression. For almost a century, motorists have selected personal transportation in the belief that what they drove held meaning beyond its function.
Today, sport utility vehicles are imagined to confer an aura of action, adventure and environmental awareness on their owners, even if most of their time is spent idling in traffic jams. In an earlier age, drivers who wanted to stand apart often chose sports cars, typically two-seat roadsters with superior handling, performance and economy. 
 Before World War II, the sports car was a toy for the wealthy and a prop for Hollywood stars. But in the postwar years, English marques like MG, Jaguar, Triumph and Austin-Healey, along with Italian nameplates like Alfa Romeo and Fiat, brought affordable sporty motoring to the masses.
With their emphasis on efficient packaging, sure handling and responsive controls, these cars were anomalies in an era of ever-heavier land yachts, Sensing the emergence of a new market, Chevrolet responded with the 1953 Corvette. Ford followed two years later with the two-seat Thunderbird.
The two-seat sports car faded in the 70's and 80's, but signs of its wide-scale return are plentiful. Mazda's nimble Miata was introduced with virtually no competition in 1989 and went on to become the best-selling sports car in history, a development that seems to have switched on the industry's recessive sports car gene. Recent, highly successful introductions of the BMW Z3, Porsche Boxster and Mercedes-Benz SLK suggest that some of the world's leading manufacturers believe the pendulum will reverse.
 Paradoxically, in light of Americans' stature as the world's largest consumers of sports cars, European enthusiasts have some wonderful choices not available in the United States, and more are on the way. A few may eventually make it across the Atlantic in somewhat modified form, though for now a passport is required to sample any of these diminutive driving machines. Furthermore, the huge expense to certify European-market cars for American safety and emissions standards makes it nearly impossible for individuals to buy these cars overseas and bring them home.
 
ALFA ROMEO SPIDER -- Alfa Romeo pulled out of the United States in 1995, and there is no evidence that it plans to come back. Still, a weekend in England in a four-cylinder Spider convinced me that if Alfa ever chose to reverse course, this would make a credible vehicle to spearhead a return.
Front-wheel drive now, with a striking convertible body from the Pininfarina design house and a chassis derived from a Fiat cousin, the Tipo hatchback, Alfa's latest Spider is a roomier, wider and considerably more comfortable car than the rear-wheel-drive machine it replaced. While Alfa's ergonomics were once the butt of jokes, the new Spider can comfortably accommodate a variety of human bodies.
Not as exquisitely precise as the finest rear-wheel-drive cars, including some of the great Alfas of the past, the Spider is nonetheless very satisfying to drive. Its 150-horsepower, variably timed four-cylinder engine offered brisk acceleration and smooth operation on English country lanes, with none of the flat spots or tuning mysteries of its predecessors. The lead-footed will prefer the optional V6, but the added performance comes at the expense of extra weight and slightly less agility.
The new Alfa sells in Britain for the equivalent of $30,000. Its lines are modern Italian design at its most kinetic, offering a vision of a modern sports car with nary a nod to retro cliches, a remarkable achievement in a segment largely consumed with visual tributes to the past.
 
FIAT BARCHETTA -- Alfa's parent company, Fiat, is remembered fondly by some Americans -- and less so by others -- for its 124 and 850 Spiders and the mid-engined X 1/9. Fiat has now returned to the sports car fold with the retro-looking but up-to-the-minute Barchetta.
It, too, is a treat to drive, with the looks and moves of a sports car, the thrifty ways of an economy hatchback and none of its ancestors' tendency to start rusting on the showroom floor. Based on the floor pan of the front-drive Fiat Punto subcompact and featuring the 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine from the larger Bravo, the Barchetta has sold well in Europe at around $20,000.
It will not be sold in the United States at all. In spite of American sales that once exceeded 100,000 a year, Fiat withdrew from the market in 1983. Although Fiat's high-end brand, Ferrari, has done well in North America, the small profit margins of a car like the Barchetta make it too costly for Fiat to meet Federal requirements and re-establish a sales channel.
 
LOTUS ELISE -- This light, Spartan car has a gloriously retro skin of molded fiberglass. Beneath the surface, however, lies a clever and notably modern machine that sets new standards for road-holding and inspires considerable technical interest to boot.
With an extruded and bonded aluminum space frame, it is the boldest expression ever of Lotus's signature devotion to light weight. Partly as a result, lowering one's self into the car is a formidable task for those over 25 years old. The seats, also in the name of heft excision, are barely cushioned.
With just 1,570 pounds to lug around -- some 500 less than a Miata -- the 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine, mounted transversely in the middle of the car, puts the Elise's off-the-line acceleration in the muscle car league. And that is despite its mere 120 horsepower.
The Elise may make make it across the Atlantic in a few years, though company managers are said to be debating what added luxuries Americans would want and what type of redesign this might require. If the build quality is good -- and it was on a car I drove last year -- and if the Elise's basic price in Britain of $27,300 makes the journey overseas, the Elise could do nicely in America.
 
MGF -- Perhaps the best of Europe's practical new sports cars is the MGF, which has sold well in Britain at a starting price of around $24,000. Despite its petite size and demure silhouette, it is quite the best MG ever built. Its road-holding and handling are extraordinary, thanks to the mid-engined placement of its 1.6-liter four-cylinder and an unusually rigid body.
BMW, which acquired rights to the MG name (along with those of Triumph, Austin-Healey and several other British golden oldies) when it purchased the Rover Group, has said it is considering returning to the United States with the MG nameplate in the new century. But the MGF -- which was designed before the BMW takeover -- will not make the trip.
BMW says the car cannot be made to comply with Federal standards. But the company also has its own roadster, the Z3, for which it does not need more competition.

LENGTH: 559 words

HEADLINE: Pope's Unanswered Request: Put Christmas Back in Cuba

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 11

 BODY:
When they met for the first time a little more than a year ago at the Vatican, Pope John Paul II asked Fidel Castro for a Christmas present: the restoration of Dec. 25 to Cuba's calendar of public holidays.
Since then, one Christmas has gone by. Now, with another less than two weeks away, and only one month to go before the 77-year-old Pope makes his long-awaited trip to one of the world's last Communist redoubts, Mr. Castro has yet to reply. 
 "I don't know if next week we will have a response," said Enrique Gonzales, a spokesman at the Cuban Embassy to the Holy See. "We can't say whether it will be a reality. It is a political decision that will be taken at a high level."
In the intervening silence, the Vatican seems to be stepping up the pressure on the Cuban Government on this and other outstanding details about the Pope's five-day visit, which is to start on Jan. 21. At a news conference in Havana on Tuesday, Jaime Cardinal Ortega repeated the Pope's request for a Christmas holiday, and asked again for live access to the state-run media during the Pope's tour.
As a master of the political surprise, Mr. Castro may make his decision on the Christmas holiday at the last minute, Cuba experts say. "I wouldn't be surprised if the President, as a gesture of good faith, makes these changes to the calendar," said Bishop Roberto Gonzales, of Corpus Christi, Texas, a close observer of the Roman Catholic Church's lurching recovery in Cuba.
The Cuban Government has already ceded on some points pressed by the Vatican before the Pope's trip. It has granted more visas to visiting priests and nuns, and has agreed to let Cardinal Ortega appear on state television to explain the scope of the Pope's coming visit.
The Pope, who will spend each night of his stay in Havana, is scheduled to make day trips to Santa Clara, Camaguey and Santiago de Cuba, and to conclude his visit with a Mass in Havana's Revolution Square. He is due to have a private meeting with Mr. Castro on Jan. 22, at the Palace of the Revolution.
One key issue, raised by church officials during negotiations between the Cuban Government and the Vatican over details of the trip, is the provision of public transportation to and from the Pope's far-flung Masses and public appearances, in a country of uncertain bus service.
But of all the final points still awaiting an answer from Havana, none has the symbolic power of Christmas -- a holiday that was excised from the Cuban calendar in 1969, at a time when the island was pushing to bring in a record sugar-cane crop.
Now, unlike in every other country in the Western Hemisphere, on Dec. 25 Cuban children go to school and their parents to work.
Before the 1959 revolution, Cuba was predominantly Catholic. In the Communist era, the Cuban church has been stifled by the one-party state; its properties were nationalized, its schools were closed, many of its priests were jailed.
Still, Cuban authorities insist that dropping Christmas from the calendar was not intended as a blow against the church. "It was a problem of 30 years ago, when the revolution was still under way," said Mr. Gonzales. "It was also for economic reasons," he added, noting that the celebration of the revolution takes place a week after Christmas, on Jan. 1. "It was difficult to have people not working for so many days."

HEADLINE: Asian Import Prices Plunge By Extremely Strong 1.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
As holiday shopping reaches full swing, the Asian financial crisis is helping drive down the price of imports to this country, with goods from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore dropping by an exceptionally strong 1.2 percent in November, the Government reported today.
These products account for 11 percent of all imports to the United States. Japan, whose products were three-tenths of 1 percent less costly last month, accounts for an additional 17 percent. 
 "For American consumers, it's a great deal," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at the Fleet Financial Group in Hartford.
With inflation already down to about 2 percent -- even less when allowance is made for overstatement -- the Federal Reserve has been able to avoid raising interest rates to keep inflation at bay.
And the turmoil in Asia is another reason for the Fed to make no change in interest rates, despite the tight labor market, because lower American exports to Asia should cut economic growth next year by half a percentage point or more.
Higher rates, analysts said, would not only aggravate the Asian distress by further weakening Asian currencies but would also risk slowing the American economy too much.
Indeed, more evidence emerged that the economy was slowing on its own. Retail sales climbed a lackluster two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said. This was only enough to erase a same-size decline the month before.
"The consumer has slowed down a good bit from the third quarter," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist for Prudential Securities. He added, however, that while pent-up demand for cars and other vehicles had been satisfied, strong consumer confidence and ability to buy were likely to prevent a slump.
Still another Government report today showed that the labor market remained tight. First-time claims for jobless benefits totaled 311,000 last week, with the four-week average edging down 500, to 318,250.
But it was the falling cost of imported goods that captured much of the attention. Over all, these prices retreated three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the most since some sharp declines at the beginning of the year because of a skidding price of oil. Not counting petroleum, import prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month to bring the 12-month decline to 2.3 percent.
The biggest change was the 1.2 percent drop in Asian prices, which was the biggest since the Labor Department began keeping monthly records in 1992 and four times the average decline for August through October.
"There is a great deal of incentive for these countries to export their way out of trouble," said Greg Mount, international economist at First Chicago NBD. The dollar's strength relative to their currencies makes this possible.
China, the chief foreign source of toys and holiday decorations, is lumped in the statistics with "developing countries," a category that showed a nine-tenths of 1 percent price decline last month. A worldwide product grouping of toys, games and sporting equipment showed no price change last month after small declines in the three preceding months when the bulk of seasonal goods arrived.
Importers of the goods, some of which are only components, might pass on part or all of their lower costs to consumers.
The retail sales results, covering one-third of the economy, showed increases of two-tenths of 1 percent for both durable goods -- cars and other items designed to last at least three years -- and nondurables. Total spending was $213.82 billion in November, 3.8 percent more than in November 1996 without any adjustment for inflation.
Before seasonal adjustment, however, sales last month declined slightly. The Commerce Department's tally showed a 1.3 percent sales gain for merchants selling furniture and other home equipment, a two-tenths of 1 percent gain for automotive dealers and an eight-tenths of 1 percent decline for stores selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
Among nondurables, drugstores gained 1.8 percent, clothing stores 1.2 percent, food stores four-tenths of 1 percent and department stores and other general merchandisers one-tenth of 1 percent.
Receipts at gasoline stations fell five-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting lower prices, while those of restaurants and bars eased three-tenths of 1 percent.
