HEADLINE: Transformation in the Bronx

 BODY:
The new South Bronx was on display this week when President Clinton visited spanking-clean neighborhoods that were burnt-out relics as recently as 15 years ago. Dismembered by highway construction in the 1950's, abandoned by the middle class in the 60's and torched by arsonists in the 70's, the Bronx was salvaged by community groups that rousted drug dealers and reclaimed the borough street by street. Nonprofit organizations then developed thousands of affordable homes and apartments, using state, city and Federal funds in concert with programs that allow corporations to reduce tax liabilities by contributing to projects for the poor.
Mr. Clinton was right when he called the Bronx a national model for urban revitalization. But with all levels of government doing less in housing, the tax credit program has had to carry more and more of the burden. The obvious success in the Bronx has encouraged participation from banks that would have avoided the borough in the past. Financial institutions have now contributed $250 million to an equity fund jointly developed by the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the Enterprise Foundation, the country's two largest operators in the low-income housing business. In partnership with New York City, these two organizations will build 5,000 new units over the next three years. In addition, they are now exporting Bronx know-how to other communities in New York City and across the country. 
 In the Bronx itself, the next step is to employ Federal loans in an attempt to replace businesses that fled during the fire and chaos of the 1970's. Creating businesses is more difficult than building houses. But if the participants work as diligently during the next decade as they have in the past, the enterprise has an excellent chance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clock Ticks at Trade Talks With Focus on U.S. Demand

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 11

 BODY:
All eyes are now on the United States, as negotiators from more than 100 countries try to hammer out a global trade agreement here to remove national barriers in banking, insurance and securities by midnight Friday.
In a role that is becoming almost typecast, the United States is once again playing the world's bad cop by threatening to walk away from a treaty unless it gets what it wants. The United States is demanding that countries in Asia and Latin America make it easier for American financial companies to do business there. 
 Today, trade officials and business executives here predicted that the countries would reach a deal. Having walked out of the last round of talks two years ago, the United States has already pressured dozens of countries to sweeten their commitments on opening their markets.
American officials said that at this point the odds favored a deal, but that a successful outcome was by no means a certainty. They said they had received encouraging offers from a number of countries, but that they still had problems with others, including Japan and Malaysia.
But this time the gamesmanship has been clouded by two new problems: the financial crisis sweeping Asia and anger among some American politicians toward the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based organization that would enforce the trade agreement. Last week, a panel of the W.T.O. infuriated members of Congress when it rejected the Eastman Kodak Company's high-profile complaint about barriers to the Japanese film market.
A lot is at stake. International bond offerings have doubled in the last five years and will probably total $1 trillion in 1997, according the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. Companies now list their shares on stock exchanges around the world, institutional investors have ballooned in size and international currency trading runs to more than $1 trillion every day.
Although the United States, Europe and Japan now have relatively open financial markets, countries in Southeast Asia and Latin American giants like Brazil remain much more closed. It is still illegal for foreigners to have majority control of banks or brokerage firms in Indonesia, and many countries hinder foreign companies with regulations from which local operators are exempt.
The Asian crisis may actually nudge countries toward agreement. With currency and stock markets plunging from Indonesia to South Korea, leaders from Asia and the United States worry that a collapse of the talks might further alarm investors.
Though a few countries like Malaysia have angrily blamed international currency speculators for their problems, most Asian countries have offered more liberal terms for an agreement out of heightened desperation to increase confidence among foreign investors.
The Asian crisis has also complicated the American bargaining position. The biggest fights as the deadline approaches are between the United States and countries like Korea and Malaysia. But trade negotiators say the American negotiators have not been as truculent as usual, apparently because they are worried about pushing too hard on behalf of United States business.
The second new complication arises out of American politics. Spurred in part by the ruling against Kodak, which had complained that Japanese business arrangements prevented it from obtaining a bigger market share in that country, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, warned the Clinton Administration not to enter any deals that would "unwisely handicap" American companies.
Negotiations have also been bogged down in a fight involving Malaysia and the big American insurer American International Group Inc. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who has stridently blamed international speculators for derailing Asian currencies, has steadfastly refused to let foreign companies own more than 51 percent of Malaysian insurance carriers.
A.I.G., based in New York, owned 100 percent of several insurance companies before that restriction ever went into effect. Though A.I.G. has not been told to reduce its ownership, it has insisted that Malaysia include an explicit "grandfather" clause in its trade proposal -- a demand that Malaysia has refused.
Under the negotiation process, each country puts forward its own offer of the rules it will adopt within its borders. The countries do not have to agree on the same rules; they simply make a legal commitment to stick by the rules they put forward. The agreement goes into force if the countries attending find each other's proposals acceptable.
Because the American market is so big, the operating premise for all negotiators is that there can be no agreement without the United States. If the countries fail to reach an agreement by midnight Friday, they can revoke their offers and the negotiations will come to an end.

HEADLINE: Havel's Silver Tongue Lashes Out at Czech Political Scandals

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, is one of the world's most sought-after speechmakers. He has made speeches, with soaring ideas and rich language, before European business leaders, American students and Asian human-rights advocates.
But this week, when Mr. Havel turned toward the political crisis at home, what he had to say was anything but lofty. 
 In his annual speech to Parliament on Tuesday, according to a transcript, Mr. Havel directly attacked a situation in which power was "again in the hands of untrustworthy figures whose primary concern is their personal advancement instead of the interests of the people."
He lamented a state in which the "biggest success could be achieved by the most immoral." And he questioned the "strange role" of Czech banks: "They indirectly own companies that are operating at a loss, and the more the companies lose, the more money the banks lend them."
Mr. Havel did not mention Vaclav Klaus, the Prime Minister, who was forced to resign last week because of a financial scandal in his Civic Democratic Party. But it is clear that Mr. Klaus, who has been criticized by financial experts at home and abroad for privatization policies that have led to widespread corruption, was his prime target.
Soon after Mr. Havel finished speaking, Mr. Klaus hit back, saying the President failed to understand "the functioning of a market economy and a free society eight years after the fall of Communism."
Mr. Havel's searing speech was almost as much of a political sensation as the fall of Mr. Klaus.
Not all of the President's admirers approved of it. The former Interior Minister, Jan Ruml, who like Mr. Havel was a dissident during the Communist era, said the speech was too harsh. "We are not all criminals," Mr. Ruml said, referring to the Civic Democratic Party, of which he is a member.
Others asked why Mr. Havel had not tried to influence Mr. Klaus's economic strategies two years ago when corruption among Czech business executives involved in the privatization of state companies became evident.
In a vexed tone that he maintained through his hourlong speech, Mr. Havel chastised Czech politicians for excessive pride and unnecessary provincialism.
But Mr. Havel did not limit himself to the economic and political turmoil. He emphasized what he called the poverty of "human relations" and "culture" in the Czech Republic.
"I am afraid this is a sphere where we have most of our debts to pay and most of our work to do," he said. "Culture in the broadest sense is not measured by the number of splendid rock stars who visit this country, or by the beauty of dresses by prominent designers presented here by world-class models."
Instead, he said, culture is measured by what is "chanted by skinheads in a pub, by the number of lynched or murdered Romany people, by the dreadful behavior of some of our people toward their fellow humans simply because of the different color of their skin." Romany is what many Gypsies call themselves.
He also criticized the Government for failing to convince Czechs of the wisdom of joining NATO. "It is all the more unfortunate that we have so far seemed unable to convey this message to our citizens convincingly enough," he said. "Maybe this was also due to the unfortunate emphasis on pure economy."

HEADLINE: Worry on Asia Sends Stocks Down Again

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market tumbled for the fourth straight session yesterday as worries spread that the economic slowdown in Asia would depress corporate earnings. But some stock analysts argued that other, potentially bigger problems were beginning to arise in the United States.
Before Wall Street opened, sharp declines in the world's major stock markets set the tone for the day. Investors looking to reduce their risk helped push the yield on the 30-year bond, a traditional haven, briefly below 6 percent. It ended the day at 6.00 percent, down from 6.07 percent. 
 In the stock market, technology issues accounted for much of the pain. I.B.M. fell 4 7/8, to 101 5/8; Intel Corporation was off 2 7/8, to 71 13/16, and Microsoft declined 3 3/16, to 139 1/16. After the market closed, a Federal judge ordered the company temporarily to stop a controversial market practice that antitrust officials are seeking to halt. General Electric, down 1 1/4, to 72, also led the stock market lower. All of these companies get a significant portion of their revenues from abroad.
But Asia did not do all of the damage. The Quantum Corporation, the disk drive maker, said its third-quarter earnings would be well short of expectations because of falling prices for hard drives, something analysts attribute in part to oversupply and a decline in domestic demand for computers. Quantum's stock fell 3 7/8, to 19 15/16.
Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, acknowledged that Asia's slowdown would be a drag on big corporations that do business there, but said he is more worried about the United States next year. Slower sales growth here and rising costs, like wages, could reduce earnings.
"I see a lot more bombs in domestic companies," he said, referring to companies that derive most of their earnings in the United States. Earnings disappointments being pinned on Asia may really be a result of problems in the United States, he added.
For example, he said he was surprised by the problems in the United States business of the Oracle Corporation, whose stock fell 29 percent after announcing on Monday that its earnings would not meet expectations. Oracle fell again yesterday, ending at 21 15/16, down 1 1/2.
No one is denying the impact of Asia's financial crisis, which some economists are saying could shave a full percentage point off United States economic growth next year.
Among the industries considered vulnerable are financial services. Bank stocks tumbled again yesterday as investors considered a stream of reports, including J. P. Morgan's on Wednesday, that showed an earnings disapointment.
Mr. Acuff noted that stocks were coming under additional pressure from portfolio managers who were trying to protect their good returns for the year. This means that many of them are selling now to avoid losing any more of their gains if the market continues to tumble.
In trading yesterday, the technology-heavy Nasdaq index got the worst of it, plunging 2.4 percent, or 38.07 points, to 1,558.54. The Dow Jones industrial averge fell 1.6 percent, or 129.80 points, to 7,848.99. And the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 1.5 percent, or 14.85 points, to 954.94. In the last four days, the S.& P. has lost all it gained last week when the index reached a new all-time high Friday.
In Asia, South Korea's composite index slumped 5.6 percent, while the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong plunged 5.5 percent. In Japan the Nikkei index dropped 2.6 percent. The major markets in Europe were down about 2 percent or more, with the Financial Times index in London off almost 95 points, to 5,035.90; the DAX index in Frankfurt down 100 points, to 4,016.70, and the CAC index in Paris almost 104 points lower at 2,828.45.
For the last several weeks the battle in the stock market has been between hope versus Asia, and this week Asia has won out.
The rally that took the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks to a high last Friday seemed to be built on the hope that Asia's woes would slow U.S. economic growth enough so that the Federal Reserve would not have to raise interest rates but not so much as to hurt corporate earnings.
But this week investors have heard warnings from Oracle, Quantum and J. P. Morgan.
The Asia story, said Douglas R. Cliggott, U.S. equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, was "front-loaded with good news but backloaded with bad news."
James Clunie, the investment manager at Murray Johnstone International in Glasgow, said, "The markets want to go up because there is a lot of money to be put to work, but they are now facing harsher and harsher fundamental news."
Though off from the October pace, inflows into stock mutual funds were strong last month. The Investment Company Institute yesterday estimated the net inflows at $13.5 billion, down 26 percent from the previous month. The report attributed part of the decline to withdawals from international stock funds.
The report also showed heavy buying of bond funds, with an estimated net inflow of $8 billion in November, up from $3.7 billion in October. The conversion of some unit trusts to bond funds contributed to the $8 billion increase, the I.C.I. noted.
Robert Adler, the president of AMG Data Services, which also tracks mutual funds, said he had also picked up a strong surge in bond funds, with the pace picking up to an average of $1.2 billion a week for the four weeks ended Dec. 3.

HEADLINE: Kennedy Presses Democrats to Focus on the Needs of Families

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Senator Edward M. Kennedy called upon Democrats today to use the nation's economic vigor to help struggling families secure higher wages, good educations and basic health care.
The Senator from Massachusetts scoffed at reports of a rift between the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, and President Clinton, saying the party's internal differences were trivial compared to its differences with the Republicans. 
 "The American people don't care about New Democrat or Old Democrat," said Mr. Kennedy, the party's best-known liberal, adding there is room for differing views. "They care about the quality of their lives."
"If this country can't fulfill the hopes and answer the needs of average families in a time of peace and prosperity, when will we ever do so?" Mr. Kennedy asked. "If as Democrats, we are true to our principles, we will seize this opportunity to shape a common agenda that unites us across any differences around the values that are the very ground of our party's being."
Speaking at the National Press Club, Mr. Kennedy proposed a Democratic agenda in Congress next year.
First off, Mr. Kennedy said, he plans to push for increases in the minimum wage, which was raised to $5.15 an hour two years ago after battles between Democrats and Republicans. Under his plan, the minimum wage would be increased to $6.65 an hour by the year 2000, and then be tied to the cost of living.
Mr. Kennedy said inflation continues to outpace the minimum wage, making it almost impossible for families to make ends meet. Full-time minimum-wage workers earn $10,712 a year, he said.
"I'm optimistic that we will succeed," Mr. Kennedy said, "because Republicans have learned that it is dangerous to resist a Democratic increase in the minimum wage in an election year."
As lawmakers maneuver to stake out positions on next year's ground-breaking tobacco legislation, Mr. Kennedy renewed his push to raise the Federal tax on a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 to help curb teen-age smoking.
That increase, Mr. Kennedy said, would raise $20 billion a year for medical research and children's programs, including Head Start, but would also set off a blitz by the formidable tobacco lobby.
This summer, Mr. Kennedy along with Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, beat back the tobacco lobby to win a 15-cent tax increase on tobacco to help finance children's health insurance.
Mr. Kennedy said he would re-introduce a bill that would require every employer to contribute to the cost of health insurance for workers and their families. The initiative would be tied to a health care "Bill of Rights" meant to protect patients from the more egregious aspects of managed care, he said.
It is one issue that Republican leaders believe "is getting away from them," Mr. Kennedy said, referring to abuses in managed care.
The Senator also attacked a showcase Republican proposal to simplify the tax code by creating a flat income tax or a national sales tax.
Mr. Kennedy advocated a saving of a different kind, zeroing in on the Social Security payroll tax. At present, all wage-earners pay a tax of 6.2 percent into Social Security on wages up to $65,400 a year. He proposed removing the cap, so all wages would be subject to the tax. The move would lower the tax rate by 5.3 percent, he said, and provide a tax cut for people who earn less than $80,000 a year. Wealthy people would contribute a higher share.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Talk of Tougher Medicine for Korea's Ills

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
A week after the world came to South Korea's rescue with $57 billion in emergency aid, the country's economic troubles have worsened so rapidly that officials here fear that far more drastic steps may be needed to stop financial hemorrhaging that is already threatening world markets.
The initial financial bailout organized by the International Monetary Fund, with the United States and Japan agreeing to provide a second line of defense if needed, was called a "stabilization package." But so far, the result has been closer to financial panic. By late tonight, the South Korean currency, the won, had fallen 34 percent since Dec. 3, the day the bailout was announced -- more than it fell for 1997 through the beginning of this month. 
 Because the I.M.F. required officials in Seoul to disclose monetary statistics that were previously hidden -- forcing them to acknowledge that the country was nearly out of cash to pay short-term debts -- credit-rating agencies downgraded Korean debt to a level close to junk-bond status.
That, in turn, is undercutting the main objective of the I.M.F. in the country's rescue program: to convince private investors that it is safe to lend money to South Korea and to its humbled industrial giants. Without that confidence, the Korean Development Bank was forced to back away today from a $2 billion bond offering intended to alleviate an acute repayment crisis.
In public, American officials maintain that markets always go to extremes and that if South Korea enacts the financial changes it promises, investors will be back.
In private, though, they are rattled. When the United States bailed out Mexico in 1995, the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo quickly took Draconian steps. But South Korea is seven days away from a presidential election, in which leading candidates are promising in newspaper advertisements to renegotiate some of the terms of an international deal that many Koreans regard as humiliating.
And until a new government is assembled, a senior Clinton Administration official said, "there is almost no one in authority to talk to."
Instead, there is growing distrust -- and sometimes open hostility -- between Washington and a seemingly paralyzed Government in Seoul.
"In Mexico, we were dealing with an economic team that was outstanding, with a longstanding relationship with the country's President and economic decision-makers who were competent, well knit and long established," said Jeffrey R. Shafer, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a key official in arranging the Mexican bailout. "They played a major role in reassuring the markets by taking some very stiff steps."
No one in the Clinton Administration is using such phrases to describe the lame-duck Government of President Kim Young Sam. Relations between President Kim and American officials have been strained for years, chiefly over Mr. Kim's wavering about how to deal with a suspected North Korean nuclear program.
But relations have reached new lows in recent days, especially after Seoul's new Finance Minister, Lim Chang Yuel, used an interview with The New York Times to appeal to the United States and Japan to provide their backup financing immediately. That created a sense in the markets that the South Korean financial situation had turned dire.
Such statements have prompted many investors -- including some in South Korea -- to move their money out of the country quickly. The result is a cycle in which bad news begets a faster rush for the exits, which in turn worsens Korea's cash squeeze.
So far, the country's immediate problem lies in the crushing debts of its banks and huge industrial groups, known as chaebol, rather than in Government debts. The Government itself, experts note, is relatively free of debt, making this situation dramatically different from the crises that afflicted Mexico in 1994-95 or several Latin American countries in the 1980's.
Yet there is talk about the possibility of a national default, out of fear that the Korean Government will cave in to political pressure and rescue failing institutions -- a step toward which Japan is headed. The difference is that Japan has a war chest of more than $230 billion in Treasury bonds and other reserves to turn to. South Korea has none.
To market professionals, the answer seems obvious: Officials in Seoul have to let failing enterprises fail, the first step toward rationalizing a bloated economy and insuring that investors who made poor decisions pay the price. But market professionals do not have to worry about Korean politics, pride and culture, as Korean politicians do.
In Seoul, the capital, it has always been difficult to discern the difference between the Government and the giant steelmakers, car companies, semiconductor producers and banks. The businesses have long been directed by South Korea's industrial planners. And in turn, they have financed the country's military leaders and, for the last decade, the two Governments that were freely elected.
Those connections are not easily broken, especially in a country like South Korea, where economic strength and national strength are considered inseparable.
And with an election seven days away, there is a clear expectation there that the new government should step in to prevent bankruptcies and mass layoffs. That is exactly what the I.M.F. wants to head off.
American officials were alarmed when the Finance and Economy Ministry said this week that it would invest nearly $1 billion in two failing banks, giving the Government 59 percent ownership in those institutions.
"It was one of a series of dubious decisions," an American official said today, "that have been surrounded with a lot of ill-though-out pronouncements."
Investors are responding to a flood of disclosures about South Korea's low foreign-currency reserves, misleading statements about the size of its foreign debt, and hesitation to take politically unpopular steps before the election.
If there are no more surprises, and no major bank failures that begin to shake other emerging markets, the worst could be over.
A more pessimistic possibility is that more surprises are buried inside a Finance Ministry known for extraordinary secrecy, and that Korea's new government may balk at the possibility of a public backlash against austerity. In that case, last week's $57 billion package could come to be known as the first South Korean bailout.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE CLIMATE ACCORD: THE OUTLOOK;
Despite Pact, Gases Will Keep Rising

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In a corner of the tiled tunnel leading from a subway stop to the Kyoto International Conference Hall, the kindergarten children of Kyoto left a message for delegates to the climate conference here this week.
Their message was an assemblage of miniature trees and flowers accompanied by a small sign. "The Kyoto people are praying for the success of this conference," the sign said. "The future of all people, especially the children, depends largely on the outcome of this conference." 
 But even if it is ultimately ratified, the agreement to cut emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases that emerged today from 10 days of high-stakes politicking will not secure those children, or their children, from the climatic disruptions that mainstream scientists say lie ahead. Participating countries could obey its emission limits to the letter, and atmospheric levels of the gases, produced chiefly by the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil, would continue to rise.
The Kyoto Protocol does make a start, however. It would establish at least the foundation of an institutional framework and accompanying mechanisms for dealing with the problem in coming decades. And it signals business and industry that the issue is here to stay, that the ways in which energy is produced and used must change, and that these issues should be taken into consideration in planning and investing for the long term.
The burning of coal, oil and natural gas, the energy mainstays of the modern economy, produces waste carbon dioxide that remains in the atmosphere, trapping heat. If nothing is done to limit emission of these gases, scientists advising the delegates here say, the earth's average surface temperature will rise by 2 to 6 degrees Fahrenheit by 2100 if the world pursues business as usual. (By comparison, the world is now only 5 to 9 degrees warmer than in the depths of the last ice age.) The scientists say this much warming would bring rising seas, more severe droughts, rainstorms, heat waves and floods, together with broad shifts in climatic and agricultural zones that would benefit some regions but seriously harm others.
The Kyoto Protocol legally binds industrialized countries to cut their greenhouse emissions, collectively, by an annual average of about 5 percent below 1990 levels for the period 2008 through 2012 -- a 30 percent reduction below what they would otherwise be. Some are to cut more than that, some less, and a few will be allowed to let their emissions grow because of special circumstances. Among the industrialized big three, the United States must reduce its emissions 7 percent below 1990 levels, the 15-nation European Union 8 percent and Japan 6 percent.
But even if the countries adopt and adhere to these standards, an uncertain prospect, they will only be slowing the accumulation of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere. As a result, many experts believe that it may already be too late to avoid serious climatic disruption, that the task ahead is one of keeping it from becoming truly catastrophic.
Although there are dissenters, many scientists now predict that unless far more drastic action is taken, atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide, the major contributor to climate change, will double sometime late in the next century from the pre-industrial levels of the late 18th century.
Atmospheric levels of cardon dioxide are now about 360 parts per million, and many experts say it will be difficult, if not impossible, to stabilize them at 550 parts per million, close to a doubling of pre-industrial concentrations. Though it is difficult to predict exactly what climate changes would result from such a doubling, there is wide agreement that they would be highly disruptive.
Predictably, the fossil fuel industry warned that the Kyoto cuts would bring economic pain, while some environmentalists said they did not go far enough. Other environmentalists and many business interests hailed the protocol as a solid agreement that would make the economy more efficient and boost growth in the long term. Only time will tell who is right.
What seems clearer is that ordinary Americans will notice little immediate impact on their everyday lives. If it is able to win Senate approval of the agreement, the Clinton Administration intends to phase in domestic measures to meet the Kyoto target over time, starting with the provision of financial incentives, tax cuts and cooperative government-industry efforts to accelerate the use of energy-efficient technologies.
After a decade or so of experience, according to the Clinton plan, the United States would inaugurate the centerpiece of its emissions-cutting strategy and a principle hard-won here: emissions trading. Under this arrangement, a cap would be set on permissible carbon-dioxide emissions. Companies that reduce their emissions more than required could sell the excess emissions, at a profit, to those that exceed the cap.
The Administration argues that use of this mechanism for reducing industrial emissions of sulfur dioxide has shown that it achieves more emissions cuts at lower cost.
But emissions trading emerged as one of the most contentious items here, almost torpedoing the talks. After a bitter 11th-hour debate, the developing nations agreed to an international trading mechanism for developed countries. But they fear that trading would allow rich countries to buy their way out of reduction obligations, so it remains to be seen whether they will agree to the regulations necessary to make it work. The issue will be debated in the next round of climate talks, scheduled to begin in Buenos Aires in November.
Another innovative mechanism approved here is an international fund through which rich countries could invest in specific emissions-saving projects in developing countries. The two countries involved would share in the resulting emissions credits.
Apart from that, the Kyoto agreement did little about the future involvement of developing countries. While everyone recognizes that their growing greenhouse emissions will ultimately require them to submit to binding limits, the poorer countries have refused to accept them until the richer countries show the way with action. The question remains a subject for future negotiations.
Because the new protocol does so little about developing countries, it is unclear whether the Administration will sign it, and there are very grave doubts that the Senate would approve it. But President Clinton has said he will proceed with his domestic plans for emissions reduction in the meantime. Beyond that, the Kyoto Protocol is about the long term, and the United States could join it at any time in the years immediately ahead if conditions are right.
The 10 days of sleepless negotiations may well have established a adjustable instrument that in coming decades can respond to emerging new knowledge about both the science and economics of the problem -- if the governments of the world buy into it seriously.
Should they do so, the descendants of those Kyoto kindergartners and others like them throughout the world may have cause to be grateful.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT A GLANCE: The Climate Accord"
REDUCTIONS -- Thirty-eight industrial nations are required to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases below 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012. The European Union would reduce emissions by 8 percent, the United States by 7 percent and Japan by 6 percent. Some countries would face smaller reductions, and a few would not face any now. As a group, the nations would cut emissions of such gases by slightly more than 5 percent below 1990 levels.
GASES INVOLVED -- Emissions of six gases would be affected: carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and three halocarbons used as substitutes for ozone-damaging chlorofluorocarbons.
TRADING EMISSION RIGHTS --Countries that do not meet their own emission targets can strike deals with nations that do better than required, to buy the excess quota. This may encourage reductions to be made where they are most cost-effective. Details of this plan will be negotiated at a meeting next November in Buenos Aires.
ENFORCEMENT -- A later meeting of the treaty parties will decide on appropriate and effective ways to deal with noncompliance.
DEVELOPING COUNTRIES -- Developing countries, including major greenhouse-gas emitters like China and India, are asked to set voluntary reduction targets.
RATIFICATION -- The accord approved by the Kyoto conference takes effect once it is ratified by at least 55 nations that represent at least 55 percent of 1990 carbon dioxide emissions. The terms are binding on an individual country only after its government ratifies the accord.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Korea Delays Bond Sale, Rattling World Markets
The crisis in South Korea worsened as the country's largest state-owned bank abruptly postponed an important bond sale, meaning that South Korea must come up with other ways to pay or renegotiate billions of dollars in debts coming due in the next few weeks.
 
 The delay of the $2 billion bond sale rattled financial markets around the world and raised the possibility that South Korea might become the first Asian nation to default on its debts since an economic crisis began in the region last summer. Page A1.
 
Asian Import Prices Fall
The Asian financial crisis reduced the price of imports to this country from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore by 1.2 percent in November. It was the sharpest drop since the Labor Department began keeping monthly records in 1992 and four times the average decline for August through October. Products from the four account for 11 percent of all imports to the United States. Another Government report said retail sales climbed a lackluster two-tenths of 1 percent. D2.
 
Bank Wins New Power on Bonds
A Salt Lake City bank, Zions Bancorporation, has won approval from Federal regulators to use a new system to underwrite municipal revenue bonds. The system allows national banks to establish or expand subsidiaries to market new products and services, which could include securities and insurance products. Zions's application could be the model for other banks to follow. D2.
 
Japan Bailout Plan Gains Support
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan appears to have prevailed in winning over support in his party for a plan to raise 10 trillion yen to bolster the Japanese banking system. Opposition to the plan within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party faded after Mr. Hashimoto promised that none of the money would be used for a tax cut or some other stimulant that violated the party's pledge of fiscal austerity. D4.

Global Finance Trade Pact Advances
Negotiators from more than 100 countries are trying to work out a global trade agreement to end barriers in banking, insurance and securities before the deadline Friday. Trade officials and business executives in Geneva predicted yesterday that the countries would reach a deal. D5.

Kyoto Accord's Impact
The Kyoto agreement on controlling gases that contribute to global warming will, if approved by the Senate, have a sweeping impact on business and consumers. Solar and wind power and other alternative energies may become more cost-effective if fossil fuel prices rise sharply. A16.
 
Nasdaq Reins in Bulletin Board
The National Association of Securities Dealers moved to impose new rules on OTC Bulletin Board, the forum for the shares of almost 7,000 tiny companies. The Bulletin Board is also home to most of the stocks that have played starring roles in some highly publicized securities frauds in which investors have lost millions. Market Place. D8.

Safety Conference on Light Trucks
Many vexing problems concerning the safety of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks were discussed at a two-day meeting of nearly 200 auto industry engineers and regulators in Dearborn, Mich. A1.

KPMG Sues Consulting Rival
KPMG Peat Marwick sued Stern Stewart & Company, contending that it was unfairly trying to stifle competition in a new area, economic value added management. D2.

HEADLINE: Diamond District Tries to Dispel Its Private Bazaar Image

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
It is just a block of 47th Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, but its importance in the international diamond trade has been equated for 50 years to that of Wall Street in stocks and bonds and Broadway in the musical theater. So is the luster of 47th Street fading?
Apparently so, according to several of the more than 100 diamond merchants, cutters and industry executives who braced against a chilly bluster yesterday to watch Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani inaugurate the city's newest, and by far its smallest, business improvement district. 
 Like the more than 35 other districts established by commercial property owners around the city, the 47th Street Business Improvement District will pay for several new services -- private security guards, street cleaning and the installation of new diamond-shaped street lights -- that are intended to enhance property values.
But the comparisons basically end there.
Executives said the impetus for such a designation on 47th Street, where more than 2,500 diamond industry companies are crammed into a single block, has less to do with real estate values and more to do with image.
They point to a block still perceived by many as a seller's bazaar, where zealous merchants employ a centuries-old sales technique: using price tags as a mere starting point for bargaining and sometimes leaving customers uneasy with such traditions feeling shunned or exploited.
Several merchants said yesterday that one of the chief purposes of the new district is to make 47th Street more attractive to retail customers, who in the past have been far outnumbered by wholesale buyers.
"We have been too closed," said Richard Winick, a partner in Manny Winick and Son, one of the block's retail staples. "There are a lot of people who would walk into Tiffany's and pay $15,000 for a diamond without even visiting 47th Street, and that is something we have to address."
The president of the newly formed district, Howard Herman, one of the street's most prominent diamond merchants, said the image of 47th Street as a bastion of Jewish control and tradition has become both inaccurate and harmful to business.
"The problem is not who we are," Mr. Herman said. "The street is a very diverse place, with people from India, China, Puerto Rico and other countries, but somehow there is a lasting impression among the public that in order to be in the diamond business you have to wear a long black coat and a beard."
Such was the subtext among those who gathered for what has become a typically boisterous appearance by Mayor Giuliani, this one featuring praise for the improvement district's founders while he posed for the assembled news photographers in an offbeat version of a ribbon-cutting.
Instead of a ribbon, the Mayor went through the motions of cutting a large diamond, one which had been so painstakingly prepared for him by 47th Street's professionals that he needed only tap it like a boiled egg for it to split neatly in two.
"We plan to make the diamond district sparkle once again," he said, unable to resist the pun.
But perhaps more symbolic of the district's approach is the background of the executive it has hired as the only full-time staff member: Terrence Clark, an African-American whose 20-year career has been in jobs programs and economic development agencies of New York State and the Federal Government, not in the diamond industry.
"The major idea is to make this a better business environment and a friendlier place for buyers," he said yesterday. Mr. Clark said that part of his job would be to field questions from tourists and shoppers who are unfamiliar with the dense layout of 47th Street's shops and showrooms, many of them two or three stories above street level.
Among the immediate plans of the district, whose members have agreed to pay $900,000 for street improvements and services, are to erect four 30-foot-high pylons -- two at each end of the block -- that would support large diamond-shaped lights.
Mr. Clark said those fixtures, and other new street lights along the extent of the block, would be installed in the spring.
The district has hired a four-member private security force to patrol the block during business hours, he said, and will soon employ a sanitation worker to pick up litter.
But while those services are similar to what are being offered by other business improvement districts, where property owners simply augment the work of the city, other projects planned by the 47th Street group go further. In order to attract wholesale diamond buyers who attend trade shows at the Jacob K. Javits Center, Mr. Clark said, the group plans to provide shuttle buses when the shows are in session.
And to attract retail buyers from outside New York City, he said, it plans a marketing campaign to encourage travel agencies and tour companies to include the diamond district on the itineraries of visitors.
"Why not include 47th Street on tours just like Lincoln Center or Madison Square Garden?" he said.
To be sure, the 47th Street diamond merchants have not lost their distinction as one of the nation's most highly concentrated industries.
According to the Diamond Dealers Club, a group of 2,000 executives, most of them based on 47th Street, more than 95 percent of the diamonds imported to the United States last year were first handled on the street, either to be cut into finished jewelry or sold in the street's retail shops and wholesale showrooms.
For those who know the rules of the street, the sheer volume can mean bargains. "From what I can see, you are paying far less than retail here," said Margaret Ruden, a Manhattan cosmetics industry executive who was shopping for jewelry on 47th Street late yesterday.
"But you have to be an educated buyer," she said. "People can be deterred if they are not familiar with New York City."
And the diamond merchants who have created the new 47th Street district said it is precisely those who are not familiar with the city -- or at least the rules of their street -- whom they need to attract.
"If you just look up and down this street you find an unparalleled selection," said Michael Eigen, a diamond merchant whose grandfather and great-grandfather preceded him on 47th Street. "But we have to find a way to attract more new faces."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The diamond center on West 47th Street in Manhattan has an image slightly tarnished by the practices of some of its dealers. Now it will try to put a gloss on itself. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Korea Situation Deteriorates, Raising Specter of a Default

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN with ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
South Korea plunged deeper into crisis yesterday when its largest state-owned bank abruptly postponed an effort to raise $2 billion to help pay billions of dollars in debts due in the next few weeks.
The postponement raised the specter that South Korea might become the first Asian nation to default on its debts since an economic crisis began to engulf the region last summer. 
 Reaction to the postponement was swift and brutal in the financial markets, which viewed it as another sign of lost confidence in South Korea and alarm over Asia's spreading malaise. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 129.80 points, or 1.6 percent, to 7,848.99, its fourth-straight decline. At the midday break today in Seoul, the Korean stock market's main index was off 6.1 percent to its lowest level of the year, following a 5.6 percent drop yesterday, and the Korean won fell to its fifth-straight record low.
 Officials in Washington now fear that far more drastic steps may now be needed to stop the hemorrhaging that is threatening world markets. News analysis, page D1.
The decision by the Korea Development Bank to delay the sale of bonds came barely a week after the nation signed a record $57 billion bailout agreement designed to restore global investor confidence.
South Korea must quickly come up with other ways to pay or renegotiate billions of dollars in debts coming due before the end of the year, because it is only entitled to a small portion of the International Monetary Fund bailout money for now.
The Korea Development Bank's $2 billion offering had gained great political significance over the last two days, becoming a litmus test for investor confidence in the fundamental health of the South Korean economy.
Up until yesterday afternoon it looked as if the bank would proceed with the sale. But it suddenly changed course because of indications that few buyers were willing to buy the bonds, at least without a double-digit interest rate usually associated with the sale of risky, speculative-grade "junk bonds." That was evidently too onerous or embarrassing for the influential bank to stomach.
The fact it was shelved was a strong indication that despite the I.M.F. rescue plan signed Dec. 3, the investment community still does not believe South Korea has addressed the welter of economic and political problems that have produced the country's most wrenching financial crisis since it first emerged more than a decade ago as one of Asia's fast-growing "tigers."
To make matters worse, the Thomson Financial Services Company, the world's largest bank credit rating agency, downgraded South Korea's sovereign risk rating, noting a "deepening liquidity crisis" and the "increasing prospect of the recent I.M.F. emergency package being insufficient to meet the country's short-term financial obligations."
"As a result of these intensifying volatilities and mounting short-term liquidity problems, domestic money and capital markets have become nearly paralyzed and credit lines have become virtually frozen," Thomson said.
Standard & Poor's, another major credit rating agency, also downgraded the debt ratings of once seemingly stellar South Korean corporations like the Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation, the Korea Electric Power Corporation, SK Telecom, Hyundai Motor and Samsung Electronics.
A glaring weakness in South Korea's finances is a lack of foreign exchange to pay loans denominated in foreign currencies. The South Korean won has lost more than half its value against the dollar this year, declining by 30 percent in December alone.
Thomson justified its downgrade partly from I.M.F. estimates that put South Korea's usable foreign exchange reserves at just $6 billion, down from $30 billion at the end of October.
Finance Minister Lim Chang Yuel, in a news conference with foreign news media in Seoul yesterday, tried to talk up the value of the won, saying the currency had overshot its appropriate level.
Mr. Lim also said South Korea's situation was not as dire as analysts said. The nation now has about $10 billion in usable foreign currency reserves, he said, up from $6 billion on Dec. 2. By the end of this month, he said, South Korea will have received another $3.5 billion from the I.M.F., $2 billion from the Asian Development Bank and at least $2 billion from the World Bank. In addition, foreign banks operating in Korea have committed $2 billion in securities transactions known as swap deals.
But amid this tangled crisis came K.D.B.'s unsuccessful bond offering. The proceeds from that offering were part of South Korea's financing plans.
There was no lack of initial blue-chip support for the offering. It was managed by J. P. Morgan & Company, a premier investment house, with assistance from the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company, two other titans of American finance.
But despite the willingness of such powerhouses to get behind the bond offering -- an international conference call with 600 participants, including K.D.B. representatives and officials from South Korea's Ministry of Finance, was convened yesterday morning to pitch it to investors -- the interest rate needed to get it off the ground did not sit well with K.D.B., according to people close to the offering.
The bond offering was structured so that the securities would mature in 10 years but permit investors to exercise a one-time option after three years of selling the bonds back to K.D.B. at face value. That alone was had considerable allure for investors skittish about South Korea's prospects.
Some investors and analysts said the bond offering, coming amid such market uncertainty, was poorly timed. There was also frustration that K.D.B. and Ministry of Finance officials were not apparently ready to disclose more details to investors about all of the fundamentals affecting South Korea's economy.
A banker close to the transaction, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the offering was a "screw-up" because the officials did not recognize a "need to be completely forthcoming about the situation in South Korea."
During the conference call, a Ministry of Finance official told participants that South Korea had $116 billion in external debt at the end of November, with about $62 billion of that short-term debt, compared with $122 billion in external debt at the end of October, of which $68 billion was short-term. Nonetheless, the official was unable to provide details about exactly when South Korea's short-term debt comes due, other than to say he believed that less than $2 billion would mature by the end of this month. The lack of detail frustrated at least one participant on the call, who was concerned that the Government did not have a better grasp of its debt schedule.
Although Morgan declined to comment, people close to the offering said that K.D.B. was advised last week not to pursue it because of pricing problems. These people said the Korean bank insisted on following through with the transaction until it became apparent that the bank could not avoid paying high interest for it to work.
In Seoul today, Kim Won Geun, deputy general manager of K.D.B.'s international finance department, said the failure of the bond issue would not put the bank in danger of default on roughly $1.6 billion in short-term debt, providing its credit lines stayed open and the loans it made to Korean companies were repaid. But he conceded that many industrial companies were in a bad position to repay loans. Indeed, some of the money from the bond offering was to be injected into the industrial companies.
All of this occurred against a backdrop of mounting concern about the dimensions of South Korea's problems and a weak response to other changes the country was making to attract foreign investors and capital.
As of yesterday, foreign investors were allowed to own 50 percent of a Korean company, up from 26 percent.
It has been estimated that South Korea has about $20 billion in short-term debt coming due by the end of the year. Mr. Lim, the Finance Minister, while not mentioning any figures, told reporters in Seoul that he had talked to foreign banks and that some were now committed to renegotiating the debt.
If foreign banks forego calling in their loans, South Korea should at least get through December without defaulting. "Foreign bank sentiment has turned for the better," said Kang Tae Hil, deputy general manager of international sales at Daewoo Securities in Seoul, who said he talked with some foreign banks yesterday afternoon.
One factor continuing to make foreign investors nervous is a suspicion that South Korea will not adhere to the I.M.F. agreement, which calls for more market forces to be introduced into a state-directed economy. Seoul recently pumped more than $2 billion into two ailing commercial banks to avert their failure, an action some analysts say violated at least the spirit of the I.M.F. agreement.
Foreign investors have also been spooked by the fact that Kim Dae Jung, a front-runner in the race to become the next president, has taken out front-page ads in major newspapers vowing to renegotiate the I.M.F. agreement if he is elected on Dec. 18.
Mr. Kim, hoping to capitalize on popular resentment toward the I.M.F., backed down a bit after newspapers and other politicians criticized his stance as contributing to financial market turmoil.
Lee Kyong Shik, governor of the central Bank of Korea, was reported to have tendered his resignation yesterday. Mr. Lee himself would not confirm it.
One government official in Seoul said the announcement of the resignation was put off because it coincided with a nationally televised speech by President Kim Young Sam accepting responsibility for the crisis, and would have been awkward for him to dismiss the central bank governor the same day.

HEADLINE: THE CLIMATE ACCORD: THE IMPACT;
Whether It Creates Jobs or Joblessness, the Agreement Will Affect Everyone

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
To Scott Sklar, the executive director of the Solar Energy Industries Association, nothing could be better for business than an agreement on controlling gases that contribute to global warming.
Already, the solar business is booming, and with tax and research subsidies its growth might go from 27 percent a year to 40 percent, he predicted, and the price of clean electricity from the sun could drop by 25 percent. 
 In the niche of the economy that aims to replace coal, oil and other sources of carbon dioxide, the main gas implicated in global climate change, "the United States could create 400,000 new jobs by 2010, equal to the largest U.S. corporate employer," he said.
But Mary H. Novak, vice president of Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, an economic consulting firm engaged by industry groups opposing the climate change treaty, says her forecasts predict job losses in the millions.
"The coal mining industry in this country will be wiped out," she predicted. "Agriculture, manufacturing and transportation will all be seriously affected. Farm incomes could be cut by as much as 50 percent."
Whoever is right, every American uses energy, almost everybody wastes it, and its price affects every product's costs. So nobody can escape the repercussions of the treaty that was emerging in Kyoto -- assuming that the binding new protocol is signed by the United States, after it is approved by the Senate.
The Energy Department, in a study by five national labs, found that with aggressive research, new technologies aimed at meeting Kyoto's goals could be brought to market. But for many of them to be cost-effective, fossil fuel prices would have to rise the equivalent of 12.5 cents per gallon of gasoline to help stimulate most of the emissions savings the treaty envisions. Further price increases would bring even more exotic technologies into play.
Wind power, for example, is getting more cost-effective and in some places is close to under-pricing fossil fuels, said Terry Peterson, manager of green power marketing at the Electric Power Research Institute, an organization financed by the energy industry.
"The prospects of getting the costs down through a combination of further technology development and larger scales of production are very good," he said.
But asking how much energy will cost in 10 or 15 years, or which technologies will win the race to replace coal, is like predicting the price of a cellular phone in the year 2010.
Perhaps in the future all new schools will use geothermal heat pumps for cooling and heating, the way the new Choptank Elementary School in Cambridge, Md., did this year. The devices can cut greenhouse gas emissions by 40 percent compared with conventional technology, and Dorchester County, Md., expects to save $400,000 in energy and maintenance costs at the school in the next 20 years, according to a consortium of businesses that is pushing the technology.
Perhaps the American Power Corporation, a Boston utility, and the Electric Power Research Institute of Palo Alto will achieve a breakthrough in the field tests they announced last week of a small fuel cell to produce electricity at home. Fuel cells cleanly and efficiently convert natural gas and other fuels to electricity. Their device is expected to cost $5,000 and is big enough to easily provide the energy needs of a typical household.
More energy consumers and producers will make such novel choices, presumably, if the cost of fossil energy goes up in the next 10 or 15 years, when the treaty's terms would effectively put a lid on the nation's emissions of carbon dioxide.
The auto industry would be profoundly affected, since gasoline consumption is the biggest single factor, and the fastest growing, in American emissions of carbon dioxide.
And the industry might risk billions of dollars in losses if emissions are capped, because virtually all its profits come from making large sport utility vehicles and light trucks that use much more gas than cars.
But even a big vehicle can be made more fuel-efficient.
The Ford Motor Company predicted in a recent study for the Energy Department that it could make an electric van using fuel cell technology that would get 32 to 34 miles a gallon, more than twice the Econoline model's current performance. And the engine, the study said, could be mass-produced at a price competitive, if not quite on a par, with today's internal combustion engines.
The other big source of carbon emissions is coal burned by electric utilities, which generate 56 percent of the nation's power that way.
The Edison Electric Institute, an industry trade group that represents most of the private utilities in the nation, estimated in a study that it would cost the industry close to $30 billion to convert most of the coal burning capacity to plants that would produce power by burning natural gas, which would produce steam to drive turbines.

HEADLINE: THE CLIMATE ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON ADAMANT ON 3D WORLD ROLE IN CLIMATE ACCORD

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The White House, beginning the arduous task of selling an accord to reduce emissions of climate-altering gases, said today that it would not submit the proposed treaty for Senate ratification until developing countries agree to participate in the global environmental effort.
But developing countries at the global climate-change conference that just ended in Kyoto, Japan, said they would not act until they see the rich countries succeed in cutting their own emissions. And many members of the Senate are already saying it has no chance of passage. The accord is dependent on Senate approval. 
 At the insistence of China and other developing countries, the Kyoto conference imposed no requirements on newly industrialized countries and created only limited mechanisms for their inclusion in global efforts to curb so-called greenhouse gases.
The developing countries delayed a compromise that would have allowed the United States and other major polluters to buy or trade emission credits from countries whose emissions are within acceptable levels, and therefore avoid making significant cuts in emissions in a compressed time period.
With Senators denouncing the accord as not tough enough on developing countries, the stage was set for a yearlong political fight with the Clinton Administration, which has embraced the outlines of the deal.
The developing countries' objections provide Mr. Clinton with additional time to muster his arguments in favor of the treaty and an opportunity to portray himself as a defender of the United States' interests. For the next year -- an election year -- he is in the risk-free position of being able to make a strong pro-environmental political pitch while not having to face a damaging vote in the Senate.
President Clinton defended the agreement as "environmentally strong and economically sound," even as Administration officials were admitting that its flaws made it unacceptable to the Senate.
Mr. Clinton is likely to either win credit for tackling a difficult problem or pay a huge political cost for misjudging the public's appetite for sacrifice, even if doled out in small portions over many years.
The outcome of the debate and the political impact on Mr. Clinton and Vice President Gore are yet to be seen. But it is certain that Congress and the American people will be subjected to millions of dollars worth of lobbying and advertising in the next months by powerful coalitions that support and oppose the proposed treaty. Already, both sides are making sweeping claims about the dangers of global warming and the high cost of proposed solutions. Among the President's most difficult jobs will be to help the public decipher those assertions and bring pressure on Congress to take action on a matter over which there is still wide disagreement.
"The game is afoot," a senior White House aide said today.
In an appearance at a Coast Guard station in Miami, the President acknowledged that he faced the difficult political and diplomatic job of persuading the American people and leaders of developing countries that the threat of global warming is real and requires immediate action.
"There's still a lot of challenges ahead," Mr. Clinton said.
Even if the countries that agreed to the targets set in Kyoto begin taking steps to reduce so-called greenhouse gases that mainstream scientists believe are warming the earth's atmosphere, concentrations of these emissions will continue to rise for many years. Mr. Clinton and others say that a potential catastrophe in the next century will be averted only by concerted global action beginning now to cut emissions.
Officials in Washington said the Administration would not put the treaty before the Senate before 1999 at the earliest, after a meeting in Buenos Aires late next year aimed at persuading developing countries to accept the Kyoto agreement's limitations on emissions of greenhouse gases. That timetable would also postpone some of the ratification debate beyond the 1998 Congressional midterm elections. President Clinton has until March 1999 to decide whether to sign the proposed agreement.
"As we have said from the very beginning, we will not submit this for ratification until there's meaningful participation by key developing nations," Vice President Gore said at a Washington news conference today. Administration officials did not define "meaningful participation," saying that it was a matter for months of bilateral and multilateral discussions.
Mr. Gore added that the Administration had ruled out tax increases to meet the obligations of the treaty. And he said that the Administration would soon propose a $5 billion package of tax incentives and research grants to move the country onto a more energy-efficient path.
One senior White House official, who insisted on anonymity, said it was possible that the treaty would not be ready for submission to the Senate during the remainder of Mr. Clinton's term in office.
Despite the Administration's go-slow approach, domestic opponents of the accord continued to rail against its terms, saying that it meant colder homes, a shrinking economy and higher gasoline prices.
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, said the United States "surrendered" to pressure in Kyoto and called the proposed treaty "an outrage." He said the accord would cripple the American economy.
"Early reports from those in attendance indicate that on 10 critical issues such as cuts in emissions, future developing country commitments and new U.S. commitments, we sacrificed the future well-being of the country based on environmental correctness and inconclusive science," Mr. Gingrich said. "It is profoundly wrong that approximately 134 countries were allowed to vote on a treaty by which they will not be bound."
"Mr. President," the Speaker asked, "is this putting America's interests first?"
Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of oil-rich Oklahoma, called the Kyoto accord "a political, economic and national security fiasco" that will never be ratified by the Senate in any form.
Mr. Inhofe, in a news release, said that the failure to secure binding commitments from developing countries meant that the agreement fell far short of the standard set in a 95-to-0 Senate vote earlier this year. Among its flaws, he said, was the lack of an exemption for military vehicles and operations.
"They went to Kyoto determined to get a treaty for its own sake, regardless of the content," Mr. Inhofe said. "What they have come back with is scientifically dubious, economically disastrous and militarily stupid. Yet I don't doubt their determination to try to make it all politically saleable."
Indeed, that is the challenge facing the President and the Vice President as the debate over global warming moves into a new phase that will likely keep the issue before the public well into the 2000 Presidential campaign.
Mr. Clinton insisted that the United States can make a start toward reducing its emissions without disrupting the economy or reducing the country's standard of living.
"I see already the papers are full of people saying, 'The sky is falling, the sky is falling, it's a terrible thing,' " Mr. Clinton said. "Every time we've tried to improve the American environment in the last 25 or 30 years, somebody has predicted that it would wreck the economy. And the air is cleaner, the water is cleaner, the food supply is safer, there are fewer toxic waste dumps. And the last time I checked, we had the lowest unemployment rate in 24 years.
"So don't believe the skeptics" Mr. Clinton said. "Give us a chance to make the case."
Congressional committees are preparing now for hearings next year on the Kyoto accord and the broader question of the severity of the peril of global warming and how to address it.
Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said United States negotiators failed in Kyoto to achieve any of their major objectives and came home with a document that makes unacceptable demands on the domestic economy for questionable benefits.
Mr. Lugar compared the climate negotiations with Mr. Clinton's defeat on "fast-track" trade negotiating authority, which the House last month rejected because a majority of Democrats did not believe the President's promises to insure environmental and labor protections in future trade agreements.
"The President needs to spend some time explaining to the American people the validity of his arguments on global warming," Mr. Lugar said. "He didn't make the case on fast track and he hasn't even begun to make the case on climate change. And now he has to explain how the U.S. negotiators botched it in Kyoto."
Mr. Gore, whose presidential ambitions will hinge in part on how the public perceives his role in the global warming debate, appeared mindful of the political risks of the coming months and made an effort to move the issue out of the partisan arena.
In a White House news conference, the Vice President said: "In the coming days and months, it will be critical that we avoid looking at this effort through a narrow political lens. Too much is at stake. We must focus instead on the longer-term future of our planet and our economy, and on the health and well-being of our families and communities.
"This is not a Democratic or a Republican problem, nor is it a problem for any one nation alone," Mr. Gore continued. "It is a problem for the entire world. The stakes are simply too high, environmentally, economically and morally, for us to allow the special interests to get in the way of the common interests of all mankind."

HEADLINE: Don't Ignore Immigration's Benefits to the U.S.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George J. Borjas and Richard B. Freeman, in their Dec. 10 Op-Ed article on the economic impact of immigration, write as if the United States economy operated in isolation and American immigration policy could be constructed as if its major influences stemmed from within our borders. In fact, the United States must respond to global pressures. The skills, contacts and labor of immigrants help assure the viability of American companies, securing employment for both newcomers and native-born workers.
Mr. Borjas and Mr. Freeman also exacerbate social tensions when they write, "The critical issue is how much we care about the well-being of immigrants compared with that of the Americans who win and the Americans who lose." It is divisive and inaccurate to posit an inevitable competition between immigrants and Americans. 
 Immigrants are part of the same families as natives and become part of our society. The businesses they create benefit us all. Only by falsely conceiving of them as outsiders can Mr. Borjas and Mr. Freeman focus on the problems rather than on the contributions they have made and will continue to make to this society.
 
GARY E. RUBIN
New York, Dec. 10, 1997
 
The writer is assistant executive vice president for public policy, New York Association for New Americans.

HEADLINE: Don't Ignore Immigration's Benefits to the U.S.;
Glue of Our Society

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Leave it to two economists to reduce the immigration issue to economic growth factors and natives versus immigrants (Op-Ed, Dec. 10). Certainly the United States cannot admit immigrants without regard to economic considerations. But why do American politicians persist in presenting immigration in almost exclusively economic terms?
American society is largely held together by the glue of shared ideals that are political, not cultural. Most of this country's finest universities seek out international students because their unique perspectives foster intellectual growth. Why not then view immigrants as potential invigorators of the democratic system and as people who bring cultural offerings that cannot be measured monetarily? 
 If there is one "critical issue" in the immigration debate, it is not relative material well-being but that the debate reveals a country where making money has supplanted political ideals. The country of immigrants has become a country of capitalists.
 
MEGAN MC CARTHY
San Francisco, Dec. 10, 1997

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
City to Sell Parcels of Land

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
New York City is about to sell a little bit more of itself.
Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, announced yesterday that the city will sell 1.2 million square feet of land and commercial space in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan. 
 "By privatizing city-owned land, the city is encouraging development, increasing its revenues and creating jobs for residents," Mr. Millard said.
He said many of the sites are in a federally designated empowerment zone or state economic development zone, which means significant tax abatements and other incentives are available for developers.
The sites are eligible for the city's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, which is a tax exemption-abatement program based on the value of improvements to the land. Most of the sites are eligible for Federal and state wage tax credits, investment tax credits, utility rate reductions, employee training benefits and tax-exempt bond financing.
About a quarter of the sites, or about 277,000 square feet, are in central Harlem. The Bronx sites are near the Whitestone Bridge and in Morrisania. In Brooklyn, several industrial sites are being sold in the East New York In-Place Industrial Park.
Since July 1, 1995, the city has sold 48 pieces of property for $408 million as part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's privatization agenda. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:

'Lines of Loss'
Artists Space
38 Green Street
SoHo
Through Jan. 10
Mexico is producing a staggering amount of new art of all kinds, and bit by bit some of it is trickling into New York. The five participants in this show, all of whom are making their local debuts, were selected by the artist Gabriel Orozco, and like him they offer a witty, materially economical conceptual art with, here and there, a melancholic edge and a mild political bite. 
 Damian Ortega, who has worked as a political cartoonist, is represented by two videos. In one, he slices into a golf ball so that its innards writhe out as if disemboweled; in the other he dresses in a funky black-and-silver Christopher Columbus-as-Darth Vader outfit to wave to motorists from a highway bridge in Mexico City.
Mr. Ortega's sendups of death and history find an echo in Gabriel Kuri's piece, which uses withering funeral bouquets to spell an abbreviated form of the word abbreviation (i.e. abbrv.). Guillermo Santa marina evokes a sense of existential malaise in a plastic chaise lounge that emits a mournful cascade of notes when stroked, and in a volume of poetry by the 60's guru R. D. Laing, whose psychological mind-twisters get a reality check in the form of bookmarks made from laboratory slides of human and animal tissues.
The brothers Manuel and Mauricio Rocha concentrate on ambiance rather than objects. The first, Manuel, fills the gallery's bathroom with the sounds of retching, burping and flushing, as if the plumbing had indigestion; the second, Mauricio, cuts holes in the gallery walls so the Artists Space staff and visitors have no place to hide. Like their irreverent colleagues here, the Messrs. Rochas get a lot out of a little. With luck, they'll make a return trip soon. HOLLAND COTTER

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 39; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk
