HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Portrait of the Machine Age, With Guessing Game

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
The exhibition "Images From the Machine Age: Selections From the Daniel Cowin Collection," at the International Center of Photography, opens with a photograph of one large-toothed gear attempting to mesh, improbably, with a small-toothed gear. The picture, "Out of Mesh," taken by Mannie Lovitch, an amateur photographer from the Bronx, serves as a metaphor for the whole show: here is a machine whose parts do not fit together but that is nonetheless intriguing in its misfitting parts.
Chronologically, the machine age runs from the 1920's through the 30's, and esthetically it includes anything having to do with machines and manufacture. It has ties to Surrealism, Constructivism, Futurism, Art Deco and Bauhaus design. And its characteristic subjects are gears, smokestacks, factories, cities, workers, repetitive patterns, machine-made artifacts and machine-made angst. This exhibition embraces every one of these types and definitions and then throws in the kitchen sink for good measure. 
 No kidding about that kitchen sink. Inexplicably, the show includes Marion Post Wolcott's photograph of "Mrs. Rosa Wilkins Making Biscuits, Granville County, N.C.," a woman working near a kitchen sink. The only thing machine-age about this picture is that it was taken in 1939. And it is not the only oddity exhibited here.
The show also includes a close-up of a cactus, a snapshot of a chain gang, a picture of a sleepy street in Cody, Wyo., and a moody portrait of a woman veiled in lace. Such misfits, though, are not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, some of the fun of seeing the show is trying to guess why in the world certain objects were chosen.
Some of the misfits expand the concept of the machine age. Others simply reflect the tastes of Daniel Cowin, an investment banker and collector of photography, Art Deco objects and American folk art, who died four years ago. The show includes his brass bookends, colored buttons, papier-mache busts and wooden tea trays as well as his photographs, drawings and lithographs.
Many of the photographs are just what you would expect to find in a machine-age show: pictures of cranes and lathes; playful photocollages of mechanical bodies; photograms of manufactured objects; vertiginous shots of the Empire State Building, including one spireless view by Man Ray; Berenice Abbott's spectacular night picture of New York taken from the top of the Empire State Building; Brassai's view of cars on a Paris street; a Constructivist book cover by El Lissitzky; William Rittase's comical picture of a tiny mechanical object taking a bow before gears, and a few slickly shot pictures of slickly manufactured objects, including a pair of Bausch & Lomb binoculars and a pointy can of Eel-Skid oil, both casting long, suggestive shadows.
The grand obsession of the era was mechanical reproduction. And there are some beautiful examples here: Albert Renger-Patzsch's detail of a cheese grater with its deep black holes and surface scratches; George Daniell's picture of the construction of the George Washington Bridge with reinforcing rods poking up repetitively out of the concrete; Josef Sudek's endless loop of stacked teacups and, best of all, Wynn Richards's grid of wooden matchsticks on a flat white surface, backlit so powerfully that, in a curious reversal, the heads of the matches look dull, while the sticks glow.
Mass production was clearly the order of the day. So how did Georg Trump's still life of a misshapen orange get into the act? And what about Jack Delano's picture of a trompe l'oeil cow enclosed in a trompe l'oeil barn?
The show includes not only various thematic misfits but a handful of chronological trespasses, too: Frantisek Drtikol's dreamy shot of figures ascending a stair in 1911; Ilse Bing's bird's-eye shot of a street sweeper in Paris in 1947, and Charles Pratt's sea of men in coats and ties walking onto the Hoboken ferry in 1955. But at least these anachronisms feature faceless workers.
One of the recurring worries of the machine age was that workers themselves were beginning to look like mass-made objects. Hans Casparius's photograph of shadows descending a staircase shows the workers as shades. And Dorothea Lange, by shooting one of San Francisco's unemployment lines from above, turned the men into hats and coats.
These were not the only rips in the neat fabric of manufacture. The exhibition includes a number of photographs of posters torn in significant ways. One of Walker Evans's photographs is of a minstrel poster whose rips reveal the tigers and lions of a Barnum & Bailey poster underneath. And John Vachon photographed an advertisement that was ripped to show a woman's face with its two halves rearranged: her smiling teeth at the top and one smiling eye at the bottom. The most violent dismemberment in the show, though, is Hans Bellmer's hand-colored photograph of the pieces of a doll, lying near a caliper in what appears to be blood.
The machine age was all about smooth efficiency. Documenting it never was.
"Images From the Machine Age: Selections From the Daniel Cowin Collection" is at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through Feb. 22.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Out of Mesh," a 1920's work by Mannie Lovitch, at the International Center of Photography. (International Center of Photography)

HEADLINE: John Fitting Jr., 81, Executive At Dreyfus and a Fund Pioneer

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
John Fitting Jr., a Dreyfus Corporation executive and pioneer in the creation of no-load mutual funds in the early 1970's, died Wednesday at his retirement home on Marco Island, Fla. He was 81.
The cause of death was prostate cancer, said his wife, Judith Kingsley Fitting. 
 In 1973, Mr. Fitting became the first head of Dreyfus Asset Management Inc., the company's first mutual fund. It was known as a no-load fund because there was no load, or sales commission, charged up front. The fund was sold directly to customers instead of through brokers.
When Dreyfus Asset Management and other funds like it were buffeted by the high inflation and economic dislocation of the mid-70's oil embargo crisis, Mr. Fitting was active with other fund managers in trying to reassure clients that the funds were not at risk of collapse from withdrawals by nervous investors.
The new mutual fund Mr. Fitting led required a minimum investment of $50,000 and charged a minimum management fee of $1,000 a year, high by today's standards. At the time, Mr. Fitting said he expected his fund to produce an average 9 percent annual return, compounded over five years.
Following his retirement from Dreyfus in the early 1980's, Mr. Fitting worked as a consultant to the American Can Company in its transition to the Primerica Corporation, the financial services company. In 1986, he joined the National Securities and Research Corporation, a mutual fund management company, as chairman and chief executive. He retired from that position in 1988.
Mr. Fitting was born in New York City, grew up in Westchester County and attended Dartmouth College but left before graduating to join the Marine Corps in 1939. He was a fighter pilot and a decorated squadron commander in the Pacific during World War II, his family said, and he earned his college degree from the University of Miami.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Fitting is survived by a daughter, the Rev. Wendy Fitting of Gloucester, Mass.; a son, Keith Fitting of Basking Ridge, N.J.; a brother, Paul Fitting of Pittsburgh; a sister, Virginia Demetrius of New York; four grandchildren, and two stepdaughters, Melinda Kingsley Nester of New York and Ellen Kingsley Hirschfeld of Houston.

HEADLINE: Honesty on Immigrants

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George J. Borjas and Richard B. Freeman, in their Dec. 10 Op-Ed article on the National Academy of Sciences report on immigration, attribute statements to me that I never made. They assert that I fail to mention that the bulk of the increase of the gross national product from immigration goes to the immigrants themselves. In fact, I go out of my way to make precisely that point. 
 They claim that I have argued that the drop in wages in low-skill jobs caused by immigration are good for the less skilled because it gives them an incentive to finish school. While these wage cuts do provide such an incentive, it would be absurd to argue that less skilled workers are better off, and I have never done so.
I am proud of the quality of scholarship and balance reflected in the report. The public presentations that my colleagues and I will continue to make on the report reflect that balance.
 
JAMES P. SMITH
Santa Monica, Calif., Dec. 11, 1997
 
The writer was chairman of the National Academy of Sciences panel on immigration.

HEADLINE: Asia Turmoil Proves Bullish For U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
There is much debate over the impact of the Asian financial turmoil on the stock market. Some analysts are worried, others are not. But for bonds, there is no debate. The Asian turmoil is great for bonds.
And this is not just because of the flight of foreign investors to the safe harbor they see in United States Government securities. More important, it is because of the drag that Asia is expected to have on inflation here, as slower Asian growth moderates United States growth and the stronger dollar cuts the price level of goods imported from Asia. 
 "The reason that it is good for bonds is that the No. 1 enemy of bonds is inflation," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company. "And it is impossible to stand up and tell an inflation story when one-third of the world is going to be cutting the dollar price of its products."
The power of the Asian impact -- combined with a surprise decline in prices at the producer level in November -- pushed the yield on the 30-year bond to 5.92 percent yesterday, down from 6.00 percent Thursday and its lowest level in more than four years. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 1 7/32, to 10227/32.
What makes this decline potentially more important than the last move below 6 percent is that many economists think that rates can hold at these lower levels, while the last two dips below 6 percent, in late 1995 to early 1996 and in 1993, lasted only a matter of months.
This year's bond rally, which has brought long-term rates down from 7.17 percent in April, has also reduced mortgage rates to their lowest level since February 1996. According to the Bank Rate Monitor, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 7.17 percent in their weekly poll through Wednesday. And if the decline in bond yields since then holds, mortgage rates should fall further.
But while long rates have fallen, short-term interest rates have not come down nearly as much, which means that the prime rate, which sets lending rates for many consumers and small businesses, has not budged from 8.5 percent since March. The stubbornness of short-term rates has also limited any savings for large companies with loans tied to other benchmark short-term rates.
Yesterday's assault on 6 percent was bolstered by the Labor Department report that prices at the producer level fell two-tenths of a percent and are now down to an annual rate of 1.2 percent through the first 11 months of the year. It is likely that the Producer Price Index for finished goods will show its first decline for a year since 1986. Producer prices rose 2.6 percent last year.
Despite the good inflation news, many analysts are still marveling at the decline in interest rates. They say there are other economic signals out there flashing red but they are being ignored, mostly because investors are convinced that the slower growth and lower inflation fallout from the Asian turmoil will turn those signals to green.
Currently the economy is growing near a 4 percent annual rate and there are signs of wage pressures building with the unemployment rate at a 24-year low of 4.6 percent. All these factors would normally be worrying bond investors, said Robert V. DiClemente, the chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. And they probably would have forced the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, either at its meeting in November or at its policy- making session Tuesday.
But no such move is expected. "The fact that interest rates are declining in the face of a strong economy tells me that people are putting a lot of weight on the shock that is taking place" in Asia, Mr. DiClemente said.
In assessing the impact of Asia, Mr. DiClemente noted that the value of the dollar against its trading partners has risen 7 percent since mid-October and 4 percent in the last 30 days. This means that the prices of imports have already fallen significantly, which cuts inflation.
In addition, he said his 1998 forecast showed a decline in American exports of about $80 billion, which cuts more than a full percentage point off his growth estimate.

HEADLINE: Another Dip In Prices Paid To Producers

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers dropped an unexpected two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Labor Department said today. The economy now appears likely to record its first yearly decline in producer prices since 1986.
Today's price data confirm that inflation remains contained and indicate that Federal Reserve policy makers are unlikely to raise interest rates when they meet next week in their final meeting of the year. 
 "Those worried about inflation are fighting the last war," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in New York. Indeed, Mr. Steinberg and other analysts say that the Fed may soon lower the Federal funds rate.
Bond prices surged in response to the price report, with the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond falling to 5.92 percent.
Energy led the decline in producer prices, falling eight-tenths of 1 percent in November. Excluding the volatile categories of energy and food, the so-called core rate of the Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent last month. In October, the index rose one-tenth of 1 percent, while the core rate was flat.
For the first 11 months of 1997, the index fell at an annual rate of 1.2 percent, in contrast to a 2.6 percent rise for the first 11 months of 1996.
"We expect more low P.P.I. figures in the months ahead," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York. "Oil prices are falling again, and the Asian crisis will pull down commodity prices."
Indeed, Asia's economic crisis could lead to price cuts by producers hoping to offset weak sales in their home markets with shipments to the United States. That would leave businesses with "very little pricing power," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Consumer prices are also on course to show their most subdued performance since 1986, analysts said. "Inflation is simply not heating up," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York. The Consumer Price Index for November is scheduled to be released Tuesday.
Other reports today pointed to slower growth and a lack of inflationary pressure. The Commerce Department said that business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October while sales dropped one-tenth of 1 percent. In September, inventories rose seven-tenths of 1 percent and sales rose 1.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Decline On Concern About Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, dragged down by concerns that Asia's economic crisis would eat into corporate earnings. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, ended its worst week in seven years.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.69 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 7,838.30, its fifth straight decline. The Dow lost 3.8 percent for the week. It was the first week since the five days ended March 21 that the Dow lost ground in every session. 
 The Nasdaq composite index fell 21.96 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,536.58, bringing its loss for the week to 5.96 percent. It was the Nasdaq's worst week since Aug. 24, 1990. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 1.55, or two-tenths of a percent, to 953.39, down 3.1 percent for the week.
"There's no doubt about it; technology is in a bear market," said Robert Streed, a money manager with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, which oversees $130 billion. "Investors are selling first and sorting things out later."
Computer-related companies tumbled on signs that demand was easing in the United States and that the growth of profits they earn in Asia would slow because of the region's financial turmoil.
Intel fell 1 5/16 , to 70 1/2; I.B.M. dropped 1 1/4, to 100 3/8, and Texas Instruments lost 1 1/4, to 40 7/8.
Microsoft declined 2 5/16 , to 136 3/4, after it was ordered to stop making computer makers install its Internet Explorer browser program as a condition for their getting the company's Windows 95 operating system. The rival Netscape Communications rose 1 5/8, to 27 7/8, after the ruling.
Cisco Systems dropped 6 1/8, to 76 9/16 , on concern about rising inventory of its products, although analysts said the buildup represented increased demand, not declining sales.
Gannett fell 1/8, to 59 5/16 , after the newspaper company said it expected slower profit growth in 1998 because of higher newsprint costs and slightly lower advertising.
Shares of Fine Host fell 5 3/8, to 10 1/8, before trading was halted in the afternoon. The shares have plunged 65 percent this week, prompting the National Association of Securities Dealers to investigate the unusual trading, a N.A.S.D. official said. Fine Host officials did not return repeated telephone calls. The company, based in Greenwich, Conn., runs food and beverage operations for locations like football stadiums, prisons and convention centers.

HEADLINE: Our Hungry Legal Immigrants

 BODY:
Close to a million legal immigrants across the country have had food stamps revoked under the 1996 welfare law, 50,000 in New York City alone. The city's food distributions to soup kitchens and food pantries are soaring, and some are reportedly running out of food each month. But statistics mask the individual tragedies. As reported by Rachel Swarns of The Times, a mother of four from Trinidad has been forced to use her rent money for food and substitute Kool-Aid for orange juice. A Peruvian mother spends her days pleading for groceries in one food pantry after another.
White House officials will meet next week to decide what programs need additional money next year. No item should rank higher than food stamps for the legal immigrants cut off by the harsh 1996 act. Congressional leaders and some Administration officials smugly believe that this year's balanced-budget plan corrected the worst of the 1996 cuts in aid to immigrants. But Congress restored Medicaid coverage and cash assistance for only some elderly and disabled immigrants. It did not restore food stamps. Food stamps are crucial because they are the only surviving welfare program whose benefits are set by Washington and not dependent on the generosity of state legislatures. 
 A dozen states, including New York, have decided to spend their own money restoring food stamps for immigrants. But almost all of these state programs cover only some groups of immigrants, like children or the elderly, and are likely to shrink once state budgets contract under the weight of the next recession. Even in these generous states, however, the picture is not pretty. In New York, for example, a Cambodian father of six has seen the value of food stamps fall to $127 a month from $354. A Dominican mother of three has lost $214 a month in food stamps.
Rising tax revenues in flush economic times should give the Administration some leeway to raise spending next year. White House officials have already drawn up a tentative list of entitlement programs to trim to make way for new initiatives. The cost of restoring food stamps need not be huge. Providing them for immigrant households with children would cost only about $400 million a year -- a small price to put food back on children's plates.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Lowering the Credit Fence;
Big Players Are Jumping Into the Risky Loan Business

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Beatrice Smith has refinanced the mortgage on her small Atlanta home six times in the last decade. As a result, her monthly payment rose from $267 to $417 -- before she defaulted on the loan late last year.
A 68-year-old former cleaning woman who lives alone on a monthly Social Security check of $709, Mrs. Smith said she initially refinanced her mortgage so she could pay some overdue bills. But she said she was not sure why she went through with the other ones. 
 "I can't remember things as well as I used to," she said softly. "I didn't understand a lot of things the banks were doing."
So rich are the profits to be mined from borrowers like Mrs. Smith that major companies are lining up to lend to them -- despite the risks these borrowers pose. Indeed, some critics say, it is precisely because of the borrowers' lack of financial acumen that so many are jumping into the business.
Big lenders like Chase Manhattan, Norwest, Nationsbank, General Electric, Keycorp, Countrywide Credit Industries and others are expanding their lending to "subprime" borrowers, as they are known in the trade. Other companies long involved in the industry, like Household International, are broadening their reach.
Subprime borrowers, in contrast to those considered prime-lending prospects, generally include people with poor credit histories -- or no credit history at all. A large number appear to be low-income, inner-city minority residents. Others with more substantial incomes may patronize subprime lenders and pay their higher interest rates because they have suffered a recent financial calamity.
The market is so fragmented that there is little comprehensive information available about it. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates and charters national banks, said it had no data because big banks had just begun to make their push into the market, which, confusingly, has nothing to do with the so-called prime interest rate that banks use as a reference point for many business and personal loans. Subprime auto and mortgage lending reached about $145 billion last year, with 80 percent of that amount mortgages and the rest auto loans, lenders and analysts estimate.
This financial frontier is already littered with the wreckage of small lenders that have been severely battered or crippled the last year by bad loans and dubious management practices. But the big players now plowing into the market say they bring sounder lending policies and a less free-wheeling approach to what has long been one of the shabbier arenas in lending. They argue that their sophistication will enable them to succeed where the small-fry lenders have failed.
"The subprime market is a burgeoning market," said Michael Carney, senior vice president of marketing and communications for Nationsbank's subprime unit, Nationscredit. "For a company that can deal with people who have credit issues, it really sets the tone between success and failure."
While subprime loans represent only about 10 percent of the country's $5.19 trillion in outstanding consumer loans, the fact that it has become a magnet for the titans of banking unnerves some experts.
"The entire consumer lending business has been engaged in risk warfare for almost three years now," says Edward Furash, a banking consultant with Furash & Company. in Washington. "There is an expansion of credit across the board for people who wouldn't have gotten credit under the old models. And it's making me nervous."
Some big lenders have hit rough patches in their subprime business, but nothing yet to compare with the blowups that have burned smaller companies. Consumers are taking their time paying back loans, a situation that could become very ugly if the economy falters. Consumer loan delinquencies hit a low this decade of 1.66 percent of all outstanding accounts in 1994, before shooting back up to 2.55 percent by June -- close to the highs of the recession of the early 1990's.
Moreover, while the entry of more established lenders into the subprime market has the potential to meet the social and economic goals of extending credit at lower cost to low-income borrowers, it is a rough-and-tumble world that is rife with tales of abusive lending and harsh collection practices. Critics acknowledge that lenders must charge higher interest rates for riskier borrowers, but they say that exorbitant rates are often inflated to insure big profits -- not just to account for risk.
"We have financial apartheid in our country," said William Brennan a lawyer specializing in home-lending abuses with the Atlanta Legal Aid Society. "We have low-income, often minority borrowers, who are charged unconscionably high interest rates, either directly or indirectly through the cover of added charges."
These days, mainstream borrowers can usually line up mortgages carrying interest rates of 7.5 percent to 8 percent. Until this year, most subprime mortgage borrowers had been paying about 14 percent for a loan, according to Inside Mortgage Finance, a trade publication. (Subprime rates have dropped this year, in some cases to as low as 10 percent, because of increased competition).
Mr. Brennan said that people he represents in the Atlanta area pay mortgage rates ranging from 12 percent to 16 percent, with borrowing costs further inflated by extras like credit life insurance and disability insurance. One of the people he represents is Mrs. Smith.
Mrs. Smith bought her house in 1969 for about $14,000. She said she had paid off a large chunk of her mortgage by the time she stopped working in 1984, but refinanced the loan in 1987 so she could eliminate her other debts. Her original lender was the Chrysler Corporation's Chrysler First unit, which Nationsbank bought in 1993 and renamed Nationscredit.
A series of refinancings helped Mrs. Smith pay off other debts, but she was charged interest rates ranging from 10 percent to 15.5 percent. Her mortgage debt rose from about $20,000 in 1987 to $35,000 by 1993. While Nationscredit lent her money at rates lower than those charged by Chrysler, her latest refinancing with Nationscredit was at 12 percent.
Mrs. Smith said she was not aware how the home equity loans the companies arranged caused any borrowing she made against the line to increase her debt.
"I thought I could get $32,000 in my hand and my note to the bank wouldn't go up each month," Mrs. Smith said. "My note went up to $500, and I didn't understand why."
Nationscredit's Mr. Carney said the bank went over all details of the loan with Mrs. Smith and that "her renewals are consistent with our policy." Nationscredit restructured Mrs. Smith's loan in 1993 without a home-equity component, lowering her monthly payment to $417 from $492. But when her workers' compensation payments ended in 1993, Mrs. Smith was forced to turn to her children for mortgage help. By late last year, her children could not afford to keep helping her and she defaulted.
Nationscredit and Mrs. Smith are now negotiating repayment terms. Despite the problems with Mrs. Smith's loan, Mr. Carney said that Nationscredit's overall subprime mortgage portfolio was performing well. Even though it has had some recent losses in subprime auto lending, Nationscredit said it intended to increase its $3.6 billion subprime portfolio about 20 percent a year.
Other big lenders are also interested. Chase said it was originating subprime mortgages across the country at the rate of about $82 million a month, up from just $12 million a month early last year. General Electric's financial services arm, GE Capital Services, said it expected to double its $1 billion subprime auto loan portfolio by the end of next year. Keycorp, which already owns a subprime auto lender, recently bought Champion Mortgage, a well-known subprime lender, which generated $500 million in home-equity loans last year, for $200 million. (Champion's motto: "When your bank says no, Champion says yes!")
The few big companies with longstanding subprime experience, like Household, are adding new lines of business. Last month, Household bought the ACC Consumer Finance Corporation, a subprime auto lender, picking up an executive along with the acquisition who has ample expertise navigating the perilous waters of subprime lending.
ACC's chief executive, Rocco Fabiano, was chairman of Far Western Bank, a subprime auto lender in Tustin, Calif., when state regulators closed it in 1990 because of risky lending practices. The Government prosecuted Mr. Fabiano in 1993, contending that he was involved in bribery at another bank. He was acquitted in 1995. In the meantime, Mr. Fabiano founded two other subprime lenders, one of which was ACC.
Household said it was aware of Mr. Fabiano's history and is "comfortable with the quality and the integrity of the management" at ACC. Mr. Fabiano, noting that he has never tried to hide his past problems, dismissed the Government's charges as meritless. "Every investor," he said, "has to determine what they think is legitimate" about the management of a public company.
The last year has been a brutal one for small subprime lenders. Many of these former high-fliers have fallen to earth beneath the weight of lending and accounting scandals and other problems. In the auto market, the financial meltdown of the Mercury Finance Company earlier this year has been followed more recently by earnings problems at competitors. On the mortgage side, the Cityscape Financial Corporation, the Aames Financial Corporation and the Green Tree Financial Corporation, have also been battered.
Although Keycorp had some early difficulties in subprime auto lending, and GE Capital has troubled loans to at least two subprime auto lenders, big companies now entering the subprime fray predicted that they would avoid similar blowups because of sophisticated credit-scoring systems that help gauge lending risk more effectively than smaller lenders can. They also note that they use more conservative accounting methods than the pioneers of the business do.
Moreover, the big companies say they want to avoid practices that might lead to accusations of abusive lending. "The more the consumer knows," said Sandy Derickson, president of GE Capital's subprime auto unit, "the better off he is."
Still, some remain unconvinced. "The national companies that are in this market are doing many of the same kind of abusive things that the little companies have done," said Mr. Brennan of Atlanta Legal Aid. While larger lenders are not as interested as some smaller lenders in forcing homeowners to give up their homes in foreclosure, Mr. Brennan said, the practical effect of keeping consumers deep in hock is often the same. The big companies don't want to foreclose," he said. "They're more interested in getting borrowers to refinance."

HEADLINE: For Microsoft, Ruling Carries Fateful Tones

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The wording of a temporary ruling issued Thursday in the Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation suggests that a final decision next summer could erode the power of the company, which had seemed poised to dominate information industries around the globe far into the next century.
Microsoft, the world's most powerful and profitable software company, in recent years has leveraged its control of personal computer operating systems to enter a growing array of new businesses as varied as telecommunications, cable television, entertainment and travel. In the process, the company has evolved into one of the most respected and feared corporations in the world. 
 That could change if the final ruling in the case forces Microsoft to delay or halt shipments of Windows 98 and Windows NT 5.0, the next versions of the operating system that runs on more than 90 percent of the world's newly shipped personal computers.
Operating systems are complex programs that handle myriad interactions among a computer, a user and applications like word processors or spreadsheets. Windows 98 is the next version of the operating system for personal computers that use single Intel processors. Windows NT 5.0 is a high-end business version of the operating system designed to run on more powerful network computers as well as on standard desktop machines.
Both new versions will completely integrate Microsoft's World Wide Web browser, Internet Explorer, a product that directly competes with the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator browser.
At issue in the antitrust case is the fact that Microsoft, in at least some instances, required hardware companies that wanted to ship their computers with Windows 95 already installed to also install Internet Explorer.
In his temporary ruling, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson called the company's control of the operating system market a "monopoly" and warned that this "bundling" of its browser with Windows had so stifled competition that Microsoft "might also acquire yet another monopoly in the Internet browser market."
It is not clear, however, whether the court will determine that a complete integration of the browser into the operating system poses the same kind of anticompetitive threat as bundling a separate browser application.
The difference is not apparent to the user, but it could have enormous legal implications, which in turn could have a sizable effect on Microsoft's bottom line.
Microsoft receives only a small payment for each machine sold with its operating system, but the almost 100 million computers sold worldwide each year added up to a huge part of the $5.97 billion the company's operating systems division earned this year. Such revenues have allowed Microsoft to invest billions of dollars over the years in both development of new technologies and expansion into other industries.
"The revenue implications are huge," David Readerman, a securities analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said of the ruling on Thursday by Judge Jackson of the United States District Court in Washington.
Mr. Readerman has forecast that in its first 24 months on the market, Windows 98 will generate $3.1 billion. By June 2000, he predicted, Microsoft will have shipped as many as 80 million copies of the new Windows versions.
Microsoft defenders argue that delaying Windows 98 could have a broader detrimental impact on the United States economy than a monopoly would have.
"This doesn't make much sense from a cost-benefit point of view," Luke Froeb of the Owen Graduate School of Management at Vanderbilt University said of Judge Jackson's ruling. Professor Froeb, an antitrust expert who pioneered a new model for analyzing mergers now used by the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, added, "Any time you slow down the pace of an industry you are going to undercut investment, and that can kill innovation."
Today, all sides in the dispute said that the impact of the temporary ruling on Windows 98 was unclear and would remain so until Judge Jackson issued his final ruling next summer.
That means it is entirely possible that the case could either delay the expected June introduction of Windows 98 or dampen the computer industry's enthusiasm for upgrading if the new version is sold without an integrated Web browser.
What is more, in papers filed by Microsoft with the Federal court last week, David Cole, the company's vice president in charge of Internet Explorer development, argued that Internet Explorer had always been an integral part of Windows 95.
"Microsoft has never developed any version of Windows 95 for computer manufacturers that does not include Internet Explorer," he wrote in his deposition. "In fact, since Windows 95 was first released in August 1995, Microsoft's ongoing development of its Internet Explorer technologies has been the central thrust of the company's development efforts for the operating system."
Critics of the company challenge that assertion, however, as offering more of a marketing definition than a technical explanation.
" 'Integrated' is a code word at Microsoft that simply means bundling," said Andrew Schulman, a senior technical editor at O'Reilly & Associates, a publisher of technical books, and the author of "Unauthorized Windows 95," an insider's guide to the software. "I don't see anything that any reasonable programmer would call integration."
Despite Microsoft claims that Windows 95 requires Internet Explorer to function, Mr. Schulman said it was a simple matter for even nonexpert users to turn the browser off.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

An Accord to Open Up World's Financial Markets
The United States and more than 100 other countries signed a global trade agreement to open up the world's banking, insurance and securities markets. 
 But the new pact could ignite steep criticisms in Congress, where some lawmakers are already suspicious of the World Trade Organization, the organization that will oversee and enforce the accord. The new pact is also less dramatic than many American companies had hoped, in part because of the financial turmoil sweeping through much of Asia. A1.
 
South Korea's Plight Worsens
The fourth-largest brokerage firm in South Korea collapsed, stocks plunged and the nation's vaunted opening of its bond market to foreigners attracted only $700,000 in purchases. The latest signs of deterioration in South Korea came as the Government spent hundreds of millions of dollars from its dwindling supply of foreign exchange to defend the won to little avail. Page D3.
 
In Indonesia, one of the early victims of the Asia crisis, many citizens who had enjoyed years of increasing prosperity are now braced for rising prices, high unemployment and, perhaps, social unrest. D2.
 
Technology Stocks Slump
Concerns about the Asian economic crisis continued to weigh down stocks in the United States. Technology stocks were hit hardest, led by Cisco Systems and Microsoft. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, fell 21.96 points, or 1.4 percent. For the week, the Nasdaq was down 5.96 percent -- its worst week since Aug. 24, 1990. D11.
 
Report Confirms Inflation Is Tame
Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers dropped unexpectedly in November, the Labor Department said. The report indicated that the economy was headed toward its first year-to-year decline in producer prices since 1986. D3.
 
Russia Reaches I.M.F. Deal
Russia and the International Monetary Fund agreed on a plan to control government spending, opening the door for an quick infusion of $1.7 billion from the fund and World Bank. The agreement comes at a critical time for the Russian economy, as foreign investors have been fleeing Russian markets. Still, the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin has a spotty record in carrying out its promises to the I.M.F. A1.
 
Behind the Microsoft Ruling
Microsoft has argued that century-old antitrust laws originally aimed at curbing the marketing abuses of the railroad and oil barons are irrelevant in the new economy of information technology. But in ordering Microsoft to separate its Internet software from its operating system, a Federal judge has reaffirmed that the old-fashioned laws still apply. News Analysis. A1.
 
Broad Rally in the Dollar
The dollar rose against European currencies and the yen as traders remained skeptical about Japan's stimulus plan and a German official said weak Asian markets would affect Europe. The dollar settled at 130.45 yen, up from 129.75 yen on Thursday, and at 1.7753 marks, up from 1.7620 marks. D11.
 
Orange Juice Prices Rise
Orange juice futures surged on concerns that foul weather could damage crops in Florida, the biggest growing state. Grain and soybean futures fell in part on expectations that demand from Asia would slow. D4.
 
A Trustee to Run Marvel
A judge plans to appoint a trustee to run Marvel Entertainment in place of the board, to resolve conflicts among the parties vying for control of the comic-book publisher. D3.

HEADLINE: Poor Nations Reject Role on Warming

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan, Dec. 12

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration has said it will not submit a landmark environmental agreement for Senate approval unless developing countries also do more, the world's poor argue that cost and fairness dictate that the sacrifices needed to preserve the globe's climate should not be heaped on them.
Even with the signing of the accord here this week by 160 countries, industrialized and developing nations continue feuding over which side bears the burden for reducing emissions of gases implicated in global warming. 
 The developing countries upset the conference by refusing to commit themselves to emission reduction targets that their wealthier counterparts have pledged to meet under the agreement.
Poorer countries were exempted from such goals and were called on only to take part in efforts to use cleaner energy sources that would be sponsored by richer nations.
"How can we devote our precious resources towards reducing emissions when we are struggling every day just to feed, clothe and house our citizens?" said F. V. Mayinga Mkandawire, Malawi's Minister of Forestry, Fisheries and Environmental Affairs.
The resistance by developing countries came after many years of fence-sitting in the face of Western pressure, and it marked a turn toward a more antagonistic stand against the global cleanup effort.
But poorer countries have long argued that the world's rich industrialized countries got that way by using the cheapest and dirtiest energy sources available to them for generations.
Most of the gases already contributing the globe's warming have come from industrialized nations. For example, the current per-capita emissions of the gases in developing countries are far below those in energy-intensive countries like the United States and Japan.
"The third world produces far less of these dangerous gases than industrialized nations, but we are being asked to do more than our fair share to clean them up," Mr. Mkandawire said.
Even rich countries fear the economic effects of complying with the costly reductions outlined in the proposed treaty, and they have far greater resources and know-how available to them.
For poorer nations, meeting the accord's goals would not merely force them to make factories run cleaner or to forego buying gas-guzzling minivans and Suburbans as in the West. It would instead call for sacrifices far more basic to their social and economic development.
If the West wants the cooperation of poorer nations, these countries say, it should share its wealth and technology.
The developing nations also maintained that the West has ignored the progress they have already made in reducing emissions.
Prosposals at this week's conference from industrialized countries for voluntary emission cuts by developing nations proved that point, they said. The talks nearly fell apart when delegates from 130 developing countries flexed their combined muscle in opposition to just such a plan.
"It's a myth that the developing countries don't care about the environment," said Jonathan Lash, president of the World Resources Institute, a Washington-based research organization. "Many of these countries have already made significant reductions in their emissions, but larger, more industrialized nations rarely acknowledge this fact."
For example, Mr. Lash said that in recent years, China had increased its fuel prices by 121 percent, resulting in a 20 percent reduction in emissions of carbon dioxide. He noted similar emission reductions by India, Mexico and Brazil, which have also raised fuel prices. In some cases these steps were taken to increase govenment revenues, but the environmental effect was the same.
In addition, environmentalists say India has become the world's largest wind-energy producer and Bangladesh has provided energy to many of its rural villages with solar power.
But it is less the current situation than the projections for the future that make the participation of developing nations vital to any effective action to stem climate change, many experts say.
Although developing nations now account for 30 to 40 percent of the world's emissions of the so-called greenhouse gases, they account for 80 percent of the world's population, and their emissions will soon exceed those of industrialized countries as their economies expand.
If the world's most populous, poorer countries indeed develop as much of the West did -- burning coal and other fossil fuels -- the consequences will be disastrous, some experts say.
"Within the next 30 years, increases in emissions by developing countries will reach the point where it's fair to say that the problem of global warming cannot be solved unless these nations agree to emissions targets," Mr. Lash said. "We in the industrialized world created the problem, but we can't solve it without cooperation from the developing countries."
But that cooperation may prove difficult to gain, particularly given the economic restraints of poor countries, and it may depend on some sign that richer nations are meeting their own commitments to reduce emissions.
Under the accord, which must be approved by the legislatures of the countries that have signed it, industrialized nations agreed to cut emissions by an average of 5.2 percent between 2008 and 2012.
Yet another bone of contention was a plan to set up an emission trading system that would allow countries that exceed their pollution limits to purchase "credits" from countries that pollute less. The United States, in particular, said Congressional approval of the accord could depend on such a provision.
The developing nations said they feared that such a trading system would allow rich countries to buy their way into compliance.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Reportedly to Seek More Capital

 BODY:
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has requested a $160 billion increase in the fund's capital base because of the economic crisis in Asia, a British newspaper reported today.
Mr. Camdessus wants the fund's board to raise the $200 billion capital base by 70 to 80 percent, rather than the 45 percent agreed in September, The Financial Times said. 
 Mr. Camdessus warned the board, which will discuss his proposal on Wednesday, that the fund's finances had worsened significantly since September -- especially because of its $21 billion loan to South Korea, the paper said.
Mr. Camdessus, however, has in years past called for ambitious increases in the fund's capital base that were subsequently scaled back in the face of opposition from the United States and other I.M.F. member countries.
Appearing on the television program "Newshour With Jim Lehrer" last night, Mr. Camdessus said that Japan would not need help from the fund. "Japan will not be next," he said.

HEADLINE: Russia Reaches I.M.F. Accord To Free Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Russia reached agreement today with the International Monetary Fund on a plan that would open the door for a quick infusion of $1.7 billion in Western loans.
Under the accord, Russia made new promises to improve its collection of taxes and cut Government spending. 
 The deal gives President Boris N. Yeltsin a chance to keep his promise to pay $1.7 billion in back wages to millions of public sector employees before the end of the year.
It will also help Russia relieve pressure on the ruble, which the Government has propped up in recent weeks with costly interventions in the currency markets.
The conditions for releasing the money include a new round of budget cuts, some of which will require approval from the Communist-dominated Parliament which has vocally questioned the monetary fund's right to tell Russia how to run its economy.
The agreement comes at a crucial moment for the Russian economy, which has been buffeted in recent days by anxiety over the health of Mr. Yeltsin and sales by foreign investors of Russian Treasury bills.
The agreement calls for the monetary fund to proceed with the next $700 million installment on a three-year $10.1 billion loan suspended since October because of Russia's failure to collect taxes.
Russia will receive the $700 million in January, a month ahead of schedule. The fund will review its adherence to the new plan before any further installments are paid.
Today's pact also unlocks $1.05 billion in World Bank money. The bank requires the monetary fund's certification of Russia's fiscal and economic soundness before making loans.
The plan will improve Russia's relations with the monetary fund, a critical step if the Yeltsin Government needs further loans to shore up its currency. Senior Russian officials have already had exploratory talks about the possibility of expanding the fund's assistance to Russia.
The accord has yet to be officially approved by the I.M.F. board, but that is regarded as a formality.
"We are pleased that the Russians are taking steps to improve their monetary and fiscal performance and that this has led to agreement with the I.M.F.," said David Lipton, Undersecretary of the United States Treasury. "These steps are aimed at bolstering the confidence of Russian and foreign investors and promoting economic recovery."
The monetary fund suspended further disbursements last October after Russia had drawn down about $5 billion of a three-year, $10 billion loan. The fund said Russia had failed to meet key conditions, chiefly the collection of taxes.
Monetary fund officials said that if Russia improved its tax collection, the next $700 million would be turned over in February.
With the turmoil on the world economic markets, Russia asked the fund to speed up that disbursement, a plea that received a sympathetic hearing in Western capitals.
In the end, officials said, the fund agreed on the faster timetable, but used the occasion to extract additional promises of fiscal restraint from the Russians.
Under the agreement, Russia pledged to reduce its Government payroll and to establish a new Treasury system that would give its Finance Ministry authority over the budgets of powerful ministries, like the Interior Ministry and the Defense Ministry.
Russia also said it would crack down on tax delinquents, open up the accounting ledgers of Gazprom, the politically powerful natural gas company, and confiscate property from persistent tax debtors.
According to officials here, the monetary fund presented Moscow with a new demand in recent weeks: the establishment of a multi-billion dollar contingency fund to deal with budget shortfalls.
The Russians argued for a smaller contingency fund than the monetary fund proposed and, one official said, the two sides eventually split the difference.
Even so, the measure is likely to draw protests from the Communist-dominated Parliament because the contingency fund would essentially be created by diverting money from the proposed 1998 budget. That budget received preliminary approval from the Parliament last week after President Yeltsin made his first appearance before it ever.
Russian officials say some of the steps are to be included in a new presidential decree, which is to be issued before the end of the year.
The Yeltsin Government has a spotty record in carrying out its promises to the I.M.F. And it remained unclear whether Moscow's recent financial difficulties will translate into budgetary discipline and sufficient support in Parliament.
To win the monetary fund's support, Russia has already taken some steps. It recently seized the property of two oil companies that failed to pay taxes and allowed interest rates on Treasury bills to rise to stem the exodus of foreign investors.
The monetary fund's long-term aim is to reduce Russia's vulnerability to disruptions in the world market.
"The I.M.F. is using this as an opportunity to get the Russians to more seriously address the fiscal issues," said Charles Blitzer, chief economist for emerging markets at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette. "You cannot really sustain a healthy economy when you have large tax arrears and large Government spending arrears. You need to have a functioning system."
That means making sure 1998 is different from 1997.
In 1997, the Yeltsin Government and the Parliament agreed on an unrealistically high budget only to see spending stopped when tax revenue failed to materialize as projected. The process was disorderly and led to a growth in government debts, including unpaid wages to workers.
Russia also maintained a large budget deficit. The deficit was financed by the sale of bonds, about a third of which were owned by foreign investors. When foreign investors became nervous about Russia's prospects and decided to sell, the ruble came under serious pressure and the Central Bank was forced to deplete its reserves to prevent a decline in the currency.
Russian officials hope the monetary fund's plan will restore the confidence of foreign investors. They have temporarily shelved plans to seek $2 billion in loans from commercial banks to help the country ride out the global fiscal crisis. They also hopes to raise additional money through privatization, like the sale this month of the government-owned Eastern Oil company.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Hopes Climate Fight Echoes Health Care Outcome

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
As the debate begins over the agreement to reduce global gas emissions, many Republicans sense that they have a political opportunity reminiscent of the health care fight of 1994.
The country then supported the basic idea of health insurance for all, just as it now supports strong environmental action. But Republicans skewered the health plan on the details, and in the process painted President Clinton as a big-government liberal. Some now think they can repeat their success and this time tar Vice President Al Gore. 
 Even if the Senate never ends up voting on the pact, Republicans are already testing arguments. Steve Forbes, a Republican Presidential contender, immediately called the accord "an unprecedented government seizure of American freedom and sovereignty." He added that "the Clinton health care plan pales in comparison."
Jim Nicholson, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, said the pact will "radically change the American life style." And Audrey Mullen, the executive director of the conservative group Americans for Tax Reform, said, "Al Gore would prefer to stick working-class America with a big tax increase and stick America with lost jobs or seek the approval of his liberal environmentalist tree-hugging friends."
At the same time voices of caution in the party recognize that the Republicans have often fallen on the wrong side in the environmental debate and need to be very careful how they approach an issue on which Democrats have traditionally had a great public advantage. And some party members remember how ineffective President George Bush was when he went after Mr. Gore in 1992 on his environmental views, calling him "Ozone Man."
"The Republican Party, as far as public perception is concerned, has not been a strong position to go toe to toe on the environment," said Tony Blankley, a former spokesman for Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House. He said that while he believed that the accord and the Vice President were vulnerable, it would require an extended, concerted effort to sway public opinion.
The Republican opportunity is enhanced by division among the Democrats about the accord. It is supported by one core Democratic constituency -- environmentalists -- but has drawn significant opposition from the labor movement. This may be an issue where many Congressional Democrats stand back and let the Administration and the Republicans fight.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, who is considered a likely challenger to Mr. Gore in 2000, has been conspicuously silent about the agreement. His aides said he wanted to consult with members of his caucus. The Democratic delegation he sent to observe the Kyoto negotiations on global warming was split in its views.
The Administration does not expect to move forward to seek Senate approval until 1999 at the earliest. That means that there is plenty of time for an array of interest groups to wage a campaign of lobbying, grass-roots organizing and television ads, much as they did during the health care debate.
The question for the next year will be who will frame the debate for the American people.
"What's important now is that this is a battle for definition as much as anything else," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "The issue of the treaty is completely undefined in the public mind and is in fact probably a new chapter in environmental politics."
Pollsters from both parties agree that the public right now is disposed to favor environmental measures.
A New York Times Poll last month found that 65 percent of those polled said the United States should take steps to cut its emissions of greenhouse gases "regardless of what other countries do." And a survey by the Pew Research Center last month found that a majority of Americans would even pay more for gasoline to reduce global warming.
But most Americans also favored the idea of universal health care before its opponents swung into action in 1994, ridiculing the complexity of the President's bill and running the "Harry and Louise" television ads featuring a couple voicing doubts about the plan's details.
White House officials say they learned lessons from that defeat that they are applying to global warming.
In his White House appearance on Thursday, Mr. Gore moved immediately to take off the table two potent lines of attack by the Republicans: He said the Administration would not submit the accord to the Senate until developing nations agreed to take part in the global effort. And he said the Administration would use tax incentives, not tax increases, to encourage reductions in emissions of "greenhouse gases" that are blamed for global warming.
"We were really clear about the words 'no taxes' on day one," a senior White House official said. "It was totally off the table in the first day, really quickly, no fuzziness."
At the same time, White House officials said, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore now have a powerful record on the economy, which they lacked in 1994. Their record on job creation, they argue, will help inoculate the White House against charges that the emissions-reduction effort will hurt the economy.
Finally, because the Senate will not actually receive the climate agreement until next year, there will not be actual legislation that can be picked apart. "Without the legislation, the debate's about protecting the environment," a Clinton aide said hopefully.
But Republicans are already working to reframe the issue as one of economic security and national sovereignty. This is a theme officials say can unite the Republicans' business base and economic populist faction -- and also tap into sentiment against global trade that surfaced when Mr. Clinton was defeated last month in his attempt to win expanded trade authority from Congress.
As was the case in the health care debate, the Republicans are also expecting outside help. Using the same media team of Goddard-Claussen that produced the Harry and Louise ads, the Global Climate Coalition, an association of industry groups and some unions, has already run $13 million in television advertisements against the agreement.

HEADLINE: Longtime Giuliani Assistant Will Lead Tourism Bureau

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gained extensive control over the marketing of the city to tourists yesterday -- and solved a personnel problem at the same time -- when the private New York Convention and Visitors Bureau agreed to appoint as its president Fran Reiter, formerly his Deputy Mayor and campaign manager.
City officials said the bureau, which gets about half its $7.5 million budget from the city, will now take on an expanded role as the chief marketer of New York City's shiny new image around the world, working much more closely with the Giuliani administration. 
 Stephen J. Morello, who has been president of the tourism bureau since 1994, submitted a letter of resignation yesterday and said in a brief interview that he had not decided on a new job. "The transition developed rather quickly," he said, declining to elaborate.
Several business leaders in the hotel and tourism industry said yesterday that the Giuliani administration had prevailed on the executive board of the Convention and Visitors Bureau to oust Mr. Morello and hire Ms. Reiter. By installing Ms. Reiter, who has long been a loyal and dutiful member of the Mayor's top management staff, City Hall now has a trusted associate at the helm of New York's marketing agency, which has been criticized in the past for not aggressively luring tourists. And by burnishing the city's image, the Mayor will indirectly be helping his own.
The bureau has had a low profile in recent years, and Ms. Reiter will now be further from the center of power within the Giuliani administration. Although she has worked hard for the Mayor in a variety of capacities, she becomes the first high-level casualty of the constant political power struggles within the Mayor's inner circle. Administration officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that in recent years she had run afoul of some of the other deputy mayors, who resented her aggressive style and were concerned about how her ties to the Liberal Party would be perceived by Republicans if Mr. Giuliani ran for national office.
The administration also announced yesterday that three City Commissioners would not be reappointed in Mr. Giuliani's second term, including Christopher R. Lynn, the outspoken Commissioner of Transportation. Mr. Lynn, the most prominent gay official in the administration, had run into controversy on several occasions during his tenure. In October, for example, he got into a dispute with a Bronx parking lot owner after Mr. Lynn ordered the removal of a sign that the owner had put on a street. Mr. Lynn accepted an appointment as a commissioner of the city's Tax Appeals Tribunal.
The other Commissioners who will be leaving their jobs are Nora Chang Wang of the Department of Employment and Marta Moczo-Santiago of the Department of Juvenile Justice. Ms. Wang declined another job from the Mayor; administration officials declined to reveal where the post would have been. Ms. Moczo-Santiago, who earned $117,370 as Commissioner, accepted a position as associate commissioner for program services in the Department of Probation, where she is to earn $90,000, said Colleen A. Roche, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary.
Although her policy role has narrowed, Ms. Reiter will make more money; officials said her total compensation at the bureau would be more than $200,000, greater even than Mr. Giuliani's $165,000. And she will be in charge of what city and bureau officials said would be a much more intensive effort to promote tourism in the city, which is at its highest level ever.
"There is a recognition that we have to take tourism coordination to a much different level," said Paul O'Neil, the chairman of the bureau's executive board and the president of Sheraton Hotels of New York. "We're going to be stepping up our effort to coordinate all aspects of tourism promotion around the city, including the millennium celebration and the centennial of the city's unification, and we needed somebody familiar with all of these constituencies."
He denied that the Giuliani administration had pressured the board to hire Ms. Reiter, but acknowledged that the city's contribution of half the agency's budget spoke loudly. The Mayor appoints five members of the bureau's 15-member executive committee. "The Mayor has always contributed 50 percent of budget, and that's a lot," Mr. O'Neil said. "When he spoke, he was listened to. He has representatives on the executive committee of the Convention and Visitors Bureau, and they were listened to."
Up to now, the bureau has concentrated on bringing major conventions and trade shows to New York, and it has drawn criticism from some leaders in the hotel and restaurant industries for not coming up with more imaginative ways to lure visitors to the city. Although the city is now awash in tourists, most in the industry say that is the result of an improved economy and lower crime, rather than any intense effort on the part of the bureau.
Administration officials said the bureau would now begin many marketing efforts long urged by the industry, and would take on the role of spreading word about the city's successes -- particularly, Mr. Giuliani's successes -- to potential tourists around the country and the world.
Although the bureau's budget has been cut slightly by the Giuliani administration in the last three years, city officials said they wouldn't be surprised if the allocation increases in coming years as the bureau's mission expands.
Ms. Reiter, who had a background in marketing before entering politics, was on safari in Africa and could not be reached for comment yesterday.

HEADLINE: In Gulf Casinos' Wake, a Pawnshop Boom

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: GULFPORT, Miss.

 BODY:
For gamblers who have run out of cash but refuse to accept defeat, Drew Pitts and his 24-hour, drive-through pawnshop offers one last chance to test their luck.
"You really see how bad it is in the pawn shop," said Mr. Pitts, who worked as a dealer in the Las Vegas casinos for 14 years before opening his "Quick Cash" shop here last spring. "I see the final result now. They're having so much fun when they start -- not when they finish and end up here." 
 Anyone seeking proof that legalized gambling has thrived in the five years since casinos arrived on the Mississippi Gulf Coast need look no farther than the neon signs of the 53 pawnshops that dot the landscape like so many dandelions among the magnolias.
Pawnbrokers here tell of late-night gamblers who, unable to get more cash on their credit cards, buy televisions and radios at 24-hour discount stores, then pawn them for one-third of their value. Others pawn whatever they have because they cannot wait until midnight, when their bank cards will allow them to withdraw more money.
To be sure, many of the shops here catered to soldiers from nearby bases and local shrimp boat workers long before the casinos arrived. But the pawnbrokers and others who lend money on automobile titles have flourished alongside a casino market that has become the third largest in the country.
Later this month, Imperial Palace, which owns a major Las Vegas resort, will open this area's 12th casino, which will include a 1,088-room hotel. Construction is also under way on a $600 million, 1,800-room hotel and casino called the Beau Rivage, or "beautiful shore," which is being developed by Mirage Resorts.
For the pawnbrokers like Mr. Pitts, more gamblers and casino workers mean more people willing to trade their valuables for cash loans at a fraction of their full value, with an interest rate of 25 percent a month.
"There's already plenty of business for all of us," Mr. Pitts said. "But this town is really going to explode after they open the Beau Rivage."
Casinos and pawnshops have long gone hand-in-hand, but here the ratio of nearly five pawnshops for every casino is unique. In the nation's gaming capital, Las Vegas, for instance, there are 96 casinos but just 40 pawnshops. Kenneth Bond, who serves on the board of the Mississippi Association of Pawnbrokers, said that about 15 shops had opened on the Gulf Coast since casinos were legalized, and while local residents are a large share of their business, the casino trade had altered the customer base.
"The out-of-town customers have replaced the local people who were unstable before casinos came," Mr. Bond said.
One factor in the huge growth in pawnshops is Mississippi's relatively loose regulations. When Hayes Bolton lived in Texas, an application for a pawnbroker's license was required to show proof of having $150,000 in unencumbered liquid assets. But in 1993, when Mr. Bolton opened his Lighthouse Pawn Shop across the street from Biloxi's historic white lighthouse, he had only to produce a $10,000 bond and pay licensing fees of $150 to the state and $250 to the city.
Perhaps more important is the lucrative return that Mississippi allows pawnbrokers. The pawnshop interest rate of 25 percent per month is equivalent to an annual percentage rate of 300 percent. On a $1,000 loan, for example, interest at the end of a year would be $3,000. As a practical matter, however, most loans last only 60 days; after that, the pawnbroker is entitled to take possession of the pawned article. By comparison, in Las Vegas, the monthly interest rate is 10 percent.
"If I had known how liberal Mississippi's rules are," Mr. Bolton said with a smile, "I would have opened when I first got here in 1990."
Instead, his first enterprise was a gasoline station and garage, which now doubles as his pawnshop. The parking lot in front of his station is filled with used cars for sale. Under a state law passed a few years ago, borrowers can put up the title to their cars, boats or mobile homes, though they can keep them unless they default on the loan.
As a result, dozens of title loan businesses have opened up over the past three years, and many, like Mr. Bolton's, are physically attached to the pawnshops. The title loan businesses, which usually lend up to one-third of a vehicle's value, also charge 25 percent interest a month.
"The title bond business is so good you can't do without it," Mr. Bolton said. "It's so good, it's like dope."
While electronics and jewelry are the most common items pawned, the shelves of the pawnshops are filled with just about everything. Standing behind a glass case with diamonds as large as four carats, Don Schwartz, the owner of Gulf Coast Jewelry and Pawn, said that serious gamblers liked to wear jewelry because is gave them security.
"The main objective of having a lot of jewelry," Mr. Schwartz said, "is they can liquidate it fast and get back in the game."
But, he added, "you never know what's going to come through the door." He then pulled out the deed to a burial plot that he bought from a customer. "It was worth $1,700," he said, "and I bought it for $400."
Mr. Schwartz operated buy-and-sell shops in Atlantic City for five years and then moved to Nevada, where he decided against opening a pawnshop in Las Vegas because the license was too expensive and the business was dominated by a few large companies. Last year, he opened his shop here, across the street from the Beau Rivage site.
"Everybody wants to buy this place from me now," he said. "It's a good business, but it's a risky business, too," he noted, as he slapped the holster of a 9mm pistolt.
Mr. Schwartz has a glass case filled with new portable radios and cassette players, and Mr. Pitts's shelves are often lined with new televisions, still in the box, bought and pawned by addicted gamblers who had exceeded the cash advance limit on their credit cards. When the customers do not return to pay off their loans and interest, the new merchandise sells quickly, Mr. Pitts said.
Since the casinos are open 24 hours a day, Mr. Pitts keeps his drive-through window open 24 hours during the summer and on weekends, when tourist traffic is at its peak.
"I've sat in this window at 4 in the morning and had people willing to pawn their wives," he said. "I've seen some sad stories. All kinds of people and ages."
Some of his best customers, Mr. Pitts said, are the casino workers. While employees are prohibited by state law from gambling at the casinos where they work, they can freely gamble anywhere else. Over the past seven months, he said, one casino employee has pawned and retrieved 17 items.
"He's a good customer," Mr. Pitts said. "I appreciate him."
Lloyd Rushing, a doorman at The Grand Casino in Biloxi, confided that he used to gamble at other casinos until his paycheck was gone and that he knew plenty of casino employees who gambled and ended up at the pawnshops. "You get addicted to it," he said. "You keep going and you think you can win."

HEADLINE: Second Opinion on South Bronx Revival;
Where the President Did Not Visit, Concerns About Cutbacks

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
The drug addicts still stumble down Prospect Avenue, not far from two soup kitchens where the lines seem to grow longer every day. The homeless shuffle along, ever present, surviving in the shadows. This is the South Bronx that Ellen Rodriguez sees, and she wishes President Clinton had seen it, too.
"Just too bad he didn't come around to this area so he could see the way some of these people really live," said Ms. Rodriguez, who works at La Casita, a residence for mothers recovering from drug addiction on 156th Street near Prospect. "It's just sad to see." 
 When President Clinton visited Charlotte Street this week, hailing the South Bronx as a model of urban renewal, he left a warm afterglow in a place more accustomed to derision and contempt. His appearance brought national attention to a dramatic housing renaissance across the South Bronx that began more than a decade ago and continues, financed largely with public money.
If, as Mr. Clinton rightly noted, the South Bronx is no longer the urban wasteland President Jimmy Carter saw in 1977, people like Ms. Rodriguez know that its recovery remains piecemeal and incomplete.
The 16th Congressional District, which includes Charlotte Street, is still among the poorest in the country. There are still abandoned buildings with windows boarded shut. There are still scattered empty lots. In South Bronx neighborhoods like Mott Haven, old men push shopping carts filled with cardboard, hoping to scratch out a few nickels, if they are lucky.
And if the South Bronx has enjoyed enormous public and private investment in new housing in recent years, local activists warn that its impoverished residents now stand to suffer disproportionately as Federal, state and city governments scale back welfare benefits and food stamps.
"Yes, they've done some decent things with housing, but it doesn't mean it's all fixed," said Liz Krueger, the head of the Community Food Resource Center. "It doesn't change the fact that it is still an area with abject poverty and a long, long way to go."
A study by the resource center of the three primary political districts in the South Bronx -- Community Boards 1, 2 and 3 -- revealed that the total value of public assistance coming into the area declined by more than 17 percent between October 1994 and October 1996. While some of this decrease can be attributed to people getting full-time jobs, experts attribute most of the decline to cut-backs in benefits.
"The visit really made people feel good," said Caroline McLaughlin, executive director of the Citizen's Advice Bureau, a social services agency in the South Bronx. "But I'm still very, very worried about welfare reform, which is hitting in pieces but still hasn't totally hit."
Just a short walk from Charlotte Street, Ralph Santiago Sr., 56, stood behind the counter of his grocery store, ringing up customers who had shopped there for decades. A center for the elderly and a bank are being built across the street, reminding him of when the area thrived 40 years ago. But Mr. Santiago said sales are down recently. In the back unloading soft drinks, Ralph Jr., his son, explained why.
"It has been slow because they've been cutting back on the food stamps," he said. He said another grocer ordered 200 turkeys for Thanksgiving but sold only half because of the cutbacks. One longtime customer of Mr. Santiago's store, Sonia Fuentes, said the food stamps she receives to help feed her three children have been cut from $184 a month to $166. She says she expects further reductions.
Ernie Acosta, a supplier with Nestle Foods, said the same trend can be seen in stores across the South Bronx. "There is less money floating around," he said.
And less money means less food. Officials with Food for Survival, the organization that supplies soup kitchens and food pantries across New York, said the current increased demand for meals across the city is particularly acute in the South Bronx, where 749,000 free meals were served in September.
This endemic poverty underscores how even as 30,000 housing units have been built or renovated in the South Bronx during the last 10 years, other indices of prosperity continue to lag. In particular, unemployment remains in the double digits.
"Jobs in this neighborhood?" laughed Jessica McCormick, 29, as she and her 10-year-old son, Skylar, walked home along Prospect Avenue. "Doing what? There are not any jobs around here."
The combination of extreme poverty and improved housing has given the neighborhoods in the South Bronx almost split personalities. The blocks with new or renovated homes are considered safer and better, with a population of middle-class families. But blocks with older apartments, perhaps only a short walk away, are often considered dangerous.
Donna Nelson, who lives on the Grand Concourse, said she admires the new row houses she sees in parts of Mott Haven, where she works as in-home health aide. She said she considers these blocks safe enough -- and nice enough -- to live in. But when she walks from the bus to her job caring for an elderly woman in public housing, she keeps to busy streets for fear of crime. On the day President Clinton visited Charlotte Street, Ms. Nelson said she encountered teenagers smoking marijuana in the hallway of the housing project.
These lingering problems are why Bobby Gonzalez, 35, believes there is still much to be done in the South Bronx. As he walked home along Cypress Street near East 141st Street in Mott Haven, Mr. Gonzalez passed buildings covered in graffiti. He ran into a friend, Evelyn Salgado, 42, who said she rarely leaves her apartment, fearing crime. Because Mr. Gonzalez works, at an aluminum supply company, he could not attend Mr. Clinton's visit, but he said he would not have gone anyway. He wants to see the same sort of progress on this block.
"These buildings here probably contain more families than that whole area of Charlotte Street," Mr. Gonzalez said. "All they did was help a small number of people in the Bronx, and they are the middle class. The working class who make about $20,000 a year can never afford a house in the Bronx."
