HEADLINE: Madison the Cat Is Safe! Oh, the Avenue's O.K., Too

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Yesterday was a good day for Madison the cat and Madison the avenue. One was reunited with his owner, examined by a veterinarian and found to be fine.
The other was reopened to traffic. 
 For the first time since loose bricks from a high-rise building rained down on Madison Avenue last Sunday, nearby stores were allowed to open and cars and buses were finally permitted on a two-block stretch between 53d and 55th Streets. The avenue had been closed all week while construction crews worked to shore up the damaged facade and until the city finished putting up a tunnel-like scaffold between 54th and 55th to protect cars and buses in case any more bricks fell from the high-rise.
And after a 10-minute rescue mission, Madison the tabby was freed from his owner's apartment at 536 Madison Avenue, a couple of doors down from the brick-shedding high rise. Mike Tietje of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and three employees of the city's Office of Emergency Management climbed the stairs to the top-floor apartment where Madison spent the week by himself.
His owner, Tim Curran, 27, a bartender and unemployed Wall Street stock trader who was forced to leave his apartment on Sunday because of the precarious situation, spent the week in a nearby hotel, worrying.
"If they want to come to you fast, they will," Mr. Tietje said, and Madison did. "It came out of the closet in the rear room. It started to run around us. It was scared because it didn't know us."
Shortly after Mr. Tietje carried Madison to safety, stores across from the damaged high-rise reopened for the first time since the bricks pelted the street. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went shopping, buying $71 worth of wine and stopping in cosmetics and candy shops. Officials said that buildings on the other side of the street would be allowed to reopen soon, probably tomorrow.
That was a relief to tenants like Dr. Frederick Kahn, a dentist at 538 Madison Avenue. The emergency workers who accompanied Mr. Tietje to free Madison retrieved Dr. Kahn's appointment book yesterday.
Next door, crews continued to shore up the damaged high-rise. William G. Nagle, a deputy director of the Office of Emergency Management, said bracing and structural supports had been put in. After construction workers discovered that the weakened wall was in worse condition than had been believed, work crews were ordered to reinforce it with wooden planks and steel rods.
By nightfall, traffic had been allowed back on the closed-off section of the avenue. Workers had put up waist-high barriers between 53d and 54th Streets, forming a pair of traffic funnels leading to the mini-tunnel covering the avenue between 54th and 55th.
"A building that was as high as this one, with bricks falling off, they had to make sure it was secure" before allowing traffic on the street below, the Mayor said.
City officials said on Monday that water damage to the building, accumulated from years of neglect, probably caused the damage. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he had also asked the city's Department of Investigation to look into the accident.
For Mr. Curran, yesterday marked the end of a week of worrying over the fate of his beloved cat. As Mr. Tietje rescued Madison, Mr. Curran waited with emergency workers on the street and heard the good news over a walkie-talkie: "We have the cat. We have the cat." Mr. Tietje wrapped Madison in a blue blanket and carried him down the stairs.
Then it was off to a familiar place: A.S.P.C.A. headquarters on East 92d Street, where Mr. Curran adopted him about four years ago.
He weighed in at 16.9 pounds, about the same as before his week alone in Mr. Curran's apartment. After a checkup, Madison's condition was described in five words Mr. Curran was happy to hear: none the worse for wear.
"He certainly didn't seem hungry," said Peter Paris, a spokesman for the association. "We believe he did actually manage to make it to some food during the week."
It certainly wasn't takeout. No one, whether tenants, letter carriers or delivery people, had been allowed in all week. The rescue came after The New York Times described Mr. Curran's frustration at not being able to see or free his cat.
After Mr. Curran had taken Madison to a friend's apartment on East 85th Street, city officials said that they would have sent someone in on Thursday had Mr. Curran been there with his keys.
"Whoever he was told to see, he didn't see," said Bruce Brodoff, a spokesman for the city's Emergency Management Office.
Mr. Curran disputed that, saying that he was never given such instructions and that the officials he had spoken with at the command post on 54th Street did not have clearance to enter the building.
It turned out that Madison was not the only cat stuck on the block, or even in his building. Holed up in the ground-floor restaurant in Mr. Curran's building was Mera, a white cat with a camel-colored tail and a fondness for tuna. Never mind that his owner, Steve Tsirnikas, described Mera as "a cheeseburger cat."
Mr. Tsirnikas had left food for Mera on Tuesday, when he entered the restaurant through a basement entrance. But he could not find her. Yesterday, when he went in again, "she was all over me."

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED TO LOWER BARRIERS IN GLOBAL FINANCE

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Saturday, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Under the darkening clouds of Asia's financial crisis, the United States and more than 100 other countries signed a global trade agreement early this morning to open up the world's financial markets.
The agreement, reached after protracted negotiations that ended early this morning, commits countries to dismantling hundreds of barriers and admitting foreign banks, insurance companies and investment firms to their markets. 
 The new agreement could lead to big changes in countries from India and Indonesia to Brazil and Argentina. At its essence, the nations legally committed themselves to giving foreigners more freedom to own and operate companies in all segments of the financial services industry.
The United States, which already allows unfettered access to its financial markets, conceded nothing in the agreement. Most of the changes will be in Asia and Latin America, where countries retain many restraints on foreign banks, insurers and brokerage firms.
Even so, some economically desperate Asian countries like South Korea and Malaysia refused to commit themselves to expanding foreign access much beyond current limits -- despite the meltdown ravaging their currencies and stock markets.
The new pact could also draw sharp criticism in Congress, where some lawmakers are already suspicious of the World Trade Organization, the international body that will oversee and enforce it.
Some in Congress are still angry about a tentative ruling in which the trade organization rejected the Eastman Kodak Company's complaints about restrictions in the Japanese market. But Congress has no power to block the new pact. The Clinton Administration had the authority to negotiate and sign the agreement, which goes into effect immediately.
The new pact is less dramatic than many American companies had hoped it would be. Nonetheless, the fact that it was signed at all was viewed with considerable relief, and proponents said the deal could help reverse the tide of pessimism caused by the Asia crisis. "I don't think it would be good for confidence in the financial markets if this deal failed," said Patrick Low, the W.T.O.'s director of economic research.
 Several of America's biggest investment firms immediately praised the pact. "This agreement advances the cause of free and open markets, which will help bring the benefits of a more integrated financial system to people everywhere," David H. Komansky, chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, said. Jon Corzine, chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the pact would be "a powerful engine of prosperity."
 A lot is at stake. American banks and investment companies have led a worldwide expansion in financial services, from orchestrating corporate mergers to exporting American-style pension funds. International bond and stock sales have doubled in the last five years, as companies from Daimler-Benz to France Telecom listed their shares on stock exchanges. Institutional investment has ballooned, while international currency trading has swelled to $1.2 trillion daily.
Against this backdrop, it was the Asian financial crisis that overshadowed most of the talks. Though the United States has pushed harder than any other country, executives here said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the U.S. trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, had been worried that walking away from an agreement would aggravate investor uncertainty even more.
 In Washington late Friday night, President Clinton welcomed the accord, saying it would insure market access in sectors where the United States led the world. "In the wake of recent financial instability, it is particularly encouraging that so many countries have chosen to move forward rather than backwards," Mr. Clinton said in a statement.
 American companies were conspicuous at the negotiations. Citicorp, Goldman, Sachs, Merrill Lynch and numerous insurance companies established command posts at a hotel near the W.T.O. headquarters.As the organization's self-imposed midnight deadline for an agreement approached, many executives conferred with American negotiators.
American representatives quit the trade talks two years ago, complaining that countries were not going far enough on opening markets. Talks began again in earnest this week. As it happened, the deadline was extended by several hours as the United States kept seeking concessions.
"It is all because of les Americains!" one tired trade official said. The European Union had been ready to sign a treaty long before.
The biggest disagreements, according to officials and executives, were with Japan, Malaysia and South Korea. The South Koreans, for example, refused to commit themselves to letting foreigners own controlling stakes in banks, even with the threat of defaults looming over many Korean financial institutions.
The country is already locked in arguments with the International Monetary Fund about opening its system, barely a week after signing a $57 billion bailout with the I.M.F.
In one of the United States' toughest victories, not reached until nearly 2 A.M., Japan agreed to a sweeping array of market-opening measures. Japan had already reached a bilateral agreement with the United States that would give American companies broad access to Japan's insurance market. But Japan had refused to broaden that commitment to all countries in the organization, or to bind those pledges to the legal enforcement mechanisms of the international body.
Under the agreement, each country put forward its own best offers for opening up its local financial markets to foreign companies. The offers differ greatly, but countries become legally bound to stick by those commitments. If they do not, and the World Trade Organization rules that a country has backed away from its word, other countries get the right to seek compensation or impose retaliatory restrictions.

HEADLINE: From Close Family to World of Hate

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: DENVER, Dec. 12

 BODY:
In a sedate, upper-middle-class neighborhood here, where streets carry the names of Methodist bishops, young Mat thaeus Reinhart Jaehnig grew up in a large neo-Georgian brick house and attended a private school that nurtured freethinking. The household was headed by his father, a cerebral pastor whose pacifism dated from a childhood in war-ravaged Germany.
Last month, at the age of 25, Mr. Jaehnig burst into Denver's consciousness as a drugged-out skinhead who stole a red Pontiac Trans-Am, led the police on a wild 30-mile chase, killed a police officer in a blaze of automatic weapon fire and then committed suicide. 
 A coroner found traces of cocaine, marijuana, and methamphetamine in his system. Tattoos on his upper body included five skulls, two lightning bolts, one swastika, and, on his belly, the Nazi slogan "Blood and Honor."
The trajectory of Matthaeus Jaehnig (pronouced ma-TAY-us YAY-nig) from a liberal upbringing to a neo-Fascist end, offers insight into how neo-Nazi groups nationwide tap into the frustrations of alienated young people, offering solace with a scapegoating view of the world.
But Mr. Jaehnig's short life, disclosed in the accounts of his parents and friends, also offers a more universal tale of family despair over a brooding child who grew into an angry man who could not -- or would not -- find a lasting career or a place in society.
Mr. Jaehnig's end was the most violent in a string of recent attacks by skinhead groups that have rocked the Denver area, prompting much soul searching in a city that prides itself for tolerance.
Standing 6 foot 4 and weighing 200 pounds, the blue-eyed, sandy-blond Mr. Jaehnig was a two-fisted pillar of the skinhead group Denver Skins. In the summer of 1995, said a former Ku Klux Klan organizer here, Mr. Jaehnig attended a training camp at the Aryan Nations compound in Hayden Lake, Idaho. Mr. Jaehnig's family and friends denied this.
Aryan Nations, a nationwide white supremacist group linked to several incidents of racial violence in the past decade, was a a common link for two other skinheads arrested in the recent racist attacks here. The two, Nathan Thill and Jeremiah Barnum, are in jail, charged with murdering a West African immigrant, Oumar Dia, at a downtown bus stop on Nov. 18. It is unclear whether Mr. Jaehnig knew them.
"We have so many young people through here, I can't remember all the names," the Rev. Richard G. Butler, the leader of the Aryan Nations compound in Idaho, said in a telephone interview. "The youth is the future of our people, so naturally we concentrate on the youth. It's going up all the time."
Monitors of hate groups say that about five years ago Mr. Butler decided to revive his flagging movement by turning apolitical skinheads and other disaffected youths into Nazis, using forums like a newsletter, a Web site, appearances at gun shows and neo-Nazi jamborees at the Hayden Lake compound.
Yet it is not clear whether Mr. Jaehnig made neo-Nazi beliefs a core of his philosophy, or whether it was instead a tool he used to carve out a sense of belonging.
Indeed, toward the end of his life, some of Mr. Jaehnig's closest companions were members of an all-black Harley Davidson motorcycle club.
In remarkably candid interviews, friends, family members and teachers talked about Mr. Jaehnig's life.
"Matthaeus was from the very, very, very beginning a slow learner," said Ina Jaehnig, his mother, a 54-year-old high school history teacher whose voice revealed the strain of the recent events. "He was clearly dyslexic."
Ina Jaehnig and her husband, Diethart, moved here from Germany in 1971, bringing with them the psychic scars of World War II. Mr. Jaehnig's father, a German soldier, was killed by a land mine in Alsace. Mrs. Jaehnig, who grew up in Stuttgart, met her father only after the war; he had spent two years as a prisoner of war in the United States.
In Denver, the couple helped start a Waldorf School, and Mr. Jaehnig served for 20 years as pastor of an affiliated church, the Christian Community. Founded by the philosopher and educator Rudolph Steiner in Germany after World War I, the two institutions preach free-thinking, independence from governments and the nurturing of the spiritual side of children and adults. Christian Community churches are now in 16 countries and Waldorf Schools are in 32.
Until his death in 1991, Mr. Jaehnig's greatest passion was leading peace conferences for European and American young people.
The Jaehnigs bought the large six-bedroom house with a gift from Mrs. Jaehnig's father, an architect in Germany. At the west end of their block-long lot, they built the Christian Community Church, a wooden structure that resembles a Buckminster Fuller geodesic dome.
 
At Home and School, Difference Stand Out
To the despair of his intellectual parents, Matthaeus was slow to learn to talk. "For me as a parent, he was always a riddle," Mrs. Jaehnig said. "In kindergarten, children would say, 'I'm going to play Matthaeus.' Then, they wouldn't say anything."
His older sister, Jelena, was speeding through school. "Teo was an interesting child, very odd, very quiet, who didn't like to move a lot," said Ms. Jaehnig, a Waldorf teacher in Oregon, using her brother's nickname. Referring to their middle sibling, she added, "When Sam and I would play, Teo would usually watch."
In the small classes at Waldorf, the quiet Matthaeus was insulated from the wider world. When he reached the ninth grade, which was not offered then at Waldorf, his parents had him tutored by his shop teacher, Michael Baker. "I took him through Tarzan of the Apes by Edgar Rice Burroughs," Mr. Baker said. "We had to plow through, word by word, and then go back and look at the whole sentence."
But in 10th grade, Matthaeus started attending the nearby South High School, whose 1,500 students were about half white and half minority members. The boy was so far behind that teachers called his parents asking whether he could be tested for retardation. Assured that he was not, he was placed in a class for slow learners, where most of the other students happened to be black.
"They teased him mercilessly," Mrs. Jaehnig said of her son's classmates. "They wouldn't let him go to the bathroom. They chased him through the park."
On several occasions, the gawky boy sought refuge in the familiar warmth of the Waldorf school. After barely passing most of his first-semester classes, he withdrew from school in the spring. He was failing all subjects.
"I scold myself for letting him go to public school," Mrs. Jaehnig said.
Sam, his older brother by three years, agreed, adding: "Teo just got lost in the shuffle of a huge high school."
At South High, Sam and Matthaeus found protection in a white punk set that eventually migrated to the Denver Skins. "It was sad to see this big, simple kid harden himself," Mr. Baker said. "I watched him start to dress in black jeans, boots, combat jackets."
 
Unskilled Worker In High-Tech World
To others, Matthaeus was not just a victim of his environment. He was a victim of his own inertia, his own stubbornness, and, ultimately, his own choices.
"You can lead a horse to a river, but you can't make him drink," Jelena Jaehnig said. "Some of it was learning disability, some of it was stubbornness."
After high school, Matthaeus dropped out of a series of vocational programs, including one that taught gardening at the Denver Botanical Gardens. He went through seveal manual jobs, and once went to Europe to work for his grandfather.
"We could not find a place for him, something that would fit," Mrs. Jaehnig said.
Eventually, Sam grew out of the skinhead scene. He started getting his younger brother jobs setting up stages for rock concerts. But while Sam steadily progressed from rigger, to crew chief, to licensed stage builder, to partner in a staging company, his younger brother remained a rigger, at $7 an hour.
His old phobia of books, tests and failure apparently kept him down.
"My regular call guys had commercial driving licenses," recalled Nick Williams, Sam Jaehnig's business partner. "But Teo never took the bull by the horns for the license. There is a written test. I am sure that had a lot to do with it."
While Matthaeus Jaehnig scraped along on the fringes of Denver's booming high-tech economy, his personal life was similarly going nowhere. At 18, he became a father. One day, after a spat, his girlfriend moved out of the Jaehnig house with their baby. Mrs. Jaehnig recalled, "It shocked Matthaeus that one week after moving out, she got married -- to another man."
About this time, when he was 19, Mr. Jaehnig was arrested for the first time, charged with carrying a concealed pistol. Because of his arrest record, he was denied visitation rights. "He kept a picture of his son in his room," his sister recalled. "He would even go and watch him from a distance."
With passing years, his growing anger at "the system" seemed more directed against police officers than against racial minority member. Indeed, a few years ago, he started hanging out with the black motorcycle club.
"He went up to the mountains for campouts with them, for barbecues with them," recalled Michael Barnum, a close white friend who is not related to the skinhead arrested here recently. "One of the guys was like an adoptive father to him."
 
Bitter Anger Turns To the Outlaw Life
 But Mr. Jaehnig took drugs and lived the outlaw life. In the last two years he ran up six arrests -- for drug possession, carrying a variety of loaded handguns in his car and for pressing a loaded gun to the throat of a former girlfriend.
On June 26, 1996, Michael Blake, a Denver police officer, arrested Mr. Jaehnig after a high-speed chase. Of Mr. Jaehnig, Officer Blake recounted: "I almost shot him. When I stepped out of my car, he was going down. I told him he had better come up with open hands, or he would not enjoy the outcome. On the floor of the seat in front of him was a loaded automatic, with the safety off. His attitude was 'You won this one, they'll be another one.' His attitude was, 'I don't have a driver's license. I don't have insurance. So what's the big deal?' There was no responsibility, no respect for authority."
For eight arrests, Mr. Jaehnig spent a total of about 100 days in jail, the police say.
Neighbors fault a laissez-faire household. After Mr. Jaehnig's death, they say, the boys held skinhead parties and unleashed their dog, Mugger, on passers-by.
Last Saturday, two women, both family friends staying at the mansion, stabbed each other in a knife fight. One of the women was a homeless friend that Mr. Jaehnig had offered a place to stay.
"He would often bring home homeless friends -- that generosity is the other side of this violent boy," Mrs. Jaehnig said. On the guns she started seeing around the house, she said: "I had many, many conversations with him: 'If you have a gun, it will be used one day.' He always said: 'Mom, don't worry.' "
But for Mr. Jaehnig, the outlaw life also had a revolutionary edge.
In the summer of 1993, Don Gilworth and Bruce Vander Jagt, two police officers, were patrolling the area that included University Park when fireworks erupting over the Jaehnigs' house drew them to a backyard party of skinheads.
"I heard someone say 'Get 'em,' then a pit bull and a Rottweiler came out and ran us back to the sidewalk," Officer Gilworth recalled, saying that Matthaeus Jaehnig was the only one arrested. "On the way down to the jail, he was saying that the K.K.K. was not violent enough for their faction," Officer Gilworth said. "He said he was more in line with the white Aryan Nation."
Last month, Officer Vander Jagt, 46, had a second encounter with Mr. Jaehnig. He was the officer killed after the chase when he peered around a building corner -- straight into a fusillade from an SKS assault rifle. Mr. Jaehnig recovered Officer Vander Jagt's pistol, placed it under his chin and pulled the trigger.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Unbundling Microsoft

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The fast-spreading field of information technology represents what its proponents call "the new economy," an increasingly affluent incubator of innovative products, business practices and work habits. In the new economy, its advocates insist, none of the old rules apply -- and certainly not the old antitrust ground rules that date to the late 19th century and smoke-filled rail cars.
The Microsoft Corporation, the software powerhouse, is a leading standard bearer of the new economy. So in its marathon dealings with Washington's antitrust authorities, the company has understandably taken the stance that it is engaged in a lengthy education program. 
 Microsoft executives have often expressed the view -- in tones that ranged from sincere to condescending to belligerent -- that the more Washington understands about the software industry, and its special attributes, the more the Government will be persuaded to leave Microsoft alone so it can push ahead, unfettered, to continue producing great products, rich shareholders and satisfied customers.
But in issuing a temporary order on Thursday that bars Microsoft from forcing computer makers to bundle its Internet software with its popular Windows operating program, a Federal judge stated that the antitrust issues surrounding Microsoft were not mainly about the intricacies of software programming. Instead, citing Supreme Court rulings in other industries, the judge declared that the issues in the Microsoft case were ones of old-fashioned market power, its use and its potential abuse.
"Microsoft's 'unfettered liberty' to impose its idea of what has been 'integrated' into its operating systems stops at least at the point at which it would violate established antitrust law," wrote Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of United States District Court in Washington.
Judge Jackson's ruling is not an outright victory for the Government. His "preliminary injunction" against Microsoft is not a final decision. He appointed as "special master" a Harvard Law School professor, Lawrence Lessig, to study the issues of "cybertechnology" associated with the case and report back to the court by the end of May.
Yet for the moment, the Justice Department has achieved its goal of making it more difficult for Microsoft to use its dominant Windows operating system -- the program controlling the basic operations in more than 80 percent of world's PC's -- to give the company a special edge in the Internet browser market.
"The judge seems to agree with us that this case is about marketing practices and marketing power, and that traditional antitrust laws apply to this world," said Douglas A. Melamed, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General in the Justice Department's antitrust division.
Microsoft executives say they believe the company will win in court, after the judge and special master review further evidence. "We remain confident that continuing to innovate and integrate technologies is good for the software industry and good for consumers," said William H. Neukom, senior vice president for law and corporate affairs.
The current case is a narrow one. But Microsoft executives fear that losing it could open the door to what the company sees as Government meddling in its technology decisions -- perhaps, they say, having to get an approving nod from Washington before including new features in future versions of its operating system.
"The specter here is of a Federal Bureau of Operating Systems," said Nathan Myhrvold, the chief technology officer.
Yet many industry executives are skeptical that Washington's antitrust scrutiny poses any threat to Microsoft's ability to bring innovative new products to market.
"This isn't about innovation; it's about the limits of power," said Richard Shaffer, principal of Technologic Partners, a research firm. "At some point, sheer market power reaches a threshold where it tends to be abusive. It is a political and public policy issue. It's happening in a new context now with Microsoft, but it has certainly happened before with Standard Oil, the Morgan bank and others."
In the case before Judge Jackson in the Federal District Court in Washington, the Justice Department contends that Microsoft has been violating a 1995 consent decree in which the software company agreed to make slight changes in the way it prices and sells its Windows operating system to personal computer makers.
The consent agreement was signed just as use of the Internet was beginning to soar, fueled by easy-to-use browsing programs for using the World Wide Web. The first major commercial browser was the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator. Netscape remains the leader with more than 60 percent of the market, but Microsoft's Internet Explorer is gaining ground rapidly and now has about a 35 percent share.
In its antitrust action, the Justice Department argued that forcing PC makers to bundle Internet Explorer on their machines if they wanted to have Windows was a violation of the 1995 consent decree. Under the decree, Microsoft cannot "tie" a separate product to its Windows operating system, thereby giving it an unfair advantage in new markets.
The consent decree, however, does permit Microsoft to add new features to Windows as part of an "integrated" product. Microsoft's contention is that Internet Explorer is an integrated feature of Windows with the two programs sharing some programming language, making each dependent on the other to some degree.
Yet Microsoft also markets Internet Explorer as a separate product in shrink-wrap boxes in retail stores with its own advertising campaign and its own product logo. For the purposes of the consent decree, a key determination Judge Jackson must make is whether Internet Explorer is a "separate product" that Microsoft is unfairly tying to Windows or simply an "integrated" feature of Windows, as Microsoft contends.
In his ruling, Judge Jackson seemed to suggest that Internet Explorer appears to be a separate product, and he raised antitrust issues extending beyond the consent decree. He cited two Supreme Court rulings, one in 1984 addressing whether anesthesiology services were a product separate from the other services provided by a hospital and another in 1992 involving photocopier equipment and copier parts and service.
In those cases, the Court ruled that the key issue was not so much whether the services were integrated but the "character of the demand" and whether they were seen as "two distinct product markets" in the "eyes of the buyers."
In short, Judge Jackson appeared to be saying that the issue he was deciding in curbing Microsoft's marketing of its browser was market behavior and not technology.
"How this plays out remains to be seen," said Carl Shapiro, professor at the University of California at Berkeley, who was formerly the chief economist in the Justice Department's antitrust division. "But the ruling certainly shows that Microsoft cannot consider itself immune to antitrust law."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Russia to Cut Its Budget For $1.7 Billion in Aid
The International Monetary Fund and Russia agreed on a plan for a quick infusion of $1.7 billion from the fund and World Bank. The accord, which would allow for the payment of back wages and relieve pressure on the ruble, entails a new round of budget cuts that may be hard to get through Parliament. A1 

Bickering After Kyoto Pact
After the signing of a landmark environmental accord in Japan by 160 countries, sparring continued over whether developing countries would be obliged to match the industrial countries' commitment to cut emissions. A7
 
Several Republicans began testing arguments against the global climate agreement, sensing that they might skewer it despite the country's general support of strong environmental action. A1
 
Albright Praises Congo Leader
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visited Congo and applauded the leadership of President Laurent Kabila. She stressed the need for democracy and the rule of law, but pledged higher American aid despite reports of opposition leaders being jailed and rumors of human rights violations and corruption. Ms. Albright, in the middle of a seven-nation African tour, expressed hope that the huge nation would become the "engine of regional growth" in central Africa. A3
 
Trial of the Jackal in Paris
Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, the international terrorist known as "Carlos the Jackal," went on trial in Paris on charges of killing two French security officials and a Lebanese informant 22 years ago. The Venezuelan native, who is wanted by at least four other countries for kidnappings, killings and bombings in the 1970's and 1980's, took his defense into his own hands and gave lengthy monologues about his political militancy for the Palestinian cause. A6
 
Dispute Ends at Polish Camps
A group of large stars of David and Christian crosses put up by Polish Boy Scouts in 1983 have been removed from the main burial ground at the Auschwitz and Birkenau death camps. That ended a dispute that delayed plans to preserve the sites where more than a million Jews were killed during World War II. The burial ground has been considered a national shrine for the millions of Poles who died in the war, but more than 90 percent of those killed at the Auschwitz and Birkenau camps were Jewish. A6
 
Belarus Blocks Rights Monitor
The Government of Belarus is preventing the establishment of an office there that would monitor human rights and assist in democratic development, European and American diplomats said. They said Belarus had agreed three months ago to allow the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to come to Minsk but has refused to provide the visas, diplomatic privileges or office space needed. A6
 
NATIONAL A8-13, A16
 
Internal I.R.S. Report Critical of Agency Tactics
The Internal Revenue Service, quoting from its own internal audit conducted this fall, admitted that taxpayer rights are abused by a systemwide "climate" of high pressure that encourages auditors to go to improper lengths to meet statistical benchmarks. The study said that this use of benchmarks by the I.R.S. was "unbalanced" and routinely confused as quotas. The I.R.S. commissioned the study after Senate hearings in late September where taxpayers and whistleblowers told of abuses, leading to an extraordinary public apology from the agency. A1
 
Senators Threaten Clinton
Senate Republicans threatened to block Administration nominees and freeze funding for Administration programs if President Clinton uses his power next week to make a temporary appointment without Senate approval and name Bill Lann Lee to the nation's top civil rights enforcement post. A9
 
Court to Hear Firearm Case
The Supreme Court agreed to decide what it means to "carry" a firearm while committing a drug crime or crime of violence. Existing law imposes a mandatory five-year prison sentence on anyone who "uses or carries a firearm" during that type of crime, but the cases the court will hear involve defendants who were convicted of committing drug trafficking offenses while they had guns either locked in a glove compartment or car trunk. A13
 
Senator to Summon Reno Aides
The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said he would summon top aides to Attorney General Janet Reno to testify about how she reached her decision to reject an independent prosecutor in the campaign finance case. A11
 
Nomination Was Mishandled
The State Department admitted that it mishandled the vetting of M. Larry Lawrence's 1993 nomination as Ambassador to Switzerland. But officials denied that contradictions in his record were overlooked by a dozen investigators because he was a leading Democratic fund-raiser. A16
 
Diarrhea Vaccine Ruled Safe
The first vaccine against a virus that is the leading cause of childhood diarrhea is safe and works, Government advisers said. The virus, called rotavirus, sends 55,000 American children to the hospital each year and kills one million in other countries. A8
 
California Highway Reopens
Traffic began moving cautiously through the fog on California's Interstate 5, which had been closed since Thursday morning, when 37 trucks, pickups and cars were involved in collisions that killed five people. Nine big-rig trucks and 28 passenger pickups and cars smashed together after being engulfed by sudden patches of dense fog on northbound Interstate 5 near Elk Grove, 17 miles south of downtown Sacramento. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5
 
Panel Ends Hearings On Flight 800 Crash
The National Transportation Safety Board wound up a week of hearings on the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 without uncovering what made the plane explode shortly after takeoff, but with something that its top officials said was almost as good: a consensus that steps should be taken to cut the risk of fuel tank explosions in all planes. A1
 
Sentencing in Cosby Case
A Federal district judge in Manhattan sentenced Autumn Jackson to 26 months in prison after the young California woman tearfully apologized for trying to extort millions of dollars from Bill Cosby. The judge said she would recommend to the Federal Bureau of Prisons that Ms. Jackson, 23, enter a prison boot camp program. Ms. Jackson was convicted of threatening to sell a story to a supermarket tabloid that she was the actor's out-of-wedlock daughter unless he paid her $40 million. B3

Redefining 'Holocaust'
The release of the flim "Amistad" this week, based on the mutiny of African captives aboard a slave ship in 1839, has focused attention on what is commonly becoming known as the "black Holocaust." The increasing use by African-Americans of a proper noun so closely identified with the Nazi genocide that it does not require the modifying adjective "Jewish" has raised the issue of who, if anyone, owns language, particularly language of rare moral urgency. HEADLINE: Think Nuclear Power As Warming Solution

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Meeting Reaches Accord to Reduce Greenhouse Gases" (front page, Dec. 11): In discussions about global warming and measures to mitigate its consequences, nuclear power is often overlooked. 
 Nuclear power does not produce carbon emissions, the major contributor to global warming. France is a dramatic example of what can be done. Its use of nuclear power to generate nearly 80 percent of its electricity allows it to maintain the lowest per-capita carbon dioxide emissions level among members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
True, nuclear power produces radioactive waste, which must be isolated for hundreds of years. But the amounts are relatively small and can be safely and economically managed, as shown in Europe. The impediments to the resolution of nuclear waste management in the United States are largely political, not technical or economic.
 
SIMCHA GOLAN
Foster City, Calif., Dec. 11, 1997
 
The writer is a nuclear engineer.

HEADLINE: Think Nuclear Power As Warming Solution;
Sacrifice Isn't Necessary

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You report (news article, Dec. 11) that for the United States to meet the promises agreed to at the global warming conference in Japan, Americans would have to make significant cuts in their use of fossil fuels. However, it will hardly be a sacrifice for this country to shift away from fossil fuels and embrace energy efficiency, fuel cells, photovoltaics and wind power. These technologies will improve the way we live, not with shocking sacrifice but with good old-fashioned American ingenuity. 
 We can reduce carbon dioxide emissions dramatically with energy efficiency and low-emission technologies at no net cost. This is because energy efficiency frequently costs less than energy generation. Most efficiency investments pay for themselves in just a few years.
While the Energy Department has indeed determined that our appetite for fossil fuels is growing, it has also concluded that a shift toward efficiency would not hurt the economy.
You note that politics -- not technology -- is the barrier and that restructuring of the utility industry provides a crucial opportunity to reduce greenhouse emissions. If done properly, restructuring will bring energy-efficient products and services to consumers and remove the indirect subsidies that have allowed coal-fired generating plants to avoid compliance with the environmental standards that other power generators in the country must meet.
 
ASHOK GUPTA
Senior Energy Economist
Natural Resources Defense Council
New York, Dec. 11, 1997

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Who Can Lead South Korea Out of the Quagmire?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 12

 BODY:
As South Korea lurches through an economic crisis, the presidential campaign here seems unusually clean and democratic. People are grumbling about just one detail: the candidates.
None of the three contenders has given a very credible explanation of how he would manage the economy. Two have even said they would renegotiate the International Monetary Fund bailout that is now the country's life-support system, although they have since been backtracking. 
 This has alarmed investors and foreign governments, particularly because each candidate had signed a pledge agreeing to go along with the bailout. But the broader challenge for South Korea may be that none of the candidates seems likely to emerge with a broad mandate that would allow the closing of insolvent banks and factories, a confrontation with striking unions and the unification of the nation behind a program to restructure industry and finance.
The two leading candidates, Kim Dae Jung and Lee Hoi Chang, are both respected as intelligent, cosmopolitan and courageous. But questions linger about whether they are up to the herculean task of carrying out the I.M.F. accord and presiding over a bleak landscape of layoffs, inflation and bankruptcies.
"Politically, it's very difficult," said Lee Hong Koo, a former Prime Minister. "Whoever is President next time, he's got to be unpopular. There's no other way. We need someone to say, 'This looks bad, but this is what we've got to do.' " The election is Dec. 18.
Mr. Lee favors Lee Hoi Chang, the ruling party's candidate, to bear those bad tidings. A former Supreme Court justice who has been a visiting scholar at Harvard and the University of California at Berkeley, Lee Hoi Chang is a stern, independent-minded figure whose drawback as a campaigner is that he has the charisma of a statue.
A bit ahead of Lee Hoi Chang in the polls is Kim Dae Jung, a longtime dissident who has exhibited enormous courage in defying military dictators but a bit less in challenging voters. A hero of the long struggle to bring democracy to South Korea, Mr. Kim makes the establishment nervous and is broadly popular only in his native Cholla region, in the southwest.
"If I am elected President, I will pursue new negotiations with the I.M.F. in order to regain our economic autonomy and benefit the national economy," Mr. Kim declared a few days ago.
The third candidate, Rhee In Je, who seems to have little chance of winning, has also called for renegotiation, while Mr. Lee has said that he will stick with the agreement.
The policy differences among the candidates are relatively minor, with all agreeing on a pro-American foreign policy, on the importance of a market-oriented economics, and on efforts to engage North Korea. Indeed, one of the most obvious policy disagreements concerns whether to try to negotiate a new I.M.F. accord, and lately even Mr. Kim and his aides have been signaling that this might not happen.
Indeed, in a letter to the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, released to the press today, Mr. Kim said he sought "to resolve additional issues and make up for shortcomings in the agreement."
"There have been some press reports that I demand to renegotiate the entire package," he added. "I have never made such a demand."
Ben Q. Limb, a Korean-American lawyer who serves as an adviser to Mr. Kim, said, "What he means by renegotiating the agreement is not the same as repudiating it." Mr. Limb said Mr. Kim would simply seek adjustments within the I.M.F. guidelines.
The latest opinion polls, campaign officials say, show Mr. Kim with about 37 percent of the vote, Mr. Lee with 35 percent and Mr. Rhee with 20 percent. The difference between the two leaders is statistically insignificant, and some analysts say that in the end, undecided voters are more likely to support Mr. Lee because he seems to be the safest bet.
"The mood ranges from anxiety to anger," said Han Sung Joo, a former Foreign Minister who is advising Mr. Lee. "If the anger prevails, then I think Kim Dae Jung has a good chance, because he not only is in the opposition but also has been tapping that anger by saying he would renegotiate the I.M.F. agreement. But if worry prevails, then I think that Lee Hoi Chang has a better shot."
While the administration of President Kim Young Sam has been severely tarnished by the economic crisis, this has not hurt Mr. Lee and the ruling party as much as one might expect. Although President Kim and Mr. Lee have worked closely in the past, they are now feuding, and President Kim may be supporting Mr. Rhee. Indeed, Mr. Lee has gone so far in distancing himself from President Kim as to change the ruling party's name, to the Grand National Party.
In the absence of major policy differences, the campaign has centered on such matters as Mr. Kim's age and health (he says he is 71, while his critics say he is about 74 and too old for the job) and Mr. Lee's family. Mr. Lee's election would have been almost a sure thing were it not for the failure of his two sons to enter military service.
It is perhaps natural that candidates are not extensively describing their economic policies, for there is not much political mileage in detailing to voters precisely how a candidate would make them suffer. The candidates say, only in general terms, that they are eager to shake up Korea and preside over the transition to a more modern economy.
Still, each might find that task overwhelming.
Mr. Lee is a product of the Korean establishment that many analysts say is the nation's central problem, with inbreeding between politicians, the bureaucracy and huge corporations. Mr. Kim is an outsider and might find it easier to uproot the establishment, but he has a reputation as a populist and might find it difficult to say no to trade unions, which wield enormous power.
"Clearly, this is a very difficult political environment to do something like this," a senior Western diplomat said, referring to the bailout. "You're striking at some of the connective tissue of how this system has functioned."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kwon Young Gil, a former South Korean labor leader eyeing the presidency, has his head shaved as a protest to the I.M.F. bailout plan. Two of the main candidates for the election have also voiced concern over the deal. (Associated Press)(pg. D3)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ELECTRONICS FOR IMAGING STOCK DROPS SHARPLY

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The stock of Electronics for Imaging Inc. fell more than 61 percent yesterday after it became the latest technology company to warn Wall Street of an earnings shortfall for its current quarter. In Nasdaq trading, the shares plunged $24.125, to $14.875,. The company, based in San Mateo, Calif., a maker of color-printing products, said it would earn 6 cents a share in its fourth quarter ending Dec. 31, excluding charges, in part because of weaknesses in Asian economies. Analysts surveyed by First Call had expected the company to earn 49 cents a share. The company also said delays in purchases associated with product transitions and aggressive inventory reductions by some customers were also behind the earnings shortfall.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: Already, The Getty Has a Full Agenda

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Barry Munitz has what might seem an enviably easy job. When he takes over as the president and chief executive officer of the J. Paul Getty Trust in January, he will inherit the recently completed product of more than a decade of efforts, a pristine, $1 billion art museum and research complex on a hilltop here that will celebrate its grand opening with ceremonies on Saturday.
With a $4.3 billion endowment, it has already captured worldwide attention. 
 But in a recent interview, Mr. Munitz, the chancellor of the California State University system, was strikingly blunt in dismissing the festivities, which will continue through the Getty's opening to the public on Tuesday, as having little relevance to what he described as a herculean task ahead. He wants to make this this imposing institution -- as well as the somewhat shapeless city over which it looms -- a national, and popular, center for culture.
"I'm not even paying much attention to them," said Mr. Munitz of the ceremonies and parties. "It's a great occasion, but to me it's the most preliminary kind of thing. It's too early to tell even what we are. We have so much work to do."
Mr. Munitz is a populist taking over what has been an elitist institution with little connection to the civic life of Los Angeles. His plans to draw a wide public to the new museum and other related institutions represents not only a big step in Los Angeles's coming of age as a major cultural center, but almost a repudiation of the majestic but isolated location of the fortresslike center, which is accessible only by a tram that leads up from a large parking garage whose parking spaces have been booked far in advance.
The campuslike structure covers 110 acres and sits on a hilltop towering above the San Diego Freeway and the tony west side neighborhoods of Brentwood and Bel Air. Designed by Richard Meier, it is a cool, austere series of buildings covered with Italian travertine, connected by a large off-white plaza and commanding a view of the ocean on smog-free days.
The museum includes 55,000 square feet of display space for its collections of ancient art, European decorative arts and Old Master and 19th-century paintings. It is a detached island of repose amid Los Angeles's busy sprawl.
"We have to think every day how we work against that," Mr. Munitz said of the aloofness of the setting. "There is a set of conditions against which we have to push back. It won't happen naturally."
Until now, despite its great wealth and creative talents, this city has traditionally made a far greater impression in movies and on television than in arts circles. In fact, when wealthy arts patrons here are interested in high art, they often fly to New York. And the city's many ethnic communities have traditionally had little involvement in the museums here.
David Geffen, one of the founders of Dreamworks SKG and a major collector and arts donor, observed: "People here go to New York all the time, for culture and theater. People don't expect to do that here to the same extent. In Los Angeles you have smaller goals, you have smaller institutions."
The hope now is that the Getty's opening can become an important part of a shift many people say is already beginning to take place.
"We do not have the tradition that New York, Chicago, Minneapolis, Cleveland have," said Eli Broad, a wealthy businessman who was founding chairman of the Museum of Contemporary Art here and is a former chairman of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. "We're younger. And you have a lot of first- generation wealth here. That's one reason why Los Angeles has not been a cultural tourist destination. It has been so fragmented. The Getty may be the locomotive to help the change."
It helps considerably that the Getty is opening at a time of unusual ferment in Los Angeles. The long-stalled plans to construct a new concert venue, Disney Hall, designed by Frank Gehry, just received a a $25 million donation from the Walt Disney. Plans are moving ahead to construct a new Roman Catholic cathedral downtown. A huge new sports and entertainment complex is also planned for downtown.
"When all that is completed, it will be a city that has dramatically transformed itself," said Rusty Powell, the director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the former director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. "The art market is always going to be pre-eminent in New York, but the second city aspect of what you find in Los Angeles is going to become irrelevant."
Michael Ovitz, the former president of the Walt Disney and a philanthropist, emphasized that these new architectural landmarks could themselves attract more interest. "When all that is built, you can finally make a compelling case for people coming to Los Angeles as a cultural destination," he said. "Those buildings will be a real draw for a city that hasn't had those kinds of draws."
Adding an even greater sense of momentum is the booming growth in the technology and entertainment industries, which are fueling an economic surge. In many instances, these businesses are just getting organized to back the arts here.
"Now the economy has been transformed," said Mr. Munitz. "Here we are at the Getty, close to but not much connected to, either of those communities. We are going to look quickly and aggressively at ways to partner up with the technology industry and the entertainment industry." Mr. Munitz is certainly not facing a blank slate, but he characterizes the huge new campus as little more than a $1 billion seed. He said that he had few specific plans so far, but that he wanted the Getty to become even more involved in education, bringing schoolchildren to the museum and training teachers in the arts.
When the outgoing head of the Getty, Harold M. Williams, took over in 1981, he had little mandate other than to create an important cultural institution. The Getty Trust had a modest museum in Malibu and a huge endowment. Mr. Williams pushed hard to develop not just the museum and its collection of ancient art, Old Master paintings and the like, but also research into such areas as art conservation and support of education.
Today, the immaculate new campus houses, in addition to the museum, institutes for arts research, conservation, arts information, education, grants and arts leadership.
The principal public draw, of course, will be the collection, but Mr. Munitz was cautious about what it could achieve, even with its huge acquisition budget.
"It's never going to be an encyclopedic museum," he said. "It will be a spectacular museum."
That is one area of potential friction as Mr. Munitz tries to connect the museum with other arts institutions here. The Getty can outbid almost any other institution, including local museums, for major works, and has done so on occasion. Mr. Williams explained that one reason the Getty had decided to collect works only up to the 20th century was so it would not compete in more recent art with other museums in the area. (The trust has filled its private administrative offices, however, with works by artists like Jasper Johns and Willem de Kooning.)
Mr. Williams said the museum could reconsider the self-imposed limits on 20th-century art. Some museums here are concerned that the Getty might outdo them in seeking donations of major collections of contemporary art from wealthy individuals.
Meanwhile, Mr. Munitz is trying to stress the trust's functions other than the museum as a way of building connections with the city's various communities, particularly its Latino, Asian and other ethnic groups.
"Perhaps most critical is that this will strengthen and awaken the local awareness of an arts culture for a variety of communities in Los Angeles, many of which aren't used to thinking of these things," said Mr. Munitz.
Some of the other museums here are also trying to build bridges to groups that were traditionally neglected. "When this museum was built, there was no belief in outreach," said Andrea L. Rich, the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, which has recently created a collection of Mexican art. "You may not need that in New York, but in Los Angeles you have to make a conscious decision to come to the museum."
Whatever kind of relationship develops between the Getty and communities around the city is likely to be complicated. There will be almost no drop-in traffic because of the need for parking reservations. There will be no street life in the big plaza in front of the museum, no mimes passing a hat or food vendors.
"We won't have the pretzel guy and the hot dog guy," said Mr. Williams. "But we'll have our espresso carts."

A picture caption in the Arts and Ideas pages on Saturday, with an article about heightened expectations for the new Getty Center in Los Angeles, referred imprecisely to the buildings shown and misstated the extent of the opening scheduled for today. The picture showed the entire Getty Center, not just the museum, and all of it is opening to the public.

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
The saddest crimes in Archer Mayor's rawboned mysteries set in Vermont are the slow deaths of those hard-working mill towns that were once the backbone of the industrial Northeast. Its factories closed and its spirit broken, the worn-out specimen that Mayor mourns so eloquently in BELLOWS FALLS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $22) has already deteriorated into a welfare town plagued by crime and burdened with social problems. But a reclamation movement is also afoot in this picturesque village, so the last thing it needs now is a new drug merchant -- or a sex scandal in the already demoralized Police Department.
Lieut. Joe Gunther, the iron man of this rugged series, is lent out by the Brattleboro Police Department for the internal investigation of a cop accused of harassing the wife of one of the town's less-than-solid citizens. Gunther knocks down the bogus charge but sticks around to keep an eye on the complainant, a known drug dealer whom he suspects of setting up a distribution network sure to undermine the fragile stability of Bellows Falls. Mayor creates the kind of characters who have always had to fight for survival. Individuals like the villain's battered wife and the naive young cop who falls in love with her seem painfully real. But it is when these people are viewed collectively -- as Bellows Falls in the flesh -- that we can really see the value of their lives. 
 On a perishing cold winter's day in 1895, the naked, abused body of a young housemaid is discovered frozen to the ground in a squalid back alley of Toronto. Maureen Jennings makes a tender moment of this stark scene in EXCEPT THE DYING (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95), a first novel enriched by the vividness of its period settings and animated by the lifelike characters caught up in its broad social sweep.
The newsboys on their street corners, the prostitutes in their filthy beds, the widows at their craft work, the courting couples on their skating ponds, the rich men at their clubs -- Jennings has a wonderful feel for the places and tasks that give life and context to a character. She also understands the barriers of economics, class and religion that imprison people in their separate niches.
By virtue of his sympathetic nature, Detective William Murdoch slips easily through all these worlds, unafraid to shake them to their foundations in his search for the person who is using and discarding women with such contempt. In private, Murdoch mourns the fiancee who died young ("gone as quickly as a shadow on the lawn") and silently practices his waltz steps on the bare floor of an empty room. Although he solves his case in a fairly conventional way, there's more to Murdoch than his genre traits, and his warm heart makes him the right sleuth for this cold city.
Ian Rankin's Scottish police procedurals are so gritty you have to pick the shards out of your teeth when you finish one, and BLACK & BLUE (St. Martin's, $24.95) is as flinty as they come. Only a hard cop like John Rebus could shrug off the attacks of gangsters, the threats of senior officers and the grief he gets from his own Calvinist conscience to carry on a lone-wolf investigation into several heinous but far-flung and seemingly unrelated crimes.
Don't ask him why, but Rebus senses a connection between the murder in Edinburgh of an oil rig worker from Aberdeen and the Godfatherlike maneuvers of a mobster in Glasgow. More unnerving are the parallels he sees between the current activities of a serial killer known as Johnny Bible and the work of Bible John, the legendary "bedtime bogeyman" of an earlier generation.
It takes a lot of traveling time and close, often dangerous police detection for Rebus to work all the information he gathers into a coherent pattern; and some events, like a trip to an oil rig in the middle of the North Sea, stick in the mind more than others. But Rankin has a point to make about the corrosive effects of human wickedness that, if left unchecked, seeps into the bloodstream and poisons the national body -- a point well made in his blunt and bruising style.
The air of moral certitude in Margaret Yorke's new novel of psychological suspense, A QUESTION OF BELIEF (Mysterious Press/ Warner, $23), brings to mind those cozy classics of the golden age of the English mystery. The forces of good and evil line up neatly when a mild-mannered department store executive is falsely accused of sexual harassment by a vindictive customer. After losing both his job and the trust of his family, the poor chump fakes his suicide and tramps off to a little village where nobody knows of his shame. Here his fate intersects with that of another outcast, an illiterate teen-ager who has been shabbily manipulated by a militant animal rights activist with a hidden agenda. Several other folks come out of the woods to play, and although their convergences are strictly contrived, their characters are sharply defined in this fatalistic tale of modern morality in tatters.
Compared with the nimble-witted academics D. J. H. Jones satirized with such gusto in "Murder at the MLA," the brain-dead cultists who get hammered in MURDER IN THE NEW AGE (University of New Mexico, $19.95) are an easy target. Still, it's a nasty pleasure to watch the clever series heroine, the Chaucerian scholar Nancy Cook, stick it to the colony of New Agers whose house she is sharing while on sabbatical in Santa Fe. In her inspired intellectual assaults on cant, she debunks their theories on near-death experiences, gives them the scientific skinny on crop circles and informs them that their beloved Anasazi were cannibals. But both Nancy and the pseudonymous author are wasting their talent for invective on these chowderheads, even if one of them does happen to be a killer.

HEADLINE: Self-Remade Man

BYLINE: By Andrew Delbanco; Andrew Delbanco is Julian Clarence Levi Professor in the Humanities at Columbia University. His most recent book is "Required Reading: Why Our American Classics Matter Now."

 BODY:

George Bush
 The Life of a Lone Star Yankee.
 By Herbert S. Parmet.
 Illustrated. 576 pp. New York:
 A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $32.50. 
 Somewhere, some entrepreneur must be preparing a video library of 20th-century Presidents for release during the coming turn-of-the-millennium marketing frenzy. When the tape rolls around to George Bush, there will be the line-in-the-sand speech in which he went eyeball-to-eyeball with Saddam Hussein. There will be footage of Bush, at just the moment when Americans worried about becoming economic vassals of a predatory Japan, vomiting at a state dinner in Tokyo. And, to catch the irony of his eight years' service as Ronald Reagan's loyal Vice President, there will be his contemptuous charge -- issued during the 1980 campaign against Reagan for the Republican nomination -- that the California Governor was a believer in "voodoo economics."
These and lots of other familiar images scroll by in Herbert Parmet's "George Bush: The Life of a Lone Star Yankee," the first full-scale biography of the penultimate elected President of the 20th century. Parmet, a professor of history at the City University of New York, has given us a sympathetic portrait of a moderate Republican in the doomed lineage of Wendell Willkie and Nelson Rockefeller, who tried to refashion himself for the Sunbelt politics of Barry Goldwater and Ronald Reagan. He even finds a hint of tragedy in this career -- as Bush fails, despite his rise to the Presidency, to preserve the core value of the tradition from which he came, which Parmet sums up as "mitigating the excesses of capitalism" for those who gain or lose too much from the workings of the free market.
Ultimately descended on his father's side from Scottish Protestants and on his mother's side from English Catholics (the ancestral religious divide closed when the two families converged into socially irreproachable Episcopalianism), George Bush was born in 1924 into a family with a good pedigree and a solid fortune. After growing up in Greenwich, Conn., he took the prescribed route via Andover to Yale, where he acquired lifelong friends in the secretive Skull and Bones Society. His father, Prescott, was a partner in the investment firm of W. A. Harriman, and a member of the Yale Corporation. An imposing and formal man, Prescott Bush commuted for years to Grand Central Station, then rode down to Wall Street on the subway. "He'd die now," according to George's sister Nancy, "with limos picking them up. He was a straphanger." Though more than proficient at earning and saving, Prescott Bush regarded zeal for money as a contaminating passion.
Parmet's theme is how George Bush found his father's patrician New England scruples a handicap in the changed political world to which his own ambition drew him. Prescott Bush himself was elected to the Senate in 1952 (defeating Abraham Ribicoff), and when Parmet gives us a glimpse of him uneasily sharing a Bridgeport platform with Senator Joseph McCarthy, we get a premonitory feeling, as if we were watching a preview of the destiny of his son: the half-desperate, half-appalled blue blood cozying up to the xenophobes and demagogues who are taking over the Grand Old Party.
Having realized early that power was shifting westward, the younger Bush built his own political future, according to a friend, "by breaking away from the white-shoe set of Yale and Andover by going out and being a relative roughneck in the oilfields of Odessa, Tex." But the break was never clean. Throughout his Texas career, and beyond, he was dogged by suspicions that he was a silver-spoon Yankee dissembling in a cowboy hat.
Parmet gives a meticulous account of Bush's rise to prominence in Texas, beginning with his ventures in oil exploration, financed in part by family funds. When Bush moved into politics (becoming Harris County Republican chairman in 1963), he never lost his adopted identity as an oilman -- always defending the oil depletion allowance and other tax and regulatory benefits for the industry, even while preaching the evils of government interference in the marketplace. Some of the social attitudes he had brought with him from New England were, however, more dispensable. "His first significant break with his moderate background," according to Parmet, came during his run for the Senate in 1964 against the Democratic populist Ralph Yarborough. With "working-class ethnic minorities, especially blacks and Mexican-Americans . . . threatening to depart from their traditional roles as suppliers of cheap labor," George Bush responded by defending poll taxes as better than having the polls "swamped" with the "liberal bloc vote" they potentially represented.
Though he lost to Yarborough in 1964, he was elected two years later to Congress from Houston's Seventh District; and by 1968 the young Congressman, with his unusual aura of Texas savvy and New England polish, was widely discussed as a possible running mate for Richard Nixon. After another failed try for the Senate in 1970, Bush changed course, building his circle of patrons through a series of appointed offices: Ambassador to the United Nations, chairman of the Republican National Committee, head of the United States liaison office in China and Director of Central Intelligence.
Throughout this career, many found it hard to tell just what George Bush believed. Parmet, too, seems uncertain -- reporting, for instance, that Congressman Bush was sufficiently liberal on family planning and abortion laws that he was known in Washington as "Rubbers." Yet when he ran with Ronald Reagan in 1980, he endorsed in full voice the party platform calling for a constitutional amendment to repeal Roe v. Wade. Every politician sometimes has to bend to the wind; but Parmet's book raises, again and again, the question of whether George Bush ever came to a moment in public life when he followed his convictions rather than his interests -- or whether there was any distinction between them.
This question is never resolved. Parmet finds hints in Bush's diaries (to which he had free access) that he recoiled from what the biographer calls the "tacky ostentation" of the Reagan circle. Yet he notes in passing that when it came time for Bush's own inauguration in 1988, it was twice as expensive as Reagan's. Still, he seems to want to dissociate Bush from the "Teflon President," in whom Parmet finds hypocrisy raised to a public art. Reagan, he writes, "could increase deficits while calling for budget balancing and win praise for fiscal responsibility. He could ignore export laws by making covert shipments of arms. He could do almost anything without jeopardizing assumptions about his patriotism and good sense."
In the end, the suggestion of discontinuity between the master actor and the career politician is unconvincing. The era of Reagan and Bush was continuous in the growth of income disparity to its greatest levels since the Gilded Age. It was continuous in inflaming racial animosities, narrowing access to education and shifting the burden for social welfare to the private sector even as the pace of charitable giving declined -- despite Bush's talk about a "thousand points of light" and being the "education President." And thanks to the Iran-contra circumvention of the Congressional ban on supplying arms to Nicaraguan "freedom fighters," the savings and loan scandals, and the atmosphere of venality and greed that Parmet describes with appropriate revulsion, the Reagan-Bush years contributed to the breakdown of public trust in the processes and persons of government.
Parmet tends to describe George Bush as valiant rather than insouciant within the historical limits in which he found himself. He points out that Congress shared responsibility for the deregulation of the savings and loan industry that led to the most costly taxpayer bailout in American history. And he writes admiringly of Bush's handling of foreign affairs in the aftermath of Tiananmen Square, during the potentially explosive meltdown of the Soviet empire, the controversy over German reunification and the gulf war. Yet in the end Bush's reputation will be safer with those who get their history from video clips than those who read this ultimately disheartening book. For fans' coffee tables, there is "George Herbert Walker Bush: A Photographic Profile" (Texas A&M University Press, $39.95), compiled by the former President's personal photographer -- a feel-good album ranging from boyhood photos to snapshots of the "grandkids." By contrast, Parmet's book leaves one with the feeling that it was written with respectful intent by an author too scrupulous to conceal its indicting effect. It is the story of a man who never quite convinced the new Republican ideologues that he was one of them -- though not for lack of trying. "To passionate critics on the far right," as Parmet puts it, "Bush had to do more, more, more," and he never did enough. Whether he stopped short out of decency or weakness is never quite clear.
The theme of desperation and inconstancy in an unmoored American leader that Parmet explores in this book was anticipated with uncanny prescience by Walter Lippmann nearly 70 years ago: "Our rulers today . . . are to be found in the inner circles of banks and corporations, in the best clubs . . . among the political churchmen . . . and the grand panjandrums of the secret societies. They give orders. They have to be consulted. . . . But none of them is seated on a certain throne, and all of them are forever concerned as to how they may keep from being toppled off. . . . Nor do they count with any confidence upon retaining their power, nor of handing it on to their sons. They live, therefore, from day to day, and they govern by ear. Their impromptu statements of policy may be obeyed, but nobody seriously regards them as having authority."
In 1992 -- still flush with war victory, but weakened by years of trying to placate the forces of reaction within his own party -- George Bush finally toppled. Perhaps a new generation of Republican leaders like George W. Bush, now Governor of Texas, will find a way to restore the old combination of economic conservatism and social liberalism for which his father and grandfather once claimed to stand. "You can count on it," the senior George Bush might say, as he used to do on the campaign trail. But who would believe him?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 469 words

HEADLINE: The Population Explosion Is Over

 BODY:
After arguing for years that societies have little trouble adjusting to rapidly growing populations, Ben J. Wattenberg is worrying that aging populations and slower growth are obstacles to human well-being ("The Population Explosure Is Over," Nov. 23). What delicious irony!
Birthrates are certainly declining around the world. Not a world made lonely by fewer children, however, but one with better access to education and health care for women, and with families who are choosing to have fewer kids in order to give each child a better life. 
 Wattenberg would have us believe that "the saddest funerals are those in which the deceased have no offspring." In developing countries, the saddest funerals are those of the 600,000 women who die needlessly each year from pregnancy-related complications, many of them mothers with young children.
Yes, world population growth is slowing, but is unlikely to be over "soon." Today's population of 5.9 billion puts us just past the midpoint of some 50 years of unparalleled growth: some 2 billion people since 1970 and most likely another 2 billion by 2020. If the world's population starts to decrease in size, it will only do so several decades from now at the earliest, and from a level substantially higher than today's.
Most future growth will occur in developing countries. While birthrates have fallen in many of these countries, they are still high in many others. In sub-Saharan Africa, birthrates are not "plunging," but falling modestly. For example, in Kenya, the average number of births per woman has fallen from over eight to between five and six. Under even the lowest of the U.N.'s projections, sub-Saharan Africa's population will nearly double in size to 1.2 billion by 2025.
Many poor countries are struggling to support their current populations. Slowing population growth is essential to insure a world worth living in for future generations. Even with declining birthrates, by the middle of the next century, at least two billion people will live in countries where water shortages may constrain food production and economic development.
Wattenberg rightly attributes declining birthrates in developing countries to the success of international efforts to expand access to family-planning services, to social and economic change, but most of all, to the conscious choices about childbearing made by millions of individuals. But his misrepresentation of other facts provides further ammunition for those seeking to deny women and men the means to control their reproductive destinies, including our own Congress, which has slashed funding for international family planning by one-third since 1995.
 
Robin Chandler Duke
National Chairman
 Shanti Conly
 Director, Policy Research
 Population Action International
 Washington
