HEADLINE: Housing Investment Surges in Cambridge, Mass.

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
A YEAR ago Linda and Russell Gee sold the roomy home in suburban Newton where they raised their two children and bought a Victorian house on a marginal block dense with housing in Cambridge.
"Classic empty-nester stuff," said Mr. Gee, a 51-year-old partner in a software company in the nearby town of Waltham. 
 The couple used the $400,000 from the sale to buy a 100-year-old house on Sacramento Street, a few blocks from the Harvard campus in a neighborhood with a mix of artists, academics and affluent professionals and working-class families.
They intend to invest $175,000 more to renovate the house. Given the expense, Mr. Gee said, "we're asking ourselves, 'Is this a bad idea?' "
"But it's so cool living here," he said. "We can walk to stores and bars that aren't chains and have neighbors who teach, who make furniture. Money is not at the center of everybody's life as it was in Newton."
In the last three years, this city of 92,000 residents in Boston's backyard has seen a wave of newcomers like the Gees invest in upgrading the existing housing stock. Along with them as well have come professional developers producing luxury housing for others to buy or rent.
Cambridge is buzzing with renovation activity because the end of rent control has coincided with a strong economy and favorable interest rates. A statewide referendum three years ago, financed by property owners and real-estate trade groups, led to the demise of controls in the three communities that had it -- Cambridge, Boston and Brookline.
In Cambridge it stripped 15,000 housing units of rent protections, about 37 percent of the entire housing supply.
Real estate specialists note that the long housing recession of the late 80's and early 90's has given many baby-boomer families the time to amass equity to plow into a housing investment.
"The housing market here is exploding," said Roger Herzog, the director of housing for Cambridge, who runs the city's affordable housing programs. He expressed concern that owners who developed low-income housing years ago under Federal programs would convert about 2,000 units to market-rate rentals once they became eligible to do so. If the owners refinance with conventional loans, they would be able to charge market-rate rents.
Already about 800 new luxury rental units are being built, the first upsurge in new market-rate construction in 25 years. And all around the city existing homes are being refurbished, sometimes expanded by new owners who build additions, and sometimes converted from rental or ownership occupancy to condominium apartments.
In the 1997 fiscal year, which ended June 30, Cambridge issued 2,100 permits for building projects, up from 1,488 for the year that ended in June 1994, the last 12-month period under rent regulation. Ranjit Singanayagam, the city's assistant commissioner of the Inspectional Services Department, estimated that the 1997 permits would generate $170 million in renovation activity. The 1994 permits brought forth about $61 million in renovation work, he said. The department keeps no figures on the number of housing units represented by the permits it issues.
"In Cambridge, we've seen some properties flipped after a rehab for prices that are almost too high," said Stephen E. Doran, a vice president for Fleet Mortgage Corporation, which recently had about a 30 percent increase in the origination of home-improvement loans over the last three years. According to Karl Case, a housing consultant to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, "The low end of the market is disappearing and the high end is reaching new heights."
THE house the Gees purchased had not previously been a rental. They bought it from a woman who had lived in it for 70 years. With about 2,000 square feet on two floors, it is much smaller than their Newton house and has never undergone major renovations. It has two bedrooms, a sleeping porch and one bathroom upstairs. Downstairs, it has a gracious entry foyer and staircase, parlor, dining room and kitchen.
The Gees expect to spend about five months to modernize the interior and refurbish the historic exterior. They will tear down the garage to have a larger backyard and space to expand the sleeping porch and one bedroom into a master suite. They will also add one and a half bathrooms, finish part of the basement for an office, gut the kitchen and existing bathroom and rebuild a side porch.
Elsewhere in Cambridge, the ever greater presence of commercial developers has raised questions about whether residential streets in higher-density zones will lose their character as builders seek to maximize the economic potential of their sites.
The city's oldest house, the 307-year Cooper-Frost-Austin House, is on Linnean Street, where Steven A. Cohen, president of the CEA Group of Cambridge, who has long experience as a builder in the city, purchased an 1872 Victorian for $825,000 late in 1995. A long battle with neighbors ensued when he proposed to build eight new condominium units on the property, which was zoned for 14 units.
Ultimately, he compromised by renovating the existing house and building a four-story addition on the rear of the lot, with one luxury condominium of about 2,200 square feet on each floor. He had the original house lifted up while a larger foundation was poured for the project. He is also renovating the original house, and he has sold three of the five units at prices of just under $900,000 to just shy of $1 million each.
But neighbors are still unhappy, fearing that their Avon Hill neighborhood and similar districts with a historic character will be unwisely transformed.
Gwendolen G. Noyes, a partner in the Cambridge-based Oaktree Development Corporation, did a different kind of expansion and renovation on Garden Street, just a block from the Historic West Cambridge District where Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's mansion is maintained as a National Park site.
IN 1995, Oaktree purchased a 3,400-square-foot, single-family Victorian for $575,000. The company intended to renovate and convert the three-story, 1890 house into three units. But the city, fearing overdevelopment, downzoned that type of house, Ms. Noyes explained.
Instead, starting in the spring of 1996, her company added four feet to the back of the house and created two condominiums, which sold for a total of $1.2 million by last summer, she said. The most dramatic changes in the house -- the additional footage, a new entry, a widened and altered stairway, a new bathroom, finished basement, elaborately landscaped garden -- were made in the back unit purchased by Jerome and Marlene Schultz.
They sold the three-bedroom colonial where they had raised their two daughters in suburban Needham for a price they declined to disclose, and paid more to buy their 1,800-square-foot condominium with two bedrooms and a study.
"We were coming in every other week to have fun anyway," said Mr. Schultz, a clinical neuropsychologist who, with his wife, spent two years looking for a home here.
Ms. Schultz can walk to her job as an administrator at Lesley College while Mr. Schultz can easily commute throughout the region or around the country. His new home is near all the major highways and about 15 minutes from Logan International Airport.
"To decide at the last minute to go to a restaurant and walk to one of a hundred places is very exciting," he said. "We're close to the pulse of things."
As a bonus, he added, "We have enough space to maintain a family home that our daughters, and hopefully our grandchildren, can come back to."
Mr. Gee of Sacramento Street, meanwhile, wonders if some of the creative, youthful energy in Cambridge that attracts him and his wife will be priced out of the market.
Ms. Noyes, the developer, who herself is a Cambridge resident, acknowledges that to a degree, it is inevitable.
"People are being displaced," she said. "It can be heart-rending, but as an architect and a builder, when I see people fixing up houses and giving them 50 more years of life, I can't say I feel bad about that."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2976 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
With a Lavish Bow to the Past, A Broadway Palace Is Built

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
"TONY, ARE THEY GOING to pour the orchestra Thursday?" Peter H. Kofman asked one morning last February, the edge in his voice suggesting that there was only one answer he wanted to hear.
Mr. Kofman, an architect and engineer from Toronto, stood near Times Square inspecting an embryonic steel skeleton that was growing even as he watched, beam upon column etched against a pale winter sky. In the fanlike arcs of the balconies-to-be, the framework had begun to hint at its structural destiny. It was becoming a theater. 
 A really big theater.
Concrete was about to be poured to form the auditorium floor. And Mr. Kofman sought assurance from the on-site project architect, Tony Tarazi, that this would occur the next day, as scheduled.
Every hour mattered. Mr. Kofman's client, Garth H. Drabinsky, chairman and chief executive of Livent, the Toronto-based theatrical production company, had told the world that he would have the theater, the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, open by December 1997. More than Mr. Drabinsky's reputation was on the line with this high-stakes goal; so were investment-tax credits worth $4 million to $5 million, applicable only if the theater was in operation by year's end.
As it happened, the orchestra floor was poured on schedule. Indeed, it seems that almost everything has gone right with the $22.5 million construction project, including elements not susceptible even to Mr. Drabinsky's considerable influence, like a mild winter that barely interfered with progress.
And so its many doors -- there are entrances both on 42d and 43d Streets -- are about to open, on time. This brings to a close the story of how a plush theatrical showplace emerged from what was a muddy pit only a year ago.
With a flourish, the Ford Center has appropriated the exuberant 43d Street facade of the Lyric Theater -- a turn-of-the-century, four-story riot of richly sculptured detail. But it has replaced the actual structure of the Lyric and its handsome next-door neighbor, the Apollo Theater of 1920, bookends to the brief period when 42d Street was the theatrical hub of New York City, the giddily high-spirited province of Shubert brothers and Ziegfeld girls.
Two historic 42d Street playhouses, the New Victory and New Amsterdam Theaters, have already been reclaimed as part of the government-sponsored 42d Street redevelopment project. Twelve days from now, when its curtain rises on the first New York preview of the musical "Ragtime," the 1,821-seat Ford Center will take its place as one of Broadway's largest theaters (rivaled only by the Gershwin and the New Amsterdam) and its first new playhouse in more than a decade. Opening night is Jan. 18.
Mr. Drabinsky is so proud of his theater that today he is inviting the public to an inspection tour between 10 A.M. and 6 P.M. Visitors will walk over the speckled mosaic faces of Tragedy and Comedy. They will discover as many chandeliers as a dowager has diamonds. Under the great elliptical dome salvaged from the Apollo and restored to Easter-egg perfection, they will find murals depicting music, dance and drama in ancient Greece. And everywhere they will spot lyres, emblems of the Lyric; painted, stenciled, cast in iron.
What they will not see is a restoration of the Apollo and Lyric auditoriums. Until a year ago, the Livent team artfully presented its plans to the public as a kind of combination and renovation of two old playhouses. Livent's annual report for 1995 described the new project as being built "within the existing framework of the legendary Lyric and Apollo Theaters."
In truth, the Lyric and Apollo were demolished. Yet key features were preserved and reincorporated in the new building: the Lyric's facades and the domes, proscenium arch, boxes and 42d Street lobby from the Apollo, which was designed by Eugene DeRosa.
"We're saving history and putting it in a much more practical environment," Mr. Drabinsky said. "The other theaters would have sat there and rotted. There's no point in talking about the conservation and restoration of history if it can't be savored by the public."
There is much to be savored in the Lyric facade, designed by V. Hugo Koehler, who was also the architect of a celebrated Harlem playhouse, the Lafayette Theater. Athena and Hermes gaze impassively on arriving theatergoers while demonic ram's-head masks leer over their shoulders. Banded columns soar upward from a second-story balustrade, framing arches that contain the busts of three bewhiskered Edwardian gentlemen. The brickwork is punctuated by oculi and festooned with enough wreaths for an opening-night bouquet.
(The theatrical historians Mary C. Henderson and Louis Botto both believe that the busts probably depict Reginald DeKoven, the composer for whom the Shubert brothers built the theater, and Gilbert and Sullivan, whose names were synonymous with musical comedy.)
Behind this facade was built an entirely new four-story structure housing the main lobby, a box office and two rehearsal halls.
On 42d Street, behind a smaller Lyric facade that was also preserved, is a renovated three-story structure containing another box office and a through-block link to the main lobby. On the second floor is an office, once used by the Shuberts, that will serve as Mr. Drabinsky's New York base.
Just west of the Lyric's facade on 43d Street is a new 94-foot-long, 70-foot-high box clad in red-brick panels that contains the auditorium of the Ford Center.
Rising beside the auditorium is the structure known as the stage house, which contains the stage deck, the fly loft into which scenery is hoisted and, below, the trap room into which the stage floor can be lowered. Reaching 100 feet, this structure is as tall as a 10-story apartment building. Atop it is a 40-foot-high rooftop sign.
At the pinnacle of the sign is the familiar logo of the Ford Motor Company, which paid Livent for "naming rights," as it has for theaters in Chicago, Toronto and Vancouver, British Columbia. Just how much, neither company will say. But Christopher P. Dixon, an entertainment analyst at Paine Webber who follows Livent, estimated that the New York theater commanded at least $8 million to $10 million. In return, Ford gets its blue oval in lights over Broadway and its name repeated in countless advertisements, posters, playbills and press accounts, including this one.
To justify the economic investment, the new theater needed 1,800 seats. Neither the Lyric nor the Apollo alone had that capacity. Combined, however, they offered a site that would accommodate such a theater.
But it took more than a little ingenuity to realize this vision.
 
February: A Steel Skeleton, And Each Inch Is Precious
"Every patron has to have a full view of the proscenium," Mr. Kofman declares. "If you work from that premise, the rest of the geometry almost sets itself." Rather than a single deep balcony, the Ford Center will have two shallow balconies, each only eight rows deep; the lower one has been designated the dress circle.
The view from the back of the dress circle is stunning now, although it is nothing theatergoers will ever see. There is no proscenium, just the emerging framework of the south proscenium tower.
Overhead is a skeletal balcony, a latticework of steel beams. Through the interstices can be spied the steep profile of the Hotel Carter down the block. Across the street, the gleaming terra-cotta facade of The New York Times building is visible, looking almost like a wall of the auditorium.
The only actual wall now standing is the 70-foot-high Lyric facade. Just three feet thick, it is braced by a scaffold built over the 43d Street sidewalk. The new structure behind the facade has a yawning hole in the center of its second story. This, Mr. Kofman explains, will be the lobby rotunda.
At the other end of the site is the stage house, which must be made as large as possible to accommodate changing theatrical technology. By tucking the steel columns of the stage house into vertical niches carved into the walls of the adjoining Selwyn Theater, the designers will pick up an extra eight inches of space. Ordinarily, such columns would be free-standing.
The goal at the Ford Center is a stage at least 55 feet deep by 97 feet wide; greater in area than those of the Lyric and Apollo combined. "Productions keep getting larger," Mr. Kofman explains. "The number of devices is becoming more significant, the electrical loads are growing, and there seems to be no stopping any of that."
More space will be gained by putting dressing rooms and other backstage functions in the basement, as was done at the restored Pantages Theater in Toronto, on which Mr. Drabinsky and Mr. Kofman also collaborated. "He's excavating the wig room," Mr. Kofman notes, as a backhoe operator tears at the raw earth.
Standing on the corrugated metal deck where the orchestra floor will be poured, Mr. Kofman draws a circle in the air, saying, "The main historic dome goes right in here."
 
June: The Roof Goes Up As the Pace Intensifies
Mr. Kofman's cell phone rings. "I'm on the roof of the Lyric," he tells his caller. That is how quickly the Ford Center is getting built. It already has a roof. And from this vantage point comes a surprising discovery. The rear wall of the auditorium is not flat, as it appears to be inside, but curving. This concave shape will help disperse sound and increase intelligibility.
For now, cacophony reigns as 250 workers swarm over the site. The only problem (at least the only one Mr. Kofman will share with a reporter) is that the pace of building threatens to overtake the production of detailed construction documents.
With the roof in place, the Ford Center is getting its exterior walls. It is here that the project is gaining a considerable saving in time -- at least two months -- by using prefabricated wall panels, typically 12 by 20 feet. The panels that cover the auditorium are surfaced in red brick, those that envelop the stage house in precast concrete.
They arrive from Richmond Hill, Ontario, on flatbed trucks and are lifted into place by a giant crane. The panels are attached to the superstructure but are isolated from the steel by synthetic rubber pads that will reduce vibration and thus the transmission of sound from the street.
Now that it is enclosed, the stage house looks as if it could do double duty as a dirigible hangar. Filling the auditorium is a lacy forest of scaffolding, recalling in its delicacy the interior of a Gothic cathedral as if rendered by a Cubist.
On stage sit three plaster domes, the largest one eight feet in diameter, that were extracted from the Apollo. They have just returned to the site from a warehouse in Bayonne, N.J., where they had been kept since demolition. They will be inserted under the dress circle and worked into the new design. For now, they are encased in welded steel frames, their ever so refined Adam esque ornament looking incongruous in the midst of burly construction equipment.
Elegance is otherwise in short supply today. For instance, the V.I.P. room -- for theatergoers who pay an additional $49 -- is filled with foil-covered duct work, metal-sheathed cables and insulation pads. No mahogany wainscoting yet.
 
July: Hearing a Pin Drop, And a Huge Alabaster Pie
"This is very important -- very important," Mr. Drabinsky insists, as he conducts a tour of the Ford Center one sweltering afternoon. He is not talking about stage depth, sightlines or public spaces.
He is talking about a small wedge-shaped room between the auditorium and the lobby, with doors at both ends. The double set of doors in this vestibule will serve as a noise and light barrier. In theaters where only one set of doors separates the auditorium from the lobby, a patron who arrives late or leaves early can disrupt the darkness and tranquillity of the whole house.
So Mr. Drabinsky insisted on vestibules at every entrance. It is just one way he has imposed himself on the design. "Everything matters to me," he says. That means the ratio of women's toilets to men's (two to one), the width of seats in the theater (22 inches, rather than the customary 18) and the distance between rows (34 1/2 inches, rather than the customary 30).
That means studios with cushioned floors and enough room for a full-scale rehearsal. "This is worth everything," Mr. Drabinsky says, "to rehearse people in air-conditioned, acoustically sound space."
Mr. Drabinsky also demanded a generously sized lobby. "I've been so cognizant of the claustrophobic nature of going to the theater in New York," he says.
The Ford Center lobby will have as its centerpiece a two-story rotunda, ringed by columns and a cast-iron balcony. A grand staircase will rise between the columns and branch out around the rotunda.
While the ceiling of the rotunda will be new, the auditorium will house the original 39-by-28-foot elliptical Apollo dome. It now sits on the scaffolding in two dozen sections that look something like segments of a gargantuan alabaster pie.
It is Mr. Drabinsky's turn to show off the vantage from the back of the house, encompassing the entire proscenium. "See it?" he asks triumphantly. "Needless to say, you're seldom playing to the top of the proscenium. If you do, you've got a director who doesn't know what he's doing."
 
August: Details Emerge As the Dome Turns to Gold
Finally, after all the talk about seeing the proscenium, there is a proscenium to see, framed in the ornamental arch recovered from the Apollo. Because it was too small for the new stage opening, the arch had to be widened eight feet across and lengthened five feet at the sides. Lighter-colored patches of plaster disclose its hybrid nature.
The main Apollo dome has been reassembled, and a crew of painters is revivifying it in a palette of slate blue, terra cotta, mustard and gold. Tiny flecks of excess gold leaf drift down and litter the work platform like glittering autumn foliage.
Subtleties are becoming evident. For instance, the auditorium walls are divided into panels that have a slightly convex shape, meant to spread sound more evenly throughout the house.
The most challenging work now is the installation of the 75-foot-long vault that spans the area in front of the proscenium. It is suspended in pieces from cables attached to the ceiling beams. Until the pieces are joined, the designers will not know exactly where it will meet the auditorium wall. "We're not sure at what angle the vault is going to hit the entablature, plus or minus an inch," Mr. Kofman says. "It's like a three-dimensional puzzle hanging out there."
 
September: People-Gazing From a Perch in the Rotunda
The network of scaffolding has been removed from the auditorium, revealing for the first time its cavernous volume. Richard Blinder, the partner in charge of design at Beyer Blinder Belle, enjoys the astonished look on a visitor's face. After all, he says, this is the point of the theatrical experience: "You drop your jaw just a little bit."
Clearing the scaffold forest has also uncovered the side boxes. "They animate the theater by placing people on the side, instead of a blank wall," Mr. Blinder says.
Wherever he looks, Mr. Blinder already sees crowds in his mind's eye. "One of the most important things about intermission is people-watching, and that's the purpose of this balcony," he says as he makes his way through the lobby rotunda.
Under his feet, covered by protective planks, are mosaic masks of Tragedy and Comedy, made of 172,800 green, gray, black, brown and ivory marble tiles by 18 artisans in a studio in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. "We looked at having it done in Italy," Mr. Blinder says, "and we thought they could do it better."
Pointing to a spot just above the first landing of the grand staircase, he adds, "Zeus goes there."
 
October: Finishing Touches Add the Grace of Years
Zeus has arrived. His fierce, bearded visage glowers from the center of a four-and-a-half-foot circular plaster medallion that once crowned the proscenium boxes at the Lyric. The arrival of this piece, which sits for the moment like an archeological artifact on the steps of the 43d Street lobby, marks one of the final deliveries of salvaged material.
While the builders seem busier today than ever, the place has begun to turn from construction site to cultural hub, as the rough-and-tumble edges get smoothed. Within a month, the "Ragtime" set will arrive.
The auditorium still resonates with hammering, sawing and drilling, but the sounds are muffled by carpeting. It is the color of cafe au lait, with a burgundy check, and it blankets the poured concrete floor Mr. Kofman worried about eight months ago. The house is bathed in an ivory-tinted glow. Light glints softly off the newly installed brass railings along the balcony parapets.
Incredibly, the theater actually seems to be aging as it nears completion.
Roger Morgan, the interior designer, says he hopes one day to overhear an exchange along these lines between a couple "of a certain age" arriving at the Ford Center for the first time.
"Alice," the husband will say, "this is where we saw 'Guys and Dolls.' "
"No," the wife will answer. "This is where we saw 'South Pacific.' "

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2377 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
An Abundance of Wit On the London Stage

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THE FUTURE OF THE LONDON theater may be as gloomy as local observers predict, though the visiting American can't worry too much when (like me two weeks ago) he can find 24 straight plays running in theaters in the West End, at the Royal National Theater and at the Royal Shakespeare Company. That compares to what is in fact an unusually high total of eight currently on Broadway, which has long since abandoned straight plays to the more adventurous, somewhat less economically pressed Off Broadway producers.
But it isn't only numbers that impress the visitor. It is also the enthusiasm with which London audiences, young as well as old, respond to the new, the difficult and the unpredictable. 
 A case in point: the National's ravishing production of "The Invention of Love," Tom Stoppard's latest play, a free-wheeling, idea-and language-stuffed comedy that takes as its subject the buttoned-up life and tumultuous times of A. E. Housman, the poet and scholar.
Housman (1859-1936) would not seem to be the most likely inspiration for a comedy, but Mr. Stoppard is a risk-taker. "The Invention of Love" also touches on textual criticism, Britain's notorious 1885 Criminal Law Amendment Bill (not repealed until 1967) under which Oscar Wilde was tried, the Esthetic Movement (with its emphasis on "boy love"), which was all the rage at Oxford in the 1870's and 1880's, and the nature of love itself. Supporting characters include Wilde, the critics John Ruskin and Walter Pater, the journalist Frank Harris and various Oxford and Cambridge dons whose names are probably familiar only to a dwindling number of Oxbridge students.
No matter. The wizardly Mr. Stoppard is an effective popularizer of esoteric knowledge. Remember "Arcadia" and the delight he took in coaxing audiences to pay attention to the basics of Newtonian physics, the mathematics of deterministic chaos and the historical import of English landscape gardening. "The Invention of Love" is in the same league, and so beautifully constructed that the playwright seems to be discovering his play only one jump ahead of the audience. It has that sense of surprise and wonder.
Housman, a closeted homosexual, lived out his carefully circumspect life mostly in academe, first at Oxford and then at Cambridge. For 30 years he worked on what he hoped would be his "monument," assembling the definitive Latin text of the "Astronomica" by Marcus Manilius, a first century Roman poet and astrologist. He believed in the acquisition of knowledge as an end in itself. Knowledge, Housman said, has a moral aspect; by being true, it is good.
At the same time, he was pouring his unrequited, nearly lifelong passion for Moses Jackson, whom he met when both were Oxford students, into his poetry. The initial result: "A Shropshire Lad," the collection of severely spare poems about lives of unfulfilled promise and desires (mostly young men's), set in a largely imaginary Shropshire, of which Mr. Stoppard has him say, "A county where I never lived and seldom set foot."
Housman is trying to get a fix on his life in the course of the play, which opens with his arrival at the River Styx to join Charon, the ferryman, for the voyage to the far shore. Whether what he sees and remembers is fact or fantasy, he can no longer be sure. Dead or sleeping? Even that is uncertain. In a succession of scenes that blend one into the next with cinematic fluidity (and with no regard for the classic unities), he moves back and forth in time, his secret love for Moses Jackson defined in the doubleness of his life as poet and scholar.
As Mr. Stoppard writes him, Housman is a figure of pinched rectitude but heroic dimension.
On his way to the other side, he sees himself on his arrival at Oxford, meeting Moses for the first time, but then when he has a chance to talk to the young Housman, he doesn't immediately recognize him. When he does, he suggests they sit down to chat: "I'm not as young as I once was. Whereas you, of course, are."
A hilarious croquet game, during which the master of Balliol College criticizes Pater for signing letters to an undergraduate "Yours lovingly," is crosscut with Housman's memory of coaching Moses as he trains for a track meet. At one point a myopic don mistakes the commonplace young Housman for the notorious Irish student who wears plum-colored velvet breeches and his hair long.
Though Oscar Wilde doesn't enter until near the end of the second act, his presence shadows the play. His proud flamboyance describes a sense of freedom and self-assurance that Housman denied himself in all things except his poetry and his work on the Manilius texts. Wilde's terrible fate at the hands of the law apparently haunted Housman. Though they never met in life, they meet in death by the River Styx, courtesy of Mr. Stoppard, in a scene of immense wit and melancholy.
HOUSMAN COMES UPON Wilde sipping a brandy and reading aloud from "A Shropshire Lad." His selection, one of the angriest in all of Housman's poetry, is the poem that begins: "Shot? So quick and clean an ending?" Inspired by the newspaper report of an inquest, Housman wrote about the young man, a Woolwich cadet who, shortly after the Wilde trial, blew his brains out to insure that his family would never be similarly disgraced by his own "weakness." Says Wilde: "Poor, silly boy!"
Weepily, the overweight esthete announces that he must return to Lord Alfred Douglas. "Bosie is what became of me." Bosie, he acknowledges, is spoiled, vindictive, selfish and untalented, "but these are merely the facts. The truth is he was Hyacinth when Apollo loved him."
Housman seems to shrink as Wilde goes
on: "Before Plato could describe love, the loved one had to be invented. We would never love anybody if we could see past our invention. Bosie is my creation, my poem. In the mirror of invention, love discovered itself."
Housman tries to offer sympathy to Wilde: "Your life is a terrible thing." But Wilde will have none of it. "Better a fallen rocket than never a burst of light," he says. "Dante reserved a place in his Inferno for those who willfully live in sadness."
Housman's life, Wilde realizes, was one of such sadness. Uncharacteristically benign as he departs, he mentions Housman's poems. "How can you be unhappy when you know you wrote them? They are all that will still matter."
Housman's final speech is filled with stoic rue. "Oxford in the Golden Age!" He recalls "the hair shirts versus the Esthetes; the neo-Christians versus the neo-pagans." "What emotional storms, and oh what a tiny teacup."
With his staging of "The Invention of Love," Sir Richard Eyre leaves the National Theater, where he has been artistic director since 1988, to be succeeded by Trevor Nunn, the man who staged Mr. Stoppard's "Arcadia" at the National in 1993.
"The Invention of Love" is a gala farewell piece. The production, starring John Wood as the old Housman and Paul Rhys as his younger self, is consistently well cast, simply but elegantly designed by Anthony Ward and lighted by Peter Mumford with the care of an obsessed poet, someone who knows when not to use a comma, and who would throw himself on the pen that would put it in.
Mr. Stoppard's work demands such care. Anything less, and the play goes out the window.
Note: I saw "The Invention of Love" at its last performance at the small Cottesloe Theater, where it opened in September. The production goes back into the National's repertory on Saturday, when it reopens at the larger Lyttelton Theater.
 
'The Chairs'
The falling-down funniest, most exhilarating production in London at the moment could well be "The Chairs," Eugene Ionesco's 80-minute "tragic farce," revived in a faultless production by the Royal Court Theater and the Theatre de Complicite, now at the Duke of York's.
Directed and choreographed by Simon McBurney, using Martin Crimp's translation, and starring Richard Briers and Geraldine McEwan, "The Chairs" seems to have slipped into town with almost no advance want-to-see, but left the local critics limp with unexpected pleasure. It deserves to be a hit.
Ionesco, the half-French, half-Romanian absurdist playwright (1909-94), has himself slipped into near-oblivion in recent years. After his vogue in the 1950's and 1960's, his work was overtaken by Samuel Beckett's pared down, far more uncompromising plays, which closely followed the appearance of Ionesco's. It seems clear on the basis of this production that the two playwrights are not really competitors. Beckett is a moralist; Ionesco is an absurdist-satirist whose wild humor transforms nightmares into occasions of grandly theatrical hilarity.
Mr. Briers, as the Old Man, has the face of an ancient spoiled child. Ms. McEwan, as the Old Woman, displays a skinny, bendable frame and a bandy-legged walk that recall Popeye's Olive Oyl gone to seed. He's a janitor, bitter about his missed opportunities. They're survivors of who knows what ghastly apocalypses, inhabiting a cavernous dump of a house surrounded by water, bucking up each other with banalities and endearments that flow from their mouths like pre-recorded announcements. She is his "petty-pie"; he is her "poppet."
On this night he is to deliver his message to the world, his gift to mankind, for which he has hired an orator (he is modest about his own public-speaking abilities) and invited guests who, lo and behold, start arriving: a "fabled beauty" (her "eyes still twinkling over the cataracts"), a famous field marshal who makes obscene proposals to a young woman, family groups, the media, opinion makers, strangers, hundreds. The house is packed to the gunnels.
The guests may be invisible but they are all clearly present, requiring -- nay, demanding -- chairs, which the poor Old Woman attempts to supply with mounting desperation. Doors open and close with increasing speed. Chairs of all descriptions and state of repair appear and pile up to create utterly blissful pandemonium. Think of the stateroom scene from the Marx Brothers' "Night at the Opera."
At one point, the double doors at the back of the stage part for the entrance of the Emperor, also called the King of Kings. "The king of what kings?" asks the momentarily grumpy Old Woman. He is a blinding light shown directly into the eyes of the audience, a variation on the celestial effects in one of Cecil B. DeMille's old biblical epics. The Orator does appear, a macabre, white-faced ghoul, who moves like a mannequin.
The Old Man and the Old Woman, their mission accomplished, serenely jump into the sea to their deaths. The Orator, who turns out to be deaf and dumb, can only mumble, then scribble a few words of gibberish on a blackboard. The End.
What does it all mean? Whatever you want to make of it. The remarkable thing is that it's so funny in the primal, uncomplicated way of slapstick. It is also moving.
Mr. Briers and Ms. McEwan (remember her as the elegant, mischievous Lucia in "Mapp and Lucia"?) are without price. The set, the lighting and especially the sound design (a cacophony of doorbells, buzzers, music, hubbub, squeaks and squeals) are all superb.
Mr. McBurney is the artistic director of the Theatre de Complicite, for which he directed and acted in the socially responsible peasant drama "The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol," presented in New York as part of Lincoln Center's Festival '96.
This man's bow has more than one string.
"The Chairs" goes off on Saturday, but returns to the Duke of York's on Jan. 6 to run through Jan. 31.
 
'A Delicate Balance'
Further notes: Edward Albee's comedy, "A Delicate Balance," is being revived at the Haymarket in a handsome production directed by Anthony Page, starring Maggie Smith, Eileen Atkins and John Standing.
Dame Maggie, who receives top billing, takes the supporting role of the sister Elaine Stritch played in Gerald Gutierrez's hit New York revival. The night I attended, she gave a fine, unbusy performance without any Maggie Smith interpolations -- in London that seems to be news. Ms. Atkins is superb as the wife. More than Ms. Stritch and Rosemary Harris, Ms. Atkins and Dame Maggie look and sound as if they could be sisters.
How does this production compare to Mr. Gutierrez's? It is different, more intimate, perhaps, but less grand and ghostly. The two star actresses are the attraction here, though Mr. Standing is exceptionally good in the husband's role, in which George Grizzard was exceptionally good in New York.
 
'A Letter Of Resignation'
Now at the Comedy Theater is "A Letter of Resignation," written by Hugh Whitemore, about Prime Minister Harold Macmillan during the 1963 crisis involving his secretary of war, John Profumo, a teen-age showgirl and a Russian naval attache. Edward Fox gives a good, serious impersonation of Macmillan, though he seems to be straining his voice at times. Clare Higgins is excellent as his wife, who is something more than she initially seems.
The revelation of the play (at least to me) was the way in which Mr. Profumo's marital difficulties reflected those in the Prime Minister's own house. Quite startling, but the play itself is made for the matinee trade. I saw it at an evening performance when, looking out over the sea of gray- and white-haired heads, I felt as if I were a member of a theater party for Macmillan's well-heeled Tory friends and associates.
 
'Art'
Keep an eye out for Yasmina Reza's "Art," the French comedy that has been running at Wyndham's Theater since October 1996. If the New York production opening on March 1 is as much fun as this one, which is now on its fourth three-man cast, it should be a good bet for Broadway.
Christopher Hampton's English translation, directed by Matthew Warchus, is intelligent, funny and very French, as are the characters: three mid-30's Parisian fellows, fast friends until one of them buys an expensive white-on-white painting. Sometimes a friend goes just too far.
Even Mark Thompson's set has wit: a bachelor's expensively but minimally furnished pad in what could be a high-rent building in Paris's nearly characterless 16th arrondissement. If apartments were people, this one would be a maitre d' with standards far loftier than those of any of his guests.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM/A Catholic Worker House;
Where Nonviolence and Commitment to the Community Rule

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
KEELEY COLVILLE had quite a seventh birthday party at her home in New Haven a few weeks ago, even though her father was in jail in Maine and several other members of her collective household were at an anti-military demonstration in Georgia. That kind of disruption is par for the course when you live in a Catholic Worker house, a place where people believe in doing the works of mercy and justice, as enumerated in the Sermon on the Mount of Jesus.
The love of her mother and siblings and extended family of down-and-out neighbors and fellow justice seekers is also par for the course, and Keeley and her younger sister and brother seem to thrive living in a real village that is raising them and other children. 
 Home is the Cesar Jerez Catholic Worker House in the Hill section of New Haven, founded four years ago by Mark Colville and Luz Catarineau-Colville, Keeley's parents. Members of the Catholic Worker movement subscribe to pacifism and a radical political and economic analysis that leads them to identify with the poor and take personal responsibility both for helping the poor and for changing the social conditions that allow poverty and militarism to exist.
Nov. 8 marked the centennial of the birth of Dorothy Day, co-founder of the Catholic Worker Movement, and, some say, a saint. She died in 1980. Her philosophy of nonviolence and her practice of voluntary poverty have inspired followers who have established 140 Catholic Worker houses around the world; New Haven's is named for a revolutionary Guatemalan priest.
It was in February, on Ash Wednesday, that Mr. Colville and five others, calling themselves the Prince of Peace Plowshares, poured their own blood on and hammered on a nuclear-armed destroyer being built at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Me. Mr. Colville has been in jail ever since, having been convicted last May of destruction of government property and conspiracy; in October he was sentenced to 13 months, including time already served.
The day after his sentencing, the Cesar Jerez House received the fourth annual Morris Wessel Prize, named for a beloved retired pediatrician, to honor "unsung heroes" in the New Haven area who work with families and children. The monetary award is not large, but the honor was welcome. That same week, almost 100 people squeezed into the small house for a prayer service and celebration.
Rosette Street, where the house is situated, has not yet been touched by the nascent revival of inner city New Haven and by the drop in violent crime evidenced in the city and around the nation. There have been several shootings in the immediate neighborhood in the past few years, including one homicide. Despite noticeable progress on demolishing some abandoned properties and planting gardens in their stead, the abandoned buildings on Rosette seem distressingly resistant to change.
But at the Catholic Worker house, there is always something upbeat going on, and usually many more people than just its full-time six or seven residents, some of whom rotate through the house for periods of weeks or months. One recent afternoon after school, four seniors from Fairfield Prep, a Jesuit high school, arrived for their weekly one-on-one tutoring session with neighborhood children. It's how they've chosen to fulfill their two-hour-a-week senior service project, although Marc Robert, one of the volunteers, says he thinks he'd do this work without being required to.
Mr. Robert has an ongoing relationship with Herman Santiago, a fifth grader at nearby Truman School. They work on language skills and math for an hour, then hang out and play together for an hour. Another high school student takes plays educational games with the children on the computer. Both games and computer have been donated, as is virtually everything else in the house, by a large and growing band of supporters.
Carmen Castro, Herman Santiago's mother, lives next door and takes part in activities at the Catholic Worker house, including street Masses. At Give and Take sessions, neighborhood residents are invited to take what they need in terms of food, clothing, furniture and toys, and donate any possessions they no longer use, so that others in need may have them.
"To help the next person is always good," Ms. Castro says.
She says she knows Mark Colville is in jail, but is not sure why. Of one thing she is certain: "I know he is a terrific person."
Mr. Colville has been busy from his jail cell, running prayer groups and writing letters and articles for his Catholic Worker newsletter and for Catholic newspapers around the country.
In one letter, he wrote, "Christianity is supposed to be centered around the Cross. It is supposed to be about suffering. Not suffering for suffering's sake, but redemptive suffering, acting for justice, embracing the consequences, healing the world by afflicting ourselves in solidarity with the afflicted. A Plowshares action strikes me as a particularly good way for a family, especially an educated white family living in the modern Empire, to take up the Cross. It solidarizes us with so many, many families in this world who are separated by war, hunger, economic crisis, unemployment -- all of which are the direct result of policies of the U.S. Government, especially the arms race."
The other members of the house say they feared people would not understand Mr. Colville's action, particularly his decision to voluntarily separate himself from his wife and three young children. But they say the response, both among the peace community and among their poor, mostly black and Latino neighbors, has been very positive. Winning the Morris Wessel Award was another, more tangible, measure of support.
Meanwhile, life goes on at the Catholic Worker house. Jimmy Byun, a recent Yale graduate, moved in for the summer and helped organize a gardening project for the homeless in collaboration with the Columbus House shelter in the Hill. He says he first became aware of the Catholic Worker movement when he picked up the group's national newspaper in a New Haven church. What caught his eye was the price: a penny. He started going to gatherings in New York City, and it was there he found out there was a house much closer to home.
The gardening project is based on the idea that homeless people have, or can learn, a lot of skills to make them self-sufficient. They grew and sold food and flowers from the 1,200-square-foot plot. Plans are to double the size of the garden next year, and to start growing in early spring instead of early summer as they did this year.
Mr. Byun said his family converted to Catholicism when he was 13. "I took it very literally," he said, "and when I saw what the Catholic Worker was doing, I saw that as a return to a more pure form of Christianity before it was co-opted by the state."
He was one of 2,500 people who went to Fort Benning, Ga., in November to call for closing down the School of the Americas, a United States-financed military school that opponents have dubbed "School of Assassins" because graduates have returned to Latin America and committed large-scale human rights abuses. Eight New Haven area people were arrested, including Mr. Byun and David Amaral.
As for Mr. Colville, in a note published before his sentencing, he wrote, "Pray not for a shorter sentence, but for the continuation of dialogue and the clarification of thought."
His sentence will be followed by two years of supervised release, during which time he must report regularly to a parole officer. He is also required to pay restitution for the damage to the ship.
In his sentencing statement, however, he said: "I will pay no restitution; I will report to no one, nor will I allow my conscience to be supervised."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Residents and neighbors gather for a service at the Cesar Jerez Catholic Worker House in the Hill section of New Haven. (Michael J. Doolittle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
American, Asian and a Warm Welcome

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY 

 BODY:
REMEMBER Duffy's Tavern on the radio? The Merry Pedlar in Floral Park is the same kind of homey, neighborhood spot. Instead of a bartender telling all comers, "Duffy ain't here," there was a beaming priest sitting at a table near the entrance who volunteered, "This is a wonderful restaurant with great food." Who could argue with a heavenly endorsement like that?
On a second visit, we were welcomed with a round of applause. No, it was not the priest and his parishioners. Rather, two multitalented musicians had just finished playing. 
 Even though the hand was not for us, the greeting by the smiling hostess was a warm one. At the Merry Pedlar everyone feels at home. Family groups in jeans and baseball caps are as comfortable as the couples dressed for an evening out who occasionally get up and dance to a song or two. Valet parking, live music, an inviting antipasto table and a waiter sporting a tuxedo are weekend additions that do not alter the casual spirit of this hospitable restaurant.
The pleasing decor combines a garden motif with antique touches: plants, bentwood and wicker chairs with floral cushions, striking etched-glass windows, botanical prints, an old wood bar, period light fixtures and dark wood wainscotting.
Service is a bit wobbly. One evening our very sweet waitress was knowledgeable and seemed competent, but the meal took forever. The problem may have been in the kitchen. We were ordering a la carte selections while most diners were trying the very economical (and possibly faster) three-course dinner at $19.97. On another evening, service was more speedy, but it always took at least two requests to get a beverage refilled.
Longtime residents of Floral Park may remember a restaurant at this location called the Merry Pedlar a decade or two ago. The original owner is back, the name is the same but the food is a new story. The chef is Bill McCann, who is French trained, was sous chef at the Rainbow Room and most recently cooked at 13 Barrow Street and the Screening Room in Manhattan.
The food is 1990's American with a few pastas and a smattering of Asian offerings (a trio of stir frys and an orange lacquer duck).
Among the standout starters are a wild mushroom salad ( a toss of greens, a ragout of mushrooms and a warm thyme vinaigrette) and a plate of seafood-vegetable fritters. The crisp, greaseless morsels, combining corn, peppers, salmon and shrimp, surround a chunky tomato-pineapple relish.
In that same major league was the soup of the day, a pureed vegetable brew that was full of flavor. Another treat was the help-yourself antipasto table ($6.95) that sparkled with roasted peppers, grilled vegetables, olives, cheese, meats, asparagus, a bowl of mesclun and dressings.
Also earning kudos were the rich onion soup, the goat cheese-topped caponata, the mixed green (mostly romaine) salad in a pleasing lemon vinaigrette and the rustic salad chock full of blue cheese, apples, croutons and nuts. The less than classic Caesar, though, had a bland, creamy dressing.
Among the entree choices on the $19.97 dinner is a superb penne with a meat sauce made with chunks of fork-tender sirloin, red wine and vegetables. Another good pick on that menu is the chicken stir fry, overflowing with crisp vegetables and Asian flavors.
Speaking of the East, the orange lacquer duck is a beauty: a roasted leg with crisp skin, rare slices of tender grilled breast and a seductive pecan-currant rice. In sharp contrast, though, was a lackluster breast of chicken in a very faint Dijon mustard sauce.
The only fish we sampled, Southwestern grilled tuna, was overcooked. Still, its salsa topper and bed of warm greens nearly saved it.
Meats fared better. The T-bone veal chop, escorted by artichoke hearts, tomatoes and a marsala sauce, was a hit, as were a special steak in a mushroom-wine sauce and the menu's baron of lamb. The last included juicy chops and a slow roasted meld of shredded leg of lamb.
Desserts are great. When did you last see a do-it-yourself hot fudge sundae on a restaurant menu? It was a bell ringer but so, too, were the satiny creme brulee, the flaky warm apple tart, the impressive peanut butter brownie torte garnished with peanut brittle, the three-layer chocolate mousse cake and the rich hazelnut cappuccino sundae.
The six wines on the restaurant's temporary list offer solid dependable choices at prices of $16 to $28. Two French 1995 selections, a rich, ripe Louis Jadot Beaujolais Villages ($23) and a crisp, dry Joseph Drouhin Macon Villages ($23), are recommended.
 
The Merry Pedlar
339 Jericho Turnpike, Floral Park.

HEADLINE: Riverhead Plans to Take Over Navy Site in Calverton

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
COMMERCIAL and industrial real-estate brokers who toured the former Grumman plant in Calverton last week were surprised to find a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in their midst.
The agent was on hand to steer visitors away from the industrial heart of the 2,900-acre site that the Navy owns, the cavernous main hangar where a reconstructed section of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 is protected behind a thick security cordon. 
 Ever since the disaster in which 230 people died on July 17, 1996, the plant where Grumman built F-14's and other Navy jets has been headquarters for the most expensive and extensive Government investigation ever into the crash of a commercial airliner. Its centerpiece is the fuselage of the Boeing 747 jumbo jet, painstakingly assembled by investigators and technicians over two months from 876 pieces that divers and salvage vessels recovered from the ocean floor off East Moriches.
Victims' family members and the few outsiders allowed to view the reconstruction described it as awe inspiring, horrifying and altogether overwhelming.
"When I walked through the door, all I could think was, oh, the humanity," said John J. Seaman of the Families of T.W.A. Flight 800 Association, recalling the words of a reporter who saw the burning of the Hindenburg in Lakehurst, N.J., in 1937.
Now, after delays caused in part by the crash investigation, the Navy is preparing to sign over the 2,900-acre property to the Town of Riverhead Community Development Agency for a development that would mix commercial, industrial and tourist-related recreational uses. Such a complex would have broad economic implications for eastern Long Island. Town officials said the transfer could be carried out in February.
As the transfer nears, questions are arising about what to do with the reconstruction of the jetliner, a high-technology artifact that produced volumes of information with major implications for air travel.
The National Transportation Safety Board, owner of the wreckage and reconstruction, said its inquiry would continue in the hangar through next year and possibly longer. Civil litigation over the crash, which investigators have said was caused by an explosion in the center fuel tank, may require that the reconstruction remain intact for years as cases move through the courts. Some legal experts estimated that the litigation could run up to 10 years.
Jesse R. Goodale 3d, chairman of the Riverhead Development Corporation, created by the town to oversee the development of the site, said the town was close to agreeing to lease the space that the safety board was using back to the Federal Government after the transfer. "They are prepared to compensate the town," Mr. Goodale said.
Mr. Goodale and the director of the town's community development agency, Andrea H. Lohneiss, said they did not expect the presence of the reconstruction would slow development elsewhere at the site. "We don't see that as an impediment," Ms. Lohneiss said.
Mr. Goodale said rent that the Government would pay would partly cover the town's estimated $3 million-a-year maintenance costs. That figure does not include the highest level of upkeep for the 7,000-foot and 10,000-foot jet runways.
Mr. Goodale said the development corporation had not taken an official position on what should be done with the reconstruction after the investigations and litigation had been complete.
But eventually decisions will have to be made. A spokeswoman for the safety board, Shelly Hazle, said the board was "trying to determine the best solution." She noted that the reconstruction, on a frame with wheels, was designed to be dismantled in large sections.
Last week Suffolk County Planning Director Stephen M. Jones suggested that the reconstruction could be an exhibition at an air museum at the Calverton site. "If it was done tastefully and properly, it could be very favorable," Mr. Jones said. "It could be an educational tool that would attract people to the site. They should certainly consider that before they take it apart."
Some people recoiled at that suggestion. "It seems a little morbid to me to be exploiting something so many people were killed in," the curator of the Cradle of Aviation Museum in Garden City, Joshua Stoff, said. "It's not the impression a commercial aviation museum wants to make. We don't want to be showing wreckage."
"It might be insensitive," said Jack O'Connor, president of Grubb & Ellis Island Realty of Melville, the agent for the 2,900-acre property, who added that interest was high among developers with other plans. "I'm not sure I would want that if I was one of the family members."
But Mr. Seaman, whose niece died in the crash, said: "We have been talking about this quite a bit. There are mixed feelings right now. But the families are talking about a permanent monument or memorial. I am not sure whether people would be comfortable with the aircraft itself being the permanent monument to the ones we lost."
But Mr. Seaman, who formerly lived in Huntington and who now lives near Albany, said the families had formed close bonds with rescuers and investigators, including divers who brought up wreckage and technicians who examined each piece in their search for the cause of the crash. The reconstruction, Mr. Seaman said, was a monument to their work.
"Families' members looking at it will always remember those who died," he said. "But for other people it may be more positive. It is very impressive. It's an enormous achievement. And from what we are hearing, the crash of T.W.A. 800 is going to become a turning point in commercial aviation in this country."
The salvage operation reportedly recovered 95 percent of the 400,000-pound plane from three underwater fields of debris. Some pieces were as small as a quarter.
At the former hangar, officials began around-the-clock operations as the F.B.I. looked for evidence of bombs, a missile or sabotage. That meant that the hangar became a high-security zone for the criminal investigation.
"You had to give your life story to get in the gate," said Mr. Jones, referring to the fact that the Government closed the entire site to the public.
Investigators from the safety board noted the location of each piece and its damage as truckloads of wreckage arrived at Calverton. Parts and pieces not used in the reconstruction were placed on a specially marked floor.
As work advanced a 60,000-pound section took shape. Holes marked where damage was so extensive that recovered pieces were crumpled, deformed or all but obliterated.
Seats, galleys and lavatories were reconstructed. The four engines, all recovered, were disassembled and examined.
At a hearing last week by the safety board in Baltimore results of the investigation poured out. Included were volumes of information learned at Calverton. Virtually no detail of the jet's interstices, from wires to metal skin to seat fabric, escaped examination.
"Every piece was thoroughly examined for evidence of an explosive device," the board's investigator in charge, Alfred W. Dickenson, said in his opening statement. "None was found."
Last week, in an incident indicative of a controversy over the cause of the crash, a senior T.W.A. pilot involved in the investigation admitted he stole fabric from the wreckage for a writer who wrote that a missile struck the jet. The pilot, Terrell Stacey, was cooperating with an F.B.I. investigation of the writer, James Sanders, and his wife, Elizabeth Sanders, a T.W.A. flight attendant.
The F.B.I. decided this month to close its criminal investigation, and the Calverton site has begun to reopen.
"We had some tremendous impediments, but the problems seem to be coming to an end," said Mr. O'Connor, adding that the F.B.I. had cooperated in providing escorts for tours.
Mr. O'Connor and Mr. Goodale confirmed that negotiations were under way with a prospective tenant about leasing the entire 2,900 acres for mixed uses. Mr. O'Connor said the tenant would have an option to buy the property.
"First and foremost," Mr. Goodale said, "the preference for the town is for a management agreement with a master tenant that would lease the entire site. The town really has no interest in running the place in the long term. The market will dictate what happens. Our planning will accommodate broad uses."
The town plan envisions an industrial park in former production areas on 800 acres of the property, according to Ms. Lohneiss. It envisions commercial and recreational developments on open land. Office buildings, golf courses, an automobile-racing track, a sports arena and a theme park are also possibilities.
County officials concur in the town plan. "Redevelopment is a tremendous opportunity for the Town of Riverhead, the entire East End and the county," said George Gatta, deputy county executive for economic development.
The land includes 400 acres in the core area of the Pine Barrens Preserve, which would be left untouched.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. Seamus O'Cleireacain;
Professor's Spin on Global Trade Policies

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS a professor of economics at Purchase College, Dr. Seamus O'Cleireacain hears not only from American students but also ones from Korea, Russia, Austria, Poland and Japan. As a specialist on international economic policy, he is in a position to influence the distribution of foreign-aid money.
Dr. O'Cleireacain (pronounced oh-CLARE-a-con) has been a consultant to the United Nations and Congress. In 1996 and '97, he was a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington, where he set up a global network of economic reformers who had been economics or finance ministers in developing countries of the former Soviet Bloc. 
 Last year, he served on the Council of Strategic and International Studies Bipartisan Task Force on the United States and the multilateral development banks.
The author of many publications, the Irish-born Dr. O'Cleireacain, a Manhattan resident, is also an adjunct professor at Columbia University. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. Why should a person who is not directly involved in financial matters pay attention to stories like those about the World Bank?
A. Because it's through the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and through regional development banks that we have some rules of the game, that we have an international economic government. Those organizations deal with international finance and development. On the trade side, we've got the World Trade Organization to set the rules.
Without having these organizations, we would be a much poorer planet. We would have a much lower level of economic growth for most of the countries of the world.
For the really poorer countries, the World Bank is the only place they can go to borrow. They are not good commercial creditors. Commercial banks do not want them. Somebody needs to insure that there is a flow of financial resources into those countries. It gives them a chance.
Q. Is it partly a moral obligation?
A. I didn't call it a moral obligation. I won't call it that. I think that these days a phrase like "global interdependence" is a trite phrase, but it really does have meaning. We're a much smaller planet. We're much more closely connected than we had been in the past, and we have an interest in what happens in these countries. Diseases spread. Ideas that are not conducive to freedom of expression, freedom of religious rights, spread very quickly. A small group can have a rather horrendous impact on the larger society. And we have an interest in stability and prosperity everywhere.
Q. How do you feel about the United States' trying to use economic policies as a tool to make political change, say in Iraq?
A. I think that in the case of Iraq that without sanctions Saddam Hussein would be even more dangerous than he is. Saddam Hussein has the ability to sell oil to get money to pay for food and to pay for medicine. He has had that ability from the very beginning -- from the time the sanctions were imposed. They were imposed by the United Nations in a way in which the weaker members of Iraqi society could be taken care of. For years, he didn't take that option. I don't follow it totally, but I have a sense that in the last year or two, he finally has.
So I have no problem at all with really strong sanctions against Iraq. I have a different perspective on sanctions elsewhere, because too often people impose sanctions or ask for sanctions to be imposed just to make themselves feel better, to make themselves feel morally superior. There may be a moral argument for sanctions, but they may not work.
Q. Are you thinking of Cuba?
A. Sanctions on Cuba are a mistake. They've been a mistake for years. They've had no impact on the Cuban economy, but they're politically great for Fidel Castro and his Government to argue that the reason that the country has been in such trouble, has fallen so far behind the level of development elsewhere in Latin and Central America, is because of the nasty U.S. The reality is every other country in the world will trade with Cuba, so the sanctions economically are relatively meaningless. Cuba's economic problems are the result of very bad economic policies inside the country. But everyone understands the sanctions were imposed for political reasons.
Q. Did you support our changed economic policies toward Vietnam?
A. Oh, sure. I think the worldwide move toward market-oriented economy and democratically oriented political systems is terrific. It is to be applauded, supported and promoted. It doesn't happen in some countries without providing moral support, political support and economic support to those forces in the countries that want those kinds of changes.
Q. What about China? Is it moral to make China a most-favored-nation trade partner?
A. China is not yet a member of the World Trade Organization. It's the last major international organization that it has been kept out of. It has been kept out of it for very good reasons. The W.T.O. is an organization for countries that have market-oriented economies. People know in advance how their products are going to be treated, and they know what the trade barriers are. For the last number of years, China has been negotiating with members of the W.T.O. on what it has to do in order to be allowed in. It's very close to it. There has been a lot of technical assistance from the U.S. trade representative's office to China and by the European Union on how it needs to reorganize its economy. At some point that will be settled.
Once China gets into the W.T.O., it will automatically have most-favored-nation treatment in all the products it sells to any of the W.T.O. members. Most-favored nation is a phrase that gives the impression of something terrific. In reality, it is almost the worst treatment that anyone gives W.T.O. members because everyone wants some type of preferential treatment beyond that.
Q. What about the moral issues of dealing with China, a politically repressive country?
A. China is too big to ignore. It's part of the international community, and if it's part of the international community the rest of us are better off having it inside the organization. It does not mean we need to like its domestic policies. It does not mean we should not support people who want to change it.
Q. There have been many currency devaluations in Asia. How will this affect people in Westchester?
A. It will probably mean cheaper computers. Most of the components of PC's are coming from a number of countries that have been devalued. The impact on the American economy should be pretty small because the bulk of U.S. exports don't go to that part of the world. The U.S. will be less impacted than a country like Japan. This is a part of the world where the banking systems are really fragile and the problems have not been solved. The financial effects of what is going on there can be dramatically larger in the United States than the trade effects.
Q. What was the Council for Strategic and International studies that you served on?
A. I was on a task force looking at the appropriate roles for the U.S. in multilateral development banks, the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, and there are a series of regional development banks. The task force had politicians from the Hill and a fair number of business executives and a handful of academics. We were trying to influence what Congress would decide to do about funding U.S. foreign aid bills that include contributions to those organizations and what should be the conditions attached to it.
Q. And what conditions do you think should be imposed?
A. I think it needs to be tied to whatever the U.S. decides are its foreign policy objectives. The U.S. is just one of many contributors to those organizations, but it should only be contributing to them if it thinks those organizations are furthering the broad scope of U.S. foreign policy. But at the end of the day, these are sovereign countries that have to decide for themselves what their appropriate path is.

HEADLINE: Stores Wait For That Last-Minute Rush to Buy

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AT the Williams-Sonoma store in White Plains recently, free samples of gourmet herb and Parmesan pasta disappeared by midafternoon -- scooped up by eager Christmas shoppers with hearty appetites. Most of the pricey merchandise for sale, however, remained on the shelves, as it did in other stores at The Westchester mall.
In another, less-expensive section of the city, a similar scenario played out at the Sam Ash Music Stores location on Mamaroneck Avenue, the main street of White Plains: hype about the shopping season but not as much action at the cash register. The Sam Ash manager, Tony Faranda, worried that a sale earlier in November had taken some of the starch out of his holiday effort. 
 Although better days may be in store, the retail trade mostly languished in many sections of Westchester during the first weeks of the holiday period. On Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving when many merchants hope to turn their ledgers from red to black, business was "O.K., but not great," Mr. Faranda said.
In the downtown shopping areas of small hamlets and villages like Hastings-on-Hudson, some shopkeepers reported that the quiet was deafening. And along main streets in cities like White Plains, foot traffic was light. Even at busy malls like The Westchester, where parking spaces were in short supply, retailers fretted as many in the crowd, like those at Williams-Sonoma, only sampled the offerings.
Why more talk than action so far this year? Shoppers who were interviewed said they were merely on initial surveillance missions and not ready to make their purchases.
"First, we're having a look around," said Stephen Morrissey, a New York City police officer who was reconnoitering in toy stores on Black Friday with his wife, Martina, and their 6-month-old daughter, Stephanie. "We're raring to spend, but right now we're just checking things out." Most malls began decorating for the holidays on Nov. 8 in an attempt to lure customers early, but the first weekend after Thanksgiving now accounts for only 10 percent of Christmas sales, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan.
"Thanksgiving weekend is a good indicator, but it plays a less important role than it did years ago," said John Konarski, president of the trade association, which measures traffic in 35 malls around the country.
The day with the highest mall traffic is actually the Saturday before Dec. 25 -- this year that will be Dec. 20 -- the association said. And the week to watch is the one beginning on Wednesday and running through Christmas Eve.
Also, because there are five fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas this year, the sluggish start is most likely to be replaced with a flurry of shopping activity when it dawns on consumers that time is running short, said Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce.
Early in the season, most shoppers said they were reaching into their pockets only when a bargain beckoned, and few tarried at racks where merchandise was not marked down.
"I'm taking my time and waiting for the sales," said Annabel Ramos, an accountant who was shopping recently at Bloomingdale's in White Plains. "No rush yet."
At the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, Ruthe Berman, executive director of marketing, said that two department stores known for their bargains and heavy promotions -- Sears and Stern's -- were thriving. "Absolutely, people are buying," she said, "but only under certain circumstances."
Not only in Westchester, but in many locations throughout the New York City area, the Christmas shopping season started unhurriedly, reported Kurt Barnard, editor of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, an industry newsletter. He said that even though parking lots were packed 10 deep in some places, merchandise was not moving well, as witnessed by the dearth of bulging shopping bags.
Throughout the United States, too, reports indicated that the season had not begun with a bang despite the robust nature of the economy. On the first holiday shopping weekend after Thanksgiving, sales nationally were up only 1 percent over the same weekend last year, according to Telecheck Services in Houston, the world's leading check acceptance company, which measures check writing in more than 27,000 locations each year.
As recently as Tuesday Telecheck reported that consumers continued to be cautious in their holiday spending. New York and the rest of the Northeast, however, showed slightly more activity than the rest of the United States.
Checks are not a preferred payment method for most shoppers, although Telecheck's numbers tend to be consistent with industry trends.
There is hope ahead. Telecheck and other companies predicted that the shopping activity yet to come would make up for the sluggish beginning. Many shoppers confirmed that forecast, saying they entered the season feeling financially secure and would buy, but not wildly.
"Judging by most indicators, this will be a good year for spending," said Karl Lamson, an accountant who was at The Westchester last week with his son Andrew, 8. "The stock market is good, unemployment and inflation are low, and Congress is working on the budget deficit. So what could be bad?"
Or as John Clark, a carpenter who was checking the merchandise in F.A.O. Schwarz in White Plains with his wife, Lisa, and their 2 1/2-year-old twins, Kevin and Sean, explained it, "The economy is optimistic and so are we."
In assessing the shopping picture this year, economists suggested that because the recession is long past, consumers may be running out of new things to buy. They reported, too, that some buyers have overextended themselves on their credit cards and are pulling back.
Ms. Berman at the Cross County Mall observed that the stores have created demon shoppers who expect deep discounts and will not settle for less. "Why would you buy something for $50 when you know that if you wait, you'll be able to get it for $30?" she said.
Telephones and computers are also becoming significant competitors in the Christmas shopping marketplace and siphoning off store customers. Catalogue sales are expected to grow at a faster rate than store sales, and Internet sales could double what they did last year, widespread reports said.
The contributing factors notwithstanding, it is becoming increasingly difficult to forecast how any retail season will evolve. Last year, the shopping season began optimistically and ended with little more than a whimper. In other years, the first shopping weekend of Christmas was described as lackadaisical, but the season ended strongly overall.
And while the first weeks may no longer be the key shopping period, trends emerge during that time and provide a glimpse ahead for retailers. The Council of Shopping Centers predicted that jewelry would account for most of the Christmas sales at malls -- 24 percent -- with home entertainment and electronics following a close second.
But for those who would rather place bets based on what shoppers on the street are forecasting, then Ruth Treglia, a physical therapist from Scarsdale, might be the one to consult. Shopping with her daughter, Dana, at Bloomingdale's on the Sunday after Thanksgiving, Ms. Treglia predicted that 1997 would be remembered as a year when practicality reigned. "It's all getting too gluttonous," she said. "Just give me a pair of running shoes, and I'll be happy." She said that she was buying bedding and other practical gifts for people, not frivolous items.
Sonja Bernstein from Scarsdale, who sells high-end jewelry, observed that even in that category, shoppers were being practical. "No one's going on a spree," she said. "They're buying watches, not expensive baubles."
And Gil Schwartz of New Rochelle, a public relations specialist who was at Sam Ash's buying his son a cymbal for Hanukkah, said: "I'm definitely not going wild. This year, it's a sense of careful optimism."
While the not-going-wild syndrome is holding for most categories, the toy and book businesses have bucked all trends. Favorite items did, in fact, sell out over Thanksgiving weekend, and others are in short supply.
If a Sing and Snore Ernie is on the list, the giver should think again, because the doll whose tummy moves while it "sleeps" sold out not only in Westchester but also across the United States, stores reported. A substitute is Interactive Barney, who was in F.A.O. Schwarz just days ago. Acti Mates, the manufacturer, is calling the purple dinosaur "your child's best friend."
Books, too, "are flying off the shelves," said Kristy Janiszewski, manager of Waldenbooks at the Galleria mall in White Plains. The three hottest books this year at Waldenbooks are "Angela's Ashes" by Frank McCourt (Scribner), "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil" by John Berendt (Random House) and "All Over but the Shoutin' " by Rick Bragg (Pantheon).

Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. 1); At The Westchester mall in White Plains recently, browsing seemed to supersede shopping. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. 6)
