HEADLINE: Hearings Begin on Carting Industry

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IT has been called the mob tax -- the added amounts that governments, businesses and individuals have to pay for garbage collection because of organized crime's influence in the carting industry.
In the aftermath of Federal indictments and guilty pleas from five people and 13 garbage-hauling companies, including some that do business in Westchester, a committee of the County Board of Legislators has begun hearings aimed at seeing what can be done to increase competition and decrease disposal costs. 
 "So far, we have heard confirmed what everyone knows -- there is a problem in Westchester County," said Thomas J. Abinanti, a Greenburgh Democrat and chairman of the Board's Committee on Legislation. "Organized crime controls the carting industry and that control impacts everyone who works or lives in Westchester."
The purpose of the legislative hearing is to establish a record of corruption by the carting industry, which can be used to justify the Board of Legislators's using its police power to regulate the industry. The Board has also set up a Mob Tax Hot Line for tips about potential illegal activity of carters. The number is 285-2144.
At its initial hearings earlier this month, the committee heard from Edward Ferguson, executive director of the New York City Trade Waste Commission, and Chad Vignola, the Deputy Commissioner, both of whom urged Westchester to follow New York City's lead in regulating the industry. "For too long," Mr. Ferguson said, "New York City and Westchester County have shared a common affliction: a basic, necessary service in an advanced society -- the collection and disposal of the waste it generates -- has been controlled by organized crime. For decades, a criminal cartel of carting companies, operating under the auspices of La Cosa Nostra, kept competition out of the industry with a wide range of anti-competitive practices, including customer allocation, price fixing and bid rigging."
Mr. Ferguson testified that things changed in New York City only after the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Police Department began a five-year undercover investigation of the carting industry, which led in 1995 to the indictment of many carters on corruption charges. A year later, at the instigation of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council passed a law that created the Trade Waste Commission and gave it extensive authority to regulate the carting industry.
As a result of this regulation, Mr. Vignola said, New York City residents and businesses have saved $335 million in garbage collecting fees because of increased competition. The Acting County Attorney, Gregory F. Meehan, said that until recently, Westchester had little basis for trying similar regulation. But now, he said, Westchester can make a case for regulation because of the guilty pleas on Sept. 30 of several carting companies and people who do business in Westchester, including Suburban Carting Corporation, Thomas Milo, its president, and a subsidiary, Trottown Transfer Inc., both of which have contracts with the county. The individuals and the companies are awaiting sentencing.
Exercising police powers to regulate the carting industry requires a legislative finding that there is a real problem and that a proposed remedy has a reasonable chance of working, Mr. Meehan said.
The alleged problem that the panel seeks to document involved what is called a "property rights systems established and perpetuated by organized crime for the purpose of eliminating competition in the marketplace," said Mary Anne Harkins, a lawyer who has been retained to help with the Board's investigation and development of regulations.
As charged in Federal indictments from the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Mary Jo White, under this system a particular carter -- "affiliated with certain organized criminal groups" -- asserted a permanent property right to every location where it picked up garbage. Competitors that failed to accept those rights were subject to physical and economic reprisals, Ms. Harkins said, describing the indictments.
"It is important," she added, "to point out that the property right system described in the Federal indictment affects every level of carting-services consumer in this county, from individual commercial customers, like restaurants, delis and liquor stores, to cities, towns and villages, which hire carting companies to transport garbage to transfer stations, to the Westchester County government itself, which uses garbage haulers to take garbage from transfer stations" to its garbage incinerator in Peekskill.
The Legislation Committee will resume hearings early next year, Mr. Abinanti said. Whatever solution the Board comes up with would fit the county's problems, he said. "We don't have the resources of New York City," he said. "But clearly we need some type of supervising authority that would enhance the power of the Commissioner of our Department of Environmental Facilities."
In his remarks to the committee, Mr. Ferguson of the Trade Waste Commission said: "The precise form that regulatory reform should take will, of course, depend on the practical range of available alternatives. That said, however, it must be stressed that whatever regulatory framework is erected must be strong enough to be a credible deterrent to corruption. The success of the carting-industry reform effort in New York City is largely attributable to the broad authority conferred by Local Law 42 on the Trade Waste Commission to clean house in the industry and open up the market to vigorous competition."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
2d Anchor Begun in Trenton's Revitalization Plan

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
ON Dec. 2 ground was broken for an 10,600-seat arena on 18 acres now occupied by industrial buildings in the landmark 45-acre former Roebling complex in Trenton. The ceremony conjured up images of the city's past and its hoped-for future.
The $45-million arena, which is scheduled to open in October 1999, will provide the second anchor in a plan by city and Mercer County officials to create what they describe as a triangle of economic development to help revitalize Trenton. 
 At its heart the plan, which borrows a page from the Baltimore Inner Harbor development, aims to blend sports, entertainment and cultural development with commerce to bolster the economy in a city that has watched its industrial base vanish over the last few decades. That in turn, the officials say, will help establish the state capital as a tourist destination -- not only a government center that shuts down by 6 P.M. when state workers leave.
The three anchors of the redevelopment area -- either completed, under way or planned -- are half a mile from one another. Many of the projects in the area are public-private partnerships.
The first anchor is a 6,150-seat minor-league baseball stadium that opened in 1994; the second is the arena and the third is the 200-room hotel-conference center planned for the downtown, which includes the state capitol and its environs. Around the anchors a mix of housing, office and retail space as well as additional recreational amenities will rise, spurring other development, county and city officials say.
By linking these areas and projects together Trenton "is building a new industry" that will help change that part of the city and filter into the neighborhoods, said Mercer County Executive Robert D. Prunetti.
"If the city does better, so do the suburban communities in the county," he added.
"For Trenton to advance we had to find a niche in modern economic times," said Alan Mallach, director of the city's department of housing and economic development, "and the leisure-spending industry is probably among the fastest growing and an area in which older cities like this can be competitive."
Both officials said the baseball stadium, which is called Waterfront Park, proved that people with money to spend would come to Trenton and that others would invest there. They said it also helped to change the perception of the city.
While many observers initially viewed the stadium as a pipedream, they now consider it a success. Attendance at the ballpark, home to the Trenton Thunder, an affiliate of the Detroit Tigers, has been about 500,000 a year. The riverfront site includes a walkway, a picnic area and a restored old fishing wharf. A private investor also converted a vacant factory into a restaurant/nightclub called Katmandu. And now the county is advancing plans to reshape a two-mile riverfront stretch, most of it south of the stadium, for recreation and commercial uses.
One developer who sees the potential of the waterfront is Peter J. Cocoziello, president of the Advance Group of Bedminster. His company recently bought a four-building, 240,000-square-foot office complex on 20 riverfront acres next to the stadium. Future plans for the 12 undeveloped acres include retail stores and office space, he said.
The market for the stadium, considered a regional attraction, is the 2.5 million people who live within a 30-mile radius of the site, as well as state workers. That is the same market officials hope to tap for the arena.
The arena, a combination of renovated existing buildings and new construction, will begin to take shape this spring at South Broad Street, Hamilton Avenue and Route 129 amid a collection of gritty industrial buildings. The old factories, which shut down in the 70's and 80's, were built for the John A. Roebling Sons and American Steel and Wire companies, manufacturers of cables for bridges, elevators and trolleys.
The arena fits within the redevelopment plan drawn up in 1985 by the nonprofit Trenton Roebling Community Development Corporation to reshape the entire site into a mix of uses. It is expected to accommodate at least 160 events a year, key among them minor-league hockey and basketball games. But concerts, collegiate games, trade shows and family entertainment events will also be held there.
L IKE the baseball stadium the arena is being publicly financed. The Berman Development Company L.L.C., which is based in Trenton, owns the land. It will develop the arena and then sell it to the county, which will own and manage it.
Mr. Prunetti, the County Executive, said the county had received $12 million in state loans and would sell $32.5 million in bonds to finance the arena and parking. The city, for its part, will invest $2 million to $5 million to create additional parking for the project, said Mr. Mallach. The arena is to become the home of a minor-league hockey team owned by Ronald J. Berman, chief executive of the company building the arena with a partner, Stephen Cowen, a Tenafly real estate investor. The as yet unnamed expansion team will be part of the East Coast Hockey League, which has its headquarters in Princeton. The Continental Basketball Association, in St. Louis, also announced plans to bring a team to the arena.
Mr. Berman said that the prospects for a recreational use such as the arena were enhanced by the existing baseball stadium. "With urban development, single projects don't work," he said.
The arena joins other projects within the Roebling redevelopment area. Mr. Berman's company, for instance, developed the 12-acre Roebling Market, reshaped from three interconnecting former factories. One contains 66,000 square feet of offices for theNew Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency, which purchased the converted building. The others were converted to 25,000 square feet of light industrial space and a 110,000-square-foot retail center, which opened last year. The retail center is 91 percent leased, said Mr. Berman, with Edwards Supermarket taking 54,000 square feet.
A 75-unit rental housing project for elderly residents with low and moderate incomes opened this month. The project, which Mr. Mallach said is in an industrial building purchased by the city, was adapted into housing by a joint venture of Pellettieri Home for the Aged Inc., a nonprofit sponsor of housing for the elderly, and Pennrose Properties in Philadelphia. Mr. Mallach said work had also started on the renovation of the former 57,000-square-foot Roebling machine shop into a museum-science center called the Invention Factory Science Center.
Because only $3 million is available so far, he said, renovation will be limited to the basic rehabilitation of the property and to create a visitors' center. He estimated that the overall cost would be at least $20 million. Completion will depend on when additional funds are secured.
Other projects are planned. Mr. Mallach said the city was in the process of acquiring another old factory to convert, beginning next year, into 150 market-rate rental apartments. Another building is to become a children's learning center. And the Y.M.C.A of Trenton is putting together financing to renovate one of the structures into a fitness center, he added.
A T the same time, plans are advancing to turn a downtown 3.5-acre site into a seven-story hotel and conference center, returning hotel rooms to the city after a 20-year absence. The hotel will be linked to the Trenton War Memorial, a state-owned historic landmark now undergoing a $30 million renovation. It is now used for such events as concerts and other entertainments, as well as community events.
The $44-million hotel project is to rise on a site at the foot of South Warren Street, which is owned by the city and the Trenton Parking Authority and is now a surface parking lot. The hotel will be financed with public and private funds. A total of $20 million in public funds is already in place.
Acquest Realty Advisors, based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is the developer and Marriott Conference Centers, part of the Marriott hotel chain, will operate the new hotel-conference center as well as the War Memorial.
"What we look for is if there is enough public commitment to the project," said David G. Ong, president of Acquest, which often works with Marriott on such projects. "We saw that commitment in Trenton. We've also done our own homework and concluded that the market is there for such a project."
Mr. Ong said most of the $24 million in private financing needed for the project had been raised. He said he expected construction to start early in the second quarter of 1998 with completion to follow 15 to 18 months later.
Mr. Mallach said the combination of redevelopment initiatives pooled together under the plan was not a panacea. "But it is an opportunity to create a significant economic engine for the city," he added. "We better not blow it."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Stores, Landlords Seek Profits Above and Below

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WHEN the owners of the Tourneau company decided to establish a flagship store in Manhattan, they realized they would not be likely to find all the space they needed on one floor in a prime location. So they decided to look up and down as well as around.
The result is their new store on the southwest corner of 57th Street and Madison Avenue, a four-level extravaganza housing wristwatches with prices ranging from $25 to $250,000. To encourage customers to move between floors, lots of vertical transportation is provided: escalators, an elevator, stairs and even a rock-climbing wall -- which is only used for special events. 
 The 16,000-square-foot store dwarfs the company's other New York outlets, which average 1,500 square feet. The larger size allows a whole new approach to retailing, company officials say.
"We don't have the space to display enough products in our other stores," said Robert Wexler, president of the family-owned firm. "With the new store, we display 40 additional brands and we have space for a service facility, for education and exhibitions."
While retailers are finding new possibilities in vertical expansion, , landlords are realizing there may be better uses for the second and third floors of their commercial buildings than offices. Combining them with the ground-floor space may provide an opportunity to rent to a retailer, who usually pays more for space than an office tenant.
"You need a good location, but, yes, landlords are discovering that they can rent their lower floors to retailers at a premium to office use," said Benjamin Fox a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services. "The psychology has changed."
Retailers who are entering or expanding in the New York market are turning to vertical retailing as a way of presenting a full line of merchandise without being crippled by the high cost of ground-floor space. Shanghai Tang, the colorful new fashion and furnishings emporium at Madison and 61st Street, uses both a lower level and a mezzanine in addition to the ground floor.
The Tuscan Square combined store and restaurant in Rockefeller Center uses two floors to attract shoppers or the hungry from both street level and the center's below-ground concourse. Managers of Rockefeller Center are working on plans to transform much of the other retail space in the complex to multilevel operations, using the concourse and the second floor, which is now occupied by offices.
It is a pattern that is becoming more common. "We are definitely going to see more of it," said Kate Coburn, Cushman & Wakefield's director of retail services, referring to vertical retailing. "Much of the catalyst has come from national retailers coming into Manhattan who need 15,000 to 20,000 square feet of space. They are not going to find many buildings that have 15,000 or 20,000 on one floor. So they have to make accommodations to fit into space that makes the numbers work."
Some of the most important of these numbers are the lower rental rates for below-ground and second-floor space, compared to the ground floor. For example, on Madison Avenue in the 60's, first-floor rents are reaching $400 a square foot, according to Faith H. Consolo, senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates, retail specialists. But the second or lower floor in the same prime location might only command $150 to $175 a square foot.
By blending the higher and lower rates, the retailer ends up with a rental rate that the store can support and still earn a profit.
Nor is it just newcomers who want bigger spaces. Much of the retail industry is looking to expand, according to real estate executives. "Everybody wants to get bigger," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at Insignia/ESG. "The store that had 3,000 square feet at grade now wants 15,000 by adding a mezzanine and a lower level," he said.
"Everybody is following apparel, books and records," observed Ms. Consolo, who said stores like The Gap, Barnes & Noble and Virgin led the way to successful multifloor selling. "Now you have the health and beauty stores following. They want to generate some excitement by giving the customer more items to choose from. These stores are becoming the 90's version of the variety store, a Woolworth's for the millennium."
Bigger stores usually mean more sales, which is good for the retailer. But Mr. Seligman argues that they are also good for consumers, by offering them more choice.
"A lot of off-price, discount and multiproduct retailers simply could not afford to be in New York without multilevel," he said. "And if they can't afford to be here, the customer loses out."
Choice, he said, has become increasingly important to consumers in recent years. "All the rules of retailing changed after the economic crash of 1987," he said. "Prior to that if you were a Neiman-Marcus customer, that's where you went. Now it is all price-value. Today it is not unusual to see someone buy a $40 pair of jeans at The Gap and walk across the street and pay $350 to $400 for a pair of Ferragamo shoes."
It is this willingness of customers to shop at different economic levels that has led to a multiple-level Warner Brothers Studio Store facing Tiffany's across prestigious 57th Street and to Niketown, a multilevel temple of sports, sharing the southern side of the block between Fifth and Madison with Tiffany's and the new Tourneau operation.
And if the bigger stores are, arguably, good news for retailers and customers, they can be terrific news for landlords, who can convert unrentable basement and low-priced second floor offices into retail space. Brokers say that the second floor of most buildings is the least desirable because of the lack of views, but that the per-foot rental rate can be easily doubled if combined with the ground floor into a multilevel store.
Indeed, the owner of an office building on Third Avenue that was purchased last year for $50 million estimates that he added $8 million in economic value by deciding to combine the second floor with the first to attract the so-called "big box" retailers who demand multilevel space to showcase their wares.
As might be expected, operators of vertical stores are resorting to some tricks to get customers moving up and down. For example, at a Gap store on Madison Avenue, the store's most popular product, blue jeans, is on the lower level. To get to them, the customer must walk through the whole street-level portion of the store where other products, such as shirts and sweaters, are displayed in hopes of provoking some impulse buying.
"It's stocked on the supermarket principle," Mr. Seligman observed. "You put the most popular product the farthest away."
ANOTHER approach is convenience. The Riese Organization recently converted a property it controls on Fifth Avenue between 48th and 49th Streets from a quick-service food court (Pizza Hut, Roy Rogers) into a T.G.I. Friday's, a full-service restaurant.
The restaurant has three serving levels, the ground floor and two upper floors. To get people to the upper levels, receptionists tell them how long it will take for a table to open up on the main floor, much of which is taken up by a bar, and advise them they can be seated more quickly if they will climb some stairs.
"People will go upstairs if there is a window; they don't like basements," said Dennis Riese, the chief executive of the company. "It's important to get them up the stairs quickly. The longer they stare at a flight of stairs, the more likely they are to go elsewhere."
Because the franchise is well known around the country, he said, he expects the renovated restaurant, which reopened last month, to draw heavily from tourists visiting adjacent Rockefeller Center. He said a full-service restaurant made more sense than quick-service at that location. "People are tired and cold, their feet hurt," he said. "They want to sit down and be served."
Mr. Riese's aides said that with a multilevel restaurant they could do things that would be difficult on a single floor. "If we don't need all the tables, we can shut down a floor, which has the effect of shrinking the restaurant," said Jamie B. Galler, the executive vice president for operations. "Or we can have private parties upstairs without disturbing the operations down below. Having the floors makes the place more modular than just one level."
Entertainment is becoming a bigger part of retailing, and bigger stores present more opportunities to attract the attention of customers. In fact, the entire Tourneau store has been outfitted to resemble the inner workings of a watch, with a structural column detailed to suggest the pinion that transmits motion between gears.
The windows along the store's 100 feet of frontage on 57th Street are 40 feet high so passers-by can see all the levels except the one below ground. The windows are recessed behind the facade holding the store's sign and the clocks, so that anyone taking a close look at the window is effectively in the store without opening the door. "Someone who is at the window is already within our space," Mr. Wexler said. In keeping with the watch theme, the display cases and counters are all curved. Much of what had been the second floor of the building has been removed and replaced with a mezzanine.
Having the mezzanine promotes an open feeling within the store and also keeps the floor area within city zoning limits, since the mezzanine space is no more than the now-removed second-floor area. "We took out 100 tons of structural steel and building materials to create the open space," said Anthony J. D'Ambrosio, executive vice president of Tourneau.
With ample space available, the display cases are placed well apart. The street level is stocked with what Tourneau executives describe as popular brands, including Breitling, Movado and Tag Heuer. As a visitor goes up, so do the prices, with vintage watches and jewelry on the mezzanine level and luxury brands like Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet and Rolex on the carpeted top floor.
Below ground are more moderately priced brands such as Bulova, Citizen and Seiko, a service area and a gallery tracing the development of timekeeping. A hall for special exhibits is also on this level and will house various contemporary events. "Tag Heuer sponsors a Formula One racing team," Mr. Wexler said, "so we had a race car here for awhile."
THE drive for vertical retailing is changing the appearance of some of the city's best-known properties. The southern half of the retail space of the building at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street, is being completely renovated to house the first store selling products endorsed by the National Basketball Association.
"This was a retail-unfriendly building, with the display glass behind columns," said Glenn Markman, an executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis New York, who represented the N.B.A. Nevertheless, with an assignment to find 35,000 square feet on Fifth Avenue in the heart of the shopping district, he was not about to dismiss any possibility.
"We started to play around with ideas of how to make it friendlier," he said. "As we thought about it, we realized that N.B.A. was about height. And we figured if we removed part of the slab of the second floor, we would have real impact space."
When it opens in September 1998, the store will have a new all-glass facade and will operate on three levels. The ground-floor space will be the smallest, with 8,000 square feet. There will be 10,500 square feet on the second floor and 16,500 square feet on the lower level.
Mr. Markman said it took 18 months to negotiate the deal, which involved moving existing tenants and getting the owner to agree to the renovations.
Nevertheless, Arthur L. Bocchi, a senior managing director of the building's owner, Sumitomo Realty & Development, said he was so pleased with the outcome that he wanted to convert the northern part of the retail space in a similar fashion.
"We had been thinking about what we could do to enhance our retail," he said. "We felt that we didn't really have a presence on Fifth Avenue." He said the retail part of the building was essentially unchanged since it was built in 1958, and had been divided into relatively small blocks and leased to airlines, such as Alitalia, for ticket offices and for bank branches. A B. Dalton bookstore operated on the ground floor and lower level.
Now, with the N.B.A. store under construction, the company is going ahead with a plan to renovate the building's lobby and entrances. And it is looking for a tenant or two for the remaining available space, 9,000 square feet on the first floor and 15,000 square feet on the second.
"We'll lease it to one tenant or split it in two, but no more than that," Mr. Bocchi said.
He said vertical retailing appeared to work when there was one company involved, to establish a presence at the street level. "There is a resistance to going up," he said. "That's why vertical malls, where customers have to ride up in elevators to visit various shops, have not been successful. But it does work if it's one store."
Carl Barbato, the chief operating officer of Shanghai Tang, which has two levels and a mezzanine, said the way to get customers to move vertically was to make the lower space physically inviting and then use a little showmanship to attract their attention.
"You have to have a high enough ceiling and the right lighting and then the right tease to make people want to know what is downstairs," he said. "We have had remarkably little falloff from the main to the lower level."He said the lower floor is stocked with such things as men's and children's clothing and decorative home furnishings, such as picture frames, that represent a growing market. In addition, the rest rooms are on the lower level.
VERTICAL retailing is as much about theater as it is merchandising, said Paul B. Boardman, the retail design partner at HLW, an architectural firm. "Brokers like to talk about the value of blended space, but if you really are to do well you have to design a space that produces a more theatrical type of retailing," he said.
He said the Tourneau store, with its video display screens, exhibits and constant evocations of watches and time in its design appears to have that quality.
Not all the practitioners of this type of retailing are new on the scene, he added.
"Why do people go to Tiffany's and pay $5,000 for a diamond they could get on Jewelers' Row for $2,200?," he asked. "The answer is that they want the entire Tiffany experience."

HEADLINE: Beyond Prayer;
Testing Faith in Their Own Hometowns, Congregations Offer Hands-On Help

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
LAST July, the mens' club of the First United Methodist Church in the impoverished Cumberland County town of Port Norris merged with the mens' club of the John Wesley United Methodist Church a few blocks away. One of the first questions the new group examined was how to create a much-needed recreation center for young people.
By November the congregations had bought avandalized abandoned house on Main Street from a bank for $3,000. They plan to strip the inside after the holidays and start renovations in the spring. 
 "The labor will come from the members of these two churches," said the Rev. Chris Miller, pastor of First United Methodist. Then in a joking manner, he added, "Maybe we can get some of the kids who vandalized it to help us out."
For some, living one's faith may mean going to services for prayer, song and sermons; giving generously when a collection plate is passed or a fund drive is announced, and taking part in other opportunities for fellowship and study at their church or synagogue.
But increasingly, religious leaders say, there is a feeling that prayer and meditation are not enough, that people can deepen their faith by reaching outside themselves and their houses of worship. Rather than just asking God to help solve society's problems -- especially those in their own communities -- they are stepping in to offer hands-on help. And, in the process, their ministers and rabbis say, they often find that they are growing spiritually as well.
Congregations around New Jersey, like the two Methodist churches in Port Norris, are tackling the needs of their towns and their neighbors not only by doing manual labor or committing large of amounts of time to counseling or caring for the troubled or destitute but also by bringing their moral weight to bear on national and international issues.
With the welfare system being retooled to drive hundreds of thousands from the rolls, with an increase in the number of working poor and the infirm elderly, congregations are reaching out in the traditional ways, of course: collecting food for the hungry at Thanksgiving, buying gifts for poor families at Christmas and Hannukah, and visiting hospitals and nursing homes.
But they are also doing so in unusual ways, like trying to set up day care services for the children of working parents, encouraging young people with career advice, and "partnering" with less affluent congregations.
To do this, many churches are crossing racial and religious lines. For example, in Port Norris, Mr. Miller and the members of his church are white, while his counterpart, the Rev. Joseph L. Scott, and his church members are black.
Throughout the state, synagogues, Catholic parishes and Protestant churches have been joining in inter-faith coalitions to help the homeless in their communities, often putting them up for a week at time in church and synagogue basements.
"Churches and synagogues are increasingly moving to do social justice within the neighborhood, like soup kitchens," said Rabbi James Rudin, interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee in Manhattan. "They're focusing more and more on the local neighborhood, the community, the village and less on the global scene."
"That doesn't mean they've taken their eyes off the environment, nuclear weapons or land mines, which is the big issue now, but I see congregations focusing more on local and regional service delivery systems."
The Rev. Jack Johnson, a high-ranking Methodist church official who is president of the New Jersey Council of Churches, said he also sees a new involvement of congregations in social issues, recalling that many ministers and members of mainline Protestant churches were highly visible in civil rights and social justice issues in the 1960's, demonstrating, marching, lobbying and sometimes ending up in jail.
"I think for awhile churches backed away from that," Mr. Johnson said, "but they are now returning, recognizing that part of the mission of the church is to reach out and witness to the community. And the church has been engaged more recently on issues relating to affordable housing, clearly on issues of homelessness and hunger."
 
Seeking More Response At the Parish Level
 Several years ago the National Conference of Catholic Bishops released a paper urging Catholics to get involved in ministering to the needs of their parishes and communities. Last month, its international policy committee, headed by Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, expanded the scope with a paper entitled "Called to Global Solidarity." The Bishops are now urging a greater response by Catholics at the parish level to international problems of poverty, hunger and economic inequality and social justice and will issue guidebooks early next year on how to do so.
"A key test of a parish's 'Catholicity'," the document said, "is its willingness to go beyond its own boundaries to preach the Gospel, serve those in need and work for global justice and peace."
John Carr, secretary for social development and world peace of the United States Catholic Bishops Conference, said there were "literally hundreds and thousands of parishes" committed to social action but, added, "There is always a danger that one committee or group does it for the rest of us. We pray for them. We applaud them. We write them a check occasionally, but we don't join them." He added, however, "That's what I think is changing."
In Port Norris, the need for involvement become obvious. Once a prosperous town, its oyster industry was devastated by marine parasites. Today the per capita annual income of its 2,000 residents is about $10,000.
Teen-agers tend to hang out in front of Dino's pizzeria or Newcomb's Supermarket, which last year was damaged when a small plane crashed into the roof, closing the only grocery store in town for about eight months. That was when Pastors Miller and Scott first joined forces and operated a bus service so people without cars could buy food 18 miles away, in Millville.
Mr. Miller estimates that the cost of materials to convert the old house into a youth center will be $35,000 to $45,000 and is hoping for donations from outside Port Norris. And this is one of those holidays when donations are at their greatest. In Catholic and Protestant churches there were Christmas trees from which members have taken paper ornaments with instructions to buy gifts anonymously for "boy 6 to 8 year old," or "girl, 10".
St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Rutherford is no different. Last Sunday about 550 ornaments, 50 of them representing gifts for patients in Bergen Pines County Hospital, disappeared, said Kathleen Lovett, a member of the social concerns committee.
St. Mary's also takes part in the "Help A Family At Christmas Project," sponsored by the Newark Archdiocese, in which parishioners volunteer to be donors for needy families suggested by coordinators of emergency food programs.
Catherine L'Insalata, director of the archdiocesan parish social ministry programs, said it began a dozen years ago when a distraught woman who had lost a son called to say she wanted to help a needy family. Each year about 300 are helped; St. Mary's sponsored 12 this year.
"It's a very busy time for the social-concern elves, as we call ourselves," Ms. Lovett said.
Synagogues, too, have been busy collecting food and gifts for the needy at Hanukkah. One of the most active social ministry programs, in general, is in Temple Emanu-el in Westfield, where children have been bringing in hundreds of toys to the religious school for the Jewish Family Service and a cancer care facility.
Perhaps the most dramatic example of community involvement comes on a Sunday in April called Mitzvah Day, when 700 adults and children sign up to work on projects in the community. One of the projects involves a decade-old affiliation with the people of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Plainfield, where members rehabilitate houses of the needy.
"It's an amazing thing," said Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff, spiritual leader of the temple. "The volunteers do physically what they can, from painting to moderate repair, but we will hire people to do more difficult tasks, like the electrical work."
The Lutheran Church of the Reformation in well-to-do West Long Branch has teamed up with the Second Baptist Church in Long Branch to explore community needs. One result is creation of a soup kitchen that feeds 100 people every Saturday.
Our Lady of Notre Dame in North Caldwell, like many Catholic parishes, has a sister parish, St. Mary's in Jersey City. Recently parishioners advised students at the school there on career day; for the last three years Notre Dame has been providing scholarships to grammar school and high school students in St. Mary's parish.
 
The Basics for Babies At a Local Church
 An unusual program geared to working poor families got its start at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood. "Baby Basics" provides the babies with formula and diapers, said Pat Hanft, a church member who organized the program in April 1995 and now serves as its director.
The program began in a Sunday school classroom and served five to 10 babies in the immediate area. Since coming under the auspices of the Red Cross in Ridgewood last summer, it now serves 40 babies in Bergen County.
Mrs. Hanft, who gets a small salary which she splits with an assistant before donating her share to the program, "These are people with dignity, and most want to give back to us. A few weeks ago, a mother gave us two afghans she had knitted said, 'Please give these to babies in the program who need them.' "
Many religious bodies have been opening after-school programs to meet the needs of single-parentand two-income families. Last year, the First Presbyterian and Trinity Church in South Orange created a non-sectarian after-school program for middle school students that supplements their regular schoolwork, said the pastor, the Rev. Charles Thompson.
"As a church we become a model to the larger community of bringing a racially and culturally diverse community together in ways that are positive and exciting," he said.
His church also provides a meeting place for a gay youth group unaffiliated with the church and an organization, "Parents and Friends of Lesbians and Gays."
Among its programs, St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Fair Lawn has what the human-concerns minister, Lenora Mosca, calls a garden ministry. The church has long served as a food pantry and feeds 50 families a month in neighboring towns, including Paterson.
Several years ago, Ms. Mosca -- an enviromentalist who gives out seeds on Earth Day, encourages parishioners to avoid using chemicals on their lawns and publishes a quarterly ecology bulletin -- told a parishioner how useful including fresh vegetables in food packages would be.
The parishioner, Zach Garripoli, a retired union steamfitter, volunteers his time to Harrison House, a historic working farm owned by Bergen County, where he explains gardening techniques to childen and their parents. So he arranged to use a section of a garden behind the house to grow vegetables for the needy.
He and other parishioners also take Holy Communion to residents of a Fair Lawn nursing home and Bergen Pines Hospital on a regular basis.
"They look forward to seeing us and I look forward to seeing them," said Mr. Garripoli. "All of us get a lot out of it."
Another parishioner, Nancy Crincoli, a former consulting engineer, helped to form a group called M.O.M.S, Ministry of Motherhood, whose activities include taking their young children to nursing homes to interact with the sick and elderly.
Many churches and synagogues are in coalitions to address homelessness. One is Faith Lutheran Church in New Providence, which was the first to join the Interfaith Hospitality Network of Union County about 10 years ago.
For two weeks each year, member congregations shelter homeless women with children or families overnight. Faith Church provides 100 volunteers to the cause, said the pastor, the Rev. Murdoch MacPherson. Members also work at a soup kitchen in St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Newark each Saturday and volunteer time at an AIDS hospice every two months.
"We have a lot of people who realize they've got a lot," said Mr. McPherson, "and they're looking for ways to share it." He added, "You sit with a family and talk to the kids in the hospitality program and they say, 'I want my own home and my own bed.' And a lot of our people get fired up and want to deal with these issues."
 
Help With Rent For Working Poor
 Another coalition, Interfaith Neighbors Inc. in Monmouth County has a different approach. A non-profit corporation supported by 100 churches and synagogues, outside donations and government grants, it provides rent subsidies to the working poor.
Its president is Rabbi Sally Priesand; its long-time executive director is Joe Marmora. As a retired real estate salesman, he was looking "to do some good deeds here and there " and ended up 10 years ago helping to form the coalition.
The group now provides subsidies to about a hundred families a year and operates a senior citizen meal program for 2,200 elderly people a year.
"What we found was that no matter what our religion was," Mr. Marmora said, "we all believed we have a mandate from above to help needy people." He added, "We kind of thrive on that."
As productive as churches and synagogues are at direct service, with salaried employees or committees to deal with social concerns, their efforts to affect policy on broad issues like welfare are less widespread.
"Policy is a very important component for social justice, complementing the direct service works," said Regina Purcell, associate director for social concerns of the New Jersey Catholic Conference in Trenton, a public policy arm of New Jersey's bishops on social issues.
The conference and other interfaith groups joined some months back to influence Governor Whitman to establish a state-financed food-stamp program for legal immigrants who were losing food stamps as a result of changes in Federal policy.
Ms. Purcell said there is a deep level of cynicism among people about whether government can correct complicated societal problems, but there is also a desire to help.
"What I see when I visit with parishes is a sincere desire to do something that will make a difference, to change the way things are done, to help influence politics and politicians," Ms. Purcell said.
"Part of our job," she added, "is to encourage people to continue to be persistent in contacting their legislators, to write letters, to make phone calls and to know they ultimately can make a difference."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
If Only One East Coast Port Can Be No. 1, Which One Will It Be?

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
The year is 2030. Broad floating behemoths, eight stories high and nearly five stories deep, chug into an East Coast port, carrying 8,000 standard shipping containers filled with European exports, everything from computers to beer. Robotically unloaded, the cargo is shifted onto smaller ships, for delivery to other East Coast ports, onto railroads for delivery to the Midwest, and onto trucks for local delivery. American exports are loaded on, and the mighty ships take off for foreign ports, all in the service of a booming international economy.
This is what elected officials, business leaders and advocacy groups mean when they say "hub port," a phrase that is popping up with mantralike frequency as the debate over the future of the Port of New York and New Jersey gradually intensifies. In contrast to the unity that label suggests, there is an overriding issue: will the port of the future be in New York or in New Jersey? 
 The stakes are high. Most hub port visionaries believe there will be only one hub for all shipping lines on the East Coast -- and other established ports, such as those in Virginia and in Halifax, Nova Scotia, are jostling for the spot. New York and New Jersey, many say, does not have room for error.
The last change of similar significance in the shipping industry was the move toward containerization, which decades ago prompted the development of Ports Elizabeth and Newark, and spelled the end of the dominance of Brooklyn's bulk ports.
So the threat of failure is as real as the promise of huge economic benefits from international port business that experts project will increase 5 to 8 percent a year over the next 30 years.
Chris O. Ward, director of port redevelopment for the Port Authority, said: "If it becomes a battle between New York and New Jersey, the region as a whole will only suffer. We could blow this whole thing out of the water if we fight over it tooth and nail."
The current commercial business is centered on Ports Elizabeth and Newark, which have the most modern container equipment, though there are also functioning ports on the southern Brooklyn waterfront. Dredging to keep the channels to Elizabeth and Newark clear, and further dredging to deepen them to 45 feet, has been the main issue of the last few years, mainly because the dredged material is tainted with toxins and cannot be simply dumped elsewhere.
That problem has not been totally solved, but Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat from Essex, Hudson and Middlesex counties, believes there has been enough progress on plans for the sludge to permit him to focus on the next issue.
And that, he said, is making the routes to Elizabeth and Newark 50 feet deep, to accommodate ships so big they cannot fit through the Panama Canal, and so are called post-Panamax. The Bayonne Bridge, with a high-water clearance of 137 feet, is just high enough for these ships, according to Peter Schaerf, a consultant at the Commonwealth Group, a ship broker.
An Army Corps of Engineers study is under way now to determine the practicality of deepening the channel to 50 feet. But there are those, including Jerrold Nadler, the Democratic Representative from New York who has been trying to expand the region's use of rail for years, who believe that Ports Elizabeth and Newark cannot be the hub port.
Brett Heimov, a Nadler aide, said that no matter how deep the channels could be made, the Kill van Kull, the waterway between Bayonne and Staten Island, is wide enough for only one post-Panamax at a time. And, he said, it would be virtually impossible to widen the channel, a point disputed by Mr. Menendez and Mr. Ward.
But just in case, two other studies are examining alternative sites for hub ports. The Port Authority is examining the largest array, including southern Brooklyn and the 437-acre Military Ocean Terminal of Bayonne, which the military is closing in 2001.
A study by the New York City Economic Development Corporation is focusing solely on southern Brooklyn, in combination with a proposed rail-freight tunnel that would link it to Staten Island or New Jersey. New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, threw his support behind the tunnel this year.
Charles Millard, head of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said that while potential trade growth probably meant there would be development on "both sides of the harbor," it was only right for Brooklyn to get a major role.
"The coming growth in world trade is going to create enough market share for everyone," he said. "But the Mayor believes that New York City has not gotten its fair share of this trade over the last couple of decades because of the Port Authority's pro-New Jersey policies."
Mr. Ward, on the other hand, said that New York benefits when New Jersey's port business grows. "Sixty percent of the freight forwarders that handle cargo in Ports Elizabeth and Newark work in New York City," he said, concluding, "Hub ports don't just come off the shelf at Kmart. We need to look at where the jobs and the economic benefits land, rather than where the terminals do."
Mr. Menendez, the New Jersey Congressman, said that while the two states' common interests were compelling, so were their differences.
"If you listen to Jerry Nadler, he wants a rail tunnel, he wants New York to be the place for a new container port, and we would in essence become the feeder port," he said. "I say that's reinventing the wheel. We already have the container ports. And they generate $20 billion for the economy and 180,000 jobs!"
Forums to try to shape the debate are beginning to spring up. On Tuesday, the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a pro-rail advocacy group, is sponsoring a seminar at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark that will include New Jersey lawmakers, Port Authority officials and rail executives. William Yates, a project coordinator at the campaign, said a separate seminar is being planned to address New York's particular concerns.
And the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, an association of New York governmental agencies and transportation providers, is planning a forum, perhaps as early as February. Gerry Bogacz, an assistant director at the council, said such discussions were necessary to supplement efforts by the Port Authority, because, he said, it is "not necessarily seen as a neutral forum -- it's seen as a stakeholder."
 
Who Has What Ammunition in Port Fight
Three ports are most often mentioned as competitors for an increase in international shipping over the next 30 years. Here is a brief profile of each, using 1996 figures.
 
PORT OF NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY -- Pros: Huge number of local consumers, good rail connections on the New Jersey side. Cons: Existing channels need to be blasted and dredged for megaships; new container plants must be built where channels are already deep enough; costs are high.
Estimated imports are 51,993,484 metric tons, valued at $55.1 billion; estimated exports are 7,925,994 metric tons, worth about $24.2 billion. Total: 59,919,478 metric tons, worth $79 billion.
The top 10 destinations of cargo imported at this port are New York, New Jersey, Texas, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, California, Illinois, Georgia, Florida.
 
PORTS OF VIRGINIA -- (ncludes Portsmouth, Norfolk and Newport News.) Pros: 36-hour transit time to Midwest; has bulk and container equipment, excellent rail connections and warehouses; deep channels, thanks in part to military presence; low labor costs. Cons: relatively small local market.
Estimated imports are 9,893,865 metric tons, worth $16.6 billion; estimated imports are 4,941,463 metric tons, worth about $17.5 billion. Total: 54,835,328 metric tons, worth $34 billion.
The top 10 destinations for imported cargo are Virginia, New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Ohio, North Carolina, Illinois, Michigan, Connecticut
 
PORT OF HALIFAX, NOVA SCOTIA -- Pros: A day closer to Europe than other East Coast ports; deep channels; good rail connections to the Midwest; low labor costs. Cons: Few local consumers, a day further from markets from other East Coast ports.
Imports are an estimated 6,031,469 metric tons; imports are 6,903,653 metric tons. An estimated value was not available.
The top 10 destinations of cargo imported at Halifax are Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia, Illinois, California, British Columbia, Michigan, Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey.
Sources: Journal of Commerce's Port Import Export Reporting Service, American Association of Port Authorities, Halifax Port Corporation, Virginia Port Authority.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Preservation Pays, A Rutgers Study Finds . . .

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
The $60 million raised in the past 10 years through three bond issues for preservation of historic sites has generated many times that amount of money and created more jobs than new construction projects costing the same amount of money would have, according to a study by the Center for Urban Policy of Rutgers University.
The study supports the contention of preservation advocates that spending money to preserve history pays off, said Harriette Hawkins, director of the state Historic Trust. 
 The last of the money available for grants from the 1987, 1992 and 1995 Historic Preservation Bond Acts will be distributed this week. The money from the bonds and from all other historic preservation work in the state generates $263 million in income, creates 10,140 jobs and produces $215 million in state and local taxes each year, according to the study. New Jersey has 1,100 historic sites on the State and National Registers of Historic Places and 240 historic districts that containing thousands of other buildings. The study said 9.1 million tourists visit New Jersey's historic sites each year and spend $432 million. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Lacking Big Boxes, Fulton Uses Gold To Draw Shoppers

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Fulton Mall is a vibrant conga line of 300 fast-food joints, electronics and sneakers stores, clothing chains, random discount stores and gold jewelry by the truckload. With its aging buildings and countless "Sale" and Discount" signs, it's like Times Square, pre-Disney, sans porn.
"It is an esthetic honky-tonk," said Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. "But it's so successful that no one pays attention." An estimated 100,000 pedestrians traverse the mall daily, and it is among the city's highest grossing streets. 
 But there are signs of trouble, or at least transition, on the drag that is downtown Brooklyn's heart. At least five stores are having liquidation sales, and several other spaces are for rent. Woolworth's is closed. King's Department Store and Wertheimer's both just closed.
Fulton Mall has become Gold Alley, with new jewelry stores and counters, most run by Russian and Middle Eastern immigrants, proliferating. But vendors said the market was sagging, either from oversaturation or diminished demand.
Some non-gold retailers also said that business declined substantially in the last 18 months. "It's really, really, really going down; it's terrible," said the owner of NuBest, who declined to give her name but said that last year she had resorted to subleasing space in her men's-wear store to sportswear sellers and a gold jewelry counter.
Countless stores on the mall have become such mini-bazaars, with sneakers and electronics operations and a gold jewelry counter sharing space to meet rising rents.
Fulton rents have always been high, but retailers, realtors and business observers said perhaps landlords had pushed rates too high in a changing retail climate.
Peter Botsaris, president of Garrick-Aug Store Leasing Associates, said rents had risen to $150 per square foot. "Based on the volume on the street, they should have stayed at $100," he said. The 86th Street strip in Bay Ridge brings $60 to $80.
Downtown developments like Metrotech have brought thousands of consumers to the area. Surveys show they want better quality and service than Fulton's stores have provided.
Mr. Adams said new sites like "the clean, bright, well-organized" Atlantic Center nearby could lure many of those consumers. With this in mind, Lou Carbonetti, the Fulton Mall Improvement Association's new director, said he had begun persuading landlords to fix up the street. Otherwise, he said "there would be a disaster in five or six years."
But one landlord, Albert Laboz, said he thought that the empty stores would soon be snapped up and that the street was "still very strong."
The Gap-free mall has many loyalists, who come in search of deals, not smiles. Judy Franklin of Flatbush held up a gold bracelet and said she had just bartered it down to $100. "That's why I like it here," she said triumphantly. AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
She's Wound Up in Her Career, but He's Ready to Wind Down

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
AFTER a career as a salesman, Ruth Cambron's husband retired, and she thought she might, too. She took a leave from her job as a health care specialist in California, and the couple traveled on cruise ships. "That convinced me not to retire," Mrs. Cambron said. "I did not want to feel useless." She also wanted to build her pension. And 12 years later, at 73, she still draws a paycheck -- a stalwart in the growing ranks of older women who continue to work after their husbands stop.
Sandra Kaul, an art gallery director and consultant, is just entering those ranks. Her husband, lured by the offer of a sweetened pension, retired in June at 58, after 30 years as a college art professor in Minnesota. "I encouraged him," said Ms. Kaul, who is 55. "I knew he really wanted to stay home and paint, while I have a career to pursue." 
 Helena Genovese, 63, stays at her job out of both necessity and desire. Her husband, a professional hypnotist, now 68, retired seven years ago, worried that if he did not ease up he might suffer a fatal heart attack, as a friend had. But his $850 in monthly retirement benefits, mostly from Social Security, is insufficient to maintain the couple's suburban life style without Ms. Genovese's $1,900-a-month salary as a manager of the parking facility at Buffalo's airport.
"Besides, what would I do all day at home?" she asked. "He plays with the dog, builds model planes and visits our children. I think that if two people are home together constantly, they could end up killing each other."
Having distinguished themselves as the first generation to leave the house to work in large numbers, women in their late 50's and early 60's are now in retirement range. If they are single, divorced or widowed, they often keep working, surveys show, because they lack the Social Security credits or pension savings of men their age, who earned more and worked more years. But in growing numbers, married women in this age group are also staying on the job -- breaking with the practice of sharing their husbands' retirement.
Surveys are just beginning to catch the shift and the reasons for it. A big one is the promise of an independent pension to avoid the poverty that often comes to widows who rely on their husbands' benefits. Social Security, the main ingredient in most cases, is cut after a husband's death.
"Older women keep working to secure their economic survival," said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington.
What is more, the extra income earned by the women helps maintain family living standards, particularly if a husband has been pushed out of the labor force before he had planned to retire. And there is what Mathew Greenwald, a market researcher who polls people on retirement issues, calls the sociability aspect.
"Building friendships on the job is often more important to women than it is to men," he said. "Women may want to go on working to maintain these friendships. They find the idea of being retired more isolating than men do."
Whatever the reasons, women's persistence in working could have broad implications for the economy. It could, for example, relieve some of the financial pressure on the Social Security system, which will be stretched thin when the baby boomers retire.
The statistical evidence is still sparse, but the shift appears to apply mainly to those 55 to 64 and not to those 65 and older. The number of working men and women in that older group has traditionally been relatively small, although it has crept up slightly for both sexes in the 1990's.
The University of Michigan, which is tracking people in their 50's and 60's in a federally financed study that is just beginning to produce data, found that of 813 married women whose husbands had retired, 45 percent still worked, most of them full time. "These are serious workers, not just women doing real estate," said Marjorie Honig, a Hunter College economist who helped tabulate the results.
Labor Department surveys also suggest that married women are working in increasing numbers after their husbands stop, or at least that married women aged 55 to 64 are staying in the labor force in rising percentages while men are not. Nearly 3.5 million women in this group were in the labor force last year, or 48.6 percent of all married women 55 to 64, up from 41.3 percent in 1989 and 36.3 percent in 1980. But the percentage of married men in that age group in the labor force has fallen to 70.2 percent, from 75.4 percent in 1980.
"Women are beginning to realize that by working just a few more years, they become eligible for good pensions," said Olivia Mitchell, a labor economist at the University of Pennsylvania. "The benefit of those few extra years can be quite high."
MS. GENOVESE, who took a salaried job in 1980 when the youngest of her four children was 13, came to exactly that conclusion. "If I work three more years, I'll be eligible for a pension of $1,000 a month," she said. She made it clear that if her health held up, she would work indefinitely, qualifying for an even bigger pension. Her job also provides the couple's health insurance.
Many other women are also working for bigger pensions. The Social Security Administration projects that if current trends continue, by 2015 nearly 60 percent of married women will be entitled to higher pensions upon retirement than the spousal benefit they would receive under their husbands' Social Security. That would be up from 33 percent today. And 20 percent of the women will qualify for pensions that are higher than those of their husbands, up from less than 10 percent today.
But there is a caveat about projecting the trend forward. What Ms. Cambron, Ms. Kaul and Ms. Genovese share with many older married women is this: They took jobs and began careers relatively late in life after raising children or at least staying home until their children were in junior high school. Younger women, on the other hand, are far more likely to have careers that parallel those of their husbands. Once they reach retirement age, husband and wife, having gone through the same career cycles, may think alike about retirement.
"The question is, will these younger people prod each other to stay on the job or will they prod each other to retire," said Angela O'Rand, a Duke University sociologist and retirement specialist.
For now, however, older husbands and wives are increasingly going in separate directions.
Six months after her husband retired, Ms. Kaul is in high career, having entered the work force only 14 years ago, once her two children became teen-agers. She is even expanding her domain, looking into using retail stores as small, makeshift art galleries for Minnesota painters. Actually, her work as the art gallery director at Bemidji State University, 100 miles north of Minneapolis, where her husband, Marlin, had taught for 30 years, is a part-time job. But Ms. Kaul has five part-time jobs, most of them as a paid consultant to various art councils and art projects in Minnesota.
"I am in the process of proposing to the university a larger position for myself," she said. "It will probably be three-quarters time. I am suggesting that we start a museum program, to manage art collections and curate them for traveling exhibitions."
Still, the Kauls do not have to rely on her income. Marlin Kaul's sweetened pension -- a lump-sum payment and $40,000 a year -- is enough for them to live comfortably. The $15,000 she brings home helps, of course, but her decision to keep working separates the Kauls from three couples who are their friends. The men, also professors at Bemidji, accepted sweetened pensions, too, and their wives have decided to retire with them. All three women had worked much longer than Ms. Kaul.
"Two of them were in teaching careers," Ms. Kaul said, "and they no longer like their jobs enough to keep doing them anymore now that their husbands are retiring."
The decision also swings the other way. And when it does, a wife who continues to work sometimes ends up on Rosalind Barnett's couch. Ms. Barnett, a psychologist and senior researcher in women's issues at Brandeis University and Radcliffe College, recounts one patient's story:
"Her husband, a lawyer who never liked what he did, lived for the day he could move to the woods in New Hampshire, and this was a nightmare for her," Ms. Barnett said. "She was the director of a nonprofit organization, involved in work and community life, with a big network of people around her, and he wanted to retire to a rural life style."
In the end, the husband did not retire. "He cut back his hours," Ms. Barnett said, "but he is still working as a lawyer. He is very unhappy."
EVEN husbands who support their wives' decisions to keep working can take awhile to get there, as Dominic Genovese did.
He had never cooked, and for five years after he retired he stayed out of the kitchen, which meant that his wife could not relax until she had prepared dinner. "The stress for me did not end with the job," she said. And the dinner hour became later and later. "That ticked me off," Mr. Genovese said, "But cooking is something I did not think of doing. I made the bed; that took only a few minutes. And I vacuumed; I did not want to be home with dog's hair around."
A life-threatening stomach ailment changed his attitude toward cooking, he said -- as did the fact that the couple's three adult sons cook. He now makes dinner four nights a week.
Howard Aronoff, 57, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., also cooks. His mother had taught him, and in retirement, he took over that task from his wife, although she still does the grocery shopping. Unlike Mr. Genovese, Mr. Aronoff did not willingly retire: he took a buyout in 1993 from I.B.M., where he was a senior planner, rather than risk being laid off without any payment. After briefly trying a new career as an insurance salesman, "I drifted into retirement," Mr. Aronoff said. "When people found out I was no longer at I.B.M., they looked on me as a piece of dead wood."
Her husband's changed status scared his wife, Roberta, who is 53. His earnings suddenly deflated from more than $80,000 a year to a $35,000 pension even as the couple, who were nearly finished paying for their two children's undergraduate education, were counting on the next five years to save for retirement. So she has continued in her nearly $30,000-a-year job as the manager of a dental office, a position she had held for a decade.
"You have to sit down and work out the money issues," she said. "My husband did that. He showed me, with spreadsheets, how we would get by, and that eased my mind. He found a way even to save a little."
The new budget meant belt-tightening. They bought a new car for her, for example, but he still drives a 1988 model. And their daughter, now at Harvard Law School, pays her own way. "My wife would have liked some new jewelry," he said, "and I would have liked to help my children more."
Sometimes a husband chooses retirement because changes at work suddenly make the job much more difficult. William Cambron found himself in this situation in 1985, when he was 62. For years, he had been a salesman for a wholesale company that offered a line of toasters and household wares to hardware stores. As those stores lost out to big discounters like Sam's Club, the Wal-Mart unit, Mr. Cambron had to travel farther from the couple's home in Sacramento.
"They kept widening his territory as the market dwindled, and he was tired," Ms. Cambron said. And so he stopped. "He does not have a need to work. Basically, he enjoys supporting me in what I do. He even keeps my car filled with gas. I never have to do that anymore."
When her husband retired, Ms. Cambron, a year younger, was only a decade into a career as a health care specialist in the California Department for the Aging. That job paid her $50,000 a year when she retired two years ago and shifted to a job monitoring nursing homes for a nonprofit organization, earning just $7,000 but working far fewer hours. Being older than 70, she is permitted to draw her full Social Security and a California state pension. They total $37,000, exceeding her husband's retirement payments by $7,000, even as she still draws a paycheck.
"I would not be well off," she said, "if I had not continued working."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Even if Gambling Wanes, Hilton May Be Worth a Bet

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
IN a week that was less than kind to many stocks, Hilton Hotels, which surprised analysts with an unexpectedly low earnings forecast because of weakness in its gambling operations, was hit harder than most.
In falling, Hilton's stock was catching up to a broad decline in the gambling business -- one that put Timothy Ryan, dean of the University of New Orleans College of Business and an authority on the economics of gambling, in mind to recall a student's paper: If Houston continued growing at its present rate, the student wrote, it would soon be bigger than Texas. 
 "That sounds like some of those projections we used to hear about legalized gambling," Professor Ryan said.
While the push for legalized gambling remains strong in cities that are looking to create jobs and generate tax revenue, industry watchers have increasingly begun to utter the dreaded "S" (for "saturation") word. And indeed, pure gambling stocks in general are lower for the year -- a strikingly bad performance against the overall market's gains.
Saturation does not seem to worry Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who confirmed nine days ago that his administration was thinking about where to build a casino, possibly including Governors Island in New York Harbor.
Nonetheless, the word is likely to be heard more often, after a 13.8 percent drop this week in Hilton's stock, which closed on Friday at $26.9375.
Late last Monday, Hilton projected that its fourth-quarter operating earnings per share would be in the mid-to-high 20-cent range, well below the 37 cents a share expected by analysts surveyed by First Call.
Still, most analysts continue to recommend Hilton stock, largely on the strength of its hotel operations.
On that basis, Jason N. Ader, senior managing director at Bear, Stearns, calls Hilton "attractive." But he warns that in gambling, Hilton had a lot of catching up to do to rank with such first-tier casino-resort companies as Mirage Resorts and M-G-M Grand -- and to stay competitive in Las Vegas, Nev.
"If you're here for a convention, you'll stay at Hilton," Mr. Ader said -- in a telephone conversation from the Las Vegas Hilton, adjacent to the city convention center. "But you don't get the entertainment or excitement that draws visitors and walk-in traffic to the casinos."
Nevertheless, Mr. Ader noted that Stephen F. Bollenbach, Hilton's president and chief executive since February 1996, "has a history of creating value." Therefore, Mr. Ader added, "I suspect you'll see a major stock repurchase over the next 12 months, if the shares stay at this level."
Dennis I. Forst, a gaming analyst with McDonald & Company Investments, has an "aggressive buy" posted for Hilton stock, which he said was "very cheap." He noted that the company was doing well at its Hilton and Bally's properties in Atlantic City. "And Steve Bollenbach hasn't yet been there very long," he added.
Mr. Forst estimates that Hilton's 1997 revenue will be almost evenly split between its lodging and gambling operations, with $2.75 billion from lodging and $2.6 billion from gaming.
Naomi Talish, gaming analyst for Merrill Lynch Global Securities, was surprised by the timing of Hilton's announcement. "Some of the problems Hilton cited didn't just happen; they were known a couple of months ago," she said.
Furthermore, "very rarely will a big casino company make a pre-announcement of the fourth quarter when about a third of fourth-quarter earnings come in the last eight hours of the year," Ms. Talish said, referring to the hoards that jam Las Vegas for New Year's Eve. Those hours, she said, could mean as much as 5 cents either way for the quarter.
Andrew Zarnett, a gambling industry analyst with Ladenburg, Thalmann, acknowledged that "a lot of small events have caused people to be more wary" of gambling stocks.
One problem is the growth in hotel rooms in Las Vegas, which now has 104,000, combined with fewer airplane seats to the city because airlines have deployed many larger planes to routes with more high-fare business passengers. But the situation should come back into balance next year, Mr. Zarnett said, with the opening of 26 new gates at Las Vegas's McCarran International Airport.
Meantime, he said, "While there clearly is concern in the market, that's when you want to buy, not when everything's rosy."
Hilton's disappointing earnings projections are related in part to a charge of about 5 cents a share from its unsuccessful attempt to take over the ITT Corporation. It will also write off about 20 cents a share for its Flamingo Casino in Kansas City, Mo., a highly competitive and tightly regulated market, and 5 cents a share for its Flamingo riverboat casino in New Orleans, which shut down two-and-a-half months ago.
While Hilton has not enunciated a grand strategy in the wake of its assault on ITT, it has acknowledged the possibility of a stock buyback and has made no secret that it will continue to look for acquisitions.
Still, Professor Ryan foresees problems throughout the gambling industry.
"Show me any product, and I'll show you a life cycle," he said, pointing to the recent explosion of casinos on riverboats and Indian reservations. While it takes years for many industries to develop, he said, legalized gambling "compressed it into 8 to 10 years."
That helped satisfy pent-up demand and created new customers, but it eventually bred disillusionment when customers realized they were far more likely to lose than to win -- and then cut back on visits or wagers. That has put a damper on growth, Professor Ryan said, at a time when the market is becoming saturated with casinos.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Scenes from the Malls: Megastores and Mini-Bazaars

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Those who consider Atlantic Center, the 380,000-square-foot Atlantic Avenue shopping mall, a leisure destination would do well to read the code of conduct posted near each entrance.
"Juvenile groups of four (4) or more will be dispersed," warns the code, which is reinforced by roving security guards. "Customers must keep moving in an orderly fashion. "Seating benches are to be used for shopping breaks not to exceed 15 minutes." 
 From its rules to its architecture -- three floors with 11 megastores separated by long narrow hallways, with few benches for those 15-minute breaks -- this safe, sanitized "power mall," as some have dubbed it, clearly means business.
A year after it opened, it is also doing big business. David Roberts, the human resources manager for Old Navy, said the store, the first Old Navy in Brooklyn, had $18 million in annual sales, placing it second among the chain's 263 stores.
The center's construction by Forest City Ratner on a long-vacant site had some smaller local businesses worried that they would be squashed by the "big box" stores' size and pricing. If anything, the opposite has proved true, said Rick Russo, the executive director of the North Flatbush Business Improvement District. "There's increased pedestrian traffic" on Flatbush Avenue, he said, "and increased sales."
Henry Rosa, the manager at Triangle Sports, which had quaked at the arrival of the much larger Sports Authority, agreed. The store had "more traffic than ever before," he said.
But Ruben Demesa, the manager at Furniture House on Flatbush Avenue, said that to compete with Caldor's lower prices, his store had begun offering assembly and other services that Caldor's does not.
On the Fulton Mall, Phil Hodges, the manager of Modell's, said business was not so strong as in the past, but he did not know if that was the center's fault. "Retail is flat in general," he said.
Residents of a borough routinely described as "understored" have taken full advantage of the center. Rachel Nash takes two buses once a week from Crown Heights to shop at Pathmark, "because it's cheaper" than her neighborhood stores, she said.
Not all is rosy, of course. While an unscientific survey of shoppers found that many had arrived by public transportation, plenty still drive, contributing to the entrenched gridlock at the intersection of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues. And some store managers, who would not speak for attribution, said sales were weaker than during last year's pre-Christmas season.
The mall has provided around 1,500 jobs, many to Brooklyn residents. But Brad Lander, the executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee, a community group, criticized the jobs' nature. "Local people are being hired in part-time, minimum-wage, no-benefit, no-union jobs," he said. "That's not a good economic development for the city." AMY WALDMAN
