HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Hoping to Follow In Others' Tread Marks

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
IT a time when demand for new stock offerings is waning, the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group nonetheless has high hopes.
Next week, the company, which consists of two car-rental businesses owned by Chrysler, is expected to sell 22.5 million shares at $19 to $22 each. Chrysler is selling off the entire operation and will keep all but $45.9 million of the expected $460 million in proceeds. 
 The reason that Dollar Thrifty is hopeful is the strong stock performance of two competitors that preceded it into the public market this year.
Since it went public in April, Hertz has seen its stock rise about 66 percent. And the stock of Avis, which went public in September, has nearly doubled.
Many of the forces that have propelled these stocks should benefit the two Chrysler businesses, Dollar Rent A Car Systems and Thrifty Rent-a-Car System. For one, they are the last car-rental companies to be spun off by an auto manufacturer. Once freed from the auto makers, which often used them as a dumping ground for their vast fleets of cars, the rental operations have been better able to pursue profitability, raise rental fees and keep the size of their fleets relatively stable, said J. Cogan, an analyst with Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
Also, the industry's small number of companies is partly shielded from competition by the high cost of assembling large car fleets, said Mark Basham, a research analyst at Standard & Poor's.
Because of persistent economic optimism, car travel in general is growing, too. Despite rising air fares, hotel rates and other travel-related costs, for instance, auto travel during the holiday season is expected to be 4 percent higher this year than in 1996, according to the American Automobile Association.
That growth and the rental companies' new independence have allowed the industry to raise prices for the first time in more than five years, and all these factors are showing up in revenues. According to Auto Rental News, a trade publication, industry revenue is expected to rise 11.8 percent this year, to $16.4 billion.
And the price increases may stick. "Leisure travelers are more concerned about airline costs than rental car costs," Mr. Cogan said. "You're not going to cancel a trip to Hawaii because the rental car rate went up 5 percent."
Dollar Thrifty has been buoyed by these rising sales and price increases. The company had a net profit of $24.2 million for the first nine months of 1997, compared with $13.6 million for the corresponding period in 1996, exclusive of a $155 million one-time charge related to its spinoff from Chrysler.
But an investment in Dollar Thrifty has risks. With total revenues of $705.6 million last year, or about 5 percent of the industry's sales, the two Chrysler operations combined rank as only the seventh-largest rental company. The three biggest -- and better known -- competitors are Enterprise, with $3.1 billion in 1996 domestic revenues; Hertz, with $2.7 billion, and Avis, with $1.8 billion.
Moreover, instead of focusing on bread-and-butter business travel, Dollar Thrifty looks at the leisure market. This may put Dollar Thrifty at great risk in a faltering economy.
True, all rental-car companies are vulnerable to an economic slowdown. "If growth were to slow, these companies could see their profits erode quickly," said Ryan Jacob, research director at IPO Value Monitor, a New York research firm. A price war prompted by the slowdown could further erode profits, he added.
But leisure travel, financed by personal dollars and basically discretionary, is much more cyclical than business travel, Mr. Jacob said.
Debt is another danger point. Like the rest of the industry, Dollar Thrifty carries large debts to finance its fleet. Its ratio of debt to total capitalization is 85.5 percent, for example, and Hertz's is 82.1 percent.
Such debts can squeeze profits in tough times. In its prospectus, Dollar Thrifty says it must sustain its improved performance this year to meet its debt service obligations using operating cash flow.
FOR investors, then, Dollar Thrifty, with both significant strengths and significant risks, poses a hard question. But its stock price may tip the balance.
At the midpoint of its offering range, Dollar Thrifty stock would trade at about 25 times its estimated 1997 earnings per share. Hertz and Avis are trading at about 22 times and 27 times 1997 earnings, respectively. As for 1998 projections, Dollar Thrifty looks slightly cheaper, with a multiple of 16 compared with 19 for Hertz and 21 for Avis.
But new stocks often have a modest discount to those of competitors who are already public. And anyway, Mr. Jacob said, all these price-earnings ratios are just too lofty.
Mr. Jacob conceded that the fundamentals of the car-rental industry "are the best they've looked in a long time." But "given the cyclical nature of the rental-car industry" and its high costs, "20 times earnings is a high multiple," he said.
Thomas Galvin, chief equity strategist with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, agreed, and said that multiples between 12 and 15 seem more reasonable for the industry. He said airlines and hotels, two other cyclical, travel-related businesses, are good comparisons, and that when averaged together, these industries' stocks trade in that range.

HEADLINE: The Collapse of a Master Builder;
80's 'Visionary' in Legal Battles on 3 Continents

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
EVEN today, when he is in legal trouble on three continents and fighting for his financial life in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Baltimore, Gooch Ware Travelstead, an alternately charming and blustery real estate developer, is described by his few remaining friends and his many enemies as a "visionary."
As a consultant from a tiny design firm in North Carolina, Mr. Travelstead persuaded the First Boston Corporation to place him at the helm of its worldwide real estate operation in the boom years of the 1980's and eventually lend him at least $37 million to share in its deals. He conceived the plan to transform the decaying Docklands of London into Canary Wharf, the biggest real estate project in Europe. He tried to erect the tallest building in the world on Madison Avenue -- while also finding time to take on a sprawling hotel, office and retail project in Barcelona, Spain, tied to the 1992 Olympics. 
Yet all of these relationships and projects ran into difficulties or foundered -- and Mr. Travelstead's career is strewn with partners, friends and investors whose admiration for the developer ultimately turned into bitter recriminations and tangled lawsuits. Even so, just two years ago the local press still hailed Mr. Travelstead as the "Lord of Broome" when he swooped into that town in Western Australia to try to save one of the country's largest landholding companies.
Now, Mr. Travelstead, who is known as Ware, seems to be coming to a dead end.
He is scheduled to appear in Barcelona tomorrow to answer criminal charges of misappropriation brought by a partner in a Planet Hollywood franchise at the hotel complex.
And on Thursday, he has a date in Baltimore in the bankruptcy case. Among other things, he will be asking the court to protect him from foreclosure on $3.8 million in loans he took from his Australian property company. A foreclosure would strip the developer of the Australian property -- which all sides say is the most valuable asset left in what he once called a $100 million empire.
This is an extraordinary denouement for a man who regularly shuttled to Europe on the Concorde, had homes in Barcelona, Connecticut, London, New York and North Carolina and counted among his friends and associates Fred Wilpon, a developer and an owner of the New York Mets; Joseph R. Perella, the merger superstar; Bruce Babbitt, the Secretary of the Interior, and even Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain.
But more than just a Hollywood-caliber saga of personal highs and lows, Mr. Travelstead's story serves as a cautionary tale for the real estate industry, which emerged only last year from a recession that began in the early 90's. The real estate market is again crackling with billions in cash, even as some observers warn that buyers are overpaying in a frenzied atmosphere, just as in the 1980's, when Mr. Travelstead was at his peak. Indeed, his success during the last boom has some people in the industry wondering just how many of the new generation of visionaries, and their fantastic plans, will turn out to be the real thing.
"There's an unprecedented amount of money flowing from Wall Street into real estate," said David S. Cordish, a fellow developer who was a crosstown rival of Mr. Travelstead's in high school lacrosse in Baltimore. "People are going to get burned, and stuff that shouldn't get built will get built. Developers -- and Ware is the personification of this -- always see the brightest scenario. He painted with a big brush on a big canvas."
Those bright pictures Mr. Travelstead so cannily painted for investors and bankers consumed enormous sums of money. That left some of his partners and investors howling. Among them was Sogo, the Japanese department store company that saw the cost of the Barcelona project that it was backing soar to more than $800 million from the projected $230 million.
"Ware is the most fascinating person I've ever met," said Richard L. Fisher, whose family real estate empire includes some of New York's major office towers. "His visions were fantastic and almost always proved to be pure fantasy, ultimately destructive to all those around him. There will always be so-called visionaries whose dreams so far exceed their capabilities that often the difference between them and charlatans is hard to discern."
DESPITE all his legal troubles, Mr. Travelstead seems unbowed. During a brief encounter in Baltimore in September, he treated the bankruptcy proceedings as a minor irritant, telling a reporter, "This won't last long."
For several weeks, neither Mr. Travelstead nor his lawyers responded to phone calls requesting an interview about the bankruptcy case and other matters. Last Wednesday, his lawyers, while declining to discuss any details, nevertheless said that Mr. Travelstead "refutes his adversaries' allegations." On Friday, his lawyers for the first time suggested that Mr. Travelstead would be available for an interview, sometime this coming week.
In court, his lawyers have denied all allegations of misconduct, including what one lawyer called "the drumbeat of charges" lodged by creditors.
Patrick J. B. Donnelly, a Baltimore lawyer and longtime friend who sometimes represents Mr. Travelstead, noted that "a lot of people made money with Ware" over the years. Others in the developer's circle added that many of his troubles were a result of unforeseen problems that occurred in the course of building what one described as "gigantic visionary projects" that ultimately changed the face of Barcelona and London. They also disputed the validity of many of the allegations in the lawsuits.
"These are things being done for business purposes," said Martin Kabat, a financial director of one of Mr. Travelstead's companies and a defendant in the Barcelona case, referring to the lawsuits.
Still, Mr. Travelstead's situation looks dire. The developer, who is 59 and lives in Barcelona with his third wife, Cheryl Stone, is facing two important hearings this week in Baltimore. At the first, he will be trying to fend off the foreclosure threatening his Australia operations.
The outcome of that hearing could well affect the subject of the second hearing: the degree of control he should retain over the sale of his other assets to satisfy creditors. A committee representing that group -- which includes his former wife Edythe, some of his ex-lawyers, a former partner and associate at First Boston and his ex-bookkeeper -- has accused him of having "lied under oath" and hidden some of his assets. In court, his lawyers have said that any discrepancies were unintentional and have been clarified.
FEW people who know Mr. Travelstead -- including Edythe Travelstead and many current and former top executives at First Boston, the securities firm and investment bank that has merged with Credit Suisse -- are willing to say anything publicly about the developer, citing either distasteful memories or Mr. Travelstead's combativeness. The securities firm has also declined to comment other than to confirm that Mr. Travelstead had worked with it in the 80's.
Mr. Travelstead was a virtual unknown in 1978 when he met executives from First Boston at a trade conference in Chicago. Mr. Travelstead, a son of a building contractor from Baltimore, had already had a peripatetic career in sales and real estate. In 1973, he was a consultant to Richard Bass, a millionaire adventurer who owns the Snowbird ski resort in Utah (and is unrelated to the more well-known Bass brothers of Fort Worth). At one point, Mr. Travelstead flew to Teheran to try to persuade the Shah to invest in the resort. Nothing came of it and Mr. Travelstead and Mr. Bass eventually had a bitter falling out.
A failed attempt to buy a ski resort in Steamboat Springs, Colo., left him and Edythe, an interior designer, deeply in debt. They opened a design firm in North Carolina, but Mr. Travelstead still had grand plans.
Enter the bankers from First Boston, who hired him in 1978 to solve some lighting problems at the firm's newly leased headquarters at One New York Plaza, at the southern tip of Manhattan. Within days, Mr. Travelstead was proposing what was then a daring alternative for an investment bank: moving away from the financial district to a planned tower in midtown, Park Avenue Plaza.
He negotiated a lease at below-market rates with the developer, Mr. Fisher of Fisher Brothers, and got an equity stake in the tower while arranging for a $104 million construction loan. At the same time, Mr. Travelstead sold the lease at One New York Plaza for a quick $7 million profit. This allowed First Boston, which was having a bad year, to avoid reporting its first loss ever. George L. Shinn, then the chairman of First Boston, and Peter T. Buchanan, who was its president, were, in the words of several investment bankers, "eternally grateful."
One senior executive at the firm who spoke on condition of anonymity said: "It was a rather spectacular deal. We got a great office and made a lot of money. It sparked our interest in real estate and showed he had certain talents."
Indeed, First Boston soon became the first investment bank to invest heavily in real estate projects, a path that others soon followed. Heading up the new operation was Mr. Travelstead, who had worked out an unusual relationship. Instead of signing on as an employee, he acted as a partner, seeking out real estate deals in which First Boston would invest for itself as well as lend him money for his own interest.
Armed with the prestige and clout of First Boston, Mr. Travelstead was suddenly everywhere, a welcome partner with well-known developers, like Mr. Wilpon, at 575 Fifth Avenue, an office tower in New York's diamond district. Mr. Travelstead seemed to have the golden touch, though his plan to transform the south end of Miami Beach into the "Venice of the South" ended in a legal battle with city officials over financing. His strength was in the vision, former associates say, not the details.
He sold his and First Boston's stake in 712 Fifth Avenue, across the street from Manhattan's Trump Tower, to the developers David Solomon and A. Alfred Taubman for a healthy profit even before the building was finished. Mr. Travelstead and First Boston then teamed up with Mr. Solomon to build Tower 49, at 12 East 49th Street, where Mr. Travelstead opened an office for his own company, the Travelstead Group. That building was sold in 1986 to a Japanese company for $305 million, or $550 a square foot, still the highest per-foot price ever paid for a New York office tower.
As fast as the profits poured in, Mr. Travelstead acquired the opulent trappings so characteristic of an era that raised deal makers in real estate and on Wall Street to the level of cultural icons. He had a triplex on Park Avenue in Manhattan, a mansion in Greenwich, Conn., a yacht and limousines. Fond of the grand gesture, he picked up the tab for luxurious vacations in Barbados, Sardinia and Venice with a group of close friends, including Mr. Perella, who went on from First Boston to form his own firm with Bruce Wasserstein and is now with Morgan Stanley.
"In those days, First Boston seemed to pretty much give Ware carte blanche," a former First Boston executive said. "He was moving up. The merger boom brought First Boston to prominence. And he and Perella were always the best of friends."
Mr. Perella declined to comment about his friendship with Mr. Travelstead, a relationship that ended in a falling out in 1990, say a number of people who knew both men.
While many wealthy investors found Mr. Travelstead to be charming and brilliant, he could also be an explosive bully, according to many former colleagues, screaming at subordinates and associates alike and using his imposing frame in a calculated effort at intimidation. Mr. Travelstead's brother, Malcolm, a banker who has worked with him in the past, testified during one of Mr. Travelstead's lawsuits that he "was not a person who likes to be confronted."
Colorful myths have swirled about Mr. Travelstead, some apparently of his own creation. According to friends and associates, he has frequently claimed to be a co-owner of the Mets, and earlier this year he even testified to that effect in a deposition. The Mets organization, however, says the developer never owned a share of the team, though it is suing him for nonpayment on his luxury skybox. He denies owing any back payments.
Mr. Travelstead is best known for the project that would consume him for more than two years -- Canary Wharf. In 1985, Michael von Clemm, chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., then the European cousin of the First Boston Corporation, was considering leasing space in a banana warehouse in London's Docklands. But where Mr. von Clemm saw cheap space on a dilapidated pier, his American adviser, Mr. Travelstead, saw what other developers would not have imagined: a vast $4 billion office complex on 71 acres that could become the new headquarters for London's financial district. He persuaded First Boston, Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley to put up the money for the mega-project, while he retained a 16 percent interest for putting together the deal.
Yet Mr. Travelstead's much-vaunted sales skills abandoned him when it came time to sign up tenants. "The Brits are scared of scale," he said to a reporter at the time. "Size is something they just don't deal with very well."
The project's enormity is what eventually prompted a skittish Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse to begin pulling out of the venture in 1987. Mr. Travelstead floundered as he tried to line up tenants and new partners who would not push him aside. Mr. Buchanan, his patron at First Boston, then opened negotiations with Paul Reichmann of Olympia & York that resulted in the Canadian developer's taking over the project. Mr. Travelstead collected an estimated $8.5 million for his stake and his fees. Although Canary Wharf is considered a success today, the complex dragged Mr. Reichmann's company into bankruptcy in 1992.
AFTER the Canary Wharf escapade and the crash of the stock market in October 1987, First Boston wanted out of the once-rewarding real estate market and its arrangement with Mr. Travelstead.
The firm made money at the beginning of the relationship and lost money at the end, said a former managing director at First Boston. "My guess is that the losses exceeded the gains," he said.
Nowhere is that more evident than at 383 Madison Avenue, the block-square former Manhattan Savings Bank building near Grand Central Terminal that Mr. Travelstead and First Boston bought for $80.5 million in 1982 with Arab partners. Mr. Travelstead had boldly declared that he would build a 140-story tower on the site, using development rights from the terminal. But the quixotic vision for the tallest building in the world would turn into a loss of tens of millions of dollars, as a court battle with the city over transfer of the rights dragged on for nearly a decade.
Even after his 1988 divorce from First Boston, Mr. Travelstead controlled the project, refusing to sell the site to Mr. Fisher for $215 million, much to the outrage of two top First Boston executives, Jeffrey Parker and Robert Razziano, according to internal First Boston documents. First Boston finally shed Mr. Travelstead from the project in 1992 and sold the building four years later to the Arab partners for $55 million. The building still sits vacant, although the Bear Stearns Companies plans to erect its new headquarters on the site.
Frustrated in New York or London, Mr. Travelstead turned in 1988 to Barcelona. Eduardo Canet, a former First Boston executive who had jumped to Mr. Travelstead's company and become a close friend, had been developing the hotel, office and retail complex there. Mr. Travelstead eventually shoved Mr. Canet aside and took over, according to a court decision in a lawsuit brought by Mr. Canet. After initially having trouble raising capital, Mr. Travelstead found Sogo, the Japanese department store company, which was willing to put up all the money for the project and give him a 50 percent stake. Sogo was less interested in the centerpiece of the project -- the 44-story Hotel Arts, billed as the finest in Europe -- as it was in finding the right spot for its first department store on the Continent.
ALTHOUGH Mr. Travelstead hired top architects, the project careered out of control and, except for a few hotel rooms, did not open in time for the Olympics. Sogo ended its partnership with Mr. Travelstead in 1993 and later sued him in United States District Court in Manhattan, accusing him of mismanagement and fraud. (Mr. Travelstead denied the contentions.)
But Sogo dropped the suit the next year after Mr. Travelstead flew to Tokyo to talk to company executives, according to court documents in a related case. In an about-face, Sogo, which declined to discuss its relationship with Mr. Travelstead, granted the developer options to buy the 29 luxury apartments in the Hotel Arts while also lending him $3 million. Sogo also invested in the local Planet Hollywood franchise. The company's department store in the complex failed in 1996.
(Only much later did Mr. Travelstead's other partner at Planet Hollywood, Raymond Velazquez, a former special agent with the Justice Department, learn that the developer had secretly granted Sogo a 35 percent interest, thereby reducing Mr. Velazquez's stake to 32.5 percent, from 50 percent, according to papers in the lawsuit he filed earlier this year in Federal Court in Miami against Sogo and the Travelstead Group. In that suit, Mr. Velazquez contended that Sogo and Mr. Travelstead conspired to defraud him as part of a scheme to avoid millions of dollars in American tax liabilities, accusations that both parties deny. As the Miami suit continues, Mr. Velazquez has opened up another front by bringing the criminal charges in Barcelona.)
After settling his dispute with Sogo, Mr. Travelstead planned a gala party in Barcelona for Christmas 1994 to market the apartments, using Lady Thatcher as a drawing card. Mr. Travelstead met Lady Thatcher in London during his association with the Canary Wharf project. He prevailed on a mutual friend, Lord Alistair McAlpine, whose family owned a construction company that served as a general contractor at Canary Wharf, to persuade the former Prime Minister to take an all-expenses-paid holiday in Barcelona.
Mr. Travelstead provided the same amenities to Jack Demorest, an independent investor who had given Mr. Travelstead $500,000 the year before to be put into a Travelstead company that would buy and sell the Hotel Arts apartments.
Mr. Demorest said in an interview that he was "swept off his feet" by the first-class treatment and the opportunity to meet Lady Thatcher. During a weeklong stay, Mr. Demorest said, Mr. Travelstead urged him to leave his $500,000 in the company, which would quickly sell them at a big profit to Lady Thatcher, Lord McAlpine and others. No such purchases or sales ever occurred.
Nor did Mr. Travelstead repay the money. So Mr. Demorest sued in Federal Court in New York in May 1995. Eight days later, Mr. Demorest said, he was repaid and settled the case.
By then, Mr. Travelstead was already in Western Australia. In partnership with Lord McAlpine and Karen Dobson, a former First Boston executive who had worked with Mr. Travelstead in Barcelona, he bought control of Australia City Properties, a struggling real estate company owned by the McAlpine family. The company's large portfolio, which included the luxurious Cable Beach Club Resort in Broome and the valuable Bishops See development site in Perth, had about $160 million in debts. Mr. Travelstead was able to gain control for about $38.8 million, putting up a small amount himself and financing most of the rest with bank loans.
He basked in the press coverage, telling reporters he would invest as much as $380 million to create new luxury developments.
IT was a brilliant deal -- that is, until he borrowed $3.8 million in two loans from the Australian operation, which was owned by Blockless, a company formed by Mr. Travelstead and Ms. Hobson and registered in the Netherlands.
Under financial pressure in early 1996, Mr. Travelstead, as the majority shareholder of Blockless, tried to extend for one year the short-term loans to himself. He needed the money to pay back $5 million he had borrowed from Planet Hollywood in Barcelona, he said in depositions. Ms. Hobson blocked him, however, and the two have been wrestling for control of Blockless ever since.
"Mr. Travelstead had now systematically cleaned out Blockless's bank account," Ms. Hobson testified in a deposition in a related hearing in Bankruptcy Court.
Mr. Travelstead's problems were compounded in February 1996 when Mr. Canet, who had been pushed aside in Barcelona, won a case in Federal Court in Brooklyn against Mr. Travelstead, entitling him to a share of the profits in a number of deals they had been in together over the years. (Earlier this year, he was awarded $3.15 million. Mr. Travelstead is appealing.)
Mr. Travelstead was hit with another stinging financial defeat a month later. This one grew out of the $3.2 million purchase of a 544-acre farm on the eastern shore of Maryland and a separate purchase of a house nearby, both in 1995. As part of the first deal, he gave a second mortgage for $570,000 to Timothy E. Wyman, a private investor. Mr. Wyman obtained a $1.2 million judgment and began foreclosure proceedings in May 1996 against Mr. Travelstead after he failed to repay the second mortgage.
Just days later, Mr. Travelstead filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Although the $58.7 million in assets that he listed far exceeded his $9.8 million in debts, he needed protection, he said, because the bulk of those assets could not easily be sold. Chapter 11, he contended, would give him the time he needed to arrange an orderly sale to satisfy the claims against him.
But Mr. Travelstead's financial activities were hard to track, since he initially failed to open a debtor's bank account and he said he had neither a checking account nor a credit card because his company paid all his expenses. Creditors became increasingly nervous as he filed a series of constantly evolving accounts of both the nature and the value of his holdings.
Karen Moore, the assistant United States trustee who is functioning as an impartial overseer in the bankruptcy matter, filed a motion last February to convert the case to a Chapter 7 liquidation. Ms. Moore said she had concluded that Mr. Travelstead had failed to provide "any credible financial information whatsoever." Under a Chapter 7 liquidation, a trustee would take control of all of Mr. Travelstead's holdings for eventual sale.
But in September, without issuing an explanation, Ms. Moore abruptly changed direction, agreeing to a settlement proposed by Mr. Travelstead's lawyers. The settlement stopped short of a liquidation, although it did provide for the appointment, under Chapter 11, of a so-called liquidating agent. The agent would manage the sale of assets, but only those assets that Mr. Travelstead has listed with the Bankruptcy Court.
The decision stunned the creditors committee, which included Mr. Canet; Virginia Kowalsky, Mr. Travelstead's former bookkeeper, and, until recently, Edythe Travelstead, who voluntarily withdrew. The lawyer for the committee contended in court that Mr. Travelstead's filings and testimony continued to be littered with false and misleading statements.
Mr. Travelstead had maintained, for example, that his company owned stock in a large ranch controlled by the family of Mr. Babbitt, the Interior Secretary. If the company owns the stock, it will not be part of the bankruptcy case. The stock certificates, however, are in Mr. Travelstead's name and dividends are paid to him individually. A spokesman for Mr. Babbitt said last week that he had sold his interest in the ranch to Mr. Travelstead -- describing him as "an old family friend" -- after joining the Clinton Administration.
Now, as this week's hearings approach, the issue for the creditors is whether they stand a better chance of getting paid by accepting the compromise Chapter 11 plan or by continuing to battle for a Chapter 7 liquidation. By most accounts, only the Australian properties could generate enough money to satisfy all the claims, which is what makes the hearing on the foreclosure so important. If the Bankruptcy Court decides that it does not have jurisdiction in that matter, and thus cannot forestall a foreclosure, the creditors may have lost their best shot, perhaps making a move to Chapter 7 inevitable.
Whatever happens, Mr. Travelstead appears to have given up on the international real estate game. He is not known to have any new projects. In a recent deposition, he said he was "semi-retired."
Mr. Cordish, Mr. Travelstead's childhood chum and a Baltimore-based developer who has built 33 profitable projects, says the two men have taken very different paths since their early days.
"Ware's projects are special and, ultimately, successful," he said. "I don't mean for the developer or his partners, or maybe even for the next guy in. But London today is better off with Canary Wharf, and the Barcelona project is a clear winner."
Mr. Velazquez takes a darker view.
"When I met Travelstead, he was the most charming, most intelligent individual I ever met," he said. "It turned out that of all the con men I have dealt with in my life, he is the most cunning and ruthless."

LENGTH: 606 words

HEADLINE: The Germ Warfare Threat

 BODY:
Though the crisis over Iraq's biological weapons has eased for the moment, Americans should not be complacent about the dangers of germ warfare. The threat that a lethal bacterium or toxin might be used on the battlefield or in a terrorist attack is real. The United States, from the Pentagon to local police departments, is not yet adequately prepared to deal with the danger.
It is relatively easy and inexpensive to produce biological agents like anthrax or plague, and not hard to conceal them. All it takes is a pharmaceutical plant, or a brewery. Many of the world's rogue regimes, including those in Iraq, Iran, Syria, Libya and North Korea, are working on such weapons, as are terrorist groups. 
 For aggression-minded countries or terrorists, biological weapons can seem an appealing way to offset America's overwhelming nuclear, conventional and economic power. No hostile country has yet perfected reliable means of delivering these weapons to the United States and known incidents of biological terrorism have been rare. Still, a determined country could launch a biological attack on its neighbors using missiles, artillery or aircraft mounted with spraying tanks. Terrorists could use trucks or aerosol canisters or target vulnerable food supplies. Washington and local governments across America still have much to learn about preventing or coping with such an attack.
An international convention bans the development, production, transfer and stockpiling of biological weapons. Unfortunately, the agreement lacks reliable verification or enforcement provisions, a problem the Clinton Administration is now trying to fix. But even that will not stop countries like Iraq from pursuing programs in secret, using home-grown ingredients and shutting international inspectors out of sensitive locations.
The Clinton Administration's efforts to prepare for a biological attack have been spotty, with the Federal Emergency Management Agency poorly engaged but the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Centers for Disease Control providing some helpful assistance. The Pentagon, which has done more research and spending on biological protection than any other agency, needs to do a better job of sharing its expertise and equipment with local civilian authorities. In response to pressure last year from Senators Sam Nunn, Richard Lugar and Pete Domenici, it has now begun to do so.
Most consequences of biological weapons are treatable if detected and diagnosed quickly. That requires training in recognizing unusual symptoms under intense stress. New York, Washington, Atlanta and Indianapolis have begun serious preparations for responding to biological terrorism. Most other American cities have not.
An expert panel meets regularly with New York officials to identify needs. Outside trainers provided by the Pentagon have prepared 4,000 city police, fire and emergency workers to teach coworkers how to respond to biological attacks. New York also involves hotels, transit agencies, private security firms and hospital emergency rooms in its preparations and has plans for obtaining vaccines against common biological agents. Though New York is acquiring some field kits used by American military forces to detect and identify biological agents, the Pentagon has declined to provide the most sensitive models.
New York's program is one of America's most advanced. But even it needs improvement and fuller Federal cooperation. With the use of biological and chemical weapons more likely than nuclear attack, all levels of government must work harder to protect Americans from the terrifying dangers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Giving Credit Where Debt Is Due

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
AS Frank Capra's mid-century holiday movie classic, "It's a Wonderful Life," crowds its way onto television screens, feel free to snicker at the moment when a desperate George Bailey screams at his negligent uncle for misplacing bank funds and threatening to plunge the family into debt.
"Where's that money?" he shouts. "Do you realize what this means? It means bankruptcy and scandal and prison!" 
 Scandal? Prison? How quaint. America, safe haven of the highly leveraged country and the highly leveraged corporation, is now home to the highly leveraged citizen. Debt is very, very cool.
 
Sub-Prime
Right now, consumers are firmly into debt overdrive as they pursue the annual rite of the holiday spending binge. Americans have even bestowed an affectionate new term on their credit cards: "mall money." That mall money is liberating, too. A recent survey of 1,000 consumers by the American Bankers Association found that two-thirds had no holiday spending plan, even though they typically end up taking about six months to pay off holiday debt. And these are not poor people. The same survey found that among those who were late with credit card payments, 44 percent earned more than $50,000 a year, while only 4 percent earned less than $15,000.
American consumers are carrying about $1.2 trillion in installment credit, up about 50 percent from just four years ago, and the average credit card holder has four cards and about $4,000 in high-interest debt. Nonetheless, lenders have begun to target the least creditworthy and most unsophisticated debtors-to-be, dubbing them "sub-prime" borrowers. Loan delinquencies are on the rise and personal bankruptcies continue to soar.
But hey, why worry? Even bankruptcy doesn't stop the solicitations from lenders.
Banks, which once upon a time emphasized savings and thrift, are now relentless marketers of debt -- or credit, to use the sanitized term favored by lenders. Billions of credit card solicitations compete for space in American mailboxes each year, with Banc One, MBNA, Citicorp, and Chase Manhattan jointly accounting for more than half of the volume.
Mortgages can be had for 125 percent of a house's market value, quite a repudiation of banks' traditional hesitation to lend no more than 80 percent against a home. Since late October, Fleet Financial Group has mailed more than one million blank checks in denominations ranging from $3,000 to $10,000, inviting borrowers to use the checks to pay taxes or "spruce up your home."
"What debt is doing is that it anesthetizes the purchasing process," said Stephen M. Pollan, a financial adviser and author of a new book, "Die Broke" (Harper Business). "Debt may be O.K. for a house or a car or an education, but for anything else you're an idiot. For a bottle of champagne or a new wardrobe you're going to go into debt? It's just instant gratification, a short-lived burst of fun, and it's not smart."
Debt is not the stigma it was for the generation that came of age during the Great Depression and World War II. So when did things change?
Cultural milestones are never easy to mark, but when it comes to consumer debt, Fresno, Calif., in September 1958 offers a likely one. Bank of America targeted Fresno for the first mass mailing of credit cards, as detailed by Joseph Nocera in "A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class" (Simon & Schuster, 1994). Some 60,000 credit cards flooded the mailboxes of Fresno. A little more than a year later, two million credit cards were circulating around California.
"There had been no outward yearning among the residents of Fresno for such a device, nor even the dimmest awareness that such a thing was in the works," Mr. Nocera wrote. "Here began the trickle of what we now call financial products, aimed largely at the middle class, that would become, by the 1980's, an avalanche."
Still, in the 1960's most borrowers paid off their credit card balances monthly, as an aversion to financial risk born in the Depression held sway. It would take another decade and the arrival of runaway inflation to bring consumer debt into the mainstream.
"Credit cards were the enablers but inflation was the trigger," Mr. Nocera said in an interview. "People in the late 1970's started recognizing that it made sense to go into debt because of inflation."
America's trouble with debt is nothing new. After all, Georgia was founded as a debtors' colony, and Thomas Jefferson died a debtor after a lifetime of buying binges that would have made Imelda Marcos blush.
But for many years it was only an elite few like Jefferson who could take on inordinate debt as consumers. Farmers and other debtors largely borrowed in order to produce something. Puritans and Quakers regarded excessive personal debt as a sin, views that were widely and firmly held until relatively recently. In the 1800's, the end of the year did not entail holiday shopping sprees but was a time to pay off debts to begin the new year with a clean slate and a clean conscience.
"Debt was a horror in the 19th century," said Robert Sobel, a financial historian at Hofstra University. "Mortgages were much shorter in the 19th century, only about 10 years. Burning the mortgage was a big family event. Nowadays, people don't even think of mortgages as debt."
Of course, there weren't VCR's, Timberlands or Gap jeans to covet in the 19th and early 20th centuries. But once the emotional shock of the Depression subsided and the post-World War II consumer boom occurred, Americans were primed to take a new look at debt. All they needed were credit cards and a nudge from those burgeoning inflation rates.
 
Treading Water
Now the costs are adding up. The consumer debt spigot has been wide open for the past five years and some borrowers are beginning to tread water, despite the robust economy. Several credit card companies, including such rapidly growing issuers as Advanta, have taken a financial beating after coaxing risky borrowers with low introductory teaser rates. Charge-offs for bad credit card debt have risen sharply this year at Advanta and other big credit card issuers. And if the economy slows significantly, America's penchant for debt may take an even uglier turn.
"People think about money in a certain way until a cataclysm arrives that forces them to change," said Mr. Nocera, who added that it will probably take a sharp downturn in the economy before people think it wise to lighten their debt loads.
If this makes you queasy, just turn off "It's a Wonderful Life" and tune in the Lifetime cable channel. There, every weeknight, you'll find a game show called "Debt," which gives contestants the opportunity to win enough money to rid themselves of personal debt -- uh, credit.

HEADLINE: Persian Gulf;
Iran's Venture in Image Rehab

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TEHERAN

 BODY:
IT was a kind of coming-out party, with all eyes focused on Iran as it stepped forward after nearly two decades mostly shrouded from world view. What guests glimpsed at an international Islamic conference here was in some ways infuriatingly contradictory: a poised, gracious Iran eager to leave a good impression, but one also still burning with old resentments.
But then, ever since its rebirth in the 1979 revolution, Iran has been a far more complex creature than the one depicted in Western snapshots of fiery mullahs, subservient women and legions of martyrs. And if the gathering in Teheran last week was hardly an acknowledgment that the old view had been altogether mistaken, the huge turnout suggested a willingness to entertain the hope that Iran's coming of age may bring with it more maturity. Those looking for moderation could find evidence, or not. 
 There was the inaugural address by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, heir to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as the steward of revolution, with the usual tirade against Western influence. But then came more conciliatory remarks by the new President, Mohammed Khatami, whose calls for opening Iran to the outside world have given voice to a very different dimension of Iranian political thought. And while reiterating its opposition to the United States' policies toward Israel and military role in the Persian Gulf, Iran did not push those views on others, acting more statesmanlike than revolutionary.
 
The Dissident
Washington, of course, was not invited; had it been, it would have stayed away. Alone in the world, the United States remains intent on isolating Iran, regularly denouncing the clerical regime in terms that probably rank it second to Iraq in American demonology. But some of the symbolism on display in Teheran seemed to underscore a spreading view that Iran is not only too important to ignore, but is also perhaps a country with which others can do business.
From Saudi Arabia, which has shunned Iran as a most undesirable neighbor: a drapery from the door of the Holy Kaaba of Mecca -- a remarkable gift from the capital of Sunni Muslim orthodoxy to the rival Shiite Muslim regime that remains the world's only Islamic republic.
President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey, another ally of the West, exchanged embraces with Iranian clerics who regularly criticized his government for its secular orientation and its military ties with Israel. Even Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt -- on his visit to a city that has a street named after the militant Muslim Egyptian who assassinated President Anwar el-Sadat -- said the gathering had produced "some kind of improvement in ties" between his country and Iran.
Iran, for its part, has silenced its calls for an export of the Islamic revolution that toppled the Shah and sent shock waves across the Middle East. Mr. Khatami's stunning victory last May over a candidate supported by the religious establishment showed how far democracy has come. And while Ayatollah Khamenei is still the supreme leader in what remains a mullahcracy, the support that 69 percent of Iranians gave to Mr. Khatami shows the urbane face of those who never felt a kinship with the radical clerics.
"For the first time, we can see Iran as not just black or white, but as complex and more refined," a diplomat here said. "I'm not saying they are angels, but this is not a one-man dictatorship, like Saddam's in Iraq."
One question still difficult if not impossible to answer is whether overtures like those on display last week encourage moderation or coddle the worst elements in Iran. American views have veered from one extreme to the other, with little success on either end of the spectrum. The effort to reach out to Iran reached its most absurd and embarrassing proportion with the secret arrival in 1986 of the Bible- and cake-bearing mission led by Robert McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, to which Iranian officials turned their backs. Since then, Washington's pattern has been to turn its own back on Iran until it forswears, for one thing, its support for violent opponents of a broader Middle East peace.
Iran, in turn, has said the economic sanctions imposed by the United States leave no grounds for any overture at all. But among its neighbors, Iran has begun to extend olive branches. It has played a restrained role in trying to mediate conflicts in countries like Afghanistan and Tajikistan, while working hard to promote warmer relations with American allies like Saudi Arabia and Egypt, which until recently had followed the United States in regarding Iran as something akin to the devil incarnate.
It was the dividends of those efforts that were evident here last week as Iran took the reins for the next three years of the 55-member Organization of the Islamic Conference. Not only was the international gathering the largest to be held in Teheran since the revolution, but it far eclipsed in size and prominence an American-sponsored gathering in Qatar less than a month earlier, which was marred by an Arab boycott in protest of Israel's participation.
 
Still Skeptical
Misgivings within the Sunni-dominated Islamic world of Iran's Shiite regime still run so deep that few if any of those who attended were doing so to demonstrate wholehearted support for Iran's domestic and internal policies. Many were motivated first by obligations to an Islamic organization they hope can wield increasing weight, and perhaps second by a curiosity about Mr. Khatami, a man who had been unknown to many of them. Tiny oil-rich monarchies like Kuwait and Bahrain that have embraced American military protection remained skeptical of their giant neighbor's claims that it has no hostile intentions. "There are a lot of lookers but no buyers," a European diplomat said.
But in taking a fresh look at Iran, with its 60 million people, vast territory and considerable resources, the guests saw an Iran that, at least on the surface, had taken great pains to present a post-revolutionary face.
In the lobby of the former Intercontinental hotel, which was nationalized after the revolution, a mosaic that read "Down With the U.S.A." was removed, after 18 years, during a pre-conference renovation. In its place, computers offered direct, high-speed links to the World Wide Web. In guest rooms, televisions offered satellite programming, still officially against the law in the rest of Teheran. And while Ayatollah Khamenei's speech featured a fierce condemnation of Western civilization and what he called its gluttony, carnality and greed, Mr. Khatami, by contrast, quickly pronounced himself in favor of "the establishment of dialogues" to achieve "deep-rooted understanding of the cultural and moral dimensions of other societies."
That was enough for the State Department to declare that the United States, too, would "welcome and support the idea of an open dialogue between different cultures and civilizations." But in Teheran, many foreign residents and visitors said they believed that both sides could benefit by being less oblique.
"It is an open question whether these hints of moderation are tactical or strategic," a European diplomat said. "But it is incumbent on everyone, including the United States, to watch closely and listen."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Success Taboo

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Somehow over the past two or three decades a lot of black kids absorbed the message that academic achievement was something to be shunned. Excellence in sports or the various entertainment fields was one thing, a good thing, but high marks and academic honors were something else. Academic achievement, according to this mind-bogglingly destructive way of thinking, was a white thing, and thus in some sense contemptible. The tragic result has been that in many schools across the country black kids who apply themselves to their studies are often ridiculed and at times ostracized.
A black teacher in the Bronx told me in a despairing tone that she has male students who would rather be paraded in handcuffs before television cameras than be caught reading a book. I've had many students tell me in interviews that they are afraid to raise their hands in the classroom because they don't want to repeat the experience of being laughed at for giving the correct answer. 
 A black 17-year-old girl who worked part time at a mall in Marietta, Ga., was taunted recently by high school classmates who showed up at her job to express their resentment at the high marks she was getting.
Now, and not a moment too soon, comes Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League, with an ambitious first step toward turning this madness around.
"We haven't surrounded our young people with enough opportunities to excel academically and to be recognized for excelling," said Mr. Price. "We haven't had the rituals in our own community that reward young people for doing well."
The Urban League has drawn together 20 national black organizations, including the Congress of National Black Churches, for what it calls the Campaign for African-American Achievement. The idea is to improve the academic standing of black youngsters by encouraging and rewarding excellence in the classroom, and by improving the quality of the education that is offered to black youngsters in the public schools.
A statement announcing the campaign said: "We have to reverse the increasing gap in academic achievement between African-American and other children. We have to increase the low rates of enrollment of African-American youngsters in college preparatory courses and attack the inequitable allocation of resources for public education."
There is an urgency in Mr. Price's manner as he talks about this effort. He and his colleagues recognize that black men and women will have to be substantially better prepared educationally if they are to survive economically as we move into the 21st century. Employers, as Mr. Price noted, "expect much more in the way of academic preparation than ever before." And affirmative action, however one feels about it, is almost certain to continue its fade from the scene.
The achievement campaign will try in a variety of ways to generate enthusiasm among students and parents for the hard work that is necessary to succeed academically. This will not be easy in environments that are plagued by poverty, broken families, drug abuse, violence and the widespread notion that what is taught in the classroom is not relevant to the lives of the students.
The campaign will establish an honor society, called the National Achievers Society, to focus attention on black youngsters who excel academically. The first induction ceremony, to be presided over by Gen. Colin Powell, will be held next spring.
September has been designated Achievement Month by the campaign. The plan is to have Urban League affiliates, black churches and other organizations conduct a month-long series of high-profile events each year celebrating the efforts of black youngsters who are doing well in school.
Meanwhile, leaders of the campaign are working with professional organizations and universities around the country to determine where improvements in the public schools need to be made and what specific kinds of academic help are needed for underachieving students.
This is not a perfect plan. Much of it will be modified and some of it will fail. But it does send the crucial message that academic achievement is as important for black people as anyone else. It's a message that somehow has escaped the consciousness of too many black children.

HEADLINE: In New Math Standards, California Stresses Skills Over Analysis

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Seeking to quell a bitter dispute over how best to teach math, the California Board of Education has approved a set of standards for the state's public school students that emphasizes mastery of basic computational skills over the ability to analyze and solve intricate word problems.
But the lengthy list of expectations for students in all grades, which was approved by the board in a unanimous vote on Thursday night, seems to have fanned the controversy. 
 The state's elected Superintendent of Public Instruction, Delaine Eastin, has joined a number of mathematicians in deriding the board's standards as "dumbed down" and unlikely to elicit higher-order thinking from the state's 5.5 million public school students. But others, including those parents and politicians who have complained that calculators and computers were supplanting multiplication tables and long division in many classes, applauded the board's call for a return to the fundamentals.
The standards, which districts have the option to adopt but which will serve as the basis of mandatory statewide tests, make clear that multiplication tables should be memorized by the end of the third grade, long division mastered by the fourth and the Pythagorean theorem of geometry by the end of the 10th.
Students will not be permitted to use calculators on the state tests. And districts are advised to avoid introducing computers into math classes before the sixth grade.
Because of its size, California tends to influence national teaching issues and the standards are expected to be studied closely by other districts across the country.
Janet Nicholas, a board member from Sonoma, said the board had succeeded in emphasizing basic skills "without mandating experimental curricula and counterproductive learning fads."
Nonetheless, Ms. Eastin, a Democrat who was elected state Superintendent in 1993, lamented that the final standards document provided teachers with few clues about how to make mathematical formulas come alive for students in the nation's largest public school system.
"If you give a kid in America a column of numbers to add up, and then say find a percentage of that column and add it to the total, they will get the right answer most of the time," Ms. Eastin said. "On the other hand, if you give kids a word problem in which they are told to order a meal from a restaurant menu, compute the tax and tip, and add up the bill, they are flummoxed by it."
"Math instruction, if it only emphasizes basic skills, will put us at a terrible competitive disadvantage in a global economy," she added. "We need people who can problem-solve."
The onus is now on districts to decide whether to adopt the standards, but the campaign to sway their votes has already begun.
In a letter to the board, the National Science Foundation, which has awarded more than $50 million in grants to Los Angeles, Oakland and four other districts seeking a more progressive approach to math instruction, threatened to sever its commitments to districts "that embark on a course that substitutes computational proficiencies for a commitment to deep, balanced, mathematical learning."
"The wistful or nostalgic 'back-to-basics' approach that characterizes the board standards," wrote Luther S. Williams, an assistant director of the foundation, "overlooks the fact that the approach has chronically and dismally failed."

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls for Bill to Stop Drug Overpayment

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton called on Congress today to pass legislation that would bar drug suppliers from charging the Medicare system more for prescriptions than their wholesale cost.
In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton said that clamping down on drug overpayments would save $700 million over five years. He noted that a recent report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services found that what Medicare pays for drugs "bears little or no resemblance to actual wholesale prices that are available to physicians and suppliers that bill for these drugs." 
 Under current practices, Medicare pays a "sticker price" set by manufacturers rather than the average price actually charged by wholesalers, Mr. Clinton said.
For more than one-third of these drugs, the White House said, Medicare paid more than double the actual wholesale prices.
Mr. Clinton said his proposal would be included in his budget for the 1999 fiscal year.
He also said that he had ordered a moratorium on all new home health care providers coming into the Medicare program, a revamped renewal process for home health agencies already in the system and a doubling of audits to weed out bad care providers.
In the Republicans' weekly radio address, Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska argued that the recently negotiated treaty to curb global warning would give the United Nations control over the economic growth of the United States.
"This treaty will have a devastating effect on the American economy," Senator Hagel said.
"The Republican leadership in Congress will not allow the United Nations to dictate the loss of American jobs and higher energy prices for America's families, farmers and businesses," he said.
Under the treaty, negotiated earlier this week in Kyoto, Japan, the United States agreed to reduce its emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases to 7 percent below 1990 levels by 2012.
Senator Hagel urged President Clinton to immediately send the treaty to the Senate, where he predicted it would be defeated. Mr. Clinton has decided to delay a debate on ratifying the treaty until some developing nations also agree to support it.

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops Finish Survey of Challenges to the Americas

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 13

 BODY:
A special synod of Roman Catholic bishops from North and South America convened here by Pope John Paul II has concluded a monthlong survey of the moral, social and economic challenges confronting the Western Hemisphere, from foreign debt to broken families.
The participants in this Special Assembly for America, which ended on Friday, listened to speeches, took part in workshops, prepared 76 proposals and wrote a final collective message. These will form the basis, one year from now, for a papal document on the tasks facing the church in the Americas -- home of about half the world's 1 billion Catholics -- as it approaches its 2,000th year. 
 But according to many of the bishops, the most significant result of the special synod -- one of several that will bring bishops together by geography rather than by topic over the next two years -- was the fact that they came together at all, from two continents that do not always see themselves as a single region.
"Some of the most important outcomes will be the ones that can't be quantified," said Roger Cardinal Mahony, Archbishop of Los Angeles and co-president of the synod delegates. "Borders and boundaries have fallen away, as we viewed this hemisphere as one."
At a final news conference on Thursday, other bishops discussed the novelty of addressing problems together.
"What struck me was that, despite the geographical differences, there was a brotherly community," said Archbishop Francois Gayot of Cap-Haitien, Haiti. "The synod has allowed us to meet the challenge of diversity within unity."
From bishops from Latin America came a preoccupation with the continuing burden of foreign debt on their countries, which they feel has caused profound economic and social dislocations. From bishops from North America came lessons in ecumenical sensitivity, learned on a continent where Roman Catholics have historically been in the minority and imparted to a Roman Catholic Church in South America that has long enjoyed dominance but has been alarmed by the inroads of Protestant evangelical movements.
But the 300 bishops gathered here also discovered how many problems are shared: declining vocations, single-parent families, immigration, globalized economies, securing the rights of minority groups, and what the bishops referred to as the "cry of the poor for justice."
"There are cases of injustice everywhere," said Archbishop Dario Castrillon Hoyos of Bucaramanga, Colombia. "The poor are not only in the South, but also in the North."
As many participants acknowledged, the synod's concluding message did not suggest any new departures. It was, as one bishop said, a "synod without tensions," and to some observers that suggested that the bishops were not addressing some of the more controversial issues dividing Roman Catholics. In that regard, they said, the mixing of South and North Americans may have served to dilute debate, and to produce broad generalities.
There was also criticism that the American synod, which was formally called only 14 months ago, was not as well prepared as a similar African synod, which had been in the works for four years before it convened in 1994.
The synod did hear an appeal, by Bishop Nestor Herrera Heredia of Ecuador, that the Vatican review a church policy that forbids divorced Roman Catholics who have remarried from receiving Communion.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO OFFER A CHILD CARE PLAN, WHITE HOUSE SAYS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton will soon propose a major initiative to help working families obtain child care, with a variety of new Federal subsidies and tax breaks, Administration officials say.
The purpose of the proposals, to be included in the President's State of the Union Message in late January and in his budget request a few days later, is to increase the supply of child care and to improve its quality. 
 Administration officials said that the President's proposals would include an increase in the Federal income tax credit that parents can take for child care expenses; a new tax credit for businesses that build or operate child care centers for employees, and an increase in the money that the Federal Government gives states to subsidize child care.
Although some details are not yet final, officials said that Mr. Clinton had made one firm decision: he will not propose national child care standards.
Proposals for such regulation have provoked bitter clashes in the past, with conservatives arguing that the Federal Government has no business setting standards.
Democrats said they saw child care as an excellent election-year issue. They said it appealed to voters, especially working women, and split Republicans, some of whom will be receptive to Mr. Clinton's ideas.
Since Congress adjourned for the year on Nov. 13, a bipartisan group of Senate aides has held many meetings to draft child care legislation. Moderate Republicans said they would support Democratic legislation or offer their own if the Republican leadership did not propose an alternative.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is coordinating the talks, said he hoped to submit the bipartisan proposals to Mr. Clinton before the State of the Union address.
Lawmakers see this year's experience with health insurance for children as a possible precedent. The legislation was pushed through Congress in six months, and the final package provided nearly five times as much money as the President had proposed.
Democrats hope to follow a similar timetable with child care next year. Republicans, who control both houses of Congress, want to control the child care issue, as well, but whether they can is unclear.
Conservatives on Capitol Hill said it seemed clear that Democrats and moderate Republicans would have the 60 votes needed to assure Senate approval of child care proposals like Mr. Clinton's.
The outlook is less clear in the House, where Democrats and some moderate Republicans are also pushing legislation.
In an interview, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican working with Mr. Dodd, said he expected Congress to approve an expansion of the child care tax credit next year. In addition, he said, "we can beef up the Child Care and Development Block Grant," which provides states with a total of $3 billion a year, mainly to subsidize child care for low-income families.
Rahm I. Emanuel, a senior adviser to the President, said: "Our child care proposals will help the most hard-pressed working families, who are trying to balance work and family. The proposals build on previous accomplishments, including family and medical leave, an increase in the minimum wage, a $500-a-child tax credit and the health insurance program for children."
A conservative aide to the Senate Republican leadership who insisted on anonymity said that Republicans felt compelled to offer their own proposals -- tax cuts and some Federal spending -- as an alternative to the President's ideas. Some Republicans deride the Administration's proposals as "Hillary care" because of the First Lady's interest in the issue.
White House officials said that Hillary Rodham Clinton had been more deeply involved in development of the President's child care proposals than in any issue since the health care debacle of 1993 and 1994.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's package would also include these proposals:
*A new Federal program to help states check the criminal history records of people who work in day-care centers.
*Scholarships for child care workers, to subsidize their training and increase their pay. Federal officials said they hoped that such incentives would slow the turnover of child care employees, 35 percent of whom leave their jobs in any given year.
*Legislation to require Federal child care centers to comply with all state and local laws, regulations and licensing requirements.
Civilian agencies of the Federal Government run 237 child care centers, while the Defense Department operates more than 800. Nearly 75 percent of the centers are accredited by private groups like the National Association for the Education of Young Children. Administration officials said Mr. Clinton wanted all the centers to be accredited.
The Senate has already voted to establish a tax credit up to $150,000 a year for companies that set up child care centers for employees. The proposal, offered as an amendment to this year's budget bill by Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, was approved by a vote of 72 to 28 in June. But it was later dropped in negotiations with the House.
Mr. Clinton's proposals coincide with a series of events that have heightened interest in child care.
With the unemployment rate at its lowest point in 24 years, some employers find that they have to offer child care to attract and retain workers. The new welfare law is increasing demand for child care because it requires welfare mothers to work.
In addition, the trial of a British au pair in the death of an 8-month-old boy in Massachusetts focused attention on the problems of child care.
And new scientific research indicates that brain development is profoundly affected, for better or worse, by a child's experiences in the first three years of life.
The President's Council of Economic Advisers has prepared a philosophical justification for Mr. Clinton's child care proposals. In a report to Mr. Clinton this week, the council set forth "economic rationales" for Federal intervention in the child care market, saying child care imposed "a sizeable financial burden," especially on poor families, who, on average, spend 18 percent of their incomes on child care.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is leading efforts to highlight child care as an economic issue. His chief of staff, Michael B. G. Froman, met this week with executives from Conagra, Motorola, Eli Lilly and several other companies that provide or subsidize day care for employees.
The Treasury will catalogue the experiences of these companies in the hope of encouraging other businesses to follow their example.
Charles R. Romeo, director of employee benefits for Conagra Refrigerated Foods, a unit of Conagra, said his company subsidized child care for business reasons, not as a form of philanthropy. Conagra, he said, had difficulty finding women to work at its turkey-processing plant in rural Huntsville, Ark., until it joined forces with the local Head Start agency and built a child care center.
Faith A. Wohl, president of the Child Care Action Campaign, an education and advocacy group, said, "Child care badly needs greater investment." Mrs. Wohl said that 60 percent of the money spent on child care came from parents, while 39 percent came from Federal, state and local governments and only 1 percent came from employers.
Among the Republicans most interested in child care legislation, besides Mr. Hatch, are Senators James M. Jeffords of Vermont, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Pat Roberts of Kansas. They have all sent aides to work with Senator Dodd's staff on a possible bipartisan bill.
In general, these Republicans appear ready to spend more money on child care, but do not want to tell states how to use it, and they think that states should keep responsibility for setting and enforcing standards.
Regulation varies widely among states, and in many states, large numbers of small day-care providers who operate from private homes are exempt from regulation.
Bruce Reed, assistant to the President for domestic policy, said, "We're not interested in some big Federal program directed from Washington that sets one-size-fits-all rules."
A White House lawyer said, "The Federal Government can certainly do more to encourage quality and safety in child care, but we've concluded that states are better suited to create their own standards."
Senator Dodd, a veteran of earlier battles over the issue, said: "Quality standards should be left to states and localities. I accept that." Insisting on national standards, he said, "could cause this whole effort to collapse."

HEADLINE: Man Is Arrested in Philadelphia Hate Crimes

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The authorities say they hope that with the arrest of Michael Gaither they have brought to an end a series of hate crimes over the last three years in northeast Philadelphia.
Mr. Gaither was arraigned on Friday on more than 100 charges stemming from the crimes that included arson, ethnic intimidation and causing a catastrophe. The defendant's bail was set at $2.45 million. 
 Among the accusations is that Mr. Gaither wrote a letter to the police threatening to hurt children as retribution for American atrocities in Germany after World War II.
As he was led to a police van on his way to jail, Mr. Gaither, 39, told reporters that he was not the one who put children in danger.
"How many millions of children did the United States bomb with napalm and everything else in this century?" Mr. Gaither said.
In all, Mr. Gaither is accused of leaving eight pipe bombs in and around Philadelphia, Sgt. Michael O'Donnell said. None of the bombs detonated.
Efforts to make an arrest intensified after the police received a letter last month threatening to harm children if the police did not pay $15,000 as retribution for United States actions in Germany after World War II.
"Who knows what's in these people's heads?" Sergeant O'Donnell said when asked about a motive.
Mr. Gaither, who lives with his mother in Philadelphia and is apparently unemployed, has no criminal record and had not been a suspect.
The police were led to Mr. Gaither after the department's radio room kept receiving harassing telephone calls. Investigators traced the calls to a few pay phones in one neighborhood and began staking out the booths.
On Wednesday, someone called the office of State Senator Henry Salvatore and acknowledged vandalizing the Republican Senator's office last year. The police said they traced the call and saw Mr. Gaither walking away from booth. He was arrested after a brief chase.
Mr. Gaither is also suspected of vandalizing the office Representative Robert A. Borski, a Democrat, whose office here was damaged at least three times from March and August 1996. Swastikas and the words "U.S. Out" were scribbled in black marker and a door and window were shattered.

HEADLINE: Getty Center Inaugurated in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13

 BODY:
On a brilliant, cool morning, dignitaries and celebrities including the Mayor of Los Angeles and the rock group Los Lobos presided over the inauguration of one of the largest arts centers in the country, the $1 billion Getty Center here.
The day seemed tailor-made for the event, with sunshine pouring over the acres of honey-colored marble, the modernistic buildings and the delicate fountains of the hilltop complex. The wisps of clouds made even more splendid the view the site commands of the Pacific Ocean and the San Gabriel Mountains. 
 "I have to confess we accomplished much more than I had any reason to expect," said Harold M. Williams, who has been president of the J. Paul Getty Trust since 1981.
Today's inaugural marked an important moment for Los Angeles, which has long struggled to be taken as seriously in art circles as it is in popular culture. The city has also struggled to recover from the devastation of a deep recession in the early 1990's, followed by an earthquake, sweeping fires and rioting in 1992.
With the economy here now booming, the celebrations today were an opportunity for Los Angeles to do something it is just starting to enjoy again -- feel good about itself.
In addition, the trust used the occasion to emphasize its efforts to contribute to the community rather than remain aloof, as it had been in the past. Denzel Washington, the actor, spoke this morning about the trust's role in helping children.
The campus-like Getty Center, which opens to the public on Tuesday, was designed by Richard Meier. Including its gardens, it covers 110 acres on the city's west side. The museum complex, a series of connected two-storied pavilions, contains artworks from masters like Rembrandt, Van Gogh and Walker Evans.
The collection is regarded as significant, but not encyclopedic. Nevertheless, it adds considerably to the prestige of a city whose museums have not had the breadth of the new Getty or buildings that cut such a striking architectural figure.
The opening brings to one location for the first time all the work of the Getty Trust, which consists of separate institutes for activities like research, conservation, education and museum management.
The opening also allows the museum to show its sizable collections in what have been described as some of the finest galleries built in recent years. They rely heavily on natural light.
The Getty Center, and especially the museum, is a marriage of the austere and the sumptuous. The buildings and the plaza are faced with off-white travertine marble. But the cool color scheme is offset by the rough hewn texture that has been left in some of the stone.
The outside of the museum and its big rotunda entranceway are signature Richard Meier designs, with crisp lines and a stark geometry. But the trust chose Thierry Despont, a French architect, to design the rooms in which the collection is shown. His designs are lavish, warm and colorful.
The trust on display today has come a long way since it was endowed by J. Paul Getty, an oil magnate and pragmatist who seemed more interested in the mechanics of running a good business than art.
He made his first important art acquisition in 1931, acquiring a Dutch landscape by Jan van Goyen in Berlin for $1,100.
Mr. Getty died in 1976 and gave much of his fortune, valued at about $700 million, to the trust. The endowment has grown considerably to its current level of about $4.3 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Above Los Angeles on a ridge in the Santa Monica Mountains, the Getty Center was dedicated yesterday. The center has six buildings that will contain an art collection of masterworks, a library and an auditorium. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)
