HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Big-Name Men's Wear, From a Stranger's Closet

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
LIKE many a middle-aged male who labors in a Manhattan office, Steven Greene sometimes wears Armani. Unlike many, though, Mr. Greene, a public relations executive, buys his suits second-hand at a men's wear consignment shop that knocks as much as 90 percent off the original price.
"I had never been in a men's consignment store before, and I didn't know what it was," he said. "But when I walked in -- my wife urged me to go -- there were great cheap clothes in impeccable condition." 
 Men's consignment stores are still rarities, especially compared with used-clothing stores that cater to women. The concept, however, appears to be gaining acceptance in and near a few big cities like New York, where stylish suits and natty sport jackets are common -- but expensive -- attire. At least one such shop is in Manhattan -- Gentlemen's Resale, on the Upper East Side. Another, Gentlemens Agreement, opened 18 months ago in Englewood, N.J.
"It's a great deal for men, but it tends to be only in metropolitan areas, where labels like Armani and Boss have more pull," said Alexandra Carroll, who runs a thrift store in Paoli, Pa., and is the president of the National Association of Resale and Thrift Shops. "You are not going to find it in suburban areas as much."
Many men cringe at the thought of buying used clothing, unless they are struggling through college, or are recently divorced, unemployed or otherwise down at the heels -- or in search of attire like that perfect Hawaiian shirt for a croquet party or Halloween costume.
And to some men, there is something almost unsanitary ("Yuck! That stain!) about such a purchase, though they may consent to picking up a used tuxedo for a few hundred dollars at a shop that does most of its business renting formal wear.
But attitudes can change, though slowly.
"A lot of men don't know about it," said Terry Selbert, a salesman at Gentlemen's Resale, referring to the five-year-old store on East 81st Street, between First and Second Avenues. He added that business had been so strong lately that the shop planned to move to larger quarters in the same neighborhood in February.
The appeal of a men's consignment store is obvious -- price. Mr. Greene, a relatively easy-to-fit, 42-long, bought his midnight blue, pin-stripe Armani suit for $200 at Gentlemens Agreement. The suit cost about $1,800 when new three years ago. He also bought a $1,200 Krizia Uomo for about $200.
"Men's clothing prices have gone through the roof," he said. "Who ever heard of paying $2,000 for a suit a few years go? But that's what some go for, even $3,000."
Mr. Greene has also bought about 20 dress shirts at about $10 to $12 each, a fraction of their prices when new. He draws the line, though, at neckwear. "They are a bit out of style," he said of the store's offerings.
Where do the duds come from? Many are placed on consignment by businessmen and professionals who have tired of the styles. (Mr. Greene's suits come from a wealthy gentleman in Westbury, N.Y., who wanted to remain anonymous.) Or the sellers are retiring and moving to Florida. Or they have outgrown the clothes because they have spent too much time either working out or dining out. (Generally, the sellers split the proceeds 50-50 with the store owner, who sets the prices.)
Mr. Selbert, the Gentlemen's Resale salesman, said the store sometimes received virtually new garments from people who work in the business and get them free or at a low price. He said one such suit, a Versace that sells new for $2,200, is priced at $450 at his store.
Mr. Selbert also said many men put up their old suits for consignment, rather than donating them to a thrift store, because they may think the value of such donations for tax purposes is more carefully scrutinized than in the past. They also get cash or a check on the spot, rather than a small reduction in next year's income tax.
The consignment stores lean heavily toward today's styles -- meaning that shoppers won't find geeky 80's-style suspenders or fuddy-duddy suits on the racks. The most sought-after items sound more like an Italian law firm: Armani, Brioni, Versace, Valentino and Zegna.
"They want Armani," said Toni Rusche, owner of Gentleman's Closet, a 10-year-old men's consignment shop in Houston.
OF course, a danger in buying a fashion-forward suit is that it can quickly become fashion-backward. "We don't take anything that is over three years old," Mr. Selbert said.
Sandi Zahn, a former saleswoman in the Garment District who is the owner of Gentlemens Agreement in Englewood, uses the same approach. "I don't take it if it is outdated," said Ms. Zahn, who opened her store in 1995. She also said she accepted suits only in larger, more popular sizes. "Just 40 and up," she said.
And none of the stores take ripped or stained clothing.
Ms. Zahn's best deal this month: a $2,600 Brioni suit, 42-regular, charcoal pinstripe, a couple of years old. "A steal -- $249," she says. "Won't last."
Ms. Zahn will agree to call regular customers when an item appropriate for them comes in, she said. Besides fashion-conscious executives, her customers include parents looking for clothes for their fast-growing teen-aged boys, she said. Others are high-society types in search of a cheap tuxedo. How cheap? $89.
"Same price as renting one," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sandi Zahn, the owner of Gentlemens Agreement in Englewood, N.J., helps Steven Greene accessorize a second-hand suit. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dim Asian Economies Casting Shadows in U.S.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Two freighters carrying logs from the Weyerhaeuser Corporation in the Pacific Northwest steam idly at sea near South Korea, their cargos undelivered -- perhaps undeliverable. Just as the ships approached port, the Korean buyers refused to pay for wood they no longer needed to build homes and furniture they can no longer sell while Asia's financial crisis spreads.
Tiffany, enjoying brisk jewelry sales on Fifth Avenue, is hurting in Hawaii; the Japanese tourists who normally visit and buy there are doing neither lately. And Reebok International, the shoe giant, reports that its sales to Asia's consumers are way off. Take the Rockport shoe boutique, a Reebok subsidiary, in Seoul's upscale Myondong neighborhood. With few customers to serve, sales clerks spend their time shining the shoes on display. 
 "People come in here and they realize this is an American brand and they don't buy," said Kim Myung Chal, the store manager.
Hundreds of stories like these are bringing the Asian financial crisis home to corporate America. So far, the effects have been small for most companies. Weyerhaeuser, Tiffany and Reebok may be hurting in the Pacific, but their sales worldwide are still rising. And added together, all the setbacks at worst only seem to be nibbling at the overall United States economy. Some companies even expect to profit from the turmoil by selling products in America that are ever cheaper to make in Asia with the region's falling currencies.
The national economy, in the view of many experts, is simply too big and too complex to be brought down by what has happened so far in Asia. "My line is always America has 130 million workers," said Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "You can go out there and find stories that affect a thousand companies and a million workers, and it is still not important in the larger picture."
But while the effect thus far appears to be marginal for most American companies -- a Weyerhaeuser official, for example, says the undelivered logs might cost the company several hundred thousand dollars, a pittance for a company with more than $11 billion in annual revenue -- the cumulative effect on the American economy as a whole could be harsh in the end.
Some of the damage might even show up at first as good news for consumers in the form of falling prices for Asian goods sold in America. But more Asian imports -- and they are already rising -- could swell the United States trade deficit to a damaging level and shrink American operations that make similar goods -- textiles, electronics and furniture for instance -- or push companies to move more operations abroad.
"It accelerates the move offshore; that is the bad news," said Jay Meltzer, director of Johnson Redbook Service, which compiles retail data. "And the good news is that it puts the kibosh on inflation. Every apparel company that I speak to talks of doing more sourcing offshore, and particularly now in Asia."
Many forecasters expect the Asian crisis to slow the growth of the American economy by only half a percentage point, to about 2.5 percent in 1998. But a few are talking about a decline of one percentage point, enough to cut back job creation and make the low unemployment rate edge up gradually.
The global trade agreement signed by 100 countries in Geneva yesterday -- committing them to dismantle barriers to foreign ownership of their banks and security firms -- could soften the impact on the American economy. The prospect that a Chase or a Citibank could soon take over a failing bank in Korea or Thailand might restore the confidence of foreign investors in these economies, some analysts say. The Asian currencies would then regain some of their lost value, and that in turn would reduce the pressure on American companies trying to compete with inexpensive Asian imports.
There is a more dire scenario -- that the panic in Asia becomes infectious, scaring American investors sufficiently to bring down stock prices. That would make millions of Americans feel less wealthy, undermining the consumer confidence that has sustained two years of strong economic growth.
"The Asian crisis, although a small thing, becomes the pin that pricks the stock market bubble in America, assuming there is a bubble," Mr. Krugman said.
In the meantime, the tales of damage to American businesses are accumulating. With Asians traveling less, passenger traffic on Pacific airline routes is growing at half the rate of last fall, shaving potential revenue from American carriers. Rubbermaid, which sells high-priced plastic toys in Asia, says sales are holding up surprisingly well, but they are in local currencies that translate into fewer and fewer dollars, also cutting into revenue.
Some of the hits are not so marginal. The Oracle Corporation, blaming Asia for a sharp decline in sales of the company's specialized software, saw the value of its stock decline by 29 percent last Tuesday -- a reminder that the prospect of falling profits can be deadly on the stock exchange. And in recent months, mutual funds that invest in Asian securities have shrunk in value by $5.5 billion.
Most big American companies are playing down the significance of their losses. The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, buys and sells Asian bonds, a bit of trading that cost it $160 million in October, the company said. Citibank, J. P. Morgan & Company and Bankers Trust New York have reported similar losses, and these are likely to show up in fourth-quarter results as slightly lower-than-expected profits.
"The one thing we are proud of," a Chase official said, by way of rationalization, "is that through all this turmoil, we are at least making a market in Asian securities, protecting a rich franchise for the long term."
Some companies are turning a profit unexpectedly, or balancing a loss in one area with a profit in another. The Eaton Corporation, a manufacturer of machinery controls in Cleveland, also makes rubber hand grips for golf clubs in Thailand. The grips are sold worldwide in dollars, while the costs are in Thai bahts, a currency whose rapid decline in value set off the Asian crisis last July.
"It is a short-term benefit; sooner or later inflation in Thailand will overtake the devaluation, and our costs will rise, but not right away," said Stephen R. Hardis, Eaton's chairman. Meanwhile, buyers of Eaton's machinery controls in Asia have not cut back orders, although Mr. Hardis says he is bracing for that to happen.
Western Digital of Irvine, Calif., is another case in point. Western makes most of its disk drives in Singapore and Malaysia, selling 10 percent to 15 percent in Asia and the rest in the United States and other foreign markets. Sales in Asia have fallen, but profits are rising. The disk drives are sold in dollars, while manufacturing costs are incurred in the weakening Asian currencies.
"We are on both sides of the profit and loss equation," said Duston Williams, Western Digital's chief financial officer, adding that the net result has been higher profit so far.
That equation also applies to Rockport, which makes casual shoes in China and Indonesia for sale not only in Asia -- only 15 percent of its market -- but also in the United States, which accounts for two-thirds of its sales. The Asian sales are collapsing: The owner of the Seoul store is having so much trouble selling Rockports that he intends to switch soon to a non-American brand. But the cost of manufacturing Rockport shoes is falling, while the price of shoes in America is not, at least not yet.
"We have seen a softening of our sales throughout Asia," said Kenneth Marshall, a Rockport senior vice president, "but to a certain extent the currency devaluation has been favorable to us from a sourcing point of view."
Car sales are also falling in Asia. For the Chrysler Corporation, the percentage decline is steep but the number of vehicles is relatively small: a 31 percent drop in November to 59,000 vehicles sold so far this year out of worldwide sales of 2.8 million. But pressure is growing to offset this loss by selling more cars in strong markets, particularly the United States, perhaps through discounts and price cuts that shrink profits.
That kind of pressure, multiplied across corporate America, could result in job cutbacks and slower economic growth. But many American executives are optimistic.
"The downward pressure in Asia means a greater competitive environment in North America," said Wynn Van Bussman, a Chrysler economist, "but only a temporary dent in our plans to expand across the world."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
All Quiet on Some Fronts: Selig Is Silent on Big Question

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Before Bud Selig can drop the "acting" from the unofficial title by which he has been known for more than five years, or before he can shed the label entirely, he has to decide which part of his life is tugging harder at his head and heart: his team and its park-under-construction or Paul Beeston.
"The whole world knows how Paul and I feel about each other," Selig said, discussing his relationship with baseball's still-new president and chief operating officer. The world knows, too, about Selig's love for the Milwaukee Brewers and the fascination he has with their -- his -- new stadium. 
 Beeston wants Selig to become commissioner; he feels so strongly about it, in fact, that if someone else gets the job he very likely will look for work elsewhere. He did not say that in a recent interview, but another baseball official said he has told Selig that.
"My whole feeling has been that if I could influence Bud to stay by doing my job properly and making it easier for him, then I've done my job," Beeston said. "I would love for him to stay. I have a great relationship with him. I work well with him. I have no hesitation in telling him what I think or what I think we should be doing."
Except for saying that his position has not changed, Selig is reluctant to discuss the continued speculation about him and the job of commissioner. But the same baseball official who talked about Beeston's possible departure said it has become a very powerful factor in Selig's thinking.
Selig, however, continues to interview candidates with the Colorado Rockies' owner, Jerry McMorris, who is chairman of the commissioner search committee.
"He has been straightforward with these candidates as we boil them down," McMorris said. "He's been consistent with me. I'm absolutely convinced we are moving ahead to pick a new commissioner."
McMorris, however, also sees the possibility that some owners will call on Selig to take the job.
"I think there's always a chance of a draft movement," he said. "I don't honestly believe Bud will accept even if the draft was strong enough to give it to him. He's made it clear he's not desirous of doing it. I know what I'm saying defies conventional wisdom and in baseball anything can happen."
The commissioner search has been so quiet that some people are skeptical that it is taking place. But the secrecy has held because only Selig and McMorris have been involved in the interviewing process that has reduced the list of candidates, one official said, to three.
"We have told the executive council we would be in with our recommendations at our next meeting," McMorris said. That meeting will be before the owners' quarterly meetings the middle of next month. "I could be very comfortable with several of the candidates," he said. "I haven't tried to rank them."
McMorris gave Beeston high marks for the job he has done in only a few months since leaving the Toronto Blue Jays.
"Everybody on the business side and the baseball side has appreciated having Paul there," he said. "He's in meetings, he's in there digging, he's taking suggestions, he's following up. In executive council meetings, he's coming in with things we haven't been hearing."
Beeston, a 52-year-old Canadian, is a man who loves his job. "I've never been happier," he said. "Right now the challenges are not only invigorating but they're exciting. I think it's really going to work. I have my frustrations some days, but I had frustrations when I was with the Blue Jays."
Beeston, sitting in his Park Avenue office, was talking about getting baseball back to the growth it had before the strike and moving beyond that stage. He believes Selig could be a major part of that thrust.
"I can't tell you if he'll do it," Beeston said. "I would like to think at least his actions lead me to believe that perhaps he will. But I don't know."
In his campaign to persuade Selig to just say yes, Beeston often asks him, "When are we going to end this charade?" But Selig is apparently not ready to end it.
"It's tough," said Beeston, who was the Blue Jays' president for eight and a half years. "I understand what he's going through. I went through it pulling away from Toronto. Those first two months when Toronto was playing, you wanted to be home for the home games."
Another baseball official agreed with Beeston. If anyone believes that Selig won't be the commissioner, the official said, "I'd like to sell him the Brooklyn Bridge, too."
 
The $30 Million Question
Andy Benes, meet Jody Reed.
Unless the Players Association can convince baseball's new arbitrator, Dana Eischen, that the contract negotiated by the St. Louis Cardinals with Benes's agent, Scott Boras, was concluded in a timely manner, the pitcher could be facing a future with considerably less than the $30 million he thought he had for the next five years.
Management's player relations committee maintains that the deal was reached after an extension granted to the Cardinals and Boras last Sunday night had expired. The only way the contract can survive is if the Players Association files a grievance and prevails.
Four years ago, in a different but nonetheless painful circumstance, Reed, on his agent's advice, rejected an offer from the Los Angeles Dodgers for three years and $7.8 million, a nice wage for an average infielder at that time. Reed wound up signing a minor league contract with Milwaukee that called for a $350,000 salary if he made the team. In later years, instead of $7.8 million, Reed earned $2.2 million.
 
Spoljaric the Starter?
Paul Spoljaric, meet Andy Pettitte.
Lou Piniella, Spoljaric's manager in Seattle, is the one making this introduction.
Saying he is considering the 27-year-old left-hander as a candidate for the fifth starting spot in the Seattle pitching rotation, Piniella remarked: "He's got a good arm, he's got all the pitches, all the tools to start. If a kid like Andy Pettitte can come up through the Yankee system and do as well as he has, we see no reason why Spoljaric can't do the same for us coming up through the Toronto system."
Spoljaric, who moved to the Mariners with Mike Timlin last July 31 when Jose Cruz Jr. went to Toronto, was a starting pitcher for his first five years in the minor leagues, then was converted to relief in 1995. But Piniella said he saw "flashes that lead me to think he could be a good starting pitcher."
"I'm talking about a kid who has a good arm, who's strong, that's got three quality pitches," he added. "You would assume that a young man with that type of equipment certainly can pitch well. I brought up Pettitte as a good-looking strong pitcher. Pettitte has done an outstanding job. He's one of the top pitchers in baseball right now. Spoljaric doesn't have his experience, especially as a starter, but we've always liked his arm."
 
Leaving Kansas City
 In 1996, the Kansas City Royals had the weakest offense in the American League, so last winter they acquired Chili Davis, Jeff King and Jay Bell, then added Dean Palmer to their lineup just after midseason. The only member of that quartet who remains is King. The others have departed as free agents, taking with them 27 percent of the Royals' 1997 run production and 38 percent of their home runs.
 
Red Sox's New Attitude
 The Boston Red Sox masqueraded as a small-market team a year ago when they failed to offer Roger Clemens enough money to keep him from defecting to the Toronto Blue Jays. Now they have broken the bank -- theirs and everyone else's -- and created a new economic plateau by giving Pedro Martinez $75 million for six years.
The stunning signing prompted one baseball official to lump the Red Sox with some other teams and call the group "the five biggest hawks in baseball." The official referred to the hard-line position the Red Sox, the two Chicago teams, Atlanta and Florida in the marathon labor dispute and their subsequent contributions to the surging salary scale.
The White Sox gave $11 million a year to Albert Belle, the Marlins $10,166,667 to Gary Sheffield, the Cubs $10,625,000 to Sammy Sosa, the Braves $11.5 million to Greg Maddux and now the Red Sox $12.5 million to Martinez.
The $17.5 million salary called for in the option year of Martinez's contract (it would be for 2004) is the largest single-season salary to appear in a baseball contract. Previous high: $12.5 million for Maddux in 2001 and 2002.

HEADLINE: Union Tied To PRI Facing Ouster at Site In Tijuana

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Korean owners of a Tijuana factory have agreed in principle to cut ties to a government-controlled union with which they had signed a secret contract and to recognize an independent union formed by plant workers. The effects of the preliminary accord could reverberate through thousands of manufacturing plants across Mexico.
The preliminary agreement, which caps a turbulent six-month organizing drive, would, if formalized in legal documents, decertify a union affiliated with Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. Executives at the Han Young truck chassis plant had signed a "protection" contract with the union affiliated with the PRI under which skilled welders were paid 85 cents an hour and blocked from forming their own union. 
 Jubilant union organizers, as well as officials of the Baja California state government and Han Young management, announced the preliminary accord late Friday. But today the same people said that a last-minute dispute had arisen over whether a state official would add his name as a guarantor or only as a witness, delaying signing of the five-page agreement. It was not immediately clear whether the delay put the accord at risk.
An agreement would be historic, labor organizers said, because never before have workers in any of Mexico's 2,700 tax-free maquiladora assembly plants succeeded in forming an independent union with no ties to the main government-controlled labor federations.
"This is a historic victory for our movement," Enrique Hernandez, an independent organizer who worked with the Han Young strikers, said in an interview Friday. "For the first time, workers in a maquiladora plant have won a fight to choose the kind of union they want."
In a statement, Han Young de Mexico S.A., a contractor for Hyundai Precision America, which makes tractor trailers, said: "In the end, the goal of every company based on foreign investment is production. Han Young has no objection to free labor association. The company will accept the union representation that the workers choose."
After American supporters of the Han Young workers called a boycott of Hyundai automobiles on Oct. 22, there were demonstrations in front of Hyundai dealerships in 25 American cities.
Mary Tong, director of the San Diego Support Committee for Maquiladora Workers, said she would send an E-mail message to a nationwide network of trade unionists and other sympathizers calling off the boycott once the accord is signed.
Alejandro Monraz Sustaita, deputy legal director for Baja California's state government, who mediated the 12 days of negotiations, said late Friday that the accord was backed by the state government but was not legally binding.
He said Han Young management had agreed to recognize the new union and reinstate several workers dismissed during the long dispute, paying them back wages. The workers committee agreed to withdraw several unfair labor practices suits, he said.
The state government has pledged to used its influence to insure that a state labor panel officially recognizes the new union early next year. The new union is to be called Unidad Obrera, or Worker Unity.
Government mediators urged Han Young executives to come to terms with the striking workers "to resolve a conflict that was getting out of hand," Mr. Monraz said.
Several Han Young welders said on Friday that they were abandoning a hunger strike, called to protest both the dismissal of 12 of the plant's 119 workers and what they have called a fraudulent Oct. 6 union election. But on Saturday they said they would not break their 23-day fast until the agreement was signed.

HEADLINE: December 7-13;
Default by Korea Feared

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
It is nail-biting time in South Korea as the nation's former miracle economy edges toward possible default on foreign debt. A record-breaking $57 billion bailout led by the International Monetary Fund failed to restore confidence in the Korean economy because foreign investors doubted the nation would seriously undertake reform of its debt-ridden financial system. 
 The South Korean currency, the won, went into a free fall. A credit squeeze sent businesses large and small scrambling to obtain funds merely to finance their day-to-day operations. By the end of the week Seoul was searching for new ways, and new money, to ward off a default that some analysts think could trigger a domino effect, hurting Japan and ultimately the United States. HEADLINE: Albright Says South Africa Is a Model for Ties With U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today held up the United States' relationship with South Africa as an example of the type of ties it wants with countries across Africa.
The theme of Ms. Albright's weeklong tour of sub-Saharan Africa has been developing new partnerships with new leaders who embrace democratic reforms instead of the repression of the past. 
 "Nowhere is that truer than in our relationship with South Africa," Ms. Albright said, adding that the United States should "lecture less and listen more" and focus on economic development and trade rather than aid.
Ms. Albright, who met first with Deputy President Thabo Mbeki and then separately with President Nelson Mandela, said, "We couldn't find problems." Mr. Mbeki agreed during a joint news conference and joked, "We tried to look for a few problems this morning and we didn't find any."
Nonetheless, the United States has been displeased with two visits that Mr. Mandela made to Libya to see its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, this fall. The two countries also have different ideas about the best approach to the Sudan, which is on the United States terrorist list. Earlier this week, Ms. Albright met with Sudanese opposition leaders and encouraged them to work together against the Islamic Government. South African leaders have taken a more neutral stance.
On another issue, South Africa initially balked at American-backed plans to train an all-African peacekeeping force, saying that African nations should lead the effort.
Mr. Mbeki is expected to be elected next week to succeed Mr. Mandela as head of the African National Congress, and he is likely to become President in 1999. And Mr. Mandela, by Ms. Albright's side, told her he would soon be playing second fiddle.
Mr. Mandela, was a political prisoner for 27 years before his release, which led to the transformation of South Africa. Ms. Albright said of him, "I stand in the presence of one of the great men of our century."
Asked about Libya, Mr. Mandela said he had invited Colonel Qaddafi to visit him in South Africa. Ms. Albright dismissed the topic, saying it was best handled in diplomatic circles.
The United States and South Africa are both trying to end the continuing violence against refugees in Rwanda, where 500,000 Tutsi were killed in a 1994 massacre by Hutu extremists.
They also are working to urge President Laurent Kabila of Congo, who met with Ms. Albright on Friday, to insure democratic reforms. Mr. Kabila took power in May after ousting Mobutu Sese Seko, whose dictatorship lasted three decades.
"We are of the same mind," Mr. Mbeki said, calling for the "cultivation of a culture of democracy and respect for human rights" across the continent.

HEADLINE: Asia's Surrender

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
For a decade, Asia's rising wealth has given the region's leaders the confidence to shrug off American demands that Wall Street powerhouses, huge foreign banks and insurance companies be granted full access to their markets.
But if money talks, the absence of money screams. And early this morning in Geneva, in the most vivid example yet of how Asia's sudden reversal of fortunes may also shift the world's financial balance of power, countries that only two years ago balked at concessions bowed to most of Washington's demands to open their financial markets to global competition. 
 It may take years before trade experts and economists can measure the impact of the 102-nation financial accord that was initialed in Geneva, committing countries to open up their financial markets starting in 1999. Like the global-warming agreement that emerged this week in Kyoto, Japan, the economic effects defy neat charts and graphs.
But the political significance was clear. When investors were clamoring for the right to pour money into Asia, the region's governments could set rules that clearly favored local companies and political favorites. Now that they are desperate to attract those investors back, they are suddenly eager to listen to the complaints of institutions like Citibank and New York Life -- which have chafed for years at rules that restrict their right to buy up local banks or sell life insurance to a burgeoning middle class.
"These are negotiations that have been going on for years, and we've had to try to wear down governments one at a time," Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, said today after a long night of last-minute negotiations with Japan and Malaysia, both of which balked at letting American insurance companies go head-to-head with their own. "But it clearly helped that, in the end, they knew that they would compound their own problems if they sent a message that they would continue to close off parts of their markets to foreign investors."
Considering the smoking wreckage of collapsed financial institutions in Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and Japan, everyone at the table in Geneva feared that failure to reach an accord might send another shock to markets around the world. And in the end, some of the biggest concessions came from countries that have been forced to turn to the International Monetary Fund and to the United States for emergency financial aid, in hopes of restoring enough stability to their battered currency and stock markets to convince Western investors to come back.
"The difference from just two years ago," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said today with considerable understatement, "is that in many countries the problem has shifted from managing capital to attracting capital." He was referring to the American decision in 1995 to scuttle an earlier version of this agreement rather than accept far less generous concessions from Asian countries that wanted to keep their markets closed.
Clearly, the deal struck today under the auspices of the two-year-old World Trade Organization fell far short of a clean win for Washington or Wall Street. American negotiators got much less from some nations than they had hoped, though by threatening to walk away from the table again they forced several countries -- notably Japan -- to make major last-minute concessions.
"If you let me draft the agreement, it would say that American companies could hold 100 percent of all their subsidiaries overseas," said Gary G. Benanav, the chairman of New York Life Worldwide Holdings, in a briefing at the White House today. "Obviously, it doesn't say that. But it's very good."
Indeed, just as many of the countries that a few months ago relished the label of "big emerging markets" were under pressure to strike a deal, so were Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Ms. Barshefsky. If the United States once again scuttled the accord because foreign market opening offers were insufficient, American officials feared they might worsen the financial instability that they are struggling to contain. And Ms. Barshefsky was clearly concerned that walking away from an accord could fuel the growing perception that the United States is using its status as the world's sole superpower to dictate how other nations must run their economies.
Resentment of American economic power is already palpable around the globe these days. And already there have been accusations that the United States, operating behind the scenes at the I.M.F. headquarters a few blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House, has insisted on a laundry list of market-opening concessions from countries in return for a financial lifeline.
"There is a real risk of the revival of anti-Americanism," Clyde V. Prestowitz, Jr., the president of the Economic Strategy Institute, said here on Friday. "People all over town feel that they have to tread lightly, because the backlash next year could get pretty ugly."
Still, the United States clearly sees a chance to use Asia's crisis to score some economic points and some philosophical ones as well. A senior Administration official noted that "these are countries that for two decades have followed the Japanese model -- keep a tight control on your financial institutions and you control your economy."
Now, he said, "they have discovered the dark side of that strategy," the risks of ignoring sound financial practices like lending money to good borrowers -- instead of good friends.
The crisis in Korea, which worsened considerably this week, is perhaps the most vivid instance yet of how sloppy lending practices, cronyism and a closed financial system can lead to disaster.
Now several of the countries that were nurturing their own securities industries and banking empires -- hoping to build them into world powerhouses, as Japan did from the 1960's through the late 1980's -- are suddenly far more interested than they were a few months ago in bringing in major American and European companies. Those companies, they hope, will bring with them a fairly steady stream of capital.
Not everyone is on board. South Korea, for instance, has long kept a ceiling on the stake foreigners can hold in a securities company, and its negotiators barely budged in these talks, chiefly because their crisis-riddled Government was trying to keep the country out of default. But American officials seem confident that as part of the conditions for international aid to Korea, the country will discover that it has no choice but to open up.
The question hanging over the Clinton Administration, however, is whether its power to force future trade deals could be short-lived.
Congress has refused to grant Mr. Clinton negotiating authority, largely because of Democrats suspicious that most traditional trade deals end up working against the United States. It will be hard to make that case with this accord, because the American financial market is already wide open. But the Administration hopes to make the case that in areas where America holds a clear competitive edge -- especially in services like high finance -- it is foolish not to participate in the writing of new global rules.
"The rules are getting written with us or without us," Ms. Barshefsky said this week. "But I've never known a foreign country that voluntarily wrote the rules in a way that would be favorable to American interests."

HEADLINE: Economic 'Flu' Isn't Asia's Alone

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You should consider dropping the "Asian flu" metaphor from accounts of the financial crisis ("Many Players, Many Losers," Business Day, Dec. 10). 
 To suggest that a mysterious virus is to blame seems culturally condescending and is also wrong. This debacle originated in New York as well as in Jakarta, Bangkok, Seoul and Tokyo.
A more accurate metaphor would evoke psychological disorder. It afflicted global bankers and financiers, both American and foreign. Their lending and investing gradually became unhinged from the economic reality, as soaring returns fostered delusions of invincibility. This binge ended abruptly, as manias do. Their borrowers are smashed. Naturally, the lenders are depressed.
The United States and the International Monetary Fund propose to make them feel better by rescuing those creditors from their mistakes. Our United States credit (and tax money) will replenish failed borrowers so that they can pay back the notes held by our worried bankers. So bankers will start lending to them again. This is a bizarre approach to therapy; it rewards the patient for his own reckless illusions.
I do observe one form of "contagion" in the present crisis. It's a virus called self-doubt, which appears to be spreading among the usual cheerleaders for global finance. This is a healthy sign for the rest of us.
 
WILLIAM GREIDER
Washington, Dec. 10, 1997
 
The writer is the national editor of Rolling Stone magazine.

HEADLINE: Math Acceleration Should be Nurtured

 BODY:
I was appalled to read about the stance taken by the Garden City school administrators re: the Wertis child's request to get credit for a math course in which she received 100 on the New York State Regents exam without having taken the course, and similarly having her language endeavors impeded. "Student Denied Credit in Math Acceleration," Nov. 23.
As a Garden City resident and mother of four, I am aware that we've gone through many administrative changes in the last few years, but I can't believe that our community would endorse such educational malfeasance. An educator's job is to educate, not to hold back; every teacher's responsibility is to take each child as far as she can go intellectually. I also can't believe that any administrator would really countenance a child's sitting a full year in a class provably beneath that child's ability. I, as a parent, certainly understand the Wertis family's rage. 
 This incident doesn't necessarily represent the whole picture in Garden City. In a similar situation, one of my high school-aged daughters was allowed to test out of basic or intermediary courses in Spanish, math, economics, and also given the option to take a year of Independent Study with an English teacher rather that the standard advanced placement course.
Some children are unbelievably self-motivated; holding them back would be impossible.
Given the encouragement, such children will plot out their own areas of discovery -- as long as they have caring adults who give them opportunities to pursue their intellectual explorations. The reality is that society needs just such children to move forward.
 
BARBARA STEINMAN
Garden City

HEADLINE: It Is Better to Give Than to Receive

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus is a contributing writer to The New York Times Magazine and the author of "Interview," a collection of Q. & A.'s.

 BODY:
On a recent saturday, vartan gregorian, the president of the Carnegie Corporation, pointed to a solid wall of books in his new office that had just arrived from his old one. "For the first few months I was here, I had empty shelves," Gregorian said. "All my books were still at Brown University. It was unnerving to greet people in such a bare room. But now I can settle in. Even the most elegant room feels empty without books."
It doesn't take long to discern that books are at the center of Gregorian's life. As a boy in a provincial town in Iran, Gregorian, now 63, first absorbed a sense of the wider world at the library, reading novels in Armenian and Persian. In 1956, when he landed in New York as a scholarship student, the first institution he visited was the Public Library on 42d Street, which astounded him as "this grand building where you could look at any book you wanted without presenting your identity papers." 
 After getting a Ph.D. from Stanford, Gregorian wrote his own book, "The Emergence of Modern Afghanistan 1880-1946: The Politics of Modernization." He went on to teach at the University of Texas and at the University of Pennsylvania, where he became the dean of Arts and Sciences and, eventually, the provost.
In 1981, Gregorian took over the presidency of the New York Public Library, which was then a decaying, underfinanced and demoralized institution. He brought high-profile leadership to the library, initiating programs to restore its books, its buildings and its standing at the center of New York's cultural life. That accomplished, he moved on to the presidency of Brown. And now, at Carnegie, he'll manage an endowment of about $1.5 billion, to be spent on education and world peace. He is also planning to write a book with the working title, "The Concept of the Educated Person From the Renaissance to the Present."
Q: Now that you're a donor rather than a fund-raiser, do you have any insights on whether it's better to give or to receive?
Vartan Gregorian: Oh, I think it's better to give. Much better. Since coming to Carnegie, I'm beginning to understand St. Francis of Assisi's dictum that it is in giving that we receive -- the receiver finishes the task that the giver has begun. It's something like, when a reader reads a book, he finishes the work started by the author.
Q: People say that you've been a grandmaster of receiving. David Rockefeller tells a story of how you once raised $2 million from him on a day that he hadn't planned on giving anything.
A: It was three million. Brooke Astor, Dick Salomon and I went to see him for the New York Public Library. And I was not supposed to make the solicitation. But -- can you imagine me saying this? -- I jumped in with, "Relax, David. I'm not going to ask you for $10 million, only 3." And he did give three million. A year later, at a dinner, he put his arm around me and said, "Thank you, Greg, for saving me $7 million." And you know, all these years it has bothered me: would I have gotten $10 million if I'd asked?
Q: What makes you such an effective fund-raiser?
A: The fact that I -- this David Rockefeller story aside -- seldom ask for money. I appeal to people's intellect and social conscience rather than to their guilt and their vanity. Second, I'm not an ideologue -- I don't ask people to give to ideological causes.
Q: Is there a seamy side to fund-raising?
A: Not for a good cause. Now, what I do find hard is that you sometimes try to please a donor by suppressing your own views. There have been times when I refused to try to raise funds from one or two people because I didn't respect them. These were very rich people without integrity or moral standing. Also, when I was president of the New York Public Library, there were several politicians I wouldn't go to for help, because they were the most arrogant sorts of people, and I was afraid I might hurt the institution by going after them -- no, I won't name them here.
Q: One Brown alumnus, Ted Turner, recently shook the philanthropic world by pledging a billion dollars to the United Nations. What was your take on his action?
A: That it was very important. Before Ted Turner announced his billion-dollar gift, he asked me, "What's the biggest gift ever given?" I told him, "If you have to ask, you can't afford it." He said, "Well, how about a billion?" I told him, "A billion isn't what it used to be."
After he made the announcement, Ted Turner came to see me. He told me that I was responsible for his giving in general -- because I initiated him in the art of giving. He said, "The first check I wrote to Brown, for 25 million, my hand was shaking. Now it doesn't shake anymore."
What Ted Turner has done is raise the national bar for giving -- along with Walter Annenberg and George Soros, both of whom have really provided enlightened leadership in philanthropy. Turner thinks that instead of having the Forbes 400 richest people, they should print the 400 most generous people.
Q: Who would be on your personal list?
A: Brooke Astor. Because she had the idea that her husband's wealth was made in New York and she would give it in New York, and she did not give it abstractly: she has visited every project she has funded. The Rose brothers, Fred and Dan Rose -- they also give to New York because their wealth was made here. Walter Annenberg -- he raised the bar because he has given away more than $2 billion. Ted Turner, in terms of the environment and the use of CNN to raise consciousness. The late Richard Salomon, who used to say, "You have to give until it hurts." Irene Diamond -- she had so much impact on helping to solve AIDS. Agnes Gund, who gives anonymously if she can. David Rockefeller -- the public part of what he's done is the tip of the iceberg.
Barbara Goldsmith, the writer, has organized a group of publishers and 100 writers to sign a declaration that they will publish only on acid-free paper. This was a tremendous thing for libraries everywhere. The Gottesman sisters -- the three of them and their spouses have been tremendous to the library, the Jewish Museum and other institutions. Randolph Hearst, and his corporation. Very quietly, he's put a major effort into improving the schools in Bakersfield, Calif.
Q: I notice that the richest man in America is not on your list -- Bill Gates. In fact, he's long been criticized for not being philanthropic enough. Last summer, though, he announced that he was giving American public libraries some $400 million in cash and software so that they can be connected to the Internet. Did you have anything to do with this gift?
A: Three years ago, I went to see him about providing a digital reference library to American high schools. I explained how doing that would eliminate the class distinction of rich school districts having access to these materials while poor ones don't. I spent two hours with him and did not hear anything except some voice-mail message to the effect of, Why don't you be a pro bono adviser to me, like you are to Walter Annenberg?
Q: Aha, so that's the secret of Bill Gates's success: you go to him for money, and he asks you to work for him for free.
A: Something like that. Recently, though, I got a fax saying that he'd like me to be a trustee of his foundation and that this money would be for public libraries rather than school libraries. And I am happy to tell you that I've been to a trustees meeting, and the first place this gift is going to is libraries in Alabama, one of the poorest states in the country.
Q: About your new job: the Carnegie Corporation has two primary missions -- education and peace. Your predecessor, David Hamburg, emphasized education. Will you also?
A: Hamburg did both. I've just begun to settle in, so I can't give you too many concrete plans. I can describe areas of interest, though. Overall, I'd like Carnegie to do things that nobody else is doing now, but I'd also like to promote cooperation with other foundations.
The way I see it is, if Soros is studying the Russian economy and Bertelsmann is studying Soviet military demobilization and Carnegie is studying Russian nuclear waste, why can't we issue a single report and call it "Russia in the 21st Century"? This way everyone can get credit and we can also have a bigger impact and get some debate going.
I'm very worried about Russia, with its tremendous nuclear arsenal, unpaid military forces, impoverished scientists.
Q: But what can a foundation do? You're not the State Department.
A: I think, for instance, we could pay some attention to the universities of the former Soviet Union. In many regions of Russia, they are still using Soviet textbooks. Professors have become part-time entrepreneurs. Higher education has almost completely collapsed. This is one area where the various American foundations can act. We won't act as lobbyists, but we can educate people.
Q: What about domestic American concerns?
A: Again, I can give you an outline of issues that attract me. Campaign-finance reform, immigration, the role of technology in the future of the teaching of the liberal arts, telecommunications policy are a few areas.
And the education of journalists. Journalism schools are teaching journalistic techniques rather than subject matter. Journalists should be cultured people who know about history, economics, science. Instead they are learning what is called nuts and bolts. Like schools of education, journalism schools should either be reintegrated intellectually into the university or they should be abolished.
I'm also interested in the aging of America. In a few decades, one in four Americans will be 65 or over. All the entertainment and all the cultural programming is done primarily for teen-agers and the middle-aged. The elderly are considered a health factor, but no one is paying attention to their cultural and educational needs.
Q: The former Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander now heads a private organization called the National Commission on Philanthropy and Civic Renewal, which issued a report criticizing the large foundations for pushing what he terms "broad social theories" instead of concentrating on "well-defined, concrete problems." His basic point was that the big foundations are nothing more than agents of big government.
A: I don't agree with him. Foundations were created to do things that government could not. And that's the way it ought to be.
Q: As government spending for domestic social programs has declined, there's been a call for private charity to fill the vacuum.
A: Foundations can only study and serve as catalysts. Their function is to stimulate, assist, ask questions and risk being critical. They cannot replace ongoing, sustained national commitments. For example, education in America is something like a half-trillion-dollar-a-year enterprise. We're talking about each foundation perhaps giving a billion or two. That won't even pay for the olive in the martini.
Q: Some people in the foundation world are saying that you're going to put a lot of Carnegie money into conflict resolution. True?
A: Well, that is a great interest of mine. One particular concern I have is the way some religious authorities are using secular powers to advance religious causes. And I'd like to see if there couldn't be more dialoguing among theologians of the various faiths so that every argument doesn't turn into a political argument but remains a theological dispute. I'd like to see more discussions with leaders of the three faiths that have Abraham at center stage -- Jews, Christians, Muslims. As an Armenian Catholic, I'd be interested in seeing why everyone is always emphasizing where they differ rather than where they have things in common.
Q: You grew up in the part of the world where religious conflict is intense.
A: I was born in Tabriz, in Iran. If you saw "Cinema Paradiso," that was my childhood -- there were two movie houses and the films changed every six months. We saw footage of Stalingrad and El Alamein in the newsreels, half a year after the events took place. However, the war came home to us in tremendous shortages. My mother died in 1941, when I was 6, from an infection because there were no medicines available.
The Armenian Apostolic Church -- where I was an altar boy -- and the local library were the only outlets for me. At the library, I read anything I could get my hands on, in either Armenian or Persian. Books were my treasures, because other than the church liturgy, they were the first signs of color I saw. Tabriz was a place on the sidelines of history, and it was oddly colorless.
Q: Don't people make lovely rugs in Tabriz?
A: Yes, and to this day people think that because I'm Armenian and come from Tabriz, I'm a great expert on rugs. They always say, "I have a beautiful rug -- I'd like your opinion." And I say, "I know little about carpets." And they say, "Oh, don't be bashful." So I go, turn the rug over, scratch the back of it and declare, "Magnificent!"
Q: Let's talk about the job you've just left. You were the president of Brown for eight years. Can you give us your valedictory to the life of a modern university president?
A: The country expects universities to defend civilization, provide leadership, keep the national memory alive, overcome all social problems and do everything that the family and the church haven't done. The modern university president has to build consensus, raise funds, deal with 10,000 laws and regulations and all the while keep the students, faculty and alumni happy. And you must do all this without ever losing your temper. And also without being controversial.
I found it very tough to not be able to express my own opinions freely. You had to be an exemplar, and you could never make mistakes. Another problem was not having any time to lead a contemplative life. On the other hand, there were so many joyful moments with the students. Graduation exercises, for instance. And then, every year you get 2,000 new students to educate. And I love that.
Q: But you found your nonacademic responsibilities draining?
A: The area of sexual mores, which university administrations are often being asked to adjudicate -- now, that was a problem. There weren't many cases like that, but when something did happen, it took up all your energy.
A lot of times it's one person's word against another's. How do you deal with that? Date rape is very problematic, especially if both parties use alcohol, which happens often.
I had to deal with one case, for instance, that had come all the way up to my level. A couple had sex off-campus and the issue was whether the second time was authorized or not. The woman said she didn't remember the second incident on the same night -- so it couldn't have been consensual. That shocked me. Because if the first incident on the same night is consensual, what is the second time? I do believe that no means no. But with this case I felt, Why are you bringing this to me?
Q: One of the big fault lines in higher education is over affirmative action. What's your position?
A: I think affirmative action is necessary, at least at this stage in our history. At Brown, we did have a program for women in engineering. If two applicants were equally qualified, we would admit the woman because we wanted to encourage women in this area.
In the end, affirmative action at the university level isn't even the answer. What is needed is to reform public education in order to eliminate the social disparities. How long will we need affirmative action? As long as K through 12 education is unequal and weak.
Q: Of all the jobs you've held in your lifetime, which was the most important to you?
A: The New York Public Library. When I got there, the library was in great decline. Yet there was no way New York could lose it. My approach was that if I failed to renew it, it would be a great martyrdom. If I succeeded, it would be a miracle.
There were wonderful people who made success possible, like Andrew Heiskell, the chairman, and Brooke Astor. The first thing we did was get rid of an ad campaign that showed the library being turned into a parking lot. Nobody wants to give to an institution that's in danger of becoming a parking lot.
Then we cleaned the front of the building, air-conditioned the library, renovated and modernized it and built hundreds of miles of stacks -- veritable catacombs -- under Bryant Park, adjoining the library. Bryant Park was a center of crime and drug dealing. One way to clear away the drug dealers was to put a fence around the library. This was the best $80,000 we ever spent. We blocked one corner for two years and it changed the path of drug dealing. Bryant Park was also dirty and bare. People stole the flowers and shrubbery. So we sent a bouquet to the Police Commissioner with a note: "These are the last flowers that will ever be seen in Bryant Park." He was so impressed -- the man had never gotten flowers at the police station before -- that he assigned eight officers to protect the shrubbery.
Q: Will you be able to be as much of a showman at Carnegie?
A: I'm not a showman. I'm a missionary and a public witness -- for a cause, a message, an institution. Let me illustrate. At the New York Public Library, I got sick of hearing about how bad all our schools were. So I said, "Why don't we celebrate at least the valedictorians of the public schools." I invited each valedictorian to Astor Hall and afterward had their collective picture taken on the steps of the library. It dramatized their excellence. And gradually, the politicians thought that they should be present in that picture. Soon you had borough presidents and city councilmen showing up for the ceremony. And this built support for the library. Is this showmanship -- or focusing attention on a good cause?
Q: Do you have a sense of what you would like written on your tombstone?
A: No, but I always joke that I'd like to be buried in those 90 miles of book stacks that we built under Bryant Park. It's quiet, and people will leave me alone. Besides, it's fully paid for. Anne Getty contributed more than a million dollars for the topsoil over those stacks.

It was Mr. Rockefeller's father, David Rockefeller, who donated $3 million to a fund-raising campaign Mr. Gregorian ran for the New York Public Library.

HEADLINE: In Poll, Americans Reject Means But Not Ends of Racial Diversity

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
As the national debate over affirmative action intensifies, most Americans today endorse the goal of racial diversity in schools and offices, but reject some of the main methods used so far to achieve it, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.
In a survey marked by ambivalence and tangled views, a majority of Americans did not want to end affirmative action immediately, as many politicians have proposed, but did oppose the idea of making hiring and admissions decisions based on race. 
 Even as they criticized preferences based on race and gender, however, Americans seemed eager to support affirmative action based on economic class. Majorities of both blacks and whites said they favored policies that give specific preferential treatment in college admissions and employment to people from poor families over those from middle-class or rich families.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is consistent with a decade of previous polling on this issue. When the Times/CBS survey first began asking about racial preferences in 1985, Americans were evenly divided. But opinion turned overwhelmingly against racial preferences in the late 1980's, was particularly hostile toward them in the recessionary years of the early 1990's and has remained negative ever since.
The new poll also highlights the political land mines around this issue. Opponents of affirmative action are aggressively promoting measures in state legislatures and in referendum efforts that would ban the practice. But in general, the survey suggests that Americans are not so much inclined to abolish affirmative action as to search for a new but elusive middle ground.
Many people of both races said they were uncomfortable with the ways that affirmative action had been made into such a divisive matter, and they often tended to fault politicians for drumming the issue. Black respondents, however, were more likely to say that affirmative action was needed to redress bias in society, while whites were more likely to say that banning it was a positive step toward eliminating that bias.
"The whole issue is just another wedge tool used by the politicians," said Sylvester Haywood, 43, an insurance broker in Gary, Ind., who is black. "If everything was truly equal, if people could deal with each other on a rational level rather than on whims and emotions, of course, we wouldn't need affirmative action. But it's not."
But Barbara Elias-Baker, 51, a retired research chemist in San Francisco, who is white, said that while she supports "an extra effort in providing training programs for minorities," she believes that preferences based on race are divisive and unfair. "Quotas are not the way to deal with the problem of unemployment in minority neighborhoods," Ms. Elias-Baker said. "I've seen several cases where promotions were given to a Hispanic or a black and the candidates were on equal footing."
Both black and white Americans say that diversity is important in the nation's universities and workplaces and that they favor "special efforts" to help racial minorities compete. But asked if they supported policies that offer specific preference to qualified applicants based on skin color, strong majorities of whites said no, while the opinions of blacks varied significantly depending on how the question was phrased.
Reflecting the modern politics of race, the survey did not find wide differences in attitudes toward ending affirmative action based on what region people lived in. But it did find differences based on education and income. For instance, whites with a college degree were more likely to favor abolishing affirmative action (by a margin of 57 percent to 34 percent) than those with a high school degree or less (31 percent favor abolishing, 51 percent oppose). Similarly, those with annual incomes above $50,000 were much more likely to favor abolishing affirmative action than those who make $30,000 a year or less.
The Times/CBS poll, a nationwide telephone survey of 1,258 adults, was conducted Dec. 6 to 9. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
The poll results also indicate that the issue of affirmative action, much like abortion, is particularly sensitive to semantics.
Black and white respondents tended to give similar answers to a hypothetical question about college admissions, in which a school can choose only one candidate between white and black applicants who are equally qualified. Asked whether the black applicant should be admitted to help achieve more racial balance in the college, clear majorities of both races -- 69 percent of whites and 63 percent of blacks -- said no, that race should not be a factor in the decision.
But there was a wide disparity between the races on a related question: "Do you believe that where there has been job discrimination against blacks in the past, preference in hiring or promotion should be given to blacks today?" Whites still said no to this question, by a margin of 57 percent to 31 percent. But 62 percent of blacks answered yes, while 23 percent said no.
 On the other hand, strong majorities of both races said they would favor "special educational programs to assist minorities in competing for college admissions."
Recent referendums have also offered contradictory readings on the public mood, and differences in wording may be at least partly responsible. In California last year, voters approved a measure banning the practice, in an initiative that was couched in language making any sort of "preferential treatment" in state-sponsored programs illegal. But in Houston last month, voters decisively said no when they were simply asked whether they wished to end the city's affirmative action programs in city hiring and contracting.
With some minor exceptions, the latest Times/CBS poll showed that respondents generally described their views about affirmative action programs intended to help women in the same way that they described programs based on race.
 
Three Questions, Complex Views
The complexity of views on affirmative action seemed particularly evident in a series of three questions in the poll that all began with the phrase, "In order to make up for past discrimination," and went on to ask respondents their views on particular policies.
For example, asked their views on programs that "give preferential treatment to racial minorities," only 26 percent -- including 21 percent of whites and 51 percent of blacks -- said they would favor such programs. Just 19 percent -- 15 percent of whites and 48 percent of blacks -- said they would favor programs that "impose quotas for racial minorities."
But asked their views about programs that "make special efforts to help minorities get ahead," Americans of both races seemed vastly more comfortable with this vaguer language. Fifty-five percent of the respondents, including 50 percent of whites and 80 percent of blacks, said they would favor such programs.
What, exactly, does "special efforts" mean? Follow-up interviews conducted after the poll with many of the respondents indicated that there was no consensus on this question. But in general Americans seem to feel that any kind of education or training programs that help to get people to the same place in some mythical "starting line" are good, while anything that gives one group a head start in the race itself is not good.
"I favor perhaps making an extra effort in providing training programs in the schools for minorities to get their skills up to par so they can compete with all other ethnic groups," said Denise Siino, a 39-year-old freelance journalist in Santa Ana, Calif., who is white. But, she added, "No ethnic group, including whites, should get preferential treatment in job placement or college admissions based solely on race."
Many black Americans also voiced serious qualms about preferential treatment based on race. "You can't make up for past mistakes by making hiring preferences," said Ruby Hall, 59, a retired accounting technician in Forestville, Md., who is black. "In many cases the jobs are available but people aren't qualified because of their education."
Ms. Hall said she would support programs that help children who lack basic reading and writing skills reach college.
"This would include special education classes or tutoring programs," Ms. Hall said. "This needs to start as early as the third grade in elementary school so kids don't fall behind."
 
Blacks and Whites: Opinions in Contrast
Still, there were often wide gaps in the ways that white and black Americans viewed affirmative action. Blacks were much more likely to support any kind of affirmative action program, and were much more likely to say that discrimination persists in the workplace and in society at large.
Blacks and whites also exhibited sharply contrasting views in their responses to a question about what constitutes a bigger problem in the workplace -- blacks losing out because of racial discrimination, or whites losing out because of affirmative action.
The overall pool of those surveyed was almost exactly split on the answer. But white people, by 39 percent to 31 percent, described "whites losing out" as the bigger problem, while black people, by 63 percent to 10 percent, said "blacks losing out" was a bigger issue. (Remaining numbers for both races either said both problems were equally serious or said they didn't know.)
Whites were also much less likely to say that race has ever been a factor, one way or the other, in whether they got a job or promotion. Eighty-three percent of whites said they believed it simply had never been a factor for them, but blacks offered a much more textured range of answers to this question: 21 percent said their race had helped them in such a situation, 26 percent said it had hurt, 5 percent said it had helped in some cases and hurt in others and 46 percent said it had not been a factor.
Among all those of both races who said they favor banning affirmative action, whites were much more likely than blacks to say they would stand by that view even if it meant fewer black professionals and university students. Given a specific example of a professional field, white people were also much less likely than blacks to say that affirmative action programs were necessary "to make sure there are more black doctors."
 
Races Seem Close On Core Principles
In many other ways, though, the two racial groups seemed closer on the issues than often seems to be assumed when the subject of affirmative action comes up for discussion.
Both races seemed to agree on some core principles, among them that laws are still needed to protect racial minorities from discrimination, that racial diversity is an important aim, that special efforts and "outreach programs" to help minorities advance are acceptable and even laudable, but that specific racial preferences often are not.
Blacks and whites were also much more likely to say that, in general, white applicants for schools and jobs win out over equally qualified black applicants and that white people have a better chance of getting ahead in society than black people do.
And, given a more open-ended way to explain their views on affirmative action than a straight favor-or-oppose question, Americans of both races would seem to agree that the programs need to be preserved in some fashion.
Asked what society should do with "affirmative action programs giving preference to some minorities," people were much more inclined to say that they should be maintained or revised than they were to say that they should be abolished.
In the poll, 24 percent of respondents (21 percent of whites, 36 percent of blacks) favored leaving the programs alone, and 43 percent (41 percent of whites, 56 percent of blacks) favored changing them. But only 25 percent (30 percent of whites and 3 percent of blacks) said they would "do away" with such programs.
Similarly, despite the vote in California that basically asked whether affirmative action should be banned immediately, respondents in the poll seemed much more comfortable with a more amorphous option.
Asked whether affirmative action programs should be ended now, phased out or continued, just 12 percent of those polled -- 13 percent of whites and less than 1 percent of blacks -- said they should be ended now. Forty percent (45 percent of whites, 17 percent of blacks) favored phasing out the programs, and 41 percent (35 percent of whites, 80 percent of blacks) said they should be continued.
The poll focused on the attitudes of white and black Americans and, while members of other minority groups were surveyed, their numbers were not large enough to provide a statistically reliable snapshot of the attitudes of Hispanic and Asian Americans.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 6-9 with 1,258 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
Black Americans and residents of California were sampled at somewhat higher than normal rates in order to facilitate analysis of these groups, and were then weighted back to their proper proportion of the overall population.
The results have also been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for blacks taken as a group it is plus or minus seven percentage points.
There were insufficient Asian or Hispanic respondents in the poll to separate out either of those groups' views with confidence.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.
