HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
Muni Bonds: You Can Take Them With You

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:

Q. I'm retiring and moving to Florida. Do I have to sell my New York State municipal bonds and replace them with Florida bonds?
 
B. INGHAM
Syosset, N.Y. 
 A. Setting up shop in a new location usually causes some confusion. Years back, for instance, General Motors realized that Nova, its popular Chevy model, meant "It won't go" when translated into Spanish.
But one thing is certain: When it comes to a municipal bond, you can take it with you. No law prohibits you from owning the bonds of one state after you have moved to another.
However, most municipal bonds do have a home-state advantage. Such bonds are typically free from Federal income tax. But when you live in the issuing state, the interest is usually free from state and local income taxes, too. Generally, this is not so with out-of-state bonds: If you live in, say, California and own New York municipal bonds, you will pay California tax on the bond income.
But that does not mean you should necessarily sell or swap your New York bonds for Florida ones. To decide, do the math.
Specifically, you must determine if the yield on the New York munis, minus the taxes you must pay Florida on those out-of-state bonds, will be greater than the yield you would get on Florida municipal bonds. The calculation demands a close look at yields, tax rates and commissions.
For the most part, the current interest-rate climate dictates bond yields. Variations tend to reflect the differences in bond quality -- their credit ratings, maturities, call provisions and so on. But you may still want to comparison-shop because, just like the highway speed limit, bond yields can vary slightly from state to state. This is a result of the supply of and demand for the bonds.
Florida may be as renowned for its freedom from an individual income tax as it is for Key lime pie. But the Florida life is not all sweet when it comes to investment income. The state levies a tax on intangible personal property, like cash, stocks and most bonds (but not Florida munis).
The intangibles tax sets a rate of $2 for every $1,000 worth of investments, as measured by their fair market value. However, the first $20,000 ($40,000 for joint filers) of your bonds is exempt from all tax. The next $80,000 ($160,000 for joint filers) is subject to an assessment of only $1 per $1,000. Only for investments in excess of $100,000 ($200,000 for joint filers) would you pay the full $2 per $1,000.
In other words, unless you are a mogul or a movie star, "you may discover that in the case of Florida, the tax is quite minimal" on out-of-state munis, said Marybeth Whyte, a director at Salomon Brothers Asset Management. For instance, for a single person, the tax on the market value of $80,000 of bonds would be only $60 and the tax on $100,000 worth would be $80 -- about the price of a day at Disney World.
But commissions must also be considered. At a typical 1 percent commission, it would cost $2,000 to sell $100,000 in muni bonds and then to buy new ones. And if your New York bonds have appreciated, you may also have to pay tax on the gains.
The commission seems hefty compared with the $80 tax. But before deciding to stay with your New York bonds, remember that you will pay the commission only once. The intangibles tax will be due every year. If your New York bonds have 30 years to maturity, for example, your intangibles payments will total $2,400.
After you have crunched the numbers, you can decide whether to hold your old bonds or to buy new ones. But there are other considerations.
If you opt to swap, for example, you may want to buy Florida bonds with a longer duration than the ones you are selling. By extending the maturity, you can normally receive a higher yield and make up some of the outlay for the commission and any taxes due on the gains. However, during that longer time there is a greater risk of rising interest rates, in which case the value of your bonds would fall. That doesn't matter, of course, if you hold them to maturity.
You may also want to check with a Florida broker. "A local broker may have better access to the Florida muni market," said Robert Zipf, author of "How the Bond Market Works" (Prentice-Hall, $17.95).
Another factoid: The Florida intangibles tax is figured on your investments as of one day only, Dec. 31. It doesn't matter what you own during the rest of the year. Think of it as the Sunshine State's own little way of saying "Happy New Year."
Despite all the fine points, there are general rules for munis and moving. For example, if you are going to a high-tax state, like Massachusetts or New Jersey, a bond swap is more likely to be in your interest than if you go to a lower-tax state.
Also, watch your tax bracket. If you are retiring as well as moving, you may no longer be in a bracket high enough to make munis worthwhile. The best course, then -- assuming you want to keep holding bonds -- is to sell your munis in favor of Treasuries, which are federally taxable although exempt from state and local taxes, or corporate bonds, which are taxed at all levels.
Nevertheless, many people who own muni bonds are in too low a bracket for the bonds to make sense, Mr. Zipf said. So why do they own them? Three reasons, he said. Some investors just prefer not having to set aside a portion of their interest checks for taxes. Others may have fallen into a lower tax bracket -- through a job change, retirement or a business loss -- since the original purchase was made. And some buyers simply do not realize that they could be getting a better return from a taxable bond.
But if muni bonds are right for you, pack a calculator with the sunscreen when you head to Florida. Don't expect to avoid the hard work even on the "miracle flight" -- the name a flight attendant friend of mine has given her New York-Florida route. About 20 wheelchairs are requested for the flight's pre-boarding , but, oddly, not for disembarking. Moments after landing in Fort Lauderdale, most of the former invalids are seen striding briskly into the sunshine. Our very own Lourdes.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 25, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A listing of state tax provisions with the Minding Your Business column on Dec. 14, about investing in municipal bonds, referred incompletely to six states' treatment of those investments. Those states -- Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma and Wisconsin -- levy taxes on only some of the bonds they have issued, and in some of the states, the exempt bonds are numerous. A reader's letter dated Jan. 9, pointing out the error, was delayed in routing at The Times.
 

GRAPHIC: Charts: "When Tax-Free Makes Sense"
Municipal bonds have lower yields than taxable bonds. In return, the muni investor generally pays no Federal income tax and often no state or local income tax, either.
The higher the tax bracket, the more appealing munis are. Investors in the 39.6 percent bracket would need a taxable bond yielding 8.28 percent to get the same return, after taxes, as from a muni yielding 5 percent. But for investors in the 28 percent bracket, the taxable-equivalent yield for the same muni is just 6.94 percent.
As a group, munis now have relatively high yields, paying 5.26 percent on average, according to the Bond Buyer index. That is about 90 percent of what comparable, federally taxable Treasuries earn -- well above the normal range of 75 to 80 percent. Chart shows muni and equivalent taxable yield by tax bracket.
 
"Unusual States"
Most states have an income tax and impose it on out-of-state munis but not on in-state bonds. Still, there are exceptions, including these.
 
* Seven states have no income tax: Alaska, Florida*, Nevada, South Dakota, Texas, Washington, Wyoming.
 
* Six states tax both in-state and out-of-state munis: Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, Wisconsin.
 
* Three states have income taxes, but impose them on neither in-state nor out-of-state munis: Indiana, Utah, North Dakota.+
 
*Florida does impose an intangible personal property tax on out-of-state munis, however. +Only if investors use the short state-tax form.
 
(Source: Merrill Lynch)

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: Iraqis' Suffering Widens as U.N. Sanctions Drag On

BYLINE: By HADANI DITMARS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The restaurants and cafes are often empty. Movie theaters are closed, and the few nightclubs left in this once bustling, prosperous city are frequented by a handful of wealthy "embargo cats" -- smugglers who have made a fortune evading the United Nations sanctions to import everything from tires to lingerie.
The trade embargo, which was imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, has cut across class lines, from the poor of Saddam City in the popular quarter of Baghdad to the rapidly disappearing middle class. 
 Taxi drivers with doctorates are commonplace as people struggle to get by on an average monthly income of less than $5, down considerably from 1991. Government bureaucrats who once earned comfortable salaries now take home the equivalent of $2 dollars a month and drive broken-down cars with smashed windshields and rusting engines. Spare parts are restricted by the embargo.
American officials hold President Saddam Hussein responsible for the economic and social collapse of his country. The Iraqi leader, they insist, is cynically using his populace as pawns in a public-relations effort to gain relief from the sanctions, which the United Nations has said will remain in effect until its inspectors verify that the country has destroyed its nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.
Mr. Hussein, in turn, blames the embargo for the suffering of the Iraqi people, and has repeatedly criticized the United States for its insistence that it remain in place.
The United Nations has allowed Iraq to sell $2 billion in oil every six months to pay for food and medicine. Iraqi officials say the amounts are insufficient and that the program is slow and inefficient at distributing the aid.
Whatever its cause, the suffering in Baghdad and surrounding cities appears real.
According to Unicef, which relies largely on Iraqi-provided statistics, the infant mortality rate has nearly doubled in the last six years -- from 61 per thousand in 1991 to 117 per thousand today.
The average number of children under 5 killed by respiratory infections, malnutrition and diarrheal illnesses has increased from 500 a month in 1991 to 8,000 in 1996. The United Nations agency estimates that one third of the children in Iraq are malnourished, a figure comparable to sub-Saharan Africa.
Eric Falt, a spokesman for the United Nations relief operations in Iraq, said, "The status of Iraqi children can now be associated with the most disadvantaged countries in the world." Mr. Falt said the meager rations given to Iraqis under the United Nations program were simply not enough.
The per capita distribution per month includes about 20 pounds of flour, 5.5 pounds of rice, 4.4 pounds of sugar, 5.4 ounces of tea, 2.2 pounds of chick peas and beans, 5.4 ounces of salt, 2.2 pounds of cooking oil, 9 ounces of soap, 12.6 ounces of detergent, and 6 pounds of infant formula for children under 2.
The so-called food-basket does not include any animal protein, vitamins or minerals. It includes no meat, fish, poultry or fruits and vegetables.
These rations were in place for August and September. They have since been smaller, mainly because of delays in delivery and in the United Nations Security Council's approval of the contracts for oil sales.
The food aid reaches Iraq through a circuitous process. First, the United Nations sanctions committee in New York authorizes Iraq to pump oil, which is then sold on the international market. The money is deposited in a bank account controlled by the United Nations, which must approve each food purchase. Distribution of the food in Iraq is then handled by the Iraqi Government in central and southern Iraq and by United Nations officials in northern Iraq.
The lack of food is felt keenly in Saddam City, one of Baghdad's poorer neighborhoods. Malek, a 13-year-old market boy, quit school two years ago to support his family. He spends 12-hour days as a delivery boy in the local market, where he and bands of other children ply their trade with rusting iron carts, carrying produce back and forth for vendors.
In the rain, he walks in cracked plastic shoes through streets strewn with sewage. His breakfast on a recent morning was a thin porridge of leftover rice and beans. Supper may be some bread with a little oil.
The skinny youth has an old-man's face, pale and drawn with dark circles. He says his father is too ill to work, and the kidney operation he needs is far beyond the family's meager means. His two older brothers, ages 16 and 21, have been unemployed since the embargo began.
Malek said he hoped to become a doctor some day, but has no immediate plans to return to school. Although his friends chant "Down, Down America" almost haphazardly, as a kind of nursery rhyme, he does not seem to share the sentiment.
"One day, when I'm rich, I want to go to America," he said wistfully. On a good day at the market, Malek earns about 80 cents.
Meanwhile, in a once-middle-class neighborhood 15 minutes away, Kamal, a cafe owner, serves his first cappuccinos of the day to a young couple dressed in relatively stylish attire. The man wears what appears to be a Rolex; the woman wears gold jewelry.
"Embargo cat" he whispered to a foreign visitor, describing a customer willing to pay half a civil servant's monthly salary for two coffees.
Kamal cannot afford to drink at his own cafe. His family, he said, can afford to eat meat only three times a month.
But he has been to America, and many other places. Now, though, he must live in Iraq.
Before the war, he was an engineer for an Arab company in the Persian Gulf.
When Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, he was unceremoniously dismissed by his Saudi employers. Officially, he was given "open leave" with a chance to return, but he does not expect to do so anytime soon.
Kamal took over the cafe from his father in 1991, and manages to eke out a living of $60 dollars a month.
"It's not enough" he said, "but somehow we get by." To feed their two children, he and his wife have sold most of their prized possessions -- silver, jewelry, china -- the likes of which can be seen in shops throughout Baghdad's better neighborhoods.
He refuses to let his children work -- something he sees as an option only for the lower classes -- and insists that they stay in school. His income is only slightly higher than that of Malek's family. And he worries about his children.
What if one should get sick? Last year, he managed to buy a special inhaler for his severely asthmatic son, at $100. "I can't depend on the hospital anymore," he said. "If I took him there it might take three hours before they could help him. By then he might already be dead."
Often, Kamal must choose between buying nutritious food for his children and providing them with medicine when they are sick. Even the price of a bottle of aspirin is formidable.
If any of his few remaining possessions are stolen, Kamal said, he could be in financial ruin.
As a safeguard against Baghdad's rising crime rate, Kamal has recently purchased a German Shepherd dog.
"This allows us to leave the house for a few hours," he said. "Before the dog, someone had to be there all the time."

HEADLINE: Down Country Roads, Come Modern Phones

BYLINE: By DAVID BATSTONE 

DATELINE: PAICINES, Calif.

 BODY:
Lisa Knutson once believed that sharing a phone line with seven other ranches in rural California was romantic.
But in late 1995, she began marketing nutrition products out of her home near Tres Pinos, an hour's drive southeast of San Jose. The business quickly attracted her neighbors' interest. 
 "I can't tell you how many times I was interrupted in the middle of a sales call to be asked when the line would be free," Ms. Knutson said. "Other times I was the one waiting hours for an open line."
Eight months after starting her business, Ms. Knutson and her husband sold their home and moved to a more populated region -- mainly, she said, so she could get phone service from Pacific Bell.
Too bad she didn't live a few miles to the south. On his ranch in Paicines, about 13 miles from Tres Pinos, Rex Bryan runs the Pinnacles Telephone Company, laboring so that ranchers and farmers need not make the choice between rural life and modern technology. While more than half of Pinnacles' customers were on party lines six years ago, today they all receive private service.
Pinnacles is the smallest of 11 telephone companies still independently owned in California. With annual revenue of slightly more than $1 million, it reaches 185 subscribers in an area that stretches across 200 square miles -- but not, unfortunately for the Knutsons, as far north as Tres Pinos.
Mr. Bryan established Pinnacles in 1953 after he acquired a single "farmer line" then used by 30 ranches. The previous owner offered Mr. Bryan the title to his tiny phone business if he would pay for a $500 roll of copper wire that had recently arrived at the county railroad dock. A decade later, Mr. Bryan paid $1,200 for a second local line. While both lines date to around 1906, they remain Pinnacles' main signal routes.
Little else has stayed the same. Pinnacles' plant assets now total nearly $2 million, and its annual operating expenses run close to $466,000.
During the last two decades the company has directed roughly 60 percent of its spending to technical upgrades.
Mr. Bryan's company, much like the 94 other privately owned telephone companies with fewer than 500 customers across the United States, does everything possible to keep pace with rapid changes in telecommunications technology. Rural residents, whether they raise cattle or harvest grain, rely on communications as much as transportation to get their products to market. Timing is everything, so they value the ability to get crop reports over the Internet or fax stock projections to commodities traders.
Some aspects of rural life do not adjust so quickly to the rhythm of the network economy. Mr. Bryan says, for instance, that a majority of his customers are in no rush to get off party lines.
Charlotte Berberick, 90, was one of Pinnacles' first customers. She still recalls the ring -- four shorts and a long -- that signaled an incoming call on her ranch's 10-party line. Ms. Berberick acknowledges that neighbors did drop in on one another's conversations. "No one had a television then, and very few folks owned a radio," she said. "We needed to entertain ourselves somehow!"
Another longtime Pinnacles customer, Fern Fancher, 79, said party lines contributed to a stronger community life. She cites several occasions when neighbors alerted one another of an approaching grass fire or other emergency with a single call, and help was soon on its way.
Such an intimate community, however, often means a loss of privacy. When Ms. Fancher's father-in-law died, his widow called and asked Ms. Fancher to pass on the news to relatives on a neighboring ranch. No need, for by the time Ms. Fancher arrived, the family was already grieving. "From that day on," she said, "I treated every phone conversation as public."
Pinnacles made its first big technical overhaul in the early 1970's, bringing overhead lines underground and converting open wires to insulated copper. Despite steady upgrades in ensuing years, more than half the company's customers were still on party lines by 1992.
More far-reaching changes accompanied Pinnacles' turn toward fiber optic cables about six years ago. It costs slightly less to lay copper wire than fiber optic cable -- about $10 a foot, compared with $10.50 -- but a pair of copper wires can serve only eight subscribers, while hundreds can fit on a fiber optic line. In a single year after installing its first fiber optic cable, Pinnacles made more progress than it had in the previous 20 years. Every customer had a private line, and several ordered a second one.
Pinnacles also recently installed digital switches that allow customers to choose among long-distance carriers, and it plans to introduce lines for high-speed Internet access within a year.
Mr. Bryan stresses that his company could not keep pace with telecommunications technology without the aid of the Universal Service Fund, a $793 million Federal program that puts a tax on all phone customers and uses the proceeds to subsidize phone companies with customers that are costly to serve, like those in remote areas.
Not that public assistance is the main source of income for Pinnacles. The money from Universal Service represents only 13 percent of annual operating revenue, while roughly 21 percent comes from the company's share of payments for long-distance calls.
All the same, Mr. Bryan argues that rural areas would become isolated if Universal Service did not exist. "The valuable stakes are the metropolitan zones," he explains. "Large phone companies can't make money out here."
Several years ago Mr. Bryan ran a phone line five miles up a creek for a new customer who lived in the high-elevation Gabilan Range. He had no choice but to attach the line to trees along the creek bank. Every winter he can count on at least one tree falling during a storm and damaging the phone line.
That adds up to a lot of time and expense for a single customer. But Mr. Bryan, whose 1996 earnings were close to $140,000, says his company is not driven solely by profits. "I simply enjoy serving the public and doing some good," he said.
Pinnacles' customers do value the personal relationship they have with their phone company, and hope it continues to thrive after Mr. Bryan, now 80, turns the business over to his two sons.
Ms. Fancher, a widow who lives alone, tells of being awakened at 3 A.M. one stormy night by a car turning into her driveway. Through sheets of driving rain she could make out Mr. Bryan's figure running to her door. The central office had received a faint signal that sounded like a 911 alert, so Mr. Bryan had visited each customer who lived alone to make sure they were not in trouble.
"The sky was falling, yet he felt he had a duty to take care of us," Ms. Fancher said.
Mr. Bryan worries about the future of his community. San Jose is sprawling in its direction, and he notes that commuters and weekend ranchers are beginning to make their presence felt.
Still, the potential of a more lucrative business climate for his telephone company holds little allure.
"I'm still a farmer, born and bred," he said. "And like all my ilk, I hate the plague of development."

HEADLINE: Tumbling Technology Stocks: Problems Go Beyond Asia

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The wreckage was devastating. In a matter of days, an entire herd of technology stocks was taken out to pasture and slaughtered.
The shares of little-known companies like the Quantum Corporation and Applied Materials, as well as members of the "fab five" of the technology world -- Oracle, Intel, Microsoft, Cisco Systems and I.B.M. -- were all battered in what turned into the worst week in a decade for technology issues. 
 The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index lost 6 percent of its value last week, and indexes that included only technology stocks were hit even harder.
A big reason was the growing fear among investors that the economic crisis now engulfing much of Asia would soon stunt the growth of a whole legion of technology companies. Indeed, many of those companies had bet on Asia as a platform for sales and earnings growth.
But the problems facing the industry go well beyond Asia. For months, many technology companies have been feeling the pressures of stiff pricing competition, a glut of components and a worldwide slowdown in personal computer sales.
As a result, when the Asian troubles sharpened last week, many investors who had long considered pulling back from technology stocks went into full retreat. And when a host of companies fed the fears by announcing weaker earnings forecasts and swollen inventories, the entire sector was punished.
"If you make computer components, you had a problem whether Asia collapsed or not," said Roger McNamee, a principal at Integral Capital Partners in Menlo Park, Calif. "Everybody is using Asia as an excuse. But Asia was just the latest catalyst for selling."
The dismal performance of technology stocks is significant because the technology sector has grown into one of the largest and most closely followed by investors. It increasingly sets the tone for the broader stock market. If the coming week brings even more warnings of earnings shortfalls, the tone could get even nastier.
The recent selloff was best viewed through the prism of the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index, where 94 of 100 issues fell last week, with 2 issues losing nearly a third of their market value. For the index, which dropped 9.8 percent, it was the worst week since October 1987, when technology stocks collapsed along with the broader market.
"I don't think people realize the carnage that has taken place," said James Renck, a portfolio manager at Merrill Lynch Asset Management. "A lot of stocks are down 50 to 70 percent since mid-October."
Particularly hard hit were shares of semiconductor makers and companies that sell the capital equipment that helps manufacture semiconductors -- both of which have heavy exposure in Southeast Asia.
While Oracle, a data base software maker, dropped 27 percent last week on record volume after the company reported disappointing earnings, large declines were also seen in semiconductor companies like Applied Materials, which plummeted 25 percent, and LAM Research, which dropped 22 percent on earnings worries.
As a result, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index fell 14.7 percent last week. For the year, the index is up just 3.3 percent while the broader market is up more than 20 percent.
That disparity worries technology investors, many of whom have been riding the crest of a huge growth wave. In 1990, for instance, the market value of the 10 leading technology companies was about $50 billion. Today, Microsoft alone is worth $165 billion and the top 10 technology companies are worth close to $650 billion.
"Technology is still going to be a great area," said Fred Hickey, editor of The High-Tech Strategist, a newsletter based in Nashua, N.H. "The problem is, investors have to separate the business from the market valuations. People wonder why stocks go down 20 points in a day; it's because the stock market was out of control. It was so ga-ga over the industry. Now those stocks are going to correct."
Behind the big selloff, though, are indications that the technology industry is undergoing a subtle but momentous shift in the way it does business, one however that many industry experts say will benefit consumers by resulting in cheaper, more powerful computers.
One change is that disk drive and semiconductor manufacturers are now under great pressure to find more efficient ways to produce, partly because of the success of the "just in time" inventory model used by Dell Computer.
"All that's going on is the industry is deciding it's going to be more efficient," Mr. McNamee said. "The whole supply chain is being optimized. It's being forced to conform to the model of Dell."
Whether component companies can accomplish this, however, is still unclear. "Semiconductor plants cost $1 billion to build and two years to put in place," Mr. Hickey at The High-Tech Strategist said. "That's a difficult process. Dell just assembles and tests computers."
Some analysts, however, say that the twin troubles of turmoil in Asia and an oversupply of components in the rest of the world, will force the industry to push even harder to optimize its manufacturing channels, creating even cheaper computers that could, in turn, open up an even larger consumer base.
"When you can buy a good multimedia PC for $1,000, that opens up a whole new group of buyers," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter.
In fact, many analysts expect the industry to shake off its recent troubles, and the stocks are likely to begin another sharp growth phase. That is largely because most analysts believe that technology components will continue to grow exponentially. Semiconductors, for instance, are already being used in cars, toasters, refrigerators, computers, televisions, even Nike sneakers, almost anything that processes signals.
"They've been shooting all the tech stocks, even the ones that don't have exposure in Asia," said Thomas Thornhill, director of technology research at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities. "But that's going to be corrected because the end consumption of technology remains on a relatively constant, upward trend."

Last week saw 94 of the 100 stocks drop, and two of them -- System Software and Kulicke & Soffa, both of which mentioned problems with Asian sales -- lost more than a third of their value in just five days. HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
With a Film Due, Homage To Bond. James Bond.

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
The latest installment of the James Bond series, "Tomorrow Never Dies," reaches theaters this week, and Bond mania -- building through weeks of incessant marketing -- is bound to reach fever pitch. The World Wide Web offers sites aplenty for true Bond aficionados as well as the merely curious.
MGM/UA has two sites aimed at fans impatient for the new movie. One is the unsubtle www.tomorrowneverdies.com, filled with trailers, photos, movie-related information, a Bond role-paying game and links to companies that have made deals to have their products featured in the movie. 
 The other is a disappointing "Official James Bond Home Page," which seems nothing more than a brochure to sell Bond-related merchandise.
"The Web's amazing -- the tremendous amount of Bond sites out there cover all things Bond," said John Cork, a director of the Ian Fleming Foundation in Burbank, Calif., an organization dedicated to preserving the legacy of the author and his most famous creation. "The best part is that most of the best sites are made by fans."
The foundation's site features the Web magazine "Mr. Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" (Mr. Fleming is said to have described his novels as being of the "bang-bang-kiss-kiss variety"), and updated information about the movies and other aspects of Bond lore. It has a set of frequently asked questions about James Bond, along with the answers. (Among them: "Just who is this James Bond guy anyway?" and "Some of these actors look awfully old. When were they born?")
While the perception is that Bond is popular mainly with males, one of the best starting points for Bond sites is run by a woman. Kimberly Last, a fan in Chicago, started her site in December 1994 and has since built a fan following of her own.
"I was not much of a Bond fan until Pierce Brosnan took over," Ms. Last said, referring to the actor who assumed the role of the dashing spy in "Goldeneye," the last Bond film. "But now I really enjoy putting everything I can find in one place."
Her site, James Bond, 007 OHMSS (On Her Majesty's Secret Service), has some obvious resources (a profile of Mr. Brosnan, for example) and some not-so-obvious ones (the lyrics of most Bond movie songs). One section, the Literary Bond, has extensive information about Bond's creator and the authors who continued the series after his death. Ms. Last also has an exhaustive set of links to other Bond sites.
Another comprehensive fan site, Nuvs' 007 Shrine, is a tribute to James Bond. The site, which is run by Navin Jain, a college student in Buffalo, uses plenty of multimedia resources and also something rare in the world of Bond sites: negative comments about the newer films. A fan in Britain who saw a press screening last week reported on the site that the new movie was "not a Bond film but a 90's parody of a Bond film."
A more detailed negative look at the movies is available at the James Bond Movie Faults site, which is dedicated to finding "all the faults, blunders, mistakes, bloopers, errors and flaws" in the films.
A serious approach to the subject of Bond is taken by a Web magazine, Her Majesty's Secret Servant. It includes articles, interviews and some intellectual content.
Guns, cars and gadgets all play important roles in the series, and most sites feature a section on them. One site, run by a high school student in Ireland, has details on the toys that make Bond tick.
And anyone who nearly flunked out of school because of a Bond obsession, or just wants to obtain college credit for their interest in the character, should look up the site of Eastern Caribbean University on the island of St. Kitts, which offers Bond studies courses over the Internet. Among them are "Geo 30071: Economic Geography of Bond Films and Their Impact on Countries," "Bus 30074: Marketing of Bond Films Worldwide" and "Eng 300710: Comparisons of Bond Films/Novels."
Those who think they know their Bond trivia can test themselves at Quizland's Bond site. It even provides rankings of the top scorers among recent players. Sample questions: What rank does James Bond hold? (Royal Navy commander). What children's book did Ian Fleming write? ("Chitty Chitty Bang Bang").
Copyright appears to be something easily ignored in the world of Bond, as most of the sites contain photographs and articles that are obviously taken from elsewhere and are often not credited. Almost every site seems comfortable acquiring such material.
Fans who want to go beyond vicariously enjoying Bond in movies and books can check out the Commanders Club, the site of a group "dedicated to the preservation and celebration of the lifestyle of a Scottish peasant named Bond, James Bond." Members of the San Francisco-based group dress up in tuxedos, go to casinos and pay attention to their "007 Day Planner," which marks Bond dates and anniversaries. The first listing: Jan 4, 1900, the birthday of a Philadelphia ornithologist named James Bond, after whom Mr. Fleming named his character.
A site that includes an extended discussion of the late ornithologist is run by William E. Kelly, who reports that Mr. Bond's widow wrote to him to say that her husband had always resented the invasion of his private life through the "theft" of his name by Ian Fleming.
"He wishes he could be left alone to do his work, which means everything to him," she said, "and put 007 behind him."

HEADLINE: Philanthropic Magazines' Circulation Rises, Along With Interest in Giving

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Charitable giving is in. Americans are donating $150 billion a year to charity. Nonprofit organizations now number more than one million. People are taking an increasing interest in volunteerism. And some publications are reaping the benefits.
"People are looking more to philanthropic sources for new ideas and leadership in a period when government is shrinking," said Susan Vail Berresford, the president of the Ford Foundation. "And people who publish magazines and newspapers see that as a new market." 
 Industry statistics prove it. Circulation at the Chronicle of Philanthropy was up nearly 5 percent for the six months ended June 30, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. And The Nonprofit Times, which is not audited, said its paid circulation has increased 50 percent since July 1996, to 4,000. It also has a controlled (free) circulation of 30,000.
New publications have come on the scene, including regional publications, newsletters and Internet offerings, like Guidestar, the Donor's Guide to the Nonprofit Universe, a free service with information on the programs and finances of more than 600,000 American charities and nonprofit groups. And mainstream publications seem to be taking a new interest in philanthropy, publishing lists of the most generous donors.
"We're riding a monumental interest in the subject of philanthropy and giving back," said W. Randall Jones, the chief executive of Capital Publishing, which in March started The American Benefactor, a glossy consumer magazine financed by Fidelity Investments.
Other publications that have sprung up over the last few years include Who Cares: The Tool Kit for Social Change, based in Washington, which started in 1993 as a magazine for young people and was reissued this fall with more nuts-and-bolts advice for nonprofits. It also increased its frequency to six times a year from four and tripled its circulation to 50,000. "The era of big government is over," said Leslie Crutchfield, the founding editor. "The era of big citizenship has begun."
The magazine More Than Money, published in Eugene, Ore., by Impact Project, a nonprofit group, has a circulation of 1,000 and covers topics like what makes giving satisfying. "Our publication focuses on the personal side of what it's like to have more money than other people," said Allen Hancock, the publisher. "How to make the experience of having money something positive and meaningful."
These publications are distributed primarily through nonprofit organizations and foundations. The American Benefactor, which is not sold on newsstands, is distributed as a gift to principal donors and prospective patrons of 3,000 nonprofit groups. Advertisers in these publications range from software companies and marketing services to Timberland boots.
People in the philanthropic world give several reasons for the surge of interest in charities, chiefly a strong economy and baby boomers at the peak of their earning years. Then there are the reliable reasons for giving, ranging from pure altruism to raw egotism, from social climbing to a desire to buy one's way into heaven (about 40 percent of charitable contributions go to religious organizations).
There has been a growing interest in taking social action as well as writing checks, people in the nonprofit sector say. This may explain the success of Build, a magazine started about five years ago by Do Something, a nonprofit organization in New York that encourages young people to take action in their communities. Build is distributed free to 100,000 people through a network of national nonprofits.

HEADLINE: Theorist's Task: Make Old Laws Fit in Digital World of Microsoft

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Into the epic legal battle between the world's most powerful software corporation and the U.S. government, enter the quixotic Lawrence Lessig, a 36-year-old Harvard law professor who speaks softly and espouses radical new -- and stubbornly non-partisan -- ideas about how traditional legal principles translate into cyberspace.
Anointed a "special master" in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp. last Thursday, Mr. Lessig has five months to interpret the questions raised by the case, in which the government claims that the Redmond software giant violated a consent decree when it required computer makers to sell its Internet browser software with its Windows 95 computer operating system. 
 A constitutional scholar and by all accounts one of the leading intellectuals of his generation in American law, Mr. Lessig is not an anti-trust specialist. But he is a certified computer whiz whose career accomplishments include almost single-handedly propelling the Supreme Court's computer system into the modern age when he clerked there in 1990.
In choosing Mr. Lessig for a job that may help redefine how anti-trust doctrine is applied to the ephemeral realm of software, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson appeared to underscore the importance of achieving a better understanding of the relationship between new technology and existing law, legal experts said.
Mr. Lessig, whose father's steel fabricating company built bridges up and down the east coast while he was growing up, has spent the last several years formulating legal bridges between physical space and cyberspace. Driving much of his scholarship is the concern that, almost unnoticed, computer code has taken on the governing properties of law -- and moreover, that it is a more potent regulator of behavior than law could ever hope to be.
Unless Constitutional principles like free speech and privacy protection are consciously transported into the electronic domain and embedded in its architecture, Mr. Lessig has argued, the "tyranny of code" will dominate.
In an interventionist position that has won him few friends among the libertarian Internet community, for instance, Mr. Lessig contends that free speech principles might be better served by limited government regulation of pornographic material on the Internet than the voluntary adoption by Internet firms of a software standard that could block such images. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in her opinion on the Communications Decency Act case, also cited an article of Professor Lessig's for the idea that the Government might zone the Internet by age.
"The most effective way for government to regulate in cyberspace is to regulate its code," Mr Lessig said earlier this month. (Mr. Lessig, who has been vested with many of the powers of a judge, declined to comment on his appointment Friday.)
How Mr. Lessig will apply his theories on the powerful nature of code to the Microsoft case, if at all, is unclear. The software firm has long held that the traditional doctrine of anti-trust stifles innovation when applied to its fast-evolving industry. But Judge Jackson, who barred the company from packaging its Internet Explorer browser with Windows 95 last week pending a final decision, emphasized that the old rules still applied.
Lawyers familiar with Mr. Lessig's work suggested he might construct another catwalk between the two positions that would seek to embrace the underlying principles of anti-trust law in the new context.
"There is a question of when something becomes unlawful 'tying,' and how that analysis is different when you are dealing with technology as the bundler," said David Post, a law professor at Temple University and co-director of the Cyberspace Law Institute. "I think it's fair to conclude from his writing that Larry is suspicious about the market power over the basic architectural features of this landscape, which means the operating system."
Mr. Post, who discussed the subject with Mr. Lessig when they met by chance in an airport lounge awaiting a flight to Washington a few days before the ruling, said he received a flurry of calls over the weekend as lawyers from all sides tried to size up the new force on what many in the computer industry consider to be a watershed case.
As Mr. Lessig's curriculum vitae was faxed around the country and his journal articles downloaded from Lexis, some attorneys speculated that his association with the University of Chicago, which is known for embracing free-market approaches to law and economics, was a good sign for Microsoft.
Mr. Lessig studied for a year at Chicago's law school and taught there for a number of years before going to Harvard. He also clerked for two well-known conservatives closely associated with the school, Supreme Court Justics Antonin Scalia and 7th Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Richard Posner, after graduating from Yale Law School.
But Gary L. Reback, the attorney for Microsoft's rival in the browser market, Netscape Communications, and a persistent legal gadfly in matters involving Microsoft, said he was encouraged by Mr. Lessig's knowledge of technology.
"He's young, and I suppose it's unusual for someone so young to play this kind of role in the case of the century," Mr. Reback said. "But he will surely understand what's at stake, and that's half the battle."
Cass Sunstein, a law professor at Chicago who along with Mr. Lessig helped pioneer a new doctrine they call the "New Chicago School," warns against jumping to any conclusions about his former colleague's political alignment.
"I would be very cautious about assuming because he has been a Chicago affiliate that he has the usual Chicago view on antitrust law," Mr. Sunstein said. "He may, but he's an independent thinker. In fact, he's a very independent thinker."
Born in South Dakota and raised in Williamsport, Penn., 90 miles north of Harrisburg, Mr. Lessig's views were not always so unconventional. In high school, he was chairman of a group called Teenage Republicans for the State of Pennsylvania And in 1980 he took a semester off from the University of Pennsylvania, where he received degrees in economics and management, to run a campaign for a Republican state senator.
After studying philosophers in England at Cambridge University's Trinity College, however, Mr. Lessig returned to the United States to attend law school with a new political outlook. He dabbled in the postmodernist Critical Legal Studies movement, which attacks law as a tool of the powerful.
But colleagues say he may have been unable to subscribe to such theories because he is too driven by a belief in traditional legal values and law's power to promote social progress and remedy injustice.
He has taken a major role in helping to write the constitution for the former Soviet republic of Georgia, and is a leader of the activist "New Chicago School" which identifies "social norms" as a regulatory force that can influence behavior like smoking, or wearing a seatbelt.
"He was always passionate about his ideas," said his father, Lester O. Lessig, Jr., reached by phone from his home in Hilton Head, S.C. "When he went into teaching he felt he had the ability to have a greater impact than if he had done anything else."
Although the younger Mr. Lessig owned one of the first IBM personal computers, he is now one of a dwindling breed of Macintosh users. He likes opera and Lyle Lovett, and usually wears headphones while at the keyboard. He plays squash, agonizes over decisions, and strives for fairness even in grading student papers.
Even those who disagree with him cited Mr. Lessig's extreme fair-mindedness combined with a willingness to take unpopular positions as qualities that would stand him in good stead as he develops his analysis of digital age anti-trust doctrine. At a computer industry gathering dominated by cyber-libertarians earlier this year, the lanky Mr. Lessig, propounded his belief that a software standard for filtering indecent material posed a danger to free speech.
Mr. Lessig radiated a quiet intensity last winter as he told an unsympathetic audience that "PICS is the devil." But when pressed by civil libertarians to state whether he is in favor of Government regulation of cyberspace, Mr. Lessig qualified his position, acknowledging that criminal penalties connected to the regulation of speech in cyberspace might well be unconstitutional.
"The fact that he's responsive to criticism suggests that he has an open mind," said Mike Godwin, chief counsel for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, who has argued with his views. Mark Snyderman, a friend who clerked with Mr. Lessig on the Supreme Court and is now a labor lawyer for the Coca-Cola Co., witnessed what was perhaps Mr. Lessig's first demonstration of the power of computer code over the legal system, when as a clerk he was enlisted to help show Justices Scalia and O'Connor the difference between composing a decision on the Court's ancient mainframe system compared to a personal computer.
Both he and Mr. Snyderman were at computers -- Mr. Snyderman using a terminal connected to the mainframe, Mr. Lessig using a PC. "We had identical documents on both computers," Mr. Snyderman recalled. "Larry said, 'Now imagine you're writing something and there's a word you've written and you think there's got to be a better word that works here. What do you do under the old system?'
Mr. Snyderman's response at the time was the stand up, go to a shelf and get a thesaurus.
" 'What do you do under the new system?' Larry hit the thesaurus key. Scalia went wild. That's it, he was compeletly sold."

HEADLINE: Walter James Levy, 86, Oil Consultant, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Walter James Levy, a New York-based oil consultant who was considered the dean of United States oil economists, died Wednesday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 86.
In a business charged with intrigue and fierce rivalries, Mr. Levy was respected for his integrity, rectitude and trust. He owned no oil stocks, and his word was taken as solid by rival companies and oil-rich countries from Indonesia to Venezuela. 
 Whether consulted by companies or various governments, Mr. Levy made no secret of his dealings with competitors. His opinions and market analyses were sought and widely read until he retired about 10 years ago.
In World War II, Mr. Levy headed the petroleum section of the Office of Strategic Services, the forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency. After the war, he guided the petroleum sector of the Marshall Plan. In 1948 he became chief of the petroleum, oil and lubricant division of the Economic Cooperation Administration, which administered the plan to mend Europe's shattered economies and provide the political stability for democratic institutions to thrive. He filled that job until 1949 and continued to advise the E.C.A. until it ended its mission two years later.
In the ensuing decades, he ran his own business, the W. J. Levy Consultants Corporation, with offices in New York and London. His horizons widened from the strategic role of oil in war and reconstruction to a world emerging from colonialism and foreign tutelage.
It was a world in which sizable pools of crude underground betokened vast riches to which foreign corporations usually held the keys. Mr. Levy helped renegotiate oil leases between states that wanted to tap their own resources effectively and companies that feared outright nationalization.
His clients included India, Brunei and Saudi Arabia as well as the United States and European countries. In 1979, West Germany bestowed on him the Commander's Cross of the Federal Order of Merit, one of many honors he received.
Walter Levy was born in Altona, Germany, now a part of Hamburg. He studied at the Universities of Berlin, Freiburg, Heidelberg, Munich and Kiel, where he received a Doctor of Laws degree.
He migrated to England in 1933, found work at the Petroleum Press Bureau and wrote a book about oil in war that drew the interest of British economic officials. He provided them with briefings, but when war broke out in 1939 he was branded an "enemy alien" and moved on to New York as a freelance economist.
When the United States entered the war, the newly formed O.S.S. beckoned and he became section chief in the Enemy Oil Committee, analyzing German petroleum resources and pinpointing supply routes, refineries and synthetic oil plants for air attacks.
He was in charge of petroleum research at the State Department before he joined the Marshall Plan administration. After opening his private consultancy, he continued to advise numerous Government branches, among them the White House, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the State Department, as well as the School of Advanced International Studies in Washington.
He wrote articles that appeared in magazines and newspapers around the country and was the author of "Oil Strategy and Politics, 1941-1981" (1982).
Mr. Levy's wife, Augusta Sondheimer Levy, died in 1981 after 40 years of marriage.
He is survived by a daughter, Susan Levy of Altamonte Springs, Fla., and two sisters, Herta Grove of Philadelphia and Kate Freyhan of Bedford, England.

HEADLINE: Turkey, Rejected, Will Freeze Ties to European Union

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Stung by the European Union's rejection over the weekend of membership talks with Turkey, Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz said today that his Government would freeze its political contacts with the Union and seek a "strategic partnership" with the United States.
Mr. Yilmaz, who is scheduled to meet President Clinton in Washington on Friday, said Turkey "will have no political dialogue with the European Union from now on." 
 Turkey's decision to limit contacts with Europe's most important bloc came only days after Islamic leaders from around the world, meeting in Iran, voted to condemn Turkey for its military ties to Israel.
By taking steps that risk alienating both European and Islamic nations, Turkey appeared to be counting on increased support from the United States, an old ally, and Israel, a new one. Mr. Yilmaz said Turkey did not fear being left with few friends.
"We have very close relations with the Turkic republics of the Caucasus and Central Asia, and very good relations with Balkan countries except Greece," he said. "Turkey will not be isolated. But nobody should believe that Turkey will be forced to accept some unacceptable formulas just to enter the European Union."
At its meeting in Luxembourg over the weekend, the European Union agreed to open membership negotiations with 11 of its 12 applicants. But it offered Turkey only a vaguely defined "strategy of rapprochement" and said it should improve its human rights record and treatment of minorities as well as compromise on issues related to Greece and Cyprus.
The United States has been pressing the European Union to admit Turkey, which American officials believe must remain a key strategic partner of the West. European leaders are reluctant, fearing the high cost of admitting such a large and turbulent nation as well as the number of Turks who might flood into their countries. Some have also wondered aloud if a Muslim country can be considered part of Europe.
In an interview in his office today, Mr. Yilmaz said of the European Union's action: "We reject these preconditions. The aspect of the Luxembourg summit that disturbed us the most is that certain Central and Eastern European countries that are behind us economically and that only began taking steps toward democracy in the last five or six years were given a status ahead of ours.
"For those countries, including Cyprus, there is a very clear prospect of membership, and even a timetable. For Turkey there is none. We see this as very clear discrimination. If the European Union persists in such discrimination, we will have no place in such an organization."
Mr. Yilmaz, who heads a shaky five-month-old minority Government committed to secularism, said the reasons European leaders gave for turning aside Turkey's application were "not the real reason." Asked what the real reason is, he replied, "Religious discrimination, of course."
"So we come to the conclusion that even if we meet all the conditions being put to us, the real argument against our membership will still be there," he said. "The most important decision in Luxembourg, I believe, is the construction of a new Berlin wall, a cultural Berlin wall."
In freezing its relations with the European Union, Mr. Yilmaz said, Turkey will no longer discuss political questions, including the Cyprus issue, with its representatives. He also said Turkey would stop cooperating with delegations from the Union or the European Parliament that come here to study the human rights issue or the war against Kurdish insurgents.
He charged that the European Union had in effect taken the Greek side in disputes over Cyprus and Greek-Turkish relations, a posture he called "impossible to accept."
He said that by deciding this weekend to open membership talks with the pro-Greek Government of Cyprus, the union "will also be responsible for negative developments on the island from now on."
Mr. Yilmaz praised the United States for having "a strategic point of view, unlike the European Union." But when asked how he would like a new partnership between Turkey and the United States to develop, he said only that he wanted the American side to lower tariffs on Turkish textiles and to support construction of an oil pipeline across Turkish territory.
Although American officials have quietly urged their Turkish counterparts to make some concessions on issues raised by human rights advocates, Mr. Yilmaz offered none today. He said he could not interfere with a court that seems to be preparing to ban the country's largest political party on the ground that it foments Islamic fundamentalism. He also described the country's most prominent prisoner, Leyla Zana, a Kurdish nationalist and former member of Parliament, as a confessed terrorist, evidently crushing hopes that she might soon be released.
The European Union has for years refused to act on Turkey's application for membership, and few were surprised by the outcome of the Luxembourg meeting. Several European leaders urged Turkey to embrace the proffered "strategy of rapprochement," but a member of the European Parliament who closely follows Turkish affairs, Claudia Roth, said the offer showed the union's "determination to hold Turkey at bay."
On the eve of the meeting, the host, Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg, spoke bluntly about Turkey's prospects. He said Turkey "has a place in the E.U., but this will take decades."
"It cannot be that the representatives of a country in which torture is still going on can sit at the table of the European Union," Mr. Juncker said on Thursday. "I do not believe the human rights problems can be solved in three to five years."
A Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman rejected Mr. Juncker's comments as "unacceptable, baseless, humiliating, deplorable."
Mr. Yilmaz's four-day visit to the United States, which will begin in New York on Wednesday and end in Washington on Sunday, is to be packed with meetings. Three American Jewish organizations will present him with an award, partly a gesture of thanks for his role in moving Turkey into a close partnership with Israel. He will visit the stock market, meet senior Administration officials and energy company executives, appear on television programs and have brunch with former President George Bush.

HEADLINE: Rosemarie Rogers, 61, Refugee Migration Expert

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Rosemarie Rogers, a scholar of international migrations and former academic dean at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, died on Nov. 28 at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 61.
The cause was multiple myeloma, a form of bone-marrow cancer, said her husband, Peter P. Rogers, a professor of environmental engineering at Harvard University. 
 Dr. Rogers was a native of Austria, and her fluency in several languages led her to a career in international relations. She lectured in political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology before moving to the Fletcher School, where she advanced to a full professorship and served as academic dean from 1985 to 1987.
Her more than 50 papers, monographs, book chapters and books reflected her research on international migrations, including forced migrations and refugee policies.
At her death she was completing a comparative study of the migration policy of six Western European countries. In it she documented the difficulties host countries have, on the one hand, encouraging migrants to return home, and on the other, integrating them into their own societies.
Her recent research was foreshadowed in an earlier book, "Guests Come to Stay: The Effects of European Labor Migration on Sending and Receiving Countries" (1985). Another volume, written with Emily Copeland, "Forced Migration: Policy Issues in the Post-Cold War World" (1993), was widely distributed by the United Nations High Commission on Refugees and various national governments.
Dr. Rogers was born Rosemarie Straussnigg in Klagenfurt, Austria, and studied at the Universities of Vienna and Innsbruck, the University of Texas and the Sorbonne. She settled in the United States in 1958 and earned a doctorate in political science at M.I.T. in 1967.
She served on the board of the World Peace Foundation.
Besides her husband, Dr. Rogers is survived by two sons, Christopher, of Cambridge, and Justin, of Albuquerque, N.M.

HEADLINE: Calls Rising For Food And Housing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Despite a surging economy and low unemployment, the demand for emergency food and shelter continued to grow this year, the Conference of Mayors said today.
A conference survey of 29 cities, to be released on Monday, said that requests for emergency food rose an average of 16 percent, the largest increase since 1992, the survey found. Among the reasons, officials said, were low wages and high housing costs. Nearly all the cities expected demand for food and shelter to rise next year as well. 
 Requests for emergency housing, however, were up just 3 percent, the smallest increase in the survey's 13-year history. Of the homeless population, about 47 percent were single men, 36 percent families with children, 14 percent single women, and 4 percent minors, the survey found.
The study, based on self-reporting by the cities, which varied widely in detail, found that: emergency food assistance requests increased in 24 of the 29 cities; about one-fifth of emergency food help demands was estimated to have been unfulfilled, and 17 cities had increases in shelter requests, while the number of emergency shelter beds decreased an average of 3 percent in all of the cities.
Only Alexandria, Va., and Charlotte, N.C., reported that no food assistance request went unanswered. And Charleston, S.C., reported a 23 percent reduction in shelter demand by single adults, because the city said it provided "an array of services in an accessible location."
More common, however, were reports of fewer beds and tougher eligibility requirements.
"Admission criteria to emergency shelter has been tightened, and the word is out that emergency shelter is not an option that a needy person can depend on," St. Paul officials reported. "So many do not ask."
Other cities surveyed were Boston; Chicago; Cleveland; Denver; Detroit; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Louisville, Ky.; Miami; Minneapolis; Nashville; New Orleans; Norfolk, Va.; Philadelphia; Phoenix; Portland, Ore.; Providence, R.I.; St. Louis; Salt Lake City; San Antonio; San Diego; San Francisco; Santa Monica, Calif.; Seattle, and Trenton.

HEADLINE: Thailand Economic Crash Crushes Working Poor

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PATHUM THANI, Thailand, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Six weeks ago, the seamstresses at the P.A.R. Garment Factory here on the outskirts of Bangkok arrived at work to find a sign on the gate that read: "The company is closed."
Uniformed guards told them to go home. The factory was bankrupt. But many of the workers -- migrants from poor rural areas -- had nowhere else to go. 
 So they stayed, sleeping on straw mats on the sidewalk by the factory gate, waiting for some stroke of good fortune they know will never come.
"We can't find work at another factory because other factories are closing too," said Song Siwang, a 37-year-old seamstress. "And we don't want to go back to our home villages because there is no work there either."
Since the summer, Thailand and its Southeast Asian neighbors have been gripped by the region's worst economic crisis in decades. Currencies and stock markets are plummeting, banks and businesses are closing and jobs are being lost by the hundreds of thousands.
The 449 people at the factory here who lost their jobs here are among some four million rural migrants who flooded into the capital during the last decade, when Thailand had one of the world's fastest-growing economies and everybody dreamed of riches.
"I came to Bangkok because I thought life here would be wonderful," said Suthasini Keoleklai, 29. "I thought I would make a lot of money and be a wealthy person."
Now she and the other workers here -- still as poor as ever -- are part of the first wave of layoffs in an economic catastrophe that could cost two million jobs by the end of next year, according to Pasuk Phongpaichit, an economist at Chulalongkorn University.
Their story is the story of poor workers throughout Southeast Asia who in growing numbers are expected to lose their jobs in the months to come, some of the last to benefit and the first to suffer in the region's economic rise and fall.
Ms. Pasuk is co-author of a book published last year titled "Thailand's Boom!" (Silkworm Books) in which she describes the astonishing transformation of this rural nation into an exemplar of the "Asian miracle," with 8 percent annual growth, thriving new industries and an expanding middle class.
Few nations have experienced the kind of building spree that turned Bangkok's skyline, in a blink, into a chaos of odd-shaped towers. Few have indulged like Thailand in car-buying: it is one of the world's leading markets for Mercedes-Benz sedans and the leading purchaser, after the United States, of pickup trucks.
But there was always an underside to the boom: fully 60 percent of the country's 60 million people remained poor. Half the nation's wealth was in the hands of its richest 10 percent. The disparity in income between the country's rich and poor became one of the five sharpest in the world, according to World Bank figures.
Throughout the region, to varying degrees, economic growth has brought the greatest benefits to a privileged few. The poor majority often gained better health care and better social services, but they remained poor.
Miss Suthasini, who came to work at the P.A.R. Garment Factory a decade ago, has lived this side of Thailand's boom.
"In these 10 years my country has grown rich," she said, "but not me. Nothing for me has improved."
She earned the minimum wage on her first day of work 10 years ago and she earned the minimum wage on her last day, last month. Far from making her wealthy, her salary of $3.50 a day was not even enough to cover her basic needs.
Like the bankers and property developers whose profligacy helped cause the country's crash, Miss Suthasini has been left not only jobless but also in debt. She owes $40, or nearly two weeks' pay.
Beyond this, she has little to show for Thailand's economic boom.
The lives of the country's new middle class have been transformed by their new wealth. Even if they lose their jobs, they have new homes, new cars, a new appreciation for wine. But the people who worked at the P.A.R. Garment Factory have been left with almost nothing.
"The role of the poor in the boom has been to create the wealth," said Ji Ungpakorn, a political scientist at Chulalongkorn. "Now when the boom turns to slump, some of them will be cast aside, and they have nothing to cushion them at all."
Miss Song is one of 10 children in a farming family in Thailand's poor northeast, a region that suffers chronically from a cycle of drought and flood. All but one of her siblings also migrated to Bangkok -- the sisters as factory workers, the brothers as drivers.
"These were the only jobs we could get," she said. "None of us finished elementary school."
"I love sewing," she said. But she had only four years of schooling and she could not read the labels on the garments she made for Gap, Nike and London Fog. She is not unusual. Eighty percent of the country's work force has not progressed beyond elementary school.
As Thailand searches for silver linings in its time of hardship, a mood of nostalgia has emerged. These hard-pressed factory workers can return to their farms, people say, and to the gentle traditions of former times.
This is an illusion, said Mr. Ji, the political scientist. "The past is gone."
The boom years transformed the country's farms and villages as well, tying them more closely than ever to the economy of the cities. In many places, Ms. Pasuk said, much of the rural population depends on the earnings of family members in Bangkok.
"We came to the city to work and send money home to our parents," said Miss Song. "Now we are losing our jobs. Who will support my family? If I go home, who will support me?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Since the summer, Thailand has experienced its worst economic crisis in decades. Laid-off workers waited outside the P.A.R. Garment Factory in Pathum Thani, which went bankrupt more than a month ago. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)
 
Map of Thailand showing the location of Pathum Thani: A factory closing in Pathum Thani left workers with nowhere to go.

HEADLINE: IRANIAN PRESIDENT CALLS FOR OPENING DIALOGUE WITH U.S.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14

 BODY:
President Mohammed Khatami of Iran aimed a conciliatory message at the United States today, saying that he hoped to re-establish a discussion with the American people that has been virtually suspended since the Islamic revolution of 1979.
The tone of Mr. Khatami's remarks, at his first news conference since he took office in August, was markedly different from that usually heard from Iranian leaders. He declared "great respect" for the "great people of the United States" and even his criticism of the Government in Washington, which he said stood in the way of possible reconciliation, was restrained. 
 "I hope the American politicians would understand their time better, understand the realities, and move forward," Mr. Khatami said.
At the "appropriate" time, he said, "I will present my words to the American people."
"I would hope for a thoughtful dialogue with the American people and through this thoughtful dialogue we could get closer to peace and security and tranquillity," he added.
But the Iranian President stopped short of saying that he expected renewed official contacts between the two Governments, and he did not spell out how he intended to reestablish this dialogue with Americans.
Mr. Khatami, 55, a Shiite Muslim cleric who won a landslide victory last May over a candidate supported by the country's religious establishment, is generally regarded as the most moderate official to emerge in Iran's top ranks of power since shortly after the revolution, which overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi.
The United States severed its relations with Iran after Islamic revolutionaries seized the American Embassy in 1979 and held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days. The two states, close allies while the Shah was in power, have remained hostile ever since, and the United States has tried with little success to enlist allies in isolating Iran through political and economic sanctions.
American officials have said they have been watching closely for signs that Mr. Khatami's triumph might mark a shift in Iran's orientation toward the United States, and his remarks were certain to be scrutinized by the State Department and other agencies that have been reviewing policy toward Iran.
 In Washington, a State Department spokesman, James B. Foley, cautioned that "it's too early to tell whether this represents an offer or not." He said the United States has been "open to a dialogue" with Iran, but has "stipulated that the dialogue would have to be official and authoritative, acknowledged publicly by the Iranian Government."
 If such a dialogue occurred, Mr. Foley said: "We would certainly be raising with the Iranians our concern about aspects of their foreign policy, which are deeply troubling to us, concerning weapons of mass destruction and terrorism and the like. But we are open to a dialogue and would expect they could raise issues of concern to them as well."
President Khatami has generally adopted a low profile since he took office in August, rarely speaking out either to reporters or to the Iranian public. His more conciliatory approach has been somewhat overshadowed by the fiercely anti-Western pronouncements of other Iranian leaders, including an address delivered last week to an Islamic conference here by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader.
Aides to Mr. Khatami say he has been wary of saying anything that might promote a backlash among Iranian conservatives. They also concede that it remains unclear how much influence the new President can wield within Iran's complicated power structure, particularly regarding foreign policy.
But Mr. Khatami clearly intended that today's remarks be widely heard. In addition to Iranians, his audience included several dozen journalists from the United States, Europe and Arab countries who had been granted visas to cover last week's Islamic conference.
As he answered reporters' questions for more than an hour, Mr. Khatami sounded a fresh tone, even suggesting that it was "a source of sorrow" to him that the United States and Iran had not done more to patch up their differences in the nearly 19 years since the revolution.
He said that the "first step" toward a dialogue would be for American politicians to "understand their own time" and recognize that it was a mistake to maintain their efforts to isolate Iran.
"Instead of talking with forked tongues we want to have a rational dialogue," Mr. Khatami said. "We want to have a dialogue of civilizations."
Mr. Khatami's message might help to mute American objections to closer ties with Iran, but there was little in what he had to say that appeared sufficient to allay what have been the United States' principal concerns.
He did not address allegations that Iran is attempting to acquire nuclear weapons, a charge that his country has repeatedly denied in the past. He said Iran was opposed to terrorism, but made an exception for "the legitimate defense of people in occupied land," thus offering an implicit justification of Iran's support for Hezbollah and other militant groups fighting against Israeli occupation.
And while he said that Iran was "not going to take any action" against a broader peace in the Middle East, he criticized as unjust the approach being promoted by the United States. Mr. Khatami singled out Israel and its "Zionist regime" as "the only country which we do not recognize these days." His reference was not merely to Iran's lack of diplomatic relations with Israel, but to the latter's legitimacy as a state. The other country Iran previously placed in this category was apartheid-era South Africa.
But the overall thrust of Mr. Khatami's message toward the United States was both warmer and more specific than anything that even he has had to say in the past, and it appeared to mark a new phase in Iranian efforts to mend fences with old foes.
In the last month alone, the Iranian President noted, Iran and the European Union have patched up differences that had resulted in the withdrawal of the European ambassadors, while its playing host to the Islamic conference helped Iran to begin rebuilding ties with neighbors like Saudi Arabia and Egypt.
The Islamic conference, attended by representatives of 54 countries, proved that Iran is not isolated, Mr. Khatami said.
In calling Washington's attempts to ostracize Iran dated, Mr. Khatami cited in particular an American law that calls for sanctions against companies worldwide that invest more than $20 million a year in Iran's energy industry. A consortium of French, Malaysian and Russian firms recently defied the law by signing a $2 billion contract for investment in Iran's natural gas industry.

HEADLINE: In Bosnia, U.S. Shouldn't Be Choosing Sides

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Now that the party of Biljana Plavsic, the Bosnian Serb president, has lost its hold on the National Assembly of the Serb enclave in Bosnia, to whom will the United States turn to influence peaceful policy in the region (news article, Dec. 8)? 
 As a supervisor for election monitoring in the Serb Republic of Bosnia conducted by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe last month, I witnessed developments there firsthand since since the war ended.
Unemployment is upward of 90 percent. Factories and mines, shut down during fighting, operate at 5 percent to 10 percent of prewar capacity. Students attend classes in school buildings in dire need of reconstruction.
As a result of politicians' refusal to assist the international community in indicting Serbs charged with war crimes, people who live in the Serb enclave receive only 6 percent of international aid for reconstruction in Bosnia.
Concentrating democratization efforts on Ms. Plavsic has proved fruitless. Why not focus United States policy on stabilizing a war-torn people rather than on choosing political sides?
 
CARMEN BUTLER
New York, Dec. 9, 1997
