HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
A Tone of Conciliation From Iran's President
President Mohammed Khatami of Iran professed "great respect" for the United States and said he hoped that American politicians would "understand their own time" and stop trying to isolate his country. A1
 
Iranian and American diplomats have been exploring ways to end the civil war in Afghanistan. The meetings, held at the United Nations, began after the moderate Mr. Khatami became Iran's first popularly elected President in August. The talks are aimed at devising a power-sharing arrangement between the militant Taliban movement that controls most of Afghanistan and a loose coalition of resistance leaders in the north of the country. A12 

Hutu Kill 272 in Rwanda Attack
Hutu guerrillas killed 272 people and injured 227 others in a Tutsi refugee camp in Rwanda, leaving behind pamphlets preaching genocide. The attack was part of a campaign apparently aimed at making the country ungovernable. A1
 
Turkey Ends Europe Dialogue
Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey said his Government would freeze its political contacts with the European Union and seek a "strategic partnership" with the United States. The move came after the European Union rejected talks on Turkey becoming a member, and after Islamic leaders at a conference in Iran voted to condemn Turkey for its military ties to Israel. The European Union has criticized Turkey's human rights record. A3
 
Clinton to Visit Troops in Bosnia
President Clinton is planning to go to Bosnia next week to visit American troops before Christmas and to begin building a public case for keeping them there past the current deadline of June, Administration officials said last night. A8
 
Talks May Move Out of Belfast
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland said he and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain would try to invigorate the sluggish Northern Ireland peace talks by moving some of the sessions early next year from Belfast, the northern capital, to Dublin and London. Mr. Ahern also confirmed that he and Mr. Blair were working on a detailed list of proposals for the Protestant and Roman Catholic delegates to the talks. A8
 
Yeltsin Makes Appearance
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia appeared in public in an effort to allay growing doubts about his health. Mr. Yeltsin, 66, spoke at a polling place in a Moscow sanitarium, where he cast his ballot in municipal elections. He said he entered the sanitarium last week after catching a cold. He said that although he felt ill he was alert and that "there is control." A5
 
NATIONAL A14-21
 
U.S. to Announce Rules Governing Organic Foods
The Department of Agriculture will perform an about-face today and announce a sweeping set of proposed regulations that would cover all organically grown food, from the farm to the consumer. The proposed rules would define exactly which products, whether raw or processed, could be labeled organic food. They also set standards for the production and handling of organically grown crops and organically raised meat and poultry -- for example, prohibiting the use of antibiotics in animals, except to treat illness. A1

Tobacco's Lobbying Effort
The nation's five major tobacco producers, led by Philip Morris, will have spent more than $30 million on lobbying by the end of 1997, and are expected to spend far more than that next year, according to Senate records and interviews. The companies' focus is the shaping of comprehensive tobacco legislation that they hope will help shield them from liability claims and raise their corporate share prices on Wall Street. A1

Fraternity Leaders and Drinking
A study reported that fraternity leaders were among the heaviest drinkers and out-of-control partygoers, casting doubt on the efforts by some colleges to have those leaders help curb excessive drinking. A20

Building a Benign Arsenal

HEADLINE: In Turnabout, Housing Authority Will Begin Favoring Jobholders

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The New York City Housing Authority, trying to reverse the concentration of the desperately poor in public housing, will soon begin to favor working families over welfare recipients when it fills vacancies, a move that advocates for the poor say will shut out those who need housing help the most.
The measure follows a nationwide trend in which housing authorities are seeking to lure the working poor back to public housing as an antidote to the economic and social problems that plague many projects. And it comes as Congress is considering a bill that would go much further, repealing the landmark 1937 Federal housing law and cutting roughly in half the number of extremely poor tenants in projects, through attrition. 
 The city's Housing Authority, by far the nation's largest, has long been considered the most successful because it was able to maintain a better balance of working-class and poor tenants than other cities. But over the last decade, it has seen the percentage of tenants with jobs fall to less than a third from nearly half, in part because of Federal and city rule changes favoring the poorest.
Officials assert that the new plan, which a Federal judge recently approved after a two-year court battle, is the only way that the authority can continue to prosper as many other cities either tear down housing projects or watch them devolve into violent warehouses for the poor.
"I sincerely believe," said Ruben Franco, the authority chairman, "this is the one initiative that will have the greatest impact on the stability of the public housing community in this city. Anytime you have too many very poor people living together, with a significant number of social problems, you run into trouble."
Opponents of the new rules say the primary reason the authority wants to favor working applicants is to generate more money as public housing funds from Washington dwindle, not to cut crime at the projects or mend their social fabric.
"They are doing this in response to budget cuts," said Scott Rosenberg, litigation director for the Legal Aid Society of New York, which successfully sued to stop the plan in 21 of the system's 320 projects where it was likely to interfere with a desegregation plan imposed in an earlier court case. He said the system already screened applicants thoroughly to weed out those with criminal backgrounds and other problems. "The real issue is that the Housing Authority is seeking more income by the somewhat perverse means of excluding those in greatest need," he said.
At a time when other housing programs for the poor, like rent subsidies and incentives for building low-income housing, are also being frozen or cut, the Legal Aid Society and housing advocates say the change will be devastating for tens of thousands of applicants on welfare who look to public housing as a way to escape unsafe, overcrowded apartments and cycles of poverty.
The new plan breaks a longstanding policy that gave equal weight to applications from families on public assistance, the elderly and working people. Combined with Federal rules that gave preference to many low-income applicants, the old policy had the unintended effect over the last decade of giving many more vacant apartments in housing projects to welfare recipients. As a result, working families began to find public housing increasingly unattractive.
By 1995, 77 percent of new admissions were people in the lowest income category, while only 8 percent of new applicants were working families. And dozens of projects, like the Coney Island Houses in Brooklyn, became known as virtual dumping grounds for the very poorest.
The change in policy will essentially juggle the order of the top part of a huge waiting list of about 130,000 applicants for the system's 180,000 apartments, 6,000 to 8,000 of which become available every year.
In the 299 projects where Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan said the new plan could proceed, the authority will assign the highest priority code to families whose incomes are near the upper limit of the eligibility cutoff for public housing, which means they are most likely working (for example, a family of four making about $39,000 a year).
The poorer the family is, the lower its priority code will be. But only families with members who are working, are receiving unemployment benefits or are unable to work because of disabilities will be given any priority code at all. The change will also reorder the list of applicants preferred under the Federal rules so that working families will also be favored over welfare recipients.
Because only those people with the highest priority ratings are usually called in for eligibility interviews, housing advocates say the plan will make it next to impossible for anyone not working to get in when the change takes effect early next year, an assertion that Mr. Franco of the Housing Authority disputes.
"It may slow down the availability of some units for some families, but we vehemently disagree that they will never be able to get in," he said, adding that the authority will still honor an agreement with the city to house about 1,400 homeless families a year who are referred from municipal shelters.
Housing officials admit, however, that the change -- along with an advertising campaign planned to try to change working families' perceptions of public housing -- is expected to shift dramatically the income mix in projects over the next decade.
It is a change that officials say many of the 600,000 tenants now in public housing welcome as a way to improve their homes. But tenants and tenant leaders appear to be more ambivalent.
"I have mixed feelings," said Sarah Martin, a tenant leader at Grant Houses in Morningside Heights, Manhattan, who has lived there 40 years. "I know working families who have come and looked at apartments here, and they've turned them down. Long-term welfare people have turned this place around in a very negative way."
But she added that she had also watched some welfare families lift themselves out of poverty with the help of low public housing rents, and she said she worried what would become of such families now. "I wish I had a magic pill to fix that," said Ms. Martin, a retired cafeteria worker and health care assistant who raised five children in public housing. "But I don't."
For many of those without jobs who have been waiting as long as five years for public housing in New York City, word of the changes has brought apprehension and anger and now a degree of despair.
Shawana Gerard, a 25-year-old single mother, lives in a dilapidated two-bedroom apartment in East New York, Brooklyn, with five other family members. At night, she shares her bed with her 2-year-old daughter, as well as with her own younger sister. She says she is forced to subsist on welfare because raising a 2-year-old and attending community college make it impossible to hold a job.
"Before I had my daughter, I had jobs, and now that I have her, I do the best I can do," Ms. Gerard said. "This isn't fair. I put so much time into trying to get into public housing. I was trying to get in there so I could make it."
The changes follow efforts by other large cities like Chicago and Baltimore to try to attract higher-income tenants and are a preview of what could happen on a much greater scale across the country under a sweeping housing bill passed by the House of Representatives last summer.
The bill, sponsored by Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Long Island Republican, has been promoted as the most realistic alternative to save public housing in an era of shrinking housing budgets. It would loosen Federal rules to let housing authorities admit tenants with much higher incomes. It would also retool rent policies so that payments would not necessarily rise along with income, a rule that housing officials say discourages residents from getting off welfare.
Republicans characterize the bill, which will be taken up in a House-Senate conference early next year along with a similar Senate bill, as another major step in their efforts to move more people from welfare to work.
The measure has generated a debate that also cuts to the heart of the changes under way in New York: should such a basic need as housing be used in a carrot-and-stick approach to discourage dependency on government help?
Christopher Jencks, a professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University who has urged more financing for rental subsidy vouchers to help the neediest, said a consensus has grown even among advocates for the poor that housing projects must change directions to survive. But without other forms of government housing help, the poorest who are excluded from public housing will never be able to escape poverty.
"You've either got to put substantial additional resources in here," he said, "or we're at the end of what we can do."
But while the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development views Mr. Lazio's plan as too harsh, HUD officials suggest that housing programs cannot be excluded from the equation of welfare reform. This is especially true, they say, when everyone agrees there will never be enough Federal money for low-income housing for even half of those who need it.
"Housing is a privilege, not necessarily a right," said Sara Manzano, an assistant general counsel for the New York and New Jersey HUD office, which supports the changes in New York City. "We have to decide who gets the preference."

HEADLINE: 'Nutcracker' Dreams vs. Fiscal Reality

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
American dance companies came of age in the "dance boom" decades of the 70's and 80's. With age came new responsibilities. No more seat-of-the-pants operations: to get money from government and private donors, books must be balanced and show a profit, in a field where dreams had long been the currency.
With the 90's, an even sterner reality took hold, far more complicated than hand-to-mouth existence. As government and private support for the arts dwindled with the economy, fiscal responsibility remained the byword, with little diminution of the drive toward corporate-style growth and risk taking. 
 One of the most spectacular and public instances of the collision of dreams and reality came early this year with the news that Donald Byrd's company, called Donald Byrd/The Group, and his new, highly praised "Harlem Nutcracker," which had its New York premiere last December, were in serious financial trouble.
The ambitious production, which was only halfway through a six-week tour, cost $1 million -- more than six times the cost of other recent dances by Mr. Byrd. But the small experimentalist troupe was poised for major success. The choice seemed to be between stagnation and growth. Already heralded as an important American modern-dance choreographer, Mr. Byrd and his "Harlem Nutcracker" had drawn the kind of reviews and full houses that company administrators envisioned would propel him into the first ranks.
The strain of reaching for that next rung up the ladder nearly did the troupe in, plunging it into debt and a yearlong scramble for mere existence. Fortunately, the company won a second chance, and it has mounted another season of "The Harlem Nutcracker," which can be seen in its only performances in the New York area at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark from Thursday through Sunday.
For Mr. Byrd, now 48, "The Harlem Nutcracker" was a work especially close to his heart.
"Since 'The Nutcracker' is such an institution in this country, this was a way of expanding the 'Nutcracker' family by including another group of people," Mr. Byrd said in a recent interview. The choreographer, who is black, placed his production in a Harlem brownstone in modern times. He set "The Harlem Nutcracker" not to the familiar Tchaikovsky music but to the Duke Ellington-Billy Strayhorn "Nutcracker Suite" and a jazz score by David Berger. And he shaped the dance around a grandmother's memories of Christmases shared with her family.
It was the most spectacular production the company had ever attempted. Until "Nutcracker," no Byrd dance had ever cost more than $150,000. Twelve dancers were added to the 10-member company, along with four musicians. There were an astonsihing 500 costumes, with a touring staff of 44 and additional, pickup performers at each stop.
One reviewer described "The Harlem Nutcracker" as an "instant classic." And local producers noted happily that the ballet was drawing new black audiences. Ticket sales were strong.
But reports of problems had begun to circulate by late December 1996, when the troupe appeared in Los Angeles. The mothers of several dancers added for the production called newspapers in New York City, where the Byrd company is based, to complain that their daughters had not been paid. New York-based musicians were said to be prepared to take legal action against the company for unpaid wages. By January, the company acknowledged that it owed creditors $400,000.
 
Fighting a Threat To Its Existence
"The company's very existence was threatened, and still is," said Benjamin Mordecai, the theatrical producer and assistant dean of the Yale School of Drama, who was brought in to run this year's "Harlem Nutcracker" and its six-week tour. Mr. Mordecai has whittled production costs by streamlining last year's cumbersome touring schedule and cutting expenses. "They're not out of the woods yet," he said. "This tour will break even or come close. It is doing a lot to re-establish credibility for the company."
A little over one-third of the debt was paid off before the current tour began, and long-term discounted-payment plans have been arranged for nearly all the rest. Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which picketed the company's June season at the Joyce Theater, recently settled with the company, and last year's touring musicians have returned to the production.
In retrospect, company officials admit, the decisions they made last year may have been misguided, even irresponsible. But at the time there seemed to be little choice. Whatever else, their story suggests the contradictions of success in the arts today, when it is necessary to "act like the big boys," as Mr. Byrd puts it, in order to survive and grow.
In 1991, his company began to seek financial support for a new "Nutcracker." Mr. Byrd had come to dance relatively late, as a drama student at Tufts University, but made up for lost time with intensive training in ballet and modern dance here and abroad. He founded his company in 1978, two years after he began to choreograph, eventually developing a style rooted in classical ballet and modern and black vernacular dance.
By the 1990's, Mr. Byrd had established himself as an innovative creator of charged, high-energy dances with social themes that often touched on racial issues. Modern-dance and ballet companies in the United States and in France, Britain and the Netherlands performed his works. He had choreographed theater and musical productions for the director Peter Sellars and for the New York Shakespeare Festival and Center Stage in Baltimore and was in national demand as a teacher and arts adviser.
 
A Chance to Reach A New Level
In 1995, the company was working 45 weeks a year, with tours in Europe and the United States, mostly in small experimentalist theaters. It seemed ready to climb to the next rung or even higher.
Mr. Byrd began thinking about staging his own "Nutcracker" in 1989 after reading about a performance of the Ellington-Strayhorn score. The holiday classic has proved to be a cash cow for ballet companies, and he saw a chance to address specific issues about black Americans and the family. Government and private sponsors were expressing interest.
The initial production and tour budget was projected at $1 million. The National Endowment for the Arts was in trouble, and major foundations were phasing out or changing programs that supported the performing arts. But it seemed equally clear to Mr. Byrd and his advisers that a successful "Harlem Nutcracker" would in turn generate the money to support new dances and sustain community programs.
The company needed to "heighten its profile," as Elizabeth Powers, who was then executive director, put it. And everyone wanted to give Mr. Byrd the chance to create the piece he dreamed of. "Part of the problem in the dance field in general is that we all want so badly to see the work get made," Ms. Powers said. "If you don't, you have nothing."
A new booking agent was hired in 1995. By the 1995-96 season the operating budget had climbed to $850,000 from $500,000, excluding the tour. Mr. Byrd continued to work on "The Harlem Nutcracker" while the company raised money. It was slow going.
 
An Unusual Practice In the Dance Field
"But we'd been talking about the production for so long that people who were interested in presenting it started to wonder if it were ever going to happen," Mr. Byrd said. "We felt we should take advantage of that interest."
In the early fall of 1995, still short of its goal, the company held workshop performances of the piece, an unusual practice in dance. With a workshop, company officials reasoned, Mr. Byrd, as well as committed backers and fence-straddlers, could get a taste of the production.
As a fund-raising tactic, the company offered presenters co-commissioning credits for $80,000 to $125,000, in addition to performance fees paid to the company. By late spring last year, some $400,000 remained to be raised for start-up costs. With general operating costs and workshop and touring expenses added in, the total budget jumped to $1.8 million. Still, with major corporate and private support in place, the goal seemed tantalizingly close. But there were warning signs.
The expected buzz -- and money -- failed to materialize after the formation of a prestigious national fund-raising committee. The production budget was cut back to $750,000, and the office staff was cut to an overworked two people.
Looking back, Ms. Powers says, she should have been clearer about the problems. "I should have planned differently once the crisis became apparent, around August. But somehow or other I'd been pulling major rabbits out of hats, so I thought I could keep doing it."
The decision was made to go ahead with the tour. "It seemed a reasonable risk," Mr. Byrd said. "Not pie in the sky."
Ticket sales went well everywhere except Minneapolis. But the company, having spent advances from the producers' fees to pay for the production, was not making any money. A further blow occurred when one presenter made a last-minute decision not to pay an expected co-commissioning fee, worried, Mr. Byrd now believes, that the company was in over its head.
A board member helped out with a large loan, later forgiven, but it was not enough. Checks began to bounce in mid-December. "From that point on, the truth was out," Mr. Byrd said.
One problem, common in dance, was that reports of the troupe's sold-out performances convinced potential donors that the company did not need help. And as touring continued, unpaid bills piled up.
"Donald is brilliant, but he does a lot of mind-tripping," said one performer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I'm one of the few who haven't been paid in full. I still haven't seen a penny of my last two paychecks. I could really use that money."
 
Mixed Opinions On Going Ahead
Some have questioned the company's decision to go on. "I think it was definitely better for them to keep going," Mr. Mordecai said. "I don't think they would have been able to raise the money otherwise."
With hindsight, Mr. Byrd admits that the company was not prepared for the huge job of creating "The Harlem Nutcracker" on its own.
"Seeing how smoothly it is going now, I realize we could probably have done this in a better way if we had had more experience," Mr. Byrd said. And he wonders, he said, whether the success of "The Harlem Nutcracker" outweighs its many costs. "But after watching the performance last night, sitting in the house and watching the people with their kids, the grandmothers, all the black families who had come such a long way to see it, I thought, 'Well, maybe it was worth it.' "

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Quieting the Mouth That Roars

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

 BODY:
Wherever he goes and whoever he meets, Kevin Kelley, the World Boxing Union featherweight champion, gets the same question and the same request.
Why is he, a world champion born in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn and raised in Flushing, Queens, getting second billing to Naseem Hamed, a fighter from Sheffield, England, on a boxing card at Madison Square Garden? And can he please knock out Hamed as quickly as possible when the two fight on Friday night for Kelley's crown and Hamed's World Boxing Organization title so that Hamed will shut up already. 
 "My aunt, who is a really religious lady and doesn't speak bad about anybody, called me the other day and said: 'Kevin, I saw those commercials and he's so arrogant and so nasty. That's not God-like. You need to give him a beating. He needs it,' " Kelley said in an interview at a Whitestone, Queens, restaurant on a recent afternoon.
Nothing would give Kelley more pleasure.
"The first round I'm going straight for that mouth," Kelley said. "I've been saving up everything for the bell."
For Kelley, this fight, which will be televised live on HBO as part of its World Championship Boxing series, is business and it's personal.
Hamed, 23, is the highest-paid featherweight in boxing history, with $12 million in purses and endorsements last year. And with his new agreement with HBO, which will pay him a reported $2 million a fight as long as he wins, Hamed has usurped Kelley on the cable network where Kelley has fought seven times.
Kelley believes a victory over Hamed will derail HBO's plans for Hamed and put Kelley in line for bigger paydays. Junior Jones (44-2) will defend his W.B.O. junior featherweight title against Kennedy McKinney (32-3-1) on the undercard.
Kelley, a slugger who describes himself as a fighter first and then a boxer, will be Hamed's toughest opponent to date. If Hamed can weather what Kelley throws at him, then Hamed can indeed thump his chest. The flamboyant Hamed brags without any prompting, and it's that kind of arrogance that rubs many people the wrong way. Toss in his narcissism, and it is like a thumb in the eye.
Here's what Hamed said about fighting Kelley in New York: "I could have brought Kevin Kelley to my own backyard and beat him up there. But I didn't want to do that. I wanted to come to his own backyard and bring him down in front of his own crowd, a place he loves. I've come right to the lion's den, where he's comfortable, where he can make no excuses after he's knocked out."
Kelley is clearly perturbed by Hamed. He cannot understand why HBO is spending $1 million on publicity for this fight to introduce Hamed to the American public. He does not understand why he wasn't able to get the same kind of multifight deal from HBO that Hamed got. The deal puts Hamed, an unknown quantity in the United States, in the same category as such HBO boxing stars as Oscar De La Hoya, Pernell Whitaker, Roy Jones Jr. and Lennox Lewis.
"We signed Hamed because we believe he is a talented fighter, he's very popular internationally and we believe that he can be just as popular here," said Lou DiBella, vice president of programming for HBO.
Hamed, who is of Yemeni descent but was born in Sheffield, has fought mostly in Europe. Hamed is 28-0, with 26 knockouts.
"This represents a great opportunity for Kevin," DiBella said. "He is a terrifically exciting fighter, and he is an HBO fighter. If he beats Hamed, then he will move up to a level of popularity that he didn't have before. If Kevin were to beat Hamed, I don't view it as a waste of money, because Kevin will benefit from the publicity that we've done for Hamed."
Kelley will earn an estimated $500,000 to $600,000 from all sources for this bout.
"I'm not in their economic scheme," Kelley said. "I guess I never was. But I helped make 'Boxing After Dark' popular. I opened the way for guys like Hamed to fight on HBO. I made featherweights popular here. It's like I'm the black sheep of boxing now. I'm the only world champion from New York City who hasn't fought here in five years. I don't get it."
He added: "I think they're jumping the gun with this guy. They're putting too much interest in a guy who no one knows and who is not from this city and who is not even from this country."
Kelley, 30, an only child whose mother is a postal supervisor and whose father is an electrician, is New York through and through. He bought a house in Valley Stream, N.Y., not too far from his old neighborhood in Flushing, Queens. He was a two-time New York Golden Gloves champion as an amateur. He was on the last boxing card at the old Felt Forum at the Garden in 1993.
Even his self-promotion, which began more as a matter of survival than self-absorption, is New York-style kitsch. As a house fighter for the Garden back in the late 1980's, Kelley promoted himself by handing out pencils with his name on them. He still does that, but has added lollipops, cookies, hats, T-shirts and jackets that bear his "Flushing Flash" logo (a red boxing glove grasping two gold lightning bolts). He used to rent a limousine and drive around the city promoting fights. But he refused to do much publicity for this fight against Hamed, because he said he wanted Hamed to have all the pressure.
Kelley has toiled for comparative peanuts for 10 years, has lost only once in 50 fights (47-1-2), but has watched boxers such as De La Hoya and Hamed "fight tuna fishes" and become very wealthy in a short span. He said he did not begrudge Hamed or any other boxer earning money or using shtick but thought they should not earn big money until they fought worthy opponents.
"These guys aren't fighting anybody, and people are throwing tons of money at them," Kelley said.
Kelley's ring record is dotted with tough campaigns, such as his 12-round World Boxing Council title defense against Jesse Benavides in 1994.
But his career has been a struggle. He spent two years as the No. 1-ranked featherweight by all three of the major boxing organizations and never got a title shot; he was 36-0 and 26 years old before he got his first one. He defeated Gregorio Vargas in a 12-round decision on Dec. 4, 1993, to win the W.B.C. crown, which he lost to Alejandro Gonzalez in January 1995.
He hit a low point three years ago when a promoter asked him to fight in a non-televised title bout in Ireland for $25,000. Kelley retired, but came back six months later. Those are the types of things he was thinking about while he toiled in seclusion in the Poconos in preparation for the Hamed fight.
"When I fight, I fight with everything that's in me," Kelley said. "I'm going to hit him with everything that I've ever been hit with. When the bell rings he's going to see me and know that I'm out to hurt him seriously."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Williams Is Hopeful, But Expects A Struggle

BYLINE: By JOHN MARINO 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 14

 BODY:
With no movement in his talks with the Yankees, Bernie Williams acknowledged today that negotiating an acceptable contract with his team would be a tough proposition. But he held out hope that an accord could be reached soon that would keep him playing in New York.
"I expect it to be hard," Williams said. "The kind of contract we're talking about isn't something that gets negotiated every day. It's been my relationship with them during the past years that everything I've ever tried to get, I had to fight for it. So I don't expect this to be anything different." 
 Williams spoke before the start of the fourth annual Carlos Baerga Celebrities Softball Game at Hiram Bithorn Stadium here. He had not publicly discussed his contract situation until this past weekend. The optimism in his comments reflected the diminished rhetoric between Williams and his agent and the Yankees as they near serious negotiations.
"I'm very optimistic about it," WIlliams said. "Hopefully, we'll get something done in the next couple of weeks. I certainly hope that something will be resolved before the season starts, or at least before the arbitration period starts."
Williams backed up the assertions of his agent, Scott Boras, that he has never made specific contract demands. Yankee officials, who made a five-year, $37.5 million offer last season, say Boras has spoken in general terms about a seven-year contract worth $10 million to $11 million a year.
"We've never mentioned any numbers," Williams said. "The only thing that we have asked for is to look at my situation and to compare it with players that have more or less my numbers and my time in the big leagues. And on that basis, make me an offer."
Boras has repeatedly compared Williams to Gary Sheffield, the Marlins outfielder, who signed a six-year, $61 million extension in April and Sammy Sosa, the Cubs outfielder, who signed a four-year, $42.5 million extension.
The Yankees, on the other hand, can use Cleveland's Kenny Lofton and Baltimore's Brady Anderson as comparable in the negotiations; Anderson recently signed a five-year contract that with noninterest-bearing deferred money is worth about $5.6 million a year. Lofton signed a three-year deal worth $8.1 million a year.
Yankees General Manager Bob Watson has said he had been advised that Williams could get $7.5 million in arbitration this year, while some agents contend Williams could get $10 million.
The Yankee center fielder also denied that Boras had caused any problems among Williams and his teammates and Yankee officials.
"There is a reason I hired my attorney," Williams said. "I certainly feel he is one of the best at what he does. You know, he's got a job to do. And his job is to do the best he can working on behalf of Bernie Williams. That doesn't necessarily mean a contract, but the relationship with the club as well. I think he's doing a pretty good job.
"There's been a lot of talk over the past years about him being a rough agent. But if you want one guy in your corner, you want it to be the kind of guy who is able to fight and has a well-made reputation of being a tough guy."
Williams said escalating baseball salaries should not surprise anyone.
"The economics of the game allow the owners, with their competitive nature, to try to outbid themselves in order to get the best personnel available," Williams said. "Fortunately, players are the recipient of that situation. In a way, it's great. I mean, we're living in an era right now that if you stay healthy and keep producing the way the top players are capable of producing, then they've got a chance to stay financially secure for a long while."
Williams said he is staying focused on his preparations for the coming season, and that living in his native Puerto Rico, where he spends most of his time when not playing in New York, has helped him keep things in perspective.
"I know it's been crazy up there," Williams said of the New York news media's coverage of his contract talks with the Yankees. "I'm very fortunate to be down here, and isolating myself a little bit from the situation. I'm spending a lot of time with my family and training very, very hard. I'm making a commitment that I want to be ready for next year and the years to come."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The CARLOS BAERGA celebrities softball game, which drew players like PEDRO MARTINEZ, MOISES ALOU, DAVE JUSTICE and SANDY ALOMAR, has raised more than $120,000 for charities in Puerto Rico over the past three years. This year, for the first time, a portion of the proceeds will be donated to a New York-based organization, the Queens Child Guidance Center.

HEADLINE: Where to Find New Designers' Labels

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO 

 BODY:
Just as designers are constantly seeking new places to sell their clothes, so are stores always on the lookout for new designers. How else can retailers differentiate their wares when the same big lines can be found in just about every store? And how else can they try to stay a step ahead of women's changing demands?
Fashion is a volatile business where standing still can mean economic death, so stores have to replenish stocks frequently to entice customers to make return visits. Offering new labels is one way to get a woman's attention. While exclusivity is not always possible in a highly competitive market, latching on to the next fashion star can give a retailer an inside track on developing an ongoing relationship with a designer. 
 There will always be women who feel safe in clothes like those their peers are wearing, labels that are immediately recognizable to their friends and associates. But to other women, safe means boring. They want to stand out, to be the first with the newest, and they're confident enough to venture into the unknown. And then, of course, there are women who want the latest fashions but either cannot or will not pay high designer prices, and a young designer's clothes are often more affordable.
The trick for retailers is to tempt all these women by presenting them with new design talent that is fresh enough to attract the adventurous and wearable enough to appeal to the timid. They may find this talent in a trade show, an East Village walk-up, an obscure boutique in Paris or simply by opening the office door to an unknown designer with a garment bag (that's how Calvin Klein, among others, got his first break).
"As we go into the millennium, there is a whole new group of designers we weren't familiar with a year ago," said Kal Ruttenstein, the vice president for fashion direction of Bloomingdale's. "The amazing and interesting thing is that they're doing some of the things top designers are doing, like sheer looks with touches of glitter, and doing them in a wearable way, so they can be worn off the runways and out in the evenings."
Some of these young designers are really new in business, while some have been toiling in relative obscurity until a big store gave them a chance.
Rebecca Taylor, a native of New Zealand, has had her own business in New York (in partnership with Elizabeth Hutchens) for just a year, after spending five years as an assistant designer to Cynthia Rowley. She makes dressy dresses and separates with a vaguely vintage air. Bloomingdale's and Barneys New York are selling her clothes.
Paul & Joe is Sophie Albou's two-year-old French label, which started with shirts and now includes a range of sportswear with an element of street style. The company carries the names of Ms. Albou's two sons. Her clothes can be found at Bloomingdale's and Barneys.
Yoshiki Hishinuma was designing clothing, theatrical costumes and home furnishings in Japan for 10 years before taking his fashion collection to Paris in 1992. His signature style involves intricate seaming and crinkled fabrics. The first store to carry his clothing in America, Henri Bendel, has had it for two seasons.
O Zen is a new label by Carla Sozzani, who owns the influential gallery-cum-fashion store 10 Corso Como in Milan, Italy. Her latest endeavor is marked by architectural shapes combined with flowing lines. Barneys New York introduced the line for fall. Henri Bendel will have it for spring.
After five years of designing the successful Parallel sportswear line, Katayone Adeli, who is based in California, started a collection under her own name earlier this year. Her sexy, body-conscious clothes were immediately picked up by major stores, including Bloomingdale's.
Theory, an instantly successful line of stretch sportswear, was brought out earlier this year by Elie Tahari, who is better known for career clothes, and Andrew Rosen, formerly of Anne Klein. It is sold in many major stores and trendy boutiques.
Isabel Marant is a French designer who started in accessories, switched to knitwear and evolved in the last few years into a full-fledged collection of clothing that blurs the line between day and evening. Her clothes are sold at Bendel's, Barneys and Bergdorf Goodman.
Jagoda Kursa, who was born in Poland, works in Paris, making hand-painted, handmade clothing of crinkly, fluttery fabrics. Bendel's will have her dresses and separates for spring.
Mark Kroeker started designing highly detailed and inventive ready-to-wear in New York last year after stints as an art director, interior designer and illustrator. Linda Dresner carries his clothes on an exclusive basis.
Fake is a London-based line of recycled cashmeres designed by Desiree Meyer, who cuts up old sweaters and reassembles them into abstract patterns or variations on the Union Jack. They are available at Barneys.
Cathryn Avison, whose clothes are also sold at Barneys, is a British designer who specializes in elegant dresses and accessories marked by embroidery and cutout work inspired by the 1920's.
Equality is a three-year-old California line designed by Anke Crispen, who is German-born and whose clothing has a vintage look with embroidery and velvet trimmings. It is sold at Barneys and Bloomingdale's.
IS, a five-year-old California company whose designer, Ilana Siboni, is a native of Israel, specializes in unusual fabrics cut into simple shapes. Barneys and Bloomingdale's carry the line.
Although it becomes more difficult each year for a new designer to sustain a business financially, these newcomers are at least getting a chance to take the next big step into label recognition.

HEADLINE: UAL's Results To Top Forecasts

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said today that it expected its fourth-quarter income to exceed analyst estimates.
Shares in UAL rose $5.375, to $89.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 UAL said it expected per-share earnings to beat the $1.58 that analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had forecast.
UAL's chairman, Gerald Greenwald, said that the booking trends for the fourth quarter and 1998 for the airline had not changed, despite the economic situation in Asia. UAL also said it believed that 1998 income would improve on 1997's record results.
While prospects for the Atlantic, Latin American and the South Pacific markets remain positive, the international environment could be more volatile, UAL said.
Revenue growth in the Pacific has been slower than in the United States for much of 1997, and is expected to continue into 1998, the airline said.
UAL said that the airline still faced a number of challenges, including increased costs resulting from recent labor agreements, increased maintenance expenses and the volatility in Asia.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Snow and Cold Hit Mexico, Causing Jump in Coffee Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Coffee prices soared yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after snow and cold temperatures in Mexico raised concern that next year's harvest could be damaged.
On other markets, platinum fell to the lowest price in four and a half years. 
 Over the weekend, freezing temperatures swept into the states of Hidalgo and San Luis Potosi, which grow 4.5 percent of Mexico's coffee. Monterrey, in northern Mexico, recorded its first snowfall in 30 years. Temperatures stayed above freezing in Chiapas, home to about one-third of the nation's crop.
"There could be damage to next year's crop or delays to this year's harvest," said Charles Cronly, a vice president of trading at Harry J. Acer Corporation, a coffee trader in Palisades Park, N.J.
Because of damage from hurricanes this year, Mexico's coffee crop will probably be 5.2 million to 5.5 million bags, down from an estimated 6 million, said Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
The adverse weather comes as shipping delays from Mexico and Colombia have forced roasters to draw down inventories. The Green Coffee Association of New York said after markets closed yesterday that warehouse stockpiles in November were 1.515 million bags, down 25 percent from October. Traders had expected a decline of about 4 percent.
Coffee for March delivery rose 5.55 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $1.8545 a pound, the highest since Sept. 8.
Platinum fell to its lowest price in more than four and half years and palladium reached a three-month low amid expectations that a weak economy would reduce demand from Japan, one of the world's top importing countries.
"Concern about what is going to happen in the Far East is certainly pushing platinum and palladium prices down," said Frank Redden, a trader in Wayne, Pa., for Johnson Matthey, a marketer of precious metals.
Platinum for January delivery fell $8.20, or 2.3 percent, to settle at $352 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for a most-active contract since March 18, 1993. March palladium shed $8.25, or 4.1 percent, to $191 an ounce.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Yen On Japan Business Pessimism

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday after a survey showed that Japanese companies' confidence in the country's economy had severely eroded.
The dollar touched an intraday peak of 131.45 yen, the highest since May 1992, after the Japanese central bank released its business confidence survey, known as the Tankan. The business confidence index fell to a level of -11 from +3 in the previous survey on Oct. 1. The survey figure represents the percentage of companies reporting that conditions are improving, minus the percentage seeing conditions worsening. 
 After the release, the yen recouped some losses as currency traders seemed wary about the expected announcement today of Japanese Government measures aimed at stabilizing the sagging financial system. "It's critical that they come up with a credible way to recapitalize their banks and not just throw all their money into a bailout fund," said Ricardo Gomes, foreign-exchange chief at Republic National Bank.
The dollar also erased earlier gains on the German mark as the mark remained strong against the yen.
"The markets are shifting into holiday mode," Mr. Gomes said. "It's fairly thin. It doesn't take much to move the markets now."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 130.68 yen, up from 130.45 on Friday. It changed hands at 1.7740 marks, down from 1.7753.
Adding to the concern about Japan's economy, the Malaysian ringgit, Thai baht and Indonesian rupiah all dropped to record lows against the dollar yesterday. The Philippine peso and Singapore dollar also fell.
The dollar rose to a nearly two-month high against the British pound as prospects dimmed for another rise in British interest rates. The Bank of England has raised rates five times since May in attempts to slow inflation.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of industrial nations, said yesterday that British economic growth was likely to slow "considerably, to a more sustainable pace" in 1998 and 1999.
The pound was quoted at $1.6316, down from $1.6496. It was the dollar's highest level against the British currency since late in October.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 84.29, but Nasdaq Index Dips

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Cautious investors waded into the stock market yesterday, buying selectively and moving some broad market indexes higher after five consecutive sessions of declines.
But many preferred to stay in the shallow end of the pool, embracing a defensive posture and just purchasing stocks of domestic companies and other concerns they believe are less likely to be severely hurt by Asia's economic woes. 
 Aided by investors' more cautious stance were companies like Allstate and retailers like Costco, Safeway, and Wal-Mart, as well as newspaper companies such as Washington Post and Gannett. In addition, traditional havens like drug and pharmaceutical stocks of Pfizer, American Home Products, Merck, Eli Lilly, Abbott Labs and Schering Plough and Johnson & Johnson finished higher. Lilly, for example, rose 2 1/8, to 65 3/8, while American Home Products gained 2 3/16, to 74 13/16.
A 7.2 percent rise in South Korea's stock market yesterday and news that the Government would allow the country's currency, the won, to float freely did little to ease investors' concerns about the region.
"I'm trying to keep my portfolio as defensive and Asia-proof as possible until the stock market tells me it's safe to come out," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation.
"It's clear that the market has not gotten over its jitters," Mr. Johnson added, saying that investors are still worried that Asia's economic problems will lead to "more bad news announced by American companies." That expectation and concerns about eroding portfolio gains as the year closes, are keeping investors "very cautious about buying something new" this late in the year, said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York.
In these cautious crosscurrents, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 84.29 points, to 7,922.59, a 1.1 percent gain after falling more than 310 points or 3.8 percent last week.
Standard & Poor's 500-company stock index rose 10 points, or 1.1 percent, to 963.39. It also fell more than 3 percent last week.
Despite turnarounds in some previously battered stocks like Intel, Applied Materials, Cisco and Oracle, the Nasdaq composite index just failed to break into positive territory yesterday, ending down 0.02 point at 1,536.56.
And while some technology shares were stronger, several computer-related shares led by the Dell Computer Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation fell again amid renewed concern that the economic crisis in Asia will slow worldwide demand for personal computers next year.
Because of such declines, a growing number of portfolio managers say they are beginning to like some battered technology stocks at these cheaper prices, but few have backed up the rhetoric with purchases.
"Two months ago everything was up equally," said John T. Wilson, a portfolio manager for the $1.8 billion State Street Research Investment Trust. But "now defensive stocks are up and some technology stocks are on sale" and investment decisions are "less clear now. Do you really want to be selling Compaq in the 50's when its fallen from almost 80 and putting it into Bell Atlantic which has risen from the high 50's into the 90's?"
"Some of the risk has come out of technology and some defensive stocks are not as attractive," he said, but "no one wants to do anything too brave or too Draconian at year-end."
"If you could see some stability in the technology sector and the Pacific Rim, then people would put money to work," said Michael W. Clark, a managing director and head of United States equity trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "But that's a big if."

HEADLINE: Albright in Africa: The Embraceable Regimes?

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Dec. 15

 BODY:
When Madeleine K. Albright flew to Africa last week to begin her first tour of the continent as Secretary of State, the aim was to open a new era in relations by embracing a "new generation" of leaders that Washington has cited as examples for others to follow.
But by the time Ms. Albright flew from Zimbabwe to Europe today, at the end of her seven-nation tour, events throughout her visit -- like the questions she faced from audiences here and there -- served instead to cast doubt on Washington's new African choices. 
 Ms. Albright made obligatory references to the need for democracy in almost every country she visited, but African commentators and critics of the Administration's new Africa policy noted that her very choice of countries seemed to undermine any American emphasis on democratic development in a continent still struggling with a heavy legacy of dictatorship.
Except for South Africa, power was won by the gun in every country Ms. Albright visited. And although Africa is not lacking in fragile but reasonably well-functioning democracies, Ms. Albright's visit with Nelson Mandela was her only meeting with an incontestably democratic leader.
In Congo, the centerpiece of Ms. Albright's tour, bitterness over her itinerary was particularly sharp. Congolese opposition leaders complained that Washington and the West generally gave only tepid support to their democratic struggle against the three-decade dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko, who finally fled an armed revolt in his country -- then called Zaire -- and died in exile earlier this year.
And once Mr. Mobutu was seriously threatened, Washington and many other Western capitals enthusiastically backed the rebel leader who overthrew him in the spring and who has since become President, Laurent Kabila.
"Frankly, we are somewhat confused by the signals Washington is sending to Africa these days," said Serge Kalonji, a Congolese opposition leader. "For years we were lectured about the virtues of democracy and the need for the rule of law, and we took this to heart. But in reality, if you want to get Washington's attention and respect, you are better off picking up the gun."
During their stop in Congo, as they did with other leaders throughout the trip, Ms. Albright and her entourage steadfastly played down Mr. Kabila's democratic and human rights shortcomings. Ms. Albright's announced tactic of "listening more and talking less" ultimately led to embarrassment, when Mr. Kabila gave a mocking performance at their joint news conference. Warning that he would continue to imprison his opponents, he smirked as he sarcastically pronounced "Vive la democratie" at the event's conclusion.
Ms. Albright was generous in her expressions of regret for serious flaws in Washington's past policies, notably its long support for Mr. Mobutu, and for its failure to react swiftly to the Rwandan blood bath, which saw half a million members of the Tutsi minority and some moderate Hutu there killed by the Hutu majority.
Critics of Washington's new approach say Ms. Albright's Africa team must go further still, if it is to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past.
Washington's support or opposition to African leaders in the past was based almost entirely on cold-war calculations of national security and access to mineral wealth.
But, even absent the cold war, some critics say that Washington's new policies eerily mimic those of the past. Like Washington's discredited old allies, the new favorites on the continent -- leaders like Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Meles Zenawi in Ethiopia and Gen. Paul Kagame in Rwanda -- have been embraced largely for security reasons.
Mr. Museveni and his counterparts in Ethiopia and Eritrea are closely cooperating in an American-supported bid to unseat a strict Islamic Government in the Sudan that has for years tried to impose Islamic law on a non-Muslim south, and that Washington accuses of supporting international terrorism.
Washington's new allies in Rwanda and Congo, meanwhile, are counted on to keep a lid their countries, which are seen as potentially explosive, and therefore costly. But in each country, events during Ms. Albright's visit only underlined the precariousness of the United States' bet.
As Ms. Albright was leaving Rwanda, Hutu militiamen attacked a camp of Tutsi refugees in the country's northwest, killing hundreds. The same day, armed rebels overran Bukavu, a major provincial city in eastern Congo.
During her stop there, Ms. Albright expressed sympathy and understanding for Rwanda's leaders, who are mostly Tutsi and remain deeply scarred by the 1994 killing frenzy waged against their minority, who make up only 15 percent of Rwanda's people.
Left unaddressed, critics of Washington's policy say, is whether reconciliation in Rwanda can ever be achieved under minority military rule, or if United States support for the Tutsi Government is merely delaying another violent day of reckoning by a disenfranchised and angry Hutu majority.
While some of Washington's new African allies have begun to rehabilitate their devastated economies, they have been far slower to reform their methods of governing. Free elections are unheard of, and the arrest of journalists and other human rights abuses are common.
In official briefing papers for Ms. Albright's trip, shortcomings like these were neatly glossed over. Mr. Museveni in Uganda, for example, who does not permit multiparty politics, was called a "beacon of hope" who runs a "uni-party democracy."
Elsewhere in Africa, where multiparty elections are regularly held under international pressure, albeit often with flawed results, the American praise for Uganda was met with harsh criticism. Some saw the approach as hypocritical and patronizing, charging that the policy said, in effect, that the West does not expect Africans to uphold widely held standards of democracy or human rights that are emphasized in other parts of the world.
"In the 1960's, many American experts on Africa were supporting one-party states, citing Africa's supposed specificity," said Peter Rosenblum, projects director of the Harvard Human Rights Project.
"Today, we seem deeply unbothered by the widespread rights violations in Ethiopia, the failure of Uganda to secure the rule of law, or by the creation of a Tutsi military ethnocracy in Rwanda," he added. "In Congo, people in the Administration resent questions about human rights."

HEADLINE: U.S. Production Increased By 0.8% During November

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities surged eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, propelled by increases in the output of computers and motor vehicles.
The seasonally adjusted advance pushed the industrial operating rate of capacity to 83.2 percent, the highest rate since September 1995, from 82.9 percent, the Federal Reserve said today. 
 Though relatively high, that rate does not necessarily signal the development of inflationary bottlenecks, analysts said. That's because slacker economies, mainly in Asia, have left plenty of capacity worldwide to produce most manufactured goods.
Today's report comes just one day before Federal Reserve policy makers gather to set short-term interest rates. Most economists believe the Fed will opt to hold rates steady into early next year.
The November production advance was the sharpest since July and marked the 20th month without a decline.
"Information processing equipment and parts used in high-technology equipment contributed notably to the gain," the Federal Reserve said. "In addition, the production of motor vehicles, which had declined some in October, increased sharply."
Output of appliances, carpeting, furniture, aircraft, chemical products, construction supplies, lumber, electrical machinery and food products rose, too.
Production at factories alone rose 1 percent, the best gain since April 1996. Output at mines and oil wells fell two-tenths of 1 percent and at utilities, nine-tenths of percent.
Output of business equipment rose 1.5 percent after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Within that category, output of computer and office equipment rose 1.8 percent, while production of information processing equipment increased 1.1 percent, the Fed said.
Output of consumer durable goods increased an adjusted 2.5 percent after falling seven-tenths of 1 percent. Materials output rose an adjusted seven-tenths of 1 percent after increasing five-tenths in October.

HEADLINE: Dominicans, Scrabbling for Hope;
As Poverty Rises, More Women Head the Households

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
On a white counter in Josefina Disla's tiny kitchen a place of honor is reserved for a small ceramic statue of Our Lady of Charity, who, legend has it, saved three drowning fishermen from a Caribbean storm in the 17th century. La Virgen de la Caridad, as she is known to believers, is said to save those who have lost all hope.
In Ms. Disla's kitchen, the virgin is submerged in a crystal bowl filled with water and surrounded by hundreds of pennies. Each penny represents a wish: health for her three children, ages 14, 15 and 19, and for her 3-year-old granddaughter; jobs, mostly cleaning other people's homes and taking care of their children, and, more and more these days, a fervent prayer that her older daughter will not end up like her, a poor, single Dominican immigrant mother in a strange land. 
 Fervent though her prayers may be, she is up against daunting probabilities.
A growing share of New York City's Dominican households -- roughly half, according to a new study -- are headed by women. Like Josefina Disla, they are mostly single mothers confronting language barriers and a shortage of jobs for unskilled workers, and their lives, sociologists say, go a long way toward explaining the rising and alarming poverty of the city's Dominican community.
Dominicans are hardly alone at this intersection of single motherhood and economic distress. But nowhere is the phenomenon more common than among Dominicans, the largest and fastest-growing immigrant group in the city.
The reasons, experts say, are complex. Many are common to most immigrant groups; indeed, the process of immigration can often leave families in shreds -- by its very nature and because of legal vagaries that allow one member of a couple to get a visa but not the other.
But the Dominican family also faces special stresses, rooted in the national culture and in the extraordinarily fluid way in which Dominicans move between homeland and new land.
Ms. Disla's family had been scraping by together in the Dominican Republic until 1989, when her husband traveled to New York in search of a better-paying job. Ms. Disla and her children waited five more years for visas. When they arrived, they found that time had taken its toll. Ms. Disla's husband had started a new family with another woman. Soon after, he returned to the Dominican Republic, leaving Ms. Disla and their children alone in Washington Heights.
"We were a normal family before," said Ms. Disla's 19-year-old daughter, Elba Bautista, already a single mother herself. "I went a little crazy here. We all did."
Ms. Disla does not blame the United States for her husband's infidelity or the crumbling of her family. Instead, she points to the plight of immigrants, who, in their desperation to abandon the poverty of their own country, sometimes are willing to sacrifice the family unit for the opportunity to live in the United States.
Many arrive in New York alone, hoping to support the children and partners left behind in the Dominican Republic. Others say that once established here they plan to bring the rest of the family over.
Studies show how poverty among Dominican households in New York City is rising with the increase in the percentage of households headed by women. One released last month by professors from City College and Columbia University and based on an analysis of annual census surveys found that 49 percent of the city's Dominican households were headed by women, compared with an average of 25.6 percent for the city as a whole. At the same time, the study found that the poverty rate among Dominicans, 45.7, was almost double the overall poverty rate in the city last year (23.8 percent).
"The two go hand in hand," said one of the two principal researchers, Prof. Ramona Hernandez, a sociologist at CUNY. "When there are no fathers at home and when there are no good paying jobs for women, there is going to be poverty."
Indeed, another study, by the Citizens Committee for Children of New York, a privately funded nonprofit organization, shows that just over half of the children (50.9 percent) in Washington Heights, a predominantly Dominican neighborhood, receive public assistance. The citywide average is 33.8 percent. City statisticians have found that in 1990 a higher percentage of Dominican households received public assistance than any other immigrant group except for people from the former Soviet Union.
Professor Hernandez said that, aside from immigration, other issues conspired against the Dominican family. Traditionally, she said, some poor Dominicans have shied away from marriage because it is just too expensive and cumbersome to have a formal wedding and because, for many people in the Dominican Republic, there is little shame attached to a couple living together outside of marriage. In many cases, though, economic pressures drive men away, and the women are left destitute and with no legal rights to protect them.
"In our culture, the men are supposed to be providers," she said. "When the men can't do that, when they try and try and can't find jobs, they simply pack up and leave. Better to do that than to face the daily consequences of their failure. It happens back home, and it obviously is happening here, too. And then it's the women who have to pick up the pieces."
When her husband left, Ms. Disla, who had never worked outside the home, found herself with three young children and no way to support them. The jobs she found did not pay enough to allow her to afford child care. Ms. Disla was forced to solicit public assistance and find odd jobs, cleaning homes and baby-sitting.
Ms. Disla, who owned a home in Santo Domingo, the Dominican capital, lives in a one-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights. Welfare checks and food stamps -- about $600 a month -- pay for part of her rent and for the food she puts on the table every day. Medicaid pays for her children's and granddaughter's medical bills and even for the insulin shots that keep her diabetes under control.
At 39, Ms. Disla is often depressed and sometimes unable to get out of bed. Without the support of her husband, she cannot live in the Dominican Republic. If she remains here, she can at least hope that her children will have better opportunities and that welfare checks will help to support her family. Already, her older daughter, Ms. Bautista, is studying English and hopes to become a bookkeeper.
Women like Ms. Bautista are sometimes aided by community organizations, such as the Alianza Dominicana and the Dominican Women's Development Center, which train them to become self-sufficient. But with limited resources and a constant stream of new immigrants needing services, agency workers say they barely scratch the surface.
"The numbers are certainly alarming, and so are the needs," said Ydanis Rodriguez, executive director of the Union of Young Dominicans, a group of professionals who are forming committees to study the problems of Dominican immigrants and who plan to seek the help of wealthy Dominicans, such as the fashion designer Oscar de la Renta and Juan Luis Guerra, a musician. "But the worst part, really, is the lack of hope: the belief that some of the poorest in our community have that, no matter what they do, they are not going to get out of where they are now."
Frida Marte, a member of Mr. Rodriguez's group, sees the consequences of poverty every day. She is a teacher at George Washington High School, where the majority of the students come from the Dominican Republic. Most of her students live only with their mothers, she said, and many do not even know their fathers. They come from poor households, where the mothers have to work two and three jobs just to feed the children and pay the rent. Many are at risk -- from quitting school to committing crimes to suicide. Recently, three George Washington students were arrested and charged with kidnapping and killing Nelson G. Gross, a New Jersey millionaire businessman. Last year, five girls attempted suicide, she said.
Ms. Marte may well understand her students perhaps better than most teachers. She is a single mother of two children, a 14-year-old girl and a 3-year-old boy. The children have different fathers. Ms. Marte, who came from the Dominican Republic in 1970, when she was 10 years old, said she chose not to marry her first partner. The second time she married her child's father but he, too, left. Neither one of her children's fathers helps support them.
Ms. Marte leans on her family for help in buying clothing and winter shoes for the children. Yet, she says she feels lucky. Compared with the lives of her students, her children are fortunate that she has an education and a good job.
"I see how my students suffer every day," Ms. Marte said. "And it all starts with the home and their lack of self-esteem."
How her children view their lives and themselves is Argentina Urena's main preoccupation. A psychology student when she was in college in the Dominican Republic, she is particularly aware of her children's needs and how the fact that she is a single mother may affect them. These days, though, her boys, 8 and 12, seem to be more worried about how she makes a living than about their absent father, who left the family seven years ago.
Ms. Urena, who came to the United States 14 years ago, following her boyfriend, sells empanadas and other Dominican pastries and cold drinks in the streets every morning and makes gift baskets in a New Jersey factory the rest of the day. Her days begin at 6:30. Dressed for business, which in cold weather entails hiking boots, two pairs of pants, a knit cap and five layers of sweaters, she pushes her cart up and down St. Nicholas Avenue from 8 A.M. until noon. Three hours later, she is at the factory, where she works until midnight, making $6.17 an hour.
Her older son, Luis Javier, wants her to give up the empanada business and get another job, in an office or a house, anywhere but the streets. On Sundays, he reads the classified advertisements in the newspapers and suggests that she apply for some of the jobs. Ms. Urena has applied to several but has had no luck so far. Her younger son, Yadiel, recently punched a classmate who made fun of his mother on the school bus, chanting, "Quipe, quipe!" the name of a pastry Ms. Urena sells for $1.
Ms. Urena, 34, says she no longer thinks of what is best for her. She concentrates on her children's future and, while returning to the Dominican Republic remains a dream, she says she will not. "My children are American," she said. "This is their country, and this is what is best for them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fellyesterday as stocks gained on upbeat news from Korea over the weekend.
The 30-year bond fell 21/32, to 102 6/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.97 percent, from 5.92 percent on Friday. 
 Traders said signs of a return to global stock market stability could signal the end of the flight to quality that fueled last week's bond rally.
Bonds also slumped ahead of today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting after a larger than expected increase in factory output. The increase of eight-tenths of a percent last month was higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent some economists had expected. It challenged the notion that the economy is slowing, which some thought would be hastened by the Asian market slump.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, believes rates are currently caught in a tug-of-war. On one side is the Asian financial turmoil, which some market participants believe will slow the United States economy and keep inflation low, not to mention the flight to quality by investors seeking shelter from those markets that have lowered short-term rates here and supported Treasuries for weeks. Also, the shrinking Federal budget deficit, rising stock market -- despite recent volatility -- strong consumer confidence and strong dollar. On the other side, he said, we have a strong United States economy that has the potential to accelerate inflation, with faster wage gains in a tighter labor market, rising consumer debt including delinquencies, along with personal bankruptcies. And in the middle, there is the Fed.
"The balance of these pro and con factors favors continued economic growth in 1998, albeit at a noticeably slower pace," Mr. Hoffman said.
Yesterday, yields slipped as market participants grew cautious ahead of today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting and release of the November Consumer Price Index and housing starts, putting buyers on the side lines. Few in the market expect the Fed will take any action today, but even that did not dissuade the market from pricing the risk premium anyway.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., thought the market was also concerned about how the Japanese were going to remedy their banking problems. "That is more important than any of the other stuff," he said. "If no solution is found there is the threat that the Japanese can liquidate some of their Treasury holdings and that could put pressure on prices regardless of what the Fed does. That is the critical issue this week. Even the threat of it happening has put pressure on the market." "Nonetheless, I'm still sticking to a 5.80 yield on the long bond very shortly," Mr. Pugliese said.
