HEADLINE: Clinton Hails Iran Overture but Isolation Policy Is Unchanged

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton today hailed conciliatory remarks toward the United States by Iran's new President, but his Administration remains committed to its policy of isolating Iran as punishment for its behavior.
In remarks to reporters during a White House picture-taking session, Mr. Clinton said he "would like nothing better than to have a dialogue with Iran." But at the same time, he listed his Administration's continuing concerns about what he called Iran's sponsorship of terrorism, its violent attacks on the peace process and its development and acquisition of weapons of mass destruction. 
 Administration officials said President Mohammed Khatami's surprising expression of hope for "thoughtful dialogue" with America did nothing to persuade Mr. Clinton to alter, or even seriously review, the policy of isolation against Iran that has been in place since the fall of the Government of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in 1979 and the taking of American hostages at the embassy in Teheran later that year.
But Mr. Khatami's comments did intensify a debate that has been raging in the Administration on the best way to carry out that policy. Senior officials have argued for weeks about whether the United States should impose sanctions on foreign companies that do business with Iran in violation of American law.
And Administration officials said they were concerned that Mr. Khatami might have been trying to play into that debate by making Iran seem reasonable in the eyes of American allies, who strongly oppose Washington's sanctions policy.
Iran has bedeviled every American President since Jimmy Carter, whose Presidency foundered in part on the hostage crisis. Mr. Clinton throughout his Presidency has made an effort to stay away from Iran -- and even to increase its economic and diplomatic isolation.
The President's remarks do not reflect a substantial policy change, although an Administration official said they were intended to send a "positive response" to Mr. Khatami.
But Mr. Clinton and his team are still so committed to a policy of "dual containment" -- isolating both Iran and Iraq -- that they have resisted calls by Democratic lawmakers and independent experts to modify their policy on Iran. The United States has declined to order a full-scale policy review of Iran since elections there in May and has not conducted a government-wide intelligence assessment of Iran in the last year.
The most heated debate in the Administration over Iran policy is whether the United States should impose sanctions on companies in France, Russia, Malaysia, Canada and Indonesia that have signed ambitious deals to develop natural gas fields in Iran.
The White House has convened several meetings of the Administration's top national security advisers or their deputies in the last several weeks, but they have failed to reach a decision on the issue.
In such a meeting on Dec. 5, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, presented a written analysis on the costs and benefits of sanctions against Iran, including the argument that imposing sanctions, as required by law, would seriously damage Washington's relations with European trading partners and with Russia, according to Administration officials familiar with the meeting.
But Mr. Eizenstat has said sanctions might be waived if the Europeans and Russians took tougher joint action against Iran, including punitive measures for its development of weapons of mass destruction and what the United States defines as its sponsorship of terrorism.
But other officials, including Leon S. Fuerth, Vice President Gore's national security adviser, argued strongly for imposing sanctions, saying the Administration's priority must be to punish Iran for its support of terrorism and its efforts to develop its military ability.
During the 1980's, Mr. Gore took a hard line against the Republican policy of engaging with Iraq, going so far as to blame Mr. Bush's policy for the war with Iraq. And as a potential Presidential candidate in 2000, Mr. Gore does not want to be seen as being soft on Iran.
The President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, and his deputy, James Steinberg, have been described by participants in the meetings as the "referees." Mr. Berger has made the point that waiving sanctions would cause a protest from the Republican-dominated Congress.
In another dispute, the State Department has praised Russia for cooperating with an American-led initiative to eliminate the transfer of missile technology to Iran. Officials at the Department have pointed to steps taken by President Boris N. Yeltsin to curb missile exports by Russian companies to Iran, including the expulsion of an Iranian diplomat for trying to buy Russian missile-engine blueprints.
But American intelligence officials who closely watch Iran and Russia say that despite the positive steps, they do not believe that Russian companies have limited their cooperation with Iran, and that in any case, it may already be too late.
"By having done what it has in the past two years, the Russians have allowed the Iranian missile program to progress so far along it doesn't matter what happens now," a senior intelligence official said.
Still, there are small, isolated signs of good will to rebuild a relationship of trust with Iran that has not existed since the fall of the Shah nearly 19 years ago.
In a bold rescue mission several weeks ago, sailors on a United States Navy vessel in the Persian Gulf saved the life of an ailing Iranian seaman by removing him from his vessel, a senior Adminsitration offical said. He was moved to the American vessel on a winch and flown in an American helicopter to Bahrain, where he underwent surgery before being returned to Iran.
And the Administration has allowed Karl F. Inderfurth, the Assistant Secretary of State for South Asian Affairs, to step up talks on Afghanistan at the United Nations that were begun by his predecessor and to include Iranian officials.
Meanwhile, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat and a key foreign policy player in Congress, has added his voice to the chorus of experts on the Middle East who have called on the Administration to modify its Iran policy.
Over the last few months, he said he has told a number of senior Administration officials, including Mr. Berger, that the United States should abandon dual containment.
"I support the military containment of Iran, but slowly and gradually we should establish a reliable, authoritative dialogue," Mr. Hamilton said in a telephone interview. "I do not exclude commercial relations with Iran in the future. We need to review the policy."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Malaysia Taking Pledge of Austerity

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 15

 BODY:
For months, Malaysia resisted the pain, blaming foreign speculators, playing down its economic problems and leading analysts to brand it a country in denial.
Now, desperate to avoid the ministrations of the International Monetary Fund already under way in Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, the Government here has swung into action. 
 Over the last 10 days, it has announced a program of austerity measures that some Malaysians are calling a home-grown I.M.F. plan -- abandoning aggressive growth policies the nation has pursued for a decade.
The measures are a belated but ambitious effort to rescue the economy. Since the beginning of the year, the currency has dropped by 35 percent, and the stock market has plummeted more than 70 percent in dollar terms -- most of that damage occurring in the last three months. Prices for imported goods, and even for some staples, are starting to rise.
"We must reassure the world that we will carry out what we have undertaken to do at whatever cost," Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said this past weekend, dropping his resistance to economic changes.
The task here now, as it is for other ailing Asian economies, will be to follow through on restructuring plans that challenge an ingrained way of doing business.
Gathering here today, the leaders of nine Southeast Asian nations expressed their frustration with the help they had received so far from the I.M.F. and called on the United States, Europe and Japan to help rescue the region.
"Despite the economic fundamentals of the regional economies being corrected and improved through the support and advice of the I.M.F., the depreciation of the currencies has continued unabated," said a statement by the leaders, who are marking the 30th anniversary of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
As they met, together with leaders from China, Japan and South Korea, the currencies of Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand all fell to new lows. Some other Asian currencies also declined.
Malaysia's economic retrenchment has been outlined in a series of statements by Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who is also Finance Minister and something of a foil to his aggressive boss, Dr. Mahathir.
Government spending is to be cut by 18 percent and officials' salaries, by as much as 10 percent. Several of Dr. Mahathir's ambitious building projects will be put on hold, and expensive imports like aircraft and ships will be halted. Military spending will be cut and most lending for construction will be frozen.
"We don't have any choice," Mr. Anwar said. "We have to take these tough measures if we want to boost the economy and restore confidence."
Bank credits will be restricted, he said, and there will be "no question of any bailout" for ailing banks and other financial institutions. "I have sympathy," he continued. "I don't want to see these guys go bankrupt. But there is a limit."
Last week, Malaysia's central bank governor, Ahmad Mohd Don, said, "We will not hesitate to close down any banking institution operating in a manner which is detrimental to the interests of its depositors or is insolvent."
In his remarks over the weekend, the Prime Minister agreed. "What is not viable must be killed outright so the survivors can be free to consolidate their positions," he said. "People unnecessarily employed should be retired."
Mr. Anwar acknowledged that these steps meant unemployment -- as many as 200,000 jobs -- and the possibility of social tension with a political cost. "Decisions now have to be purely economic," he said. "Obviously, we will have to undergo a period of slowdown before things get back on track."
In what amounted to a swallowing of national pride, he cut a previous estimate of annual growth in coming years to 4 or 5 percent, from a projection of 7 percent just two months ago. Financial analysts said the figure could be lower still.
In addition to less growth, the analysts said, the austerity measures would probably mean an increase in interest rates, a wave of bankruptcies and a rise in inflation.
Dr. Mahathir was out of town at an air show when Mr. Anwar made his first announcement on Dec. 5. The new austerity measures are a severe blow to the 72-year-old Prime Minister's ambitions, which have been expressed in showy and expensive building projects, with a goal of making Malaysia a fully developed nation by the year 2020.
"We must make sure that we no longer spend as we used to," Dr. Mahathir conceded in a statement late last week, in which he called on Malaysians to seek economies in their daily lives. "Small things like reducing the consumption of sugar from four spoonfuls to three or two will help," he said.
In detailing the austerity program today, Mr. Anwar said it was time to admit that there were serious problems with Malaysia's economy and that currency traders were not to blame for the current crisis. He said -- as economists have repeatedly -- that the country had benefited from foreign investment as its economy soared over the last decade by an average of 8 percent a year.
When currency traders attacked the Malaysian ringgit this fall, touching off a sharp fall in its value, as they had attacked the Thai baht earlier, Dr. Mahathir took aim at foreign speculators. He pointed his finger at the American financier George Soros and also said that Malaysia might have been the victim of a Jewish "agenda."
Economic analysts said his remarks only heightened the country's problems, raising doubts about its seriousness in dealing with the crisis and contributing to investors' nervousness.
The new measures address some of the causes of Malaysia's problems -- particularly the big infrastructure projects that have been handed out over the years to well-connected companies, without competitive bidding. These have been at the heart of a Malaysian sort of capitalism that has helped cement Dr. Mahathir's political control during 16 years as Prime Minister.
As Mr. Anwar said, "There is a perception that Government will not allow big players to be touched."
This will have to start to change, he said.

HEADLINE: Tax on Cigarettes May Rise To Help Pay for Health Care

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders tentatively agreed today to raise New Jersey's cigarette tax by at least 25 cents to help cover the cost of hospital treatment for uninsured patients, the Governor's top aide said. Additional money would come from the state's unemployment fund and the general budget, the aide said.
Michael P. Torpey, the Governor's chief of staff, said that lawmakers would probably introduce a bill on Tuesday that would likely provide $315 million annually over five years to help hospitals cover the cost of treating tens of thousands of uninsured people. The plan would also provide $101.5 million a year for the state's Hospital Relief Fund, which helps urban hospitals treat hundreds of patients with AIDS and tuberculosis. The program would expire after five years. 
 The state's current financing system, which expires on Dec. 31, provided $300 million this year for charity care and $71.5 million for the relief fund. But hospitals say they spend closer to $400 million annually on charity care.
Although legislative leaders were still arguing over the details tonight, Mr. Torpey said they might increase the cigarette tax by as much as 40 cents a pack. But only 25 to 30 cents would go toward charity care, with the rest going toward school construction projects. A 25-cent increase would raise about $125 million in revenues annually and provide about one-quarter of the money needed for charity care.
Smokers in New Jersey already pay a 40-cent tax on cigarettes, which cost about $2.35 a pack. In comparison, New York has a 56-cent cigarette tax. New Jersey is among about a dozen states that require hospitals to provide free treatment to uninsured patients who are not eligible for Medicaid or Medicare and are unable to pay their bills. Since 1993, the state has used more than $2.2 billion from the unemployment insurance fund to pay for its charity care program.
Both organized labor and business groups have harshly criticized the current plan, which relies almost entirely on the unemployment fund. Union leaders have said it was unfair for the state to divert money from the fund to pay for medical care.
Mr. Torpey said the new plan would use about $250 million from the unemployment fund in 1998. But the state would decrease the amount it took from the fund over five years, eventually phasing it out completely, he said. It would make up the difference with money from the general budget, he said.
Mrs. Whitman recommended increasing the cigarette tax by 25 cents for the charity care program two years ago, but the State Legislature refused to consider her proposal. Democrats have been especially skittish about raising the tax, because voters punished them for supporting former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990. But Senator Richard J. Codey, the new Senate minority leader, said tonight that he was not against using the cigarette tax to pay for part of the program.
Two years ago, the last time the charity care system expired, hospitals around the state were forced to cut staff and postpone payments to vendors while the Governor and legislators took more than six months to agree on a plan.
Roughly 1.3 million people in New Jersey have no health insurance, even though many of them have jobs, according to the United States Census Bureau. Union and business leaders have said that instead of relying on the cigarette tax and the unemployment fund to pay for charity care, New Jersey should tax employers who do not provide health insurance.
The new plan, which would likely be up for a vote on Thursday, would also provide a total of $67 million for two separate health insurance programs, including one for uninsured children and another for people who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid but whose employers offer no heath coverage.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Freedom of Corruption

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
International freedom of trade has taken on new important meanings, three of them.
It now means the freedom of Asian leaders, bankers and business executives, working in tight partnership, to drive their countries into chaos through institutionalized corruption, nepotism and crony capitalism. 
 It means the freedom of foreign investors to throw money at Asian banks without making sure of their long-term solvency, and to gamble risk free in local currencies.
They acted surprised when the inherently rotten machinery collapsed. Maybe they were. They never looked carefully into the kind of governments and business types they were supporting or the choke hold the government-business alliances put on the economy. Just the thought of that happening at home would have driven American investors into ecstasies of fury and sent out Federal prosecutors in battalion.
They did not see because they did not care. Interest rates were deliciously high. The currency game looked real profitable. They bought the blather about "Asian values" somehow eliminating the need for open dealing, inspection and auditing. Meanwhile, Asian leaders ruled their countries by economic dictates and personal regulations, from forbidding large families to forbidding chewing bubble gum.
Sophisticated, aloof study of Asian business-government partnerships would have shown the dangers. But investors danced right in. No, the foreign investors were not complete fools. They remembered Mexico and knew that if Asian economies collapsed, another bailout would be arranged, paid by U.S. and other taxpayers from international funds.
The Clinton Administration boasts that Mexico has repaid the bailout of foreign peso-gamblers. Mexican workers are not as jovial. Repayment came out of their hides.
So, the third new international trade freedom is the right of citizens of Indonesia, Thailand, Japan, Malaysia and Korea to have more of their own hides peeled off. Corruption and the bailout to pay for it will force them to wait for more decades to get the medical care, social insurance and housing that their own skills and diligence had earned long ago.
But supporters of real free trade can take some heart -- its perversion can be stopped, maybe.
Two ways exist for the International Monetary Fund to make sure that penalty-free bailouts of economies destroyed from within do not happen yet again. They should be conditions of the $100 billion-plus Asian bailout.
The I.M.F. should appoint international investigation commissions for each sacked country, to dissect the endemic corruption in the former Asian tigers. Countries crying to be bailed out would have to promise to follow the investigations with trials.
Investigations await in fine variety. In Indonesia, we have the deals arranged by and for the Suharto family, their courtiers and agents abroad. In Thailand, we have the falsification of foreign reserves. In South Korea, the central bank arranged a pre-bailout bailout -- drawing down its reserves by secret loans to faltering Korean banks.
Japan has its problems, but it was quite open about the alliance among the banks, government and bureaucracy. When that anti-free-trade partnership wounds the economy, foreigners cannot pretend surprise.
And, spare us astonished cries from foreign investors when China's economy is destroyed by its very special Mafia -- the same combination as in other Asian countries, but with the Communist Party, police and army added on.
Now, as for foreigners who threw money at Asian banks, bought into crumbling companies or gambled in Asian currency, they deserve no compensation. At most, the insurance Americans get when they lose their money in a savings account should do -- $100,000 for each American investing company.
These companies should have to send checks to each stockholder, dividing the money. The company would have to throw in whatever was needed to make the check at least a nickel apiece.
Then, stockholders could keep the same company officers. Or they could choose officers who might look hard enough, and care enough, not to invest in organized, sanctioned corruption and then cry to the world, alms, alms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Korean Currency Surges After Restraints Are Lifted
In what may prove to be a turning point in Asia's financial crisis, the South Korean won surged early today after the Government relaxed long-held restraints in how the currency is valued. The decision to scrap the artificial limits on the value of the won was announced late Monday.
Since agreeing to a record $57 billion International Monetary Fund bailout nearly two weeks ago, the won had fallen in value by almost half during that time. But the decision to float the currency may help restore investors' confidence in the Government's response to the crisis. Korean stocks also continued to climb early today. Page A1. 

First Dow Gain in Five Sessions
Cautious investors bought stocks selectively and helped the Dow Jones industrial average snap a five-session losing streak. The Dow rose 84.29 points, or 1.08 percent, to 7,922.59, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10 points, or 1.05 percent, to 953.39. But the technology-laden Nasdaq fell marginally on declines in Dell and Microsoft. D12.
 
Bond prices fell slightly. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 5.97 percent from 5.92 percent on Friday. D7.
 
Microsoft to Appeal Court Order
Microsoft said it would appeal a temporary order to change one of its marketing practices and called the judge's ruling an "error." The company also outlined how it planned to comply with the court order. D2.
 
U.S. Bancorp Adding Piper Jaffray
Shares of Piper Jaffray rose 22 percent, or $6.625, to $36.375, after the investment house agreed to be acquired by U.S. Bancorp, the nation's 15th-largest banking company for $730 million in cash. With the acquisition, U.S. Bancorp will have assets under management of about $65 billion. D4.
 
Ernst & Young and KPMG to Vote
American partners at Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick are to vote this week on a merger that would create the world's largest accounting firm. Regulators at the S.E.C. have expressed concern about this merger and the union of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, which would reduce the number of major accounting firms to four from eight just a few years ago. D2

Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities surged eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Federal Reserve said. It was the 20th month without a decline. D4.
 
Fine Host Executives Dismissed
The chairman and treasurer of Fine Host were dismissed and the catering-service company said it would restate earnings. The company also moved to hire a crisis management firm and an accounting firm to review accounting practices and investigate computerized records. D12.

Andrew Bressman, the former president of A. R. Baron & Company, admitted to defrauding customers of millions of dollars. Mr. Bressman became the ninth executive of the defunct Manhattan brokerage firm to plead guilty. D6.
 
More Women in Corporate Suites
The percentage of women corporate officers at Fortune 500 companies rose slightly last year to 10.6 percent from 10 percent the previous year, a new survey shows. D6.

HEADLINE: Suicide Rate Higher in 3 Gambling Cities, Study Says

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
The dramatic increase in legalized gambling in the United States may be leading to a significant increase in suicide rates among both residents of and visitors to communities where casinos are thriving, according to a new study on suicide and gambling.
In the study, Dr. David Phillips, a professor of sociology at the University of California in San Diego, examined death certificates in major gaming cities in the United States -- Atlantic City, Las Vegas, Nev., and Reno -- and found that suicide rates were up to four times higher than in comparably sized cities where gambling is not legal. 
 Because there is a long lag in the compilation of death certificates nationwide, it was not possible to determine whether the 24 states that have legalized casino-type gambling within the last 10 years have experienced a similar increase in suicide rates, said Dr. Phillips, an expert on suicide.
The study by Dr. Phillips is reported in the December issue of the journal Suicide and Life-Threatening Behavior. It is the first large-scale statistical investigation of gambling and suicide.
Earlier studies have shown that compulsive and pathological gamblers have many problems, including alcoholism and drug addiction, that contribute to suicidal behavior.
Still, several smaller studies have found gambling to be associated with increased suicide rates, white-collar crime, substance abuse and child abuse, Dr. Phillips said. For example, one study found that 3 of the 6 Atlantic City suicides for which the researchers had information probably occurred because of gambling problems.
Americans love to gamble, Dr. Phillips said, and spend nearly as much on gambling (6 percent of the G.N.P., according to a Standard & Poor's Corporation 1996 survey) as they do on family groceries (8 percent).
Dr. Lanny Berman, executive director of the American Association of Suicidology in Washington, praised the study as "quality sociological research," and said the next step would be to design smaller studies that compared gamblers and non-gamblers -- matched for age, occupation and other factors -- over time, to see whether gambling itself was the direct cause of higher suicide rates.
But Frank Fahrenkopf, president of the American Gaming Association, an organization in Washington that represents major hotel and casino companies, said legalized gambling might have very little to do with suicide.
Mr. Fahrenkopf cited studies that say that people moving to the American West, where suicide rates are highest, find themselves isolated and without personal support systems and that these factors, not gambling, explain why they kill themselves.
Dr. Phillips said he got the idea for his study after talking to people who run Gamblers Anonymous telephone lines in Texas. He said callers would say, "I've embezzled all the company's funds, my kids can't go to college, there's no money left for groceries and I don't see any way out."
To look for an association between suicide and gambling, Dr. Phillips examined death certificates that tell how people died. Las Vegas has the highest suicide rate in the nation, he said.
Based on suicide patterns, one would expect a city the size of Las Vegas to have had 310 suicides in 1990, for example, but he found that the actual number in Las Vegas was 497.
Visitors to Las Vegas also kill themselves at a higher rate, Dr. Phillips said. For most cities nationwide, 1 in l00 "visitor deaths" on average is recorded as a suicide. A visitor death means that someone from another state dies while visiting the city in question. In Las Vegas, 1 in 25 visitor deaths on average is a suicide, four times the national average.
"In the case of Atlantic City, we can trace what happened before and after gambling was legalized," Dr. Phillips said. (A similar analysis cannot be done for Las Vegas and Reno because gambling there was legalized in 1931 and mortality statistics do not go back far enough to allow such comparisons.)
Atlantic City legalized gambling in May 1978. Before casinos opened, the residential suicide rate for the city was indistinguishable from adjacent communities in New Jersey. In 1975, the expected number of suicides for Atlantic City was 45 and the actual number was 52, a statistically insignificant difference. In 1990, after gambling had been in place for more than a decade, the expected number of suicides remained the same, but the actual number of suicides was 64 -- a statistically significant increase. In Atlantic City, 1 in 53 visitor deaths is a suicide, roughly double the national average.
The study cannot say for certain which people are killing themselves at a higher rate, Dr. Phillips said. It could be the local gamblers or visiting gamblers, spouses or children of gamblers, non-gambling relatives of gamblers or non-gambling residents who work in the industry. Nevertheless, he said, gambling or some factor associated with gambling is linked with the suicide levels.
Gambling also creates economic benefits in many communities, providing jobs where unemployment used to be high. Some groups may benefit while others lose, Dr. Phillips said, a trend that should also show up in mortality data. "I am starting to study that question now," he said.

HEADLINE: First, Army Neo-Nazis, Now Racists on Internet Worry Germany

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Dec. 15

 BODY:
At a time of growing signs of neo-Nazism in the German armed forces, a Government agency has registered new apprehension about surging racism in the former East Germany.
A report says that right-wing extremists are using the Internet to boast of "foreigner-free" zones, threatening to keep foreign-born residents out of certain discos and cafes. 
 For several years, right-wingers have used the Internet and computer bulletin boards to gain access to white supremacist web-sites in the United States and elsewhere and to send encrypted messages between extremists in Germany.
But the annual report published last week by the Government office that addresses issues relating to foreign residents was the first official allusion to the use of the Internet to stir up ethnic violence in the east. Racism there is widely ascribed to discontent over mass unemployment rather than the actual presence of a growing foreign population.
Germany has Europe's highest proportion of foreign-born residents -- almost 9 percent of its population of 82 million. But most of them live in prosperous western cities. Unemployment in the east is even higher than the national average of around 11 percent.
The biggest group of foreign-born residents in Germany is some two million Turks. But in recent years, there has been a huge influx of Balkan war refugees and asylum-seekers and clandestine immigrants from Eastern Europe and Africa.
Cornelia Schmalz-Jacobsen, the director of the office that issued the report, said that, in some areas of the east, "foreign residents and visitors are advised not to leave their homes alone after dark."
Right-wing extremists in at least 25 towns in the east, she said, had posted Internet proclamations of "foreigner-free" zones to be enforced by the extremists.
Typically, he said, an Internet announcement would say that "such and such a club has now been liberated."
But, Ms. Schmalz-Jacobsen said, "these are not liberated zones, but occupied zones."
German authorities were deeply alarmed by a wave of violent xenophobia after unification seven years ago. In 1993, the authorities launched twin crackdowns -- on right-wing groups and on illegal immigration -- hoping to suppress extremist politics and simultaneously to stem the flow of foreigners.
But that has not solved the problem, the report said, even though the number of crimes attributed to racism has fallen slightly -- to 2,323 in 1996 from 2,468 in 1995.
Right-wing extremism is generally attributed to an estimated 6,500 hard-core activists along with some 35,000 people classified by the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution as Nazi sympathizers.
The display of Nazi emblems, like swastikas and stiff-armed salutes, is banned in Germany. But in recent weeks many Germans have been stunned by disclosures chronicling neo-Nazi activities in the army.
One scandal erupted when the news magazine Der Spiegel reported last week that Manfred Roder, a neo-Nazi with a criminal record of bombings, had been invited to give a speech to the country's most prestigious military academy in 1995.
The Defense Minister, Volker Ruhe, suspended a lieutenant general and instituted disciplinary action against a colonel because of the invitation.

HEADLINE: Campaign Accusations Divide 2 Prosecutors

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
The Justice Department was given evidence that a powerful Venezuelan banking family had funneled improper campaign contributions to the Democratic Party in 1992, but Federal prosecutors have shown little interest in pursuing the case, Manhattan prosecutors said yesterday.
Speaking at the sentencing of one of the members of the Castro banking family in state Supreme Court, the prosecutors said they had delivered witnesses and bank records to Federal agents in April 1997. But, they said, Lee J. Radek, who then headed the Justice Department's campaign finance investigation, replied in a letter that the investigators had interviewed one important witness in the case and had no further use for him. 
 The Justice Department sought to counter that impression yesterday, however, saying that it had pursued several leads since that initial interview and that the investigation remained open.
Mr. Radek's judgment has been the subject of controversy in the Federal campaign finance investigation. Earlier this fall, he was, in effect, pushed aside when Attorney General Janet Reno brought in a new prosecutorial team led by Charles G. La Bella, a career prosecutor from San Diego. At the time, law-enforcement officials complained that Mr. Radek had failed to investigate leads aggressively enough and had repeatedly been beaten to witnesses and evidence by news organizations following the case.
Federal Election Commission records show that about $92,000 in contributions to the Democratic National Committee came from individuals connected to the Castro family.
The Democratic committee said yesterday that it knew nothing of the $92,000 contribution.
"As with all contributions, if we receive new information we will review it and take appropriate action," said Steve Langdon, a spokesman for the committee.
Lawyers for some members of the Castro family have repeatedly denied making any illegal contributions.
The Castros controlled a banking and insurance empire in Venezuela before that country's financial collapse in 1994. Earlier this year, in Manhattan, three family members, including its leader, Orlando Castro Llanes, were convicted of financial crimes related to the collapse of their banks and corporations.
It was during that investigation that Manhattan prosecutors said they uncovered evidence of improper contributions to the Democratic Party. It is illegal for foreign citizens to contribute to American political campaigns.
One family member, Jorge Castro Barredo, faced up to 25 years in state prison and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors examining campaign contributions.
As Mr. Castro Barredo was sentenced yesterday to 3 to 10 years in prison, Manhattan prosecutors said he had given them important information about efforts to contribute foreign money to the Democratic Party and they revealed their conversations with the Justice Department about the case.
Other officials with knowledge of the case said yesterday that it might be too late to take any legal action because most campaign finance laws had a five-year statute of limitations.
Mr. Radek would not comment on the details of his exchange with the Manhattan prosecutors, but a Justice Department spokesman denied that his letter to Assistant District Attorney Richard Preiss on Oct. 17, 1997, indicated lack of interest.
"It does not say anything about what we may or may not do in the future," said the spokesman, Bert Brandenburg.
The conflict between Manhattan prosecutors and the Justice Department reflects a longstanding friction.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan has regularly criticized Federal prosecutors for failing to act on evidence that he regarded as solid.
Prosecutors said that Mr. Castro Barredo, a United States citizen, told them he was reimbursed by foreign companies for the contributions he made to the Democrats in 1992. It is illegal for foreign companies to contribute to American political campaigns, and it is also illegal to make contributions through a surrogate.
The Manhattan prosecutors said Mr. Castro Barredo was interviewed at length by Federal investigators. They said that they had also offered Federal prosecutors bank records and correspondence that corroborated his account of an illegal contribution scheme.
Last February, Mr. Morgenthau raised questions about the campaign contributions, saying the contributions appeared to be part of a scheme to violate United States campaign finance laws. At yesterday's sentencing, prosecutors said information about the contributions was first sent to the United States Attorney in Miami in October 1996. At some point after that, they said, the case was transferred to the Justice Department's public integrity section in Washington.
Prosecutors declined to speculate about why the contributions were made.
In 1991, Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn tried to seize $1 million from one of the Castro banks, maintaining that the money had been transferred as part of a money-laundering scheme. But the matter was dismissed at the request of Federal lawyers before any of the contributions had been made.
The prosecution of the Castro family was a highly unusual case for a local prosecutor to assume. After thousands of people lost money in the 1994 Venezuelan banking collapse, the Manhattan District Attorney's office took the case at the request of the Venezuelan Government.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Key Japanese Panel Devises $77 Billion Bank Rescue Plan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The ruling Liberal Democratic Party agreed Monday on a plan to use at least 10 trillion yen in public money to strengthen Japan's shaky banking system, the first solid progress in resolving this problem since four financial institutions collapsed last month.
The plan, announced by a special party panel, coincided with new evidence that the banks' frailty and Asia's deepening financial crisis were further undermining confidence in Japan's economy, the world's second largest. 
 An influential quarterly business survey released by the nation's central bank showed that Japanese executives had become far more pessimistic, which helped briefly send the yen down to a five-and-a-half-year low of 131.45 to the dollar.
The party panel, led by former Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, proposed that the Government supply 10 trillion yen in bonds to the Deposit Insurance Corporation -- roughly equivalent to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States. The agency could then call on the Government to purchase the bonds back for cash as needed to help solve the financial crisis engulfing banks, securities firms and insurers.
Many of them are swamped in bad loans -- a situation that has incubated since the speculative "bubble" economy, and stock market, burst in 1990.
In share trading here today, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 104.89 points -- or two-thirds of 1 percent -- at 15,804.50 early in the afternoon session. It gave up one-tenth of a percent on Monday.
The debt problem took on new urgency last month when the four financial institutions failed, including Japan's oldest brokerage firm. The collapse of these businesses badly damaged public confidence and intensified pressure on Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to devise a rescue.
On Monday in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where he was attending a meeting with Southeast Asian leaders, Mr. Hashimoto promised to carry out a financial rescue operation quickly.
Some analysts have suggested that it will take more than 10 trillion yen -- which is equivalent to roughly $77 billion -- to strengthen the Japanese financial system, and the Miyazawa panel left open the possibility of raising more money. It suggested that the Government guarantee another set of bonds, of unspecified value, that would be sold directly by the Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The plan, while formally only a proposal, has the backing of powerful party members including Mr. Hashimoto, and is expected to take effect.
Yet political bickering in the governing party, which had threatened to scuttle the plan as it was taking shape last week, remained near the surface. Seiroku Kajiyama, who initially proposed a 10 trillion yen bond sale, criticized the Miyazawa panel, saying that its solution did not go far enough. He promised an alternative.
Mr. Kajiyama had also suggested last week that some part of the money go toward stimulating the economy through tax cuts or public works projects -- an idea that fiscal-austerity advocates in the party refused even to consider.
The Miyazawa plan stipulates that the bond revenue will be used only by the Deposit Insurance Corporation to strengthen the financial system. Under it, the Government would sell shares it owns in Nippon Telegraph and Telephone to raise the cash required to buy the initial 10 trillion yen of bonds.
Although these shares have been pledged to redeem other bonds, the Government needed a way to avoid the impression that the new bonds would be a form of deficit financing, which it has vowed to eliminate.
Some of the money raised would be used to recapitalize weak banks the Government has deemed salvageable.
Critics say, however, that such a measure leaves officials flexibility to revert to the old policy of saving all banks regardless of merit.
The Miyazawa panel's proposals also include expanding the role of the Resolution and Collection Bank, which is now responsible for disposing of failed credit cooperatives, to include similar responsibilities for failed banks. The panel also suggests extending public funds to policyholders of failed insurance companies and securities firms -- an indication that it expects those financial sectors to require a shake-out, too.
The plan further includes a Government guarantee of central bank loans made to cover the losses of banks that have already failed.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Endgame Shaping Up In Bids for the N.F.L.

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
The temptation is to cease chronicling the National Football League television negotiations until the winners announce their deals and one network that bid the ranch loses because the other networks bid bigger ranches.
Mind you, it's a temptation impossible to act on, for no subject on the business side of television sports boasts more endgame rumors than the N.F.L. television talks. 
 One subject that ran rampant yesterday was whether CBS brazenly opened its wallet to league officials during a meeting on Friday to show what it would pay to acquire what ABC or NBC have. All we know for sure is they met to discuss the parameters of the process. But did their chat become a mock auction? (And it's "Monday Night Football" for $500 million, Mr. Tagliabue!) Not likely.
The real action won't commence until CBS exhibits the full innards of its wallet. Its offer will set the floor, most likely, for NBC's American Football Conference rights and ABC's "Monday Night Football."
And yes, there's more speculation. One, that Fox's FX network is a big contestant for the Sunday night cable deal. That's a silly notion, what with its 35 million subscribers being less than half of TNT's or ESPN's. If a Fox cable service entered the mix, it should be The Family Channel. But selling a package to T.F.C. -- which bestows "The Three Stooges" on us but no sports save morning evangelism -- would mean that a blowout bid from Rupert Murdoch means more than the powerful promotion and identification that TNT and ESPN have long provided.
Second, a Thursday night package for CBS. That's been a ditsy idea for a long time. Not only would it place pro football against NBC's blockbuster prime-time shows, thus risking low-rated games, it would shift games from other networks and add more advertising to the market. But worse, it would make all the networks happy, rather than keep one watching forlornly from the outside.
For a little wisdom, we usher in Fox's John Madden. In 1993, he lost his job at CBS when CBS lost football then quickly regained it when Fox got the N.F.C. rights and decided he was worth $8 million a year.
"In '93, I learned nothing is for sure," Madden said from Sea Island, Ga., yesterday. "I thought CBS was always in the N.F.L. with the N.F.C. and always would be. I was going to broadcast on CBS and nowhere else. Every time I heard a rumor that Fox would bid, my reaction was, 'Yeah, but not us.' "
He added: "Looking back, I thought if anything would happen, I'd know it. But now I know, nobody knows what will happen. Anybody who says they know what will happen has to be guessing. There are too many 'yeah, buts' out there."
Regarding his future employer, Madden was equally firm. Will he stay at Fox? "I don't know that," he said. Will he join Al Michaels on "Monday Night Football," where he nearly landed in 1993? "I don't know," he said.
Alas, nothing is certain save for the uncertainty. Sometime soon, maybe this week or later, NBC, Fox, ABC, CBS, ESPN, TNT (and who knows, maybe UPN and The Food Channel), will meet with the league, be asked which packages they want, and learn the cost. That's when the real fun will begin.
You can be sure that CBS has learned the errors of its ways; four years ago under the reign of the pinch-penny CBS chairman Larry Tisch, the network declined to make an offer for anything but the N.F.C. package. Fox's $395 million-a-year bid paralyzed, then sank CBS; CBS's after-the-buzzer stab at trying to take the A.F.C. from NBC was flagged for a flagrant delay of game.
When the new deals are signed, the next game will be how much of each network's N.F.L. contracts will be written off as losses. Fox wrote off $350 million in 1994, estimating that figure to be the difference between what it paid and the ad revenues the broadcasts would generate. Murdoch hardly cared. With prices for the new contract poised to explode through the retractable roof, losses should explode, too. Then maybe an advertising recession will hit. Then, whose stock will plunge on the rotten news? Football is a tough game.
 
Women's Hockey on Tap
Lifetime Television, one of the three networks sharing Women's National Basketball Association broadcasts, is expanding into women's ice hockey tomorrow night with a pre-Olympic matchup between the United States and Canadian teams from Vermont. Margaret (Digit) Murphy, the Brown University coach who will be a first-time analyst beside Mike Emrick, said: "I think viewers will be surprised at how similar the women's and men's games are. The differences are subtle. There's contact, but not checking. Once in a while, you see big gangs and crunches. It's more flow, less whistles."

Ted Shaker is leaving as the president of Sports Illustrated TV to create his own production company. Shaker was formerly the executive producer of CBS Sports. . . . The Jets' rout of Tampa Bay on Sunday produced a 19.8 local Nielsen rating, while the Giants' victory over Washington generated a 16.7. Both games were televised by Fox.

HEADLINE: Fed, Seeing Few Signs of Inflation, Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, acting after the latest Government reports on the economy showed inflation remains benign despite vigorous economic growth.
The central bank's decision, widely anticipated by economists and investors, continued a pattern that suggests the Fed has set aside its usually predominant concern about an inflationary spiral set off by strong growth and low unemployment. 
 Instead, the Fed has chosen to focus on the paucity of early warning signals of inflation and on the need to maintain calm in the financial markets at a time when the crisis in Asia has unsettled investors.
With the bank's policy-making body not scheduled to meet again until February, analysts are increasingly divided over whether it will feel compelled to raise rates next year to make sure that inflation does not infect the economy, which is enjoying the third-longest expansion since World War II.
Some, in fact, are already arguing that the Fed's next move will be to cut rates to offset slower growth and the possibility that inflation's opposite, a general fall in prices, could hurt the economy.
At some point in 1998, "deflation risks will overcome inflation risks in Greenspan's mind," said Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch, referring to the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan.
The latest reassurance of subdued inflation came today with the Labor Department's report that consumer prices edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in November to pull the 12-month pace down to 1.8 percent. Some reflection of Asian turmoil was found in the weakening price of goods.
For American consumers, weak currencies in Asia along with slack domestic demand represent "an unmixed blessing," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. "The crisis will result in cheaper imports and lower prices in the stores. It will also reduce the worldwide demand for goods and may help slow our economy enough to forestall an interest rate increase by the Fed."
Workers, moreover, are able to spend. Real weekly earnings jumped an average 1.4 percent in November to a level 4.9 percent above that of November 1996, the Labor Department estimated.
Last month's surge reflected a nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in hours and a six-tenths of 1 percent increase in earnings per hour, a total slightly shaved by the month's inflation.
Still another set of figures today from the Commerce Department showed further gains in an already ebullient housing market powered by low interest rates. Builders broke ground on new homes last month at a pace that equaled 1,531,000 on an annual level. That was a modest eight-tenths of 1 percent faster than in October but considerably above what most analysts expected. Permits for future construction eased.
The one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index last month followed four straight increases of two-tenths of 1 percent. November's deceleration mainly involved a 3.9 percent drop in airline fares, moderately lower energy prices and a smaller increase for tobacco products.
The so-called core rate, which excludes the wide-swinging energy and food components, also rose one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the least since August.
Consumer inflation has not been lower than today's 1.8 percent rate since 1986, when oil prices collapsed.
The price of goods, which account for 43 percent of the index, edged one-tenth of 1 percent lower last month and was only six-tenths of 1 percent higher than in November 1996, the report showed.
Services, 57 percent of the index, advanced two-tenths of 1 percent in November and 2.9 percent over the year.
In the New York metropolitan area, prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month, bringing inflation over the 12 months down to 2.1 percent, modestly higher than the national average for urban consumers.
Inflation for the latest 12 months was 3.6 percent in San Francisco, 2.2 percent in Chicago, 1.5 percent in Los Angeles and 1.3 percent in Philadelphia, the report also showed.

HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Recover From Selloff

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday for a second consecutive session as some technology shares recovered from a recent slide.
Calmer Asian markets and consumer price data showing that inflation remains tame also bolstered stocks. And the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee left interest rates unchanged at its meeting yesterday. 
 "Many stocks were down the last few days, and investors who have a time horizon of more than a week saw an opportunity," said Philip Schettewi, who oversees $4 billion as chief of the Washington office of Loomis, Sayles & Company. "It's another case of investors buying on the dips, which overall has been a good strategy."
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 53.72, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,976.31, led by I.B.M. I.B.M. rose 2 7/8, to 103 3/4.
The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, rose 16.44 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,553.00, and the Standard & Poor's 500 Index increased 4.65 points, or half of 1 percent, to 968.04.
On the Nasdaq market, Cisco Systems gained 2 5/8, to 80 1/8, and Microsoft rose 2 15/16, to 139 1/16.
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, down 37 percent from its high this year, gained 1.1 percent. The Philadelphia Oil Service Sector rose 3.3 percent; it is off 22 percent from its high. Global Marine, down 27 percent from its high, rose 2 3/8, to 28 1/8.
"Oil service and technology stocks in particular were dirt cheap, and due for a bounce," said Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management, which oversees $6.5 billion.
Among other individual issues Micron Technology rose 1 1/16, to 23 9/16, after reporting disappointing earnings on Monday. Prices for the type of memory chips it makes have fallen so low that they might have reached bottom, some investors say. Micron shares have declined almost 60 percent since August.
American depository receipts of Danka Business Systems P.L.C. fell 17 15/16, to 13 1/16. The British distributor of office equipment said it would take a $20.5 million charge and report lower-than-expected earnings because a plan to integrate business units is behind schedule.
Pepsico Inc. fell 5/8, to 35 7/16, after a Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company analyst, Andrew Conway, cut his earnings estimates for the beverage giant to $1.33 for 1998 from $1.36. He said he had made the change to reflect increased advertising and marketing expenses. Pepsico was also downgraded to "market perform" from "trading buy" by Skip Carpenter, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Higher in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher in thin trading yesterday, getting a lift in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged in its final policy meeting of the year.
While the Fed's decision was expected, it was still a bit of a psychological lift as it meant that rates were likely to remain unchanged until policy makers meet again in February. 
 Until the central bank made its announcement, the market had been little changed on light volume. Economic data released at the beginning of the session were mixed, with the economy showing little signs of slowing, but with inflation tame.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 5/32, to 102 21/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction fell to 5.96 percent, from 5.97 percent on Monday.
Most market participants did not expect that the Fed would change rates yesterday. After all, it had not adjusted interest rates since March 25, when it raised the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
While the latest housing report showed new housing starts up eight-tenths of 1 percent, to an annual rate of 1.53 million last month, the November Consumer Price Index showed inflation tame. Most dealers and traders had reasoned that the economic turmoil in Asia and low inflation here would keep the Fed sidelined.
The index, both with and without food and energy, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in November as car prices, airline fares, gasoline and the cost of entertainment all helped to keep inflation under control "and resulted in a performance that must be making the F.O.M.C. absolutely giddy, and deservedly so," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
"Despite strong economic growth, very tight labor markets and budding wage pressures, inflation has remained remarkably contained," Mr. Fine said. "Indeed even a pre-emptive Fed bent on avoiding inflationary tendencies did not want to lift rates and exacerbate international financial tensions, particularly when the prognosis for the period ahead calls for slower economic growth and a lessening of pressure on goods inflation brought about by the global financial turmoil."
Mr.Fine said bond yields remained under 6 percent as a direct result of the Fed's unchanged policy, the calm inflationary environment, and the fact that the United States was still the safest of havens for investors.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Bloc's Anniversary Celebration Becomes a Plea for Outside Help

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Meeting in celebration of their 30th anniversary as a regional bloc, Southeast Asian leaders have swallowed their pride and pleaded for further economic help from abroad.
The economic formula that had led to a decade of extraordinary growth was seen as the root of their problems as currencies plummeted unchecked and investors fled. 
 "Forget politics," said Rafidah Aziz, Malaysia's trade minister, as he urged the West today to provide further rescue packages to the region. "It is pure survival of the global economy."
The meeting of heads of governments that ended here today marked the anniversary of the founding in 1967 of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a political and economic grouping that now includes nine members.
Instead of unalloyed celebration, though, Asean, as the group is known, was preoccupied with a financial crisis that so far shows few signs of abating despite billions of dollars in bailout packages.
The leaders acknowledged that they were unable to cope with these troubles on their own, declaring in a statement that it was "urgent that global efforts be undertaken, including the central role of the I.M.F., to arrest the currency slide and restore stability to the currency markets."
They called for "greater national, regional and international efforts, including by the major economies such as the European Union, Japan and the United States and international financial institutions, to overcome this situation as soon as possible."
But as they convened, the Philippine peso, the Malaysian ringgit and the the Indonesian rupiah were among currencies that plunged to new lows, reflecting a continuing erosion of investor confidence in the region.
The International Monetary Fund has challenged the economic methods that fueled the region's growth, and, as a prerequisite for assistance, demanded greater accountability in financial institutions, more responsible lending and investment practices, and a move away from the back-room deals that had brought great wealth to politicians and favored businessmen.
Indeed, just as some of the region's leaders used economic success as a justification for autocratic rule, economic failure is pushing them now toward more openness in the management of their economies -- and potentially of their political systems.
All of this engendered an unusually reflective atmosphere at the meeting here.
Two events early in July signaled the difficulties the association is now facing: a coup in Cambodia and the effective devaluation of the Thai currency, the baht, which was the trigger for the economic crises affecting much of Asia.
Problems stemming from these events have forced Asean to revisit some of its guiding principles and to address unresolved political questions.
Facing a common economic crisis, sharpened questions on human rights abuses and an environmental disaster producing a choking haze from forest fires, members pondered whether they could indeed maintain their credo of noninterference in one another's affairs.
And with the recent or anticipated inclusion of new, economically weak members -- Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar -- could the group meet its regional targets for expanded free trade, or would it separate into haves and have-nots?
The more successful members of Asean -- countries that just a few months ago were seen as part of an "Asian miracle" -- are Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, Brunei and the Philippines.
This year's anniversary was to have fulfilled the dream of Asean's founders by including all 10 Southeast Asian countries as members. But the coup in Cambodia -- in which one of the nation's co-Prime Ministers, Hun Sen, forced out the other, Prince Norodom Ranariddh -- made Cambodian entry impossible. A land on the verge of civil war was considered too great a liability.
Yet, that turmoil gave Asean nations an impetus to exercise political influence in a way they had not before, pressing Mr. Hun Sen toward a more stable Cambodian government and promised democratic elections.
This only heightened questions about Myanmar, formerly Burma -- which Asean admitted at the end of May, along with Laos -- even as it excluded Cambodia.
In accepting Myanmar, Asean members largely turned a blind eye toward the country's political repression and human rights abuse.
Myanmar's admission was propelled by two desires: to assert the regional group's independence in the face of Western pressure against the move, and to embrace a nation that is being vigorously courted by China.
Regional solidarity in the face of China's growing economic and political influence is emerging as a unifying theme, replacing the anti-Communism that motivated Asean's founders and energized its policies in the 1970's and 80's.
Still, the meeting here included the leaders of China, Japan and South Korea, and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, was gracious. "Friendly relations and cooperation between China and Asean is not only in the interests of our two sides, but also benefits the Asia-Pacific region," he said.
China promised not to devalue its currency, the yuan, and to encourage its enterprises to invest in Asean countries. Japan and South Korea also expressed good will and promised job-training programs and market access, but noted that they must deal with economic crises of their own.
Asean's policy of noninterference along with a political style stressing consensus rather than confrontation have been keys to its success as a grouping of nations with sharp political, economic and religious differences. But the problems the region has faced this year have pushed the bloc toward a more active and aggressive style.
"The new Asean way is what they call constructive engagement, which is just a euphemism for intervention," said Yusuf Wanandi, director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Indonesia.
"On their 30th anniversary they have to deal with the issues of Cambodia, the haze and the currency," he said. "So they have to cooperate much more closely on things like their macro-economic policies and on the environment. Their problems have gotten serious. They cannot stay quiet forever."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S PRESS CONFERENCE: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Urges Education Aid for Minorities

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton today made a passionate and detailed defense of affirmative action, arguing that not merit but differences in academic preparation and business contacts produce racial disparities in the United States.
In an extraordinary 94-minute news conference, Mr. Clinton repeatedly suggested that universities should begin offering minorities "a hand up" well before college, to gird them for the rigors of higher education. He maintained that, while Americans might be misled by charged words like "racial preferences" in the debate over affirmative action, almost all shared his views on the need for some remedy. 
 "If we get down to slogans, you have no better than a 50-50 chance of seeing any kind of affirmative effort prevail," the President said. "If you get down to brass tacks, I think people in both parties of good faith, what they want is a society where everybody who needs it gets a hand up, everybody's got a fair chance, but where unfair criteria don't deprive the deserving," to the benefit of the undeserving.
During the news conference, which ranged from the political prospects of Vice President Al Gore to the environmental problems of Los Angeles to the name of the Clintons' new dog (Buddy), the President pointedly passed up an opportunity to express confidence in Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Freeh dissented from Attorney General Janet Reno's decision earlier this month not to seek an independent counsel to look into aspects of Democratic fund-raising in last year's Presidential campaign.
Mr. Clinton, who sought today to dispel criticisms from former aides and others that he is adrift, moved from formal to prickly to chatty as he repeatedly ignored aides' entreaties to stop. He solicited 31 questions in all before calling a halt with a promise to sum up his agenda in just one sentence. Instead, he reeled off several paragraphs, and 14 sentences in all.
Asked if Mr. Gore was the victim of a campaign by Democratic rivals to dim his Presidential prospects, Mr. Clinton said Mr. Gore "needs no defense from me" but then went on to provide one, asserting, "He's had the most full partnership with the President of any Vice President in history."
The comment illustrated his strong support for Mr. Gore's Presidential bid, which Mr. Clinton has made clear unusually early for a sitting President. But it also showed how the roles of the two men have changed, since Mr. Gore was once seen as Mr. Clinton's ablest defender.
Mr. Clinton was most animated today on the subjects of race and the effectiveness of the panel he has appointed to address the subject. He got into a testy exchange with a reporter who said that "reports from the front lines of your race initiative suggest that the initiative is in chaos," and that it amounted to "a little more than 'Presidential Oprah.' "
"That may be your editorial comment, that's not my reports," Mr. Clinton shot back. He then challenged the reporter to name one source for his reports. "Just one," he said, almost taunting. "Give me a name."
"I don't want them to get fired by you, sir," replied the reporter, John Donvan of ABC News.
Mr. Clinton said the initiative was "on track," citing new Administration policies on ending housing discrimination. He contended that "hundreds and hundreds" of people had accessed a new White House web site soliciting details on community practices for easing racial differences.
He said of the initiative: "I think it is working and I think it is taking shape, and I believe it has got clear direction, and I think you will see better results as we go forward."
The panel is to meet on Wednesday in Fairfax, Va., with teachers and education experts, including William J. Bennett, who was Secretary of Education under President Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Clinton said he might need the panel to work beyond June, his previous deadline for what he originally envisioned as a one-year national "conversation" on race.
He dwelt today on the Army's success with affirmative action, which he also noted at a town hall meeting on race two weeks ago.
The Army, Mr. Clinton said, does not use quotas or promote unqualified people. "But," he continued, "there is an intensive effort to qualify people so that in each promotion pool, the pool of applicants for the next rank roughly reflects the racial composition of the people in the next lowest rank."
The President said the Army's experience might hold a lesson for universities, who could try "in a more systemic way" to find students who, because of their schooling, might score poorly on standardized tests "but whose probability of success in college is very, very high."
He later returned to that theme, rejecting the idea that merit governs college admissions.
"The whole premise on which affirmative action is being attacked," Mr. Clinton said, "is that there really is a totally objective, realistic way you can predict success in college." In fact, he said, schools' grading systems vary, and Scholastic Assessment Aptitude Tests are "not a perfect predictor of capacity to learn and capacity to perform."
He added, "I honestly believe that if every kid in this country had the right kind of preparation and a hand up where needed enough in advance, and the right sort of supports, and you had a realistic set of criteria for letting people into college, that there would not be much racial disparity in who got into which institutions."
In the same vein, the President argued that success in business stemmed in large measure from "the whole fabric of contacts people have and what they know and what experiences they've had." That is why, he said, he has supported economic affirmative action programs.
Asked about campaign finance charges, Mr. Clinton called for tighter campaign finance laws. And, as his aides have in the past, he accused Republican members of Congress of investigating his campaign in the hope of bankrupting the Democratic Party.
"I think the Democratic Party's financial problems are due almost entirely to the legal bills it incurred with a lot of very vigorous help from Republican Congressional committees," he said. "So it's obviously part of a strategy, and it's worked to some extent."
In response to other questions today, the President repeated previous statements that he would not rule out fundamental changes in the tax code, proposed by Republicans. But he added that any such changes would have to be "fiscally responsible" and "fair to all Americans." Further, he said, the changes would have to benefit the economy and simplify the tax code.
Insisting on fiscal discipline in the face of tax-cut proposals, he said, "There are a lot of tax cuts that might be desirable, but how would you pay for them?"
He also tried to minimize differences between him and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader who is viewed as a rival to Mr. Gore. Mr. Clinton said that Democratic division over free trade would not "split this party in 1998," because ultimately all Democrats believe that "we should trade more, and we should do more to help people around the world with environmental and labor problems, and to help people here at home that are being left behind."
Asked about criticism that he was doing too little to help the District of Columbia, the President said he "can't do everything that everybody in the city wants me to do as soon as they want me to do it." While he planned to do more, he added, the District has to do more itself to improve schools and fight crime. "In the end, a city is formed and made by the people who live in it and shape its life day in and day out," he said.

HEADLINE: Doubling of Cigarette Tax Grows Near in New Jersey

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
A 40-cent increase in New Jersey's cigarette tax appeared all but inevitable today as a powerful legislative committee overwhelmingly approved the plan and lawmakers prepared for a general vote on Thursday.
Although Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders have pushed for a cigarette tax increase several times in recent years, they have never found enough support for the proposal until now. The additional tax revenues would help cover the cost of hospital treatment for uninsured patients, replacing a financing system that expires on Dec. 31. 
 While most of the extra revenues -- 30 cents per pack of cigarettes -- would help pay for charity care, the remaining 10 cents per pack would go toward school construction projects. Lawmakers predicted that the tax revenues would provide $50 million a year for such projects, which are sorely needed in urban areas.
"There has been strong bipartisan support for this plan all the way through," said State Senator Peter A. Inverso, a Republican on the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, which approved the bill this evening. "That in itself is a very good sign."
The tax increase, to 80 cents per pack from 40 cents, would make cigarettes more expensive in New Jersey than in any neighboring state. A pack of cigarettes would cost $2.75 on average after the tax is passed. But while lobbyists for the tobacco industry warned that the high price would only prompt smokers to buy their cigarettes in states like New York and Delaware, anti-smoking advocates insisted it would cut the number of smokers while increasing cigarette tax revenues.
"This is the single most effective intervention we can make to reduce smoking, especially among teen-agers," said Larry Downs, the program director of NJ Breathes, an anti-smoking group financed by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. "Every other state that has increased its tax has seen less consumption and more revenue."
After New Jersey raised its cigarette tax by 13 cents in 1991, 90 million fewer packs of cigarettes were sold in 1992, Mr. Downs said. Nonetheless, tax revenues increased by $60 million that year, he said.
Lawmakers have predicted that the tax increase will bring an additional $155 million in annual revenues, all of which help hospitals treat tens of thousands of uninsured people. Additional money would come from the state's unemployment fund and the general budget. Hospitals would receive $320 million annually for charity care, and urban hospitals would get another $101.5 million to treat hundreds of patients with AIDS and tuberculosis.
The new plan would also provide $68 million for two separate health insurance programs, including one for uninsured children and another for people who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid but whose employers offer no health coverage.
Even as they showed support for the tax increase, several lawmakers said they feared it would not guarantee a steady source of revenue because the number of smokers in New Jersey is dropping. State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat on the budget committee, predicted that the state would have to find a new source of revenue by 2002.
"I don't see this as a long-term solution," said Mr. Kenny, who supported the tax increase. "We just have to hope we'll be able to make up the difference by dipping more into the general fund."
New Jersey would be the 10th state to pass a cigarette tax increase in 1997, and the increase would be among the steepest. New Jersey's 80-cent tax would be the third-highest in the nation, after Alaska's $1 tax and Washington State's 82.5-cent tax. In comparison, New York has a 56-cent tax on cigarettes, Connecticut has 50 cents and Pennsylvania's tax is 31 cents.
Walker Merryman, the vice president of the Tobacco Institute in Washington, said the sharp increase could put small retailers out of business. "The people who will be hurt the most are convenience store operators on the Pennsylvania and Delaware borders," he said.
Anti-tax groups also criticized the tax increase, which would be the first in New Jersey since Gov. Jim Florio raised taxes by $2.8 billion in 1990. They said it would hurt poor people in particular, because they are more likely to smoke than affluent people. They also said it would force smokers to buy cigarettes illegally, from smugglers.
"This is going to turn the smokers of New Jersey into criminals," said John Sheridan, director of New Jersey Citizens for Tax Reform. "Are we now going to tax people as a means of controlling their behavior?"
But legislative leaders in both parties said they were comfortable with a tax increase because the money would go toward two worthy causes. Even Senator Richard J. Codey, the leader of the Democratic minority, promised "a significant number of votes" from his party.
"I think that on the merits, it's fair," Mr. Codey said. "Hopefully a 40-cent increase in the cost of cigarettes will discourage some people from smoking."
